reviews.review: Much more interesting than I expected. When asking previous visitors to Buenos Aires what things I should see and do, Recoleta Cemetary was mentioned every single time. I was a little surprised, thinking "It's just a cemetary." But once I was there, I understood completely. It's unlike anything I've seen in the United States. It is an entire city for the dead, with streets and alleys, and huge, ornate mausoleums. The opulence and the architecture will leave you wanting to see every last edifice.

Surprisingly fascinating!! . Took a tour with Free Walks BA ( although they charge a very small fee for this tour) - really interesting and definitely worth a visit - recommend a guide though as it's the stories that make it!!

A magnificent city onto itself. Waited until the last day to visit this site. It should have been my first stop. You could spend days here and never see it all. Surprisingly, there are still people being buried there today. It is touching to see how important family is to Argentinians.

Evita's Tomb. Evita's (Lady Eva Perón) and many other famous, rich people are buried here. No more room for more family tombs, but family members are still buried here. The ground is paved on isles between rows of tombs. Site is elegant and very well cared for. You might think it something other than a graveyard.
Guided visit to the Recoleta cemetery. There are guides who tell the stories of the people buried in this cemetery. The tour is free and there are tours in different lanaguages.

Unique cemetary. A definite must see. The mausoleums reflect the glory days of old Argentina. Impressed by the range of care - from rundown to emaculate. Don't miss Eva Peron's final resting place. Also some really fine sculpture

Boring. We did not get a guide. Everything felt very forced and touristy. Not nearly as cool as cemeteries I've seen in Vienna, Prague and New Orleans. There were a few stray cats, which for me was the highlight.
Great historical cemetery . Good start to see the city. This is different than the New Orleans type as they dig up to 8 feet down to hold the caskets. Elvira is buried here.

A labyrinth of tombstones and crypts.. I had this make up a part of a day when I was out and about, visiting multiple points of interest around Buenos Aires. I would say this should be on your 'must see' list if you can afford the time. If you do go here there are quite a few surrounding things to see as well, so it is worth it.If cemeteries are not your thing or can be a bit off-putting, I still strongly recommend having a look. The sheer scale of the place is not unlike a small city - having said that you can get lost quite easily as paths go off in every direction, with your line of sight being obscured by a multitude of tombs. Sections of the cemetery have masses of tourists, but you can still wander off and find things of interest.There isn't really much to say about it except that there is so much to see, empathise with, and appreciate... while it can feel a bit morbid or a little irreverent that you are just touring through, there is a sense of solemnity amongst the locals and tourists.
Beautiful architecture and 20th century history . A pleasant stroll and interesting to learn a little about the history of argentina's elite throughout the 20th century and earlier.

Well kept cemetery- main attraction Evita's tomb. Was a free attraction but for a small donation got a map from a volunteer on the door. Some very grand family tombstones, in many different and intricate designs. Main attraction is the family tomb where Eva Peron (Evita) rests. Family tomb under her maiden name 'Duarte'. Its worth a visit if in the area/ worth jumping off in on the hop-on hop-off bus tour, doesn't take long to get around - spend approx 45mins there.

One of the most interesting activities in BA. I really found this an interesting experience. The whole lay out of the cemetery. Eva Peron and other interesting tombs. The crypts were impressive. Something we would never see in NZ.

Curious place, but really not prepared for tourists. An intriguing and often morbid collection of tombs - some with great stories you'll need to research on the internet first in order to appreciate - including Eva Peron's final rest place (after her body disappearance for decades - Google it).Prepare to wander aimless to find anything of interest (including Eva Peron's resting place, which is to the left of the main center, and then two blocks north). There is only one map with a list of names which is not very helpful or easy to look at. It seems they avoid giving out information on purpose in order to have people paying for the guided tour.Anyway, worth a visit if you're in Recoleta. It's free, so why not.

Interesting and creepy place. The Recoleta cemetery has a really interesting architecture. The tombs were created in the 20's style some of them are huge. You easily can see the interior of some of them where pictures and other family artifacts had been keep for years. The most famous is Eva Duarte de Peron tomb. Her tomb is simple if you compare it with other ones. It is a Must see in Buenos Aires.

The resting place of Eva Peron. Be sure to check at the cemetery how to find the grave site of Eva Peron. There are many other impressive tombs here, not to dwell on a gloomy but inevitable ending for us all. This is a beautiful cemetery in an upscale neighborhood in Buenos Aires. There are some great outdoor cafes and eateries around the place. Worth seeing.

Must See. Definitely see this beautiful old cemetery. Be sure to get a map as getting lost is very easy also maps show locations of VIPs. Saturday when I went, there is a local artesian market in the park in front.

Touring. We went there to check it out. After walking around the entire outside we found the entrance. It was mind blowing! My husband called it the city of the dead. Each family had their own mini mausoleum that had lower levels. Some were so elaborate. They were like small houses. In an old broken down ones we could see the remains if the body, hip bone, femur. Quite a place you should not miss. We didn't have a map, just wandered for a half hour or so. They offer maps, tours & Evita is buried there if you Can find it!
Worth a visit. Located next to the Recoleta Mall and in the vicinity of some of Buenos Aires best hotels. Surround by great restaurants and bars. Especially fun area on the weekends and sunny days.

Incredibly big and so interesting !. You wouldn't think that a cemetery would be that interesting but when you look at the size of the place, the size of the monuments and more so who is burried there you can only say WOW this is so incredible. It is know to be one of the most visited places in Buenos Aires. Now among the important people burried there there is Eva Perron, Isabel Walewsk Kolona who was the gan child of Napoleon, Mr Guido who was a known general in the independence war. There could be tons of other information to write in here but I will only say that this is another must see within the many things of Buenos Aires has to show.

Must see in Buenos Aires!. If you only have one day in Buenos Aires I would recommend visiting this cemetery. You won't see anything like this anywhere in the world. You can spend hours wandering around the cemetery! There is a tomb of Evita Peron and many more famous argentinians are resting here.
Interesting. It is worth the visit. Try to go on a guided tour if you can because it is probably going to be more interesting.

Better than Paris. Huge beautifully constructed crypts. A national treasure. Took a tour and got a lot more out of our visit then a self guided tour. Another plus is high end shopping nearby. Interesting to compare this location to similar to the Paris. No Jim Morrison here but architecture better in BA.

A must-see. Great experience! I recommend that you go visit the Evita Museum first, have lunch at the museum's café ( which is great) and only then head to the cemetery. It will make a lot more sense. There are guided tours in different languages but times are iffy. There is a map located at the entrance of the cemetery with its points of interest.Free admittance, restrooms available and it closes at 5pm sharp!when you're done, recoleta mall is the next door neighbor. Starbucks :) enjoy!

Extremely Interesting. This is a must see. Everyone from Evita to the entire Duarte family are buried there as well as the rich and powerful. Very competitive as each tries to have bigger crypts than their peers. Much better with some kind of guide to show you around so you don't miss the good stuff.
See it!. It's a beautiful and impressive cemetery, never seen anything like it before. We said hello to evita and walked around for like 40min and that was enough for us. It is worth a wisit tho!

Ok for what it is. Had a friend tell me i 'have' to go there and that it was their highlight of Buenoa Aires. If this was their highlight, they dont get out much.It was interesting to see how opulent some crypts are and that you can see coffins from the door.30 minutes is more than enough unless you have a macabre need to hang around.Evita's resting place wasn't as grandiose as i was expexting. It is basically just a smaller family crypt non-distinct from others apart from a few flowers.Worth a visit just to have a look and tick the box.

Fascinating (and spooky) place. Despite the warm sunny day, I couldn't help but feel a chill in the quieter corners of the cemetery. Some of the tombs are especially moving, with the photos of the inhabitants enjoying life on the top of the coffins. Worth taking your time here and looking at all the amazing architecture - well worth the visit.

Stunning . A tour through the history of the great and the good of BA.Also a wonderful architectural tour through Art Nouveau and Art Deco as expressed in funeral art.And of course Evita's resting place!

I'd been dying to get back!. Came here 30 years ago, why I thought it would be different??A yeah, joking apart it is swept now, it's not only ancient Egyptian's that believe in reincarnation, the Argentinians wealthy seem to hope for it as well, Nirvana Recoleto.Paris and London both offer great tombs to the famous, but this place has a sea of 5 star tombs, perhaps of lesser known 3 star beings, less than London (Marx etc) and Paris (Jim Morrison and Pissarro to name but two stradled by 150 years)Outside, a Londoner offered me a tour, sacre bleu, cor blimey, whatever next!

Worth every minute . We walked from our hotel (Emperador Hotel), super easy to find. We found a guide outside who offered to show us around. Simon our guide is English and was so knowledgeable and answered all questions. Visited Eva Perons grave (which we wouldn't have found without Simon). Highly recommend this place to spend a few hours. Look for Simon out the front, he is amazing!

Resting In Peace. The cemetery is a peaceful and historically important place. It is definitely worth the visit and it would be much more worthwhile to have a guided tour. One of the things you'll learn is that many plots are being sold. Many of the monuments are magnificent.

interesting place to take pictures. I had a nice walk checking out graves. It's a safe place to take a walk in Buenos Aires. Feeling completely safe is precious and rare in Buenos Aires. Anytime you feel safe in this city, you would feel more relaxed and happier.
Super!. It is the most important cementry in Buenos Aires. It is in the middle of the city. You can get a tour and the experience is great.
Beautiful!. This is a very interesting beautiful place to visit. The mausoleums are amazing. Evita is buried here however it will take a little hunting to get to it! Very peaceful beautiful landmark.

Lovely and enchanted place!. This cemetery is a must stop if ou are in Buenos Aires! The tombs are so beautiful and unique and they all have a story to tell. You can visit the place at your own pace and spend the whole day or just a couple of hours. You might want to take a guided tour which are also available. I stayed at a close hotel and visited Recoleta Cemetery in three different ocassions during my stay. I just had to come back evey time!

Best thing we saw in Buenos Aires. When the guide told us we were going to a cemetery to see Evita Peron's grave I thought "this is going to be boring". Well, I was proven wrong, so much so that the cemetery was the best sight we saw in Buenos Aires. I won't say more as it was nice to be surprised by it when we arrived, all I will say is that it is worth a visit!

A must see very interesting . During a recent stopover on our way to Peru we spent a few days in BA, this was the highlight of the trip as I found BA very underwhelming and not tourist friendly at all.Stay in Recolleta or Palermo.We spent a lovely afternoon wandering around this spectacular cemetery. Truly amazing

Odd attraction. I loved the idea of visiting, went to cemetery in New Orleans and enjoyed it. But here you can see the coffins, just felt more disrespectful than I had hoped. Selfies next to propose graves just didn't sit right with me.The mausoleums are beautiful and if you can switch off from other tourists actions will be fine.Spent around 45mins here, free to visit.TIP: Google cemetery Map and key people before you go, save to your phone, saves you 40pesos

Definitely something to see. You have never seen a cemetery like this! Famous Argentines are buries here, but you should see it for the architecture alone. It was amazing, but I'm still surprised that I'm saying "go to Buenos Aires and go see the cemetery", but go to Buenos Aires and go see the cemetery.

An amazing place that is a must see when visiting Buenbos Aires. plan for an hour or so of walking through history, seeing where the rich and famous have been buried since Argentina was born. Feel the culture, the influence of religion on the political and social scene, and view increadible pieces of arquitecture and sculpture to honor the dead and display who is who in the Argentine food chain.

A bit creepy - of course . The architecture is quite a sight and strolling past some simple and some truly elaborate "tombs" often make you wonder if someone who's family owns it would visit and have a picnic inside. But since it doesn't have lights and inside there are coffins with dead bodies but yet there are tables and chairs in there, skylights and such, it kind of throws you off. It's indeed an adventure if you're curious but I won't likely return.

Surprisingly interesting. Very large cemetery that includes mausoleums , crypts, graves and coffin cubicles. Final resting place of many famous Argentinians including Evita Peron. Well worth a couple of hours, but I suggest that you find a guide to take you thru - there is usually 1 or maore standing at the main entry.
Worth a walk through for sure. Beautiful setting and memorials. This is a must see while in BA. Find the Duarte memorial and it makes the visit a little more special.

AMAZING. This is a must visit - perhaps the best place to see in Argentina - I have been to many cemeteries in stunning places like Paris, but this one takes the cake - 21 past presidents, tons of visually appealing things - would recommend a guide to help you understand what you're seeing, but you don't need that.

One of a kind. When you enter the cemetery, you are transfixed into another dimension as in front of you lies street-like venues with monuments galore as as you rome along these streets, you pass the highly impressive tombs and monuments of former Presidents, boxers, artists, along with those of other portenos (Buenos Aires residents). Often, there are english-speaking guides at the entrance offering their services and a good investment as the cemetery is a highlight of a visit to this fabulous city.

Must See. This is a must see site on a Vist to Buenos Aires. We are travelling with Scenic Tours and it's important to have an expert guide to explain the history of the Cemetery as Scenic does. There are guides available at the front gate but I have no idea what they charge. It's like a small village. Very interesting.
Spectacular!. We weren't sure that we wanted to visit a cemetery but this was more like a trip to an art museum. It is very well maintained each gravesite is unique and historical.
Must visit . Very eerie place, definitely worth a visit ! ..We saw Eva Peron's resting place which was pretty special

Amazing place to see, including resting place for Eva (Evita) Peron!. The staff member at the gate was very helpful with questions. Unfortunately, there were no free tours available during my visit. The map at the gate does provide help in trying to locate the crypts you want to visit. Of course, the number one crypt to visit is Eva Peron’s but she is located with her family under her maiden name Duarte (#88). Walking down each aisle you can see that each crypt is unique and has so much detail.
Great place to see how the wealthy look after their deceased. Most people come to see tomb of Eva Peron, but it is like a small village of tombs, some very grand.

A beautiful place to reflect on Argentine history and culture. It may seem odd that a cemetery has become a major tourist attraction, but if you take a tour of Recoleta Cemetery, it is easy to see why this place is so popular with visitors. The cemetery itself is really beautiful, but it is also the resting place of so many significant people in the history of Argentina. A truly worthwhile stop for architecture lovers and history buffs alike.

The resting place of Eva Peron is indeed a must see..... Let's be honest, this is despite the beautiful architecture, a graveyard but.... a graveyard for the whose-who in Argentinean history. The tomb is Eva Peron is the biggest attraction here but the stories of the other famous and infamous deceased are equally- if not more- as interesting. A guide would be a bonus as then you can full trap the whole experience.

Visit the cementery with a Buenos Aires Tour Guide !. Just hire a guide through internet to really appreciate the beauty of this place. Is gorgeous. We took the right decision. We saw different groups with a guide and that is perfect. We prefer a private guide to be alone and that was fantastic as we did the tour following our interests! Great . A must!

Certainly a must do. A great experience, interesting architecture, monuments, and morbid curiosity! I purchased a map for a couple of dollars, and it showed where some of the important people were buried - Eva Peron, presidents, etc. I think it would have been better with a guide to explain in more detail, but I couldn't find one!

The Argentinean Père Lachaise. Beautiful cemetery where you can find the graves of Argentinean historical heros and celebrities, or, who knows, a posible relative who immigrated to Argentina! Most foreigers look for the grave of Eva Peron the ""Evita". It isn't so easy to find because it is under the name of "Familia Duarte"; I sugest to look for it in advance in Internet or in a map of the cemetery. There are guides offering their services and people selling maps at the entrance of the cemetery but I am not sure it's a good choice. Anyway, it's worthwhile to visit - don't miss it. Being in the near, take a rest at café "La Biela", traditional café where the writer Jorge Luis Borges used to go (you can even "see" him sitting at one of the tables inside the café). If you go there on a sunny day and wish to sit outside, be aware that the prices will be a bit more expensive (you pay the view).

Amazingly beautiful. It may be odd to describe a cemetery as beautiful but Recoleta is certainly spectacular.Amazing tombs and monuments ordered in neat rows but each one so unique. Great to spend time just wondering around.FYI there is a map at the entrance showing the tombs of the famous people. I took a picture and used this to explore the graves we wanted to find.

A Must See on your Buenos Aires Trip. This is unlike any cemetery I have ever been to - delivering a mix of every type of architecture, history, and beauty. We ended up taking a tour with one of the guides stationed at the entrance, which we really enjoyed since she added another layer beyond just enjoying the sights.

Fascinating. The cemetery is more like a mini city of grand tombs, stunning sculptures and interesting laneways. I would recommend investing in a guide to show you around and explain the stories behind some of the tombs.Just a word of caution, outside the cemetery we were approached by a guide and agreed on a price which we confirmed several times.The guide was very good and provided background information that made the whole experience much more interesting than if we just wandered around independently.However, on completion the guide then claimed the agreed price was per person rather than for the two of us. We felt this was rather cheeky and deliberately deceptive and we really had no option but to pay it. Just clarify and maybe get it in writing before you start.

Amazing unexpected. This Cemetery is a must for anyone visiting Buenos Aires.It is like a town with with ornamental houses for the dead.It even has a map so that one can locate where's family is housed.I have never seen anything like it I my life

Incredible!. This is hands down the most impressive cemetery we have seen in our lives. The architecture alone is simply incredible. Our only regret is that we didn't get a guide or were part of a guided tour. If you're not doing a tour make sure to have a list of people's crypts that you want to see. Make sure to wear comfy walking shoes.
Not just any cemetery. Very interesting especially if you are able to go with a private guide or tour, so that you can appreciate and understand what you are seeing. Great history here!

Worth to visit, nice but mixed experience. The place is usually really crowded by tourist. Needless to say, architecture of many of the tombs is amazing and worth to visit. For me, it was kind of a mixed experience, when you are working around the cemetery, but I would also say, it's a must see in Buenos Aires.

A must when in Buenos Aires. If you have an interest in cemeteries, this place is for you.You can easily spend 2 hours walking the grounds and looking at the different mausoleums from the wealthy and not so wealthy families; some grave sites are in desperate need of some TLC, but the families ran out of money; so sad to see this.Watch out for the feral cats, they are everywhere.It's easy to get lost here, so try to get a map before you go in (we didn't).

Impressive. Visited the cemetery but it was raining, so could not venture far but the cemetery was very impressive. Do walk in a group if not you could get lost as there's no signage to guide you. The place is huge.

Wonderful to Wander Through. This place is filled with mausoleums--some new, some quite old. Some in good repair, some in very poor repair. Very interesting to explore and to mentally compare to other great cemetaries in other countries.

An amazing experience in Cemetery. This is an unique experience visiting this cemetery and never seen something like this in my experience in Europe so far , this is a must see when visiting Buenos Aires. The structure of the mausoleums are artistic , mix of modern and historic design , the materials are brought from different places even from Europe. Some of the mausoleums are built for family and some stand for single person . Many eminent cultural , political person, presidents of Argentina in different period are lying there .It is sad to see some of the mausoleum glass doors or gates are broken and coffins are seen with dust and dirt . There are platforms to keep the coffins in different layers underground and permanent stairs are made to access different layers .There are paid guided tours in english too , but the entry is free.It is close to another point of attraction floralis generica.

An experience like no other. Had heard much about the cemetery but nothing prepares you for this unique'town'. You can easily spend an hour or two wandering around looking at the various monumental buildings and fascinating inscriptions. Architecturally is a fascinating comment on the different styles since the beginning. Dont miss - you will not forget it.

Well worth a visit. This is truly an experience worthy a visit. Here you can stroll around and think in a cemetery that is like a borough within the city. And it is beautiful and fascinating architecture that is intriguing. Free of charge which really makes this a great place to visit. Good quality for time and money.

Could have been a museum!. This cemetery is like none other you will ever visit. It was like a museum of beautiful gothic like mausoleum buildings. Some of them accommodated a family of 20. This is where Evita was buried.

Unusual.... We were in Buenos Aires for 11 days, basically to dance tango. However our itinerary also included a few walking tours around the city, and Recoleta Cemetery was one of the places we visited. It is certainly unusual, and the different tombs are often incredibly ornate. I was certainly pleased that we were with a guide, as she was able to tell us a lot of stories about the cemetery, why some of the tombs have a little fence around them for instance (they were Protestant, and the fence is to keep Catholicism out!) and guide us to various points of interest. I think it is one of those things that once you have seen it, you might not feel the need to see it again. But definitely worth a visit.

Knock on the door...?. The cemetery is fascinating on a variety of levels. The architecture Morris every style fashionable in the last 200 years and some not yet invented. It's somewhat macabre to see coffins that were put into crypts 100 years ago, but on a bright sunny day it was not at all gloomy with lots of people sightseeing or visiting graves. A one-off experience

A different stroll. A quiet walk within an aristocratic resting place, where the Argentine wealthy families buried their dead. Lots of stories to hear, such as that of three friends who bet they could spend a night here and all died in mysterious circumstances, one of them from a heart attack the same night of the bet. The area is the city's traditional district, thencemetery being one in many attractions in that spot.

A Must - so much History. They call this the City of the Dead and that is just what it is. From the very early days to today. We visited and there was a funeral taking place so it is still very much in use. It was interesting to learn that Eva Peron is not in her husbands mausoleum but is with members of her own family. The maps your can purchase at the entrance for 40 pesos gave all the family names and their locations. Very useful.

Can you call a cemetery awesome?. I must say I have never seen a cemetery like this! I was in awe to see such detail in the mausoleums and small cotteges built as a place to rest for Argentina's elite! Best of all I was able to visit the resting place of the famous political leader and First Lady Eva "Evita" Perón!
Excelente visita. It worth it.Go there and you will have a great experience. one of the best cementeries all over the world.Peaceful

Interesting and grand cemetry. The place has some of the grandest or weird cemeteries in the world. Unfortunately we didn't visit with a guide so don't know the history or the people that's buried here except for Eva Peron. Luckily we got a map (after highly suggested to donate 40 pesos to get the map) and was able to avoid walking aimlessly around the cemetry.

Nice, interesting, but poorly maintained. Like strolling through the cemetary. Interesting monuments, a bit eerie with broken old coffins in some of the monuments with windows.. seeing Eva Peron's place of internment is always humbling...

Fascinating and a little sad. This graveyard is the most beautiful and fascinating one I have ever visited. The love these people showed for their loved ones by building these exquisite tombs! The sad part is the ones in disrepair. They are old, and left unattended -almost look vandalized. One coffin was open and the skeleton was coming out. Nonetheless, they were once someone's loved ones too, but time past and I suppose no family members were left to care for them. It's a beautiful amazing place. I'm glad I went.
Wow! So unusual. So interesting and unusual, the architecture is very striking, wonderful examples of the art noveau and deco period.

A Must for Those Visiting Buenos Aires.. Very interesting cemetery where the wealthy and famous of Argentine society have been laid to rest. Some of the mausoleums are very ornate and ostentatious and well cared for, while there were a few that were neglected and in some cases the actual caskets were completely exposed. Regardless, the place is replete with history and some very interesting stories. I highly recommend you hire a guide, which are staring outside the cemetery, to walk you around and show you and explain the most interesting and popular graves, including Eva Peron's mausoleum.

Cemetery like no other... although a little confusing. With elaborate tombs squeezed into narrow lanes, it is a little confusing to navigate around the cemetery. As we visited during an off peak time, we had to head back to the entrance a few times to study the map of the area to locate Eva Peron's resting place. While visitors gravitate towards Peron's tomb -- other monuments in the cemetery are much more elaborate.

Great cemetery that feels like a museum. A must do for people who enjoy history and art. Get a guide at the front gate who has a white badge on. Just ask if they are tour guides. I had Simon from England for a personal 2 hour tour. Be sure to tip well if it is a private tour. I would not suggest trying a self guided tour. Too big and it's a maze in there.
Awesome. 100 % recommendable for people who like history and art. The entrance is free and you can enter with or without a guide

Interesting. The monuments were very artistic and remarkable in comparison to the European version. I would recommend a visit purely to see how much respect they have for there dead.I have to say it was beautiful to see.

Must see, very unique!. Stunning and so fascinating too. You can see into some of the tombs and it's easy to get lost just wandering around in the maze of this cemetery. In my book, this is a must see in Buenos Aires.

Well worth the trip to see. We took the metro and walked the couple blocks to the entrance. Eva Peron is the grave most people come to see, but I also wanted to see the grave of San Martin's wife. There are also graves of a number of former presidents of Argentina. Depending on how long you feel like wandering, plan on spending at least 40 minutes.

Worth the visit. I had low expectations for this cemetery. I wondered if I was wasting my time before I went. I was pleasantly surprised to find it so interesting. Just the above ground layout is interesting but add to that all of the history that you can learn (and the fact that it is free) and you've got a great experience. One more thing, recollect a market is outside the cemetery. I've not visited the other markets, but I did find this a nice bonus.

Need a guide. Had planned trip to coincide with English tour guide. It would appear that all guides were cancelled. You lose a lot by just meandering and not knowing the language. Still worthwhile and was able to locate Duarte family tomb, check map in reception area for location, Duarte is family name of Eva peron.
Amazing. Wander amongst the monuments and lose yourself. Or attach yourself to a tour so you know what's what. But go!

Beautiful, peaceful place!. This cemetery is a miniature city filled with mausoleums in many architectural styles. Examining the beautiful buildings, statues, stained glass windows, portraits of the deceased, and the grave of Eva Peron made the hour and a half we spent there fly by. You enter through an old church, itself quite lovely, and then walk into the cemetery. We went on a weekday afternoon and there were no crowds. After ward, we ate at La Biela, right across the street from the church. Two good choices in Buenos!

Evita's tomb site. Great place to visit - I went on a relatively quiet day so couldn't rely on the crowds to lead me to Evita's tomb - I would suggest looking it up before you go as there's no signage - and remember she's buried under her maiden name 'Duarte'

A must see in BA. The cemetery surprised me. It is a great contrast seeing the different Mausoleums and how much money would of been spent on them. You need at least 3 hours here to really appreciate it.

Creepy but fab!. being in a cemetery is not a good activity you will imagine to do, but when we talk about recoleta`s cemetery is a must! u will find art in every corner, creepy but fantastic stories about crazy and rich people from argentina`s aristocracy. Its located in the middle of the city, and u will be amazed about how quiet the place is!
"Something You've got to See". I had never toured a cemetery before, but this truly was something to see. Thousands of mausoleums, beautiful architecture, just a very interesting place to visit.

Breathtaking. This place is amazing 6,400 mausoleums that only the rich and wealthy lay. The architecture is unbelievable seriously I could have spent hours going through the place. In each mausoleum there is a small circular stair case that goes underneath were other family members are buried. Evita is here and many famous people what is amazing is the size of some of these mausoleums and the detail carvings it is truly a work of art. You have to see this place it is a must......
A must see place. Unique architecture and great stories. Wish Evita´s tomb were more spectacular. You should take a guided visit or you´ll miss most of the interesting part of the journey

Eva Perone is buried here. This above ground cemetery is a tourist attraction. Many well-know people are here. The vaults are beautiful, much like the ones you see in most New oceans cemeteries. It is free but I could not find any public toilets there. Keep that in mind. It takes 15-20 min to see most of it. The strange thing (to me) was that the "residents" are considered to be "living" in the vaults and therefore, the living owners must pay property taxes on the real estate. If you can't pay, you must leave. Also, a mid-range vault costs about $300K to purchase.

Visit Eva Perron. This is a very interesting cemetery where the tomb are purchased by a family and each holds many, many bodies. As it gets full, people remove the old ones so that newly deceased people can be put in and what is more, you can sell your tomb to somebody else. The bodies must be removed before, of course. Don't forget to stop and visit the tomb were Eva Perron is buried. It is the tomb of her brother-in-law's family but she is the main attraction. It is free and very cool.
Recoleta Cementery. It's a place all tourist should visit, not only for the great architecture you may see but also because there lots of argentinean politics and Presidents who are buried there.
Worth a visit. This was an eye opener. Reasonably well maintained but there are many sites in ruins. The wealthy were laid to rest here as was Evita who championed the less fortunate.

MACABRE YET CAPTIVATING. Call it thanatophobia, but for those matters associated with the inevitability of our mortal existence I normally pass. Here to, at the doors of La Recoleta Cemetary, I would have declined a stroll among the vaults of the dead, but my wife insisted one HAD to see one of Buenos Aires' landmark tourist attractions. Her comment says what is says about what there is to see, or the lack there of, in this city. If the foregoing hasn't tipped you off, let me be clear, I'm not a fan of Buenos Aires. That's not to suggest that it isn't an interesting existential experience, just not a city one needs to see to be a citizen of the world. For goodness sakes, CNN of all organizations is reported to have rated La Recoetta as one of the top ten most beautiful cemeteries in the world. That has to count for something. Who would have thunk it? In any event, if you're into the macabre, or are looking for ideas for your final resting place, than this certainly is the place to window shop. You'll have the pleasure of viewing, and in large, every conceivable style of mausoleum there is to see including, but not limited to, Art Deco, Art Nouveau, Baroque, Neo-Gothic and a few modernist. It is amazing the length to which individuals will go to make a statement that they existed, or is it vanity? Nevertheless, If nothing else it certainly is a captivating place (no pun intended).

A story to tell.... La Recoleta cemetery should be definitely among the places to visit, with respect. It's a cemetery so it can occur a service while you are around. Stories that make you take a deep breath; a father that lost a daughter, a young lady that may be was not dead... It shows also part of argentinian culture of a certain part of its society..

You cannot miss the opportunity to visit an authentic city of the Dead.. For the ones who love architecture, art and photography, you must come to the Recoleta Cemetry at Recoleta district in Buenos Aires. It's impressive.
Unique. Historically interesting and from a design and architectural perspective very interesting. Some good photographic oppertunities
This Cemetary is Awesome. We went to this cemetery because we did the BA Bikes tour. This part of the tour was great and our guide Ezequiel told us all about the history of this place. Really great.

Recoil at Recoleta Cemetery. We went there with a friend who likes to visit cemeteries. I, on the other hand, was simply interested in seeing Eva Peron's. Aside from a map at the entrance, there were no markings on the streets for the more popular ones. I understand this is meant to be a solemn place, but let's face it, it's one of the top tourist attractions in Buenos Aires, so why not make it a bit more user friendly? We were not the only ones looking for Eva, and when we finally found her resting place, well. . .

What a beautiful place to be buried . Sensational graveyard with some mausoleums bigger than a lot of Hotel rooms!A must see place when you visit Buenos Aires. We had a guide for the City and he walked us around the cemetery detailing who was buried here and how much this mausoleum cost etc . I'd highly recommend you get a guide as there's some much more information they give you than guide books .

Amazing, amazing resting place. I purposely chose at hotel for a 2-week vacation that's right across the street from the cemetery (Urban Suites Recoleta). It's awkward reviewing a cemetery, except to say that you can buy a map at the entrance for 30 Argentine pesos (she also accepts US$2 cash), or just wander around on your own.Of course, the first place everyone visits is Eva Peron's burial site. From the entrance walk a quarter of the way in, turn left, walk almost to the end to the next street, turn right, then turn left just after the two benches. It's the Duarte Family mausoleum. Don't try this if you're given 15 minutes to get back to a tour bus, because you might get lost in the maze of tiled streets within the cemetery.The cemetery closes at 6 p.m. However, a bell starts ringing around 5:30 to warn visitors, and many times I saw guards not let people inside as early as 5:10 p.m.

We spent hours walking, appreciating the intricate art & stone masonry, sensing & experiencing another time.... City of the Dead. I loved it. If that is okay to say about a cemetery, but then again I love the way different cultures honour their dead. We went twice. We spent hours walking and appreciating the intricate art and stone masonry, sensing and experiencing another time and life. Opening up history. It is Important. Take your time. We just meandered. There are guides to be hired, and maps to be bought, but we preferred just to wonder with the stories edged in stone to guide us. Other note is there is free, clean and assessable toilets during open hours.

A leisurely stroll to visit Evita's mausoleum . This was a well spent visit with a magnificent row of mausoleums akin to that in Jerusalem. Our mission was to visit Evita's site but surprised that it was listed as Eva Perron in the Duarte Family mausoleum.

Amazing place.. We did this with a guide who brought the cemetery to life with the stories behind some of the inhabitants. It was amazing to see the many and various tombs in varied states of repair. A hour well spent.
Worth a SHORT visit. We went in here because our hotel is right next to it. Unless you get a tour guide, you will need to look at the map to find Evita's tomb.
Dead centre of Buenos Aries. Got to see Eva Peron tombstone very interesting place a little morbid but worth a look. This area has about 65,000 members buried here.

Unfortunately not my cup of tea. . Was my first visit to a cemetery, so I had no idea what to expect. Other reviews said it was more like visiting a museum and I love museums, so I was rather eager! Unfortunately, the very sad, opulent site was just a very sad reminder of sheer decadence and wastage of resources. We took the tour, and regardless, I just could not bring myself to like the idea of such a place! I understand what it means to the people in Buenos Aires to be buried there, but, truly what a sad memorial site. And not in a good way!
so interesting . very interesting to visit... ..you could use several hvours to look around and take so many photos. I do recommend you to visit this place.
Amazing Place. We went to the cemetery as a part of a tour. Would highly recommend that as directions get confusing quickly here. The art is LOVELY, but a bit macabre.
Fascinating. Beautiful tombs stretching in all directions. Fascinating to wander through. Worth even a quick visit if that is all there is time for but I could have easily spent a few hours.

Must do, really interesting. Buenos Aires has a very 'European' feel in the centre, but this cemetery feels unquestionably like somewhere unique. It's eerie but beautiful and many of the structures are simply incredible.

Extraordinary, obligatory stop in Buenos Aires. There is nothing like this incredible cemetery filled with the mausoleums of many of the founding fathers of Argentina and of course Evita's tomb. It is like a small city, with incredible architecture, and you may even have the experience of seeing a burial take place, since the cemetery is active, which is another cultural experience in itself.

Creepy and morbid but beautiful . We went here because everyone suggested it. We spent about 10mins in total walking around.It's very eerie and creepy to see coffins inside these grand beatitiful construction. Some are from the 70s and earlier and the glass on a few were broken and the coffin are just sitting there!I guess if you're into beautiful Gothic and grand statues the yes, check it out but not really for us and to see other people taking Selfie here makes it even more morbid!

Fascinating, very European. A lovely place in the middle of the bustling city of Buenos Aires, this is a must visit. Known as the final resting place of Eva Peron, it is much more with elaborate crypts that are works of art. A very pleasant place to walk around and imagine the history that is there.

Interesting! . A very interesting place to walk around. We googled some graves of interest before we went, just to get a better idea of the different graves there. Amazing architecture and uniquely designed tombs.
A must in B.A.. Visiting the cemetary is a must when you visit Buenos Aires. The crypts are works of art and it is the final resting place of Eva Peron.

Wonderful. A beautiful old European style cemetery - although not huge, it is large enough to enable you to escape the packs of guided tours that clog the paths and find a quiet area or two to admire the statues and stone work. It is hard to leave.

Recoleta Cementery. In one of the most beautiful Cementery´s and the most important in Arnetina´s Caital Buenos Aires.
Is located just in front of the most known, restaurants, bars, shopping malls, and same time the Cementery trough guide you will see all the Tombs of Argentina´s famous Politicals, Muscis and other, with beautiful building inside
Good to visit. Went there to see famous grave of Evita, could not believe how much flowers were put on her grave every day, I guess population of Argentyna must still love her.

The first thing we did in buenos aires, and we did it again another three time. Recoleta Cemetery is absolutely amazing. It was not at all what I expected it would be, it was far more extravagant and we really loved wandering through the rows and rows of various fancy resting places. It was a cool experience that I think people of all ages can enjoy. Free entry, loads of cute stray cats and some strange feelings...

It Makes Me Sad. I find cemeteries worth visiting because they are a snapshot of how we remember the past. Old monuments, tombstones and mausoleums speak volumes about a person's life, stature and achievements over a lifetime. Yes, Evita Duarte Peron's tomb is in Recoleta. It is well maintained. Some visitors leave notes and flowers. But it's the other tombs that you must see. Those with stained glass are beautiful. However, some have been vandalized; others neglected; still others in disrepair. It's sad to see. Just keep that in mind as you wander through this historic cemetery.

Worth a visit on any tourist visit to BA. Spent almost 2 hours on a tour of the cemetery. I would strongly recommend taking a guided tour. Guides are available at the entrance to the cemetery. They can take you to the most interesting and significant tombs explaining the history of the families buried in them. Most tombs are very well kept.

Stunning!. This is a must see, a beautiful maze of a cemetery that reflects a time gone by, the magnitude of some of the tombs will leave you in amazement. A guide will take you to particular spots of importance, and will give you a background story & afterwards you can wonder by yourself as there's plenty of information you can access easily.Afterwards, wonder across to any of the restaurants near by.

You have never seen anything like this!. Before we went, other than knowing that Eva Peron (Evita)'s grave was here, my husband said "what is so interesting about seeing this?" But he, and my whole family, were impressed by these elaborate mausoleums. There was row after row after row, and they were made from marble with statues and sculptures. Each more elaborate than the next. We got a free guided tour in English from a guy who approached us outside of the cemetery and worked off of tips so that was helpful to have a guide.
Must see. There is a lot of Argentina history here --- hiring a guide is well worth the money. It is within walking distance of s lot of nice hotels.

Like nothing you will have seen before.... A grave yard unlike any I have seen before. A labyrinth of imperious and grand family tombs that one can easily get lost in.Self-tours provide sufficient entertainment and a map at the entrance will help you find Evita's final resting place - or just tag onto a guided group.Being a grave yard, children (and girlfriends) may well find the experience frightful - the scraping noise of a stray cat/zombie scaring my partner half to death...

Beautiful cemetary!. One of my favorite highlights of my trip to BA! Gorgeous cemetary and just so much to see. The architecture of the mausoleum were simply beautiful! Worth the trip and take lots of pictures!

Fascinating. I did a walking tour of the cemetery and it is absolutely amazing. Even without a tour it's quite interesting to look at the various tombs and the different styles throughout. It's essentially a must-see because of Eva Peron, but hers is probably the most boring of the tombs. Spend an hour or two here and enjoy!

Historic. We went and visited with a guide - very helpful to know some history of the tomes there. Could easily spend over 2 hrs looking around and reading comments of the past. Visiting Evita's site was incredible and always has fresh flowers adorning it. A must see but would really recommend getting a tour guide on your first visit and then take your time to wonder around without a guide.

Very Cool . I wasn't planning on going here, but since we were in the neighborhood, we decided to stop by. Entrance is free, although there are people selling maps and guided tours. Unless you are interested in the history aspect, I would not recommend. We were just fine wandering around and it was easy to see Evita's final resting place because of the crowd. It is a nice walk from the metro station.

Special place to visit. If you find yourself in Buenos Aires, it is a place not to be missed. One of a kind. Mausoleums and sculptures that will blow your mind. Definitely one of a kind. Worth the trip.

Unbelievable landmarks. There are almost 5000 mausoleums in this cemetery. The architecture and ornamentation is stunning. Most of the tombs are in perfect shape and it makes for a fascinating walk. It is free to go inside and walk around. There are people standing out in front that will walk you around and give a tour for about 100 pesos. I got a great guide, Isabelle. There are also free tours each day, tour guides work for tips.

Make a quuck visit. The cemetery is fascinating and should be on your list of things to do while in Buenos Aires but you don't need to plan a large amount of time here. It is interesting, and grandiose but isn't a place to linger for a long time.

Quiet stroll through landscape of marble Angels . Visited two times as missed Evita Peron's final resting spot on our first visit. Must agree with the brochure that states "it has become a major expression of funeral architecture worldwide." From modest style to ornate, side by side monuments to loved ones stand.

Spectacular! . For the cemetery its 5 stars grade but overall its 4. You have to see how people can be stupid to spend so much money for what! Its grandios and there is a place where Eva Peron is now resting. But I can't give 5 stars for something like this. For 5 years renting a grave you have to pay 40000-4000000$!!! I would rather spend it while I am alive...
Unique!. It is a good place to visit ! Everything is big and old. Recoleta is a great place to spend a day, next to the cemetery you can find a church.

A must see if you visit Buenos Aires. Don't miss this top tourist attraction. Supposedly one of the top cemeteries in the world. It gives you a history of Buenos Aires and is a relatively quiet reprieve from the noise of the city. Be prepared to run into a lot of locals and tourist. The highlite of this cemetery is that this is where Eva Peron is buried

intruiging place to visit. A must see spot with hundreds a family crypts which are open to the public for free. There are for hire guides hanging around the entrance also. There is also the most incredible rubber tree near the entrance that is enormous and has struts and a statue to hold up it s branches.

Ostentatious and Spectacular!. In life and death, some people go larger. Lucky for us, this ostentatious burial ground is really one of the most spectacular burial grounds in the world. Of course Eva Peron is buried here, but unless you are a big fan her family burial site is not a big deal in comparison to the other family sites.

Absolutely amazing cemetery. The highlight of our day exploring the city was this impressive and very interesting cemetery. As something we have never experienced before (the exposed coffins and large tombs to these people) we found this intriguing and spooky at the same time. Would highly recommend a visit. There appeared to be free tours (which we didn't take as we were short on time) which we'd recommend to get a better understanding of the history and significant figures laid to rest here.

So, death.... When visiting a place like the Cementario de la Recoleta, it's hard not to spend some time mulling death and the way different people and different cultures deal with it. The cemetery is huge. One could easily get turned around wandering through it, and one could also spend hours just looking at different architectural styles and choices amongst all the mausoleums. What I kept mulling over is, what does a place like this say about the living? To be here is to lie among the most prominent citizens of Buenos Aires, and it's not cheap. Plots are rented, not bought. Although one does wonder what happens if anyone's family can't keep paying. It's also, frankly, ostentatious. Is this place a function more of status than of memorializing? It's well worth visiting, although I did wish I had taken some time to learn more about key people in Buenos Aires' history, as the names didn't have much meaning for me. I was reminded of trips I've made to Boston in the US, where visiting an old cemetery is like reopening my old US history textbook. I could have used something like that here, some kind of interactive online map that would have pop up single paragraph entries for specific families. Maybe it already exists, and if so, it would be a nice thing to know about!

A must visit when in Buenos Aires. We were most surprised to read that this cemetery was in Buenos Aires top attractions and went along to check it out. I found it incredibly interesting and striking to see all at the same time. It is literally a 'city of the dead' with streets and streets of huge family tombs, as big as houses, with elaborate design and prayer rooms and decorations. There are wealthy and important people dotted around including Evita and presidents etc. Some are really old, some simply huge. You can see inside a lot of them and it is quite creepy to see the actual coffins of the dead laying before you! The history of it all is so interesting and to let your imagination wander on the lives of these people I found fascinating. We spent hours wandering around looking at all the architecture of the tombs.A must see attraction.

A must see cemetery. I usually don't visit cemeteries while on vacation, but this is not like any other cemetery. There are no graves. There are family mausoleums of the wealthy aristocrats of Argentina. Most of the mausoleums are beautiful adorned with magnificent sculptures. I strongly suggest getting a guide to take you around and provide interesting insight and history. Eva Peron is interred here. Getting the story of Eva Peron and what happened to her body after she died is really bizarre. Some of these mausoleums are so beautiful, i wouldn't mind spending my vacation in one.

Scary like a STEPHEN King novel. We walked around trying to locate Evita Perrones resting place. Every where you looked you seen big cats just laying around tombs and plots. I'd recommend going early and wearing comfortable shoes. Lots to see. Also on the weekends there's a market just outside the cemetery. You can get the best spicy sausage there. Grilled to perfection.
Wonderful Sunday Outing. Highly recommend walking in this area to understand more about Argentina's history. It's nice to have a tour guide but you can self-guide by doing research in advance.

Unlike anything I've ever seen. When it was suggested that we see the Recoleta Cemetery it seemed like an odd tourist spot. It is well worth seeing as it is not your usual cemetery. Grand mausoleums alongside those long neglected. Evita is interred here as well.

A small city dedicated to the dead. Wow, what a place, yes Eva Peron is buried here but it really is so much more than that. Coffins can be seen, they don't smell. Why do Argentinians do that? Don't know..they apparently burn the bodies when they need the space. Interesting facts...I think....the architecture and dedication is all part of the granduer of this place and the street cats that live here...

Journey through the history of Argentina. This cemetery is mainly for the rich families in argentina and also for the famous. Evita Peron is buried there although she wouldn't like to be buried there. Excellent fo black and white spooky photo shotting. Increible toombs.
Tombs like mini churches . Man oh man these tombs are the bomb ... The cemetery of all cemeteries! It was amazing to see the money invested into these historic grave sites. Definitely worth a visit!

Wow! . We just walked in and was so surprised as wasn't expecting the beautiful work in this place. We just wandered round ourselves but it was massive and well worth a visit as it is like nothing you will have ever seen before. I took some pictures but it doesn't do it justice you need to go and see for yourself.
Worth the visit -. I'm not normally into cemeteries, but this was fascinating, and beautiful Also, it is convenient for other attractions.

Oddly enjoyable.. I'm usually somber in cemeteries, like Arlington, or New Orleans, which this one is very much like, but this one was not like that for some reason. I knew virtually nobody other than Eva Peron/Duarte and that may have helped. Very accessible and we could see right in many of them, interesting experience. Smaller than I thought it would be and not hugely English friendly.

Historic Cemetery. Interesting place to visit and wander around. It's worth taking a guided tour to learn the history and some stories of the place. Eva (Duarte) Peron is buried there - it's a little difficult to find the Duarte mausoleum. One of the BA free walking tours offers a guided tour in the afternoon.
Interesting visit.. A good place to spend a few hours of the day walking around. We didn't take the walking tour- which I'm told goes into detail about some of the famous people buried here.

Why tour a Cemetery?. It tour was very unique and fun to see..we stayed in the Urban Hotel right by this location and got a view from our room. Then walked the grounds with a guide. Very interesting to see and hear the history. Susy
Beautiful and quiet walks. Besides seeing Evita Peron tumb, which is the most famous, however not so easy to find, the place is a quiet and peaceful refuge from noisy Baires.

Touristic place to see. This place is an historical place to know in Buenos Aires. Perhaps is a little scary some times, but for sure you need to know the way that Argentinians were living years ago. And that is reflected on this cementery.

'Must' visit in BA. The place is not creepy at all, well aside of being a cemetery, you know. But it's beautiful, with nice tree guarded paths, and a lot of art. In a more contemporary way it's like old cemeterys where art mingled with grief. If you are in for history, you will find here the best known names in local events since independence times to now. From San Martin's relatives to Evita. On the other hand, you will also see beautiful art nouveau constructions, statues, and if you take a tour, you will learn a lot about Argentina's art and history. Don't be lazy and take some hours to visit this place.

Must do.. This cemetary is cumpolsory for a trip to BA. Look beyond Evita's tomb as the are far more detailed and interesting tombs. Note when looking for the famed Evita tomb it's in her family name, not Peron.

Don't cry for me Argentina!~. Nice historical place to visit on a cool, sunny afternoon. Visited Evita's crypt and walked through the "avenues" of the cemetery. Go during a weekday when there are less people, if you can ~ weekends are pretty crowded.

Do it!. I don't know if you can call a cemetery "must-do" for a visitor to a city, but this was surprisingly cool. Unless it's really inconvenient or you've only got like 2-3 super packed days in the city, check this out for at least an hour. Better yet, if you can spare the time, plan a few hours of slow meditation, contemplation and picture taking before they close (better sunlight).

Interesting visit. A cemetery is not somewhere I would normally visit but it was a part of our city tour of Buenos Aires. You could spend quite a bit of time. Also interesting to see where Evita is buried.
Historical cemetery . A little eerie in the evening for kids but very unique in Argentina and well preserved for its age. Never seen anything like this before.

Don't Miss This World Class Cemetery. Amazing history in this cemetery which is the size of a city block filled with leafy avenues and narrow, marble walled streets and alleys. It is filled with the last resting places of the many notable Argentinians such as presidents, Nobel prize winners and a granddaughter of Napoleon. Evan Peron, the First Lady, can be visited at site 88. Ironically she was buried by her sisters in the family tomb with the father who did not play a role in her life after a long journey and controversy on where her final resting place should be. The cemetery is an eclectic collection of elaborate mausoleums and statues in the Art Deco, Art Nouveau, Baroque and Neo-Gothis styles. Much of the materials used from 1880-1930'were imported from Paris and Milan. Take a tour to understand the history.
Beautiful and cool!. I loved how each area told a story of the family. We had small children and teens with us and we all thought it was a really cool place. Don't miss this.

You must se this special place. If you ar win BA. I only had an hour, because I was on a tour- but I could have spent four hours here. The breathtaking variety of funerary architecture is amazing and wonderful, a rich tapestry of style, materials and messages. Beautiful, busy and one of a kind. This is one of the worlds top cemeteries to visit. Perce lechaise in Paris is another of these.

Worth the stop. This is an incredibly touristy stop, but well worth it! The cemetery is unlike anything I've ever seen. I would recommend visiting this as part of a tour to better understand the history and significance.

A must. An amazing place with so much history and beauty ...not just Evita's ashes here but those of other important figures and their tombs are breathtaking in their style, immensity and choice of material. Fascinating

Amazing Cemetery - You have to see it to believe it.. This is not just a cemetery it is an amazing city of the dead with street after street of beautiful, extravagant mausoleums. You could easily spend a half day or more just strolling the streets of this cemetery observing the historical mausoleums that only the rich and powerful families could afford to build. This cemetery definitely has the "Wow" factor and is worth the time to view.
Very Interesting and a Must See. I am not one to go to a cemetery just because, but this one is full of history and very interesting architecture. Definitely worth a stroll and it is free.
Unique attraction. Argentinians really know how to make their cemeteries artistic! So nice to be able to see the tomb of Evita Peron. What an inspiring person.

Recoleta. An interesting walk through the history of the rich and powerful families of Buenos Aires. It is a cemetery like none I have ever seen. Download the guide from the internet before you go so you can follow it to get the back story of various 'inhabitants'

A must see. Eerie to say the least. It is incredible to see the lengths people will go to and how much money they will spend to be remembered. Splendid mausoleums as well as the final resting place of Evita Peron.A must see just to take in the grandeur of it all!

More interesting than most cemeteries. You might be a little taken aback when you stroll around the cemetery, as it's not the sullen and respectful kind of place you'd expect. Guides take tour groups around pointing out the "important" tombs - like Eva Peron's - telling anecdotes as people laugh and snap the architecture.But that's all part of its charm. This is an attraction, and definitely worth the walk around. One of the highlights of Buenos Aires.

Nothing like it! Majestic Cemetery in the heart of Recoleta!. If you go to Buenos Aires you need to go here. There is literally nothing like it. These are the most majestic tombs and burials! When you think about the history it's really interesting. There is so much art and design that has been perfectly executed. Tomb or Gravetone 88 is the Eva Peron burial. It's breathtaking when you enter it.

History - Dying during the Argentina´s "Bell Epoc". And then?. "Recoleta", apart from a neighbourghood is a Cementery, right in the middle of one of the most smart places of the city. In it, there are tombs of many important people of Argentina History (politicians, nobel prize winer, merchants, priests .... Evita). There is a free walking-tour provided by the administratios of the Cementery that belongs to the City of Buenos Aires. Interesting walk (1 or 1,1/2 hour) -history, stories, architecture, sculpture). Check the web site for more information. Say what you liked best & leastTell us what to bring (camera, walking shoes...)Say if it's a short visit or an all-day event

Something interesting. I went there on a weekend , and the amount of people inside the place is unbelievable. I recommend to go on a week day if that's something possible.There's a tour, that i dodn't take, but that would make it more interesting.

Super Interesting. We went with an English guide called Simon who was very good. This is a great place to visit with kids and with a guide made it all the more memorable as he could find the gruesome bits of the cemetery my boys thought were great

Historical and Architectural Delight. Unlike any other cemetery. Beautiful architectural designs and historical markers throughout. You can spend hours looking at the different designs and the evolution of cemetery throughout the ages.
You have to go. You can spend hours there, stunning place, wonderful structures, take your time and walk around and dont rush out.

Worth a visit. Beautiful cemetery full of the creepy, the touching, the heartfelt tributes to those who rest here. My kids loved the ornate structures, taking photos of the picturesque views and visiting the cemetery cats. A perfect way to end our rainy day.

Stunning. I had precisely two hours for sightseeing on my trip to Buenos Aires last week (it was a business trip) and I chose to visit Recoleta Cemetery. That was my plan from the beginning, as I enjoy visiting cemeteries as a general rule, but when I arrived in Buenos Aires and asked my co-workers what I should visit, they all said "the cemetery" without hesitation. Despite my own preference, this surprised me because most people don't place visiting cemeteries high on their tourism to-do list. This made me realize that the cemetery in question must be pretty remarkable.Remarkable doesn't begin to cover it. Stunning and extraordinary are the first words that came to mind upon my arrival. You could easily forget that you are in a cemetery and believe instead that you're in a massive sculpture exhibit. The mausoleums spanned the gamut from simple to ornate, from modern to gothic. Many had stained glass windows. I spent more than an hour just wandering around in awe. I am so glad that I visited; it was the perfect choice for my sightseeing time in Buenos Aires.Note: despite what Google Maps will tell you, the entrance is NOT on Azcuenaga. The entrance is on Junin, which is on the opposite side. It's a large cemetery, so if you find yourself on the wrong side as I did, it's about a 10 minute walk around the perimeter to the entrance. It's not a big deal in retrospect, but at the time it was very frustrating as I thought as I was lost.

Wow!. This is a Buenos Aires MUST! I know that you can consult a map to find some of the more famous tombs, but I just loved meandering with no plan. Since the cemetery follows a grid pattern, it's really hard to get truly lost. I'd allow at least an hour to wander, although I spent two hours wandering and didn't see everything. There are so many mausoleums -- and they're so tightly packed together -- there are a lot of details and architectural styles to savor. Such a beautiful place!

Interesting place to visit . Quite cool to see such a varied and expensive range of graves.
Highlight was the Eva Peron grave, though it was quite hidden away, there was quite a large crowd.
Pleasant walk through the cemetery.

World class . I have been lucky enough to visit what are probably the most famous museums in the world; Pere Lachaise, Prague Jewish cemetery, among others. Not that I look forward to visit cemeteries while on vacation, but these are the ones you can't miss. Having said that, Recoleta is a work of art at each corner. It's an ever increasing effort to out do the previous one that simply brings out amazing architecture within a few meters. Amazing. The guided tour is in Spanish, but that lady knows her stuff. Of course you can't miss Evita's tomb, but the entire tour is pleasant and keeps you in awe of the age of grandeur that Buenos Aires experienced.It compares with Pere Lachaise in beauty.

one of BA must see. You really cannot just miss this place. The architecture itself is tremendous, plus going straight around 100-150m and then turning left you can find Evita's grave, one of the Argentina heroes.

Definitely worth a visit. Ideally go as part of a tour to hear about the interesting stories. It is free to enter and it really impressive to see! Evita's grave is inconspicuous - she was buried in her brother's grave. But without knowing the story behind it, you miss the drama.

Favorite attraction in all Buenos Aires!. This cemetery is absolutely beautiful! There are very few of its kind in the world. Yes, there are a few creepy mausoleums (with some visible dilapidated coffins inside) but you can't miss it. The pictures don't do it justice!

Beautiful, peaceful and very spiritual. Do not miss this if you go to Buenos Aires. I went there as part if the free walking tour of Recoleta and stayed on after visiting Evita's grave, to take photos and just feel the atmosphere.

Surreal. It's very odd to be sitting here typing, "If you go to Buenos Aires, make sure you visit their cemetery!" but there you go.If you go to Buenos Aires, make sure you visit their cemetery. Full of grand tombs - some of which are more tended to than others and historical figures, it's a City for the Dead. Well worth the visit. Make sure you visit Evita's tomb - the only properly 'active' grave we saw (in the sense that people bring plenty of flowers and candles).

So weird, so grand.. What a strange thing to be buried with candied popcorn sold outside and tourists taking selfies in front of tombs! The grounds are grand and eery, and whilst most gravesites are splendid there are some very badly neglected spaces too. You can get a tour guide at the gate if yo want, but it is free to walk around on your own in you prefer. Keep an eye on small children as it would be difficult to find them if they ran off!

A lot of history at this spot. If you travel to buenos aires and you have time here you should visit this place to learn a little bit of Argentinean history. This place is situated in the middle of recoleta, a chic neighborhood in Buenos Aires.

I went three times. I was in Buenos Aires for less than a week. Being a photography and architecture buff I couldn't stop going back to Recoleta. Its a beautiful little environment inside the city and has a wonderful historic spirit. I think of it often and will certainly go back some day. A MUST if you're in Buenos Aires.

An awesome place, a must see. A really awesome place, wandering around such very ornate tombs etc. If you do visit make sure you find the memorial to Eva Peron (Evita). I have to admit I had a tear or two in my eyes when I think of her story,

Interesting. Enjoyed walking around the cemetery. Didn't have a tour as none available when we arrived, but bought a map ($40 ars) which showed where Eva Peron is buried. After that we just wandered and marvelled at the price paid to be the richest man in the cemetery. An interesting place to see and loose an hour or two. Nice surrounding, we went on a Saturday and there was a cool market, plus Palmero shopping centre, Starbucks etc.
Great architecture . Nice to see different perspective of a cemetery. The culture here is different than the normal cemeteries.

Must see for families. Darn, I reviewed this under the City heading, so I will repeat, this is a must-see. The architecture, history and beauty was breathtaking. So many stories, we could have spent a day there. Take a guide with you to get the real flavor of the history you are viewing.

Very interesting place. Definitely worth a visit. Beautiful arquitecture, many interesting stories. We were here as part of a guided city tour and for sure it is better to come here with some kind of guide in order to listen to the small stories behind this very specual place

An Experience.. One has to visit this extraordinary cemetery in B.A. I went to look for the tomb of Eva Peron. The whole cemetery is a history on to itself. I recommend spending a while there. Worth it.

Magnificent Cemetery. This is a wonderful tourist attraction, with beautiful tombs and interesting stories about those famous and not famous, yet nevertheless very well-to-do individuals and families that are interned there. A must see in Buenos Aires.

Amazing!. I don't think there is another place like this in the world! I was leery about going to a cemetery as a tourist attraction. I ended up going back 2 more times in my 5 day visit to BA! It is truly amazing, full of history, and the mini architecture is our of this world. This is a DO NOT MISS stop when you are in BA!

Evita's resting place.. and many others'. Graveyard architecture may not be everybody's cup of tea but sometimes cemeteries contain some really interesting pieces of sculpture well worth a visit. Apart from the pilgrimage to Evita's tomb (which was surprisingly lonely when we went there) there are many other beautiful mausoleums which justify half a morning of your time in the city.

Well as this is famous . Have been around and coming to BS AS since 2005 but never got in to this place so this time I spare some time well old stuff construction is from years ago but interest no afraid of this type of locations anyway as they have guides and tours explaining the history b hind the locations

Art and Architecture?. This is one of the highlights of our trip to BA. Walking around the cemetery is going through Art & Architectural History. It was educational and a feast for the eye and heart to see period art & architecture in one place that you forget where you are. We visited this place to see Evita Duarte Peron's tomb and we had no idea how awesome this place was. Don't miss this for the world. TIP: No need to buy maps. just take picture of the map on the side of the entrance. Evita's tomb is under her maiden name Duarte.

Spooky but worth it. No trip to Recoleta is complete without a visit to the Cemetary. Free to get in, even if you just spend 5 min there its worth the effort. The immensity and variety of tombs/homes is excellent. Preferably go before dusk :)

Nice historical place to visit. Nice historical place to visit and have lot of stories associated with it . You the guide as it will help you to explain significance of various pieces of history associated with this place.Have 2-3 hours spare so that you can visit the entire cemetery.

Must visit. This place is so fascinating and weird all at the same time. I highly recommend seeing this if you are visiting Buenos Aires. Their is a tour in English at 11am on Thursdays that is perfect for any English speaking visitors. The only cost is a tip for the tour guide.The tour gives you a real understanding about Argentinian culture and status.
Interesting graveyard.. An interesting place to visit, search the graveyard for a while see some stunning tombs and Do one of the tours to learn about history of Argentina! .

The first cemetery i didnt mind being at, it was amazing!. This place was amazing, I had never seen anything like it! My wife and I stayed at the Dazzler hotel right behind it and our room view was this cemetery and I swear every second I was in the room I didn't take my eyes off of it! it was gorgeous and just out of the ordinary! When we went to visit it was something that you just have to experience for yourself! dont get me wrong I wouldn't take a nightly tour lollll but by day it was extremely nice and definitely worth the while!
Huge and beautiful. There is so much to see here! I just wandered up and down the rows and there was so much to see. Really beautiful art, and a great way to spend an afternoon.
who would have thought. Just amazing to see the history and architecture of this place. And if your on a budget its even better as this is free

Mistery and Architecture to explore and enjoy. I live in Buenos Aires and I`ve visited Recoleta Cemetery several times, by myself and with tourism guides, which turned out to be very different experiences. If you want to just admire the variety of monuments, sculptures and architecture in general it is ok to go alone (don`t forget to bring your camera!!). But if you also want to learn about the many stories behind these and the tombs and cripts, hire a tour. It will be well worthy! There is much more mistery to explore along with the architectural aspect. And be careful...you might bump into a ghost!

A must if you are in BA. I think this is my favourite place in BA, a museum, art, history, picturesque...everything in on place, a lot of coffee stores around, artinsans..dont miss the opportunity if you are here. And...it´s FREE
Like no other place. It is a maze of art masterpieces and temples, made by famous artists many of them european classics. Not to miss.

Great place to take pictures. If you love to take pictures, this is the right place to do it... you wouldn't believe how many beautiful statues and mausoleums are inside, can also take a walking tour or just going by yourself.

Very interesting . Recoleta neighbors have that European style that makes Buenos Aires a distinguished city. This part of the city is one of the preferred local high society to show all the splendor. And the cementery is famous for all the important people of this nation who rest there. Politics, nobles and famous distinguish people of Argentina have known people resting forever. No doubt, original attraction

One of the top tourist attractions in Buenos Aires. Necropolis where the rich, powerful and famous of argentine society are buried. No need for a guide( they will try to snag you at the entrance). There are maps available for locating the graves, including that of Eva Duarte de Peron

Something different. If you are in Paris, you go to visit Pere Lachise Cementary, so in Buenos Aires people visit Recoleta Cemetary. Evita´s place of rest is there, so there are sometimes tourist taking pictures of this. It is different and more spectacular than any other cemetary I have seen.

Great attraction. Really interesting to walk around. It's free to enter. I went with some friends from Buenos Aires who took us to the main mausoleums (Sarmiento, Evita, Julio Argentino Roca). Other than that we just wandered around. There were lots of tour groups throughout - I would recommend joining one to learn more about the cemertery. It's also really easy to lose your way (so at least find a map)!.

Amazing - don't miss it. The cemetery is beautiful and intriguing. We spent about 3 hours here. We paid 50pesos for a tour which was well worth it and lasted an hour. The guide was very knowledgeable. Easily walkable from the CBD.
