City of the Dead. This is an amazing place - imagine a city, but instead of homes and office buildings, there are mausoleums - street upon street of them, one next to the other. Full of ornate statuary and loving inscriptions, it is a beautiful and fascinating place. I wondered why anyone would want to visit a cemetery, but it was a special place. You can see Eva Peron's grave, and people are still leaving flowers.

Beautiful. As you enter the cemetery you are immediately surrounded by mausoleums. They were beautiful and not like any other cemetery I have ever visited. It is easy to get lost looking at the beautiful structures. Staff is also very helpful to find Evita's location

Spooky. Seemed to be a popular place to visit while in Recoleta, a lot of people wandered in and out. I did not have the courage to enter as the statues seemed so spooky from the outside like an old European horror movie.

Unique atmosphere. This famous cemetery on a hill in the upscale Recoleta area is unique. It gives a beautiful view on the way the upper class and the high army officers have been buried. It looks like a town, with some monuments well preserved and others totally decayed. The monument grave of Evita Perron has not been indicated, and is in the Duarte family monument in a remote spot of the cemetery. Free entrance.

Incredible social history of BA society. This cemetery is remarkable....absolutely fascinating. We went as part of a tour and the guide took us to Eva Peron's family crypt, which is surprisingly unassuming. We were so fascinated we went back another afternoon and wandered around for about 3 hrs. The architecture of the crypts is astonishing - like miniature mansions. We found so many interesting notable BA citizens - it's really worthwhile. Go to Cafe Biela afterwards for refreshments.
Worth the visit. This cemetery is a really great representation of the various cultures in Buenos Aires and even kind of a microcosm of the cities various types of architecture.

Weird and Grand. It seems some what strange to wander around cemeteries taking photos, and somewhat disrespectful yet you feel obliged when the size of some of the family monuments tower over you as they do. It was a good experience and fascinating look. Cemetery does not feel like death and has lots of staff puttering about feeding the cats and cleaning nice stroll around on a nice day

Good for a walkthrough. The architecture of the grave sites is magnificently varied. I very much enjoyed walking through the cemetery. Don't limit yourself to only finding the grave of Evita. There is much more to see.
Must visit. Not religious however found very interesting and respectful. A must see should you visit this city. Surrounding area is upmarket with plenty more sights.

Not so creepy!. I always visit cemeteries as i believe it is part of a cultural journey to understand a bit more about the people and the practices around different cultures.The Recoleta Cemetery hold the remains of he richa nd the powerful !Beautiful Carrara marble statues and bronze sculptures.Evita Perón alongside many of the generals are buried here!

Interesting ; having a guide helps. We showed up for the English language tour and were told that it was cancelled. After some persistence on our part , the ladies at the ticket counter told us to hire one of the private guides and escorted us to her. It was worth the money ($10/person) because wandering around and just viewing Eva Duarte's mausoleum does not do the place justice.
Mas Museo que Cementerio. Is a Wow place one visit is not enough or go really early so you can enjoy the art like this place alot
A must see!. Intriguing bit of history including Evita tomb. We did a walking tour with Soledad and the history lesson really brought the whole cemetery to life.

Atmosphere, History & Fascinating Stories -- no free English tours in June 2016. This is a site not to miss when you visit Buenos Aires. It's a place to take in the history of the whole city as well as the personal histories of individual families; to be awed by ostentatious and soaring monuments; to be sobered by the ruins of crypts falling into decay; to hear of intrigue, grief, jealousy, power and wealth. It definitely helps to take a guided tour. But NOTE: when we visited in June 2016, signs indicated that the free English-language guided tours offered by the cemetery staff had been suspended. !! Quite an unpleasant surprise to us when we arrived. We accepted a guided tour by a fellow who approached us at the gates and said we could pay him whatever we felt right at the end. He told us great stories about the cemetery and surrounding area and was quite entertaining, so I'd say it was worth it. But since the cemetery staff were still giving Spanish-language free tours, it was hard not to shake the sense that something was amiss with the English tour suspension. We ultimately racked it up to a case of paying a penalty for having failed to learn any Spanish all these years (American hubris). You don't have to take a guided tour to enjoy the place, however. It's worth also visiting the church next door.
A must see . Like nothing I have seen before. The cemetery was grand, beautifully kept, detailed and respectful. A must see - spent about an 1hr30mins here.

Wow! . When we came to BA out driver said that the best thing to do here is to visit a cemetery. Well, we looked at each other thinking 'what is that city that the main attraction is the cemetery ' but well, he was right. The place is magic, full of sculpture masterpieces and spooky at times. Must see when in BA

Evita grave. Interesting to see the ostentatious mausoleums in this place with Windows into the crypts containing coffins. Evita's grave is tucked away and could easily be missed if not for the flowers and people visiting

An above ground cemetery/city not to be missed. You don't need a lot of time to visit this place, but if you are in Buenos Aires, you definitely should do so. It's an easy walk or cab ride from most areas you'd stay as a tourist or on business. Really fascinating architecture and history, well laid out in guide books and on the internet

Beautiful site seeing . We did the tour by ourselves (not with the guide). It's really beautiful and a touristic spot. There's a street market nearby on weekends and some restaurants and bars. If you do the guided tour they tell you some curious stories of the place.
Very ornate cemetery including Eva Peron. Recommend going on the weekend to walk through the cemetery and then the open air market right outside. A must see if you are in Recoleta.
Beautiful. Beautiful cemetery, grand and respectful. Interesting to walk around and in a very nice area for lunch / coffee after. Would definitely recommend a visit.

Could have stayed all day. Went as part of a guided tour. I recommend that's the best way to get the understanding of what you are seeing and then you can explore more. It would take all day to see it all, maybe even more. And of course respecting it is an operating cemetery, as we witnessed a mass in progress the day we were there

This is not your average cemetery. This is a must see! The history here is something special! All Mausoleums. This is where the rich, famous, and in-formis are buried. Spectacular structures! Privately owned by "the families" of the deceased. The families pay taxes to own and maintain these mausoleums. Eva Peron is here with her family. A MUST SEE!
The strangest of outings. Absolutely fascinating , the famous one hard to find , but an interesting experience looking for it , give the shocking realisation you likely to be put out for the bin man

Toured with Joy of Buenos Aires . Joys tour was delightful! We would have missed so many stories and highlights! From boxing to Evita Joy had all the stories and respect for the local! It is a very interesting sight, especially with Joys tour!!

Very atmospheric on a cold, wet day. It was a cold and wet weekend last week and the cemetery was very atmospheric in that kind of weather. It's amazing how much money is invested in this little piece of real estate. The highlight was finding Eva Peron's mausoleum.

THE Tourist Highlight of Buenos Aires. We arrived early morning to Buenos Aires on Saturday July 2nd 2016 to thunderstorms and quite a bit of rain. Having done little research about what to see in BA, the locals say this "is" the major tourist attraction for Buenos Aires, other than the Pink House and Tango. Our hotel, Mio Buenos Aires, was in Recoleta, steps away from the Cemetery so after checking in and a light breakfast, Googlemaps said it would be a 16 minute walk to the Cementario Recoleta. We literally did a full circle and walked right around the cemetery when we could have just walked directly to it. If you're walking from Alvear Palace Hotel / Mio Buenos Aires, go right and look for the entrance with the white pillars and gold tipped fence. The entrance is also to the left of the Recoleta Cultural Center. On the left there is a Map of all the different tombs the most famous being Eva Peron (C7). Free English and Spanish walking tours are offered - English at 11am Tuesday and Thursday and in Spanish at 11am and 3pm from Tuesday to Friday but were cancelled due to the rain. It was an unusual walk through history, very different to what you'd typically expect at a cemetery especially with some tombs with glass doors where you can see the casket (. We found Evita's tomb easily enough using the entrance map but didn't have the background knowledge to appreciate the significance of the other tombs.

Cemetario . This is the most unique cemetery and is where Eva Peron is buried. There mausoleums have interesting stories to tell if you have a guide. It is free to the public and the church next door is very beautiful. Recoleta is the affluent area of Buenos Aires and great to tour on foot or bike.

Fascinating . I recommend getting a tour of this site if you can. If you are comfortable with cemeteries as historical sites, this "city of the dead" rates very highly. Looking at the monuments allows the visitor to travel through the history of Buenos Aires and Argentina in general. With varying types of style and architecture, alongside statues and beautifully maintained "streets", it feels like a stroll in the park. The many cats that doze on or near the monuments are said to be the guardians of the loved ones at the cemetery. Of course it is worth mentioning that the tomb of Eva Peron can be found here as well.

A city within the city..... It may sound nuts, but this cemetery is gorgeous!...., the mausoleums are majestic, and if you take the time to read the plaques you'll learn a great deal of history. The EVITA crypt can't be missed!
Evita. Excellent place to visit to encounter where the rich were buried. Home to many famous (now death) people, such as Evita.

Gorgeous!. This was a beautiful as well as contemplative place and a must visit while in Buenos Aires. Make sure you check to see when certain language tours are and will be held because it looks like in the winter they cut back on the number of tours.

Just amazing! Not macabre but fascinating!. I decided to visit the cemetery to take a photo of Eva Peron (Evita)'s grave for my daughter. But spent a good hour just wandering around looking at the tombs. It is like a small city with interconnecting streets and the tombs are ornate, dilapedated, modern and everything in between! It is not macabre, although there are a huge number of coffins on show, especially in the derelict tombs, but the coffins are intact and it is fascinating just to walk up and down the avenues and "meet" some of Argentina's most famous sons and daughters! And keep an eye out for a terribly understated grave to a couple with English Sounding names!
Cementario. Pretty good place to roam around and see different ways to honor your ancestors. Do it earlier during the day because it gets hot...

Must do in BA. Really cool and free
Never seen anything like it and doubt I would again!
Spent the morning there and was great to just walk around. They do English tours but we jus pottered

City of the Dead. A day visit to Recoleta Cemetery in Buenos Aires will elevate your appreciation for the value of life. Here is a city compased of street upon street of elaborate tombs. One receives the imoression of visiting a silent city with a plethora of artistic statues, tombs with glass doors for multiple family members. The place is absolutely unreal.

Yes- you should see this!. You may be asking yourself- do I really need to see this place?! The answer is yes, yes you do. In spite of its overexposure and it being on every must see BA list- the Recoleta Cemetery is one of the great cultural heritage sights in Europe- oh wait- that's right BA is in the Americas- sometimes you have to remind yourself of that here. Yes go see it- perhaps bring some deep and philosophical reading material ( I recommend Marcus Aurelius's Meditations for moments like this) and ponder how short our time here is on this planet. Marvel at how many of the graves in this super fashionable and exclusive neighborhood appear not to have been cared for by anyone in a century or more- really- is it sad- yes-is it life - yes. So come to Recoleta to check the box, but more importantly consider how lucky you are to have the opportunity to visit this fabulous city during the nanosecond you have on this planet. Then go get yourself another incredible ribeye and dont hesitate to order that second though likely unneeded bottle of Malbec- life is short - enjoy and savor every moment!

A wonderful piece of BA's history. No visit to BA is complete without a visit here. The close to 5,000 tombs, graves and burial sites is worth an hour or two of your time. We arrived to catch an 11:00 am tour (in English we were told and free!) but these were suspended! No matter we were found by an English guide - very knowledgeable and the price was "what you want to pay" - so for around $30 we had the benefit of an hour or so of his time and knowledge

Surprisingly fascinating. This cemetery is unlike anything I have ever seen. It is a definite must on your BA itinerary. It is just very unique (you can see coffins) and the crypts / mausoleums are fascinating. I really enjoyed walking around and having a look. Eva Peron's resting place is easy to find - just follow the crowds, otherwise just wander and explore.

Won't take up too much time.... You have to swing by to pay homage to Evita. It won't take long. There will be a crowd so you'll know where to go. Just get in get out box checked. Now go drink wine. The Recoleta is perfect for that :))))

Free Entry. Fascinating place.. Because this was just down the road from where we were staying, it made sense to have a look around. If you are looking for the testing place of Eva Peron it is on the left side of the Cemetery about half way along. It is marked on the map as plot 88. Go up the central Avenue when you walk in and turn left at the Christ statue. Keep walking and you will see the tourists. Look for the tomb with lots of fresh flowers attached to the door. If there are lots of people there, be prepared to wait. Aside from that, there are many well known Argentine dignitaries buried here. There are streets of tombs and they are fascinating to look at.
Free entry . Interesting cemetery with free entry and evita is buried here in the duarte family mausoleum. The mausoleums are each quite unique and some are empty.

Haunting.... (May 2015) I can honestly say that I need to go back so I can experience this place again. I feel that I will not have the same one that I did on my first visit! Around every corner you can find something new and beautiful. We had an extremely interesting tour with our lovely guide Estrella. I definitely recommend this for a very accessible way to see many of the most interesting, historical, beautiful, etc. sites in the cemetery.

worth a look. If you are going to visit a cemetery this unique one would be my pick. Having a guide helps, they are available at the entrance for a donation. Of course Eva Peron being here has made it more famous but it's very interesting, like a small city with lots of the coffins and urns in sight, whole families and generations. There are no more plots available but you can sometimes buy an existing one for a fortune if the end of a line needs some money.Some nice shops close by.

Creepy. The cemetery is ok as a cemetery, but I felt it should not be a tourist attraction. Most of the tombs have the coffins in plain sight and I felt very uncomfortable. This should be a place of peace and respect and it is full of people walking around and talking.

The single most important thing to visit. This cemetery is one-of-a-kind and encompasses the whole of the Argentine story in its structures. Beautiful for the architecture alone, you can walk around it for hours in wonder and amazement. Eventually, get yourself a guide at the front entrance who speaks your language so you'll know what you were looking at. Even a quick 30 minutes is helpful. NOTE: the office provides no maps nor guidebooks. They do have a digital display which is fascinating but you'd have to read it for hours before you really got anywhere with it. The other visitors will have murdered you by then.

Very interesting . We spent a very pleasant half day visiting the cemetery on a walking tour. It was very interesting and definitely worth a visit. Be aware however of pick pockets this didn't affect us but the guards told us there had been several thefts that day.

Where the "rest of us" go to rest. If you've ever visited New Orleans' historic cemeteries, you have an idea of what awaits you in a visit to Recoleta -- think St. Louis Cemetery on steroids! We visited on a blustery, misty day -- perfect weather in which to roam among the tombs of the rich and famous. The design, architecture and statuary of these elaborate mausoleums is spectacular -- not to mention the roll-call of those individuals who have shaped the history of Argentina. Despite the fact that Recoleta Cemetery is considered a "must see" for visitors to Buenos Aires, there remains a sense of peace, respect and dignity over the place.

Not like cemeteries in the UK - this is like a self contained city. As well as Eva Peron's grave, this is worth visiting just to see the extravagant graves here. Some are the size of small houses and the majority are well maintained. We found it very interesting.

Unique cemetery . Very old and famous cemetery. It looks like a sculpture museum. Here is a map and suggested path of the visit so you could use it. You could also buy the map at the entrance for 30 pesos. If you are in Buenos Aires you shouldn't miss this.
Oddly interesting!. This is a massive above ground cemetery with mausoleums that are grand, imposing, impressive, and interesting! No need for a guide, just wander around and enjoy!

Outstanding. I have never visited a cemetery like this before - it's out of this world. It is truly worth a visit to see all of the amazing graves, but I recommend visiting with a guide that could point you to come of the 80+ monuments that you could find inside.

City in itself!. This cemetery is one of only three in the world. Literally could spend all day looking at different architectural influences of mausoleums and extravagance of burials. Evita is buried here and most visited. A must see!

It's worth seeing more than just Evita. We went with just the purpose of seeing Evita's final resting place. We ended out spending much more time wandering around the place. Very interesting place that seems almost like a town of its own.

What a tour. This was a bit weird since its literally a cemetery that has attracted tourist to come and see. it was a great way to spend our afternoon. since all my kids did was run around the place and just screaming.

Fascinating!. The cemetary is very old and generations of families have their tombstones there. Evita's tomb is visited regularly and always has daily fresh flowers and you can take a tour of the cemetery which no doubt be very interesting

Is a historical place, in the city center. Miost travellers from all over the word visits this cementary, different, and the most popular in south América, near you can walk and chosse many restaurants and good shooping, finest neighborhood in city center

Beautiful graves. This cemetery is where some famous persons like Evita Peron were buried and because of this, the place can be a bit crowded in your visit but it deserves a try since it has beautiful graves like true works of art as you can see on the photos.

For history and architecture lovers. A very interesting place to visit if you are interested in Argentinian and Latin-american history. I highly recommend to do it with some guide because it's easy to get lost inside.

A must for first timers to BA. This is a very unique cemetary that you will not find in many cities.
There are some wonderful tours explaining the history of many families buried there.
I would say it is amongst the top 10 things you should see in BA.

Beautiful Cemetery.. You can take tours to see the Recoleta Cemetery but I just roamed around. It's simply beautiful. Lots of history, stained glass windows, and sculptures. Afterwards, checked out the church next-door to the cemetery.

Weird. This big expensive graveyard is worth the visit if you are in BA. It's very weird - a bunch of rich families have built huge marble mausolea, which are in very different condition, some broken and dirty, some polished and renovated.
After a while it's all the same. See the Leloir one and a bunch of others and you're good.
Interesting visit. Was apparently a must do for BA & was an interesting stop on a bike tour but not on my must do list. Very ornate cemetery but still kinda creepy.

Astounding place to visit. We spent time walking around in amazement of the tombs that have been built for the departed family members. The tombs are very impressive and this cemetery is a must visit. Very humbling to see and everyone we saw there was very respectful. We didn't do a tour but I think a tour would give you a better understanding.
A family trip to Bs. As. . Is a mandatory visit! A labyrinth of beautiful crypts and statuettes of female bodies. One of the best cementeries in the world
A must visit!. This place is unique, very peaceful and so interesting. You can't miss Evita, just ask at the entrance gate.

History unfolds before you. Amazing historic walk, this attraction was opened in 1822. Taking in every past politician and the people who helped build this amazing country. Obviously, the most famous being the site of Eva Peron's resting place.
Beautiful place. Another spot of Recoleta that is a time travel. There are several tombstones from past centuries which are very well-built.

Historical soul. You will be surprise about this cemetery. This place is like a little church for everyone who was buried there. The architecture is amazing and the religious images are stunning. The place made me remember the philosophy Christian.

Very emotive place worth a visit. Visited here on a biking tour around Buenos Aires. Was unsure exactly what to expect but was surprised at the size and extent of the cemetery.
Every grave is different with stones and memorials of all shapes and sizes.
Well worth a half hour stroll round.

Better than expected. A cemetery right - that's worth visiting ?!
Absolutely - yes it's for rich families but very impressive and a must visit.

Pretty nice, better is visited with a guide. We ended at the Recoleta Cemetery after a tour with Buenos Aires Free Walking tour. The place is really nice, neat and has a lot of impressive tombs. What I recommend though is to visit it with a guide who explains you about the story of the cemetery and provides you details of the famous people who are buried here, as many of them are politics or historic characters which may be unfamiliar unless you are an expert on Argentina's history.

An interesting place. Certainly an interesting place for a short visit. we took the Subte and had a 10 minute walk. There are good maps so depending on your preferences and interests there is no need to take a guide. We enjoyed just wondering around and looking at the different crypts we were not interested in hearing who was buried where just enjoyed the the pleasure walking around. Eva Perone's resting place nothing special

Photographers Dream Cemetery. Visited La Recoleta in late April 2016 with my husband who is a photographer. The giant sculptures and tombs tell many individual stories and give the explorer glimpses into the past. We enjoyed this visit more than any of the other public attractions in Buenos Aires (which I confess we were disappointed in overall). Be forewarned that Eva's tomb is a bit of a let down considering who she is and what she represents to the people of Argentina, although was dotted with fresh flowers from her faithful admirers, the tomb seems plain compared to those monuments of the past. Bring your camera and some snacks for the many cats that call Recoleta home and spend a few hours wandering throughout the past! Must visit it if in Buenos Aires!

Exciting to see. Take a stroll in the cemetery and look at all the familiar names and astonashing graves. NB: if you are looking for a special grave, they are not easy to find. Use the digital search function at the entrance, there you can tap inn ex: Eva, and you'll find her original family name Duarte.
Must Visit!. An absolute gem of a place. Such beautiful graves, with so much history. If ever in Buenos Aires, this place is a must go! Also, in a really cool part of the city!

Peaceful . We were lucky enough to go through the cemetery with a great tour guide that explained everything with enthusiasm. Of course while you are there you must pay a visit to Eva Parons /Dantes Tomb. It is a beautiful cemetery and definitely worth the visit.

Less than we expected . The place is just gorgeous. But should be more supported by the administration. Such a beautiful walking tour, but with no signs, no staff, no information. They have guided tours but we just noticed in the end due to the low visibility of the board. Definitely the most beautiful cemetery I have ever entered.

The pall of death . . .. When I first stepped into the Recoleta Cemetry in 2003, I felt overwhelmed by the extent to which the bereaved immortalized their dead. The cemetery itself was a monumental thesaurus of grief vying over grief and excelling the other with mausoleums, epitaphs and lifesize guardians of the afterlife. When I recently revisited (2016), it appeared death had finally pulled the illusory drape over what death in reality portends: gloom. A majority of the mausoleums have undergone a state of utter decay or disrepair, and others appear vandalized. It seems, as if time had finally caught up with reality that no amount of iconic or fervent immortalization can uplift death’s affirmative pall: We are all here for a purpose for which our existence came to be necessary until our life sentence on earth is commuted by death.

A living piece of history. I was in Argentina studying for my thesis on Eva Peron, so this was the best place to go for a piece of history. You can wander on your own but also sign up with a tour group - the guides are all living history books themselves and are not fake or over the top. It is strangely peaceful in the midst of the city.
Overated. Yes...it has beatiful tombs but I wouldn`t feel sorry if I hadn`t been there. And Evita`s tomb is as simple as most of others which are there.

A must see. You can't go to Buenos Aires and not notice the influence of Eva Peron. Visiting the cemetery where she is buried is a must. Her grave site is actually not that impressive compared to many of the others, but the overall experience is fantastic!
Free museum. Very unique cemetery with incredible architecture. Some very impressive graves with lots of interesting history. Well worth a look

An adventure of those past. Beautiful cemetery with stories to discover and create. The beautiful tombstones of latin america cemeteries have always captured my senses and this is another excellent example of the beauty of those who have passed before us.

Fascinating . We went to Recoleta to of course see the tomb of Evita. We thought we'd see it and then leave, but the entire cemetery was so fascinating that we walked around for at least an hour looking at all the amazing/weird/over-the-tip/macabre monuments to the dead. Many people have said it on previous reviews, but the tomb of Evita is one of the least interesting ones in Recoleta. I was surprised at just how impressive the whole thing was and would definitely add things to your BA itinerary.
Its Amazing !!!. Its worth your time. its amazing. you can spend hrs there and you can get lots to find Eva's place,,,,if you go with hop-on-hop-off buss it will stop there
Very good. Very beautiful place but still a cemetery. Don't expect more than tombs of many famous people in Argentina's history.

Famous Cemetery. This famous cemetery is not like any cemetery I have ever seen. If you only do one thing in Buenos Aries, let it be this. This cemetery is home of the body of the famous Eva Peron. So seeing her grave is a must. Or Crypt as there are here. These crypts potential house the entire family's body's. It's. Or like anything I have ever seen. It looks like you are walking threw little streets in Europe. This experience is an A+ in my book.

Very interesting place . We spent approx 1 hour here just wandering around and also saw Evita's grave. We went without a guide, I'm sure it would be more interesting with a guide but we had done 2 walking tours already during our stay and so we're happy to potter around ourselves. It's really interesting to see the huge tombstones and graves, like being in a city. It's a must do in BA

Interesting visit. We spent an hour walking through. there's a map at the entrance which shows where Evita (familia Duarte) is. The other tombs are just as interesting. Outdoor cafes across the street.

Don't leave B.A. without visiting it!. The cemetery of the rich and famous, an open book of Argentina's history and a national monument. It's in the middle of a fabulous residential area, but when it opened its doors in 1822, that wasn't the case. The Franciscan monks were growing vegetables there and after that land was expropiated, the cemetery was created. At that time it was named "the cemetery of the North" because Buenos Aires was mostly South. In late 19th Century, the center of gravity of B.A. started to displace to the North and a wonderful neighborhood developed around the cemetery.In early 20th Century, Argentina was one of the richest countries in the world and, that wealth can be perfectly seen just by looking at those mausoleums. In many cases, they are a show-off of money and pride.Jewish and Muslim people have to be buried in the ground but, with Catholics, anything can be done, and that's why we have funerals but no burials there. You can perfectly see those caskets on shelves. As most of the people that settled in Argentina came from Italy, France and Spain, we are a Mediterranean culture and there's some implicit cult of death in it. On average, there are 20 funerals per month and that's almost nothing for a city the size of B.A. There's a much bigger cemetery West of Buenos Aires, which is the one of the middle class. Mausoleums there are not that big there, but there are huge pantheons for professions and different regions of Italy, Spain and France. There's even another cemetery further West, for poorer people.The reasons for only having 20 funerals per month in Recoleta is that people are now very different and don't like those elaborated things full of symbolisms. Therefore, in suburbs of Buenos Aires, we have private cemeteries, where people can be buried in the ground. Let me give this example: My mother in-law inhereted a mausoleum in Recoleta but, as she didn't like the idea of one day ending there, she left it to her cousins and with her husband bought a piece of land at a private one. Jewish and Muslims can be buried there, without breaking the rules of their religions. My parents in-law, who were Catholics are surrounded by Jewish people.Back to Recoleta...it's a municipal cemetery, and those mausoleums are pieces of real state. People have a deed, have to pay taxes and can buy and sell. Partially thanks to Madonna, the most visited person there is Evita Perón. Her final resting place makes some people get disappointed, as they expect to find something very big. It's just a black, shinny thing with the sign "Familia Duarte". (as her maiden name was María Eva Duarte) She died in 1952 and wasn't sent there until 1976. She shares the place -among others- with her mother, her sisters, her brother and a brother in-law. But, visitors shouldn't miss the mausoleum of the Leloir family, in my opinion, the most impressive in the whole cemetry. There's a person at the entrance who sells a mao of the cemetery and you could ask her to show you where it is. (but, please buy the map, as the money goes to repair those mausoleums which are in very bad condition. Some are collapsing, as there's nobody left to take care of them)I'm pretty sure you'll find the cemetery very interesting. Walk through the area around the cemetery and, you'll see how lively it is, just next to the dead....Contradiction and ambiguity, what would B.A. be like without them?
Architecture and peace. Visited cemetery on a very hot day so never found Evitas tomb. Beautiful place and you can self tour.

Worth seeing and not just for Eva Peron. This is a very interesting cemetery to wander round and it is full of wonderful architecture and statuary. The tomb everyone visits, is of course Eva Peron, as made famous by the musical Evita, but don't ignore all the other tombs. There is a great variety of styles and architecture from gothic to art deco!
A must to see. This is something that we do not see in my country. Well worth the experience because of the history and architecture.
Mind Blowing. "Cemetery" I had never seen anything like this. Needs a couple of hours for a good wonder around. They also have a craft market outside on Saturdays.

Impressive. I did not see myself as somebody who would visit a cemetery but this one was recommended so I am glad I went for it. We really enjoyed this short visit. It helped that it was a beautiful day to walk. There is a special beauty to this place that is challenging to articulate. Worth about an hour's visit.

Cemetery city-Eva and other characters. This cemetery is one like many others in South America, basically a "city of the dead" with many crypts and mausoleums. They are mostly well-kept and the grounds are clean and trimmed. The big draw here is Eva Peron's humble grave, new among many older ones. Just outside the cemetery there was a little local street festival going on and flower vendors as well. It sits just behind the second oldest church in the town which gives it a little more life.

Interesting but don't make a special trip. So, you want to see how insecure and ostentatious rich people in BA were... Here's the most visual example you can have. They built mini mansions to house their families. If you have ever seen a cemetery in New Orleans this is similar but on steroids when it comes to ornate and artistic style. Oh and Eva Peron is entombed there if you care to see her final resting place

A must see in Buenos Aires. We spent our first morning walking through Recoleta, we were happy we had a local guide to tell the stories of a many of the families and monuments. It is a must see if in Buenos Aires.

Amazingly beautiful experience!. My boyfriend and I visited Recoleta Cemetery knowing it was going to be amazing, but we were still blown away! The statues are phenomenal! We spent hours just walking around. Evita Peron's tomb was a highlight, but there is so much more to take in as well! And, the chapel is beautiful, a must see on your trip to Argentina!
Unlike anything I have ever seen. If you ever visit Buenos Aires this is definitely something to add to your list. Of course you must visit Eva Duarte de Perón's final resting place.

A MUST DO! Amazing Architecture! Amazing Art!. I love this place, you can go and never get bored! Not only there are lots of well known persons buried there but also the art in each mausoleum is incredible! a MUST go in Buenos Aires!!!
a must visit!. So you may think same as we did - who wants to visit a cemetery.. Don't be fooled! This is an absolute must visit place in BA!

Fascinating! Full of history. Our tour guide took us to Recoleta Cemetery on our first day in Buenos Aires. This amazing 10 acre cemetery is filled with Argentinian history. For the first trip, I would certainly recommend a guide so as to understand the who, how, and why behind the cemetery. We took a second trip by ourselves - with a map - and literally wandered throughout the cemetery for two - three hours. Yes, we did see Evita's grave! A must see in Buenos Aires.

Amazing cemetery. A really fantastic place and especially at the end of the day when all the tourist groups have left. You can just wander around and there is something different to see at every corner. I didn't end up finding the Eva Peron tomb, but knowing that it was there was enough for me.

Unique and fascinating. Absolutely essential to visit as is in a really nice part of the city and is also an insight into the previous aristocratic wealth of Recoleta. The resting place of Eva Peron (Duarte) - make sure you check out where she is buried or you'll never find it.
cemitery full of history. There many tours around this cemitery and recommend getting to know it when in Buenos Aires, this place is full of history

A CEMETERY TO DIE FOR! ABSOLUTELY PUT THIS ON YOUR LIST FOR YOUR BUENOS AIRES VISIT!. There are handful of absolute “must-do’s” for any first time visit to Buenos Aires of any length: as mentioned in my earlier reviews - don’t miss the Teatro Colon (opera house), if you’re there on a Sunday - don’t miss the enormous San Telmo Flea Market, and by all means, make sure you have the famous Cementerio de la Recoleta (Recoleta Cemetery) on your list. While it might seem strange to mention a cemetery as a “don’t miss” destination, the Recoleta Cemetery lives up to the hype and is well worth the time. In this “city of the dead” you will find buried or entombed the rich, famous and powerful of Argentina: politicians, generals, business magnates, people who made their names in the arts and, of course, Evita Peron - whose crypt is probably the most-visited. Guide books tell you the cemetery is set on 5.5 hectares (14 acres),and contains over 5000 vaults, all above ground, of which 94 have been declared National Historical Monuments by the Argentine government and are protected by the state. Laid out in blocks like a mini city, the cemetery contains hundreds of highly elaborate tombs and mausoleums, many as large as small houses, some looking like small churches or temples, and many more adorned with statues - some done by well-known sculptors - and worthy of a museum themselves. Visiting the Recoleta Cemetery is an adventure in history and art. It is considered one of the most beautiful cemeteries in the world - and for good reason - reason which becomes immediately apparent as you begin your journey down its many alleyways.Entrance to the cemetery was free when we went in May. We had been told that free tours are offered in English at 11am Tuesday and Thursday and in Spanish at 11am and 3pm from Tuesday to Friday - but we did not find anyone there offering free tours in any language when we went - only people at the entrance either selling maps of the cemetery and/or offering to be a paid guide. Look into the possibility of a free tour in case we just missed our opportunity. We purchased a map for a couple of dollars and, having a list of some of the graves we knew we did not want to miss from doing some research online prior to our visit, we proceeded to visit the cemetery on our own. We had planned to spend only an hour or two at the cemetery but wound up spending over three hours - walking up and down row upon row of mausoleums - taking in the incredible artistry of so many of the tombs. Every now and then we passed some tour group where a guide was explaining whatever tomb they happened to be standing in front of and, I must say, each time we found the narrative interesting. If you want to know more about those interred and entombed at Recoleta, joining a paid tour or paying a guide to show you around may be a good idea to enhance your visit. We were okay just wandering around with our map. We learned later that there are free maps available online. Two points to keep in mind: First - not all of the tombs are well-kept. Some look like they have been broken into and/or vandalized. We saw broken glass and trash in some of the mausoleums and more than a few looked like the coffins had been disturbed. This might be upsetting to some people, especially small children - who might find the whole experience unsettling and for whom the cemetery visit might not be appropriate. Secondly - stay close together! It is very easy to get lost or separated in the labyrinth of tombs by taking a few turns away from your group. You’ll find each other eventually, but it’s a good idea to not get separated to begin with (yes - I am embarrassed to say this comes from our own experience).Even if cemeteries tend to give you the heebie jeebies, the Recoleta Cemetery is not to be missed!
Wonderful. You have to see this and we went with a guide as part of a city tour. It should be nice weather or otherwise its a drag.
A MUST SEE if in BA. This is not only a cemetery but also a museum! It is an amazing sight to see! Don't miss it when visiting BA!

Such a fancy place!. It's hard to imagine when you walk into a cemetery that it will leave a lasting impression on you for its beauty, but this place does that. Its amazing the thought and wealth that went into burying the well off in Argentina and their family. It feels like you have walked into the city of the dead and it mesmerizes you. I'd say, come on a cloudy day. It's great for photos. Also, Evita is buried there.

A place where you want to keep visiting. Certainly, cemeteries aren't a place to visit on a regular basis. In this case Recoleta Cemetery will change the way you see or think them.Architecturally is astonishing the marble work done on sculptures and tombs, refinance, art and fine taste in details are in every corner of this place.Have the time to go, walk and admire a magnificent cemetery where is full of life due to its beauty.

Average. I was expecting to see a beautiful and clean cemetery, but, unfortunately, I've found poorly maintained tombs and signs of vandalism. This site is one of the most famous ones in Buenos Aires and should be well preserved. But on the contrary, the way it has been managed shows disrespect with the families and history represented there. It's a shame.

Fascinating, beautiful and tranquil!. I very much enjoyed coming here. Make sure you stop into the Cathedral next door. If you don't pay for a tour, piggy back on one that you hear going on. :) That is the easiest way to find Evita!

What an Amazing Place to Get Buried. A cemetery full of beautiful mausoleums of the rich and famous, including Eva Peron. (Evita). The architecture of the graves is amazing and the scale of others grand. Take a tour with BA Freewalks, 3pm every day, it costs 150 pesos, approx $15 nzd, you'll get way more out of it.

Piece of History. Lindo lugar para conocer parte de la historia argentina. Sugiero pagar guia para encontrar las tumbas de las personas famosas
Nice place to know part of the Argentinian history. I suggest to pay the guide in order to find the graveyard that belongs to the wellknown people

One of the most interesting sites in Buenos Aires. Free, not touristy and very interesting. We ended up here at the end of our morning free walking tour. Given the paucity of tourist attractions in Buenos Aires this cemetery is certainly worth a visit if you’re in town for more than a couple of hours. It’s the type of place where you can walk to Eva Peron’s grave and be done in 15 minutes or you can spend hours there going up and down each aisle noting the famous people interred there and appreciating the funerary art, some of which is truly amazing.Thanks for reading; I hope you found this, and the accompanying photos, helpful.
Different & eerie. Never seen something like this. Family mausoleums storing each family member in a coffin... Eerie!! See Evita's family crypt as well... Yes she resides in peace here!!
Absolute must see. Everyone who visits Buenos Aires should see this interesting cemetery.Of course the most interesting is the Evita Paron grave.But there is lots to see here as well s her grave

No more English tours. We went on a Tuesday for the advertised free English tour but the signs say they are now suspended.Outside a lady claimed she used to be the official English tour guide and could still offer tours for a fee (A$100 for one hour) which we did and she was quite good, giving us some stories of the deceased and, of course, Evita's grave which is less grand than others.The guide told us that the cemetery soon plan to charge for entrance. Even without Evita this would still be a cool place to visit.

A must see and on weekend right next to a wonderful craft fair. Fascinating window into Buenos Aires past and present- getting a guide is helpful but not essential. Bring cash for craft fair next door.

Tour. An opera house with over the top decor, built to rival La scala and to out dazzle versailles with gold and mirrors. Nice tour. 1 hour . Got to see the main opera house in darkness as they were setting up stage lighting. Good for a visit even if you are not interested in Opera.
Could have walked for hours. There was so much great architecture / sculpture. The tour we had was amazing. Rich in history and great photo opportunities.
Nice to go but creappy. It is a must to place to visit Evitas mausoleum. At the same time it is a creappy place with black cats and dark feelings. You can feel very strange.

So interesting for history. Who thinks of a cemetery as a 'must see', but this is. So many rows of incredible mini-monuments to families, famous people or sad stories. There is an information booth that sells a map outside of the entrance. One thing we noticed were some of the vandalized graves, some, by birds.

Nice place. This is a good place to visit in BA, even when its a cemetery, you can find great scultures and nice architecture. There are a lot of famous and important argentinian people resting in this place.

Fascinating and interesting.. Our tour guide took us here and it was reminiscent of the above ground cemeteries in New Orleans. Individual houses for the dead!! You could look in and see stained glass windows and coffins or ashes. Very interesting to see the tributes to Eva Peron brought back to Argentina after 30 years away. The poor adored her and the rich hated her. The guide told us her husband is interred somewhere else!! It was amazing to see huge statues of angels etc and then some "houses" in need of attention. Fascinating visit and interesting to see apartment blocks looking over the cemetery quite close. One not to be missed.

Fascinating place, schedule a guide!. Fascinating cemetery with notable mosoleums and beautifully designed tombs. But the real interest here are the stories! I knew a few before we arrived and had anticipated finding a guide at the entrance as many sources had told me was easy to arrange. The weather wasn't great though the day we visited and so no free-lance guides showed up! We took the official tour (regrettably in spanish) and while better than no tour it was limited to telling us the official facts and details of the cemetery and shared few of the interesting stories about the families buried there. If I could do it again I would contact a tour operator and arrange a scheduled time with a specific guide to hear all the stories. In this case this would be a good tour for families with pre-teen or teen kids.

A must see. I didn't think going round a cemetery could be so interesting but this is a fantastic place. The tombs are beautiful (mostly) and the multitude of the 'famous' here is astounding. Free entry and its close location to galleries make it a must see. Would not be so great on a rainy day but was great to see.

A must in your visit of Buenos Aires. there is a uniqueness in this cementery. May be you are used to see big landmarks with stones, as un much movie films. but this cementery is unique. there are all small buildings for each coffin or family group of coffins. A must is to see EVA Peron´s building.

Recoleta Cemetery. Definitely a must on every tourist's list. The place is open daily from 8am to 6pm. This is the resting place of many of the wealthiest and most important Argentine historical figures such as Eva Peron. The cemetery was created in 1822 and is among the oldest in Buenos Aires.

Worth 2 hours of your day.. It's really easy to visit this place. I'd allow about 2 hours, maybe 3 if you're really curious. I'm from the New Orleans area, and we have tombs above ground, too, but these are HUGE. The Recoleta cemetery is really a kind of city almost. It's walled, which makes it safer really. There are guides there, but you do NOT need a guide. Be polite, thank them, and just do your own tour. People come here to see Evita's tomb, which you can do, but it's not a big deal really. There are so many other more interesting crypts. My favorite is the one with glass and there's a room with a chair where you can go in (I mean, the family, with a key) and visit the dead person. There are some really old tombs that have bars, sort of like a barred window/wall, and you can see the coffins sitting right there. Wow. If you can go with a group or at least with a friend, I'd recommend that. I would not want to wonder the crypts too much by myself. I think it's very safe, but these tombs are close together, very big, and, well, kind of creepy at times. GO! You should definitely see this at least once!
Cemetery different from the others. I've seen all types of cemeteries from Asian, Egyptian and now Argentinean and I have to say this place was. Very interesting. I strongly recommend a tour guide.
Stunning. Beautiful moments of history....can almost touch the coffins. Great to see restoration. Must stop by. Odd when you hear voices from a crypt...a restorer no doubt
A Must in Buenos Aires. Visiting the Cemetery is like wandering through a small village with narrow streets. Be sure to see Eva Peron's - just follow the crowds to the back left.
Amazing Burial Place. So many memorials, streets of them so intricately built and maintained. Eva Peron's resting place down a side street not on a corner plot.

Very interesting memorial designs. The cemetery is very large.The crypts and/or tombs are interesting to see. There are many sculptures and stained glass works. It is also active and there are funerals going on.

One of my favorite places in Bs As. May seem creepy but I love this place. It is so beautiful with so much art and sculpture to look at, as well as tons of history. Easy to get lost in all the little alleys. Made friends with a guy who had worked there for 40 years and he showed us a bunch of highlights. Also free entry so great activity to do on a budget.

Eerie, but worth a quick visit. I visited this cemetery, primarily to see Eva Peron's grave - as are most people heading here.Initially it can be very eerie. I didn't expect to see what looked like bodies wrapped in cloth. There is a lot of such imagery.I didn't stay for too long as it creeped me out quite a bit (mind you, I was alone).Tips: do not buy a map from the lady at the entrance - there is a free comprehensive map at the entrance. If looking for Eva Peron's grave just follow everyone else or ask a staff member working in the cemetery.

Take the time to walk around. This place has so much history. Some unique designs. So worth it to go with someone who can tell you some of the fateful stories. Its an active cemetery so there was a funeral going on while we walking around.

very historical. It contains the graves of notable people, including Evita & presidents of Argentina.The whole cemetery is well laid out. It has wide tree-lined main walkways branching into sidewalks. Many cemeteries extend many levels below ground. It is architecturally rich!

The refinement of the dead.... Most Argentines of Upper classes have their Mausoleum in the cemetery. Some, if times are hard, move their dead to more humble places of rest...and sell in dollars for six figure sums their family communal graves. There is art in the statues, most executed in the XIX Century. And the grave of Evita, of course, and Gardel, two of the "Myths" (sad at that) of the Argentines. The guided visits are OK. A subterranean creek passes underneath, and it is rumored some of the oldest occupants, placed well underground, end up navigating to their final resting spot...in the Plata River...

Fascinating!. The cemetery was surprisingly much more interesting that I expected. The architecture and design elements are fascinating. And of course you can see the grave of Evita Perron. Some of the structures have broken windows and you can peek inside. Sometimes a bit creepy…Most highly reccommended!
Bealtiful, but too much gothic. Free entrance, but this is not my thing. It is very beautiful but I don't understand what is the fun in spend time in a cemetery.

Very peaceful. We went in looking for Eva Peron's grave and ended up marvelled at the magnificence and scale of some of these mausoleums. Old and new, simple and super ornate, large and small...there is one of every kind here. Very well kept by the groundkeepers.

Strange but very very interesting . Really enjoyed my walks around the Recoleta Cemetery, I just wandered freely. There's so much to see; exquisite architecture and incredible masonry. Without a tour it was hard to find the grave of Evita, yet that was half the adventure. It was a strange place because I felt I shouldn't enjoy being there so much? Anyway it's full of tourists taking photos which seemed a little disrespectful but it's permitted. If you dont like cats this is not the place for you. I think if I were to go again, I'd take a tour and then wander. I left with lots of questions!
Stunning History. A great place to get lost walking and sightseeing! Some amazing Argentina History and architecture. the guided tours are good, but just walking is enjoyable.

Just phenomenal. It is a town of cemetery - you walk and walk and walk...and you see endless number of cemeteries! And surprisingly - it's not boring at all. All of them have their own uniqueness and some of them are beyond your imagination.There are some cemeteries that are not well-managed but it did not bother me at all. You can find lots of famous people being buried here - BUT do not expect to know who is buried in which cemetery without any Spanish knowledge or tourist guide. The guide will definitely add a lot of flavour to your tourism here and you won't regret it!

Kinda creepy but very interesting. All of the people are buried in mausoleum above ground. The architecture is varied and amazing. You can look in to most of the crypto and see the coffins or urns. Eva Peron is buried there as well.

Plan for your final sleep in style . My wife refused to come initially and had to do tonnes of convincing. However, on starting the tour inside, we thoroughly enjoyed. Had a guide who escorted us and explained the background and stories behind each of the famous and richest. OMG, money makes you crazy to make you distinct and lie down in a royal grandeur. I was told that spaces are available for sale at premium pricing. Different and unique
cemetary history. Went for Evita's grave and learned about other important Argentinians buried there. Evita's mausoleum is there but not Evita
Everybody who was somebody is here. Evita,of course, but also Generals by the score. naval heroes with Irish heritage.great ladies memorialized by old Lovers. Good 2hur walk thru Argentinian history.
Awesome. We had a private guide who took us into the cemetery during a 2 day private tour of BA). Was awesome learning the history (we used Marcelo).

Must see. This cemetery is very interesting. The crypts are amazing. We thought it might be like some of the cemeteries in New Orleans, but this blows them out of the water. It's much larger and crypts are much more ornate. The place is huge. Not sure if there is a map - we had a tour guide. I think it would be good to go with a guide or find a map so you can visit some of the more interesting grave sites and learn stories about them. Eva Peron (Evita) is buried here, though her crypt is one of the least interesting ones, surprisingly.
The arquitecture is amazing. Is incredible, I love this place because it s full of histories. Some headstone are very touching dedications.

Absolutely amazing . The most beautiful and unusual cemetery I've ever seen. Our entire family went and we walked around for a couple of hours. It was amazing to see some of the most elaborate burial sights I have ever seen.Entire family's in one place and you can actually see the coffins inside.Sounds a little morbid but, beautiful. I will definitely visit here again.
Fascinating, surreal place. Unlike anything we've seen. Surprising and sometimes very sad to see the untended graves right next to beautiful granite mausoleums. Worth a visit for sure

Free to the Publis. We were lucky to have a guide to give us background of the families and mausoleums. She took us to see Eva Perro's family mausoleum. If you don't have a guide, you can purchase a map to do it on your own.

Stunning. This is a must see historical site in BA. Although essentially a cemetery, there are many famous people laid to rest. The mausoleums are absolutely breathtaking. They are from a time of great wealth in this fascinating city.

Who would have guessed a cemetary would be so fun to walk through?. This is a fun and interesting place to walk around. Take time to look at all of the graves. So many different kinds. Small and modest to grandiose. It would be fun to know the history behind many of them. There are some beautiful sculptures. We did not use a guide but I think it would probably be a good idea. You can spend as much time as you like in here. Eva Peron grave is where everyone heads to. We were no exception. It is fun to see but not the most interesting grave located in there. The area surrounding the cemetary is fun also so plan on spending a good amount of time in the area.

Worth seeing. It certainly is a unique attraction - the cemetery for the rich and famous. Its incredible how grand some of the mosoleums are. Make sure to look at the map on the left of the entrance to find Evita's grave - marked 88, otherwise its impossible to find!
Very Interesting. Walking around the cemetery was something new for me.The tombs and stories gave me a chill but it is indeed a tourist site, so many people were visiting to see Evita Peron's.

The most unimpressive grave for the most impressive person. The graveyard is a one of a kind. You have never seen anything like it. And yes I have been to Viennas central graveyard and the Stockholm forrest graveyard and many others. Here you find modest graves beside the bombastic statues in a unique architecture and style.Of course the most visited and well known grave is the one of Eva Perron (Evita). Her grave is quite unimpressive, which is impressive in itself.

Well worth a couple of hours . A leisurely stroll (best with guide) is a great way to learn more about Argentine history and society. A veritable who's who of history, including Eva Peron, one of its most famous residents. The sculptures alone are worth seeing, very very interesting!

Definitely worth a visit. It's not easy to review a cemetery but u would recommend this for its well documented historical significance and the social impact comparing the sites for the wealthy and not so wealthy locals.

An oasis of calm in a bustling city. We visited the cemetery more than once. First time as part of a free English speaking tour that was excellent and explained the history of the site and the tombs. Then we returned to wander and reflect on what we had learned. Take a tour or you will walk past too many interesting facts. Nothing dark and depressing here, beautiful architecture to admire, and historically interesting. A sun trap surrounded now by a shopping mall, restaurants, offices and homes. If staying in the city it will become a landmark as you find your bearings.

Oh, if those bodies could talk!. Very interesting walk thru the cemetery. Nothing else compares. I've been here twice. Once with a very informative guide where we stayed two hours. Too long. The last time, we were without guide and it lacked the needed structure. I'd love to find a one hour tour ( not a large group) that would hit the highlights. Worth the money to hire a private guide since the cemetery is free.

Walk around.... At first we said that we wan't go there but after we passed out of the cemetery and we said ok let's walk around to see it... We liked it very much, it was something different! Unfortunately i could say that you should go have a walk and see all this perfect creations!!!

Hauntingly beautiful history. Intricate details adorn each individual grave. The stark contrast between some of the decaying graves and the beautifully kept monuments show the economic disparity in Argentina. Free entry makes this a must-see, but the limited real estate makes this about a two-hour visit at most.

A celebration of deathly decadence . Well worth a visit if in BA. Entry is free to access the opulence of the city elite once they and their family have passed away. Some of the structures sit in disrepair next to well kept palatial graves in what is a humbling but a little morbid experience.
So Interesting and eerily beautiful. Must see when heading to BA. Amazing mausoleums and so many interesting back stories. See Eva's final resting place and so many more.

Beautiful and must see. I am from the US and this is unlike anything you can see there. The cemetery is so beautiful and historical, peaceful, and in a good area of town. You must save a few hours to walk through - it is free to enter. They offer tours in Spanish and English (not sure of cost) and there is also a great market right outside the cemetery, along with places to eat and hide from the rain if necessary.

Good experience. If you're ever going to visit this place please use a tour guide. The tour guide will provide all the insights and stories to some of the more popular tombs they will take you. It's quite an unreal experience!
A must see. I think this is in fact a must see in Buenos Aires. Fantastic! It is the appropriate place for a guided tour and for pictures.

Very creepy, but also pretty cool. We went to see Evita, but she was not that impressive. Some of the others were, though. Way impressive. When you look at some, you have to remember that someone in the family has to keep these crypts in good repair. That's quite a commitment, and it's why some are in disrepair. Stay for the closing bell. It's part of the atmosphere.
Great place to see!. Very interesting place to go to. Its one of the most beautiful cemeteries in the world and definitely worth at least one visit.

Fascinating!. Fascinating and extremely interesting but will not be to everyone's taste. Definitely for those who are interested in architecture and history. If in two minds, I would suggest visiting on a bright sunny day. I for one wouldn't have wanted to be walking around on a dark, miserable day!

Interesting. Interestng to see the many impressive graves. A must see when there. Ofcourse you should see the grave of Evita Duarte ( perron ) although it is quite difficult to find in one of the narrow side 'streets' ...
Amazing. A must see.. Recoleta Cemetery was one of the highlights of my time in Buenos Aires. It's free and fascinating - what's not to like? A true symbol of the past wealth of the city.

So many angels, so many lives and stories. I have been several times at this cemetery and you never get enough. Besides the mausoleums (some of them abandoned decades ago), the magnificent art is there trying to pay tribute to life and death.The stories are fascinating... Stories of love, stories of betrayal, mother and daughter, a young bride and her dog... Presidents, teachers, political leaders... Try, if you are not familiar with the cemetery or if you don't speak Spanish, to get a guided tour.After the visit to this cemetery, go for a cappuccino in one of the many appealing coffee shops nearby.

Mind-boggling display of wealth and staus. Recoleta strikes you as not so much a cemetery as a city-in-miniature unto itself with narrow streets and boulevards whose sides are crammed with an endless number of magnificently grand tombs and mausoleums crowded in and touching side-by-side in every style you can imagine.Of special note is the out-of-the-way, surprisingly unassuming tomb of Eva Peron, and the lonely-looking, life-size statue of the Argentine boxing sensation of the 1930's, world-heavyweight contender Luis Firpo. Allow yourself at least an hour, if not two, and make sure to get a map at the entrance.

Cementerio de la Recoleta (La Recoleta Cemetery). It is the most important and also beauty cemetery in Argentina . It is located in the Recoleta neighborhood of Buenos Aires, It contains the graves of notable people, including Presidents , Nobel Prize winners, artists and other people.The cemetery was created in the beginning of the nineteen century as the first public cemetery.There are a lot of architectural and historical graves that generates an special climate by walking along internal paths.For those who love architect designs I believe that this place is worth of a walk

The history of Argentina´s High Class condensed in one place. If you are interested in knowing who and whom where members of the high class family´s in Argentina this is were you will get all the information. Some people say that european societty have the noble titles to show and instead Argentine societty have the big monuments and mausoleums to show at the Recoleta Cementery. It is considered after Paris Per Lachaise one of most important cementery´s in the world. Of course you have to be interested either in Argentinean history or burial monuments.There are a few tours that you can take to visit. Quite interesting

A "must" when in Buenos Aires. Definitely worth the visit. One of the three most important in the world. Interesting from the historical and artistic view. Amazing to walk down the little streets surrounded by peace, transported to another time, to another world and yet in the middle of this pulsating city.

Nice . It's small and pretty, I loved the vibe but if you are looking for cemetery's there are way bigger ones in Buenos Aires. Good thing about Recoleta is that the Latin American art museum is really close and gorgeous ( 2 floors only) and free entrance, and you will find Floralis Generica (the gigantic flower) at a aveniu right behind it.

Wow. Unbelievably beautiful final resting place . The architecture of many of the mausoleums are world class. The bought that went into the dedicated memorials , sculptures , etc is eerily gorgeous. And it's free
The most interesting place in BA. One of the most interesting places in Buenos Aires. You will never see anything else like this in your life. This is a must see if you are in the city.

MUST See. This Cemetery is a MUST See in Buenos Aires. Amazing! I've never seen anything like it! And a little "tip" - right across from the entrance to the Cemetery - right on the corner facing the Cemetery is an ice cream place "to die" for! (ha!)

Was surprised. At how big this place was. Like others have said, it's like a small city with long, very narrow roads with gorgeously elaborate mausoleums and crypts on either side. Many are well maintained but it's sad to see the broken glass on some of them and all the litter inside many. There are also some crypts that look forgotten and abandoned, perhaps due to no more family being around or able to care for them. We stumbled upon Eva Peron's resting place - in the Duarte mausoleum. Lots of flowers on that one. Well worth the visit.
Impressive, a lust in Buenos Aires. This cemetery is pretty unique if we consider to visit Buenos Aires. It is a perfect way to discover who is who in BA. It is also close to a very beautiful church.
Very special experience. its a different feeling, and a very special atmosphere you feel when walking around all these temples/tombs. Its different from any other cemetery Ive ever seen.

Fascinating!. Recoleta Cemetery is a "city" within itself. The details of the architecture was incredible. The ever famous "Evita Peron" mausoleum was elegant and I found it to be, in comparison with others, rather simple. Just strolling through the cemetery was peaceful and enjoyable. There are a number of shaded benches under majestic trees to just sit back and enjoy the splendor.

Beautiful and humbling cemetery in the centre of BA. It seemed a little odd to us that Recoleta Cemetery was such a highly rated attraction but once there it's easy to see why. The endless rows of mausoleums and crypts are not a little creepy, but at the same time the dedication that has gone into remembering the city's dead is very humbling. When we were there it was pretty empty and we spent a long time quietly walking the avenues and getting caught in the stories and lives that have found rest here. There is an intense respect for the dead palpable throughout the cemetery and many of the carvings are done with great skill. One of the 'attractions' in the cemetery is Eva Peron's mausoleum, which is hidden on a small avenue near the back - look for the words 'Familia Duarte' and the flowers placed in the grill if you want to find this. A must see if you're in Buenos Aires and expect to spend a long time here. Go early in the morning if you can to avoid the crowds as being there feels like quite a personal journey.

Like a small city. This was an experience. I have never seen a cemetery with all the vaults above ground before. It is like a small city with main avenues, side streets and narrower alley ways all lined with beautiful mauseoleums. All are beautifully kept from the smaller ones to the most elaborate. We found Eva Perons resting place -it is lovingly maintained. The view from outside the cemetery is also incredible-the high walls with the tops of the vaults peaking over it. I would definitely recommend a visit. We didn't pay, we expected to but no one seemed interested in taking money so am unsure if we were meant to
Great place to visit!. Beautiful cemetery! It was a great experience and its worth going more than once. I can highly recommend it!
Do not miss this!. A unique experience. One has to see to believe the scale of the crypts, some three stories high, many with massive statuary. It's a city of the dead.
A must for every visitor. A collection of hundreds of mauseoleums for around 200 years, must see! Look on the map at the entrance to find that of Evita.
Worth a visit. Went to see the tomb of Eva (Evita) Peron. Cemetery is worth a visit and walk around to see the incredible tombs. from very simple to exceptionally elaborate

CITY FOR PAST SOULS. DO IT............ Totally fascinating. Give yourself a full day to explore if you enjoy history, sculpture, angels and even architecture. It really is a city.Some vaults humorously have gorgeous stained glass windows and are best viewed from within. I will go back

Powerful Architecture in Remembrance of the Loved. Plan on spending four hours here. Mornings best for the light. Everything you have heard does not describe this treasure. Photo opportunities at every turn. This is the resting place of Evita Perone and many other famous doctors painters artists etc.. THe architecture and sculpture here is not replicated anywhere in the world and is the number one reason to visit BA Do not pass on it!

Unique Experience. The rows of mausoleums arranged in blocks were reminiscent of a small city. Some are elaborate, some very simple. Some maintained, some all but abandoned. But fascinating to see. The Duarte mausoleum of Eva Peron's family is distinguished only by the fresh flowers left by visitors. Quite modest, and surprisingly accessible compared to grave sites of past presidents in the US. Worth a visit.

Very Interesting Place to Visit. I always like to visit historic cemeteries, but this one is really incredible because of the structures and the method of burial. On many of the mausoleums, you can look through and see the caskets inside. Also, Eva Peron is buried in this cemetery and the history of her getting there was interesting as she was buried in other countries before returning to Argentina. Sounds a bit morbid I guess to have a tour of a cemetery I guess, but I think you will consider it a worthwhile side trip.
Visit a CEMETERY!? Crazy but Fascinating and Beautiful. This place is like an exposition of the best of architecture and classical sculpture but all within a few square blocks. It's awesome and free!

Beautiful historic cemetery. We happened to run into Simon at the gate. He's a Brit who has lived in BA many years and gives guided tours through the cemetery in English. We learned so much about the history, legends, myths, notable family tombs, and of course saw the Duarte family tomb where Eva Peron is buried. Fascinating. Simon gives a good tour and its pay what you think it's worth.
A highlight of my trip. This is absolutely a must see attraction. All the mausoleums are incredible. I've never seen anything like it before.

Amazing outdoor Museum of statues. This is a very interesting place to visit. We went on the Free walking tour and our guide spent extra time explain some of the stories with the plots. A combination of beautiful statues and an somewhat awkward intimate look at many family plots. Don't go to the tourist restaurants across the street from the cemetery.
Well Worth a Stroll Around. You can easily spend a hour plus here just strolling around - free entry and plenty of history and great photo opportunities.

Most grandiose cemetery - you can get lost here for a while. Fascinating place, I ended up getting lost here taking around 200 photos. Even as a non-religious person, this was a site to see. Did it without a guide, and it was still good. I like getting lost on my own anyway...
Eva Peron's place of resting. My main idea to visit the Recolteta Cemetery was to see the tomb of Eva Peron. I found it quite difficult to find the tomb and did not spend anymore time looking around.

Bizarre and different though worth a look. Well worth a look. A bit bizarre. The opulence of some of the mausoleums is amazing. The free walking tour well worth the time. Some great historical information.

Excellent history and amazing to see. We went with the free english speaking guide on Tuesday morning at 11am. They provide a free 1 hour tour in english each Tuesday and Thursday morning. No fee to enter either although that is possibly going to change soon. It is an amazing facility and all the grave sites seem to have a lot of history. Eva Peron is the main attraction of course but there is a lot more to see than that alone.

Guide is a Must here, then it's an Awesome experience!. Very enjoyable with a guide. As an example, my guide started coming here in grammar school and still finds different stories to discuss or discover. We walked through in an hour, saw the more popular structures, could have spent the day easy.Lots of artwork here .

Surreal. Amazing place - a bit strange for those used to seeing coffins put into the ground! An incredible variety of tombs each containing visible coffins, some with built in areas for contemplation. I gather it is very expensive and if you stop paying maintenance your vault is sold on, but on the condition that your coffins are moved to a lower level (I think 3 levels below ground). Certainly worth a visit it has a tangible air of peace and tranquility in what is a very busy area.

I could spend a whole day here, fascinating!. It is free, just know that there are "guides" waiting at the entrance that are very friendly of course. And hand you a map guide, tell you where everything is and plan out an easy route for you to take depending on what you want to see- then hand you the book and ask for a donation. I gave him I think the equivalent of maybe $5 USD, I can't remember what that is in pesos but anyway, just an FYI in case you have anyone come up to you and start handing you maps and asking you lots of questions. Over all, I think that's a fair deal- not sure if they were actual staff of the cemetery or not, but just be aware. The cemetery itself is absolutely beautiful, I could have spent literally all day looking at the beautiful monuments, picking out ones I wish I could have when I pass! You can't see any bodies of course, just the coffins inside some- but reading every plaque was addicting, it was just so beautiful. I didn't take many pictures unfortunately because my friend who was with me felt it was very inappropriate in a cemetery as his culture frowns upon taking pictures inside cemeteries and I didn't want to seem "rude" in front of him. Either way, it's definitely a place to go if you love beautiful architectural tombstones/monuments.

Blimey. A couple of ladies I met recommended this place to me saying it is the most amazing cemetery they've ever been to, and they weren't wrong.I spent around an hour walking around Recoleta Cemetery and I could have easily spent two if I went down every walkway. It's more like a small village, the tombs are beautifully built. And just when you think you've seen the most extravagant one, you turn a corner and there's one even more grand. It's really quite fascinating.
Historical. Lovely nostalgic cemetary with lots of memories and famous persons from Argentina. Maybe even bump into celebrities there.

Unique!!!. If you know the Argentinian history, you can see here the tombs of many interesting people. Politicians, artists, authors, generals and so many other are buried here. For me, the only well-known person was Evita Peron. Her monument is not easy to be found without guide, is simpler than other monuments but full of flowers. In this place you can see wonderful statues and sculptures of humans and angels. It seems like an open museum, not a cemetery.

Amazing Cemetary - a must for all. A cemetery for rich and famous, incredible mausoleums, sculptures, most well cared for, a few abandoned when the family died out and there is nobody to care for the "plot". Eva Peron is buried there with a plague rubbed to shine & fresh flowers to honour her memory.

Eva Peron's tomb. I'm not big on visiting cemeteries but this is an exception. The cemetery itself has a very interesting history. Then if you go through the cemetery with a guide you will get a history lesson from the tombs. The highlight is Eva Peron's tomb.
A must see !. I was mitigated about visiting a cemetery but this is something else, this art, culture and architure in honor of the passed loved ones. It is something else .
