Gates of heaven. You might think it macabre to put a cemetery on your travel agenda, but really, you have to see this one. Splendid architecture, medal work and stone. A tribute to the dead..and a walk through the past

Definitely worth a visit. I was surprised at how much I enjoyed visiting Recoleta Cemetery. We returned the next day and had another walk around. It was so interesting and not at all grim or sad. It was a very peaceful and beautiful place. Never seen anything like it before and also found it to be very interesting.

This was a very interesting cemetery to visit.. This was very interesting almost park like. Be sure to allow plenty of time, It's almost a park. Near by are outdoor restaurants, a great wine shop, market. Theres a lovely park about two blocks away. The week end we were there a market was set up with leather and other handy crafts.

amazinh. one of a kind cemetery. it boasts of sculpture and architecture and affluence of the old BAs.
we went here to see the tomb of the famous evita. it is unpretentious probably purposive.
nothing like it in the whole world. a must visit when you go to BAs.

What a place!. This is unlike any place I've ever visited. We stopped by during a bike tour of Buenos Aires and wandered round for 15 minutes. The place is evidently hugely elaborate and a sure sign of wealth within the capital. On a bright day the colours within the buildings, and I mean buildings in a cemetery, shine through. It's certainly worth a visit if only to ponder what on earth it all represents. A photographers dream!

Nice place to understand Argentina culture. Recoleta Cementery is one of those places where you find some answers to those myths ans legends; go, observe and tske a selfie at Evita's grave so you understand the relevance that she had for unions and working class in Argentina; all will make sense after that!

Beautiful place... if it being a cemetery doesn't put you off. Death is part of life and like there is beauty in life, so is there in death. And Recoleta is one of the places where you will find it. Fron opulent family tombs to neglected catacombs... Definitely worth a visit.

You Don't Want To Miss It. Wow!! What an amazing place to visit. We wondered through the rows and rows of crypts for hours. Each crypt was unique, some of the structures were amazing works of art, while others were crumbling with broken windows and rusted ironwork. Each one could captivate you, though to look at each one would have taken days. There really are that many crypts in the cemetery! We took a 45 minute English tour offered by a women who was standing near the cemetery entrance for $7.00. It was well worth it to hear the history and for her to show us Eva Peron's family crypt. There is an official English tour offered at 11:00 am each day, but we could never get there that early.

Grim and smelly. ok, so I'm not into cemeteries, granted. But this one is especially grim, smelly (so many feral scary-looking cats!) and sad altogether. I lasted 10 min. Tour groups are obnoxious and everywhere.

Somehow touristic but still worth it. Rows and rows of graves of notable people. They have a map at the entrance but if you want one you have to pay. We just took the chance and wandered around and found Evita Peron's grave. People went extra mile to have their graves built like mini mansions. Fun to walk around but easily got lost. I would not go there at night.

Beautiful Site . I loved this small piece of history. A must see when in Buenos Aires. Eva Peron is indeed buried here. She's buried under her family's name. A great part of history if you're not afraid of being in a graveyard.

Interesting to wander around. Interesting and curious. Worth a visit for sure. More than just evita's tomb, some families go to great lengths to send their loved ones off in style. A bit macabre but a new experience. It was good to see Admiral William Brown's grave as I'm Irish and he was a huge part of Argentina's history.

A Must See in Buenos Aires. No one should go to Buenos Aires without visiting the unusual and interesting Recoleta Cemetery, if for no other reason than to visit the grave of Evita. It's a most amazing place, fun for getting lost around the huge memorials to families, and a very special place.

How Many Statues. Try and find the graves you want to visit before you wander aimlessly through the rows. There are beautiful mausoleums and nice shady spots to sit and contemplate. You get a good view from above if you go to the church next door and enjoy the exhibition.
so interesting. Fabulous! It seems strange to wander a cemetery but we honestly spent hours looking around at all the lovely features. It is definitely worth a trip.

Hauntingly beautiful. Recolletta Cemetery was an insult experience with finely carved marble and bronze masoleums standing as dignified sentries on guard over the dead. Eva Peron's masoleum is visited often but the history of others is also appreciated

Amazing day at this cemetery. I think to pay for a tour guide is the best option. We wandered around aimlessly looking for Eva Peróns grave. There are a lot of people there to help if you get lost or are looking for certain crypts. Lots of stray cats though which was a bit creepy. No maps at the info desk though which was disappointing.

Great experience . It was amazing to see what people do for their beloved family that died. They honor them. From giant to big to simple and small, from new to old. And sometimes you here knocking sounds from beneath... (Only the workers that are restoring or keeping them in de good condition).
Interesting place to visit. I enjoyed visiting the cemetery, Eva Duarte De Peron (aka Evita) is buried in here. Very artistic mausoleum examples with different styles.
Beautiful tombstones. Just a place to walk through to admire the architecture of the elaborate tombs. Of course, must see: Eva's Peron Tomb.

Free English tour. Excellent. Obviously a tip should be given. We went on the Thursday 11.00 am starting just inside the gate. Guide had over 50 people join so was a bit crowded but kept me entertained with excellent information and detail. I loved this trip and recommend it highly

Definitely worth a visit. Interesting, amazing and shocking!!! We really enjoyed our walk through the ceremetry, reading the interesting stories of people's lives and marvelling at the architecture.
Can't believe they did all that for their loved ones - the opulence is truly shocking and out of our cultural norm.
Like being in Paris. Grand cemetery with huge family mausoleums. You can visit the tumb of Evita Peron. Well kept and worth a guided visit.

Very Interesting place to Visit in BA. Great to wander the many alleyways between mausoleums. Eve Peron is buried here in a very common grave. Watch for the many, many stray cats that inhabit this interesting place full of history.
The photos say it all, stunning . I could spend days here studying the architecture, condition and details of each tomb. A must visit.

Amazing cemetery. A must see. Went to this amazing place as part of a city tour I was on. This place is amazing and the grave sites are unbelievable. Never seen anything like this before, and even got to see Eva Peron's grave. Definitely a resting place for the rich, although I'm told the soldiers who died for independence were paid for by the government to rest beside the rich. Definitely a must see.
Incredible walk. beautiful walk through the cemetery and went to Evita Perron's grave. A must see!! Some amazing Tombs!!

A must-see in Buenos Aires!. If you are traveling to Buenos Aires, you must make time to explore Recoleta Cemetery! A very impressive place to wander for hours on end. The mausoleums are incredible and feature a wide variety of architectural details. You can certainly walk through the cemetery on your own, but you are likely to get much more out of it if you take a guided tour, like we did. Our tour guide was able to tell us fascinating historic stories and point out details that we likely would have overlooked on our own.
Amazing. Carved marble works in the cemetery of La Recoleta are spectacular. They have nothing to envy to those made by large and classic artists like Michelangelo
Highlight!. We spent over an hour wandering the streets here. Derelict and luxurious mausoleums, cats wandering. Great place! Elvira is hard to find.

Fascinating cemetery. Be sure and time your visit with an English language tour. I was there on a Tuesday in March 2016 and the English tour was at 11:00. Entrance to the cemetery and the tour were free, but there was talk of instituting a fee to help with maintenance of common areas.

Can you find Eva. What a special place and not in a creepy way. One of the most unique Cemetery's you will ever seen. The history is very rich and so many faith's are represented. The cemetery is active to this day. A funeral had just concluded when we arrived. The tombs are above ground so it is interesting to wonder through the area. Yes Eva Peron is now at rest in the Cemetery after being hidden and moved many times by her captures.

Forced to buy a map. Most of us visit the cemetery as Evita is buried here. Her crypt is not easy to find even with a map of the grounds. Also since a fee is charged for the map, you would think that there would be better maintenance of the grounds.

Recoleta Cemetery. We really enjoyed this place. So much of Argentinian history is here. Socialists next to capitalists. Italians next to French. Rich next to poor. We had a guide which made a HUGE difference. There is so much to take in and you would miss MANY things without one.

More than Evita. We visited this as part of a city tour. It is similar to cemeteries in Louisiana, only MORE. We got a bit of history of some of the famous occupants. Later we heard from someone else more information that would have been better.
Must see!!. The graves are bigger than some houses!! Defiantly a must see. Didn't do a guided tour so not sure the history of the cemetery.

Argentina's history in one place. Graves are usually scary but Recoleta's cementery is a great example of architecture and decor, from the art-deco to gothic style, modern or french. If you have the chance the tour with a guide is recommended, to learn some of the most interesting parts of this country's history. Also some secrets like why a grave was built like this or that, traditional families stories and yes, some gossips from the past!

A Tour is a Must. This is our second trip to Buenos Aires and I enjoyed visiting Recoleta Cemetery the last time but felt our time was even better on the second visit. We were lucky enough to join a small walking tour of the cemetery and learned a lot about the history of the cemetery, the people buried there and the art located throughout. This is a must on any visit to the City!

An amazing collection of remembrance. Wow. Just wow. You can wander through this cemetery and look at the many ways people have been remembered by their loved ones. The memorials are truly amazing pieces of art. Don't forget your camera.

Burial Ground of Many Notables. This is a very impressive cemetery in the Recoleta neighbourhood of Buenos Aires that includes Eva Peron’s grave. A stroll among the mausoleums reveals many different architectural styles. The cemetery deserves a commitment of time and a guide to the notable interments.

A must. It is said that only Stagliero in Genoa and Pere Lachaise in Paris can equals to Recoleta.- There you can feel the fabulous richness of the Argentine of 1900 to 1930.- If you can get a good guide, you can learn about Argentine history than in the best book.-
Interesting!. This is not like any cemetery I have ever been in. Take your time and go up and down see the many beautiful building. Great place to take photos.

Not bucket list worthy but a required stop for any tourist or history buff. As far as cemeteries go this one is forgettable. Architecture isn't particularly memorable and the tomb of Eva Peron won't remind you of other great tombs (Napoleon, etc.). The park outside the cemetery is nice and good for an afternoon nap. Takes an effort to get to and isn't quite as awe inspiring as you'd hope for.

unbelieveablxe to see. We enjoyed a leisurely stroll through the cemetery. It was much larger and grandiose than i could have imagined. Very interesting to look around and quite unbelievable to see the individual family mausoleums. Sad to see some of the abandoned ones.

Interesting. We were staying around the corner from this cemetery full of the remains of people important in the history of Argentina. The most notable is Eva Peron (Evita), although her husband is not buried here. The family mausoleums are interesting. Worth a visit, and it appears to be a standard on the city tour.
beautiful. It was super cool. I could've strolled for hours if i was given the chance. Each tomb had its own story. i would definitely recommend a few hours to spend here

Beautiful Historic Cemetery. We only had an hour to visit the Recoleta Cemetery, but we could have spent the better part of the day exploring this treasure. This is the most awe inspiring cemetery I've visited. Beautiful mausoleums and plenty of history to entice your imagination.
A wonderful display of carved marble !. Very interesting and not to be missed when you visit Buenos Aires. The tombs both old and new take your breath away !

Unique!. It may seem like a morbid tour, but this place is so unique, unlike anywhere I have ever visited, it is a must in BA. You will feel in a real life Disney's haunted cemetery, with cats straight out of Stephen King`s Pet Sematary. Worth the visit for sure!!!

Unique place for people interested in art. It is a unique place...an art exposition under the sky in the middle of the Citi!...The history of the Country is also exposed in the Recoleta Cementery. When tired, just step out and take advantage of the great Cafee in the corner of Quintana and Junín...another piece of local history. I live in Bs.As. and enjoy this beautiful Citi!

Incredible . For people who love history this is a must visit .
Recoleta cemetery whilst somber provides a magnificent insight to a bygone history.
We were amazed as to the grandeur of the mausoleums and to visit Eva Peron tomb was a tour highlight

A piece of Argentina history. Recoleta cemetery looks like a labyrinth towards Argentina's past. Everytime you go there, you find something else you missed the last time. From Evita, to argentinian politicians, generals, actors, athletes and more, you will be able to live different aspects of Argentina's history. You will be amazed by some general's mausoleum, then turn around the corner and find some beloved actor's grave, then an heroic general from the independence war, and so on, everything in the same place, like a giant memorial of every person that marked the destiny of Argentina.

A must see for an hour or so...... We have never been to a place like this where hundreds of mausoleums are spread across the walled mini city. Some of the chapels are incredible but it is quite unnerving to see so many coffins. Eva Peron is resting here and to be honest, you would never find her as she is buried under what I assume is the family name of Duante. We got lucky as a large crowd had gathered and there she was. We went on a Saturday, not at all busy and a large market was setting up outside. Entry is free, we travelled via the subway, then walked it's wasn't that easy to find. Anyway definitely worth an hour or two.

One of a kind cemetery - must see if in Buenos Aires. We visited the cemetery and were amazed to see the number of large family mausoleums and statues. Rich people from early 20th century really spent a lot to be remembered. It is quite impressive. We like to visit cemeteries when we are in different cities. We visited some in New Orleans and Venezia (all above ground) that were special but this one is the densest and most unique so far. There is much more to see than just Evita Peron's family mausoleum. Definitely a must see.
Absolutely beautiful!. A must if you are in Buenos Aires - the statues and tombs were incredible. Free tours in English. Evita's tomb is there.

UPSCALE AND MADE MORE SO BY ETERNAL PRESENCE OF EVITA. We spent about an hour in the Recoleta Cemetery one of the highpoints of the Recoleta section of Buenos Aires. Evita, or Eva Peron is just one of the famous people buried here. Our guide explained to get into this cemetery as a "permanent" resident you need to spend $500,000 and up. Very interesting tombs are here!

incredible city of the dead. don't just head to the Duarte plot, meander through the site and marvel at the architecture and statues.We turned right as soon as we entered the cemetary (left for Evita). Down here there many tombs which were neglected, many you could see right in, and a couple where you could see the contents of the caskets. A lot of these tombs have staircases in them down to the lower floors. incredible.You can get lost for hours in here, and we did.

Spectacular . This is really something! Have never visited such a spectacular and beautiful cemetery. If you are in buenos Aires this is one of the things you don't wanna miss. We visited the cemetery on a Saturday and outside it was a nice handicraft market with loads of cool stuff!

Amazing mausoleums. Eva Peron (Evita) is interred here in her family chapel. It is very normal compared to the life that she led. It is under her family name, not Peron. It is worth a quiet look around, I know it sounds very morbid, but the beauty of some of the chapels is well worth a wander around.

Recoleta Cemetary. Incredible. Never seen anything like this. Think its the most visited place by tourists in Buenos Aires. Amazing stories of various mauseleoms. Dignified, clean and respectful. Everyone goes to visit Eva Peron (Duante), but there is more to this cemetary. Visit on Saturday if you can as there is a great market outside the Cemetary. Got some fab jewellery & food

Amazing attraction. We were fascinated by the cemetery and went twice during our stay. The monuments are in different states of repair -some are grand and large and some very plain. The big draw is the family grave of the Duarte family where Eva Peron rests and flowers are left on the doors. It's worth lingering and wandering beyond Eva's mausoleum to see other monuments.

Impressive, labyrinthine, must see and not just for Evita's mausoleum. A great place to spend one to two hours exploring the endless alleyways, avenues and mausoleums of this majestic, labyrithine cemetary. The cemetery is packed full of mausoleums ranging from the grand monumental tomb of General Alvear that greets you on entry, to the elegant graceful tomb of Eva Peron through to the almost derelict or slightly vandalised tombs of lesser or expired family lines.Fascinating place, looking into the tombs seeing coffins of the long or recently dead with religious symbology everywhere and every mausoleum is different, in style, in character, in dediciation.Tips for visiting the cemetary:1. Visit the cloisters for a small fee in the neighbouring chuch (Iglesia Nuestra Señora Del Pilar) for a unrivalled view across the mausoleum rooftops2. Take a printout of the map or consult/photograph the big map at the entrance before heading in3. Locate Eva Peron's tomb on a map and navigate there - finding it without one is difficult!4. Look for the stray cats looking for tidbits from tourists, especially the ever so adorable grey cross-eyed cat5. Look into the tombs where you can - they are all fascinating and different inside6. Don't forget to look up!
Nice attraction. We did get a guide at the entry way and it was worth the money. Mit wasn't expensive if it was it might not be. She filled us in on the basics of the cemetery and the history.

Must see attraction of Buenos Aires. This was my favorite of the various attractions we visited in Buenos Aires. The beauty of these mausoleums is just overwhelming. You can see that each family was showing its status by having the biggest and best. You can wander for hours and take beautiful pictures as the light changes or take a direct route to see Eva Peron's monument. Regardless, I think this is something any first time visitor to the city must experience.
Evita's grave and more. . Eva Peron is the star attraction, but it's worth a visit here and a walk around the entire map to see the elaborate mausoleums.

A must see in Buenos Aires. We had an interesting time visiting the cemetery - you are taken back to a very different Buenos Aires - one at the end of the last century when it was a prestigious and prosperous town with many distinguished citizens, buried here. We went on a week day and it was not crowded at all. It's in a nice area, so it is easy to walk to other interesting places in the Recoleta neighborhood.

Always a must if you visit Buenos Aires. I always pay a visit to this cemetery. There are guided tours, some free and others payed but so interesting that is worth the price. Eduardo Lazzari is very, very good.
Recoleta Cemetery, Buenos Aires. A very unique cemetery with so many mausoleums. Eva Peron ( Evita) is buried here along with many famous people.A must see Cemetery.

A must see!. It's giant and overwhelming and difficult to find specific tombs, but it's an amazing experience. The cemetery covers four city blocks and you can wander through here for hours. There's a map at the entrance, but try to print one out before you go if you want to find something specific.

Cemetery of Angels and Eva. Blocks and blocks if mausoleums both decorative and eerily abandoned. The bas relief and sculptures are engaging. Time flies by as you are engaged with the memorials, especially those of beauty and wonder.

A Must see!. Everyone that visits BA should see the Cemetery. We do not have anything like it in the states and it is too unique to miss. You can easily spend 3 hours just wandering through and reading all of the information.
Great Cemetery . This is an extraordinary cemetery from the times Argentina was one of the richest countries in the world. Certainly a place to visit

More like a sculpture museum than a cemetery. An outdoor maze of concrete grave sites. Some of the graves are practically ornate. Despite all this it is amazingly peaceful too. Its worth the time to get lost in the side alleys and just take in the beauty of it all. Or you can just go to Evita's memorial. I dont think a tour is that essential to appreciate the beauty of the place, but if you want information and knowledge about the themes and meanings of the sculptures than it would be recommended.

RECOLETA CEMETERY.. A DIFFERENT CEMETERY. This Cemetery is the oldest and poshest of cemeteries..if you are someone--if you carry a well known last name.. you have a vault there..There are 2 new ones in the suburbs because unless your family possess a vault is hard to get buried there..after a mass at the El Pilar church.. worth going for a stroll at and have alook at the small houses with in-built vaults...I LIVE IN BUENOS AIRES..so have been there many times..my family has a vault there

A hauntingly holy place. Recoleta Cemetery in Buenos Aires is an amazing place like no other cemetery I have visited. The closeness of the mausoleums and memorials offers a maze of artwork and thoughts to trace through.
A Different World. A fascinating example of Argentine history and culture. There are some truly wonderful sculptures throughout the cemetery.

Outdoor Art. In a way, it doesn't feel like a cemetery. There's no grass, just little marble/granite buildings with stain glass and sculptures. It's not creepy or depressing. It's artistic and beautiful. If you are looking for Eva Peron's location, there is a directory at the entrance with a map. She is listed under "Duarte" not Peron. We spent approximately 2 hours wandering around and it was well worth it. It's free and there are guides around if you want to retain one - we didn't use a guide and still enjoyed it. There are free tours if you can time it correctly.
Very impressive. This is one of the most amazing place in Buenos Aires. I have never seen so many mausoleums in my life, and some of them are bigger than a house.
Not to be missed. Certainly one of the top three (3) places to vist. Very interesting as it has evolved over many years.

Impressive mausoleums. Suffice to say cemeteries aren't usually in my to-do list when visiting places, but this one was filled with impressive and grandiose mausoleums, filled with the Argentinian elites of the past, generals and war heroes. Very interesting.

Fascinating. A "do not miss " when in BA. I recommend reading a bit of Argentine history before going to visit. The family names in this magnificent historical cemetary will help you understand the culture of Argentina.
a highlight. this is a really interesting place to walk around and watch people and drink in the history & culture of Buenos Aires.
amazing place. i would recommend taking a guided tour for some fascinating stories. It is just like a city of the dead.

A great cultural experience. You don't have to be a Christian to enjoy the Recoleta Cemetery. This amazing necropolis (city of the dead) is replete with fantastic religious art and with fascinating stories and legends. The cemetery is a primordial visit if you like history. I recommend you read a bit about it in order to understand some of the tombs and their locations. Otherwise hire a local guide throug tour hotel.

You Just Have to See It!!!!. I spent over an hour in this cemetery just walking around. There is no grass, it's all marble tile and concrete bricks that make up the walkways. If you'd like there are guides on hand you can pay to give you a guided tour. I passed on that, but they are there. I do enjoy cemeteries and this one, well, you just need to go visit it. It's FREE, there is a bathroom at the entrance. Please know, it's a big cemetery!!!
Amazing!. At first we were thinking "a cemetery", but once we got there, we realized this was no ordinary cemetery. Defiantly a must if in Buenos Aires!
Interesting place to see. This famous cemetery is where "Evita" rests. It is a unique experience and something that you will enjoy visiting for this reason.

Very interesting indeed ! . Never thought it would be as interesting as it is..... It's just amazing how they have the whole families in those "mausoleum" in crates or little boxes... all together ... Take a pick inside some of them... It's worth going !!!

Unexpected Enjoyment. I know this is considered one of "the places" to visit in BA, so i was reluctant to visit it thinking it was tourist trap. Yes, it is a true tourist destination but as others have mentioned the sculptures are amazing, the history interesting, and coming from the States openness of graves unique. We visited later in the day and the crowds seemed small, but we were there in an off season. There are some nice angles for photographs as well.
Fascinatingly creepy. Check this out if you are in BA - we spent about an hour here perving at the caskets and tombs. A bit weird but super interesting

highlight of my trip. I have never been to any cemetery as beautiful as this. Even though it is quite crowded with tourists, it is still pleasant to walk about. I enjoyed reading the inscription on the grave and story behind some of the famous mausoleums!

Coolest cemetery. Ever. . This places makes you feel like you are in a video game. The amount of beauty and tranquility might take you off guard, until you realize that this is a cemetery and the resting place of some of Argentina's finest. Careful though, you might walk around and get lost, never to come out again haha

Fascinating look into Argentina's history. This is a must-see when in Buenos Aires. There are so many stories here and they are told in a simple way. The tomb of Eva Peron is here, too. It is significant that it is a family tomb and is not signposted in any way to draw attention to itself.

Interesting stonework. Eva Peron Grave. Working Kitties. This cemetery was interesting for the sculpture and funeral art. There are a number of historic figures buried here - Evita Peron being one of the more modern persons of note. Beware that she is in the Duarte family plot - not Peron. If you're a cat person, you'll enjoy seeing a number of feral kitties that are "kept" to control rodents. This cemetery is worth a visit but isn't as nice or nicely kept as New Maiden and some others with the ornate gravesites.
Super awesome!. Very beautiful. Could walk around all day. Cool to see the different family names. Some modern dates, and some really old. Cats wondering around.

UNBELIEVABLE!!!!. This place blew me away!!! I did hire a tour guide to lead me through.... there are so many Argentinian stories that this mausoleum tells!!! I thought the cemetery in Old San Juan was cool but this blows it out of the water.... a must see for anyone visiting Argentina or Latin America
Just one time. I went there with my mom in 2013.It's a place to go just one time.We knew Evita's mausoleum,so small if you compare to the others.If you are curious or gotic,you should go there.
Awesome. Do you like art?This cemetery is full of sculptures and famous people mausoleums.It is a must visit in Buenos Aires.Be kind with the cats! There's a lot all over the place.
Part of the BA Bikes tour. Very interesting place. A must see if in Buenos Aries. If done on a local tour like BA bikes, the guides tell stories of various important and historical people.
Quite an ending. It's a must visit if you are in BA but you don't have to spend hours to get the over-the-top burial sites of many famous people.

a must-see!. Try and make the English-speaking tour on a Tuesday or Thursday at 11am, it's really worth it. Lots of History in this place, but also simple, beautiful stories of love and loss. One of the highlights of my trip to BA.
Good place to start . If you want to get deep into Argetinean History here it is a good start. A rich and strong history made by immigrants from all over the world starts here....

A must visit when you are in Buenos Aires. You really have to stop at this cemetery. Not only to visit Evita but just to walk around and take a look. Some graves are really very beautiful!Nice and quiet place.

Recoleta. Recoleta Cemetery is a must if you visit Buenos Aires. Besides the burial vault of Eva Peron, the cemetery is filled with ornate sculptures and consists of names of famous people in high positions.The cemetery is well laid out and there is a directory of names as you enter. You could easily spend over an hour just going up and down each row.

fascinating.. Never thought I would enjoy walking around a cemetery so much. Not only is the stories interesting but the architecture on all the cripts is fabulous. Worth taking the time and going into church as well.
Must visit. City of old souls. Lovely quiet place to visit. Look for the Dr who crying Angels. Ask where to find Evita grave
most impressive cemetary. I'm very glad I visited the cemetary, although it was in the pouring rain. Amazing thombs, beautiful !
Interesting. Interesting but also a very bizzare place. Home to Evita's tomb. it's an easy 30 mins to around the cemetary
Worth the visit. How can you not go to Buenos Aries and not visit this cemetery ....walk around and then visit the one of the famous names of the past century ......

Suggestive place!. A real suggestive place to visit, full of history and I would say having an alternative view of the city of buenos! Compliments to the administration cause they did not transform the Cimitery in an circus! Everything is authenting and its really quiet and nice!

Very impressive . We were surprised to see such a place full of so much art and design. We planning to only spend an hour there, but ended up spending almost 2 hours there. Spend the money at the entrance and get a map, so u can efficiently use your time. The only thing is that is not close to any subway station , so we just took a taxi there

Interesting and beautiful for a short visit. Free entry. Interesting and beautiful cemetery. It's very big so easy to get lost. We personally didn't need much time there to appreciate it, but definitely worth a visit.
Granjour of Argentina reflected in this cemetery. This is a must see when in BA. Takes half a day to do it fast and one could spend many days there. Buy the map at the front entrance, under $3 US

What's the Attraction?. Of course we all have different ideas on what appeals but I fail to see the attraction of this Cemetery. Yes it is different but as a "must see" place in B.A. it is certainly not on my list. Having said that I'm glad I went so at least I can comment on actually having been there, rather on reputation. There is so much more to Recoleta, one of the nicest parts of the city, than this place, that's for sure.

surprised. my group had a tour here and didn't understand why reviews for this place was good. After seeing it, it is very interesting. Not only with what you see but also definitely either take a guided tour or really read up to get the background story. You might not enjoy it as much if you just walked in and not know anything about the stories.
Spookily fascinating . The cemetery is a good (free) trip. One of the first things we did in BA. Quite spooky and very interesting to walk around looking at the varied architectural styles.

An unusual attracion. Cemeteries are not usually on the tourist trail but part of the attraction of this one is that it includes the mausoleum of Eva Peron, who is still adored by many in Argentina. This apart the number and variety of mausoleums is amazing with contrasting styles evidencing the wealth of the family involved. Some have glass doors and windows, other s statues and ornate metalwork. You can wander for a long time.

Interesting but creepy. I must admit it felt a bit wrong to treat a final resting place as a tourist attraction but to be fair, its an amazing place. Everyone seems to make a bee line to Evita's family tomb but I would recommend just wandering the narrow passages and wider avenues. There is a map at the entrance to help you find your bearings but it was of little help once you enter the maze of tombs. There are 2 free guided tours in English per week or you can hire a private guide who needs to be registered with the tourist board, but we enjoyed the visit with just the aid of a general guide book. There is only one entrance open and it closes at 5.30. I understand they ring a bell to warn you of closing time. I really wouldn't like to get locked in! I would allow at least an hour to wander and bring a drink... it can be thirsty walking around in the heat.

Much more than we expected it to be!. I guess I only skimmed the reviews on Tripadvisor before visiting the cemetery, which is perhaps why I was quite overwhelmed by how large the place is.It's a really interesting place to explore. My husband and I were really intrigued by the crypts and mausoleums, some of which are wonderfully decadent and elaborate. We discovered a lot about important people in Argentina and Buenos Aires. Definitely recommended.

touristic cemetery. Recoleta is one of the most visited neighbourhoods in Buenos Aires because of the architecture and restaurants. And so for this cemetery. It is located in a beautiful area, surrounded by a park (where there is always a fair) and important museums. The place is well preserved and you can find the graves of many familiar names in Argentina.

Quite amazing but a little creepy. Most people come here for one reason , to see Evitas Tomb.It is a really interesting place for sure , some of the tombs are really old and must have cost a fortune even in the days they wre made . Evitas Tomb is easy to find , just follow the tour groups,. It is still decked with fresh flowers every day by her loving fans .Many of the tombs have glass doors and you can see the ancient coffins inside crumbling away (Thats the creepy bit) stacked one above the other on shelves . Presumably there are no family members left for upkeep .Most of the tombs are architectural masterpieces and you will notice many of them belong to doctors and education people .It is really a "Must Visit "site in BA.

Very interesting place, could spend hours here.. Such an interesting cemetary. You could literally spend hours looking at the different statues, beautiful doors, interesting designs. I really enjoyed walking through here.

Another great attraction in Buenos Aires. This cemetery is something that you have to see, pictures do not show how massive it is and how elaborate the crypts are. One of the major sites there is the Duarte family crypt where Eva Perone is buried. I would recommend checking out the map at the entrance so you know where to go or go with a guide. Definitely glad I went.

Unusual Cemetary. During our Celebrity cruise, we took excursion to see Buenos Aries. This cemetery was very unusual in that the individual families own the structure and each family member is buried in that family plot. I have not seen the one in New Orleans, so this was our first visit to see this unusual cemetery. The guide was very knowledgeable . We saw the one for Eva Peron's resting place. Other unusual designs and statues were very interesting. Must see this place

If You're Intrigued By Cemetaries, This One Shouldn't Be Missed.. Recoleta Cemetery is well worth the visit. Explore the maze of mausoleums and see Eva Peron's final resting place. It's a great way to spend a morning or afternoon in Buenos Aires.

Beautifully Maintained Cemetery with Lots of History. My group spent time here walking the aisles and looking at the art of the crypts. Of course, Eva Perron's family crypt got most of the attention, but the entire cemetery was very interesting.

It was interesting . Went there a bit skeptic , but it was interesting actually.It takes 30 min and the best thing is you can have a walk to a huge beautiful park near by. Lovely neighborhood of Ricoleta indeed.

Go with a guide. This famous cemetery is quite large and you can easily get lost inside so go with a guide so they can tell you all the interesting stories behind some of the tombs. The most famous person buried there is Evita Peron so it will get quite crowded in that area. We went here as part of our walking tour and although we found it interesting it has become more of a tourist attraction than a place of mourning.

So worth visiting. I really loved this cemetery. There are some really amazing and unique headstones to see. Plus Eva Peron is buried there and some other pretty famous locals. If you like to take photos this is a must see in Buenos Aires

VERY UNIQUE. This is unlike any cemetery we have visited (and we have visited a lot in our travels). It is made up of many attempts to outdo the next guy as far as statues and money spent. Worth a visit.

Walking tour. You really do need to be taken around the cemetery which is a bit of a maze if you don't know where you are going. We had a lovely lady guide who spoke good English but unfortunately there were actually too many people on the tour which made it a bit unwieldy. She did show us many interesting burial tombs and had lots of facts and figures at her finger tips - good sense of humour too. Glad we took the tour!
Very nice. Really nice cemetery with just huge and rich mausoleums, great to wander around. Only thing I didn't like were groups of tourists with guides, sanctity of the hole place is ruined.

Breathtaking. This is a historic site, With breathtaking architecture and extravagant sculptures it is as beautiful as it is historic. Some of Argentina's most affluent families and famous luminaries lie here including of course, Evita. A guide, (free) is highly recommended as they can be very informative and specific graves (like Evita's) are not easily found. Surrounding restaurants are a step away nearby to finish up a great afternoon.
Different. We had a private tour guide to explain the history and to walk us through this hugh cemetery. Without our guide we would of never have fund Evita's resting place.

Great for pics!. There's a whole variety of architectural styles there to see. Some creepy, crumbling tombs amongst the highly decorative ones. Go on the weekend and enjoy the artesanias just outsode the cemetary on the park.

A slice of history. Our Argentinian host booked us all on a special tour of "Famous women" with historian Eduardo Lazzari on a Sunday afternoon at 4. His explanations and stories made each and every grave site come alive.

Unbelievable site to vusit. A must see! Gorgeous family vaults, some looked new, some very run down, ornate and simple, very peaceful and beautiful! Huge! We covered one little corner, it's a entire city block! Lots of shops and restaurants around the exterior.

Memorials to old egos. Some folks compare this place to the Per Lachaise cemetery in Paris. The difference pertains to the significant bones in Paris as against a bunch of carpetbaggers in Recoleta who have made Argentina the mediocre place it now is. Go figure!

Beautiful sculptures plus Evita Peron. You can tell the more affluent society of Buenos Aires repose here. If you're looking for Eva Peron, she's under here maiden name of Duarte with the rest of her family

A must see!. Yes, it sounds sort of bizarre to make visiting a cemetery a priority while you're out of the country, but trust me, unless you're from New Orleans, and see this every day, this is a treat! Be sure to check out the final resting place of Eva Peron (remember Evita?). The varying architecture is amazing!

got there at closing time be sure to schedule your arrival before 5. interesting to look thru the gates at the vaults and crypts. There are small craft booths just outside the gates to purchase local items and flowers
Unusual and must see. Iconic symbol of Recoleta, Eva Peron's resting place. A must see, for the architectural interest and restful beauty of the cemetery.
South American holiday. Such an interesting place to wander around. Most mausoleums well maintained. Grounds clean and tidy. Lots of cats that were a bit mangy looking.

Recoleta cementery, unexpected visit.. Buenos Aires shows the eccentricity even in the way you wait for the next life. It wasn't in my plans to go there but once there i just couldn't help getting in there and admire all the graves and the vaults, absolutley beautiful, peaceful, and creepy at the same time 'cause you actually can see the coffins. Completly recomended, architecturally impressive.

Amazing City for the dead.. When in Buenos Aries the Recoleta Cemetery is a must visit. Not only to see the resting place of the Iconic Eva Peron, but to see this City for the Dead. You can spend quite a while walking amongst the Tombs and see where the very rich and the elite are resting (although with all the visitors I doubt they are having peaceful days) Also there a quite a few cats residing in the cemetery that by the look of them belong in the "Walking Dead". it is very bizaar indeed.

Historico. Although it's a cemetery and with all that it involves, it's a nice place to visit if you like architecture and history. There are guide visits and maps that can help you see and understand
Beautiful cemetry. I fell in love with the little angel boy statue there. Free to get inside. Beautiful. Eva Peron is also here.

Historic and Dramatic Cemetery . Highly recommended for a look at the fascinating and dramatic mausoleums of the rich, famous and impossible people of Argentina's history. Of course the most famous tomb is that of Evita Peron and the "Duarte Family." The variety of structures and their styles is fascinating. This can be a brief visit or a longer one depending on your interest level.

Don't miss this site on your trip to Buenos Aires. This is a "Must See" on any trip to Buenos Aires since it contains the numerous mausoleums from famous local people including Evita. The different types of architectures represent various styles and the personal tastes of the builders or their families. Plan to spend 1-2 hours wandering around. We had a guide who made it very interesting.

Hauntingly beautiful!. The land of the departed lives on next to the land of the living. A wonderful place to walk and admire the sometimes baroque, sometimes austere, above ground crypts. And also to pay your respects at the Familia Duarte crypt (where Eva Peron rests). A very interesting place, historically and culturally!

Historic site that should not be missed. All of the graves are above ground (tombs) and some of them contain famous people including Eva Perón. Some of the tombs have been declared National Historical monuments. The cemetery is very walkable with reasonably wide paved pathways. There are many types of architectural styles used for the tombs and they also range from those that are well-maintained to those in very sad shape. This is definitely worth an hour or so and you should take a camera.

Beautiful place to visit in Recoleta. Old cemetery in the middle of Recoleta, with impressive graves of the high society from Argentina. Includes graves of former Presidents, Generals and Affluent People.
Well worth a visit. Well worth visiting this cemetery. The mausoleums were spectacular and of course Eva Peron is buried here.

Fascinating!. While everyone comes here to see Eva Peron’s mausoleum it is by no means the most impressive structure in this very interesting cemetery. A guide or a guidebook is useful to appreciate the back story to the numerous interesting burial places.

Never seen anything like this. We were in Buenos Aires for a few days, and our guide asked us if we wanted to visit the cemetery. I suppose it's a strange sort of "tourist attraction". We decided to go, and I'm glad we did because we've never seen anything quite like this before. Some of the tombs are in a poor state of disrepair with grass growing out of the windows. Our guide told us that in all probability, relatives of the deceased do not even know that a member of their family is buried there. Quite clearly some families have spent a fortune on a marble mausoleum for their loved one, along with statues and stained glass.We thought it was well worth a look because it was so different.
A must to see in BsAs!. Visit a cemetery might seems strange, but Recoleta cemetery is something different! Lose yourself in this "special city" for a travel into the history of BsAs

Its a different kind of morbid.... Sure Evita Peron is buried there (under the name of Duarte) but there is also the variety of architecture, the wall of graces; the holes that you look down and see coffins piled up. Its a whole other world in there...

Unbelievable . A real one off. Don't expect a map at the front as per the guide books because the guides have probably lifted them. So I suggest you print your own off before you go. Take a stroll around at your own pace and enjoy a unique experience.

Worth a visit. Feels like it shoud be a strange thing to do, wander around a cemetry looking at the resting places of people you dont know but I am pleased I went, and it is and interesting place well worth a visit

An Argentinian Masterpiece & Eva Peron's Burial Place. The cemetery contains many elaborate marble mausoleums, decorated with statues, in a wide variety of architectural styles such as Art Deco, Art Nouveau, Baroque, and Neo-Gothic,and Most materials used between 1880 and 1930 in the construction of tombs were imported from Paris and Milan.The entire cemetery is laid out in sections like city blocks, with wide tree-lined main walkways branching into sidewalks filled with mausoleums.

Not to be Missed - Recoleta Cemetery. When I was told not to miss seeing Recoleta Cemetery, I inwardly rolled my eyes. Visit a cemetery on vacation? Then, when a guide said it had works of art, we didn't exactly know what he meant, but decided to go. It is truly an incredible place. The Mausoleum structures have incredible sculptures. It's fascinating and truly a "must" on your visit to Buenos Aires.

The who's who of who has died in Buenos Aires. I recommend going with a guide as we did so they can identify the burial memorials for you and explain the significance of the family in the history of Argentina.

A Must SEE. This cemetery was wonderful. I have been to many cemeteries but this one was the most beautiful & fascinating. It was such a beautiful day when my husband & I walked around we were able to take our time & check things out. We did want to hire a tour guide but there were none waiting at the front when we arrived. I would recommend this place to visit & pay your respects.

Very Interesting. A must see for anyone's visit to Buenos Aires. Had a guide tour through the cemetery and really enjoyed the stories behind so many sits. The graves/monuments are amazing and a tribute to the people of B.A. Very enjoyable.

So interesting. This was a wonderful place to just wander, especially in the early morning before the tourist buses arrive. Evita is just one of the many people buried here, and the little side roads are fascinating.

Fascinating..... Went to the Recoletta Cemetery as part of a day tour. Thankfully we had a knowledgeable guide who could relate a lot of interesting stories. The Evita resting place is what most go to see but this was much less impressive than a lot of the other vaults

A Brit Out Of The Blue. We had planned on visiting the Recoleta Cemetery as part of our stay in Buenos Aires and, as we approached the entrance we were surprised to here an English accent asking if we would like a guide. We decided that, although we don't go in for cold call sales, this might prove worthwhile. And so it was; what Simon (sorry, no idea of his surname) doesn't know about the place probably isn't worth knowing. Yet his delivery, tone, pace and expressions we just perfect for the occasion. I am sure we would have either been disappointed, got lost several times, or simply bored had we tried doing the thing alone - guide book or no.

Fascinating cemetary. I have been to many famous cemeteries in the world, but this was the most fascinating. Each masaleum was more fascinating then the last. The carving, the pictures the way they were built. Our guide gave us an insight into many of the stories of the departed. Of course we had to see Evita Perones. You could easily spend 3 or 4 hours their roaming around.

a little creepy if you ask me. This is a must see attraction for visitors to BA but it's a little creepy. Everybody looks for Evita's final resting place and it's a little bit of a let down being much like the rest. For those that like wandering and peering into widows to see coffins, that's fine. However, there is a great outdoor dining area a few hundred meters from the gate where the less keen can wait with their friends coffee, beer, or wine.

A cemetery to impress. The mausoleums in this cemetery are so large as to be intimidating. You cannot help but think that it must have been very expensive to die in BA!Marble is the stone of choice for the more elaborate tombs and there are several levels to them. Statues grace many of the entrances and adorn the tops. If you have been to New Orleans and visited the cemetery there, this one is ten times more over the top.

A wonderful place to wander through. We couldn't miss visiting this, if only to see if we could find the gravesite of Evita Perón (tucked away off the beaten path). I took pleasure in finding the graves of some of the more notable figures of Argentina history (Domingo Faustino Sarmiento, Bartolomé Mitre) but Eva escaped us until we stumbled upon a tour group and heard the guide's pitch and figured our best bet was to tag along unobtrusively until we reached the site. But even if you're not looking for the elusive Evita there's much to see and marvel at in the memorials to those who've passed. It's a beautiful site, well worth a couple of hours' time.
Very interesting place. although a cemetry it's more like a small city of statues, houses and story of people. Eva Peron's grave and other interesting. take the guided tour

Bizarre and Fascinating. Unlike any cemetery I have visited, although I don't seek them out. Small concrete mausoleums of varying style, simple to over-the-top extravagance, were constructed to hold family members. I expected to find sealed marble or stone containers, but was surprised to find weathered, wooden coffins sitting behind iron grates. In a number of the crypts, the plaster from the ceiling had failed and fallen to the floor and/or on top of the coffins. Many of the structures were in a bad condition.
Decadence of the rich people.. Not so much different from other similar cemeteries (f.e. Paris). Much pomp. Only recommendable if you like cemeteries as such.

You cannot miss this if in Buenos Aires. However, we did miss it at first attempt as Mick Jagger was having a private tour and the cemetery was closed! However, the next day, visiting hours were back to normal and whilst a little too hot for somewhere with little shade, it was very well worth it. The variety of architecture is remarkable with many of the brick built vaults looking a little the worse for wear whilst the marble structures retained their magnificence. It's a big place, of great contrasts and you don't need to do it all and to be honest, even if you miss Eva Peron's resting place, you haven't missed much but many of the others are just magnificent.Probably not a good idea to let the kids stroke the cats though.

Creepily Great. Much more interesting than I thought it would be. Obviously to get the full story on the more unterestung crypts you should have a guide. I used and recommend Buenos Aires Walking Tours.

Very interesting. If you want to lear something about Argentina's history, definetly visit the cementery! It is amazing also for the amount of money people spent on their eternal rest!!! There are free tour guides, but the schedule is not so often, or you can find a guide at the entrance for short money.

Don't Cry For Me Argentina. Recoleta Cemetary is something of a puzzle. It is a very large, rather higgledy piggledy collection of mausoleums on a very grand scale. Family vaults capable of innumerable generations can be stored on their passing and, although there is no room for additional plots, it is still active and accepts new residents on a frequent basis.The families seem to have played a game of one-upmanship to have the most opulent tombs, engaging the most famous architects of the day. The Duarte family seem to have been wealthier than I imagined - Eva was no street urchin or working class daughter. Styles are mainly traditional. But occasionally a family fails to maintain their tomb and, after 30 years of neglect, it can be repossessed, cleared out of residents and re-sold. This is a rare chance for more modern designs, which add greatly to the experience of the visit. Take care of your belongings though. The Cemetary is just as attractive to pickpockets as it is to tourists.

Disrespectful Attraction.. I found the whole experience of being at Recoleta strange. Hundreds of people walking through masses of memorials and grave stones of people who clearly had money, and in my opinion - wanted to be remembered. The place is well laid out and quite grand, but most people go there to see Eva Peron's resting place, forgetting that other people are buried here. I felt most visitors lacked respect. One Argentine man brought flowers to the cemetery - many of the tourists took pictures of him like he was part of an act or a show.I was glad to be out of there and think a graveyard to be a rather weird place to visit on a holiday.
Interesting historical site. Landscaping makes it pleasant to walk. Mostly the interest in in Eva Peron, but the statues are everywhere in the cemetery

A MUST. We would normally not visit a cemetery when sightseeing or vacation, but this was a must place to see if you are in Buenos Aires. Evita's mausoleum is here. A brief visit is well worth it, and on the weekends, there are vendors in the park across the cemetery selling various crafts and local made products. There is also one of the oldest cafe in the city across the street called La Biela

A must see. If you've never visited a Cemetery in Argentina, you must go. The vaults are above ground and have a classic elegance. The history is amazing. You can spend hours wandering the peaceful surroundings. Great sculptures and stained glass.

A chance to visit a historical persons resting place was memorable. I had mixed feelings as I left this cemetery. I did feel that history was brought alive a little by visiting Eva Perons resting place. There was also a lot of mausoleums that were in disrepair which is sad in a way, seeing coffins covered in rubble, dust etc. Workmen leaving bits and pieces in peoples resting places seemed to show a lack of respect. There some memorable plots here and it was worth going.
Fascinating insight into Death and Life in Buenos Aires. Amazing place went back twice once by myself and once with a guide. A must if coming through this city

Free entry . English guided tours are Monday and Thursday 11:00 am and free
Entrance is free, but apart from Eva Peron I didn't know anyone, so guess the guided tour would be good.
There a nice market outside to pass your time

Amazing Experience. Took a taxi to the cemetery which is free to access. You don't need a guide as the cemetery is very easy to navigate. Eva Peron's tomb is over to the left as you enter about 50m down.
It's an amazing place that really has to be experienced if visiting Buenos Aires.

Must see my n Buenos Aires. This is a wonderful, very old cemetery. It is also the burial place for Eva Peron. It is big and filled with wonderful family mausoleums. You can spend hours walking around it if you have the time. We were there on Sunday and there was a craft market set up all around the exterior. This was a highlight for me.

Amazing cemetry in Buenos Aires to see!. On a city tour of Buenos Aires last month we were taken to the Recoleta cemetery which on first hearing, I was not impressed by. When we arrived, how wrong could I be! Some of the mausoleums were absolutely amazing and of course, Eva Peron, what a spectacular mausoleum.Wholly fascinating to walk around the cemetery, really amazing place to visit. If any one is planning a visit to Buenos Aires in the future, I highly recommend a visit to the Recoleta Cemetry.David OnslowSouthamptonUnited Kingdom.

Atmospheric place. I visited this place on Haloween afternoon. Was a special athmosphere. This kind of cementary i have never seen before. Its a place to look for details, there are so many so you can wander around for hours.

Different and interesting. Never thought I would spend any time in my lifetime mooching around a cemetery for culture but was pleasantly surprised by this trip. Lots of very interesting architectural statues of the rich, famous and influential of Argentina

How can you describe a cemetary as amazing, but it is. We were recommended by a friend to put ths on our must visit list for Buenos Aires, and they weren't wrong. To see rows and rows of family tombs, including those of many presidents of the country is unforgettable. The tomb to Eva Peron is very crowded and is far less interesting than many others but that is ignoring the historic importance of the woman. The area around the cemetary is commercial and I would suggest visiting the area by taxi and then leaving straight away

Fantastic visit to an unusual tourist attraction. A cemetery would not be on my normal list of places to visit whilst on holiday, however this is not a normal cemetery. It is a spectacular mausoleum filled with breathtaking sculptures, carvings and of course, Evita's grave. It is well worth spending a morning at this FREE attraction.
Very intersting. Very interesting and impressive place. Some graves tombs are larger than my apartment....Some signs and information could be helpful.
Most interesting cemetary. Opulent is not a word I thought I would use to describe a cemetery. Go with a guide for an in depth history of its residents.

Very Historical. From the First Lady through to rumours of Hitlers grave, the Recoleta cemetery was eerie and an amazing part of Buenos Aires history. It formed part of our bike tour with BA Bikes and o think it's much better to have it guided rather than on your own. Otherwise you'll probably not realise you're looking at what is believed to be Hitlers resting place!

Must-See Experience While Visiting Buenos Aires. Recoleta Cemetery is a fascinating attraction in Buenos Aires. Highly recommend it has a must-see point of interest and spend an hour or two getting lost in there. The attention to detail that went into creating some of the tombs was beautiful. The occasional cemetery cat was a pretty cool feature too.

Like an art gallery. This place is utterly fascinating. The drawcard is where evita is buried. But you can walk around and check out all the different mausoleums. Different time periods and lots of history. Ornate to the decorative to the conventional. Fantastic pathway. Free of charge and utterly amusing for a good afternoon work.

Must see in Buenos Aries. It may seem strange to say that visiting a cemetery is a must see in a city, but the Recoleta Cemetery is an amazing place. One of the most beautiful and peaceful places I have seen in the middle of a city. It is on many tours because the family tomb of Eva Peron and other dignitaries/wealthy families are there, but explore many of the avenues and you will find interesting sights around every corner.

A one of a kind cemetery that is an excellent reflection of Argentina's influential families and leaders.. Everyone comes here to see Evita's (Eva Peron's) family grave. But spend some time here and/or take the free tour and you will learn more about the history of Argentina, than is available in most textbooks.The mausoleums and monuments are often grandiose or worse, although some are quite architecturally interesting. If you are visiting BA, this is definitely worth a few hours of your time.

Interesting Place. If I remember correctly, there is no fee for admission and the vaults are fascinating. Evita's family tomb is in here - not as impressive as some, but a part of history nevertheless. Not too many places to just hang and enjoy the scenery but worth a look.
INTERESTING PLACE. There is a fairly long wait to see Evita Perone's grave but it is a beautiful setting with much beautiful statuary.

Interesting Mausoleum. Here you can find lots of graves of people who made history in Argentina. They offer guided tours or you can walk around at your leisure. It is a bit of a maze. It is also home to some living creatures...beautiful cats.

Fascinating!. One of the most interesting things we did in Buenos Aires. A great way to see the history of some of the politicians, celebrities, and wealthy people of Buenos Aires. Some of the burial sites are gorgeous and others are broken down and decaying. We agreed a guide would have been helpful, just to explain who some of the people were. Weird, yes, to be so fascinated by a cemetery but it's definitely worth a visit.

A pure display of wealth and historical people. Visiting a cemetery on a vacation is unusual, but there is a lot to see and learn about the culture. The most visited tomb is that of the Duarte Family where Evita is buried. Our guide gave us a history of the famous people buried here and then told us that the cost for a tomb is between US $1,600 and $2,500 per square meter starting belowground to all above ground. In addition to this, there are annual property taxes and maintenance costs.

Architectural delight in an unusual way. I don't know of another city that spent so much fortune in buried their dead, but that surely is the case with Buenos Aires. The Recolecta cemetery is quite a burial ground for the aristocrats of Buenos Aires, and each one is trying to outdone another. What you end up is a collection of architectural marvels of tombs in all different styles. One of the most fame one belongs to Eva Peron Duarte (aka Evita). The cemetary is all concrete with very few trees, so it absorb heat. We visited on a hot summer day, so the entire cemetery feels like an oven. You might want to visit on a cooler day. Take you time, stroll at your own pace, and getting lost among tombs is only half of the amusement.
See my review of La Recoleta!. I have submitted a review of La Recoleta thinking that the review was to concern the cemetery - please refer to my previous review!

Eva Peron and. Some interesting monuments. The family mausoleum that houses Evita's remains is clearly visited by admirers to this day. The avenues of this cemetery are interesting but not compelling.

Strange experience . I never thought I would visit a cemetary in a tour. It is a cemetery for the rich familiesincluding Evita Peron. It is like a gated mansions for the dead.It was strange experience. Since there isn't much to see in the city of Buenos Aires, I guess this is where all the tourist go anyway.

Only schedule a quick tour. Unless you're a history buff, the cemetery only requires 90 minutes. It is a nice walk with lots of styles, but it doesn't require much deeper immersion. We passed through with different people lingering at different spots but actually spent more time at the market outside (on a Sunday)
Burial Place of the Rich and Famous of Argentina. Clearly a culture that revers their relatives in mausoleums and grand memorials make this cemetery quite special.

Wealthy excesses!. This free attraction is well worth a visit. Apart from the tomb of Evita, the crypts of the wealthy is quite interesting. Pity their ego's weer so big of the community would be a better place!

ideal trip for photography and sculptures (if you like walk through cemeteries). If you like photography and sculptures you will find in this place many thing to do. It's not so scary. It has several incredible mausoleums. There is one with the statue of a lady with her dog, it's awesome. It's has the Evita Peron mausoleum. Ask for guided tour to know detailed history facts of important people of Buenos Aires

She's hard to find. If you're looking for the grave of Eva Peron (Duarte) then consult the map at the entrance before you venture into the maze of mausoleums. Otherwise it's a weird but interesting place to visit, full of sentimental statuary from a range of architectural periods.
Worth dying for. At this cemetery they look after the dead better than they care for the living. Worth a visit just to marvel at the way they do it.

Serene and Reflective. On day one of our trip to Buenos Aires, our friend Leonardo took us to this beautiful and well known landmark. I heard tours being conducted in Spanish and in English. The sky was bright and provided for a perfect opportunity to walk around leisurely, noticing different tomb styles and thinking about the work that went into building these crypts. I found that strolling through the cemetery was a peaceful experience. For seeing the entire cemetery in one visit, I'd suggest two or three hours.

Interesting visit with reference to Buenos Aires history. Situated on one of the best and most glamorous neighbourhoods you may visit in Buenos Aires. From the historical point of view, you should consider contacting someone who may tell you about the different important people of the country who has been buried there. Presidents, painters, poets and many other distinguished people.

A Little Different - But a 'Must See' Experience. Don't think of a cemetery visit as morbid or macabre. Located in the area of Recoleta the cemetery is located in an area of a large park. If you go on the weekend, there is a huge artists' market to walk thru on your way to the cemetery. In modern times the Recoleta Cemetery is famous as the burial site of Eva Peron. It is unlikely you will find her spot without asking someone or following a tour guide. Look for a square black stone door with the name DUARTE above the door. There are faded flowers stuffed into the grid-work on the door. Evita's name is on the side with other family members. The entire cemetery is made up of beautiful and interesting tombs. CNN has voted it one of the top 10 cemeteries in the world. If you take the time to read the plaques and examine the tombs you will learn more about the history of Buenos Aires and Argentina. If possible take a guided tour. Individuals do hawk tours (for whatever price you want to pay) outside the gate of the cemetery. Really worth a visit.
It's a cemetery. . Not a lot to see here. The graves are large and ornate. Nothing too exciting. You would think there would be more signage for Evita's grave.
A city within the city. Useful map at the entrance so it was fairly easy to find Christina's tomb. Amazing architecture, so varied and interesting.

Mausoleums. One of the more interesting cemeteries in the world with wall to wall family mausoleums of all types. Architecurally interesting. There is a map of who's buried where. Evita is buried in the Duarte family mausoleum. Juan Peron is elsewhere outside the city. Near a Freddos and a City park which has arts and crafts vendors on weekends. Good for take home gifts.
Death meets art. This cemetery is host a large portion of the Argentinean most traditional and aristocratic families, and they´ve expressed their wealth through their graves here.

This place is so magical.. The statues and monuments are gorgeous. There is a really strong feeling of wonder. There are numerous wealthy to do families and political figures buried here. Conceptually the mere grand scale of these statues is worth seeing for yourself.

Unique in the World- Do not miss. I have seen neighborhoods with less expense put into the homes. These monuments and mausoleums of great people and great families rivals walking through a museum. The architecture of the small edifices, the level of ornamentation and the history of the families entered here is fascinating. Go with a guide or take a written or audio guide, and of course, stop by to pay respects to Evita Peron, who rests with her Duarte family of origin, not with Juan Peron.

A must see.. Of the few ornate cemeteries we got to see in Latin America, this was the most beautiful. Gorgeous architecture & monuments, some very well-restored, some very church-like, and some gothic style. The never-ending fancy "housing" the alleys are just like the old towns/cities of Europe (could be a creepy thought to some). One of the memorials even had a Moet bucket inside (very curious). We asked around for the direction to Evita's tomb and managed to locate it quickly before we got further sun-burnt from the blazing summer heat. A must see if you come to BA.

Extraordinary place. It appears that competitive entombing is alive and well in BA. It is a status thing. Families try to raise their social standing by having a grander and better maintained mausoleum than their social rivals. It is really quite an appalling attitude but it does result in row upon row of extraordinary tombs. Some of the mausoleums are fully enclosed but others have windows which allow you to peer in and see a mixture of coffins, portraits, floral tributes or perhaps some pertinent artefact of the deceased. Families are required to maintain the tombs and if they don't, they are emptied out and offered for sale.Many visitors just come to see Eva Peron's tomb. It is nothing special but it rather ironic that the people's hero should have been laid to rest in such a place.

A sense of history at Recoleta Cemetery. Our private tour took us to the many historic sites here that gave us a sense of Buenos Aires's history. I recommend that you take a tour guide with you or you won't understand what you are seeing. Evita Peron is buried here which creates crowds, but there is much more to learn here as well.

Classic Vault Cemetary. Part of every tour in BA, its a good visit though found it a bit eerie. The tombvaults are all Majestic though some are in disrepair. Found it a bit confusing especially as we went there without a guide, you basically just walk thru with no idea what you are looking at, and we never did find Eva peron's tomb either. No maps or any guides were offered which was disappointing. It closes @ 5:30 so check the timings before you go. We reached around 5 as it was a really hot day so had to just hurry through.
Beautiful . Visiting s cemetery seems weird. But this place is eerily stunning. The tombs and monuments are really quite striking. Worth a visit and a stroll.

Be sure to visit here!. This cemetery is amazing! It is like visiting a small city. Every mausoleum is unique and interesting. I recommend going with a guide who can tell you some of the stories associated with the families buried there. Be sure to visit the gravesite of Evita Peron. She is with the Familia Duarte. This should definitely be part of your Buenos Aires tour.

Must-see! Beautiful tombs & sculptures that exceed New Orleans cemeteries.. Perhaps it's a morbid fascination but I love to visit beautiful & historic cemeteries. I've been to ones in New England, Key West, New Orleans (Lafayette #1, St. Louis #1, & Metairie). They all have their history, charm, and gorgeous tombs/statuary but none compare to Recoleta. Take a good camera and spend about 90 minutes here. If you love history and anecdotes like I do, hire a tour guide. (Evita's "tomb" is notable but not exceptional. It's a good item to check-off your sightseeing list but not a compelling reason to stop-by the cemetery. 80% of the other tombs are far more interesting and they should be why you visit.)
Interesting. Very interesting, but cemeteries in chile are more interesting and much less known aboutFree to go inMap a bit difficult to follow
Very interesting. The place to find the memorial to Eva Peron under her maiden name DUARTE.Gothic graves and many have a story behind them not just hers. Get a guide.

Stopped for the Eva Peron Gravesite. on tour of Buenos Aires Argentina and had to make a stop at the grave site of Eva Peron, an Icon. This place is simply stunning and worth the visit just to experience a true Argentine Memorial park. And if you are an Evita fan, than this stop is a bonus for you!

At awe. I thought I've seen cemeteries but this is different. Better still if you took a bike tour and the guides knew some history of it in relation to the nuanced architectural designs involving the candestine freemasonry. The lack of cross, the concealed or the tilted crosses and the subtle freemason symbols in defiance of the established catholic church.
Impressive. Very impressive cemetery, where the rich and famous families are buried. However it feels somewhat strange to walk through the streets full of graves, it's interesting to have a look.

Free walking tour-a little gem. We did the free walking tour in the cemetery Tuesday and Thursday only in the mornings - (English) our guide was a lovely lady and spoke very well, we were able to understand her well and she did a good tour of the cemetery with lots of history and background in understanding the reasons for many of the magnificent mausoleums. And of course Eva Peron. Well worth doing.

Had no idea this is so interesting.. Be sure to go with a good guide less you miss too much of what this is all about. It is always a "must see" and the question was "why". With a good guide you understand and understand a lot more of Buenos Aires. Now, you must go find out for yourself.
"I see dead people". And a lot of cats. If you´re into cementarys this is your place. So many nice people to say hello to in one small spot. Beautiful, I just love it!

Nice walk. To get a map, contribute a small amount at the booth outside of the main entrance and they will give you a map. The standing joke is you can keep it for a long time since the occupants are not going anywhere!The place to go of course is the Evita tomb. This great lady had a meandering journey before this resting place. Go also to the Evita museum (near the Plaza Italie) to understand more about her life and times. Obviously a controversial figure, she was both well loved and hated - so much so that her corpse was disfigured.Other than that, just a nice walk among the rich and famous of old Argentina.

Strange place but worth a visit (it's free) . We visited purely to see the evita grave. If you're in the area you should definitely drop in as it's free. You'll find the evita grave towards the centre of the cemetery and slightly to the left. It's on 1 of the corridors and is a normal size 1. We were shocked as we thought it would be huge. Her sisters put her in her fathers mausoleum even though she never had anything to do with him.
Very Interesting. History is to be found galore. Especially interesting to see the final resting place of Evita Perron.

A beautiful Cemetary. If you like cemeteries this one is excellent and elegant, especially if you were/are from a leading family from Buenos Aires. Bring your history book and seek out famous Argentinians. Follow the crowd to Maria Duarte's tomb and give yourself time to relax in the quiet of the grounds.

Must see. The Cementerio de Recoleta is a must see in BA! It is a very unique place. It's free and even if it's not of your big interest to walk around for hours it is for sure a visit worth just to get the feeling of how big and different this sight it.

Remarkable Recoleta . You simply must not leave Buenos Aires without doing a tour of this cemetery. The tours are free but a tip is requested but not mandatory but worth paying as you do get a much better insight into the real history of this place. You can of course do it by yourself & there is a great deal to see. I would recommend it as a" must see" when in BsAs but expect to spend 2-3 hours.

A must see. This is so fascinating. An amazing cemetery in the middle of the city which I would recommend anyone to see. As plots have been purchased " for eternity" there is a range in level of maintenance so some are abandoned and cannot be touched.Others are incredible- I say no more- just put this on your itinerary ( you can do a quick tour or spend ages...)

"If you like cemeteries, this is a must see". According to the information given to us there are 6,400 Neoclassical, Neogothic, Art Nuevo and Art Deco mausoleums in this small city cemetery! I must admit it is impressive. Actually, it can be a jaw dropping experience. At the end of our tour there was a real funeral procession walking past us. Our guide told us to be quiet, not take pictures and just watch. There was a wagon with a very small casket being wheeled into the cemetery with young couples crying, following the procession. Our guide deduced that it must have been a young infant that had died and these were the family members....It was quiet an emotional experience for all of us including the guide.We/did not realize that people were still being buried in this cemetery.

Really unique Place. Most of the Mausoleums at this cemetery are unusual and ornate--they are also very large. Actually, the one for Eva Perons's family was not of note, though that is why most people visit this place.

A must see if you liked Evita (person or musical). My wife really wanted to see Evita's tomb in this antique cemetery in the heart of Buenos Aires. If that's your goal, be aware that she isn't easy to find - she's with her family, the s, not her husband Juan Peron. But a visit is worth the time in any case, to see the ornate mausoleums of the rich and powerful.
