A Must in Buenos Aries!. I've visited Recoleta each time I've come to Buenos Aries. The cemetery offers a respectful, quiet, reflection of the earlier days in the city. This is the "go-to" final resting place in Buenos Aries. Take your time and stroll through the beautiful statuary and tributes to the greats of the city. Reflect on your humanity. Don't forget to look for the beautiful mausoleum of María Eva Duarte de Perón, the second wife of Argentine President Juan Perón. Eva was the First Lady of Argentina from 1946 until her tragic death in 1952.Please be respectful! There are frequent funerals and burials attended by family and friends.The surrounding restaurants, shops and markets are in sharp contrast to the cemetery, but exemplify the full circle of life. Enjoy!

Amazing! A Cultural Anthropologist's Haven. This is an amazing cemetery. Count on spending a couple of hours here at least. We purchased a map of the cemetery and walked it on our own, but I found that wasn't all that useful for the numbers on the map did not coincide with any markings on the tombs themselves. Probably would do better to hire a guide at the gate and hear what he/she has to say. When we were at the Duarte Family tomb where Eva Perone is entombed, we heard a guide talking with a couple that hired him. He was a wealth of knowledge.

Interesting walk for a brief while. It was nice to walk through the area and contemplate some historical figures and our own mortality. Easy to navigate. Worth the stop if you are in the area. A bit of factual info... 10yr plot costs about $6M USD. Not cheap!

You might get lost. This was an unexpected visual delight. There are so many sculptural stones and interesting designs, I took many more photos than I expected. Go on a sunny, warm day and stroll around. Bonus - it's free.

Strange tourist attraction . Strange tourist attraction - yet well worth a visit. Fascinating history. Still free but soon to be 100 peso entry fee. Well worth it. Take a free guided tour Tuesday and Thursday at 11:00

Well worth the visit. Well worth the visit but either do your homework beforehand or take some sort of tour to get the most out of your visit.
Needless to say everyone that stopped our guide wanted directions to Eva's morcellium which is the most popular reason for people's visit.

You must visit this beautiful city-cemetery!. It's so easy to get lost here, wandering among the incredible monuments to the leaders of Argentina. The statuary, architecture, building materials, and names make for a fascinating adventure. If you've been in Bs. As. for any amount of time, you'll notice that amny of the grave markers are also the names of many of the streets and boulevards of the city. One mausoleum is more beautiful than the next. A really really interesting and magical way to spend a morning or afternoon.

Wonderful.... We visited the cemetery twice actually. One was as part of a city tour and the other as part of a Recoleta District & Cemetery tour and we have no complaints of being there twice in two days. It's a living cemetery as we witnessed an arrival of a new "resident". It offers magnificent vaults to vaults in complete disrepair (which permits one to see beyond the stone - one we could see down to the underground caskets - cool!). Wish I could share my travel blog with all my photos!

a must see if you visit Buenos Aires. Located in the neighbourhood of Recoleta, this Cemetery is a must see... for the architecture and design of graves and boves. Many of argentinian artists and politics are buried and resting in this place, as for example, Juan Domingo Peron, among other public figures.

Historic, interesting, beautiful, slightly unsettling and free. I wasn't too excited at the prospect of going to a cemetery, but yes this place is where the elite have put up monuments to the dead and it is spectacular. Very different

History Lesson in the Cemetery!. More famously know as the resting place for Eva 'Evita' Peron - there are generals, dictators and very romantic touching stories associated with this Cemetery. Go early to avoid large tour groups.
Make sure to see the cemetery. Recoleta was an interesting and unique experience. Definitely recommend to anyone visiting Buenos Aires.
Must see!. Very interesting place. It should be visited. You can see tombs of many Argentinian famous and historical figures.

Sleeping Legends, near Chic Buenos Aires. The whole quarter takes the name from the cemetery.You'll find it amazing to walk between graves and history, where politicians, sportmans and actors from a golden century came from past and slow greatness of another Argentina, that today struggles because of economy.
Must see, butifullee place and so much work behind the sculpture for the graves.. It's to take the camera and go to take pictures, also to see the lady that feeds the wild cats is a must.
Interesting!. Is nice and interesting not just a cementery but totally recommend to make a tour guided so you can appreciate more what is deeply in the history,and the surprises you can have!
A Museum of Argentine History. Spectacular works of architecture and art. The history of the country is told by these structures and the stories of the people lying there.

History in one place!. This cemetery is the number-one attraction in Buenos Aires and I can see why. Many famous politicians are buried here as well as other famous persons. The mausoleums are amazing with some in disrepair and others sparkling. It is interesting to read a bit of history and peer inside some.

A walk through Argentina´s "aristocracy¨". My family and I have been here a couple of times, and always find something new. You can either go with a tour guide or by yourself, the guide of course will take you to the rich and famous deceased crypts and mausoleums, IE Evita Peron, various presidents, etc. We personally liked exploring ourselves. The only negative I would give, is that many of the mausoleums have fallen into really bad repair and much maintenance is needed, Other than that, it is a place that anyone visiting Buenos Aires needs to go see

Amazing city of the dead. Over 4,000 mausoleums particularly for show. Individual one vary from recently upgraded to falling in decay. Similar to New Orleans mausoleum cemetery but here foe show of rich vs. high water level in NO.

Wonderfully Preserved for All of History. We stopped here as part of a City Tour. Soo worth it.The Mausoleum's are well preserved and very well maintained. A Great Opportunity to photograph wonderful stone work --- angels, curves, dwellings of the dead.Don't miss Eva Peron's final resting place.

Both Wonderful and Sad. A city in itself. Tiny Churchs, statues and shrines. The monuments to people dead are both wonderfully preserved and loved while others are forgotten and deteriorating. A history of a culture and its people. Well worth a vist

Historical. The final resting place for Eva Perone, and many other famous people in Argentina. Architectures and garden are beautiful. Must go through with a guide to get the most out of the history of the people buried there.

Impressive!. What I remember more impressive at the Recoleta Cemetery. is pass by rich graveyard whike I was looking for the place Evita Peron rest and surprised I saw that she hads a very small and simple grave , so touching than any other, so according with the great woman, Eva Peron, The Argentina's Mother! It's impossible not to cry and stay few moments meditading about Evita!

Amazing beautiful place full of memories. You could spend a whole morning or afternoon in this incredible cemetery, looking at the magnificent granite and marble mausoleums and monuments. The sculptures are breathtaking and of course you have to visit Eva Peron's family tomb!

Remember it's a cemetery. You can spend 10 minutes here or an hour or more, depending upon your inclination to look around at the various ways that people's deaths and burial memorials have been celebrated and created. Some redundancies after a while. Worth getting a tour guide if you want to see something in particular.

Look out for the stained glass windows. An amazing place in a city of amazing places! I love the idea of a city for the departed and the realisation is even more spectacular. The atmosphere in the cemetery is beautiful as are the crypts and mausoleums. I particularly loved those with stained glass windows and the way these reflected inside when the sun hit them. Do not miss this!

Evita's grave is here -- worth the visit!. We went here and walked through the many grave sites/mausoleums. Eva Peron's family grave site is here and it is extremely simple for such a woman. The upkeep in this place is unbelievable and there's a lot to take in.

Interesting stop for history lesson. This cemetery is very usual place that has stood the test of time. Several local people are available for hire to take you through the cemetery. Old history stories are told when you venture through the winding paths. The space is clean and very interesting. A most see when you visit Buenos Aires.

An unforgettable stop. One of the most interesting self tours I have ever taken. Free entrance and the tombs are a feast for the eyes from very old ornate architectural masterpieces to brand new super modern no expense spared. Some tombs succumbing to the elements and are open with exposed caskets!

A Must See. I would definitely say you would need a map or guide to show you and explain the history behind the fascinating tombs/mini churches etc that make up this grave yard. The most visited grave is obviously that of Evita Peron, which is quite small in comparison to others and could be easily missed, but look for the crowds. Some tombs have glass fronts with tables, chairs and stairs leading down underground to a second tomb across a path!

Eva Peron's grave may be the most popular but others are even more impressive. You can tell from the crowds that the Duarte family crypt with Eva Peron's grave is the main attraction but take your time and take in the entire scene. You may want to prepare by reading tour guides so you can appreciate the scope and underlying history of this cemetery.

Interesting place. Recoleta Cemetery is the final resting place of Evita Perone and many of Argentinas eliteThe cemetery is very large and it is filled with large mausoleums and memorials of varying architecture creating an erie yet beautiful series of alleysWe spent about an hour there but could have easily spent three

Familia Duarte. Virtually everyone who visits this cemetery comes to see the grave/crypt of Evita Peron. There are numerous people hawking tours and tour maps for a price. I recommend buying a map of the cemetery and then exploring on your own. If you want to see Evita's grave, look for the Duarte family crypt or simply look for the crowds.

a place not to be imagined and not to be missed. Have visited many cemeteries but such one could not imagine!!! Like a city of chapels and family and whole clans Pantheons, with marble figures, sculptures, stained-glass windows etc. Evita Peron was engraved there - ask at the entrance for location of the chapel as it is not easy to find......

Fascinating!. We spent almost two hours roaming around this cemetery, not because of the people interred here, but because of the art and architecture. The tradition of bronze memorials instead of flowers creates many wonderful stories of those buried here. The statuary is wonderful and shows the Italian influence on Argentine culture. I would put it as a "must" for a visit to Buenos Aries.
Very interesting. I thought it would be weird to visit a cemetery, but it's actually architecturally very interesting and exudes an eerie atmosphere and I'd say that's not to be missed.

Incredible Cemetery, like I've never seen before.. We usually dont make special trips to cemetery's but this place in amazing.Huge grave sites, entire families buried together, very old coffins in view through the doors, and row after row of different family monuments to their loved ones.A very unique, almost surreal place.Definitely visit this site when in BA.

Incredible sight. The tombs, one more lavish than the next and crowded into 4 acres, are a "must see" sight in the Recoleta section of Buenos Aires. Take a walking tour that ends there, then wander on your own.

Mix emotions!!!. Of course La Recoleta attracts people mainly for Evita (who's family tomb is quite ordinary or at least not as spectacular as expected.That being said,the cemetery is home to most history making people& the rich of BA.What is surprising is the quantity of tombs left unattended (broken glass,tombs left to roth in everybodies eyes.Some really look in bad shape but nobody seems to care but others are just too much especially when you think of all the starving souls in this city.Whatever ;it is still a beautiful place to stroll around for an hour or two,and unless you really are a history buff i don't see the point of a guided tour.

The history through wealth as seen in a cemetery.. Much can be learnt by this visit. The wealthy were buried here in the most magnificent monuments.It is like a city.after death.......built to remember

Beautiful, shocking and surprising on a Grand Scale.... "Visit the Recoleta Cementery" we heard from many...okay, headstones...NOT...the many mausoleums, like small churches held the family remains...each was like a little chapel unto itself with stained glass, sculptured marble and many years of beautiful architecture. Burial place of Evita Peron and her family...the beuty is hard to describe so, I will attach photos...if you are into the history of the country, or photographic subjects and challenges, VISIT!

Most unusual.... I'm not one to wander about in a Cemetery, but this one was an exception! Like a little city, complete with little streets, and tall "buildings!". The admission is free. Take your time...
A must see. It's on everyone's list that visits the city. Best to go early am and wander aimlessly thinking about what it means to be alive.
It's nice to see. You can see the tombs of famous people as Evita, Domingo Faustino Sarmiento, etc. The architecture is quite interesting as well.

Get a tour guide. We turned up and bought the 20 Pesos brochure that contains one paragraph of an introduction to the cemetery. We ended up piggy-backing on a number of your groups as they went round which went into details about the families and history of the many many inhabitants there. It really brought the place to life. Make sure that you get one when you visit.

Fascinating example of cemetery architecture. The mausoleum of Eva Peron is the big draw here but there is much more to see. The are a number of mausoleums that are much more elaborate and ornate than hers

An amazing cemetery - a must to visit. This is an amazing cemetery and should be on your list of places to visit. It is quite spooky but very interesting. The tombs are huge. You can see the coffins in some of them. The tomb where "Evita" was buried can be found in there. It is on the left side when you enter.
Unique and eclectic attraction. A very large cemetery with 100's of crypts in a multitude of shapes, sizes, architecture and condition. Lots of tourists.

interesting. We hired a guide right at the entrance for $10 each. He was very knew of BA history and those grave sites. After 40 minutes we had seen enough and had to leave for a plane. Complete tour could have lasted with him for 45 more minutes. Just to walk through does not give you the sense of magnificence of how and why these people are laid to rest here so the tour was good.

Beautiful and historical center. I visited many different cemeteries in different countries but this is a one of the most beautiful and interesting cemetery among them.There are many beautiful sculptures in different parts of it.Family units and some personal related to sant fathers related to 300 years ago.Just behind of it ,there is a shore you can rest and be there for one or two hours.

City of the Dead. I think the main reason people visit this strange city of tombs is to see the tomb of Evita Peron (nee Duarte) Once you have wandered around countless baroque tombs and monuments to the dead you are glad to leave.

Cemetery? Tour stop? YES. Fascinating stop in BA. Most want to visit Eva Peron's mausoleum but the cemetery as a whole is an interesting stop. variety of architecture and money lends to good conversation
Mice plcae for a Cemetary. We originally didn't want to go to a cemetery on our travels, but ended up going there. It was definitely worth it. Its amazing to see the monuments.

Worth a visit. Visited the cemetery on a Saturday morning/lunchtime and it wasn't too busy. A guide map at the entrance gives the locations of all the graves. Unless you hire a guide (I didn't) a bit of prior research into who is in the cemetery is useful, so you know where to go. There are lots of guides available. You could also listen in to any guided tour, but this is cheating a bit. Of course, everyone makes a bee line for the grave of Eva Peron. Clearly shown on the map but can be difficult to locate, just follow the trail of people. There is so much more to see though. Quite a spectacular sight. One note of caution. Beware pickpockets. I was targeted by a couple of young kids in the plaza outside the cemetery, but I always ensure all pockets/bags etc are firmly closed, so they didn't get anything. Lots of signs up warning about this. The church and cloisters next to the cemetery are also worth a visit.

Interesting history education with FREE tour at Recoleta Cemetery. As one of the top attraction in Buenos Aires, I went to visit the cemetery twice - first time to browse around on my own to soak up the ambience and look at the monuments, the second day for a FREE 1-hour guided tour provided by the cemetery.(1) At the time of this writing, the cemetery offers FREE 1-hour guided tour in English at 11:00 AM on Tues & Thurs. You just show up. My Tuesday tour had a big crowd, but the guide had strong voice, well-spoken, and herded us well.(2) Guided tour is well-worth the hour. You see the highlights of the cemetery, learn interesting background and bits of Argentina history and how the cemetery operates. I was very glad I made to the guided tour.Tip for a great picture of cemetery: If you go to 3rd floor of Recoleta shopping mall just outside of cemetery, you get a vintage view of the whole cemetery which makes a great photo. I include my photo with my review.

A Treasure. This is one of the special high lights in Buenos Aires. It is really for the architectural pieces lead lights and artifacts. The English guide is very informative with lots of local knowledge. A free map is available at the entrance. The cemetery closes at 5pm and opens at 7am which I'm told is a lovely time to visit.

Pleasant way to see some history.. The cemetery is a showplace of the grand families, both old and new, and Eva Peron is located here with many other dignitaries. It's well kept, with lots of beautiful trees and benches, and seems to be a strolling site for young and old. Many grand tombs have been left to wither and rot inside, while others are shiny and tidy. Easily reached by bus or taxi, and there are restaurants nearby.

very interesting; more than Eva Peron's grave. I would recommend a visit to the Recoleta cemetery: It is really interesting to see the different styles of Tombs and hear the history of many of the families buried there

Fantastic. Certainly not the oldest but probably the most ornate cemetery I have visited. I think cemeteries are very interesting and can tell you a lot about society. This cemetery is amazing. The mausoleums have stained glass, alters, photos, live plants. I haven't seen anything like this and it goes on for row after row. Sculptures galore. A definite must see in Buenos Aires. Evita is buried here.
Not the regular cemetery. Basically one goes for the artistic designs of family tombs. Very interesting how people go all the way to design gravesite. Interesting place to visit.
Must visit ! . A must visit !!!! I do advise taking a map of the cemetery as it's somewhat of a maze - but quite a jaw dropping experience and amazing

Best with a guide. You get an excellent insight into the history of Buenos Aires and Argentina if you do this with a guide. Makes a good starting point for a Recoletta tour. Entry free if you are just going yourself.
Evita!. We were not so sure about actually "visiting" a cemetery as a tourist attraction at first! But we just had to, we were in Argentina! And to pay respects to Evita. Don't cry for me Argentina!

A true treasure of BA, not to be missed. I wanted to visit this Cemetery to see the mausoleum of Eva Peron but it has much more than this. Her tomb is quite modest compared to the ornate mausoleums of the elite of Buenos Aires. Such beautiful architecture, and a tranquil space to collect thoughts. Also as a cat lover i loved seeing the local cats. Someone feeds them thankfully as there were bowls of biscuits and water. Another of BA's sights not to be missed by any means.

Interesting place for a walk. Walked around the cemetery looking at all the beautiful buildings. The cemetery is vast and a good idea is to get a map since it is so big. Found Evitas site which was neat and seeing the actual coffins in each space was pretty neat. A good place to spend an hour if you are in Recoleta.

Interesting Place to Visit. This is a really beautiful cemetery. Eva Peron is buried here along with other famous people. The surrounding area is also great for markets on the weekends (crafts and such) and places to grab a bite to eat and sit outside.

Most Unexpected Pleasant Experience. Never thought I would ever write a rave review about a cemetery. This is not an ordinary cemetery. It is street upon street of one and two story mausoleums sitting together like a block of townhomes. The structures are amazing and marvelous in their detail. This place should be "numero uno" on your things to do in BA

Very Interesting and Beautiful Cemetery!. This Cemetery is different from any other cemetery I have seen before. The mausoleums in it are very ornate and cost a lot of money. Our tour guide told us that they are so expensive, that some people will just rent a space for up to a month until they think no one would visit the grave any longer, and then the family will have the body moved to a different cemetery. I recommend visiting this cemetery on your own, rather than on a tour, when you are in Buenos Aires so that you will have as much time as you want to look around.
Beautiful cementery. So you are probably thinking: gosh, that is odd that we are going to a cemetery. But it is worth while. There are many famous people buried and it is a beautiful place.

Stunning Gothic. We went on the hottest day 36C at HIGH NOON! (not recommended as the heat is bounced off all the statues and marble of the mausoleums) However we went with the intention of making it to Evita's tomb. We ended up seeing SO much more than we expected, we had a great private tour by someone who studied fine arts and the cemetery was part of her field of study so she knew MANY stories about different tombs and had a lot of historical knowledge, we got super lucky.It is HUGE so plan to be there for HOURS, have a knowledgeable tour guide or you COULD get lost, and even though its pretty its also a little terrifying.NOTE: not for the weak of heart as many caskets are buried exposed. It can be shocking yet beautiful.

Worth the trip to visit a cemetary. The Recoleta is as much a trip through a cemetery as it is a trip through an architectural mosaic. The mausoleum's are amazing and paint a picture of the wealth and power of many of the souls interned here. There is a section at the back of the cemetery devoted to the political elite of Argentina and of course you won't have any trouble finding Eva Peron's final resting place as you only need to follow the crowd.

Who would have thought?. I never understood the interest and attraction to the cemetery but it was very interesting! Our tour guide made it come alive (no pun intended) with fascinating stories of those who were buried there.
Beautiful and Mysterious. A must see spot in Buenos Aires. A person can spend hours here enjoying the atmosphere and monuments. Don't forget to visit Eva Peron while there!
Great Visuals!. Good place to visit and see the opulence of previous generations. The Peron crypt is a bit of a dud but the others are remarkable

Worth a visit. I certainly wouldn't go to BA without visiting this cemetery. It is unusual by any standard, and located in an area that is full of little stalls and restaurants. Evita's tomb isn't much, but the experience is worth the time.

An amazing range of architectural styles.. We spent a couple of hours wandering around marvelling at the extravagance of some mausoleums and the simplicity of others. Recommend comfortable walking shoes and a hat. Try to go earlier in the day when the sun is less intense and visitors are fewer. Great aerial view from Recoleta Plaza, diagonally opposite the cemetery. Visit the church next door.

Amazing place really a must see!. You can tour the cemetery on your own and the artistic designs for each mosolium was amazing, we spent hours walking through the cemetery and each aisle was a unique and amazing site!

Don't just go for Evita's grave. Crazy, surreal, spooky, but above all else a snapshot into how the super rich and powerful created tombs of immense self-indulgence & glory simply due to there status!
Enjoy!

Interest. Understand this is one of the major tourist attraction in Buenos Aires. Very interesting cemetery full of history. Some are extremely ornate and grand. Not entirely convince that it should be a tourist attraction.
Amazing Musoleums. This is a must on any tour of BA. 13 acres of tombs dating back 200 years. You also have Eva Peron's on site. The structures are all different.

The Dead Centre of Buenos Aires. I suppose I went to view the place because a chap called Andrew Lloyd Webber wrote a musical on an unusual subject. Or to put it another way if Eva Peron had not been buried here would I - and for that matter many other people - have visited the place? The cemetery is the resting places of many of the wealthy citizens of the city as is testified by so many magnificent mausoleums. We went unaccompanied and we would probably have been better off with a guide who would have been able to relate some points of interest. Initially it was interesting to look at so many monuments of varying magnificence but, apart from Evita, there was no-one I had ever heard of and I fairly soon wearied. We probably shouldn't regard cemeteries as tourist hotspots but I cannot help but think that Recoleta cemetery isn't in the same league as the like of Pere Lachaise in Paris or even Highgate Cemetery in London. Nevertheless I felt that overall it was well worth visiting.
Excellent cemetery. Get a guide if possible very interesting in how they bury people, evita grave . Beautiful architecture, interesting large structures .
So Interesting!. I've never seen a cemetery that was so interesting to walk around. All the crypts are so different, ornate, and have so much history. A must see for any trip to Buenos Aires.

Great Old Tombs and Of Course, Evita's!. You don't want to miss the Recoleta Cemetery. It's one of the key tourist spots in Buenos Aires, but because of that, it is also a place to watch your wallet! Our wonderful guide told us the alleyway between the cemetery and the row of charming (though touristy) restaurants, is known as Pickpocket Alley - so beware! Also, he said the pickpockets tend to be women, about 40, rather than men, just to confuse those being swindled. But the cemetery is worth a trip. Just watch your belongings - and make sure to see Evita's tomb.

THE must-see place in Buenos Aires.. This is unlike any cemetery in the USA. There's row after row of mausoleums, some in disrepair, others well maintained. Of course, the main "attraction" is the tomb of Eva Peron, it can be easily found on account of the crowds.

Very interesting visit to a very old cemetary. We visited here, like so many others, to see Evita Peron's burial place. But, in the process, learned a lot about Buenos Aires and Argentina. Worth the trip here.
Great Cemetery !!!. One of the nicest cemeteries in the world. Highly recommended to take the local guided tours. Tuesdays & Thursdays in English
Eva Peron is here. If you wish to find the Peron tomb - look at the map at the entrance to the cemetery. An easy walk from the Four Seasons Hotel.

Get your bearings. If you don't have a map of the place, don't trust the signs. They are often misleading or simply nonexsitent. You can take a picture of the map at the entrance and use that as a guide.

Take a guide on your tour. I went to this as part of an organised tour. The guide was great at pointing out the relevant sites and told me about the story of Eva Peronne. She was not originally buried in her final resting spot. It was an interesting visit.

Uniquely Buenos Aires. Very interesting glimpse into how Argentines in BA have honored one's life through death for centuries - and even today. There are free guided walking tours in a variety of languages which I would recommend to learn more of the history and philosophy around this unique cemetery. Even if you do not choose the guided tour, it is a beautiful to walk through. This is where Eva Peron eventually came to rest in her familia's tomb.

Amazing Recoleta Cemetary. Amazing cemetery. But not to be visited in the heat of the day! Half an hour to an hour is enough. Visit Evita's mausoleum. a guide is a good idea but we went as part of a private tour and so we heard the stories.

Loads of good stories: worth an hoyr. Seeing Evita's grave, hearing a guides stories makes this touristic place into a wonderful window into Argentian culture. Go early before the crowd and heat and you will be happier!

Evita is reason people go but many of the "houses" better. Every tour group comes here. I was first here in 1997 and the same. Go early to avoid the masses. Take time to see the others; presidents, generals, some are very old. Evita is not the only reason to go

Searching for Evita. A metro ride and long walks got us to the cemetery at high noon in February -- not recommended! Eschewing the tour offer from the Brit at the gate, we wandered in the muggy heat, snapping photos of the impressive edifices and searching for the final resting place of Eva Peron.It's easy to get lost in the narrow alleys between the tall mausoleums-- just ask the women who'd been to the cemetery the previous day and was unable to lead our little free-form group to Eva.At last, following a babble of four or five languages, we spied a group in front of the relatively modest grave.Try to visit on a cool day. A number of cafes are across the street and a multi-level air-conditioned shopping mall around the corner offers a spot for restrooms.
Visit to Cemetary. Well worth a visit . Fascinating place. Some of the tombs are abandoned . Eva Peron's tomb has fresh flowers. Could have spent longer here each tomb is so different.

Surprised. Visited this cemetery and it was such a surprise. As you walk in it hits you that this is no ordinary place the tombs are amazing and as you walk further into this place you finally come to Eva Peron's family resting place tucked away off the main walk brilliant

A Glimpse into the Past. This is a "homage" into the past. It gives a great insight into the soul of Argentina and is an absolutely fascinating, very peaceful way of spending a few reflective hours. Do not miss it.
Beautiful walk. Really moving and beautiful place to visit, free entrance and well maintained surroundings. A bit sad that some of the 'tombs' are not cared for but all beautiful in their own way.

A must to visit. I have been here 3 times, you cannot see enough. Tombs from 100 years ago from prominent families, tomb of Eva Peron inside. Hundreds of friendly cats roam the cemetary, people from this upscale neighborhood come and feed them.
Cemetery in a grand style. A city for the dead with small "streets" , uniquely carved marble, granite and decorated with flowers, stained glass and stone angles. Make sure you visit Avita's grave

A unique monument to the afterlife!. While the Recoleta is nothing like Egypt's ancient tombs and temples, its grandeur brought them to mind. It's very different than any cemetery I've seen before and is truly fascinating.

A must do on your Buenos Aries tour. We visited twice. First time was with a guide from Buenos Tours who launched into the most informative and entertaining history of the cemetery. Later we saw some of the magnificent old homes of the dearly departed.
City of the dead. This is a fascinating walk through a "city" of huge family mausoleums. It takes awhile to find the Duarte family (Eva Peron) but just look for crowds and you'll be there!

Must do in Buenos Aires. Yes it is a top touristy thing to do, but it is still worth it. It would be rude to visit and not pay respects to Evita (who is actually beneath your feet at the place you photograph the plaque on her family tomb). The whole cemetery has some memorable tombs and it is worth getting a guide for the story on some of them.
History lesson. Many of the people formed Argentina as it is today have been laid to to rest. Evita is now buried in the Duarte Family crypt after many years of wandering.

Fascinating, stunning, beautiful, mysterious. My favourite place in BA! Visited 3 times and I highly recommend you take the guided tour, our guide was very knowledgeable and full of facts. If you go early morning / late evening dont forget to takw some treats for the stray cats that live there (also known to some as guardians of the cemetary)
A beautiful visit to the great Eva Peron. A beautiful historic cemetery right in the middle of the city. Enjoyed the lovely architecture of the tombstones and paid a visit to the great Eva Peron.
Interesting. An interesting cemetery with a wide variety of tombs - that of Eva Peron being by far the most popular to visit.
still a cemetary. this place is the last stop of many popular and historic figures. expensive and grand tombs in the middle of the city!

Of course, you must visit . . .. It is world famous. And deservedly so. Just go early in the day to avoid the crowds and before it gets too hot - rarely is there any breeze. Give yourself plenty of time to wander slowly around. There is so much to take in and a photo op around every corner.
Block Checked . Typical cemetery for wealthy people in Hispanic countries. Visit the tomb of Eva Peron and press on.
This is a must see "Evita" tomb. This place is a must see when in Buenos Aires and it is generally packed out so be prepared to spend time lining up to see the family tomb of Eve Peron.
Amazing. Amazing cemetery with every single piece of art small monuments. You can also pay visit to Eva Duarte ( Evita ) . Every corner gives you another special feeling.

Fascinating!. I've never visited a cemetery that looks like a tiny town filled with mausoleums and statuary. Some of the messages on the tombs are heartfelt expressions of the bereaved's grief, while others include the usual honorifics. The tombs vary in size and features; some are in excellent repair and others are not. It's a fascinating place to visit.

Fascinating visit. It always seems odd to recommend visiting a cemetery, but this is a special place to wander around and see the incredible tombs and look up some the key figures / families in Argentina's history. The cafe opposite (La Biela) under the huge rubber tree is a must for traditional Buenois Aires style afterwards.

Amazing Historic Cemetery. This is more like a tiny village with lanes and streets packed with tombs. Many of these contain statues and possessions of the deceased. Fascinating and very different to the cemeteries I've seen in the past in any country.
A FIVE STAR CEMETARY. Believe it or not, this is one of the highlights of Buenos Aires. Do not miss it! The history and architecture compliment each other.
Impressive sight. A must see as you'll have never seen anything quite like this cemetery. Architecturally and historically lovely. Do some homework to really appreciate it.

Interesting. Free to get in. Somewhat bizarre for those not used to seeing tour buses outside a cemetery but an interesting collection of tombs of the rich and famous families of Buenos Aires. Eva Peron's tomb and plaque will be the one with the tour group in front. As a guide said, 'she died at 33, the same age as Jesus', which indicates how much reverence is still felt for her.

One of the most Famous Cemeteries in the World!!. A photographers heaven....a must see if you are in BA, is included if you take a city tour. Evita Peron is buried here under her maiden name "Duarte". Amazing place!!
Wow. A not to be missed site. This was the best and most interesting cemetary I have ever seen. Not to be missed!
A beautiful place. If you wanna do some sightseeing and are up to a very special thing you must visit this place. It is very beautiful and relaxing.
Cool. You can learn so much in that place, also there are so many beautifuls sculptures to see and explore, definitely one place to visit in Buenos Aires

Buenos Aires #1 Tourist Attraction. The mausoleums here are incredible to walk around! There are former presidents and other noteworthy Argentinians buried here. Whether you have ever heard of these people makes no difference. The cemetery is basically where nobility is buried. Eva (Evita) Peron is also here in the Duarte family tomb. You will have to ask around and look where crowds are gathered to find her tomb because it does not have signs pointing the way like those of some other famous personages. I suspect that is because her burial here caused controversy amongst those who opposed Peron's politics and Evita's humble background. She was opposed by the upper classes, but now permanently resides in their midst.
Beautiful. A most interesting place, a must if you visit BA. Beautifully kept and so much history and interesting stories

Away from the hustle and bustle. This might seem like an unusual place to visit, but the artistic representations in statuary alone is worth the visit. For those who wish to see how the other half are laid to rest you will find this almost mind boggling. There is a lot more history to be reviewed here if you have a keen interest in the history of Buenos Aires. Don't just run in and see the tomb of Eva Peron, but spend some time exploring the avenues of this necropolis.

A different experience. Walking through this cemetery gave me a feeling that people sometimes are willing to glorify they dead beloved to a far fetched extent. The graves and mausoleums are extravagant each trying to be more then the other. On the other hand some are very neglected.Evita Peron's tombstone is very modest compared to her part in modern Argentinian history.I recommend to spend a couple of hours walking through this cemetery.Note that they close at 15:00

If I knew folks kicked it like this when they died I'd have died a long time ago!. I was in BA for work one weekend and my coworker who lived here took me to Recoleta Cemetary. This place was unbelievable! It was like an entire city of entombed souls where nothing is too lavish or extravagant! Obviously Mrs. Eva Peron was a top priority for most of the site-seers but even her tomb wasn't too crowded to get a quick pic. The "streets" are named just like you would see in any small town but a little too small for a vehicle. Perfect for walking around and enjoying the history of this awesome place.
Recoleta cemetery. Nice way to spend an afternoon. It was very interesting to see Eva Peron'a family crypt. The craftsmanship of the stone work is stunning throughout the cemetery.

Architectural delight for a cemetery with Eva Perone. Immense in size and variety of mausoleums with 4500 containing 300,000 people including Eva Person! I cannot begging to describe the variety in tributes the families have built. Styles of all ages.My advice? Use a guide as the stories of what some of the mausoleums actually "retell " are hilarious or sad or just perfect folklore. 2 hours was enough. UT I know we could have listened to more. Take your time and enjoy the architects heaven on variety. Sorry my 50 pictures are on my Nikon still...
Well worth the visit . No wonder this place is rated in the top 5 of best cemeteries in the world. Well worth a visit, plan on spending a couple of hours.
Fascinating. This was a fascinating place to visit. The tombs are so different and interesting, and there is a market outside the entrance.

Very impressive architecture. The architecture in this cemetery is very impressive. Various families have impressive tombs and many different styles for their families. Some of these tombs are very well kept while others need much work. Of course, the most famous tomb is of Eva Peron. However, one should take the time out and just walk among the many different styles of tombs. Very worthwhile place to visit.
Don't Miss Ricoleta Cemetay. Unbeatable Buenos Aires experience. Great history and beautiful. The architecture is amazing, and it is so peaceful.

A place to die for a visit. A very beautiful cemetery for some ofthe rich and famous BA porteno families. There are lots of beautiful sculptures. Of course, one of the main attraction here is evita's resting place with her family (not peron).
This place is overcrowded by the living (tourists) and deceased masoleums.

Well worth a visit. We were lucky enough to have 5 days in Buenos Aires. On day 4 we visited this famous cemetery. My main reason for going was to see Evita's tomb, but I found myself intrigued by the many different, ornate tombs. I read what I could about the inhabitants of the tombs and their families. Fascinating! It was blazing hot while we were there, however we managed to spend an hour or so, wandering the maze of tombs. In cooler weather, I could see myself spending even more time as the architecture itself is intriguing. Upon leaving, we walked under the 200+ year old tree, Gomero De La Recoleta, and sat at an outdoor café, La Biela, located in the shade of the tree. We cooled ourselves with a fresh lemon juice and soda water. Don't miss Recoleta Cemetery, it's worth the visit.

Fascinating. Thought it a bit odd that the first thing anyone tells you to do in buenos Aires is to see the cemetery but now I understand. What an amazingly interesting and weirdly fascinating place. Resting place of "Evita" The whole place is wall to wall mausoleums with many of them not locked or just wired shut. Definitely a must see.

Well worth a visit. It is free. Great place to visit and see all the different types of graves. Evita is buried here, look for the crowd of people, but it moves quickly down the narrow passage. There are tours, but you need to check in advance for times.

Got to see Evita's grave. Evita was such a major influence to Argentina and has such an unbelievable fate since her death, that you just have to see her final resting place. Cemetery is similar to others around the world, but it's inhabitants make it historic and worth a few minutes to see. But have a guide to tell you all the interesting stuff as otherwise you'd just wander around and miss a lot.

Interesting. An interesting place to visit and it was really useful having our tour guide take us through to explain it. A good snapshot of the history and how the wealthy used it in the past. It is w visit you should make in Buenos Aires.

A must see on your trip to Buenos Aires. Amazing architecture with a wide variety of styles. There are some beautiful graves with a lot of details that tell the story of several generations. Peaceful and special place

Impressive cemetery. The cemetery is very impressive and looks more like an open air museum than a cemetery. the tombs are amazing, and for europeans, can be a bit 'creepy'. in each sepulture, you can clearly see the coffins and some of them really look like little bedrooms as they're so well decorated and looked after.You could spend hours in there if you wanted to but obvioulsy, most of the people go there to visit Evita's tomb, there was even a line when we got there.There's a map a the entrance of the cemetery so you can easily find where her tomb is located.

The place to try and take it with you...!. The remains of Eva Peron lie in the family vault in Recoletta, but the symbolism and architecture in this most unusual place tells the visitor much about the history and culture of the Argentine capital.Wherever you look, there is evidence of great wealth, with each mausoleum seemingly trying to outdo the next and standing as an eternal testament to the greatness of the families housed within.The hotch potch of styles gives a surreal air to Recoleta and the overall grandeur is quite awe inspiring. Definitely worth a visit.

Walk through history.. This cemetery has many famous buried there - among them Evita Peron. As you enter there is an info center and a map listing those (famous) entombed. Sort of eerie (it is a cemetery after all). Lots of history.

A must. When you are in Buenos Aries is to visit the Recoleta Cemetery,I was on an Evita tour so it was important to visit .Interesting different architecture of the tombs of the richest people of the area ,in times gone by .Our tour guide was excellent and pointed out some of the more important graves ,vaults and tombs .She explained some of the symbolic signs on the graves.It is busy because of so many tourists wanting to visit .Be aware of pickpocketers outside while waiting to go in !!!!
Waw. Just walk around and get lost. I really enjoyed walking without knowing where I am and finally I found Evita's tomb
Large monument and Eva Peron. This is where Eva Peron is buried. It is a large free cemetery with very large monuments. If you like to visit cemeteries then probably need to see this one.

A cemetery you see once in a lifetime!. This is a must see when visiting Argentina. Beautiful architecture with a wide variety of styles. Don't be afraid to peek in some of the vaults. Try to see this with a tour guide to enhance the experience.

Very cool Site. I could have wandered around this cemetery all day. After the hustle and bustle of the city, this was a great place to walk around and take in the mausoleums of some of the city's once wealthiest citizens. Some tombs are newer than others, but all are interesting. If you are a photographer, go later in the day for the best lighting (it closes at 5pm).

City of the Dead. This cemtary has to be seen to be believed. The family tombs are as large as small dwellings and are designed to look like houses and palaces, crammed together along a warren of streets. You can wander for hours here, reading the inscriptions and looking at the photos.
Interesting, but not worth a great deal of time. We visited the cemetery as part of a BA city tour. While interesting from a historical perspective, I wouldn't make this a goal for a single outing.

Worth a visit. I don't usually like tourist spots, but there aren't many places like this in the world. Although we had been here years ago, we came again and waited for the tour in English. On a wicked hot day the tour was worth it, short, and informative.This cemetery was created in 1822 and it is unusual in structure and beauty. Well worth a few hours.

Excellent visit for a cemetery. Was not keen on visiting a cemetery while on holiday but thought this was a must do while in Buenos Aires. We visited with organised tour which on this occasion was probably the right choice as Evitas tomb would be hard to find especially with my limited Spanish.Beautiful architecture the only place I could compare it with was when i visited a cemetery in New Orleans but this is on a much grander scale.

A cemetery that takes you back to more affluent times. A great experience. This cemetery is the current resting place of Evita but apart from that it has a plethora of decorated mosoleums. The decoration and designs can keep you interested for hours.
truly unique. Fascinating. Truly unique. Closest would be the cemetery in New Orleans. There are English-speaking guides available at a reasonable cost. Admission to the cemetery itself is free.
Amazing Cemetery. This is where Eva Peron is buried. Some magnificent tombs - have never seen anything like it. Well worth a visit.
Intreated in history..... This was a interesting area is visit for it showed the culture of the most elite and wealthy of BA member of history. This is best done well before the heat of the day.... !
Piece of Argentina's history . An interesting place to see the many elaborate tombs and tombstones and learn about many eminent families, of course the most famous one being Evita's.
A n interesting place of History.. This was very interesting and a way to learn a lot about their history. Easy to find and get to on foot or public transport.

Looking from my hotel window I could see this cemetery and was inspired to get a closer look. Having been all over the world, I had never saw anything like this before! Cemeteries in the US have more space between the headstones - these grand displays are all on top of each other. The beautiful workmanship on these pieces of art are worth seeing once.

You've never seen a cemetery like it!. One of the main attractions in BA, Recoleta Cemetery is a remarkable cemetery. More like s small suburb with mausoleums above ground and configured into streets, it's quite astonishing to see. You feel like you are walking through a neighbourhood. And of course Evita Peron's family site is there. Her name was Duarte so look for that. A mua see in BA.

Even our kids were impressed:-). Our two kids (6 and 8) had been walking all day, when we decided to visit the recoleta. And we were really impressed. We didn't see the whole recoleta but we looked into lots of graves and we found evitas. There is a very much history you can talk to your children about when you walk around the graves. And our children would like to go back someday

Fascinating window into Argentinian life and death. Visit a cemetery? Yes you should! Located in the Recoleta neighborhood, it contained many ornate and beautiful mausoleums, many of which you peer into. The basements of some are visible through the doors and you can see the coffins of the generations lined up. The place contains the final resting place of any number of Argentinian presidents and other notables, including Eva Peron (Evita). It is free to enter. We purchased a map as we entered and it was very helpful in directly us to some of the most famous of the tombs.
Where is Evita's?. Hard to find her family tomb if you do not have a guide, not well marked at the entrance. Turn left and it is about 7 rows ahead. Very interesting place to visit and it is free!

Spot Eva Peron's memorial. This cemetery was so interesting. We didn't take a guided tour although they were free but wandered around on our own reading the inscriptions. Eva Peron's memorial is not that easy to find because it's not the most obvious one, but worth the effort.
Evita. An extraordinary cemetery, because of the people buried over there, Evita Peron, but also the cemetery itself. Very interesting.

Unique Cemetary. In the heart of Recoleta, opposite a shopping mall, surrounded by a high brick and stucco wall is small city of magnificent necropolis. Statues of angels or replicas of who lies within crown many. Evita Peron lies with her family here but even if she wasn't, this is worth your time.Guides are avaiable and I am sure have great stories of some of the "residents" but we just wandered around on our own.
Great way to get lost for an afternoon. Neat cemetery that seems to go on forever. Some very impressive tombs and monuments in the cemetery. Nice to walk and explore. Plus it's free!

One of the main attraction of BA. Incredible place. Full of history and ‪intrigue, definitely worth walking for at least half an hour... In front of the entrance, slightly to the right, crossing the plaza, in front of cafe: la viela, is another astonishing thing to see, a giant "gomero" tree. Both unique things to see, death & life.

In the middle of the town. Is like a museum,the Cementery perhaps most famous in AmericaMick Jagger was in Argentina with The Rolling Stones and you can see a picture of him in all the newspapers walking in the Cementery.it,s really an amazing attraction.
Fascinating place to visit. Of course the big draw is the grave of Eva Peron, but this was a wonderful afternoon excursion with a fascinating guide.

Interesting. If a cemetery can possibly be interesting Recoleta certainly is. If a cemetery can be "upscale" Recoleta is. Folks are just "dying" to get it. Beautiful mausoleums with interesting architecture.

Every BA tourist has to visit ONCE. Every BA tourist has to visit this famous landmark. Nothing quite like it anywhere else. No trip to BA is complete without a look see to include a stop at Evita Peron's final resting place.

See Duarte Mausoleum First. This is an amazing cemetery and every walkway has fascinating people. You really need a guide to help with all the back-stories like the lady who was buried alive, the girl dying in an avalanche on her honeymoon, the Naval Captain who's daughter committed suicide after her fiancé's untimely death etc. And of course the final resting place of Eva Peron! I'm not sure how you can find out, but best to avoid this place when cruise ships are in town! On a non-cruise-day this is a peaceful place to browse and plenty of time to visit Eva Peron - on the day we arrived, 6 or more cruise groups were touring the site and they took forever to pass Evita's grave! Wished our tour guide had changed his tour and taken us to visit her first before the crowds....
Great Historic Place. Great Historic Place where some of the most importart politians are buried. Very beaituful monuments

Interesting!. An extraordinary place to walk through. From the opulent and crass mausoleums to the forgotten and neglected ones, with coffins spilling out. A little bit of history with Evita Peron's remains interred in the Duarte family mausoleum.

Attractive Cemetery. Very interesting place to stroll and photograph. We went one evening shortly before closing and again the following morning before the tour groups arrived. It's a peaceful and well-maintained place with very interesting and differing tombs.

Steeped in history. A wonderful experience, walking through the maze of incredibly opulent mausoleums. A throw back to how the rich, famous and infamous of Buenos Aries were buried and honored. Absolute must for all visitors to this beautiful city.

Fascinating on several levels.. Recoleta Cemetery is one of the more unique cemeteries I've visited (and I've visited a lot of them). At first glance, it is somewhat reminiscent of the grand tombs of New Orleans or London's Highgate Cemetery's Circle of Lebanon. But these tombs in Recoleta - instead of being walled up - often have either iron gates or glass doors and you can see the coffins and urns sitting on display. In many, you can see down narrow staircases into the depths of the mausoleums and see how well (or not) the unknowing occupants have been tended to. Some of the architecture is amazing and the styles are very eclectic. The state of repair varies quite a bit: we actually saw one with iron gates that had a couple of busted coffins (sans body parts, at least that we could see!) haphazardly stored. That was a bit strange, but I guess living family members are responsible for the upkeep as Recoleta Cemetery doesn't charge entry fees and - as far as I can tell - is still actively taking on new "tenants." We walked around the place on our own; we had to go find someone selling inexpensive guides because it's difficult to find any particular grave just wandering. We went to find boxer Luis Firpo's tomb (found it, with the map) and, of course, we stopped by Eva Peron's tomb, even though it isn't all that fascinating if you're not a fan. There really were some impressive art pieces here and it's an interesting sociological view of how BA treated some of their richest and mightiest in death. If you're a fan of cemeteries, architecture, or Peron, I'd say it's a must see.

Stunning cemetery. Not going to lie... Eva Peron could have done so much better. Their tomb was super understated compared to some of the others located here. Needless to say it was an experience just being there in the presence of greatness. I enjoyed walking around and seeing all the different tombs and it was pretty easy to avoid people as they were mostly just looking for Evita.
Join the rest of the tourists to see Evita's grave. A tourist spot - nothing more. Unless you like going to places to join bus load of tourists, I wouldn't bother. there is nothing to see here.

Incredible experience . I would have never thought I'd be writing a review recommending travellers to visit this place but you won't regret going there. It's incredible experience and one of its kind.

Interesting experience. Cemeteries are not normally on my list of must see sites but this is an exception. This experience gives you another perspective of Buenos Aires and is definitely worth a couple of hours of your time. On the way there our driver took us through several parks with beautiful monuments and outdoor art.

INTERESTING. The walk will take time, but you will discover the cult of the dead lived in opulence in the early twentieth century in Buenos Aires.
Many sculptures in marble of first quality, and many tributes to the aristocracy that ruled the nation.
The popular tomb of Evita, mixed in an environment that was not her.

An unusual and amazing free attraction. This is an incredible place. You need a guide to take you through as things could easily be missed. A great collection of tombs. Many of the works of art. I was a little underwhelmed with Evitas tomb I expected it to be grand. Some of the tombs are in need of restoration which is why next year an entrance fee will be charged. I would definitely pay to see theses weird and wonderful burial chambers

An interesting way to spend eternity. We visited Recoleta Cemetery in the hot month of February. The tombs alone were fascinating. Some were vandalized where you could see the coffins and urns in their subterranean niches. A tribute to wealth and fame but not eternal privacy. Worth the trip.

Evita's Buried here. This place is great. You have tons of famous Argentine's buried here along with Evita. You can wonder around and just take in this gorgeous cemetery. I recommend the tour a bit pricey but perhaps you can negotiate the price.

The Cemetery that always sleeps. So fantastical is Recoleta Cemetery that a visit here is essential for all tourists and travellers. It is a graveyard, but one with magnificent architecture dating back to 1880 challenging eternity - eclipsing the protestant cemetery in Rome, the Jewish cemetery in Prague, and on a par with Pere Lachaise in Paris. Here are mausoleum follies and huge tombs above catacombs, decorated with fine sculpture in stone and bronze. They house the remains of politicians, statesmen and women, military leaders and artists. It is an almost death-defying collection of buildings and history. A tip - arrive early, bring a snack, drink, sun protection, your camera, binoculars if you have them, a cushion - and take time to wander and sit. Take a guided tour (with excellent guides) or allow at the very least an hour for a DIY tour; and do not stay on the tourist trail to the Peron tomb - take the side turnings and take time to ponder. Look upwards to see some extremely fine carving, and glance downwards to the turned stairs to underground chambers. Some of the finest detail is where you would least expect it. You should also look out for the book Cementerio de la Recoleta - Fotografias by Cecilia Pastore as a memento of your visit. When you are finished, head to La Biela - at 2 o'clock across the park for refreshment and another of Buenos Aires' must-do experiences.

A must see!. What a wonderful cemetery, like a movie scene! I spent hours here (on two occations) walking around, peeling into the crypts, reading the memorial signs. You'll find Evita here as well, her grave being a bit modest compered to many others. This is a must see when in Buenos Aires! Highly recommended!
Interesting Cemetery and History. We had a wonderful guide to show us around this interesting cemetery. She gave us lots of information.

Highlight of our visit. Went to the Recoleta Cemetery early in the morning so avoided the crowds. Very important. We wandered among the tombs enjoying the different architectural styles and memorials to people of the past. Hard to find the Evita tomb. We were told to just follow the crowds but there were´t crowds. It´s not very special anyway. Some of the tombs were clearly loved still and others quite neglected. A real eclectic mix of everything and definitely worth a visit.

Strangely amazing. I wasn't keen on going to a cemetery , but am so glad I went it was outstandingly beautiful. The tombs dedicated to while families and the history and detail is simply amazing. I was shocked at how nice it was to think that people took care of the dead so well!

Pretty Cool. As one of the main tourist attractions in the city, you owe it to yourself to go and meander around in it for a while. I went with my father and we wandered around for around 90 minutes, after that it all started to blur together. It is one of the prettiest cemeteries I've been too and there was a lot of variance in the tombs. Perhaps knowing a little history on it would have added to the experience, but overall you can give yourself a tour and be just fine. Bring some water with you as there is not much to purchase nearby for reasonable prices. Really easy to photograph a lot of different religious icons in one day.

Not creepy at all. You can wander here for hours. Very interesting to see all the Tombs and crypts. Interesting architectural designs build all around them. Some are still in good shape, other are in disrepair for lack of family upkeep.
You will even find Eva Perons burial space here.
Worth the trip.
Worth a look. I didn't plan to visit this place. It was suggested by my guide and I'm glad I did. Amazing construction and nice to view Evita's tombstone.
Evita's rsting place!. It is Eva Peron's Resing place in the Duarte cript!! Not where she wanted to be as she did not like her family!
Meh.... It's a cemetery. Lot of dead people crammed together in an eclectic mess! I guess a little more knowledge of Argentinian history may have helped...

A must see!. This was a unique experience !WE have seen the above ground cemeteries in New Orleans but Recoleta is amazing! However it is best to use one the guides at the front gate--- we used English speaking Raul-- the price was reasonable and he gave us a tour and understanding of these mausoleums we would not have gathered just from on viewing on our own !

The grandest cemetery in the world. This blew me away. The location is perfect as it is in Recoleta where some of the best restaurants in Buenos Aires are located so you you can have a spot of lunch or a coffee and wander in. I went to see Eva Peron's grave and just look around in awe of the monuments to some of Argentina's most famous people's burial sites. It is so grand you should not think of it as morbid, it's quite an experience, you don't feel death here more of acclamation for what they must have been or achieved when alive. It is quite big and almost like a maze at times.

Nice place to kill the time. Good thing is FREE of charge. For "Muertos" lovers it is entertaining, but for those who could care less but appreciate the architectural side of it - is a great place to spend your free time and burn some calories in walking between the mausoleums.

An interesting collection of mausolems. There is a great diversity of mausolems here, with families trying to outshine each others vaults. Most are well kept up, some not so much. Many well known Argentinians such as Evita are buried here. Despite the unusual nature of this attraction it is an important part of local history and well worth a visit.

Resting place for th great and good. We arrived in Buenos Aries and had a wander down to Recoleta. The cemetery is a very interesting place itself. It is home to the great and good of BA. Eva Peron's final resting place is there but there are many other interesting tombs to explore. The cemetery is nothing like an English cemetery. The tombs are extremely ornate and most are well kept. Well worth spending an hour or two wondering round.
Must see. I love cemeteries and this is my absolute favorite!! You can spend many hours here the architecture of the mausoleums is so fantastic!

Get a good guide - It's worth it. Very nice to stroll around and look at all the graves in the cementary. However it get's way much better if you have a guide that knows the story and the persons in the tombs. Choice wisely, we got a guide with limited English language ability which did that the experience was ok but you didn't get the extra stories and couldn't ask to many questions. Try to catch an official tour.
Grand Place. Situated in the district of Recoleta, this is a place worth visiting only to see how grand the headstones can be. Famous personalities are in here.An abode of peace.

Resting place of Ev a Peron. Very interesting necropolis. Interesting people buried here, professors, Drs, military. Not a resting place for the average person. We walked to the cemetery from Palmero. Really nice walk, flat And interesting things to see. Lots of places..most touristy around the cemerty to have a drink or something to eat. Easy walk from here to Teatro Colon.

A unique cemetery. The cemetery in Recoleta is indeed one of those "should-visit" places of Buenos Aires. It is a unique place and definitely worth a visit, even though it feels a bit strange that a cemetery has been turned into a tourist attraction. No RIP for these folks.
A "Must" as a visitor . This is the perfect way to spend a hour or two. You can feel the history. The stories behind the different tombs make this destination hauntingly beautiful.
Must not miss. You can certainly spend a lot of time here. Beautiful mausolems and tributes. Also, amazing architecture and symbolism.Evita is in the Duarte family tomb. Very touching monument.

Better than New Orleans. The tombs here are more ornate and nicer than in New Orleans, the only place I have seen with this sort of cemetery. This easily beats New Orleans. Artisans no longer exist to make these kinds of tombs, so they say.

Quite a revelation. Who would have thought a cemetery could be so interesting! We visited with a guide, who was 'muy porteno' to the core. Bags of style, exuberance and flowing with information. Of course we did visit Eva Peron's tomb which was interesting. However, the stories surrounding the other lesser known tombs proved to be fascinating. We walked back to the centre of Buenos Aires through streets of beautiful French influenced architecture. A great way to spend a Saturday morning in BA.

Cool photo ops, unique, but wasn't for me . Admittedly the Recoleta is a pretty special place that I've never seen anything like. The rows of giant sculptures never seem to end and it's a place for some cool photos. For me though, at the end of the day it is just walking around large graves of some rich and powerful people who I know very little about (with the exception of Eva Peron). However I can see how for another person this may be a highlight

Worth having a guide. Quite extraordinary. A major display of power and wealth by 19th and twentieth century Argentinians. It really is an amazing place. It is quite a rabbit warren so I would recommend a guide. The church next door is also well worth a visit.
Awesome!. A must see when in B.A.! My partner didn't see the point of going to a cemetery, but we were in there for over 2 hours and he couldn't stop photographing all the mausoleums!

Very Cool Experience. I went there during the day with a couple of my roommates. Without doing very much research we ended up walking around the entire thing before we found the entrance. There is very little signage to tell you where to go but once we found it the experience was well worth it. Very cool experience and I would definitely recommend it. I wouldn't pay for a tour, do some research about whose graves you want to see and where they are located instead.

Interesting visit. It was a muggy Sunday in February when I decided to catch a subway and walk about 20 minutes to get to the cemetery - it seemed to be a quieter day to visit. I spent about an hour at the cemetery, followed by a respite at the local Starbucks to recover from the heat. The cemetery is very beautiful, took me a while to find Eva Peron´s crypt but eventually followed a large enough group to the right spot! I would advise spraying yourself with mosquito repellant when you go though. I was wearing long trousers and the critters attacked my ankles. I did see a sign up at the cemetery about precautions against Dengue Fever, not sure if this was overkill (pardon the pun) or good instructions. Anyway, I survived the trip to the cemetery in the end!

Well worth seeing!. Have been today and it is an amazing place to visit. It's free to go in but it's well worth buying a map of the cemetery for 20 pesos just so you can find the crypts. The lady selling the maps is a character and seems to be able to speak any language. This place is well worth a visit...Also called in a the church next door which was once lived in by the friars, and again worth going to see.

Interesting and a bit weird. This is one of the main tourist attractions of Recoleta. It's full of mauseleums of the rich and famous of BA. It's a bit show-off and can make you feel a bit strange looking at lots of coffins. But it's interesting! Find Pellegrini's huge imposing tomb and then compare it to Evitas.
Beautiful architecture. If you're in the mood to see some beautifully designed tombs/cemeteries this is a great place for a stroll if you're in the neighborhood.

Amazing!. Totaly amazing experience! So much history and a well kept area. The Eva Perron grave is to see! A must see place if you are in the Recoleta area! Also so many things of interest to see around...like the old chapel next to the cemetary and the many flee market kiosks in the adjacent park! Lovely area!

Huge Crypts..Eva Peron resting place. We stayed in Recoleta overlooking the cemetery. I found out that there was English speakingtours twice a week so we went on that. It was free admittance but the guide informed us that the trust was going to start charging entrance fees so that they can restore the monuments that were no longer being maintained by the families as they had all died off.Saw Eva Peron crypt she is is her family crypt as her body was hidden for 20 years after she died. the whole story is fascinating. Saw a tribute a father made to his daughter who had a bronze Statue made of her in her wedding dress whth her favourite dog. She was 26 when she was killed by an avalanche.

Walking with the dead. For some reason, I enjoy cemeteries as a way to connect with the past. La Recoleta cemetery tells the stories of rich and famous like Eva Peron and many others who carved the Argentinian history. This place is a town of luxurious graves, statues , and monuments celebrating the life of the dead. Even if not a fan of tombstones, a must see.
An elegent eternal address. An absolute must if your are visiting Buenos Aires and the Recoleta area. Never saw a cemetery like this one.

Eva Peron's Family Crypt. To be totally honest; I am not an aficionado on Argentina's history. There are many famous dignitaries entombed here I know; the most obvious one being Maria Eva Duarte de Peron; which we duly visited. The mausoleum always adorned with flowers and tourists.

Must see when in Buenos Aires. I had a private guide take me here while on my recent trip to Buenos Aires. It was a great place to visit, lovely statues, crypts, mausoleums, etc. All types of different styles and religions represented here. Huge place, only saw a portion of it.

A must see. This was one of the top ten sites recommended by my guide book but as an aficionado of interesting cemeteries, I needed no encouragement! Well worth a visit, not just for the family vault which is the final resting place for Eva Peron.

People dying to get into this place. A large cemetery with some very interesting mausoleums. Just walked around and view a small portion of this large place. Ideal to visit with a tour guide so they can share some of the history and anecdotal stories of those buried in this cemetery. Worth a visit if in BA.

A fascinating trip down memory lane. This cenetary has lots of historical reference points to discover - my recommendation is that it is really helpful to have a guide as the ares is vast and it would be easy to miss what you are looking for. Also a guide will have the political background which makes it more interesting. The graves of Eva Peron and WQilliam brown are located in this cemetery..

Would be creepy at night!. We only spent about an hour, checked our Evita's resting place, which is with her family, easy to find. Amazing place though. Outside check out the massive fig tree supported by concrete pillars. We were unsure about the taxi situation to take us back to the hotel - Radio Taxis vs non radio taxis so we walked up the street a block and flagged one down
AMAZING. I don't like cemeteries because of what they symbolize but this cemetery was amazing. All the mausoleums were so rich in architecture and history.
Cementery, history plus Art.... One of the best cementery all over the world. Take a tour with a guide, amazing stories. Beautiful place and mystic.
Big honchos resting place.. If you know a little about Argeninas history, you will love this place. Even Evita is resting there. Many interesting monuments, some very high quality and interesting.

Ornate cemetary...not particularly well maintained. A definite must if you want to see Eva Peron's space...just look for the long lines. Big, full of elaborate tombs and edifices. Worth a walk through, but it has not been maintained very well. Hugely popular, so expect big crowds.

peaceful recollection spot. a quiet stroll among the beautifully crafted tomb stones of the aristocratic families of Buenos Aires will not be complete without a quick stop at Evita's place of burial... truly memorable
A day in the cemetery. Great tours in English and Spanish. Take about an hour. Bring water and wear a hat it gets very hot.

Interesting. We were taken here as part of a tour of Buenos Aires. The mausoleums were interesting to read and unusual features on them, some were part of a story. We were shown Ava Peron's family crypt and her plaque near the bottom. The tour guide told us Andrew Lloyd Webber had made the cemetery a tourist attraction!
Very interesting cemetary. One can spend hours here, admiring the architecture and learning about the history. This is a most beautiful cemetery; we were glad that we found it.
Fascinating and beautiful cemetery. This was the last stop on our 1/2 day tour and well worth seeing. Amazing history and architecture of the tombs. A tiny city.

Very interesting and different . We visited the cemetery and were amazed at the beauty of the graves and mausoleums. We saw Eva Peron's resting place, but there were many more interesting plots to look at. Great for a wander around.

A 'must see' if you are interested in art and history. On my second visit to Buenos Aires, this was the only 'sight' that I returned to. It helps if you like cemeteries and monumental and religious art and I recommend leaving any grizzly kids or teens (if they do not like religious art or history) back in the hotel. The day I visited was also super hot, and this place has limited vegetation and rows upon rows of concrete passages that radiate the heat - so take water. The cemetary itself is the most amazing place to take pictures, and quite restful as it has a few seats and a few big trees in the central 'street' so you can sit down and rest when the heat gets too much.

Great trip through Argentine history!. It's creepy to say you went to a cemetery to sight see but this one has some of the major figures in Argentine history! Most notorious is Eva Peron. If you are into historic figures, then this is the place for you!

Interesting but not amazing. Its an interesting place to have a look around, but at the end of the day its just a cemetery. Can get very hot in the middle of the day so I recommend visiting in the morning or afternoon so you have some shade
Ornate vaults reasonable kept. Never that intrested in cementries but ornate vaults and some modern -conrete & glass. Take paper for the toilet!
Wonderful site to visit in BA. Everyone should make the trip to the Recoleta Cemetary during their visit to BA.So much fun looking for Evita s grave and the neighborhood is wonderful as well.

So good I visited twice. A visit to the Recoleta Cemetery was part of a free tour. The guide gave a good description of its history and its many famous residents.On a rainy day with cloudy sky, I returned to the Cemetery in an early morning. With the moody lighting, wet monuments and no other visitors in sight, the Cemetery had a very different atmosphere. With only a few feral cats as company, I strolled through every alley and photographed to my heart's content.The free admission makes this one of the best values in BsAs,
Experiencing Recoleta Cemetery. A must visit when in Buenos Aires. It contains Eva Peron's final resting place and provides a glimpse into Buenos Aires' rich history.

Eva Peron's Resting site. Eva's site is very simple compared to the aristocrats that build large rooms with altars and statues. Free to get in, the sites are 'purchased' like real estate and they pay land taxes and have 'housekeepers' that keep the site clean. Some are abandoned with family lines coming to an end. They have doors hanging off with the coffin in sight and even the coffin is falling apart.Eva is buried on the bottom under 2 other coffins for protection of her body. Usually the higher status you are, the higher up in the tomb.

Wow! What a suprise. Definitely worth a visit when in BA. Not like any other cemetery in Australia. we visited on a Saturday expecting to just see rows of headstones. This cemetery is full of elaborate statues and huge marbel carved memorials. Lots of tourists but this doesnt matter as you can lose yourself in the Labyrinth of graves and statues. A must see to believe.
If you have to visit Evita's grave. If you absolutely have to visit Evita's grave and don't mind fighting your way through the masses then go there.

Stunning family tombs in heart of city. Every style of architecture is captured in the cemetery. Like in New Orleans the tombs are all built above ground. They can't be more than one storey but that hasn't stopped wealthy families over the years competing for the largest or most ornate structure. Definitely worth an hour to mooch around.

Amazing and a little creepy. We went here because it was across the street from out hotel- so glad we did!! The history, the stories, the pictures- we spent hours wandering around in this cometary.
