The tombs are amazing!! Sadly, they only have guided tours on Tuesdays and Thursdays- would have loved to learn more!! Some of the tombs are is sad disrepair- one casket was partially open- that was creepy! Of course, after seeing that I kept expecting a hand to grab me from the tomb!

It's All About Evita. People visit Pere Lachaise in Paris for Jim Morrison. People visit Recoleta for Evita. The Cemetery is a mini-history of Argentina for those who understand it. Social climbers have being buried in Recoleta as "their final goal." The streets and alleyways of the Cemetery have some interesting stories, and some of the family mausoleums plainly cost more than most Buenos Aires houses. It's on most "to do" lists, but unless you are devoted to checking all the boxes, your life won't be incomplete if you miss it.

Interesting Place to Visit. The cemetery contains some 14 acres of family funerary vaults. Most are very well maintained, others not so. Many coffins are visible within crypts. For Argentinian's, there are many notables such as Presidents, military heroes and artists who have been laid to rest here. A free guided tour in English was available at 1100 which would have been useful if we had realised. The notable and absolute "must find" is the vault containing Eva Peron (Evita). She is within her brother in law's family vault - the Duarte vault. We, probably like others were not able to locate the vault. We watched for a large tour group and tagged along. Sure enough, within minutes, we were lined up and able to pass by the vault. Well worth a visit.

Just as well they did not take their wealth with them!. The cemetery is full of elaborate marble mausoleums, decorated with statues, in varied architectural styles (Art Deco, Art Nouveau, Baroque, and Neo-Gothic) and with tombs constructed from imported material from Paris and Milan. The entire cemetery is laid out in sections like city blocks, with wide tree-lined main walkways branching into sidewalks filled with mausoleums.Many of the mausoleums are well-maintained but others have fallen into disrepair.The free tour in English (11:00 Tuesdays and Thursdays) lasted an hour and a half and is informative and a great foundation for repeated visits to explore the walkways on your own.Those who were planning on being interned here or were interned by supporters or in family mausoleums ensured that their money and status was reflected in the grandiose styles and materials. As each mausoleum remains the private property of the family and the upkeep and maintainance needs to be paid for by them it is just as well that the interned did not take all their wealth with them!

It's not macabre to visit here. It's like wandering through an historic neighborhood. Each building is owned by the family, just like other property. They pay property taxes. And, each one is individualized. Every building style is represented here. If you are into architecture, plan to spend hours roaming the 'streets'!

interesting place. I usually don't lie cemeteries. I think it's eerie, but this cemetery was very interesting. It's astounding the amount of money there must have been in the buenos aires society in the days... anybody who was anybody in society must be buried here. It's almost like a little city of dead rich and famous people of Buenos Aires. Of course, Evita Person's tomb was the most attended
Beautiful Cemetery. Beautiful monuments and architectures! Very impressive! Such a wonderful and peaceful place. Historical too. It was nice to see Evita Duarte Peron's tomb there as well.

Find a guide ... It is well worth it. We spent a highly interesting and informative 2 hours at Recoleta Cemetery learning some fascinating stories about some of the movers and shakers of Argentinian life over the past couple of centuries.We found out English speaking guide, Simon, inadvertently. We bought a water and a strangely familiar accent explained that would be 25 pesos.One thing led to another and found out Simon was a full time tour guide and we took him up on his offer, along with 3 Dutch / Belgian air stewardesses.The guide really add so much value to the experience. It elevates from an exercise in how fancy one mausoleum is from another and where is Evita ... To a series of interesting facts and anecdotes about the people and families who the mausoleums represent. For a honesty donation, upgrade your experience
Not an ordinary cemetery . The place is grand and beautiful. There is a free tour on Tue and Thur at 11am. Nice walk and it's free, so it's hard to get it wrong.

A different visit. It seems weird to go to a cemetery , but I was amazed at the marble statues , doors , ironworks and the different types of monuments there wee. For a photographer, it is a must. If you get squeamish around cemeteries, don't go. If you really want to see something different, go and see this vast area.

View of the dead rather than the living. The visit was part of a city tour and mildly interesting from our point view for the architecture of the crypts rather than anything else. If you are into the Eva Peron thing then I suppose it is rather like visiting a shrine but not for me. It is enclosed by high rise buildings on three sides and frankly I found it all rather odd and sad. For me not a place I would have chosen to visit had I the choice.Personally I favour the living rather than the dead and was pleased that the tour moved on.

Fantastic . It was so fascinating to explore this huge example of " trying to keep up with the Joneses". We walked down every row. Indifferent to Eva's crypt although the controversy around it is interesting. Some beautiful things to see in this cemetery.

Fascinating and Macabre but you probably need a guide. This place is huge and is a maze, it is fascinating walking around on your own and you can do this but I would advise that you get a tour guide to take you around because otherwise you get no idea what anything means or who the people are. There are no explanation plaques and if you are looking for Evita's grave then forget it if you are free styling it. It took us a few hours of walking to find her grave and then it was only by chance. So a great place but would buy a book with map or hire a guide next time around.

Interesting designs. Beautifully designed crypts and statuary highlight this very popular tour with the main site being Eva Peron's grave.Students of architecture will love this and our guide was great in showing us the highlights and telling us some of the sad stories behind some of the family history.It's crowded with lots of tour groups as well as locals paying their respects. ** Tour guide warned us about pickpockets.

Good if you like cenetarurs. There are some famous people buried here, like Evita, but her sign is not very prominent. Bottom right of her family's tomb. If you don't care for cemeteries, don't go, but if you do, this is definitely unique.

Getting run down, but still fascinating. We took a short personal tour of the cemetery and learned how deep the tombs went, even saw into some as they were being cleaned. Several tombs are falling in to disrepair and the cemetery will start charging admission in March 2016 (we were told) to help with refurbishment costs. Of course we visited Evita's tomb; she is still venerated in Argentina.

Angels and Demons. This cemetery is a maze of eclectic religious architecture, historical persons of note and close maze-like streets. If you have spent some time in Buenos Aires, you may recognize the names on tombs as matching those on many streets in the city. Unlike anything I have seen before, I was in awe.
a Must-see in Buenos Aires. This cemetery is the last place of rest to most Argentinian heroes, personalities and historic characters (the best know is Eva peron).

Beautiful cemetary. The cemetary includes row upon row of beautiful and elaborate tombs and crypts, including that of Eva Duarte, also know as Eva Perron or Evita. There are other interesting and beautiful crypts and trees. You can take a paid tour but otherwise the entrance is free.

It is just a cemetery.... I still do not understand how a cemetery could be the most visited place in a big city like Buenos Aires. Apart from the "voyeurist" attraction of Evita's grave, it is just a cemetery, where the really only interesting thing could be the sculptures decorating the graves.

Very beautiful, architecture and history both. I love walking in cemeteries, and Recoleta may be the most beautiful "City of the Dead" I have ever seen. Anyone interested in Art Deco and Art Nouveau will find much to appreciate, and many of the statues and bronzes are lovely without any regard to history. But with the history this makes an excellent introduction to Argentine history. Yes, too much attention is paid to the Duarte family tomb and Evita overall, but there is so very much more here! And it is unique. I have been to cemeteries all over the world and this one is right at the top of the list.

Buenos Aires sight Not to be missed. Few cemeteries around the world are worth a visit. This is one. Better to have a guide or book to inform you of the features, history, and customs. You will remember this cemetery.
Very Cool. We came here on a bike tour. We were told about Evita, and many other interesting stories about the cemetery and those buried there.

One of a kind experience. I'm a big fan of going to cemeteries in different parts of the world and this one does not disappoint... It's breathtaking and wonderous. It's not for everyone of course but if you love architecture, sculptures and want to see how another culture memorializes past lives, it's a great adventure.

Beautiful cemetery in Buenos Aires. Worth the visit, the cemetery is surrounded with nice park and a excellent café. It's hard to find the Evita Peron's cemetery, but people are helpful to point it out.
In the dead Centre of BA. Apart from the attraction of Evita's resting place, this is just several avenues of large stone memorials, some less well kept than others.

Very elabprate cemetery- if cemetary tourism is your thing. Kind of a weird tourist attraction, but it works. The tombs are incredibly extravagant and we easily spent an hour or so walking through and viewing the most interesting ones. We passed a few tour groups, who all looked particularly uninspired, so maybe this is one of those places best viewed alone. A 20minute walk from the closest metro station- but it is an interesting walk through the upmarket Recoleta.
a must see. I went there every day for a respite from the city, peaceful and beautiful. Free to get in, there are tours in English one day a week but I just wandered around.

Definitely worth visiting this cemetery. The architecture and sculpture of the various crypts was amazing. I really enjoyed walking around and looking at all of the different styles - some very ornate and some very simple. It's where Evita Peron is buried in her family crypt. There's no charge to visit and you can wander around by yourself. If you want to spend the money, I think you can hire a guide to take you around.
Amazing Cemetery . Very overwhelming with all the monuments and beautiful crypts. We bought a map but still had trouble finding exact tombs. Evita's was easy to find because if the lines to see it.

For cemetery lovers. If you are a gothism lover, then this is one of the best cemeteries in the world to visit. A big minus is that it isn't allowed (or rather: possible) to visit the place when it's dark. It would have been totally cool, but even during the day, it's a pleasant place in which to stroll and explore details!
A must when in BA. A must visit when in Buenos Aires, Evita's resting place and also many other famous Argentinians. Beautiful grounds with amazing architecture on offer.

Not my sort of thing. Before I went I struggled to understand why people want to walk around a cemetery. Afterwards... I still struggle to understand!The place is very unique and I can see the interest in seeing where Eva Peron is laid to rest but that is it. Maybe others see something I don't!

Definitely up there, as far as cemeteries go.. Visiting mid morning the cemetery was fairly quiet and easy to find. We had a pleasant time wandering round and looking for Evita's tomb but upon reflection taking a tour would have been an opportunity to find out some more about the rest of the history as from the snippits we overheard it sounded interesting. The architecture is interesting and varied and the fact that a funeral was taking place as we were leaving brought it back into perspective that it isn't just a tourist attraction.
take the tour. There are so many interesting vaults with hsitorical importance, it is important to take the tour. It is a great way to spend an hour. Afterward you can wander around by yourself.

Iconic and a must: history, architecture and art!. The Recoleta Cemetery, besides the uneducated comments of the Brazilians, is absolutely brilliant.A National museum in the open air, it features mausoleums like the ones you could find in Père Lachaise, with great architecture in Art Noveaux, Modernism and much much moreThe histories behind the graves are equally interesting and tell tales of the Buenos Aires of yore. Great betrayals, moving stories and enemies that were reunited in death.This ia visit that is not vert interesting unless you do it with a good guide, doing the Cemetery for its aesthetical appeal and not for its history is missing out on the really fun, moving and touching stories that you can find behind every tomb.An ABSOLUTE MUST if you visit Buenos Aires

Fascinating experience . The history and architecture within this this cemetery maze was unique in my experience. Our time was limited but I'm certain that one can spend the better part of the day with a knowledgeable guide. Absolutely worth a visit.

Interesting ...and haunted. This is a very large, old cemetery in the middle of the Recoleta district. It's quite large. There's a variety of famous people buried there, including Eva Perone (Evita). Some mausoleums are well kept. Others are in various stages of disrepair. I'd recommend a tour to learn some of the history.For those of you sensitive to different energies, I can tell you that at least a part of this cemetery is haunted. The energy was extremely heavy and very uncomfortable. Some of the spirits aren't friendly. I told my friend and we walked to a different area, & the negativity didn't follow. Unfortunately, I didn't protect myself well enough and woke up the next morning sick. If you're sensitive to energy, take some precautions to protect yourself!

Unique Funereal Culture - a Must on your things to visit. The cemetery visit should be less about the resting place for Evita Peron. The visit is much more striking for the displays that are very different from any we have seen before.

Enormously touching. Walking through the paths between the tombs is a very touching experience. Many are immensely ornate, just a few are tumble-down, with rough brickwork appearing under crumbling marble facades. We spent almost two hours here - photographers' paradise, one could say. Go early in the day if you can, before noisy and irreverent tour groups disturb the peace and do explore some of the side aisles as well as the main pathways: the diversity of the tombs and their contents is amazing. Reading some of the countless commemorative plaques gives a synthesis of the history of this amazing city and of its immense wealth.

Very interesting place to visit!. You definitely need a map to venture around this place and can easily spend the whole day! You can buy a map, or simply take a picture of the map on your phone ;) It's a very peaceful place but busy too. I was lucky enough to see a ceremony, must of been someone famous as there were news vans outside and following them. I don't think you can buy a mausoleum there anymore, just who already paid for a family ahead. Some of the mausoleums are still kept nice and others are broken into and looted, or forgotten.A must see and plan to be there at least half your day, and don't get lost!

Worth a stroll. If you happen to be in the area, then do not miss it. It has a bit of the European cemetery look and feel, so you may not find it so new to you if you have experienced an European old cemetery before. However, if you are into Eve peron's story, you can see where she rests.

The place of rest of Evita Peron. Large Cemetery in Recoleta, famous for being the place of rest of Eva Peron. Her masoleum is very hard to find but ask one of the locals, they wiil know It has oppulent masoleums of the rich families of Argentina and also politicians . But i don't think anyone would go there if Eva Peron was elsewhere!
Beauty beyond words. A beautiful place to wander and get lost. Breathtaking!! The entrance is quite busy but once inside you can walk around and enjoy the peacefulness of the area.

It depends on the guide. I think that it very much depends on the guide whether you think this is good or excellent. We visited the place as part of a greater tour throughout BA. Our guide was a guide for five years in the cemetery and she could tell a load of stories, and not just limited to Evita or the most expensive grave. If you do not have a enthiousiatic guide it is just a boring cemetery that you 'must' do.

Unique Old Cemetary. Walking around this cemetery makes you feel like you're time traveling to the past as you see the unique mausoleums of the important individuals that were apart of Argentina's history. Of course Eva Peron is here and some of the mausoleums are in need of work so some of the coffins are partially exposed. You might think of this as a grim way to spend a day but I found it most interesting as rows and rows produced different and interesting things to look at. Of course this cemetery probably has more stray cats running around then any other place I've seen.
Unique!. One of the must-see locations in Buenos Aires. Fantastic constructions over coffins and graves, including Evita Peron's.

Everone says this is a must see. It certainly was an interesting experience, and very like the cemetery in Montmartre Paris. Some of the mausoleums were partially exposed and old coffins visible. The architectural styles and memorial statues are wonderful and it is an easy walk. Eva Peron mausoleum was not found, check under de Peron on the list at the gate

Interesting & Unique. This cemetery is different from anything you'll see anywhere. The maze of elaborate and distinctive family mausoleums for me was a differentiator for Buenos Aires from other great cities. Definitely unique. I read about the cemetery beforehand, but my wife and I did not use a tour guide. We saw the resting place of quite a few historical figures including of course Evita's tomb, but I suspect a guide would have enhanced the significance of the cultural aspect. An hour is plenty of time to experience the cemetery, but it really is a must see because of it's uniqueness.

Glorious Death. This cemetery is a celebration of death! Highly recommended to spend a few hours getting lost in the maze of alleyways, exploring all the different styles of tombs and memorials. I was so fascinated I had to return to explore more. There are numerous guides offering to give tours, but I managed to wander around exploring on my own, with an occasional eavesdropping to help me gather more information.

Huge mausoleums. Was nice to walk this huge cemetery and see the ornate crypts. Don't miss Evita Peron's final resting place. She was moved around quite a bit after death to avoid her supporters mobbing the place and finally wound up here in the family crypt of her father, Duarte.

Have a guide if you can.. You know it as Evita's resting place. Look for the flowers on her building.It's a small place but a guide will help you find the very unique areas along with what is inside each. We found a discussion of the lease terms and cost interesting.There appeared to be some pickpockets so be careful.

One of the 'must visit' places in Buenos Aires. Everybody visits the cemetery to see Eva Peron's family vault the Duarte's, but the cemetery has dozens of family vaults, some of which are magnificent and some historic to the early days of Argentina as an independent country.
cemetary. great and interesting place to visit,a must visit in my opinion,eva peron is buried there plus many other highlights

Famous and free so worth a visit but didn't blow me away. Located in the most expensive barrio of Buenos aires the Recoleta Cemetery is one of Buenos Aires most famous 'must visit' destinations. My partner and I visited this as part of a day in the Recoleta/Palmero area. You are best of getting the metro 'green line' and getting off at either the Facultad de medicina or Pueyyredon stop and walking from there. After visiting the cemetery I suggest visiting either the Museo Nacional de Bellas Artes OR MALBA > Floralis generalis before tracking home via the closest metro station by walking through one of Palmero's parks.This place is worth visiting both due it's fame the fact that it's free. It's pretty small but surprisingly a bit difficult to navigate so I suggest purchasing the map offered for 20AR. This will also give you a route which incorporates the famous 'Evita' grave - which despite being the most famous, is not the most impressive. The overall site is quite interesting seeing the grandeur and architecture on display. However, there is quite a lot of overlap so be ready for that. Excellent photo opportunities abound.

Amazing Necropolis. We spent hours walking around this true necropolis. Every tomb and mausoleum was individual and unique. Sleek contemporary black marble and glass; miniature Sagrada Familia, piles of rock; beautiful sculpture in bronze and marble; miniature churches complete with stained glass and crucifixes...

Nice place for a walk. Difinitely worth visiting, all the small mausoleums are very interesting and it's a very nice place to go for a walk! If you have the time do it! We didn't take the guided tour, but I there is some special grave you want to see there is a map over all the names

Eva Peron's Resting Place. Eva Peron, Argentina's most famous female politician and well loved individual rests in this remarkable cemetery with other luminaries. The mausoleums, headstones, and other monuments honoring those who have passed are worthy of your time when visiting this beautiful city. There are many that tell a descriptive story about the inhabitant. This is worth reading about before visiting to get full appreciation about what you are observing.

Amazing Cemetary - A must See.. We traveled here with a private tour guide who took the time to explain the amazing history of this cemetery. If you don't have time to arrange for a guide, you can still visit and enjoy. However, I highly recommend a guide if you want to know the stories behind each tomb, and the where the famous ones are like Evita. If I ever return to BA, I will absolutely visit the cemetery again. Its one of the neatest places I have ever been.

Interesting, artisitic and peaceful. An unexpected visit to Recoleta Cemetery was a welcome peaceful interlude from a bustling Buneos Aires. I was most interested and while my travelling companion had no interest in visiting the cemetery they became extremely interested in the place. Amazing monumental work. You could easily lose yourself here for several hours.
An unique place. A collection of mausoleums, tomb structures can give a good look at the culture of mores of the upper crust of Buenos Aires
World famous cemetary. Recoleta is a must in BA. It ranks among the world famous cemeteries. Interesting to walk around and see the elaborate memorials and customs.

Beautiful and Historical. This cemetery is like walking through an beautiful, architectural museum. Along with the Familia Duarte, the mausoleum of Eva Peron and family, there are many families of historical importantance in Buenos Aires. It's worth spending time there, wandering around.

It's a Must do, Must See!. I couldn't understand what they big deal was about going to see a cemetery. But after reading so many endorsements of it and my guide assuring me that it was a top BA attraction, off we went! It did not disappoint.

Incredible architecture. Did this as part of a bike tour, and it was very cool. The family graves are incredible, and stunning architecture, and it goes well with learning about the history of the country.

Argentina's history in one place. Graves are usually scary but Recoleta's cementery is a great example of architecture and decor, from the art-deco to gothic style, modern or french. If you have the chance the tour with a guide is recommended, to learn some of the most interesting parts of this country's history. Also some secrets like why a grave was built like this or that, traditional families stories and yes, some gossips from the past!
Very impressing. For those who like cimentarys it is an absolutely must to go there. Many thombs impressing statues trees, Mediterranean atmosphere. ...

Interesting history !. Everyone raves to see this cemetery. There are free English speaking tours Tuesday and Thursday that the government supplies. Very interesting history of many buried there including the infamous Evita.

No crowds surprisingly. This is worth a ten minute visit. Evitas mausoleum is less impressive than expected. I thought it would be like trying to see the Mona Lisa in the Louvre, but not so. Our guide made it more interesting as he knew facts about the dead

French connection and art. Years ago vising Paris cemetery while studying philosophy at Nanterre I was impressed with the tombs and their artistic concept, so it was a great moment to walk inside this Argentinian cemetery and witnesses their attempt to recreate a similar atmosphere. This is not just a cemetery, it is a sculpture park; and the tomb for Evita Peron is an enhancement. It is a must go and check it out, if you are in Buenos Aires!

Didn't meet the expectations. Maybe I just expected too much (I don't like cemetaries in general, but I was nicely surprised by the old cemetary in Salzburg, and after this I thought I might give this one a chance too, especially considering it's famosity). It has a lot of grandeur, but it's not extraordinary beautiful. The grave of Evita Peron is the most famous one, but certainly not the most beautiful one. Some of the graves could use maintenance. It's difficult to orientate at the cemetary, but free guided tours in English and Spanish are offered, which add more extra values to the place, since the stories and history is more interesting than the view itself.

A thousand stories. Even without a tour, wandering the streets of this historic place reveals so many stories--from a British officers who buried his wife in the early 1800's to Evita, of course. Some of the tombs are crumbling, while others shine with care. A fascinating hour or two.

Cool but a bit eery. We had a good time here. Odd to say about a cemetery but it was kind of cool. In UK we don't have cemeteries as grand as this was surprised to see how grand the tomb stones and grave houses were.

Beauty in death. This cemetery very well known for the beauty of the crypts and sculptures, is very worthy of your time. Probably a guided tour is a good idea, to actually get to know and understand the history of the city.

A must see when in Buenos Aires.. Some fascinating history and very expensive places for the dead to rest. Worth doing the tour because you learn a bunch of stuff that you would never know about certain people/family's within the cemetery. Allow a hour and a half to do it properly.
A must see. A fascinating place, unique to Buenos Aires, and a lovely way to spend a couple of hours. You really can't visit BA without seeing the cemetery.

Not what I expected. We were a little disappointed in the famous Recoleta Cemetery. The tomb of Eva Peron, actually the Duarte family tomb is interesting just for the fact that people still flock there to pay homage. The remainder of the mausoleums are a hodgepodge of styles each trying to outdo the others. If you enjoyed the cemetery in the garden district of NOLA, you will probably like this one.

Very interesting!. As a local, I did not know what was the attraction of the cemetery. If you do appreciate art and architecture, you will love this place. Lots of stories as well, so try to go with a guide who will tell you the stories behind the graves.

do not miss this. forget eva perrone and go to see these unbelievable monuments to the rich and famous. incredible stonework and statuary. as well, it's only a block from the saturday and sunday feria. we spent quite a bit of time looking at these century old edifices that are still being maintained by the most wealthy families in BA.

A cementery for those who like arquitecture!. Once here you understand that it's not common people buried here. The tombes are very pompouse and you'll be amazed with it's arquitecture!A lot of famouse argentinians are buried here.

Very interesting to see all of the old gravesite. Loved wandering through the cemetery. Very beautiful monuments and so interesting. Loved finding Eva Perons site and learning the history behind this city.

wonderful area. Recoleta cemetery located in best area of Recoleta is memorable ----spacious to walk--many momentums of the past and endless walks in this fabulous cemetery-----this is in the most picturesque area in Buenos Aires surrounded by restaurants and high end hotels such as Alvear

Beautiful sculptures and artistry. The skill of the mausoleum builders is breathtaking, a cemetary that is like a museum. Any art lover, historian or traveler will enjoy a walk/tour through the lanes of this mini-city. Plan to send several hours here. I would recommend that you visit a '10 ten of the Recoleta' internet site for background on some of the tombs. I'm glad I did this when I got home, but would have been better before. Take your time, you will be pleased you did.

A must-see. An enormous and stunning look into Argentina's past. Would recommend getting a tour next time, as the cemetery can be overwhelming and if you're a foreigner you wouldn't know many of the people buried there.

The stark contrasts. Beautiful cemetery that is well worth setting aside a couple of hours for. You can then go and have one of the delicious ice creams at one of the many parlous opposite to get your energy back.

Interesting. Cemetery visits aren't on the top of my list usually, I think this is only my third ever but it was facinating. Amazing self indulgent sculptures, very busy, two funerals in the hour we were there. Lots of tourist, me included. Where have all the cats gone ? Not one in sight !

A fascinating view of the "architecture of death". Most people come here to see where Eva Peron is buried... And while that is interesting, the cemetery in its entirety is worth walking through. The architecture of the individual mausoleums, many competing with each other to display families' wealth and status, is fascinating. It's a worthwhile stop on a Buenos Aires city tour.
Fascinating sight. Fascinating to walk around the tombs and take in the different styles and decor, definitely worth a visit.

The most unusual cemetery ever. Get a guide to explore this unique resting place of old families and heroes.. The monuments are very tall and you have the feeling of walking through the streets of heaven (or?). Each statue, carving, chapel or stone has a world of history behind it.

Don't miss the Recoleta Cemetery!. Even if you've been to cemeteries in New Orleans, you've never seen anything like this! Quite literally, a "city" of the dead. Entrance is free, and there is a free English language tour at 11am on Tuesdays (tip appreciated). You need at least 1 hour here, more if you like to wander and take photos. It covers the equivalent of 4 city blocks, with maze-like rows and "streets".

Amazing have a guide to fully appreciate. . We had a tour guide who explained so much. - Outsides are historic and can only be neatened up- They are owned by a family who has to keep them up. If all family members deceased or no longer have money, they can fall into disrepair. - Some have fancy coffins to show their wealth. - Some you can look inside to see the stairways to imagine how far down they go with all the generations of family.
Less like a cemetery, more like a gallery. It's one of the things you must see when visiting BA. Wander around the wealth of centuries gone and contemplate how you would like to be remembered.

A Must See. A must see to visit the Eva Peron tomb, which is the Duarte Family mausoleum. To find it, go straight through to the center of the cemetery and turn left. You will have to ask other visitors and follow the crowds. It's left, pass through a large section, turn left at the next aisle, pass two more aisles and then turn right. It's halfway down on the left.
A must-see. .. A must-see while you are in Buenos Aires. It is desirable to have a guide to weave your way through the walkways and tell about some of the people interred there.

Recoleta Cemetery visit..Buenos Aries.. A very interesting place and well worth a visit. Consists of row on row of Mausoleums in various states or repair . The tombs are often glass fronted with coffins on display. The below ground component may be up to 6.0 metres deep. Paved roadways run between the graves and the site is generally well maintained. One tomb is that of Eva Peron and other famous Argentinean persona are buried throughout the site. A miniature township for the dead.

Wow...Nothing I read did it justice. Must see if you love architecture! It is a city in miniature. Really try to get someone from Free Tours to explain what you see. SO MUCH more fascinating with the guide. If you are just going to see Eva Peron's tomb you will miss out on real treasures. We spent at least 5 hours if not more.
Fascinating!. In every tourist guide, this cemetery is mentioned...for good reason! Do not leave Buenos Aires without spending at least one hour here, you will not regret it.
What an experience, highly recommended. The display of wealth is astounding. Take the free guide that commences at 11am every day, or you can buy a map for 20 peses and make your way around.
Very different. For sure must see in Buenos Aires. Very different from other countries' cemetries. Very touristic of course.
Amazing place. Huge place, amazing buildings and statues. Went to see Eva Peron's resting place but it was well worth a visit. Huge place and easy to get lost.
Interesting occupants. What can I say beyond "it's the dead center of town"?Lot of histororical luminaries, lot of tourists, interesting crypts, the residents are still dead!

Beautiful cemetery. It does not take a long time to visit this so be sure to fit it in your tour. The tombs are quite beautiful. This is also a sanctuary for homeless cats and they are tended to by kind volunteers. We did hear them and spotted their feeding areas, but we never saw a cat.

"tribute to Argentina's past/present wealth". It is extremely interesting to observe the wealth and skill involved in crafting these mausoleums. We were told that an average cost of burial here would run $250,000. Surely a tribute to the past wealth of Argentina as I do not believe their is room for new tombs. Families fortunate enough to own one use it for the entire family over and over again. Eva Peron is entombed here and her mausoleum is probably the most visited site in the cemetery. Well worth a short visit.

Magnificent mausoleum!!. One of the highlights of Buenos Aires! Free admission and worth the time and effort.We arrived in the morning and started our day with an excellent breakfast at La Biela, an historical cafe located just outside the cemetary gates. We proceeded thereafter and was greeted by a representative who offered a map- approx $1US (included the resting place of Eva Duarte Peron) and an explanation of what we were about to see. It is the burial place of all significant political and historical figures. Each mausoleum has an interesting tale to be told.....as we were on our own, we listened to a tour guide and some of her explanations. We decided a tour guide was the way to go!We were there on an especially hot day with the sun beating down - I was thankful for our umbrella which reduced the heat by at least 15 - 20 degrees. The purchased map was also helpful to find our way around and back to the entrance. The cemetary is kept in excellent condition (maintained by all the donations). A MUST SEE on visiting Buenos Aires.
Essential Visit. Surprisingly interesting from a historical and architectural point of view over and above visiting the tomb of Eva Peron - it does get very hot so have water and wear a hat
Hard to believe. Well worth a visit just to marvel at the architecture of the individual mausoleums and of course Eva Peron is buried here.

What a cemetery . No entrance fee required. I have never seen this type of cemetery. Such beautiful tributes. Be careful you could get lost in the maze. But it on your bucket list if you are coming to buenos Aires.

Rpsie Millar. We spent about 2 hours at the cemetary. We loved it but it was very hot and a cool drink called. A tour guide is really recommended to tell the stories of the cemetery unless you want just a quick visit.

A must do for architects!. We visited the Recoleto district during the morning and had a cafe at one of the oldest places in Buenos Aires, called La viela. This shop is unique and has a lot of history, also it was the place were the famous writers used to share the afternoon. The cemetery is unique, try to not get lost!
Interesting. There's some great architecture here. Cemetery of the elite, most notably Eva Peron. Worth a visit if you're in BA.

amazing city for the dead. I was told not to miss this and that was the best advise I could have been given. The tributes to famous people like Eva Peron to the common family member is breathtaking. Beautiful "houses" for the dead. Every size, color and shape. Some were plain and some looked like you were infront of a mansion. Such a peaceful place with nothing to fear or give "shivers".This is something you should not miss. We spent several hours within the walls of the cemetery.

Unique??. Never been in such an ornate cemetery! We were with a guide so were taken to Eva Peron's grave very easily. Interesting place to walk round. Some of the mausoleums were in poor condition but it's well worth a visit.

INteresting, but creepy. Walking through rows and rows of fancy crypts dating way back. Many are in disrepair and are open so that you see the casket and the spider webs. Would be a great Halloween venue. Our guide gave us interesting info on how this system works (families buy the crypts like real estate and have to maintain them --they can also sell them). Evita Peron is buried here and a few other local heros.

Where Art, History and Mortality Meet. .Background: During an overnight layover in BA en route to Ushuaia to join a 10-day cruise to Antarctica, I ambled my way north of the city centre towards the Recoleta Cemetery. Built in 1822, this art-rich cemetery features the tombs and mausoleums of many of Argentina's "royalty" and elite: past presidents, military heroes, influential politicians and other notable historical figures, including Eva Peron.PROS: It is very famous in BA that everyone knows where it is. All taxis know the place and many city tours include a free visit in their itinerary. A mere mention of "Eva Peron" and people on the street will point you in the general direction. For orientation, it is close to the Retiro train station. The non-descript entrance gate ushers you to an elaborate maze of ornate statues, marble sarcophagi and mausoleums. It is built like a city with streets, walkways and alleys. After several twists and turns, you arrive at the Familia Duarte's (Eva's maiden name) mausoleum. Plain and discrete, Evita's grave is inside here. To the side, a small plaque (see photo below) bearing her name confirms the spot. Flowers festoon the mausoleum's door. Quite touching.CONS: A few come to mind -- First, proximity is a liability. It's a bit out of the way that it took me the better of an hour to walk over from my hotel. Second, there are not that many POIs nearby to make a taxi ride worth it. Maybe combine it with a trip to the zoo. Third, the cemetery's gate does not have a sign "Recoleta Cemetery" to identify it as such, but instead the Latin phrase "Requiescant In Pace" (Rest In Peace). Also, Eva Peron's grave is not highlighted with signs or directions (unlike the Mona Lisa at the Louvre). Without a map or guide, you'll be going blindly around in a maze. (Even the cemetery map does not highlight Eva's grave; you'll have to search her name from a list on the side, then look it up using a numerical reference on the map.)TIP: There are free English tours every Tuesdays and Thursdays at 11:00 am. I do recommend that you join one. It will greatly enhance your experience. (Other languages are available, but call in advance.) The cemetery is huge. Take a map with you; they are for sale at kiosks. Or else, do as I did, take a photo of the cemetery map at the entrance with your cell phone and use that.Verdict: To be honest, I'm not into cemeteries. The main draw for me was to see Eva Peron's final resting place, having casually known about her from the hit Broadway musical "Evita". Having said that, I treated my visit the same way I do an open-air museum, with all the statues, icons and mausoleums as art masterpieces in its private collection. As of this writing, it is my understanding that an entrance fee for tourists -- probably 100 pesos -- is in the works. If this is not your "cup of tea," I understand. Worth a visit for its artistic and historical value, if nothing else. Your call. Grade B+..
Shouldn't about it. The cemetery is so well known that I almost decoder to skip it. But I went and it was great. There are some remarkably cool things to sea.

Not so strange, worth it.. I felt kind of weird when this cemetery was suggested to me as a tourist attraction, but it isn't at all. Beautifully laid out and the structures and crypts were lovely.It is the final resting place for the high and mighty of BA society, not forgetting the famous Eva Peron. (Evita) Not sure if you need a guide here, but there are guides at the entrance if you do. I am not sure how much they charge though.I seems everyone visiting (me included) were heading to the Duarte crypt where Evita lays.It is close to the national museum so you can drop by and look at the exquisite arts on display.Good visit and recommended.

Definitely Worth Putting on Your List of Things to See in BsAs. This cemetery is impressive for its size, its beauty, its location, and the number of dignataries buried there, including Eva Peron. Situated in the heart of the Recoleta district of Buenos Aires, this cemetery is surrounded on all sides by a high stone wall. You enter the cemetery from the side that faces onto a park on which craft fairs are held on the weekends. You can find maps in guide books and on site showing you who is buried where. You can also find a woman near the entrance who sells inexpensive maps in exchange for a donation to the preservation society. Inside, you will see a seemingly endless area of beautiful vaults, family alters, statues on top of the vaults etc. If you simply want to get in, see Peron's grave and leave, you can do it all in 20 minutes. However, if you want to soak it all in and find the vaults of some of the other famous people buried there, you should allow a couple of hours.

Unusual but quaint. This is like no cemetery I have ever been to before. The proximity that you can get to the resting places of loved ones is both special and eery. The place is well kept and very quiet.

Final Resting Place of Eva Peron. . ..Evita!. The resting place of Argentine "Royalty". This is a very ornate and beautiful cemetery. Eva Peron is buried here, and you can walk right up to the grave. There are guided tours of the cemetery, and I would suggest that you take one. You will learn a lot about this cemetery and of Argentine History.

History and architecture. I do not like to go to cemeteries and I don’t find tombs entertaining, but I could not resist goint into the Recoleta cemetery as it is very famous. I basically searched for the Duarte tomb (Evita’s maiden name) and went straight to it, looking at other tombs along the way. Evita’s family tomb is quite discreet and of course quite popular. But there are many famous people buried there and some tombs are quite magnificent.

Evita!. This cemetery is a must see in Buenos Aries, has past presidents and wealthy families. A guide is helpful to visit this cemetery, so you can get all the history. The story of Eva Peron and the simple mausoleum. Also, the important and wealthy families of Buenos Aires. We were mesmerized by some of the architectural design of the rich and famous families mausoleum.

Truely Amazing. You wouldn't think it would you - but a cemetery can be an extremely interesting place to visit. I was amazed at the opulence of the many marble and ornately adorned crypts. Found the stories around some of the crypts very interesting and enjoyed visiting the final resting place of Eva Peron. It really is worth a visit - you wont be disappointed.
Unique . The rich & famous live on after death but no more vacancy. It was a quick half an hour visit for me. Quite interesting in a way seeing the glamorous cemetery in the middle of a city.

Educational. I love going there, the mausoleums, the architecture are very interesting. Some presidents and famous people lay there. My favorite is president Mitre mausoleum. You can also visit Eva Peron's resting place
There are some guided tours daily.
Interesting place . Our kids could not understand why we were visiting a cemetery, but once we did the tour they understood. There is so much history and interesting stories buried in that cemetery.

Unique and the highlight of BA. Fascinating and unusual cemetery with SN amazing collection of crypts adorned with statues, stain glassed Windows and other decorative features. Most famous occupant of course is Evita

Eva Perron Last Place. You have to visit this cemetery with a guide so you can get all the history. The story of Eva Peron and the simple mausoleum. Also all the important families of BA. I was impressed by some of the architectural design of the rich and famous families mausoleum.

Very Different. Very unlike any cemetery I have every visited. More like an unusual sculpture garden. Not creepy at all but children might not like it and I personally would not be trying to sneak in at night. Evita's grave is less impressive than one would expect but worth seeking out. We didn't take a tour but it might have been helpful to get the history and backgrounds of some of the people buried there,

it's the best place to go during holiday. I didn't plan to visit the cemetery during the 1st of jan but all the shops were closed so we had no choice but the cemetery. I can't believe it's the place where I saw most tourists than any other spots in BsAs during the new year. The cemetery is famous as Eva Peron is buried here. Apart from this, the cemetery is a peaceful and artistic area and all the sculptures are so pretty. Unlike the cemetery in asia, Recoleta Cemetery is spacious and it's just like walking in an art museum.

Interesting site. While cemeteries are not one of our usual tourist destinations, my wife and I thoroughly enjoyed our visit to this one. The Evita Peron is the main destination and it was quite a sight with a large number of flowers. However, Sarmento is well worth a visit.

Impressive Historical But...... .This is a must see but hire a guide and the experience will be so much better. The stories behind the crypts make.this grave yard come alive....pun intended.A place of beauty not to be missed. On the UN historical site list. .Have a beer at La Biela after your tour.

This is the "city of the dead". This is a must to do thing while being in BA. To get the most out of it I do really recommend taking a guided tour to get all stories of the people buried there. It will tell you a lot about the history of BA, including the legendary Eva Peron.

Unique place to visit. You will not find this kind of Big Cemetery in any other country. It is build in late 19th Century and it is pretty well maintained by the local authorities.I would say must visit place for every visitor to BA

Walking among the Dead. Not sure if this is the most famous cemetary in Buenos Aires but it is famous for being thr final resting place of Eva Peron 'Evita'.
Guided walks available, including a free one, in English, at 11am each Tuesday.

Interesting, unique place . Worth visiting.
Free entry and free English tours Tuesday & Thursday at 11am. There was around 30 people in the group so it was difficult to hear the guide at times, but it was interesting to hear the history behind the cemetery when I was close enough to hear.
You will only need to spend 1 hour here.
Facinating. Amazing above ground cemetery. Fascinating mausoleums. Eva Perin, other noted Argentinians. All with great stories

BEST CEMETERY EVER!. As far as world famous cemeteries go (Paris, New Orleans, etc), this has got to be the best. Could have easily spent a huge chunk of the afternoon walking around here. Crypts are insanely detailed and beautifully maintained. Loved it!
Must see. Wonderfully interesting cemetery. Beautiful statues and glass no wrought iron work. Very interesting and unique.

a beautiful 'uplifting' cemetery. well worth the visit. cemeteries are usually not the most positive place to be while on vacation, however this was uplifting and beautiful, and it was for me so moving to visit and see the mausoleum of the Duarte family and Argentina's beloved Eva Peron.
Probably unlike anything you have seen!. Be sure allocate at least an hour if not more for this. It is probably unlike any cemetery that you have seen before.
Amazing cemetery!!. WOW such an elaborate cemetery!! Was nice to visit and have a stroll around admiring all the detailed tombs!
Incredible- a must see destination. No words can describe this place. It's just somewhere you should go. There is an English tour (free) on a Tues and Thurs at 11am. Just turn up and be ready to go.

Quite peaceful.... A place where the former Presidents (including Evita Peron) and the elite of Buenos Aires are buried. Established in 1822 it contains more than 4,500 above ground vaults, many declared historical monuments. The place is full of marble mausoleums and sculptures by notable artists.

Fascinating-- with a guide. We would have missed out on a lot had we not hired a guide. We got one who was standing near the entrance, and she explained things to us for a bit over an hour and charged 50 pesos per person (there were two of us). I'd imagine it's easy to get lost in there without a guide, but more importantly, you need to understand how it all works. As others note, the diversity of architecture is itself amazing.

Amazing and Spoooky. We spent a few hours exploring this cemetery. Of course, visit Evita's crypt but make sure you check out more of the amazing crypts, artwork, details, architecture. We had a nice sunny day and loved it.

Interesting in itself, not just for Eva Peron's tomb. This is a real warren of a cemetery with a host of amazing tombs/mausoleums. Many were in a state of disrepair sadly, where family have either died out, moved away or lost interest or the finances for the upkeep. Some people might find it a bit creepy with all the coffins on show but for us it was heartwarming to see the tender care some families still pay to ancestors both recent and long past. The tombs themselves come in all shapes, sizes and architectural styles. Fantastic artistry and craftmanship in view. Well worth the visit

Take some time to visit. I know what you're thinking, it's a cemetery, and you're right, but it is one of the most unique and beautiful places I have seen. It is definitely worth a few hours of your time to explore this place. Don't forget your camera!

You can not take it with you, but some people want to believe they can. The Recoleta cemetery, considered one of the most famous necropolises in the world, was commissioned in 1822 for the rich and famous. It is filled with tree lined avenues and over 6000 tombs and mausoleums. Well known politicians, celebrities, and the rich are buried here including Eva Peron, along with Bartolome Mitre, and Saenz Pena, former Argentine presidents. This cemetery is almost a small city filled with those who lived large, or rich in life and wished to believe they would be remembered in the after life. Some of the tombs are still shiny and new, but others, like those interred, are beginning to show the ravages of time. One of the main tourists venues in the city, it is worth the visit to think about where you are in life and where you will eventually be.

It's unforgettable experience. I've seen a lot of cemeteries, but I was really shocked when I saw this one. The graves are monumental. Some have fine sculptures, other just plain massive. Frankly, it reminded me more about ancient Egypt Pyramids rather than Christian "We can't take our things with us into Heaven", but it's just my personal opinion. Overall, like it or not, it's going to be unforgettable experience.Some logistics. The entrance is free. There are all kinds of tours and guides if you want them, however, if you just go there and spend some time walking around - that will still be unforgettable.

Short of the Valley of the Kings or the Vatican, this is the most interesting cemetary. You've come to BA....of course you're going to see the Recoleta Cemetary. Grab a coffee and do a long walking tour. Make sure you check out the different tombs where the stay cats have taken up residence. It's interesting to see how some sites belong to families who died out long ago.
History, architecture, peace. Wonderful cemetery. Take a guide if you want to learn the history. I found the grave of Victoria Ocampo.

A cimetiere to visit. Get a guide or read about the famous people's grave. An interesting one, apart from the usual Eva Peron and Napoleons 'grad-daughter etc: Tomb of professional boxer Luis Ángel Firpo, the first Latin American to challenge for the world heavyweight champion title.

Unexpected Highlight. As others have commented, this is more than just a cemetery. Each mausoleum is unique and exquisitely designed, with widely varying styles. We entered thinking it might be special to see Evita´s tomb, but left distracted by all the other tombs, having forgot why we went in the first place. Compared to the usual graveyard with faded headstones and the occasional statue, this was quite the collection of grandiose self-monuments. A LOT of money was spent making sure certain legacies were preserved.It is free and fairly well shaded, making it a good stop between other sights.
Worth it . It is beautiful and full of history. Worth the visit. Didn't stay too long as it was a very hot day. And to be honest, seen 1 plaque seen em all

Strangly alluring. I have visited the Recoleta Cemetery on each of my three visits to Buenos Aires over the past 8 years. It is always a highlight. I love walking along the paths admiring the unique family mausoleums which span from historic catholic monuments to ultra modern marble structures. Each mausoleum is fascinating not only from an architectural perspective but also for providing a tiny glimpse into a family lineages. If you are a fan of cats, you will enjoy all the cats of the Cemetery who live there. In the summer it is best to go in the late afternoon to see the cats. The Cemetery is particularly famous as Evita's resting place. However, I highly recommend visiting the Cemetery regardless. If you go on Sunday you can also enjoy the craft market just outside the Cemetery in the park.

Very good but not the best. It is a very stylish cemetery. Full of history and beautifully designed details. I don't rate it as the best I've ever seen as where I live in Milan the Cimitero Monumentale is maybe even better and surely larger.

Museum of Mouments. This is not just a cemetery - it's a monument museum that stretches back 200 years of age and more. Very impressive how some selected families have built monuments, even little churches on top of their ancestor graves. I would say that this little piece of land is the most expensive property in Buenas Aires since it's fully occupied. Plus the Argentinian icon Eva Peron is buried here as well. Area in general is beautiful with small cafes and restaurants surrounded. Easy access by public transportation.

Monumental Mausoleums. A must see; no other cemetery compares. Opulent burial chambers. Look inside to see the stairs leading below ground. You can find the grave marker for Eva Peron under her family name Duarte. Free admission. Tours available. Near cafes and park with weekend markets.

Completely unexpected and unique. We expected a selection of headstones and what we saw was like nothing we have ever experienced. This city of family crypts was completely unlike any Cemetary we have encountered. There are many people buried here who obviously contributed to the making of the country and at the front entrance you can look where they are buried. Eva Peron is a much visited site. However, just the money, care and love that has been invested by families in honouring their deceased is amazing. Some crypts are derelict while others are still attended to, as evidenced by the flowers and living plants that can be seen inside. We chose not to take a tour, do not speak the language but still felt we got a reasonable understanding of the place.
Amazing Cemetery. The Recoleta Cemetery is the most amazing cemetery I've seen in my life. The size and luxary of a lot of graves is just amazing, definitely worth a visit!.

a must go while in recoleta. This is an interesting visit. It is an old cemetery located in Recoleta, next to the artisans fair. This is where the deaths of rich families used to be buried. Some crypts are real art masterpieces.

A Must See. The title says it all. Even if you don't care about Argentine history, the mausoleums are worth seeing. You can walk around for free, get a tour (there's a free English one at 11am on Tuesdays and Thursdays, but it's a huge group), or buy a map for 20 pesos and walk around yourself. We did the last option. It was very interesting exploring by ourselves. Time well spent!

A cemetery like no other. Beautiful and elaborate sculptures, coffins above the ground and a mysterious atmosphere. Racoleta Cemetery is impressive and makes one reflect about life and enjoying the moment

Interesting.... First let me confess that we didn't have a tour guide. We tried, but there were no English speaking ones that day. There is one stand with guides/maps and that was closed. So basically, we were just walking around a cemetery!The facades and graves were surprisingly impressive, and we found it interesting just walking around. However that wears off quite soon, as you can imagine.Evita's grave was very unexciting. I don't suppose it *should* be exciting but given that this is the main thing people go to see, it really isn't much of a centre-piece.We are staying in a hotel literally overlooking the place, and we won't be going again.One thing we did say though, was that we imagined it would be a really good place to go if it was raining.

Loved this experience but definitely best with a guide!. At first I was not particularly set on going here but the city guide I hired for the day strongly recommended it and I am glad she convinced me to go! A good guide can make this place come alive(pun intended!) by sharing with you all kinds of interesting stories - both those that track the history of the city and its politics and also those that are more personal (e.g., the caretaker who was so devoted to working at the cemetery that he saved up to buy himself a spot there so he could be laid to rest in the place he loved). Free when we went in very early January but we were told that they intend to start charging admission soon in order to use the funds to maintain the grounds and the mausoleums, many of which have started to fall into disrepair.
Unique cemetary. This area is one of the most visited sites in Buenos Aires. Legions of tourists and cruise ship passengers troop this this condominium of eternity dwellers.

Fascinating. Posssibly one of the most intriguing visits on my walk about of BA. There are guides available if you want but I chose to just walk around myself with the aid of a map. I was also intrigued with the number of Irish people buried here and who had played a part in Argentina's history.
Village for the dead!. Extraordinary place it looks like a mini village for the dead. Viewed Eva Peron's grave which was underwhelming for such a public figure but a fascinating place to visit!

Fantastic!!. This is an incredible place to visit... However you definitely have to do a guided tour, otherwise it won't make much sense! They offer a free English tour on tuesday and thursdays at 11h00. When we visited the entrance was free, but I understand that in the next while they are planning to start charging an entrance fee.

It's facinating and free.. It's fascinating to walk around in here. Seeing the history and learning some of the stories is worth a lot but this actually costs nothing to view. It is near several other tourist areas so a good location to spend a day actually. They were cleaning all over the cemetery when we were there and some of the vaults were open enabling you to stick your head in a little so that was different! I recommend getting some sort of walking guide to better understand the history of the families interred here. I wish the local authorities would better protect the property as there was quite a bit of vandalism in sight.

Once upon a time. Although cemeteries are not for everyone I happen to think this historic one is perfect. It is so gracious. It's nice to see how in older more refined times architects designed cemeteries as little cities with plazas and streets. The garden like feel is very peaceful and respectful to those who lay resting here. The mausoleums are ornate and thoughtful. Several of them are pieces of art. Although Eva Peron is buried here, it is not the main attraction. Stroll through and experience what families were able to do for their lost loved ones once upon a time.

Unique, Fascinating, Haunting. Unlike anything we have experienced in it's ability to hold your attention, fascination and imagination as you walk among over 4,400 historic, architecturally unique mausoleums.Some of the mausoleums have stairs descending with shelves of caskets of family members; some have photos of the deceased and their family members. Yearly taxes are paid. At any point in time about 300 mausoleums are for sale through a real estate agent at the cost of over $40,000! Eva Peron is buried under herfamily name of Duarte. For a fuller understand, hire a tour guide. For me it was so unbelievably unique we went there twice as we will never see anything like it anywhere else.
busy cemetery. There are a lot of people visiting this cemetery at times so becomes quite crowded. Probably allow more time than you think.

Pretty cool . The cemetery is fascinating, even if you don't go with a tour group. It's not too crowded and it is on like 5.6 acres. The tombs were really extravagant and historical. What an interesting place! We didn't stay long, but popped in to see what it was all about.

it's just a cemetery. We visited the cemetery to see Evita's grave. Honestly it's just a cemetery, would probably be worth visiting with a tour guide (we visited on Dec 25 and there was no free tour available) to get a better sense of the history of Evita. There is a map of where the graves are at the entrance, but not other markings within the cemetery. Would recommend you snap a photo of the map with your phone and use it for navigation

Crazy cool Cemetery . Really really nice place to visit. The Cemetery feels like a museum and Eva Peron's tomb is there amongst other important historical figures from Argentina. I recommend going on a Saturday or Sunday since the Recoleta artisan fair is within a couple of blocks

Definitely recommended in Buenos Aires. Must visit place in Buenos Aires, so much history. It's unbelievable! My husband and I visited cemetery on our first day in Buenos Aires. We didn't take a guided tour within the cemetery, rather walked around by ourselves. This is a busy place, many tourists are walking around. You see mostly family plots, all going back in history. Definitely on top of the list to see while in Buenos Aires.

Incredible architecture!. I went on a quiet afternoon, where the only crowd was around the tomb of Eva (Duarte) Peron. Each tomb is unique, some better kept than others and combined, the cemetary gives insight into the families of B.A. and how they remembered their loved ones.

Must visit!. Place must to visit in Buenos Aires. Better afternoon but not to late, closed after 17:00. Good Idea to see it from some view points above, one point on the middle of Florida. Ask locals or guide.

Well worth a visit!. It may seem strange to visit a cemetery on holiday but this is a tourist attraction, next to a large church which is also worth a visit. The cemetery is quite extraordinary compared to those in the UK and the architecture is quite stunning.

Don't Cry for me Argentina . Apart from Eva Peron's family grave which is why this is on the to do list for most people, the cemetery is a display of the wealth of those who had status, poeer and money. Fascinating construction of crypts, vaults and shrines to the dead who even in death are able to proclaim their superiority over most other dead.Fascinating and the ability to look inside and see decades old coffins lying in these mausoleums was interesting. Peron's family vault was modest and had queues lined up. It also had flowers adorning it
Try the free.tour!. Each half and hour you will find a free tour.Really good quality and the best you can find everything as quick as you need to get off the cemetery ....

Almost as good as Pere-Lachaise!. Pere-Lachaise in Paris is the Gold Standard, but Recoleta Cemetery and the ones in New Orleans are almost as good! Just inside the entrance, there is a big list on the left of who is buried where. It is fun just to wander, but note where Evita is buried so that you don't miss her!

Awesome. I feel weird recommending a visit to the cemetery, but seriously, go check it out. The above ground crypts/mausoleums are really interesting and beautiful. We just wandered around for an hour or so and it was great. I understand there are free guided tours on certain days but not sure exactly when - I think that would have been even better.

Graves and tombs. Pretty unique and a must see as well although pretty touristy place but inside you still find lonely places. Eva Peron grave is a must see and easy to find with lots of people looking for it.

Very original and interesting. A cemetery like no other. You'll be surprised to see the diversity and the craziness of some of the tombs there. We've been there a couple of times and each stroll allows to see different things. The proof that even a cmeentraty can be an excursion goal!

Must-be-there on your to do list. It is amazing place. I don't usually visit cemeteries but this time I got such good recommendation, that I couldn't miss it. It was worth to spend 50 minutes there and enjoy various architecture styles.

Must see. I'm not big into history but my husband is. I however has a wonderful time looking at all the architecture. We have a young child with us who did get bored. There was no wait for us. We went through alone but there were some tour guides available.
Amazing visual history. got to visit the cemetery. it's where Peron is buried. the architecture of the tombs are incredible. spend at least a couple of hours strolling the allies.

Surprising-after a long tour, we jumped right in. We had a 3.5 hour tour and then got to the cemetario, which we did not want to go into because we were so so tired, but we powered through and were not disappointed
Beautiful place. Apart from seeing Eva Peron's final resting place, there are many tombs through the cemetery which are a work of art. May they rest in peace.
Soooooo Coooool. Loved it. It was beautiful and so interesting. The caskets were in plain sight and sooo neat. If you like that sort of thing it is a MUST See

Perfect place to choose tomb! =)). You must go there! A lot of beautiful tombs helps you to choose your own in 20-60 years (it depends from how old you are now). We choosed black marble and red granite. Recommended!

Amazing History. The main reason for visiting this site was to see the tomb of Eva Perron. She was an important player in the history of Argentina, especially for women, and have studied her personal history. Interestingly enough we were there on Woman's Day.

Fascinating! Must see! . Recoleta Cemetery is possibly the number one attraction in BA. There are free English speaking guided tours on Tuesday's and Thursdays at 11am. Instead of joining a very large group we opted to have our own private guide for our group of 4 adults. We met Simon (our guide) at the entry to the cemetery. He is a UK man who had been living in BA for about 20 years and has been guiding people through the cemetery for about 12 years. He is extremely knowledgeable and spent about 1.5 hours with us. He accepts any money you wish to pay him. We were extremely happy with this tour and rewarded him accordingly. The stories behind several mausoleums are fascinating. Eva Perons mausoleum is highly decorated in flowers and gathers a large crowd. There are around 4600 mausoleums in this cemetery and each varies in size, stature, opulence and finish. Absolutely worthwhile to go and try to find Simon to have an exceptional tour. Also there was a pickpocket their walking around that we had to alert the authorities about. Be careful and wary when someone stands too close!

A good place to go on Christmas day. Most of other other places are closed,so I chose cemetery as my last stop of this trip.It was on my list but not a priority. Honestly,if you don't know Argentina history,most people in the cemetery are unknown to you,most people go there for Eva. And this cemetery is very small scale compared to Santiago's, overall layout is interesting but not many interesting design.They have a free tour 11am from the main entrance on Tuesday's and Thursdays.

Don't Miss the Cemetery. I have never seen such a cemetery before. The mausoleums are incredible. Everything from 200+ year old buildings to new ones with beautiful statuaries. I went there as part of my walking tour, but you don't need a tour to see this. Really not to be missed!

Unendingly interesting!. Lots to see, beautiful setting. We spent a few hours there on a tour, then chose to go back the next day to see more. I probably took 100 photos; the tombs are beautiful and varied. If it's a sunny day, best to go early or late so there will be some shade.

Only a small plaque commentates the last resting place of Eva. I am not much of a cemetery fan! That said, I was told by the concierge at the Park Hyatt that this is one of the grandest cemeteries in the world and Eva's last resting place is a must see. Definitely, it is ornate but mostly in a garish sort of way - I much prefer cemeteries with simple gravestones where the epitaph rather than the sculpture is the draw. To each his own, I guess.Moving on to Eva; Oh, what a shame! No matter how you feel about her, she deserves more than an innocuous plaque on the crowded and small Durate family mosoleum. After all, she is the main draw; at least, if the crowds of visitors to her last resting place are anything to go by!

There's a lot to be learned in a cemetery!. My daughter who lived for a while in BA was to be our tour guide. Luckily we stumbled upon Simon at the entrance who offered his guide services. "Pay me whatever you'd like at the end of the tour." We learned so much about the history of Argentina and its people with our tour of the cemetery. The mausoleums are works of architecture and most are well maintained. We learned so much more with the guide. He brought the place to life. Thanks Simon!

The cemetery. Well, if you want to see where Eva Person [and many others] is interred, this is the place. Very interesting cemetery- it's a little like being in a huge corn maze, as the "streets" are very straight and narrow, with tall mausoleums and no signs directing you where to go. [You can locate a specific mausoleum on a map near the entrance.] I believe they have free tours, but I missed one.
Homage to Evita Peron. Marvelous mausoleums extensive statuary Interesting to so much money spent on the after life her mausoleum is a little hard to find her family name is Duarte

Interesting place to visit. Step away for the city and enter the crypts and mausoleums. There are a variety of above ground mausoleums that range from ornate to ordinary. A fascinating place to visit. And yes, Evita is here.

Must See Attraction. If you come to Buenos Aires you must visit Recoleta cemetery. The cemetery has so much amazing history and a lot of the graves are beautiful. We looked for a guide outside of the cemetery and took a 2 hour guided walking tour for about $10 USD per person. It was highly worth it to hear some of the history of the cemetery and graves there.

For People Who Love to Take Pictures. It's a "city" of grief. Small, shaded streets lined with glorious architecture honoring those who have died while providing a place for the living to grieve and honor the memory of those who have gone before. If you're a photographer, amateur or professional, you will love the million moments and vignettes ready for a shutter bug!

MUST TO BE SEEN !!!!. I went there two days ago and it was a fabulous walk in this cemetery one of the best visit I done during my stayyou can see the grave of Eva Perron “evita” very difficult to find no direction signs when you come into the cemetery take the first aisle on your left keep going until the end and then turn right and you will see ( see picture) a wonderful statue with a woman and her dog just after it the grave of Evita will be in aisle on your left good luck the cemetery is huge with this you will gain some time.

Wow. Wasn't expecting much here, but was totally amazed by this place. The crypts were breath taking, the tour guide was great and it was so vast it was hard to take it all in. Managed to get a birds eye view of it after wards from the shopping centre near by as it overlooks the cemetery.
If you love crowds, you'll love this!. Too many gawkers, too many over-powering mauseoleums, too much noise and there are better things to do with your time.
Interesting walk in time. We spent some time at this beautiful cemetery. Artwork is impressive. Visited Evita Peron - Duarte family mausoleum - very modest!

Very nice. There were a lot of tourists and of course everything was overpriced, some of the locals were pushy otherwise it was a good visit , I didnt see the tomb although I was there I am not coming on a vacation to look at a tomb, I really didnt see anything that would make me want to go back there apart from buying stuff from the locals.
Unique. Easy to walk through by yourself. More information is learned with a tour guide. Ginormous beautiful tree outside the front gate.
as cool as a cemtery can be. great afternoon stroll , amazing place with lots of stories in it. Bring you map to make it more efficient.

Recent Argentina history told in the graves. If you car arrange a guide, better. If not, you can try it anyway. This is the best place to see the most eminent people of the recent (last 100 years) of Argentina history, including the famous Evita (but her grave is a challenge to be found in the middle of many others).

Recoleta cemetery. This is a must visit. We got there using the 62 or 93 bus and walked a couple of blocks. Evita is buried there and many if the local notables. Each family has its own mausoleum. Entry is free.

Great use of a couple of hours. Visited here with a friend on the tripadvisor review. We got conned into buying the cemetery map, which although wasn't expensive ($20 pesos) wasn't of much use at all. Wandering around was great to see the variety of mausolea for a few hours, although it's pretty hot in the middle of the day. I would advice for this, and for photography, to try visit early morning or late afternoon.
Grand and interesting place.. The cemetery contains the graves of notable people, big and grand. Interesting to walk by most of them and take some pictures.

Great experience. This is the most interesting cemetery that I've ever been in. It feels like a group of monuments, not an actual cemetery. The different mausoleums are so interesting, they are all different from one another. It's very interesting to see ones that are "abandoned" and not kept up - there are broken windows and weeds growing in them, but it gives them additional character.

Interesting place to visit. This is worth a visit while visiting Buenos Aires A number of very interesting mausoleums and related. It is also near a variety of cafes and restaurants so you can have a nice "restful" break after walking around this site.

Excellent. Deceivingly large cemetery with famous and wealthy people buried in the elaborate tombs dating back to the 1800's. We had a guide however there was a map in Spanish at the entrance. Of course we saw Eva Peron's tomb, however there is so much more to see than just her tomb.
Beautiful vistas . This was a really cool site to see. It is family friendly and easy to walk. Eva Peron's tomb is pretty cool but hard to find. Make sure you have a map.

A must to visit in Buenos Aires. Visiting the Recoleta cemetery is free of charge, unless you want to buy a map with some information. The sculptures on the tombs are worth the visit alone, but it is also quite interesting to see the mausoleum of the Duarte family, where Evita Peron is buried.

Dead Houses, Feral Cats And Evita. A strange place to visit on Christmas morning in scorching summer heat, but definitely a memorable experience. I wandered round in dazed sunstroke astonishment at the lanes of crypts. Some baroque, some Art Deco, some crumbling… a reminder that death, like life, comes in myriad forms and ends one way. My favourite crypt was for an Argentinean boxer. He didn't get up from the floor in his last fight with Death. If you want to find Evita's final resting place, look out for hordes of camera-wielding Japanese tourists: they'll be there before you, snapping each other for macabre souvenir photos.

Impressive place!. This is a landmark of Buenos Aires. So, of course, don't miss it! I'm pretty sure you have NEVER seen something like that. One of the tourists next to us said: "it makes you wanna check in, hey?!". It is quite a thing to see.

Historic and clutural visit. Amazing cemetery that shows how earlier generations venerated their dead and constructed "homes" for the dead to live together.
