Take a tour - its worth hearing which locations are more valuable and knowing where some of the more locally known luminaries are buried. See Eva Peron's tomb, decorated with fresh flowers.

A little creepy but SO interesting!. Definitely worth a go! Even if you think the whole cemetery thing is not your cup of tea, you don't much care about history or architecture - Recoleta cemetery is still a place that will leave you with a lasting impression. Full of tombs and mausoleums, you can just stroll around here and drink in the awesome atmosphere which is truly unique. That said - the main attraction (Evita Peron's) tomb is nothing special.Some of the old tombs have broken doors or windows, so you can peek in - you'll see old dusty coffins inside, a little creepy! You won't be sorry if you go here, especially as it's free to visit.
Fascinating . Surprisingly interesting excursion to explore what is both a historical and current element to the City , a well worth 40 to 60 minute wander around .

Fascinating Site. The architecture and sculptural details are magnificent. Plan to make this a leisurely stroll as there are so many unexpected architectectural gems to be found among the various alleys. Before proceeding, take some time to peruse the guide at the entrance and if available, purchase a map if you want a more detailed explanation of some of the sites without a guide. There were two office managers who were very helpful with questions and unusual tidbits of information. Absolutely a must when in Buenos Aires.

The most interesting cemetery I've ever been to.. I almost didn't make it to this gem. We ended up cutting our Uruguay week a day short to return to BA and spend the day here. After I calmed myself from the realization of seeing stacks of bare caskets.... I can say this is the best cemetery I've EVER explored. It was the highlight (and empanadas) of my South America trip. As a photographer I was in HEAVEN (no pun intended) ((=

Some interesting sights. Wife liked it a lot, saw Evita's tomb. I was kinda interested in the states of dis- and repair of different tombs. Some had even looked raided. She would recommend, but I have the "seen one castle, most look similar" attitude about it. Though this is pretty ostentatious.

Beautiful graveyard. The only thing I have to compare this to in this realm is the Pere Lachaise (Paris). This was a LOT more manageable with very interesting mausoleums MANY of which are in a bad state..which is interesting in itself..looking right into the mausoleums with the coffins lying around. Nice restaurant area directly across from this as well that's great for a drink or coffee.
Cemitery likes monuments. The cemetery is very famous due to Evita Peron crypt. There is no indication how to get there, so you need to ask people where it is. If you have time you should go there.

Recoleta Cemetery well worth the time.. Add to the list of must see places, and well worth some time to get away from the city and simply get lost. It’s not a bad idea to have a guide, although I liked the freedom of wandering about.

Very photogenic cemetery!. What an interesting place. Took lots of pictures and learned a lot of history of Buenos Aires. We even got to see the tomb where Evita was placed then stolen from or something like that. Lots of stray cats throughout the cemetery. Be careful not all of them are friendly.

Atmospheric and poignant. A visit to this amazing cemetry is not to be missed. You can stroll along the myriad of small paths for hours.
Tip: If you want to visit the grave of Eva Peron, then download a map of the cemetry to ensure that you can find it!

Worth the visit. This was must do on our short visit to Buenos Aires and because the cemetery is not large we did not have to spend a long time to have an interesing visit.The opportunities for some great photos abound and the little guide to the main sites is helpful.Wear a hat if the day is hot as there is not a lot of shade.

See it with a Guide. Other travelers have described the cemetery well and I can't add anything about the architecture. We went in a small group with a guide and I'm glad we did. You would have not problem finding Evita's tomb (or rather the Duarte Family Vault) - as one of our friend said, just follow the crowds!However, getting out could be a problem. It's a maze, with no directions. The other advantage of the guide was that she gave us a lot of historical background, not just about the Duartes, but other prominent families.Definitely worth seeing - andd there are lots of cats there if you're a cat lover!

Not a cemetry as you know it.. This Cemetery is very much like Spanish Cemeteries, in that there are family mausoleums. The main attraction for visitors is Eva Peron's Mausoleum, but the others are in many ways more impressive. Much to my surprise, found one with our surname. Did not even know how they got to Argentina

Cemetery. This place was just across our hotel. For us it was not possible to realize that it is a Cemetery. But when we visited we admired the structures. We spent time at Cemetery of 'Familia Duarte'.

High rise cemetery. This is a big cemetery consisting of mausoleums only. There are no ordinary graves. Therefore, you could conclude there are only rich and famous people buried. Evita Peron tomb is the reason you come here. If trying to find it yourself alone, you'll get lost for sure. There are many alleys, and since all around you are high rise mausoleums (higher than 2 meters) you cannot spot where are you and from where you came from. Therefore, two tips:First, when entering the cemetery on the left hand side is a map, with all important and famous graves marked. Take a photo of it and get to know your way.Second, there are a lot of tour guides there (you can rent yours also). If lost, ask for assistance.Besides Evita, a lot of military men, presidents, poets, writers..etc are buried here.

Yes this is a must see Cemetery!. Exquisite history and exceptional artwork to be seen of the family mausoleums...Touring it with a guide is ideal as there are many interesting stories you might otherwise not learn about. (we were fortunate to tour with Ceri from BuenosTours as he is writing a book about the place!)
A place to get lost. If possible, visit with a local guide who can bring the stories of the buried to life. There are lots of interesting stories to hear!

Noy to be missed. The Cemetery is a show piece of architectural designs of burial statues and enclosures.. The rich and famous are interred there, including former presidents, ministers and public figures
Well worth visiting . This is an amazing place to wander around - the private mausoleums are of staggering proportions. Moving to see the final resting place of Eva Peron.

Visit! People are dying to get in there!. A monument to the glorious days of Argentina!
A must see if in Buenos Aires!
Take you time and get a map.

Beautiful! Time well spent. Great to take a moment and take a stroll through. Was very relaxing. Breath taking detail in all the structures. Felt like a mini city. Totally a city for the dead! Interesting to look into the windows of each structure.
Beautiful art work to see in this cemetery. Each tomb is uniquely decorated, and some are very elaborate. Put this on your list of places to go.

Very interesting place to visit. Beautiful place, much bigger than I expected. You can get take a guided tour or buy a map off one of the tour guides, which is what we did. Lots to see and spent much longer here than expected.

Cemetery where eva peron is. My friend insist to visit this cemetery which she missed during her last trip three years ago.So, I went with her as a courtesy without very strong interest in...visiting cemetery. But, boy when I stepped in the cenetery beyond the gate where there is a couple security guard. I was impressed on how they set up the cemetery in such a luxurious way. And you can find a lot of beautiful art works!

One of a kind cemetery. My 2nd visit after 12 yrs. as I walked my memory clicked last visit highlights. But my guide gave lot new information new to me about history and how family maintains each areas. I would definitely advise guided tour so you can learn history and current status.

Not my type of tour .. An old cemetery in the middle of Recoleta and I went there just for just to see why people go there and did not find any thing thats worth seeing other than some nice tomb rooms.

Impressive cemetery. I visited the cemetery on a beautifull day in the morning. It was not that busy.I was very impressed with the amazing tombs that were in the cemetery.Like everyone I looked up the tomb of Eva Duartes. There were a lot of people trying to make a special selfie. This was a bit disturbing for me (respect please).Time wise: I spend around an hour or a bit more in the cemetery.
evita. hello i went and saw her tomb, even took a photo. cannot understand this selfie thing though. lot of other interesting tombs as well. go mon to fri, avoid the WE.

A little town on its own. Recoleta may be mostly famous for the (actually not easy to find without guide) resting place of Evita, Eva Peron-Duarte, but the cemetery has so many more interesting mausoleums and statues in a very compacted area.It feels like a little peaceful escape on its own in the middle of a very vibrant city.

Disappointing. I was expecting a far different attraction even though we had been warned that Eva Peron's grave was not grand. In fact, it was quite understated and not befitting of her reputation.
The whole cemetery was a collection of rich people who indulge themselves in death.
Don't set aside any more than about an hour for this so called attraction.

Crowded!. We visited on a very rainy day and the place was still packed. Took quite awhile to get to Evita's crypt. Nonetheless it is a fascinating place to visit, if it would have been a more hospitable day, we would have spent a lot of time really studying the various tombs. It just poured and poured and at about 50F, we were just miserable and quickly went through.
Very impressive! The tomb of Evita Peron to be seen. Impressive monuments! Very nice place. Take a guide to tell you the different stories of the cemetery.

Peaceful. This is probably the most amazing cemetery that I have ever seen. The tombstones are artistic and grand. It was surprisingly peaceful and quiet on the Friday afternoon that I was here, which I very much appreciated.

There by accident. I regularly fo not visit cementeries, some people do... If your hanging around Recoleta it seems everything leads to it or most taxi drivers will want to take you there. Who is there? None other than Eva Peròn. If you are a history buff that is a good book to read, Evita, a good play to see Don't cry for me Argentina a good song to hear, tgen see the grave.
A city within a city. So cool… This place was like a city of tombstones within a city. But they also beautiful and elegant, really worth a visit!

It is incredible the amout of detail these place has. some of them are a bit abandine perhaps the relatives are gone too. Price less time capsules you are expose to. The amount of history, this is not a happy place to be but it is super interesting. The level of care some one at one point had for their loved ones. Unfortunately like all things in live they too pass, some of the are a bit run down and perhaps there are not more survives near who knows?

Its a cemetary. I found it very strange that one of the key attractions in BA is its cemetery. Don't get me wrong, its a beautiful cemetery, but there's just something off about watching a bunch of tourists climbing all over a family's mausoleum and sticking their cameras into other people's tombs. As I walked past a girl doing exactly that she looked at me and said "they won't mind, they're already dead". Not the point, honey.Walked around, found Evita. Worth the visit but please show some respect.

Outstanding but sad.. I've never seen so many mausoleums in one place, some looked after, some neglected. Must see where Eva Peron is laid to rest in her family's mausoleum, also the find the statue of the girl who died twice..
Must see - cultural and fascinating. Really an unusual and beautiful place. In spite of tour groups, it's a beautiful & unusual place. Memento mori.

Fascinating structure and Eva Peron too. This cemetery reminds me of New Orleans in some aspects. Very different from cemeteries in the U.S. Some are extremely beautiful and ornate. We did a self-tour, It is easy to get lost in the maze. After awhile many will structure will begin to look the same. You really only need 30 minutes if you are in a hurry.

Interesting and strangely beautiful. We really enjoyed this tour. I would definitely recommend buying a map at the entrance to the cemetery. It isn't as big as it looks on the map. I was asked at least 5 times for directions as I was visibly holding my map. If you want to visit Eva Peron's resting place, she is buried with her family in the Duarte tomb.

How the other half die !. Definitely worth a visit ! I walked about a mile from my hotel to get there and that in itself is a pleasure through these wonderful streets.Some of the tombs are bigger than a normal house and incredibly ornate.Evitas tomb was a wee bit disappointing to be honest - especially when compared to the grander tombs.But a worthwhile visit for sure !

A must see......... This must be one of the world's most famous and largest cemeteries with huge mausoleums for wealthy families. The most popular one is for the Duarte family where Eva Duarte Peron, wife of President Juan Peron is entombed. It's not easy to find although there is a plan available at the entrance to find it's location. There was a sign saying maps were available but there were none when I went there on 2 consecutive days. Eva is known for her saying that her greatest fear would to be forgotten - she certainly hasn't been.

An Aristocratic and Egoistic Cemetery that's sadly worth a visit. When pyramids are no longer in vogue, why not just try to out do your neighbor with the grandest family burial ground perhaps on earth. It seems pretty macabre, but that's what the aristocracy of Buenos Aires have done. I'm sure the Kardashians would take up residency there if they could. Look at me, look at me, look at me! Eva Peron is supposedly buried here and that brings the visitors, but her tomb is by far less spectacular than her neighbors and it is worth walking around to appreciate the creativity and art that went into constructing many of these sites. Most of the family members are under the ground and I understand as many as 20 can be interned in any given site. If you look carefully you may see the stairs that lead underneath; there is often a coffin or two (sometimes small ones) that are laid to rest above ground. I am not a cemetery kind of guy, but I would still recommend this as a top place to visit in Buenos Aires. I'm not sure if there is an admission price as I stopped with a tour group. Please disregard my comments in any case and draw your own conclusions.

It's very strange but there some great sculptures!. It's an old and famous cemetery inside Buenos Aires Metropolitan city! Some famous people are RIP there! It's a little contradictory saying PEACE because there a good restaurant around the cemetery and a Mall ! Lol...
Evita and so many more stories. A browse around this place is definitely worth the time, although best to avoid the heat of the day. Extraordinary range of mausoleum designed in many elaborate styles

First time I loved visiting a cemetery. This cemetery is full of History. The crypts are real art pieces and many of them have stories to go with them. Plus, the cemetery has many cats, so if you are a Crazy Cat Lady like me, you'll have plenty of felines to pet.
Largest concentration of statues in the world . Quirky thing to do...quite cool to see the Tombs and intricate crypts. Check out Evita's grave here-apparently 2km under ground;)

Place to check out Eva Peron's grave. Spent a few hours walking through it. Has some impressive tombstones and architecture. The highlight is Eva's tomb, which is the only which always seems to have fresh flowers reflecting her place in the public consciousness.

Grand!. A must visit if you do not find the concept erie. Crypts more than 100 years old belonging to aristocratic families. Each crypt is an architectural attraction. You wouldn't tire of taking photographs of each and every crypt.

Most interesting cemetery. The cemetery is free and open daily from 7:00-6:00. The 13 acre cemetery was founded in 1822 and it is very expensive to have a mausoleum here. There are maps to locate different tombs which is very helpful since it is rather a maze. Evita Peron is probably the most famous person buried here. Each tomb is unique with some in disrepair and others with a chandelier, small altars, elaborate statues and carvings. All the tombs are locked with gates or doors.

Unique. This cemetery is one of a kind. No one would probably notice this place have Eva Peron not buried here, I maybe wrong. It's unique for its design. Each mausoleum has its own charm. Some have colored glass windows that you can see through inside. At the entrance there's a map but even then we had troubled finding Evita's mausoleum because it's so simple.

Don't Forget to Get a Map. Recoleta Cemetery contains the remains of the Who's Who of Argentinian History. Of course the main attraction is the grave of Eva Duarte Peron (Evita), but the massive cemetery also contains former presidents, military heroes, doctors,artists and musicians. Mausoleums run the range from the decrepit to the amazing. We spent more than 3 hours in the cemetery and could have stayed longer. Bring a high capacity memory card and extrabatteries as the picture count will be well into 3 digits.
Well worth a visit. Beautiful old cemetary. Lots of history. Well maintained. Easy to reach via public transport. No admission fee.

More than just Evita's tomb. Of course this is where everyone goes to see the tomb of Evita, but there's much more to be seen here. If you take some time to look around at dates and inscriptions and architectural styles, it offers and interesting window into the history of the city.

Amazing. If you say you should visit a cemetery for pleasure it immediately seems odd! This is a must however. South American cemeteries are spectacular and this one more so. We wanted to find the resting place of Eva Peron which we did.
A must see. I was stunned by the beauty of this cemetery. You can spend hours walking the 'streets' of the grounds. Also, there are plenty of restaurants nearby for lunch before or after your visit.

Fun to Walk Through. I live in New Orleans where all we have are these beautiful above ground cemeteries, but this one is interesting because the mausoleums (right word?) are so elaborate. There are a lot of interesting facts about this place, so if you can get a guide, I'd recommend that. We just walked through, looked at everything, visited Evita's burial site, and moved on. Eva Peron's tomb is unassuming compared to much of this cemetery and not on the "main drag" so to speak, but you'll notice larger groups of people and be able to find it. If you walk in and go to the left, that's the direction it's in. I suggest spending some time researching it on your own, printing out and bringing facts along with you, or getting a guide as that's what really makes these places so much more interesting than the usual.It's right on the site of a fair/market (?) where they have crafts, snacks and drinks for sale. There's a Starbucks in this little complex, a Hard Rock, and a mall at the street level (the cemetery is higher up). Be sure to walk the fair around to the giant ficus tree. It has to be held up by beams and there's a fun statue of a man holding one of it's enormous branches on his shoulders as one of the support beams.
creepy. I have to say that this was creepy. This is not for me. I do not like cemeteries, even though this looks nice in terms of its architecture, it is creepy anyway!!

Book a guide!. My husband and I visited this landmark - dubious as essentially we were visiting a cemetery on our honeymoon but everywhere you go it's rated as the top tourist attraction in BA.The tombstones are amazing (I know that sounds weird) but really it is an opportunity to see how the elite of Argentina are able to show their wealth even once they are dead. It's worth a visit. My regret is not joining a tour with a guide who could explain the story behind some of the people buried here. Eva Peron is there but you will get lost a few times before finding her! So book a guide to get the most out of the experience.

Interesting visit.. We called in at the Recoleta cemetery as part of our city tour. The tomb of Eva Peron was the main reason for our visit. Apparently it's the only one to receive fresh flowers daily.It was a very modest tomb compared to some of the opulent mausoleums nearby.
interesting for an hour or so. This is where Eva Peron is entombed and it is an interesting window into the history of BA but personally I found it too morbid
Famous cenetary. This was a really worthwhile experience. Lots of history and some really interesting tombs. Rated as one of the top 10 graveyards in the world.

I thought it would be more interesting. Nothing so special. It is free and it worth the visit if you are in the area. The story behind it is very interesting, but you can read at home as well. It is nice and some of the "houses" are really impressive and well reserved, but many of them are just a .... I thought it would have been better

A MUST SEE!. This is not your typical cemetery! This is like a million little castles of famous politicians, noble peace winners, Eva Perron and people from Argentina. Walking around and looking at the vaults was amazing. Free as well. The area surrounding the museum is beautiful as well - shops and great places to eat and drink. I must see!

A cemetery you will not forget!. Found myself at the gates to the cemetery after strolling through the artisan market in front of it. It is a very fascinating place. It is a city in itself. One crypt I saw had a glass door and a stairway leading down where you could actually see what looked like a cement coffin. There was one tomb that looked like a stone castle. Glad I stumbled upon it. Definitely worth a visit. They do offer guided tours in many languages.
Amazing Place. We wanted to see Eva Peron's tomb and after walking around for a while we just asked another visitor where it was. We had a great time looking around.

Unique cemetery. I have never seen a cemetery such as this. The Mausoleums are art works, each one unique. There are modern vaults, as well as falling down crypts from over a hundred years ago. Of course the big draw was Eva Peron's family tomb. Definitely worth a visit.

Beautiful Cemetary. The ornate crypts exude wealth! What a beautiful and peaceful place. You can purchase a map for a donation (about $2 US) to help you find where all of the rich and famous Argentineans have found a place to rest.

Out of this world, city of tombs within the city, a have to see in Buenos Aires.. Outstandingly beautiful cemetery which is well organised like streets in a town but research the more famous tombs you may want to visit beforehand as they can be difficult to find.It is free but closes at 5pm or so.Eva Perons mausoleum is a must as are numerous others whose names escape me, just google the top 20 tombs and try and find as many as you can, either way all of the tombs are beautiful.

Eva Peron mystery. Is she here or not? Such was the question posed by Karel our guide. Karel posed a few interesting points regarding the whereabouts of Ms Peron, which added to the novelty of this attraction.

Well worth a visit. I arrived at 4.45pm and was pleased to find out the cemetery doesn't shut until 5.30pm. i didn't have a guide but i still enjoyed my time wandering around this incredible cemetery. I've never seen anything on such a grand scale. The lonely planet guidebook provided good instructions on how to find Eva Peron's tomb (under her maiden name of Duarte). It's also great that this place is free. In all, this place is definitely worth a visit, even without a guide. The surrounding area is also very nice for a walk.

Walking Through a Story Book - Unique and Interesting Stories Behind Each Grave (Book a Tour Guide for this Place). We had two separate tour guides take us through the Recoleta cemetery, and, other than the Evita Peron tomb, both tour guides had unique and different stories to tell of different tombs. Art and impressiveness aside, I can't imagine having gotten as much out of the Recoleta experience if it had not been for the tour guides and their knowledge of the unique stories of each of the individuals there. It felt like walking through a story book, and I imagine that the individuals buried there must enjoy their people watching of us - possibly maybe even enjoy the visitors. Other than some stairs to enter the cemetery, a stroller was easy to push around (even flooring within the cemetery). There are bathrooms in the cemetery, but they had no toilet paper - so bring your own, just in case. I was fortunate that I had some toilet paper on hand. The restrooms were clean. There is no entrance fee. The Evita Peron tomb is a MUST - not for the impressiveness of the tomb, but for the touristy aspect of it. Read up on her before you go, it will mean more then.

Would probably be best with a tour guide. My friend and I walked through here after a walking tour concluded at the gates. There are clearly many stories to be told in this intriguing above-ground cemetery and I would have loved to have heard them. About the best we did was find Evita Peron's mausoleum (under her maiden name of Duarte). Even if you don't manage to arrange for a guide it's worth a walk through.

Very interesting place. Probably the best cemetery I have ever been in my life. Well, generally cemeteries are not places of interest to hang out, but this one is different. I guess it must be even better with a guide to know about all the stories. We heard one when standing next to a group and it was a fascinating story.
Beautiful crypts. Beautiful family mausoleums. Especially interesting for people with same family trees. Evita mausoleum was not marked and was in a dark alley. Had to ask workers there to find it.

You have to visit this cemetery!. We don't have cemeteries like this in Ireland so while on a walk round the city we visited this beautiful cemetery filled with many elaborate marble mausoleums. The cemetery is laid out like city blocks with narrow paths so one can walk up and down viewing a selection of well kept mausoleums and several run down ones too. Some of the coffins were visible and within touching distance which was a bit creepy. It was nice to remember the iconic lady Eva Peron who is interred there.If you are in Buenos Aires do visit this historic cemetery. You will not be disappointed.

Interesting cemetery. Perhaps I was tired by the time I got there but I wasn't "wowed" by the cemetery. There are some cool statues and crypts but have to say that I probably would not have gone had I known. Also, I wanted to have a drink afterwards and I found the area immediately outside the cemetery a bit tacky. Plus, this attraction is quite far from the centre. I ended up taking the metro and then a cab to get there.

What an amazing find!. I had read some details about the Recoleta Church but somehow was not attracted to visiting the cemetery. However I was out walking on a beautiful day in BA, and the Church was on my route. After visiting the Church - and it is particularly beautiful inside - curiosity got the better of me and I walked round the corner into the Cemetery. 45 minutes later I was still wandering through this fascinating place - I must have taken nearly 200 photographs, the lighting was so perfect ! Take your time for some fascinating sights and stories. Well worth the visit - and it's free!

Fascinating Place, must visit. From the more famous residents to the lesser known, the stories of the lives behind this ornate cemetery are fascinating. We were lucky to be with the very knowledgeable tour guide which obviously helps, but it's a very interesting place in Buenos Aires
cemetery. great - enjoyed very much---- signature tours do a great job !!! highly recommend them !!!!! buenos aires was wonderful...
Some photogenic tombstones. Eva Peron's tombstone is intentionally modest but there are a couple photogenic tombstones so its worth spending half an hour or so specially as its free.

Amazing place . This is a must while you are in BA,
The effort and architecture is amazing.
You could walk around here for hours.
Worth a visit and best of all this is a free activity.

Coffins in plain view. This place gets five points for weirdness value. It's the only cemetery I've ever seen where you can reach in and touch the wooden coffins. Some of tombs are well-taken-care-of, but others are falling apart with open doors and broken glass. Coffins are out in plain view and some even appear to be popping open. Aside from the tomb of Eva Peron, the history of the various generals and other dignitaries didn't much interest me. But if you want the most up-close-and-personal grave experience, this cemetery is for you. Unfortunately it's not open at night.

One of the most beautiful cemeteries in the world!. Build in the 1800's with 4600 + vaults above the ground, were rich and famous, politicians, presidents, military heroes have made it past the gates here. Hunt down Evita's grave and enjoy free English tours on Tuesday and Thursday. Maps are sold at the entrance. A must on every tourist's list.
Fascinating cemetary. Amazing cemetery full of ornate and simple structures. Peek inside to see the entrance to the underground burial spots. Look for Evita Peron's site.

Overrated. This place is highly overrated. It is basically showing off for the rich people. There are lots of tourists here but not sure why. If you want to skip this do something else, then go ahead.
Ostentatious Cemetery. This is an ostentatious cemetery. I was impressed by the big, great statues adorning the tombs. You can find the one from Duarte family and where Evita Peron rests.

Just wasn't for me. I wasn't that excited about going, but it was highly recommended. I walked through for about 15-20 min, trying to appreciate it from an art perspective, but couldn't get out of my own head that I was in a cemetery. If you can get past that, and plenty of people do, it is worth seeing.There is a map at the entrance, take a picture or two with your phone as once you're inside there is no plan to follow.
Central feature of Recoleta. This walled cemetery is an interesting mix of mausoleums , trees, statues , stray cats and walkways. Eva Peron's the most well known resident.

I prefer the living but..... As far as cemeteries go, this one is worth visiting.
Full of history and architecture is a very interesting place to visit.

Interesting- but Take a Guide. The story of the Ricoleta cemetery is fascination- but in order to get the most out of it, you need a guide. The depth of the mausoleums , the number interred in each, the design and art forms represented need a great deal of explanation to be fully experienced. Also, the number of people searching for Eva Peron, rushing every which way seemed like a contest to see who could get there first. It is definitely worth seeing.
Impressive. It is worth taking the time to walk through. Don't think of it as visiting a cemetery, rather admire the architecture. It is impressive. Eva Peron's grave is the main attraction there.

An extremely unique and interesting place to see.. If you are in BA you should go to see the cemetery. It is unlike most other cemetery's you will ever see anywhere else. This place is quite amazing to see and represents a collection of examples of top rated sculpture, stonework, metal work and different styles of architecture in Argentina over the last century or so. While known as the place where Eva Peron was buried, there are many other famous Argentineans buried there. Ask for directions to find Evita's grave stone as it is not that obvious or easy to find. If you get lost you will still have lots of interesting tombs to see along the way.Go on a Sunday if possible as there is an open air market outside features art, crafts, jewelry, etc. There are lots of open air cafe's in the square adjacent to the graveyard and the main BA art museum is located right across the street. Make a day of it.Definitely recommended.

Remains a roman town!. The graves and mausoleums are so impressive, it looks like a roman town! we were there for 3 hours and there were so much to see! Incredible!So far you dont need to pay to get in! ;)
Incredible place. Visited as part of a city tour and what an incredible place it is. A short queue to see Eva Peron's mausoleum and just a very atmospheric place to visit.

Not simply a cemetery. Was keen to visit the Recoleta Cemetery simply because of Evita's mausoleum... I have such interest in her life. My friend forewarned me that it was a less impressive one, compared to some others. If anyone is trying to identify her mausoleum, best do so by checking the map at the entrance it helps - Evita's name goes as - Durante de Perón, Maria Eva - Evita.Besides that however, there are many mausoleums of significant political and military personnel. The creative marble work of some of these mausoleums make it a place worth visiting. It seems like a museum!Try to make it to this place if you are in Buenos Aires.

Amazing. I know a cemetery is not a place you would think to go see, but this is such a gorgeous unique place! I've never seen anything like it. The art work on the statues and stones were just amazing. Something you don't want to miss!

Not to be missed!. This cemetery situated in one of the best districts of Buenos Aires, Ricoleta is a reall history. A real history of whole Argentina, not only Buenos Aires. There you can see tombs and vaults of presidents and traitors, unknown marines and Evita Peron, noble families and millionaires dynasties, heroes and criminals, scientists and artists, victims and next door their executioners and so on. By the way, the place there costs at least 500 000 USD and thousands per year. So it's not enough to die to be there, it's necessary to die rich :).This is on of the most touristic places in the city, mentioned in all touristic guides and maps. As I said before you should visit it during the exploring the city.Sincerely Yours,Artur

Recoleta Cemetery. Quite interesting place to visit but get a local guide for 10 U.S. and will know all local informative stories plus see Evita Peron tomb and others.It is good to use the hope on bus to get there as well as other places in Buenos Aires, although it's not cheap, 390 pesos per person (39 U.S. ) but if you change currency not in bank, better in yr hotel, rate will be 13.5 per 1US

Fascinating. We visited the cemetery with our amazing guide, who told us about the different mausoleums, the people buried here (or in casquets!) and Argentina's history as well as Buenos Aires'. The mausoleums are stunning, everyone telling its own story. If your family owns a mausoleum, you can still be placed in it. From Evita to important military figures, young poets and "normal" people, everybody wanted to demonstrate theirvwealth and position in society -- and Recoleta tells this story to us today!

Other-worldy & incredible. I spent an afternoon wandering round this incredible collection of crypts and memorials - the design blew me away. Recoleta Cemetery is huge, and with its streets between the statues, feels like a secluded city for the dead. Some crypts are very run down and neglected, while others are spanking new - it's a real eclectic mix. I didn't take a tour but I think this would have added to the experience, as there's obviously so much history here and I found myself wondering about all the stories contained in the Cemetery. Visit late afternoon and bring your camera!

A must see. We visited during a walking tour and again on an evening after dinner. It is amazing and full off rich history. If you are in Buenos Aires, you should definitely visit whether independently or as a part of a tour.

Don't miss it!. I thought, OK, it will be a nice cemetery. It is in reality an outdoor art museum, as well as a real life presentation of Argentine history. Photographers of all levels will be captivated. Death and life and remembrance never seemed so grand. The English speaking tour guide on Thursdays at 11:00 did an excellent job of telling the story of Buenos Aires as seen from the monuments.
Amazing place. It might look a bit spooky, but it is worth a visit. I couldnt imagine anything like this exists. Every tomb is unique and has its story. This is a must when in BA!

Wanted to see Evita's grave sight!. We were offered a free tour offered by the City's free tour guide program. Glad we did. This is a fantastic cementary. The mausoleums are pieces of art...many worth millions, but to understand the history & anecdotal information enhanced our visit 3 fold. The chapel next door also interesting. Get the tour! Worth it!

Outdoor Museum. It is a one of the most beautiful places in BA, it is full a history, and there are a lot of cats. Beautiful sculptures in all tombs. And Evita´s grave is the only with fresh flowes, but it is very simple.
Nice. Nice place to hang around, there is weekend market with lots handcrafts, the mall is nearby and basic.

WOW!. You can spend hours here walking through the 'streets' of sarcophagus - just mind blowing. Definitely a highlight of time in BA. We even managed to see a corpse in decaying coffin deep down in one tomb - just incredible.

If you have been to Pere Le Chaise in Paris, you will love Recoleta Cemetery. Fabulous crypts with museum worthy art/statues , it is just beautiful and not sad or creepy and amazing.There is always a small group looking for Evitas grave, which is her family, not hers. But there are so many people who were important to Buenos Aires in the past, that are buried there, it is educational in its way to go there and read and pay attention. And pet the cats. Yes, there are dozens and dozens of cats who live there and are tended to by the nuns ..

Highlight in B.A.. I thought this would be a quick dash to see the resting place of Evita. I didn't realise that apart from the Duarte family vault where she is buried (very low key and not what you'd expect) the whole cemetery is fascinating. A complete contrast of architectural styles, still being used with some minimalist modern tombs side by side with wrecked old ones with broken coffins and even bones showing. Moving family photos and mummified flowers abnd remains create the most human and moving museum ever.
Interesting. From an historic point of view this is worth a visit but don't go out of your way if you feel there is something better to do.
a place of freedom for people with money. impressed about how people thought about death and even more about what they invested for be remembered after passing away....

Weekends At the Cemetery. Full of actitivites in the weekends. You will get hundreds of stalls in the park opposite the cemetary selling various local items from precious stones to inca incenses. The cemetary itself is well kept and explained.

It's my favorite attraction. I wen to there in morning ,it's amazing place you must see and you can walk around and this is like museum you don't have to pay it it's free you can take a bus to this place after .if you are in place go to lunch in Recolata Mall and 3 third floors has some cafe and you can see great view of cementry and go to cafe Hereford Parrilla is very great and also very great price too.best exchange money in mall

Why Would I Want to Visit a Cemetery?. I was highly skeptical of visiting a cemetery as a tourist attraction, but WOW. This was probably my favorite place in all of Buenos Aires. Walking around the narrow maze-like pathways jam packed with intricately and ornately decorated crypts. So much for the eyes to see and some of the best art in town. Make sure you rub the dogs nose for good luck :)Make it a game: Print a few pictures from the internet and do a scavenger hunt with the people you are with! It will be much harder than you think.

Awesome spectacle. I find that cemeteries are amazingly illustrative of cultures - how do you keep your history and your people alive for the ages? Some places do it well. BA has this place as a model for others. The range of mausoleums and individual crypts and plots is amazing. The ornate end is truly a spectacle. The history depicted in this place was pretty overwhelming. It is a quiet and worthwhile several hours to just walk through and appreciate the care and attention to presenting their descendants to the future and to others.

Exploring Recoleta Cemetery. Visiting this cemetery was a great experience. Amazing monuments, mausoleums and history. Each crpypt was unique and full of history. A photographers dream!!!Be sure to visit Evita's family crypt which is inobtrusively located a in plain black marble crypt under her family name Duarte. The odd cemetary cat completes the experience.Strongly recommended for history and art lovers. Allow 2-3 hours.

Eva Perón, First lady of Argentina. Eva Perón, First lady of Argentina is buried here along with other notable internments. Many of the mausoleums are well maintained but others are falling into disrepair. The cemetery entrance has neo-classical gates.
A must see. Wow......absolutely fascinating......You can walk around for hours admiring everything....Very unique.....Never been to a grave yard like this......It is like a city......
A Must See for Travelers. To walk among these amazing tombstones with the history they provide is a must. The area outside the cemetery is a real joy and to see those trees!
Beautiful. Amazing place tranquil and so beautifully preserved, really incredible cemetery a must do in Ba! Also the area recoleta is one of best in Ba!

A cemetery with great history. Visited this place during the end of the free walking tour, and was simply a great experience. The greatest in the country have been buried here and each of the graveyards are great to watch and listen about.

amazing place. Each nation has its own funeral and graveyard traditions, but the graveyard as small marble house town within the city was something so special. it is like a small town with small houses, where all of the buildings are so diverse and different, with own design and superiority.
Strange but fascinating.. Like many tourists we wandered through Recoleta Cemetry admiring the monuments to the deceased. My..what grandeur! How would you like to be remembered?

Amazing Place!. Was on a tour of Buenos Aires. We stopped at this places and I was fascinated by what was there! The magnitutude of the place and the interesting sights made for an interesting morning.

Visit more than once. Since we were staying in the Recoleta neighborhood, we visited the cemetery on many occasions and always found something new. So many photos from our Argentina trip are taken from this area. There are magnificent memorials in an area near lots of restaurants and other points of interest.

Recoleta Cemetery. They say it is a city within a city that boasts the elaborate tombs of Argentina's rich and famous. That is true! It was fascinating to see the intricate architecture and learn the history of many of the tombs. Our tour guide made the trip memorable. Seeing the final resting place of Evita Peron and learning of how long it took for her to finally be at rest was very interesting. I wish we would have had more time to explore the area surrounding the cemetery. It looked interesting as well.

Respect for the departed. Amazing grand constructions erected to remember their departed. Eva Peron is buried there, her memorial is so very low key apparently, I couldn't find it. A maze of memorials. The most impressive if I remember correctly was something to do with the jockey club.

fascinating. I love to explore old cemeteries, to read the stories of lives long gone. Recolata has to be one of the most interesting ever with the many tombs, statues, doorways and alleyways. Of course there are many famous people entombed here, (Evita being one of the most popular for visitors) but there are many from ordinary families as well, some obviously wealthy with elaborate doorways and engravings, some sadly neglected, all fascinating to me. Our guide filled us in on the backgrounds to some of these, many quite tragic and sad. Worth a wander.

Go!. I was pretty ambivalent about a cemetery, but we were right there and my husband wanted to go. And good thing! This cemetery is so cool. You feel like you can get lost for hours just walking through the paths, and you really feel like you are walking through history. And the architecture of the mausoleums is so intricate and beautiful. It's free and in a great neighborhood, so take some time to visit.

A very unique, extravagant, and beautifully kept cemetery. I'm not a big fan of cemeteries, but this one is unique due to the fact that many big names like Eva Peron, and famous, rich, or well known politicians have been buried here along with their families. It's interesting to see the various tombs of the family members in one underground space. There are different levels under the ground where family members can be buried but be in the same spot. Obviously, this cemetery is for the rich and famous, not for the common people. But it was a unique experience and it's well kept. It's also worth it to take a stroll around the gardens outside the cemetery.

Well worth a visit.. This Cemetary is like nothing I have ever seen before. It is like a small town, the coffins are in the equivalent of small houses which go from being quite basic to very ostentatious. Rich families have bought the plots over the years and many famous people are buried here. The main thing I would urge is to go there accompanied by a guide. We learnt so much from ours and it gave us a marvellous insight into some of Argentinas history.Of course the must see tomb is that of Eva Peron, which is surprisingly small compared to some. There are over 4000 tombs in this cemetery and it is impossible to see it all unless you are there for a week but a couple of hours is well worth the trouble.
A what a place quite unique. This cemetery is where Eva Peron is buried. The architecture is amazing . Every different design as well as decorations for the above and below tombs.

Odd but great. The cemetery tour is a must. It is different to anything you have seen or expect. These huge mausoleums from the affluent days of the past. And of course you get to see Evita Perons , fairly modest , grave.Well worth a visit
Worthwhile to visit. Very interesting to see the different mausoleums and get a grasp of the levels of wealth for previous inhabitants of the city
Interesting. I'm not always a big fan of walking through cemeteries as it can be a bit weird, but if you're going to do it then this is one of the better and more interesting ones to look through

Something to do, only if nearby. This is a tourist favorite that can be "done" in ten minutes. Walk to see Evita (space 33) and look at the other tombs on the way. Pet a cat, ignore the "guides" and leave to do more interesting things.
Fascinating especially with local guide. We went here as part of local guided tour of city. Fascinating place, but shame that so many tombs are run down. Worth the visit

Beautiful and historical. Many people visit Recoleta Cemetery because of the well-known fact Evita Peron is buried there. However, the cemetery is a quiet place with a tremendous history that is a worthwhile visit, especially for photography. We did not take a tour, and We still enjoyed the visit but I would definitely recommend one if you'd like to fully get to know the site. Last but not least, at the entrance there is a map with the location of the tombs- it's here where you can locate Eva Peron's grave, which is smaller and simpler than most, but always surrounded by flowers and eager visitors.
Beautiful. Estrange and beautiful at the same time, you can feel a bit weird trying to look into somebody else's grave, but is a great place to go.

Odd culture.. The cemetery is staggering in its devotion to death and the hopes of an afterlife.We went to see Eva Peron's tomb. We were a bit surprised at its modesty in this collection of massive tombs.She is buried in her family's tomb in an indistinct back street of the cemetery.We left the cemetery bewildered by the extravagance of it all. Wonderful tomb creations but what a culture.

Not sure what all the fuss is about. We visited on the advice of friends and because it was part of a private tour but am not sure why it is so highly regardedThere are plenty of other cemeteries with more interesting mausoleums in other cities

Piece of history . I like cemeteries. They are filled with unknown history and this one is no exemption. The statues and crypts are impressive and never fail it impress. There is a 'volunteer' that sells maps for $arg20 at the entrance. They are actually fairly good maps. Tours I believe are available

Get lost in time... Tribute to many famous Argentine leaders and prominent people. As many people have said, this is a unique cemetery for sure. Our visit was around November 11th, where we walked to it from our hotel on M.T. De Alvear. The weather was perfect and we took our time taking in the sights along the way. As we entered there was a lady handing out a map of the cemetery, for a donation. We gave her 20 pesos, her suggested donation. We spent about two hours here looking at many of the famous monuments. Evita Peron's grave naturally had a lot of tourists stopping to look and take pictures. There are many other famous people here - many from the 1800's as well as many families that have made arrangements for their relatives. Some of the monuments are in need of repair. Happily, we saw some workers dedicated to repairing some as we toured the cemetery. It was very peaceful and moving. Such loving tributes to important people and we were happy that it was open to the public, unlike some places in the United States where the cemetery for the famous people are private. All in all, if you're in Buenos Aires you'll definitely want to come here. In many of the monuments there were freshly placed flowers, candles ,etc. and you are able to see the coffins. Don't miss the opportunity to visit. Plenty of restaurants near by ( we ate at El Bien (sp)) right across the street and was very happy with our lunch,
Interesting piece of Buenos Aires. The cemetery is a lovely place to wander and look at the names and the amazing variety of tombstones and sculptures.
Historic Wandering. the cemetery is more of a museum of the who's who in Argentina. get a guide map to help you navigate this beautiful part of historic BA

Interesting stroll round the marble monstrosities. The cemetery is an interesting stroll for up to an hour, and of course everybody good to visit Eva Peron's grave - which over on the west side. Some guides make this the number 1 place to visit in BA, and would certainly not say that, but it's interesting enough and next to the pretty Our Lady of Pilar church with the entrance facing southeast into the pretty parklands. So to me it's a pleasant visit rather than a must see.

Amazing and unique. This is one of the most unique cemeteries I have visited. The majority of the tombs are large moslem structures with caskets on display inside of them. Most of the buildings are from the late 19th or early 20th century and many have large statutes or other unique elements. Well worth the visit!

Interesting but not a main destination. Lots of interesting monuments. It's nice to walk around for an hour, but that's probably enough. Many of the tombs are for famous Argentineans that we from the US are not familiar with, so they are of limited interest.

Worth A Quick Visit. First, make sure that you find the one entrance that faces Away from the river and towards AvLas Heras. We missed it and ended up walking all around the cemetery (long walk) to find the entrance. Once there it was free to enter. Upon entry the impact is a bit overpowering. Why would so many people go to such extreme lengths and expense to place closet sized mausoleums next to each other hip to hip. The mix of old world designs next to modern (replacement) units was bewildering... what a jumble. In any case, worth a stroll to view some very nice sculpture and detail on some of the 'tenants' resting places. If you are looking to find EVA PERON make sure you look at the map at the entry way under DUARTE, her family's name.... NOT under Peron.
like Pere Lachaise. I really enjoyed. Worth seeing place. Touris should see not only Evita's tombstone but go for a walk to see other interesting tombstones.
Need a guide. We went there without a guide so it was a bit boring. The cemetery itself is impressive but I'm sure if you have a guide the tour will be much more interesting.
Minimilists beware........ As spectacular as these tombs may be, I can only say that these are a reflection of human frailty. The whole experience is bazaar.

Amazing - don't miss this.. When I heard that people go to visit a cemetery, I was somewhat turned off. However, you have never seen anything like this! It is a city of mausoleums. Blocks and blocks of shrines to former cogniscenti, including the famous Eva Duarte Peron. Everyone goes to her tomb and some placed flowers there. The people here loved her. Outside of the cemetery there are many craft booths for purchasing locally-made crafts. Very wonderful. Things to eat too. Great time.
History & Artistry. Truly amazing historic site. the magnificent tombs, family plots and sculpture is like an outdoor museum. Don't miss the famous Evita's burial site. Just follow the crowds :)

A walk in a strange but beautiful place. We took a walk in the neighborhood of the Cemetery. You'll find a beautiful park with trees that are more then a 100 yrs. old and a Monastery also. Right across the park you will find a street with a bunch of cafes. Rare experience but beautiful nevertheless.

One of the "must see " places in BA. A fascinating place to wak around. You'll never see another cometary like it. I just wish we had planned it better. Guided tours are only given once or twice a week ! Definitely get a map (sold at the entrance-- otherwise admission is free) and wander. Afterwards, enjoy a coffee in one of the many nearby cafes. We were lucky enough to have street performers performing tango while we had our refreshments!

Het Pere Lachaise van Buenos Aires. A must for every tourist. Not only for the grave of Eva Duarte (Peron) but for undergoing the impression of a catholique cemetery for the rich and famous. The statues and monuments are impressive and you also can see the sign of time if there is no maintenance of the grave.
Amazing.... such a cemetery!. Beautiful all the mausolems of the families...so spectacular, artistically, with sculptures too. Evita was a bit lost...but nice with flowers!
A Must See!. A must see and visit! The cemetary is massive. We spend an afternoon here just looking at all the archetectural detail that goes into a tombstone here. Unbelievable!!

A must see - eerie and beautiful!. If you are staying in Buenos Aires - please do not miss this important and stunning historical landmark! Whilst we have never considered visit a cemetery as tourists before, you are welcomed at Recoleta Cemetery. As well as being the burial place of Eva Perón and other notable figures, Recoleta Cemetery houses some of the most beautiful sculptures, mausoleums and statues and is an extremely peaceful and interesting location. Entry is free, but you can buy a great map from a local volunteer for $20ARS. This includes all the names of the families and notable people here and also offers some other general information and photos. You can easily spend hours here, or even just have a short look to get an idea of the history and effort that are built in to the cemetery. It is clean and well maintained and popular with tourists, locals and school groups too. A must see!
Worth the trip. Stunning organization and architecture of the tombs. Creepy and beautiful at the same time. Can't wait to come back with my teenage kids, I'm sure they'd love it. Free too!

A unique perspective on the city. Our visit to the Recoleta Cemetery gave us an insight to some of the history of the wealthy families of the city. The stories out guide told us of powerful generals, rich families and tragic deaths were fascinating. The streets of granite edifices, statues and memorials are interesting to visit. Not to mention that you can see the final resting place of Eva Peron
Amazing place. It's impressive to look at so much architectural richness and art invested in the tombstones or Breyer said houses!!! Don't miss it
Beautiful but not that exciting . The cemetery is special and beautiful but you get the point after a few minutes. We didn't took a tour but I guess it can be much more interesting with it.

The Architecture is Amazing!. One might think that a visit to a cemetery is a morbid affair, but I can assure you a visit to Recoleta Cemetery is a history and architectural lesson something not missed by the school system in Buenos Aires. Here you can learn about the history of the movers and shakers of the city and the country. Of course, Evita is purportedly buried here along with numerous generals and Argentine Presidents. But for me the most amazing aspect is the architecture of the rows and rows of monuments. A must see!

Strange and wonderful.. The cemetery in Recoleta is for the rich and extravagant. One masoleum more extreme than the other. The sense of grandeur is wild! There are marbles and mahogany, painted portraits and busts, old graves, new graves, and cats. It is so morbid, and I really love it! I totally recommend going. If you can go on a weekday it's not so crowded. Free entry, and closes at 18.00
It is true: you should not miss this.. Beautiful architecture, a truly special place. It is somewhat difficult to locate Evita's tomb. The best way is to follow a tour group.
Amazing. Stunning look at architecture, history and culture. Have not seen anything like it. Worth a visit. Free

A site to see!. I never would have thought I would go visit a cemetery on vacation but it definitely is worth it if you like architecture, marble statues, and history. We were fortunate to meet tour guide Simon at the entrance of the cemetery, he provides free walking tours, and receives a tip/payment at the end if you wish. We have had the experience of having tour guides for many sights along our travels and have found the experience to be an added bonus to the visit wherever we are. We were able to find Evita's tomb, hear the history of the cemetery, how it functions, and take in the majority of the cemetery within about an hour with the guide.
Interesting place . This is an interesting place considering how much Argentinian history this place holds. Including the final resting place is Eva Peron

unique cemetary. one of the must see places in BA. worth buying a guide of cemetery to get the full story or checking on when the walking tours are scheduled. See EVa Peron's mausoleum. La Biela cafe is close to entrance

Who would've thought visiting a cemetery would be interesting?!. This cemetery is def a must do while visiting Buenos Aires. Originally, like probably most tourists, I went to visit the Eva Peron tomb- however, that wasn't all there was to see. Walking inside this cemetery made me feel as if I was walking into a museum. The sculptors this place has is unreal- and at times I had to remind myself that I was visiting the sacred place of people's remains and not a museum. We were on a tight schedule as we were doing an all day city tour and as such we didn't really get a chance to see much and were so impressed by the grandness of this place that we went back in the afternoon to take our time and visit these impressive memorial structures. A definite must see!
Fascinating . Well worth an explore. Strange to see all the monuments to families. Some very grand and some very plain and run down. Probably best early as less crowds.

fascinating, and well worth a visit. Firstly there is no admission fee. Secondly, largely as Eva Peron is (now) buried here, it is a big draw. Thirdly it was genuinely impressive and interesting. We visited as part of a wider city tour and having a knowledgeable guide who could show us interesting aspects and explain particular facets was really worth while.Worth noting if you do go yourself that Eva Peron is buried in the Duarte family plot (her maiden name).

Slightly tatty but fascinating. Went on the recommendation of a tour guide. It is free to enter and through the entrance are 'streets' mausoleums and sepulchres. They vary from those not much wider than a door to huge and ornately decorated. Many are old and lots of these are in need of repair. There are also more modern ones.The whole experience is fascinating and a bit strange but I have seen nothing like it.Well worth a visit

Fascinating side of BA. Even at 11.30am on a Sunday it was peaceful and uncrowded in the Cemetery. The place is beautifully maintained, as you would expect from the clientele! Some fabulous and wonderful tombs and some lovely stories. Spent an hour or so just wandering and taking photos. Would love to see it with a bit of a mist!

Fascinating experience. I did a 3 hour walking tour of BA and spent at least 1.5hr in the cemetery (as morbid as it sounds). Such great stories of some of the mausoleums and it is truly a sight to be seen. Eva Peron's is just one of the great stories. I would highly recommend a visit here and wander through the many corridors. My tip would be to get a guide to tell you the history and fascinating stories of them.

great way to spend a morning or afternoon. Free cemetery that is one of the highlights of BsAs. Spend an afternoon wandering through the alleys, being absorbed by how incredible each and everyone of them are. As we left, we found the map near the entrance of where Evita's tomb was, but without the map we ended up finding it after awhile. This cemetery is worth seeing!

A Must when Visiting BA. This is one of the most interesting cemeteries that I have visited. The memorial structures are very impressive architecturally. It is a maze of walkways and some of the memorials are so sweet and are lovely tributes. Of course the Evita memorial is a must see, always filled with flowers.

A marvel to see. My wife and I did a self-guided tour of the cemetery. It took us about an hour or so, wandering through the narrow passages and stopping frequently to read thoughtful tributes and marvel at majestic sculptures and architecture. The cemetery is big enough that you can find quiet places, but not so big that you'll really get lost. The tombs are truly incredible; they've been built over the course of a century so there's a dynamic range of materials and styles represented.We weren't able to find Evita's tomb without heading back to the entry to consult the map, but it's relatively straightforward once you know where you are headed.Overall, a wonderful opportunity to share in the history of Argentinian culture.
Must see at buenos aires. This is one of the most famous places. Must see for every tourist. Beautiful and scary at the same time.

Fascinating and eerie.... Beautiful, haunting and almost surreal, wander the tombs of Agentinas powerful and wealthy ancestry. Eva Peron is interred here-though her final resting place is a little underwhelming considering the impact she had on this amazing country.

A very unique place. I always thought that visiting a cemetery as tour attraction was a little morbid. However, this place was worth both the time and effort when one was visiting Buenos Aires. We were taken there as part of a guided tour, and was amazed how large and ornate this place was, and it had many historical figures buried there. I did not have a lot of knowledge on Argentinian history, but surely recognized the story of Eva Peron who was buried there. The cemetery was so big that every isle (row) has a “street sign”, just like a little city! My wife and I followed the tour guide closely because it would be easy to get lost and separated from the group. Also noticed was some former distinguished or wealthy families had lost their power or fortune, and thus the maintenance on their family tombs became neglected, becoming very sad and rundown sights. Overall, this attraction should be high on anybody’s list while visiting BA.

One of Buenos Aires loveliest attractions. I really enjoyed visiting the cemetery, it has beautiful sights. The whole recoleta area is beautiful with lovely places to grab a bite or just walk and enjoy the views. Arrive early since it gets a bit crowded specially over weekends.
Interesting place!. Wonderful place to wander around in ... so gorgeous and ornate. You really do have to have money to be buried here I am imagaining!!!!
Very interesting. the most interesting attraction in BA. Different than any cemetery I have seen (and I am not a cemetery guy) but worth the visit.

art collection. I visited Rocoleta 3 times and every time I see new things. Most people go for and hour or less and run to see Evita grave. I made that mistake first as well. Her grave which she share with her family is not as interesting as many other beautiful mausoleums. The your time is worth it.

AWESOME cemetary. What a cool and unique cemetery to walk around. The stones were amazing and very different than we are used to in the states and many other places. It is absolutely gorgeous and its a must see. It is an active cemetary and we were there during a funeral so it is a little weird to be taking pictures but you are allowed. Eva Peron is buried here but her tombstone is hard to find you will need to ask for help.
Totally Worth It!. Do not miss this beautiful place! Make sure to get there early before it closes because the guard was trying to not let us in when it was still open for 30 minutes. Enjoy!
Only for history. Just for people strongly involve in Argentinian history. Not a bad place but you have many other great things to do in Buenos Aires.
impressing. Wonderful cemetry, get a free tour and visit the graves of many important people of the argentine history!

You're thinking, "yeah, right, a cemetery, I'll pass." Don't!! A MUST SEE.. The Recoleta Cemetery is a calm and quiet respite from the constant noise of Buenos Aires. In a one-hour tour, you will learn so much of the history of Argentina that would be difficult any other way, and some amazing stories as you walk among the burial chambers of the (sometimes extremely) rich and famous. I have been on the Spanish tour three times, and English tour twice, and I continue to go every time that I can.

Death and money. A must see in Buenos Aires. Family mausoleums, one more ostentatious than the next. Clearly in Argentine society your birth is much less important than your death. Death here will show how financially successful your life was. Fascinating.......and Eva Duarte (Evita) is buried there.

Fascinating experience!. Don't miss this amazing place if you are in Buenos Aires. It's a little way from the city centre but on the BA Tourist Bus route and well worth the visit. Everyone goes to see the memorial to Evita of course but there are numerous other intriguing monuments and stories regarding both the famous (lots of former presidents) and not-so-famous. It's also worth visiting when you can take advantage of the guided tour (free - check which day(s) it is available) which is offered in English and Spanish. Our guide was Martha who had just the right balance of sombre and amusing anecdotes.Definitely one for your itinerary.

Beautiful cemetery. Walking by, you'd have no idea the cemetery is there. It's technically pretty small, but these beautiful mausoleums and statues are packed in so closely it feels very large. Obviously the big attraction is Evita's grave (which is very modest compared to it's neighbors) but it's worth strolling around and looking at the rest as well.

A Great placeto visit. Until I got there, I w did not realize what a great place to visit. Helpful to havea guide or guide book since ther eal story are the denials and specific stories about some of the monuments and he peole buried there. Be sure to visit Evita. .

Impressive experience. During our most recent visit to Buenos Aires we visited the Recoleta Cemetery well known since Evita Perron - Duarte is buried there. What an impressive experience, what a way to be buried and still be here for ever
Fascinating (and look for signs of Marronos). A truly fascinating place to visit with at least five tombs showing evidence of Marrono roots in the community.

Impressive. If you have visited Pere-Lachaise cemetery in Paris, than Recoleta is going to be sort of a deja-vu, but, nevertheless worth seeing by all means. Impressive marble edifices, white and black as well, and some very nice statues. Not to be visited during a rainy day.
Must see. We were enthralled by the history of this place but also found it both sad & uncomfortable but having said that cemeteries that we know in the UK are just so different. Well worth a visit.
Must see. I know, a cemetery. But go. The mausoleums are amazing. Look at the stain glass from inside and be prepared to be amazed. The marble angels adorning the buildings and breathtaking.

Unique. Spent an enjoyable hour, self exploring Recoleta cemetery - read the guide book this will be sufficient! Followed the crowds to see the Evita mausoleum - not much else to see there. There are few attractions anywhere like this one - the well preserved coffins openly visible ensure this. A must see in Buenos Aires.

Much better with a guide. My husband and I have been here a couple of times but the most recent time we had a guide and it was a much more interesting experience. There are many beautiful tombs here that tell of the history of Argentina as well as buenos aires. We ended up spending almost two hours here which was much more than we had planned. Definitely go early in the day as it is less crowded and much more enjoyable. By the afternoon there were tour buses up and down the streets and hundreds of people everywhere in the cemetery.

Get lost the in maze of mausoleums!. An eerily beautiful necropolis that happens to be the final resting place of Argentina's most famous first lady Eva Duarte Peron. The English-speaking tour is very informative, but also take some time to wander around and explore on your own. Lots of interesting photo opportunities with the architecture and cats. (As of December 2014, the English tours were at 11 am on Tuesday and Thursday mornings.)

If you have nothing better to do.................... As a consequence of a half day city tour, we also did a short walk around the cemetery. The culmination was the tomb of the Duarte Family, and the final resting place of Eva Peron.Not something to make a special trip for, but you may as well do it, if it is offered.

Not as macabre as it seems. Yes, this is where Eva Peron is interned. You will need to look for the family Duarte's crypt. We spent an hour or two just marvelling at the grandeur of many of the crypts. Some were representations of the mansions that they formerly lived in. Rather bizarre to see glass doors and being able to see the coffins lying in state.

Interesting but awkward. Very interesting to see what people will do or did for status. But I couldnt help but feel a bit like watching animals in a zoo or disturbing the dead. Also coming to see Evita's last resting place between the people she hated and the last place she wanted to be doesnt feel right..

Morbidly Spectacular. Yes, it's a cemetery, yes, it won't suit anyone afraid of an attack from the living dead. But regardless of that, it's free and the time, care and expense spent on some of the mausoleums is remarkable. The crowds flock to see Eva Person's final testing place, but it's worth a walk around the whole thing. It's also close to other attractions including the Museo Nacionale des Artes and, if you like design, pop into Design Buenos Aires just next door to the cemetery.

Interesting piece of History!. We took a tour of the Cemetery and learned so much about the history. It was interesting and of course we looked for the crypt of Eva Peron. Being able to hear the stories about the wealthy families buried there was a real lesson...The location of the cemetery was very near our hotel so we walked back the next day for a longer tour.

The most famous Cemetery in all Argentina. This cemetery is the most famous in all Argentina because of the important people buried in it. In addition, the neighborhood is the most classy and refined in Buenos Aires.

A strikingly unique Cemetery. While it is best known as the cemetery with Eva Peron's crypt, the cemetery is totally unique, with "avenue after avenue" of elaborate and unique masoleums. A definite must see in Buenos Aires
Recoleta. Located in the very charming neighborhood of Recoleta, this Cemetery hosts old presidents and famous people from Argentina. You won't spend more than 1 or 2 hours at this place.

Amazing. I just really had no idea what to expect, but enjoyed that you could wander around for hours. We did NOT pay for the tour as it was highly overpriced and we were able to find Eva Peron's family's gravesite by the other people walking that way anyway. Bring plenty of water and use the bathroom before you go - the bathroom there is sparse and hadn't been attended to in awhile.

Quite interesting. Visiting this cemetery is a must, not only because of its beautiful statues but also because of the history it contains. There are guided tours both in Spanish and English, this information is generally available at the entrance. Several Argentinian iconic characters are buried here, among them Eva Peron.

Beautiful. This is a great historic landmark in the city. I wasn't sure how I would feel about it, but it was very interesting and the architecture was amazing. Definitely recommend checking this place out.
Fascinating. Well preserved, well maintained, very interesting indeed. Fabulous tombs and so ornate, some must have cost a fortune. Whole family's history in one place.
Must see. A great place to know more about the cultural site of Buenos Aires, art and passion melt together for a great experience.

A walk through history. A nice way to spend an afternoon. You can walk all through the cemetery and see the ornate buildings and shrines that are built up inside. Like walking through any neighbourhood but very quiet. The grave sites are a look back into the history of Buenos Aires. Eva Peron is there...some where. It is not easy to find her resting place. Outside of the cemetery is a nice park and close walking distance to some coffee shops after your visit.

A Must See Site. The recoleta cemetery is a one of a kind experience of old and new mosoleums for the rich and powerful of Argentina. You could spend a day or two here, so give yourself at least an hour to wander the rows of beautiful craftsmanship.

Nice, different, historical, aristocratic, artistic. Still a cementery.... Would go with a guided visit in order to fully appreciate. I'm not a lover of visiting cementeries... It's easy to get to,, centric, with a very european influence.

Never get tired of visiting this cemetery. I'm sure it seems creepy, but there are so many beautiful statues and trees, it's like a museum but in the open and with graves. It is like an oasis in the heart of busy Recoleta. Eva Peron's grave is a must for visitors. The guided tour is very helpful. Or you can just go read a book sitting on a bench, if you can put up with the fact that you are surrounded by graves.

A Remarkable Cemetery. Other cemeteries in South America have beautiful family burial sites, but Recoleta has another feature. Inside you see the casket of the last family member to pass away. You will note that their is either an opening in the floor or a stairway. When the next person dies the casket on view is moved to a lower level. I am told there could be 6 or more levels below ground. A must see if in Buenos Aires.
A must !. It would be a shame to miss this. Not necessary to take a guide but we did learn a lot from the tour guide that we were using for our 3 hour city trip.
Wonderful. Great attraction - relatively small but with wonderful tombs which many of them are just piece of art...English speaking guides are available too. A must!
Excellent free tour, the guide was very professional and entertaining.. Excellent free tour, the guide was very professional and entertaining, she deserved a big tip. Literally a city for the dead.

Top BA tourist attraction!. Even if you are not a cemetery fanatic, you will be amazed and enthralled with the mausoleums seemingly thrown together, cheek by jowl. Never made it to Evita's tomb, but I don't think she missed us among the throngs of fans. A great way to understand the history and culture of Buenos Aires.
Amazing!. Great place to visit in Recoleta!! Art lovers will enjoy it even more. Be aware of closing hours. Great for a sunny day and creepy for rainy ones.

Rest In Opulence!. Visiting a cemetery would definitely not have featured on our personal itinerary during a recent visit to Buenos Aires, but our guide convinced us that this particular cemetery was part of BA's history and very different to what one would expect to find in a cemetery. That certainly was very true! I was amazed to find some amazing memorials dedicated to departed loved ones. It seemed as if each structure was competing to be the biggest and the best in architectural design and dedicated memories. So surreal! I'm glad that I followed the my guide's steer. Well worth a visit.
Don't miss this unusual place. We spent half an hour walking around this strange and beautiful above ground cemetery. Look for Evita's surprisingly small tomb while you're here.

Unique and Compelling. Recoleta Cemetery is very unique and definitely worth seeing. I would recommend researching before or hiring a guide to get the most of it. In addition to Eva Peron's grave there are graves with compelling ghost stories attached to them.
City of the dead. This is a wonderful city of the dead. Amazing mausoleums. Evita is in here, in a vault supplied by Juan Peron via her brother.

Amazing Architecture!. One of the best attractions in Buenos Aires. If you are into architecture, or spooky places I highly recommend this. You could spend the entire day wandering around this huge cemetery. The mausoleums range from 100 plus years old and falling apart to some very new and modern crypts.

Better with a Tour Guide. Very interesting cemetery in it's structure and history. Any visit would be enhanced by an educated, trained tour guide to give details about history and the departed who are located here.

Very interesting Visit. Very interesting visit - try make it for one of the free guided tours. The sculptures alone are worth admiring, but you can also pay your respects to some well-known Argentinians and learn about some of the quirky ones as well.
