Amazing Place. Made our own way there on public transport/walking. Once there it was well worth it. Never seen a cemetery like it before. It is huge!! We only went to see Eva Peron's grave/tomb. Unfortunately it is not signposted, and it is very difficult to find, but with a bit of patience and follow people we eventually found it. Not what we expected though, but we have seen it. The memorials are opulent, oversized, they come in all sizes. Wouldn't like to visit on a evening though

Very interesting mausoleums, some dating 200 years. The cemetery contains hundreds of mausoleums with interesting historical bits of information. There is one for the famous Argentinian president Sarmiento.
Very interesting. Really worthwhile going there with a guide who can explain some of the history and the story of Eva Peron who is buried there.

Very interesting experience . I really enjoyed visiting this cemetery. The structures are wonderfully built. There's a lot of history in this place. I also loved finding cats sleeping on the steps of various tombs. It was a nice surprise. :)

Amazing cemetry. This is quite an extraordinary cemetery, with rows of opulent memorials. Of course you need to follow the tours so you see the tomb of Eva Peron which would be difficult to find otherwise. Well worth the visit.

A beautiful yet haunting place. We explored La Recoleta with our tour guide, Alex from Tangol Tours whilst on a bike tour of the area.Alex brought us to many burial places and was able to tell us all sorts of poignant stories of how many of the people had died.It was a fascinating place to visit and gave us a lesson in the history of Buenos Aires.

good English tour on Thursday at 11. It's an unusual cemetery and the sculptures are quite beautiful. Some of the sarcophagi are quite rundown. The tour was pretty good and longish, about an hour and a half.

Buenos Aires History. Good place to visit - provides a potted history of the city citizens. A guide is helpful. A must see for everyone is Eva Peron resting place - always flowers left by visitors. Take the time to look around a reals treasure trove of sculptures. No wonder UNECSO has provided support to maintain and upkeep this world heritage.

Finding the weird and the wonderful. Great cemetery. Felt much like the Saint Louis Cemetery in New Orleans with many of the above ground vaults though at the Recoleta, it was interesting to see how deep some of the crypts really went with many generations of families. The intricacies of the sculptures were beautiful. It was weird to see the cat food left under seats for the local animals but added to the supernatural feel. The one statue of the young woman with her dog in copper looked spookily like The Corpse Bride. Not sure if Tim Burton saw it and got his inspiration! Fun looking at the tombs. You could spend days here if you had the time.

You have to see it to believe it.. So much attention - and money I guess - goes into building these mausoleums, some of them are luxurious. The one where Eva Perón rests is surprisingly modest. Some of us felt a little uneasy seeing coffins through the doors of the mausoleums...

Detinitely worth visiting. So many years of history and culture in one site! definitely take the guided tour. The english one is on Tuesday and Thursdays at 11:00 am. The sites, including Evita's grave and some of the newer ones are amazing! its a surreal experience!

EVITA's Tomb. While visiting Buenos Aires in April 2011 I had occasion to visit the cemetery in Recoleta. I was in search of the Tomb of EVITA Eva Duarte Peron. She was the wife of Juan Peron, President of Argentina back in 1946. She was adored by the lower classes called the DESCAMISADOS ( the shirtless ones ) aka, the poor. Rumor has it that her remains are not actually in her family tomb but underfoot, in front of her tomb. Who really knows ? But the cemetery is really something to see. It is like a small city with it's majestic tombs and grave stones. The place had several tour groups there on the day of my visit and many of the tourist were there to view the final resting place of EVITA , imagine that.

Cemetery in a different way. Who would've thought that visiting a cemetery was a requirement during a visit to a city? it is in Buenos Aires, in the Recoleta neighbourhood.The mausoleums are unbelievably detailed and beautiful and some are just straight out creepy and maybe you see more than you bargained.There are plenty of important people resting in this cemetery, including Napoleon's granddaughter, but the most searched grave is Evita Peron's. But don't think it's right at the entrance with a huge sign for you to see it right away. You have to look for it!

Must see - very surprizing.. We were amazed at the opulence in this cemetery. It is really something unique - Evita's tomb is really not the highlight. We went here twice on our 5 day visit - surrounding area very nice as well for parks and shops.

Worth a visit if you love sculptures, statues, monuments and don't mind a cemetery. We were part of a tour group and we had a guide who accompanied us to this fascinating cemetery. Personally, I don't like visiting cemetery unless there is a beloved resting there. However, Recoleta Cemetery in Buenos Aires is a tourist attraction with many visitors (both local and overseas) daily, mainly because it is the resting place of mainly famous people and that the whole area is like an art museum with many beautiful sculptures, statues and monuments. We paid honors to Evita's grave, which was quite easy to find.
Wonderful. Go and visit it. Different from any other graveyard I have seen. Ask around to find eva peron's grave. A must see in BA.

Icon of the history of Argentina. Full of symbolism, the burial sites of some of the greatest names of the history of Argentina, take you back to many pasts. Be sure to have a guide, as many of the best symbols need to be pointed out, and the political, economic and social circumstances need to be explained. Better if an overview of the history of the country is done beforehand. The best times of the year are spring and fall, when the weather is nice. Right in front is Restaurante La Biela, or crankshaft. It's history is also fascinating.

Breathtaking and morbid all in one, nothing quite like it. The beauty hidden with the crypts. Be ready for a curious peek at one of the world's most beautiful cemeteries. Yes, there are many other mausoleum and above ground cemeteries but none that are as preserved and with so much history, nor as beautiful as La Recoleta Cemetery.Lots of interesting angles for shots can be had. Don't forget to view one of the most visited tombs in the world belonging to Eva Duarte (Evita Peron).
Fascinating. The cemetery is a unique and amazing exploration of history and culture of Buenos Aires. I would highly recommend a visit there.

Paying honors to Evita. If you don't have any beloved resting here, then probably the first (and maybe only) reason to visit this place is to pay honors to Evita's grave. As you walk into the cemetery trough the main gate you might be approavhed by someone trying to help you to find the grave in return for some tip. You don't need that: just follow the people, as most of them head for her grave which is a hundred yards up and then to the left. Also other famous Argentinians are burried here, and the cemetery in its own is beautifully held and taken car of.
A must do if you are in Recoleta. If you like to take pictures you will love this place, you have a shoot in each corner. It's like an open air museum.

Buenos Aires's Primo Attraction. Yes, sometimes the number one attraction in a place can be its cemetery -- especially if the vast majority of a country's famous political, business, artistic, and literary figures are interred there. The most famous resident, of course, is Evita Peron (she's buried under her maiden name of Duarte), but you will find Presidents like Sarmiento and writers like Bioy Casares and the Ocampo sisters. Admission is free. There is a crafts fair on weekends at the Plaza Francia just outside the front gate.

Bizarre. Interesting place to wander around. Lots of photo opportunities. I have never seen anything quite like this. All the above ground crypts, statues, monuments. It was just sort of a weird place to wander around. Just outside the cemetery there are usually people selling stuff - a little street vendor collection.

Iconic and Unique Cemetery. I've not seen anything that compares to Recoleta Cemetery. The intricate sculptures alone make this its own art museum. I spent 2 hours wandering and wondering at the effort each family made to construct such memorials to honor passed family members. I found it very interesting that many tombs were easily looked into and we could see the old caskets covered in dust sitting untouched for decades. I could go on and on but I will wrap this up by saying that Recoleta Cemetery is a MUST SEE.Recommendations: Allow 2 to 3 hours to experience this, wear comfortable shoes and check the weather before going.Safety - the area is absolutely safe to visit, just watch your pockets Watch out for pickpockets - take only what you absolutely need and nothing moreTake your camera - you will use it a lot hereThe area is crowded with tourists especially on Sunday when the street fair is happening. Street fair has great, hand made stuff for souvenirs.Great family outing or solo - everyone can enjoy thisLots of restaurants nearby that cater to the tourist crowd

A cemitery. What can one say about a cemetery? It is old. I personally find it macabre to be looking inside tombs, but worth the visit. The mausoleums are interesting enough, with different architecture and art.

A must see in BA, but not favorite attraction.. Great piece of history in center city. A little bit creepy, and in need of restoration and regular maintenance. Still, not to be missed for historical significance.

I hate cemetery, but this experience. .. It's just amazing! How could a place be so wonderful and beautiful. I can't explain, but the experience and the energy is amazing. When u stop to think about each pit, the history, and then u see the flowers, makes u see that they aren't dead. When someone goes there to put roses, means that the memory is still alive.

A must in Buenos Aires. What a magnificent cemetery!!! We went there to see Evita's grave, which was quite difficult to find. The atmosphere in the cemetery was like some scene from the novel by Carlos Ruiz Zafón.
Fancy cemetery. Meh... it's a cemetery, which is somewhat of a depressing experience, except for the extravagant tombs which were built to honor the deceased that are buried there.
Open sky museum. Just fabulous! It is a "must " in Bs As. A tip for you...if you hire a guide you will enjoy better than going by yourself.

Like an Outdoor Museum. It felt like walking in an outdoor museum being inside this cemetery. The impressive statues and sculptures were captivating. Almost every corner is worth photographing. Of course, I came here to visit the resting place of its famous inhabitant - Evita Peron.
Fascinating. Very interesting cemetery. Compares very comparably to the Christopher Columbus cemetery in Havana, Cuba.
Ok but a little disappointing. Perhaps the hype was too much, but we found the cemetary a little disappointing. Very pleasant to walk around and spend an hour, but I wouldn't say it is a must see.

Nice sculptures. This is a nice walk to appreciate the sculptures more than to follow Evita's story and all that. For me, this is a beautiful space when it comes to trees, sculptures as I said, and the great work of some mausoleums and stained glass windows.It is a little bit unkempt, but of course, some things don't depend on the care of the cemetery itself but on the owners of the mausoleums. For tourists, there are guided visits explaining part of the history of several famous figures buried there. There's a phone number available on their official website. There's a fair during the weekends on the square besides the cemetery and some of the stands remain there during the week. Check attractions nearby.

Amazing . Our tour guide said that we were going to visit a cemetery. I was not all that excited about visiting a cemetery. Then we arrived, oh my! This cemetary is incredible! Highly recommend anyone visiting!!
Enjoying a Cemetery? Weird, isn't it!. Recoleta Cemetery is a must seen place in BA, and it is very interesting for a cemetery. Note: you may not be able to find Evita's place, so follow the crowd :D
Cemetery worth visiting. Amazing architecture .... Eva Peron is also buried there. Although her grave is one of the more modest ones

Landmark rather than a cemetery. Recoleta Cemetery is more than a cemetery. You will not see gravestones as you see in another famous ones, for instance Père Lachaise Cemetery in Paris. This place is a small city with alleys, sculptures, huge tombs and even little huts for the graves. The artistic work and designs are beautiful, however it also shows that the urban legend is true. Rich Argentinian families are saving money throughout their whole life to be buried here. Evita's grave is easy to miss if there is not a much big crowd and it is quite modest.
Historic cemetary. Take a walk through quickly or spend hours walking the aisles. We did not take a tour but I'm sure it would be fascinating. We did find the Duarte family.

Nice place for a walk. This cemetery is really interesting to visit for an hour or more. Full of amazing sculptures etc. We went to the monastery next door after our visit, and really loved its small cheap museum of religious art- felt like it was a real find. Check out the alabaster windows.
A must see. Fascinating must see when you are in Buenos Aires.Recoleta Cemetery is a beautiful and well maintained resting place with hundreds of ornate mausoleums.

To see in the death how they lived.... A Must See in Buenos Aires! See all the graves of the important and rich ones who made history in Argentina. Former Presidents, wealthy citizens and even Evita Peron (don't cry for me Argentina) lie side by side in sometimes bombastic little houses and under great statues.

Recoleta Cemetery. It's a little weird to say that walk through a cemetery was a fun activity, but to see the elaborate mausoleums is quite impressive. To walk down ally after ally it seemed to be a mini city within Buenos Aires.

City of the Dead. One can spend an hour or a week in this living museum to the dead as written in the stone vaults in which they are buried. With the right guide or guid book, one can unlock personal and broader stories at the foot of each vault. The area outside the Cemetery often has interesting art-craft vendors and nearby is wonderful ice cream and empanadas.

Interesting and informative place.. Great place to visit and learn about families and traditions of Buenos Aires. Do check the times of the tours in advance and arrive early to make sure you will get a free map.

Had a great afternoon walking with the Dead. Cemeteries are not usually my thing but this place is fascinating. The sculptures on many of the monuments are fantastic. Some of the crypts have been unkempt for years and years which give them a horror movie look with decrepit coffins in full view. There are huge crowds of visitors at the crypt of Eva Peron. We really enjoyed the beauty and the morbidity of Recieta.
Buenos Aires's attic. Final resting place of many of Argentina's elite. Evita has a tomb here but she is not buried in it. Many of the memorials are beautifully sculptured.

Recolota Cemetary. Very historical cemetery. Went there specifically to see Evita's tombstone. Entrance is free but someone there was selling maps of cemetery. Even with map navigating the cemetery was confusing.

A massive cemetery . This cemetery is immense - buy a map if you are not on a guided tour.With 4800 mausoleums to view one can really only concentrate on a few.It is a must visit though for all tourists as it is so much part of the history of the country.

Interesting if you have family buried there. Having read rave reviews about the cemetry, it was a disapointment.Some of the mausoleums were of interest, but not enough to keep us captivated for long.If we had had family buried there, it may have been more interesting

Tradition. Is tradition at buenos aires, visit this cementery, have "nice tumbs", really if you dont go not problem, but many many tourist like go to visit EVITA TOMB... really incredible. But people go.

Makes you breath deep with a conscious transcendental reflection. Is nice to see all those monumental gifts, made for the beloved that has pass away, but there are some of them, not well maintain and that touches sadly in our mortal hearts.
Crowded and dirty. Cemetery full of lost tourists trying to find Evita's place. There was non info or helpful staff. The cemetery was dirty and not very well keeped. needs maintenance

Don't miss it!. It sounds kind of creepy visiting a cemetery but the statues and all the beautiful tributes to the deceased are amazing to look at. They offer a very good map showing where Evita and everyone else is and it's a nice little neighborhood to get some lunch after you're finished
Cemetery Lovers' Delight. What a fantastic place to walk around and see such wonderful celebration of life.. Of course, you must see Evita!

Wealth and Power of a Bygone Era. Row after row of magnificent mausoleums belonging to families of wealth and power in former times. Surprisingly not one of the grandest mausoleums, Evita's tomb is a must see because of her influence on Argentina's society and culture. A visit is well worth your time.

Spectacular . Words can't describe the beauty and history in this cemetery. If possible find a guide as there is so much more to learn about the "occupants" here that is not in your guide book. Bring your camera and a treat for the friendly feral cats!
Se it as a museum. It was good, for me, cause a saw all kind of monuments made of marmol and read some history of it. It help me to learn more about their history and their people

Evita remembered. The highlight of the cemetery filled with statues and walk in tombs, of course is Evita's tomb. You can't miss it. Follow the tourists! The cemetery itself is typical of past times. You will enjoy it as much as a museum!

Astonishing devotion to the dead. And the prices paid for these crypts and tombs makes those of us who signed on for cremation quake at our arrogant insignificance. Each unique building, some with benches for contemplation, and frequent floral displays from family members, is haunted by hopes from the past for a loved one's immortality. Evita's mausoleum in particular chills the heart. Well worth the time for a tour, it takes you back in time and place in that marvelous dislocation that is so much a part of a vacation.

Visit to Evita and others. The cemetery at Recolleta is quite impressive, and our guide was very knowledgeable and informative. It does get busy with lots of coaches visiting so be prepared to wait to see the most popular areas. Plenty of interesting if not a little morbid photos can be taken here.

small city. Worldwide there are cemeteries and cemeteries. The Recoleta Cemetery is an unbelievable version of a cemetery. It looks like a small city with small buildings...Some of these grave houses are so beautiful, it will open your mouth from beauty.For the people that have 'left', it must be an honor to be buried here.......
go there, you won't regret. a beautiful exceptional place, quiet and monumental, very unique, I've never seen any cemetery of this kind before

My favorite place in Buenos Aires.. History, beauty, design all in one place. Having a background in design I loved the cemetery. Everything has been touched by human hands. From the architects, artists, stone masons, metalsmiths, sculptors, glass artists, landscape designers,woodworkers the list goes on, a place of beauty.

Interesting and impressive experience. My husband was reluctant to visit the cemetery with me. However, he changed his mind and actually enjoyed it. Don't bother to purchase a map after you enter the cemetery - there was a pushy woman trying very hard to sell us one - just follow the crowd to see the mauseleum of Eva Duarte Peron.

Got to see Evitas tomb. Impressive. The grandour of Buenos Aires past can really be seen in this cemetary. A must see destination and if your tour guide is good you will develop a proper understanding of Argentina.
Interesting cemetary. We found Eva Peron's mausoleum and spent some time wandering around this large and very interesting cemetery. It was a beautiful day to walk through this old grave site.
Must see!. Definitely a must visit location. Take the guided tour for historic facts on the cemetary and a picture of Evita Peron's mauseleum.
You can not miss this spot in BA. It is really impressive to have a walk inside the cementery of recoleta and spend some time looking for the grave of famous people like the one of Eva Perón.

One of the Best!!. As I have written in past reviews, for some weird reason, I love cemeteries. I find them mysterious and beautiful. The cemetery in Buenos Aires takes it to a completely new level though! I mean, that cemetery is like it's own town! It is a must-see if you travel to Buenos Aires - even if you're not weird and like cemeteries like me. Definitely go! (Went Spring 2013).

Incredible place. I loved the cemetery, being from little old New Zealand, I'd never seen any thing like it! I could have wandered for hours. I do regret not going on a tour of some sort, in hindsight I would have liked to hear more history and facts about the place and it's people

Impressive architecture. It seems quite strange to be visiting a cemetery, but I found it very relaxing and beautiful. You can just walk along the paths and read short descriptions of people buried there. The architecture is definitely impressive and am sure this experience is quite unique. Definitely worth visiting while in BA.

Death speaks history. Interesting cemetery, with lots of stories, history and pieces of art. Walking tour worth making! It is located in the heart of Recoleta neighbourhood. it used to be the "outer" part of the city, nowadays its withing the city. Evita´s tomb is in there.

Awesome Architecture!. This cemetery is not to be missed when visiting Argentina! The architecture is simply amazing. If you are a history buff or simply love architecture and design, then you will love it! Plus...Evita is buried there, which may interest some.

Such a thing can not see anywhere else. Others do not see such a thing, only in Buenos Aires.
Avenida 9 Julio, Recoleta cemetery (Eva Duarte Peron), beef, tango.
This is not to be missed if we get someone to this city
Check it out. Wished we'd had more time here to do the free tour. Very interesting and something I'd not experienced before.

Evita’s gravesite and other interesting things to see. I went to the cemetery as part of a bike tour. Mainly tourists go to see Evita’s gravesite, and that’s what I was looking for. It was a little difficult to find, so if you are not on a tour, you may want to ask at your hotel desk or refer to a tour book for directions to the cemetery and also if you are interested in seeing Evita’s gravesite you will need directions. It is not well marked. The cemetery itself is very interesting and if you have about an hour, you can really do it justice. Highly recommend.

Great history. It's hard to believe how popular Eva Peron is after that many years after her death.Many people visit every day, there is tons of flowers taken away every evening, the architecture of this cementary is unbelievable, how much money they will spent for the monuments of dead.

Iconic must-visit spot in Buenos Aires!. Acemetery may not seem like an awesome place to go on vacation but Recoleta surely stands out from the rest. All of the most important families and historical figures of Argentina have been buried here, inlcuding Evita. In addition, to obtaining some interesting historical background while on a tour it is located in one of the most beautiful neighborhoods of Buenos Aires. You must go!

TEATRO COLON-MUST SEE. Magnificent opera house, the most beautiful we've ever seen. The art, statues of the great singers and composers, stained glass ceilings , marble floors, the theater itself are all wonderful and a must see. Get the tickets as early as possible as they are in great demand and the tours limit the number of people.We took the English tour but it wasn't easy. We went back 3 times to get tickets. The 1st time we couldn't buy them because they had a performance the next day and it wasn't available. The 2nd time we were told they were sold out for the following day. The 3rd time we got there early and bought them again for the following day. Unfortunately we had a bass drummer who decided to practice while we where there so we couldn't hear a thing our guide was saying inside the theater.

Great experience. A new experience for me visiting a cemetery - but this is not just any cementary - it's also the final rest place of Eva Duarte Peron! Beautiful and crafted tombs with some very dramatic architectural designs - well worth a visit

Recoleta still exercises a morbid fascination. Recoleta Cemetery is the resting place of Evita Peron, and as such the goal of pilgrimage of the people for whom she was a heroine, namely. the poor and dispossessed. It is also the resting place of many of the wealthy and powerful of Buenos Aires, with very elaborate catafalques and mausolea.

The place where many of our ancestors rest, turned into a breathtaking tour of tombs, statues, etc. Worthwhile visiting. "the place where some of my ancestors rest, has now become a tourist attraction. Funny as it is, I seldom see them taking pictures at the fantastic vultures, statues, tombs and similar. Narrow paved paths take you everywhere. It looks as if you could be lost in the mid of the place, but dont worry, there are guides to lead to tour or you will always find yourself once again in the "main avenue" taking you to the entrance

Wow!. I can only say wow! I have never seen a cemetery like this one! Take your time and prepare yourself of seeing inside of tombs, mausoleums, some of them are falling apart. It's a little bit morbid when your not used to seeing caskets but also it gives some sort of respect for the dead to be displayed this way.

Definitely a must see . If you are in Buenos Aires and you want to have your " quiet " moment between the hassle of the city, the Recoleta Cemetary is such place. Perfect place to take pictures and a nice stroll. It shouldn't take you more than 2 hours. Short, quiet and architectonically attractive. What else do you need to convince yourself to go? ( it's also free!)

Great to be alive. This was a half day well spent. Its really hard to put into words the feeling one gets while visiting this place. People spend a lot of money for a memory of a loved one. The very very old ones were just as beautiful as the newer ones. I just wanted to take pictures of every one

Visiting the Graveyard. Not a very usual trip for everyone, but this Cemetary is worthwhile visiting. You should take one of the guides available in almost every language at the entrance, otherwise it will not be easy to understand the history of this place.

Dust to Dust. Well, it's said we all will turn to dust once again but it's somehow funny to see all the monies labor and beauty created by the living trying to achieve a kind of Immortality when dead. If you can bypass the creepy felling of walking past tombs and some are quite dilapidated you will find some gorgeous statuary and touching messages left to the departd loved ones.
Mysterious Buenos Aires. Beautiful monuments and fantastic histories from ancient Buenos Aires. Former Presidents tombs, personalities, etc
History is here. History, monuments in a peaceful place to visit in the middle Buenos Aires city, Recoleta. Not to miss.

A really cool slice of history, and its free!. We didn't do a tour, just looked up some of the most famous graves and went and found them on our own. It is beautiful and worth a couple hours. It is a working cemetery and we ran into families paying their respects to loved ones, its nice to keep in mind that its not just a tourist site.
Evita!. Beautiful cemetery, several important people in Argentinian history rest in there. Worth visiting if in the neighbourhood.

A must stop in Buenos Aires. It is an impressive place, quite very different of what I expected for a graveyard. Each one is a piece of art on its own, nicely decorated by trees and flowers, highly recommend

City of the Dead!!. This place is so spooky and beautiful. I've been to the New Orleans cemetery as well, but the size of this location and the actual tombs in here start to put NOLA to shame (hate to admit). Our tour guide took us here and it was not previously on my list of things to see. I'm so grateful she did as this ended up being one of our favorite stops.
A must do. This is not an activity you can spend over an hour in, but it is such a beautiful experience. We didn't use any type of tour or buy the guide as we enjoyed walking around.

Tour of Recoleta Cemetery.... This place is like a city within a city....Some of the crypts are of needed repair, you can look inside some of them and see the coffins of the deceased. Look for the crowd of people to find the Familia Duarte which is where Eva Peron is buried.
interesting to see. I never thought I would enjoy seeing a cemetery but this is interesting and historic. Walking distance from downtown.

Recoleta cemetery. Impressive area, beautiful graves. Sculptures are delicate. I wouldn't go only for Evitas grave. Reminds me of Pere Lachaise in Paris. Don't forget to visit the parc opposite , the huge trees are beautiful.
Nice historic visit. Great seeing big monuments for big argentinean celebrities. Reading and standing in front of evita's grave was spectacular.Its free and its walking distance from recoleta mall.

Worth a visit . Normally a cemetery isn't a place you'd want to visit but this was something different. It was actually well maintained and it was very interesting to see. Some of the mausoleums are actually beautiful.
A must. Even though is not into graveyards, iit is a rare opportunity to see a beautiful architecture if not to visit a place where rest some famous actors of the Argentinian history

Worth visiting . We went to visit the cemetery to fill some hours prior to hour flight. We didn't book a tour, so we bought a little map with information and the marking of the graves and its about $20 Argentinian pesos. The place is beautiful with loads of history and the staff, even the landscapers were extremely nice. It was hard to understand the map as neither the cemetery or the map have names on the different streets it has (it has many streets!), so that made it hard to get from one place to the other in a limited amount of time. It's a place you definitely need to visit when in Buenos Aires, with the right amount of time, you can walk all of its streets and will be able to visit the most famous tombs. Definitely worth going

show off graves. Evita Peron is buried here, but that is not why you should go. This old cemetery is quite special and hosts many tombstones and graves that were built to show off amongst the patrician families. Here the rich and famous were buried (perhaps not if you're from France or Belgium, where most old cemeteries look like this)

Breathtaking. A friend had recommended that we go here when she heard that we were going to Buenos Aires on Honeymoon and it wasn't too far from out Hotel.The place is the size of a housing estate, which it needs to be given that some of the tombs are the size of houses! We went there in search of the Tomb of Eva Peron and we did find it amongst the hundreds of others that are there. Totally by coincidence, the day we were there was the anniversary of her death and the were many wreaths adorning her tomb. It was quite moving really.It's certainly a place to behold and visit if you're in the area. Recoleta itself is a nice area and you feel very safe there.If you're going in search of Eva's Tomb, save time by knowing that she's buried under her Maiden name of Eva Duarte!

Go with time and if possible, with a guide. It is in a very nice place in Buenos Aires, in the center of Recoleta. You can find lots of interesting stories and characters of the History of Argentina. Nice decorations and graves, where the time seems to be stopped.
Amazing art and statues. A beautiful place to see how arts merges with death in an open space. Many of the historical figures of the country are buried there.
A must see!. This is a breathtaking cemetery. There is so much history here. The free walking tour was really informative. I personally liked the cats that roam the cemetery.

A glimpse at BA and it's modern history. It is Buenos Aires most beautiful cemetery, the crypts and mausoleums are of impressive architectural quality, lots of imported marble and great statues. Entry to the cemetery is free, but if you want to get the most of your visit contract one of the many authorised guides and you will get a low down on how the occupants fit into modern Argentinas history. The who's who of the country are buried there, including Evita and many presidents.If you are into Free Mason's history there are tours that give you that aspect of the cemeteries history

Buenos Aires cementery. Although it is cementery you really can see colourful history of visionaries of Argentina including one of famous person Evita Peron. It is good idea to take guide avilable in cementery.

Recoleta Cemetary. One of the most amazing experiences of our travelling life..it is impossible to appreciate the gravity of this life after death of the obvious " fat cows " of Argentinas years gone byEviita,s grave is difficult find but inspiring..Best done very early at 09.00 opening before the hoardes arriveWould love to be there for Halloween !!!
Impressive and iconic. Very impressive. An iconic place to visit if you appreciate architecture and history. Admire the fascinating mausoleums and don't forget to pay some respect.

A must do for Buenos Aires. This Cemetery is amazing! The tombs and statues are unique ranging in all styles. We did a self guided tour, but there are many official and unofficial guides to help with background on the cemetery.

lively dead. I would recommend this cemetery for an interesting visit. It's one of those places to best go with a guide who can regale you with all the interesting stories of certain "occupants" found there.

Beautiful Cemetery. For those that have never had the opportunity to visit a cemetery like this it's awesome to see! It was interesting to hear the history of it in general as well as the history of some of the people and families buried in this beautiful place.

Death and Social Status. This late-nineteenth-century cemetery is a who's-who of Buenos Aires elite. Every statesman and his family are buried here, including Evita Peron, the first lady of mythic status and Broadway fame. Splendid tombs and good statuary, along with dozens of cats, make this burial ground a favorite with visitors.
Very nice. Is a must see classic place to visit is like a museum and its located in the best neighborhood of buenos aires

Fan of Evs Peron. She is buried here, as are other famous people. Be sure to read the story of how Eva's body was brought here. Self guided tour, though there are tour guides for hire lingering outside.

Nola feelings. For those of you that have ever been in the cemeteries of New Orleans and loved it you must go there. So much history and.. I dont know, its not a dark feeling but it is a strong one. Good place to think.

Beautiful place. Beautiful cemetery reminiscent of those in Paris, tho there aren't as many areas to sit. Like an outdoor museum, the mausoleums are works of art. Everyone goes to see where Eva Peron is buried but there are far more interesting mausoleums if you wander around. My favorite was one of a former Argentinian President. The ceiling had a stained glass cross. If you're there on a sunny day, the sun shines thru the cross, leaving a colorful reflection. Very pretty.
Amazing site. This is an amazing place, the only bad thing about it is they move the people after 10 years unless someone pays them to keep the bodies there!

Don't cry for me, ardent tina.. Pere Lachaise of the south, with touches of Montmartre and Montparnasse. Admit it: you came here for Evita. Be prepared for a rather underwhelming experience since she's deep down in a family vault and the memorial is under-stated. Unlike the rest of this cemetary, which is a classic excess of sculpted piety and sorrow, close to the Bellas Artes museum. Drop in. Drop out. Sunday market has some promise as well.
a bit of old glory history from Argentina. Impressive but a little dirty and not too looked after. The church next door deserves the visit best (Nuestra Señora del Pilar)
Not walking deads inside. It is a cemetery, it is a classic among tourist comingo to Buenos Aires, but there is notheing but dead people inside.

Stunningly beautiful!. This is a must see in Recoleta!! Make sure you also see the church that's outside the cemetery. I could spend hours looking at all the monuments, there. You won't be disappointed!

Beautiful and artsy. For an indian, this was a novelty. A cemetery to visit. But it was worth while. The tombs were outstanding and a English speaking guide really gives you so much to know about this beautiful place in beautiful cemetery.

A beautiful cemetery. There's more here than the grave of Evita.. I think this is a must do when in Buenas Aires. Many tourists come just to view the final resting place of Evita Person but there is more of interest than that. I suggest visiting this as part of one of the excellent "Tour for Tips" guided tours.

Unique. Cemetery of the rich and famous.......and a couple of hundred cats. Pretty cool to walk around and see how the upper class wanted to be remembered! It's more than just where Eva Peron is buried. Definitely worth a visit.

BEST PLACE TO VISIT. Best place to visit and enjoy harmony and art . I did spend there around 4h .Its like museum on open air with a great collection of sculptures ! I feel myself almost as in Rome that full of art. Entrance is free surprisingly ! They even have free tours ! Its most impressive cemetery that i ever visited.

In Honor of Evita.... Each time I visit Buenos Aires. I am sure to go to The Recoleta Cemetery, mainly to honor Evita, a champion of Obreros (Workers) in Argentina. She was well Loved by so many people of the working class. If only for that, it is worth a visit. Also an Artisans Market takes place in front of the cemetery, with lots of goodies to see or to buy. Enjoy the time there, Dennis

Absolutely THE most beautiful cemetery I've visited!. I thought I could never be as much in love with a cemetery after visiting Pere La Chaise in Paris. I was wrong!! Recoleta Cemetery was a stunning, mesmerizing and peaceful journey experience. On the frieze upon entry are the words "Requiscant in Pace" meaning "May They Rest in Peace". On this spot were the monks of Recollect. This cemetery was created in their peaceful, beautiful, walled "cloister". Every single mausoleum was uniquely designed and perfectly maintained. The evenly tiled walkways are wide and beautifully landscaped. The stories of its inhabitants are rich and heartbreaking and historical and awe inspiring. Being on a tour, I did not get to spend near enough time. Please allow several hours for enjoying this sacred space. I will make a special visit to enjoy in solitude upon my next visit to Buenos Aires. The frieze as you depart says "Expectamus Dominum" meaning...."Expect God". What a beautiful sentiment.

A cemetery with the most gorgeous and amazing tombs. This cemetery is a must see. The architecture of the tombs are amazing. This is also the place where Eva Peron was finally put in a tomb. A must see!

Fascinating and well worth the visit.. Just as we arrived near the entrance to the cemetery (really a necropolis) someone approached us and offered a paid guided tour. Great. But there are free tours lead every...hmm few hours or so and we happened to get there just as the English speaking FREE tour was about to begin. Tips are appreciated after the tour. There is also a map available for less than a $1 that has a comprehensive list of famous individuals resting here. Our tour leader informed us that soon the cemetery would be starting to collect an entrance fee as a number of the deserted tombs and mausoleums were in such poor condition. The tour, one hour long was historically informative, discussing architecture as well as politics and religion. And yes, of course we were taken by Evita Peron's family mausoleum. There are plenty of things to do immediately around the Recoleta Cemetary so plan on staying in the area. The adjacent Nuestra Senora del Pilar Church, Belles Artes Museum, Plaza Francia and Recoleta neighborhood.

Looking for Evita. I visited the cemetery on a very bleak and rainy day. There was almost no one in the cemetery and so a bit spooked. Only very wealthy families are buried here and it was a highlight of my trip even in the rain.
Hmm. It is interesting if you like such a places. Small town fo r death people. Can say you have visited Evitta Peron's grave.

Amazing. This was our best liked place to visit in Buenos Aires. The tombs and monuments easily rival the more famous cemetery in Paris even though we were less familiar with the Argentines entombed there. We hired for an English speaking guide as we entered the facility. Even though the guides are supposed to be free they manage to collect some payment anyway. Just pay it, it's well worth it.
Eerie but exhilirating. What a great place to visit. Had a wonderful guide who explained everything in detail. Loved it. Highlights were the Duarte Family vault and Fr. Fahy's monument.

MUST SEE. A must if you visit Buenos Aires. Part of Argentina History with all te opulent sanctuaries and the artist hand of the belle epoque. Evita Peron tomb is here. And many other important characters. Is located near a beautiful park with an antique church (DEL PILAR) and close to two shopping center (RECOLETA MALL & DESIGN CENTER) and restaurants (LA BIELA LA MUNICH ROMARIO). Life and death mingling toqether iin a lucurious way

Beautiful . This is a must see on your trip to Buenos Aires the mausoleum are so intricate and huge The area covered is pretty large so allow yourself time it's a very unique way of burying people in the ground you can see the stairs going down into the ground and exposed coffins very interesting history of the city and some very beautiful displays of marble sculpture

Take your time, walk around, get into the individual stories .... I was quite resistent to walk around the cemetery but had a great and peaceful morning wandering around. Nice Araucaria trees, interesting figures and facts, that made us forget we were in a real cemetery until we realised there was a funeral going on during the time of our visit
Wow. This is place where become to your mind idea Oh, I whish to rest in peace here...I never seen so posh cementary like this...

It's a cemetery. Yes, lots of mausoleums some of them quite impressive. But having said that, if you're from catholic Europe you should be used to this type of scenary. If you're not, have a stroll there, it will be worth it.

Amazing Cemetery!. This place is absolutely a must see in Buenos Aires. It's like a little town of dead people, with thousands of interesting mausoleums, all lining pathways. The architecture of the individual mausoleums are anything from simple to elaborate, neoclassical, to Gothic, to Greek. Eva Peron is buried here, but hers is nowhere near the most interesting story of all the burials here. One could easily spend a few hours, wandering around here. It's quiet and peaceful, and just really beautiful.

Take a walk through, you'll be glad you did.. I stumbled upon this when I was out for a walk. Be sure to get there before 5:00 because it closes. Many famous people are buried here with some fantastic architecture.

visit on a stormy day.... very creepy on a rainy day. peer through the aged dirty glass on the front of some of the tombs and see the coffins laid out, then look down to the hole in the ground and the almost vertical staircase descending into the void...

Unique cemetery. This is a very unique cemetery and well-worth walking around for an hour or so. There will be locals at the entrance offering you a walking tour. We declined, but unfortunately they distracted us so much that we did not see the map of the cemetery in the corner of the entrance building. So we missed seeing any of the important graves, but it was an amazing place nonetheless.
Beautiful. Simply beautiful and breathtaking. Definitely a place to visit if you are interested in these types of places.

For cemetery aficionados. if you are an aficionado of cemeteries, you should not miss recoleta cemetery! less celebrities than pere lachaise in paris, at least for europeans - but of corse EVITA! i love the old family thumbs, some broken, some very well kept, the marble statues - but then i enjoy browsing through cementeries :)

Don't miss FREE tour - perfect if you love architecture, design, history, politics & intrigue.. The thought of visiting a cemetery on a vacation is odd but this may be the exception if you like architecture and local history. Take the free tour to get the most of your visit. You will learn who is who in terms of Argentine powerful and wealthy families and the stories behind these imposing monuments made of the finest materials like marble, granite, ironwork, glass. Many were designed by renown architects of the period. The cemetery was filled in the early 20th century as a result of a plague which is explains why it has preserved it beauty in terms of history and design. I also like that it is located in one of the nicest residential and commercial areas of BA where you can stroll and window shop, eat ice cream, shop, etc.
Put on list to see. Historical, unique and well done. Roam cemetery and nearby church. Eva Perons tomb located here. Easy stroll on your own. Get a guide map.l

A really interesting place to visit - steeped in history. It is huge.. Even though visiting a cemetery may seem a bit morbid, it is such an interesting place to spend some time here and soak up the history. I found this place absolutely fascinating - and there are some very famous and important people buried here.

A lot of history. The cemetery is beautiful, captivating, antique, modern, old all in one place. A must see if you are in buenos aires. The entry is free, but recommend a guided tour. Furthermore, on the weekends and holidays you can enjoy the open air market around recoleta to see and but many unique gifts.
Fascinating and spooky . I didn't really think this would be very interesting, but I was wrong! The above ground mini churches go in and on, making the appearance of a city of the dead. Very unique.

Awesome visit. Great place in Recoleta, Buenas Aires. Besides finding the graves of famous argentineans, you will find sculptures and strange stories of the people buried there. if you can get a guide who could explain in detail the story of persons and graves, you will really enjoy and exploit your visit.

Make sure to take a guided tour. If you enter Recoleta Cemetery where Roca is buried along with Evita Peron, you will not know this story or others without a guided tour. The first time I went I knew nothing but this second time the guided tour was filled with historical information and great stories. Walking in here will be like walking in any cemetery without a tour guide-boring. Get a tour guide on your visit!! Only a fee with a guided tour. Free to enter on your own.

Very Unique Experience. Any visit to Buenos Aires is incomplete without a long stroll through the Recoleta Cemetary. There are some of the most ornate structures housing the remains of the dearly departed. Some of these "mini after life homes" house several generations. Do take time to check this place out-and find Evita's final resting place, too.

Cool Spot to Check Out. Never seen anything like this. Really cool to just walk around and see the crazy above ground burial chambers (mausoleums???) that people built back in BsAs heyday. Lots of other good stuff nearby too. Fun walk and I wouldn't have missed it if I had time.
Beautiful. This is a beautiful cementary to go get lost in. Even the views from the parameter are amazing. Here's a tip go to recolata mall and take pictures from the top floor.

Overwhelming.. I am not a cemetery person, but definitely, this place caught my attention in many, many ways.First, the size of the place is enormous; the graves stones and pantheons are so tall that looks more like a little town, second the graves are represented by truly works of art. You feel more in a museum than a cemetery. The visiting crowd also impressed me..... so many people visiting a cemetery that makes it unbelievable. Maybe it's just me; but it got to a point where I felt bad for interrupting, what should be a private moment for some. In any case, is an overwhelming place to visit.

Strange but must see . The cemetery is a small city build up of tombs . They are alleys and small roundabouts . Many of the tombs had a glass doors so we could see the coffins inside , some of them ,literally 20 -30 cm from us . Other tombs were deteriorated with Brocken doors and we could look inside and see many coffins . Eva Peron is buried in number 88. It was a strange but interesting experience .
Beautiful piece of history. I loved every bit of Recoleta. It's incredibly beautiful and full of history, you can spend 30 minutes or 3 hours here...wonderful place to explore.

Impressive Necropolis. Not your average cemetery more like an elaborate necropolis full of art work and history. The who's who of Argentine history is buried here. Worth taking a guided tour to learn about the tombs and mausoleums.
Intriguing . We popped in out of curiosity not knowing what to expect A truly haunting experience and would have loved to have had the time to explore it more or take a guided tour
Great place. Lots of history in this place. Not a normal cemetery. Located in a great place of buenos aires with many coffee places and shopping stores nearby!
Recoleta. the Recoleta Cementery is one of the most incredible places to visit in Buenos Aires, when you visit La Recoleta, lots of history.

Interesting but not that thing . It's interesting but not the most incredible place to visit in B.A. It depends of what you are interested to see. It's full of stories and you can see Evita's place. For me other sights have more energy to appreciate.

Cats and graves. I went to this cemetry alone and enjoyed it more this way.
Its a large area and full of new and old tombs.
There was a number of stray cats which follow you around which was unexpectrd but welcome.
The tombs are all so beautiful and detailed.

FINE DETAILS. This place is Similar to Chacarita's cemetery but smaller. It preserves nice mausoleums full of details. Angels, lions, gargoyles, even demons can be found by walking through the narrow aisles of this place. The tombs of famous writers, polititians, two nobel prize winners and doctors lay among may other citizens. There are guided tours.

get map or guide before entrance. Centary with awsome mausoleums, monuments... history of Argentina unbelievable that's tourist place.
Did they all deserve to be buried there probably not. It'sad that a lot great people who left some mark in history everywhere else around world didn't had oportunity to get these kind of respect...
interesting cats with sense of mourning
Must seen, even for short tour.

A place where death is showcased and immortalized. Recoleta cemetary is synonymous with Evita Peron's fame and legacy. Although her memorial is neither monumental, eloborate or ornate as so many others are, yet, just about everyone who ambles around makes the effort to get to or relentlessly pursue (if they are scouting around on their own) their aspiration towards her final resting place. Astonishing, how someone who came born inconspicuously among the downtrodden would end up seeking a glorious niche in history.

One of the most beautiful cemeteries I have ever visited! . I love cemeteries and I try to visit one in every country I travel too. And as I have been to a lot of countries, I have been to a lot of cemeteries. This is one of the most beautiful cemeteries I have ever visited. The details and care paid to each Mausoleum shows the care and importance of the dead in this culture. While you have obvious headstones that are quite opulent in nature, you don't get the sense that any is more important than the other. I had to make about 3 tours of the cemetery and consult the map before I found "Evita's" final resting place. It was very nondescript and simple. Walking down one of the main pathways in the cemetery leaves you feeling like you are on a regular street with homes on each side. I did not do a tour and I do not feel like they are absolutely necessary. I had a great time wandering about on my own. I will definitely be visiting this cemetery the next time I am in BA!
A city highlight. A must for any visitor. Shed your natural cringes about cemeteries and immerse yourself in a unique setting that enlightens more about Buenos Aires history than any guide.

One of the most beautiful and famous cemeteries in the whole world!. If this is your favorite cup of tea, you'll probably enjoy visiting "Recoleta Cemetery". Along with Paris' Père Lachaise, it stands among the 10 most beautiful and famous cemeteries in the whole world! "Recoleta Cemetery" was the first public cemetery in Buenos Aires, being inaugurated in 1822. Tombs and mausoleums were built in many different styles: baroque, neo-gothic, art-deco and art-noveau. Some are still in very good conditions, others totally ruined: creepy and really scaring! The most visited mausoleum is Mrs. Eva Perón's, former first lady of Argentina and founder of the Eva Perón Foundation. Just follow the crowd and you'll find it, under the name of "Família Duarte". Guided tours are available on non-official basis (check previous reviews with interesting information about tours in English). Leaving the cemetery, visit the nearby "Basilica of Our Lady of Pilar" and stop for lunch at one of the very many restaurants just opposite the cemetery. If you are going by taxi, ask help for calling a radio taxi, as Argentinean cab drivers are not at all reliable, always ready to trick you on alleged false bill notes. If that happens, call the police! You are just about to be robbed! But visiting "Recoleta Cemetery" may be a quite interesting experience. Enjoy!

just do it. the truth is this is not something I would normally do - visit graves BUT - this is completely different and not in the least bid morbid. I was persuaded to go because it was the birthday of Evita Peron - it was a site to behold. Just do it, you will be pleased that you did and you will not believe the little houses - I doubt that there is anything like this anywhere else.

Tours in English Only on Tuesdays & Thursdays at 11am. I had a hard time finding this information so am sharing it with others. The tours in English are only on the two days noted and only at 11am. The tour is given by a 'volunteer'. It's a lady who basically comes in and gives the tour for tips. She is not associated with the cemetery in any professional way at all. I don't know what happens if she's busy or sick on a tour day - I guess you'd simply be out of luck. There are people inside the cemetery gates as well as directly outside soliciting to give tours. I do not know what the normal cost is if you went for a private tour (as we did the free tour and gave a tip at the end). The lady's English was very good and we had no problem understanding her. The group was rather large however on the day we went.The cemetery itself is an interesting place to visit with many beautufl and different tombs. Having someone explain the different tombs makes it a much better visit. To find Evita's tomb just follow the crowds or ask someone. It's the only one with lots of fresh flowers aroud it. The tomb is under her maiden name and is a regular one - not big or fancy like you'd expect.There are several restaurants near by as well. We ate at Dean & Denny's which is a burger and milkshake restaurant diagonally across the street. It was nice to get a USA food fix.The cemetery is not close to any metro/subte stop. You have to walk at least 15 minutes to get to the cemetery. It's a flat easy walk. I don't recall any signs pointing the way to the cemetery. Best to have a Google map or similar handy for directions. We did and had no problem finding it.
Very interesting cimentery. It shows you the tombs of very important people from the country in a beautiful surrounding in one of the best zones of the city.

Lovely and Mysterious, Literally a Marvelous Cemetary. Recoleta Cemetery is full of beautiful mausoleums and statues. The head stones are graceful and you can find many famous people here as you stroll down the paths. It is a cat lover's dream as well, as there are many friendly cats to cheer you up. Go visit Evita Peron. They offer tours in English.
City of the Dead. Do not miss this. I'm a New Orleanian, and it puts us to shame: a tiny city of the dead, archeological fascinating, and maybe the only cats you'll meet while in Buenos Aires.
Not your typical cemetary. It was little too creepy to my taste, but architecture-wise is unbelievable. Looks like a built town with avenues and streets... all for dead people.
Amazing history. Amazing history in this place. Take the tour to get the explanation of tombs and why some look the way they do. (April 2013)

Fantastic place to visit. I thoroughly enjoyed visiting Recoleta Cemetery.There is no entry fee, so don't be persuaded by an opportunistic local to pay.I went on a guided tour, so was saved that hassle. The architecture was impressive. As were the stories surrounding prominent families attempting to out-do one another with more and more impressive monuments.I recommend a visit!
Greateful Dead. We were with a group and had no choice. If you don't like cemeteries then don't go. There are some creepy open crypts with old coffins that you can see if that's your cup of tea.
Unbelievable Cemetary. Very worthwhile to visit. See where Eva Peron is buried and where many of the city's deceased rich are. The mausoleums range from very ornate to dilapidated.

A must go in Buenos Aires. It is absolutely fascinating and beautiful. As someone who is turned off by death, horror, and morbidity, I was initially reluctant to go. It was worth the visit. Great stories and history lessons come along with the most beautiful tombs, mixed in with some showing deferred maintenance (and an open coffin or two). A wonderful cultural experience.

Worth a visit to the this Landmark Cemetery. We waited for the tour of the cemetery and while our guide was incredibly knowledgeable (in Spanish), we could not hear her after a while as our group grew to be too large without the guide having a microphone. . . we were sad to leave the group as she was really a wonderful docent of the cemetery with juicy historical anecdotes but it was just inoperable as the group was so big.

Not what I had expected!. When travelling into Buenos Aires I was thinking of missing the Recoleta Cemetery, I am very glad that I went, it is worth spending time wondering around, I joined in onto a walking tour which was great because the guide spoke about the history of those who were buried there. Very interesting!
Beautiful Cemetary. Beautiful above ground cemetery famous for housing the remains of Eva "Evita" Duarte Peron in the Recoleta section of Buenos Aires. Adjacent to the Cathedral and an easy walk.

Worth a visit. Very interesting to walk through a city of the dead. The art work on the mausoleums and statuary are worth checking out. Most people look for the tomb of Evita Peron (she is buried in the family mausoleum under the last name Duarte).

An incredible place filled with architecture and history. I went to the Recoleta Cemetery twice in a month. It was amazing seeing so many wonderful statues and angels, and tombs decorated in such ways. I had the opportunity to see the resting places of Argentinians who shaped the course of the Argentina itself. Eva Peron and Sarmiento for example. And while I admire the architecture and the many ghost legends, I decided not to take pictures because it was a little creepy and strange to be smiling or using people's resting places as "attractions."The most disturbing part for me is that visitors are able to see many of the coffins and that simply creeped me out.
Interesting Architecture. Cemetery was recommend to me and in fact it was very interesting. Many different mausoleums and interesting architecture. Definitely worth a visit!!

Worth spending some time in this place.. I enjoyed visiting this place. The monuments are awesome. Some of them are exquisite and looks like an expensive design shop in black marble from a distance, others are quite old and worn. In almost all of them you can look inside through windows or doors and you'll see exquisite cascets inside. It's the most fascinating cementary I've been to. Really worth a visite,

Special. Okay, so I visited the Cemetery 3 times within 3 days: by myself, with a friend on the trip and with my partner. One could easily spent half of a day wandering around. The mini mausoleums are each one of a kind. It was fun to see people here and there walking around looking lost because they were looking for "Evita". It is good there was no signage pointing to celebrity graves. It forces you to explore and gives some proper respect even though they are a tourist attraction. My visits reminded me of the delight I felt walking around the Paris cemeteries.

Amazing,must see!. Words run short to describe what you see and feel when you enter. It is overwhelming,and your first thoughts are,who will win,the Tears that were shed here,or the Money that were spent here? But one should look closer,the amazing statues,the lovely 'small' coulered windows ect. and a lonley cat here and there. We are in San Thelmo,and took the Subte to the end,and then walked 7+ streetblocks,to get there. We took a taxi back to Plaza de Mayo,60+ Peso. Please go.....!

A major part of Buenos Aires' history!. We visited Recoleta as part of a Buenos Aires Bike Tour. It is a beautiful neighborhood, and there's a very unique, big tree for taking pictures outside the entrance. The cemetery is like nothing you've seen, so for that reason alone, it is a must see! Evita is buried there, and make sure you hear the story behind that!

A must see in BA---add the top,gude and it become the best tour experience. Find Simon, an Englishman who is around the front entrance of the Cemetary unless he is inside educating those he is touring. He is also fluent in Spanish so could assist those travelers as well. It made a huge difference in our experience, and the arcane facts, as well as those in every guidebook, add much to this fascinating place. It is a photographers dream in there. You could easily spend a few hours wandering on your own, but Simon 's knowledge will make it a highlight of your Argentine experience.

Nice. It's not the kind of thing I have in mind when traveling, but it's nice to go there - lots of interesting stories, and once you get to know why people love Evita Peron so much, it's nice to stop by.
Amazing rooftop church overlooking the Cemetary. Haunting and amazing. We have not seen anything like this. There are many very famous Argentinians buried here with a lot of rich history.

Informative tour of a strange site. I thought the free guided tour of Recoleta Cemetery was very well done. The volunteer guide who led the English tour was quite knowledgable and spoke in a clear, personable way. She had lot's of factual and anecdotal information. Going on the tour increased my understanding of cemetery manifold over an earlier walk through I had done on my own. A highlight was seeing Evita Perón's tomb and hearing the story of how remains ended up there.

Interesting . Not some places that I want to visit initially but went ahead anyway. Strangely, the air is still inside but we were so wow by the cemeteries.Entrance is free, do see the map on the main entrance for those you would like to visit cause is a pretty big cemetery.

Free tours well worth it!. Enjoyed the free tour of the cemetery! The English tours are Tue and Thur at 11 for about an hour. The guide showed us the whos who of who is buried in the cemetery along with the oldest/newest and some fun facts about different graves and monuments. Went with a stroller for our little one and was able to move around pretty easily. Tip appriciated but not required

Come for Evita stay for the most spectacular looking mausoluems. A must see when visiting BA. Most people's first inkling would be to see the resting place of Evita but please walk around through the whole cemetery. Every corner you turn you will catch very beautiful intricate mausoleums. The amount of artistry is incredible to see.
Cementerio Recoleta, one of the main attractions of BA. a classic european style cementery that hosts the dead of most prominent families in Argentina. really worth visiting.

Death Be Proud. Recoleta is essentially a Who's Who of Argentinian history and culture. In addition, it is a magnificent outdoor sculpture garden as you walk among the dramatic statues created for the deceased. (and appreciated by the living). In spite of the fact that it is a cemetery, the ambiance is actually one of beauty and respect. Located right in the middle of the Recoleta neighborhood, it is a bit like a Central Park--albeit with a different sense of nature. And, certainly more interesting than the shopping mall across the street. It is well worth a visit to this collection of monument and memory.

Not be be missed. Never thought I'd want to visit a cemetery and this was my favorite side trip of a two week vacation. I highly recommend visiting in the hour or so before it closes to experience its unusual surreal beauty.
Great place . Amazing ... Great place to see and visit ! In the right side of recoleta cemetery there are a furniture shopping with many local designers!!! Great and quality furnitures

Beautiful Monuments. I was able to join a tour in English. The guide showed us the highlights of the cemetery with back stories for many of the beautiful and not so beautiful monuments and tombs. She said that it is the family's responsibility to maintain the tombs so some have fallen into disrepair. Eva Peron's tomb as part of the Duarte family monument was very understated which I appreciated.

Worth your time to visit Recoleta Cemetery. You may be thinking, Why would I spend time to visit a cemetery? Isn't that depressing?In actuality, Recoleta is amazing and beautiful. Yes, it's a large cemetery, but many Argentine dignitaries are buried there in remarkable, elaborate graves/mausoleums. Each burial area is simply stunning in its complexity and size.My friend and I didn't take a tour. We instead purchased a map at the entry (cost: $20 pesos), which suggests a route and has annotations regarding which spots you should visit. We spent about an hour there and it was very worthwhile.

DEAD people..... Surprised me that the coffins were right there and they had a downstairs too!! It was a shame that some of the crypts were not kept up. Evita (Eva Peron's) was very basic. Many of the crypts were partially open and you could see the steps to go downstairs. One of the crypts was open more than the other and I was about to stick my head in when I heard a knock, well I almost yelled, but realized that there was a person inside praying, but my mind went there... it actually did!!!

Hauntingly beautiful. La Recoleta Cemetery is a peaceful respite from the bustling city of BA. Give yourself some time to meander through the rows of historic and beautifully ornate family tombs. While all will rush to see the mausoleum of Eva Peron, I found the best part of my visit finding walkways to explore away from the crowds and was in awe of the place ---- it was hauntingly beautiful and a surprisingly romantic place. Tip: If you want to see Evita's tomb, be sure to check the map on the left when you first enter --- once inside, it's a maze and not as easy to discover as one might expect. The cemetery closes at 5:30 and by 5:45 security rings a bell to ensure everyone is out. If you go around 4:30pm, you'll skip most of the crowds and get some gorgeous light bouncing off the tombs for photos. It's free to enter and guided tours are available.

Amazing Private Cemetery!. This would not have been on my list of must see attractions before I visited, but after I've changed my mind. The detail and care that's gone into these monuments makes it a destination by itself. Add into it the history and stories provided by a tour guide and its a compelling couple of hours.I would add this to my top 3 destinations in BsAs.

Cats and Coffins!. A must see! Beautiful, sad, fascinating. Architecture, history, and stories! Of course, walk by Eva Peron's family monument but either get a guide or do your research before. (There are many groups that are being guided through the cemetery but the guides are quick to move their group along if you are trying to listen in on their commentary.) Be careful; get a reputable guide - we heard multiple accountings of the sad story of the young woman that was supposedly buried alive and the other young girl whose dog died at the exact time of his owner's death halfway around the world. Say hello to the cat (alive!)that curls up next to the statue of the faithful dog (and don't forget to rub the dog's nose for luck). For a different view of the amazing eclectic architecture - pay to visit the museum in the church next door and look out the windows on the cemetery - well worth it (and the museum has some nice artifacts and relics).

FASCINATING. My husband and I went on the BA Free walking tour, which referenced the cemetery and told us of Evita's grave and the story behind it. We were so glad to experience a walk through for ourselves during our trip, and see all of the old, above-ground graves that tried to out-build the others.

Interesting part of history. From the moment you walk in you feel a sense of humbleness. The grandeur of some of the crypts is amazing. It is a bit daunting or confronting when you see coffins in layers in full view. Very sad to see some tiny coffins of infants. Eva Perone is very well visited in the cemetery.
If you like cemeteries- Ricoletta. The resting place of Argentinian notables like Gardel and Peron. I was there in the 1980's, and quite lovely...just thought I give it a rah-rah!

wow - architecture is amazing. Super interesting to see. When you enter the hall you can see on the left Hand side a map where all the graves are listed - so you can easily find the one of evita - it is caled Eva Maria durante....
A must see in buenos aires... Also the area around is very nice - full with market stands

Really not much to see...... Lots of tourists looking for Evita's grave.
It's an interesting cemetery with ornate mausoleums. Evita's grave is very plain, that's interesting in itself - for info on her, go to the Evita Museum. If you're in the area and have time on a nice day, stroll through. Don't go out of your way.

Fascinatingly creepy. The size of a small town, this cemetery is a maze of crypts and is riddled with cats! It also includes the family crypt of the Famous Evita Peron, making it quite crowded at times. A must see in my humble opinion.

Important see the grave of JOSEFINA CABACERES, The Frech Delfin, Evita Duarte. is very interesting, because there are, french sculpturs, historical graves, very nice tales about each persoson that lies there.
Is similar cementery on Paris.

A must in Buenos Aires. Una obligación para el turista en Buenos Aires. A great cematary, with a lot of argentinian history and great art in the tombs. If you are a tourist in Buenos Aires, you have to go. It's free to enter. And also you can make guided tours.

Don't Miss It!!. I have lived in Buenos Aires for just under a year, and I've visited several times before that. Without a doubt, Recoleta the cemetery, is the number one tourist destination in the city. This is the finest, most extraordinary, fantastic cemetery you will ever visits in the world. It is even better than Pere la Chaise cemetery in Paris. There are so many ways to get lost in the cemetery that you will be fascinated for many hours. It is so interesting and so sad at the same time many of the tombs have been left on cared for which gives them an air of eeriness, and sadness, however the cemetery as well kept and beautiful in so many ways but it's hard to explain. So many beautiful statues to look at and so many beautiful pictures and monuments it's easy to get lost while you're wondering about and before you know it you will of past three or four hours and I've been fascinated all the while. I would return again and again. And don't miss Eva Peron's tomb as it is here as well.

AN AMAZING ARCHITECTURALMAUSOLEUM CEMETRY. it is awesome to see such beautiful mausauleums of the rich and the famous. I am privileged that I was able to pray and visit at the mausoleum of the legendary Evita Peron. Though there were no staff to lead us to the mausoleum and directional signs for the tourists. We did it on our own way of searching inside the cemetry. It will be of great help if there are signs though there is a map at the lobby of the cemetery.

History Tour. This is a must see venue in Buenos Aires. Sort of a walk thru history, it's neat to see the different family burial plots. Not at all "creepy."We bypassed the volunteers selling maps at the free entrance. Small place, easy to find your way around, and to get out!

Little Village. This cemetery looks like a little village. Sepulchers look like little houses and in many of them the coffins can be seen through the glass door. It is different and make thing about our own finiteness. It is not scary, it is just real.
Not your regular cemetary. Like a small city with laneways, full of mausoleums, some truly huge. Definitely not your regular cemetery. Well worth the visit. Walk there

Tacky and grand, at the same time. My husband and I wandered around the mostly ruined crypts for an hour or so. It was mostly empty and very peaceful. We'd never seen anything like it -- houses for the dead, equipped with chairs, candles and photos. We checked out Eva Peron's crypt, too, because, well, we were there, so why not?
For a gone period. There is no pleasure to visit a cementery, where the majority of individuals buried there, where in part responsible of the argentinian decay.

City of the Dead. Obviously the Argentinians have a great respect for their wealthy departed.
Some of the monuments are unbelievable. I am assuming the 'normal' people are buried somewhere less 'exclusive'. Even in death we are not 'created' equal.

stunning in its size. Condos for the deceased. Mausoleums everywhere all tightly packed together. Each with its own story. You must have a knowledgeable guide to fully appreciate this place, it history and construction. Evita Duarte's (Peron) resting spot is in her family tomb and a bit hard to find - another reason for aguide

Amazing Cemetery. It doesn't seem like a cemetery would be such a lovely place to walk around, but it was. The mausoleums were extremely detailed and diverse in design. I have really never seen anything like it It was really interesting seeing the ornate ways that people have chosen to honor their dead.
Worth a detour. Interesting burial vaults everywhere you turn, some more beautiful than others. The star attraction is of course the burial place of Eva Perone (Evita).
A world apart. This was very interesting to me. It was such a departure for me, from ordinary cemeteries. Everything is so ornate, and monumental. This is a great place to spend a couple of hours.

Intriguing and grand. The place is adorned with beautifully carved graves and tombs. Every grave is architecturally different and is a resting place for famous people. It is perfect for a walk and to click some lovely pictures. On some days there is a flee market set up around this place so you can shop and eat local food items. There are also few restaurants and a big mall just outside the cemetery.
Lovely stroll and many photos. We went back repeatedly at different times of the day to catch different lighting for photos. A very well-kept and international attraction.
death and luxury in one place. the best combination of luxury and abandoned places... sometimes if you get lucky, still can see some parts of dead bodies, also the tombs of the famous people

Fascinating. We've never been to a cemetry quite like this. There are some incredibly grand (and expensive) tombs and graves. Obviously most people go to see Eva Peron's grave but it is quite simple. The statue of the boxer Luis Angel Firpo is great to see. This place is well worth a visit, with some nice parks and Church next door

Eerily interesting.. We didn't know what to expect.
Who wants to go to a cemetery/graveyard as a tourist attraction?
It turned out to be very entertaining.
The sculptures were beautiful.
The architectural styles of the mausoleums were very diverse, and grand in scope and scale.
I have been to New Orleans and Paris cemeteries, and would rank this right up with them.

Fascinating slice of Argentine history.... ...and fascinating slice of man's ability to self-aggrandize.
Of course there is Evita's crypt, but all the family crypts either spell out a story or have one imagining a life story.
Probably the most interesting experience with had in BsAs. I could have spent hours there.

Get lost in a maze of history. I spent about many hours in the cemetery walking from tombstone to tombstone. Incredible to think how much of Argentina's history now lie beneath these magnificent structures of granite and marble. Don't simply go to find something/someone, go for the experience, take your time and get lost

stunning architecture. Stunning architecture and full of history. Definitely to visit during a sunny day, otherwise it could be creepy. I recommend the guided tours to take and extra advantage of the visit

A must see. One of the main attractions of this Cemetery is the fact that, even after being dead, there is a distinctive feeling of social class between the illustrious "inhabitants". For well off Argentines money and power are not gone, after all, after we depart this planet so families of the deceased make sure we all know this fact. This City of the Dead has some VIPs (Evita included of course) and some outstanding mausoleums and statues , but the best of it all is to walk aimlessly in a beautiful sunny day and think, for a little while, about how temporary everything is in this world.

Amazing!. We were not sure what to expect but were amazed at the artistic creativity of the tombs. Its a bit eery walking among peoples graves as a tourist activity but it was an amazing experience. Would not miss it.
