Creepy and beautiful. It's amazing how some areas are kept up so well and others are falling apart. Recent burials and those that date back far into history. Beautiful, intricate, others understated. So fascinating. Look out for Eva Peron.

Worth a visit. Everybody seems to go to see Evita Peron's grave, but hers is a little bit disappointing--and hard to find. The other tombs are the ones that are interesting. There is a lot of variety, and some of them are amazing. It is a great place just to walk around. You don't need a guide.

A Cemetry City. This is an amazing place, yes creepy, unusual and you have the feel of ghosts around you. But the history, stories, tombs and more are with the visit. Eva Peron indeed is here, just ask for her street and they will guide you. It is a city in itself and well taken care of There are some tombs in the oldest section that make you feel you are in a creature feature movie, but well worth the visit. There is a tomb when walking in the front entrance right at the corner of the first tomb that has always spoken to me on my 4 visits over a span of 15 years....one day, I will learn who this plot belongs to and why it calls me. Enjoy it...

Evita gravesite. It was fun to find Evita's grave among the many, take a picture of the map at the entrance so you don't have to go back. It was interesting to see the variety of sites and how families are together forever. Also enjoyed seeing the cats that live there.

Spectacular, freaky and of course, peaceful.... This place was grand, showy, bold, spectacular, freaky and peaceful rolled into one.Walking through the narrow pathways I was drowned in the sea of the most spectacular mausoleums that I have ever seen in my travels.Some of them looked neglected but majority were well kept and the "owners" or the family that own them show real pride in showcasing or shall I say, making sure that their dearly departed were comfortable in their resting place. Seeing the beautiful caskets stacked on top of each other was surreal. It was like being in a funeral home showcase room where they display their best caskets. This is a MUST DO when you are in Buenos Aires. For me, the visit was a lesson of opulence, love for the family and most of all, the ever occurring argument of "no matter how much money do you have, you'll still end up in a casket like us poor folks". Highly recommended!

Creepy but fascinating . Really is the city of the dead! Must be experienced, considering it's free it's worth checking out. fascinating to wonder around for as short or as long as you like. Strange attraction, but really cool in a weird way

Must see. This place is amazing. I have never seen anything like it. It is definitely a must when in Buenos Aires. Locating Eva Perons final resting place is good fun too. It is a bit strange and creepy because you can see into some of the mausoleums and the coffins within. And it is eerily quiet but it is brilliant to see.

Not only Eva's grave. Living in Buenos Aires, I've been there so many times. Most foreigners want to see Eva Peron's grave. Anyway, there are many important people from history buried there. The main attraction are the graves designs, little houses for eternity.

Maybe you think it's wierd, but it's a "must do". Have you ever spent at least one hour within Recoleta Cemetery? If not, you do not really understand "Argentinian Soul". You maybe find it wierd, but who did tell you life is not wierd? Who did tell you death is not a life's part? Who did tell you there is not such thing as a "soul"?Well, you have no obligation or need to answer me, but, please, catch a good Touristic Guide and get to know Recoleta Cemetery. Maybe later those questions you will find them all useless, because then you will agree with me, but just maybe...
Recoleta Cemetery - Well worth visiting. Well worth taking the time to see this place - loads of history including Eva Peron's (Duarte Family) tomb.

A Place with History and Beautiful Architecture. We didn’t plan to visit The Recoleta Cemetery but we happened to walk past and we quickly stroll in with not much time to spend, it’s an amazing cemetery with roads and avenues and a lot of history and beautiful architecture. With no admission fee It’s a must see if you’re in Buenos Aires.

Grand Displays of 19th Century Funerary Art. It's the Pere Lachaise of Argentina,only without so many famous dead; Eva Peron's tomb is the highlight. FYI, it's actually her family's tomb, and so is under the name Duarte. The variety and extravagance of the monuments suggests many things--about the 19th Century: indulgence, pomposity, even an ability to enjoy grief via total immersion. IMPORTANT: beware the mosquitos! They're silent, hungry and present in millions (the cemetery itself has many warning signs); they feasted on my wife and made, and she came down with a debilitating fever, so douse yourself with DEET.Also not tha pickpockets are nearly as umerous as the mosquitos and present all over the city. Another very popular scam is accepting large notes in payment and giving change in counterfeit.

Depends on the guide. Free English tours a couple days a week. Your experience will be guided by the quality of the person leading you around. For our tour, it seemed like we stopped a quite a few less important sites and skipped some of the more interesting figures in Argentine history

Eerily interesting. We enjoyed the stroll through the cemetery getting to see the various memorials to Argentina's politicians, sportsmen and woman, academics, poets and musicians. An interesting walk through if you're in BA but (at the risk of sounding rather uncultured) in truth it felt somewhat overrated as a "must see attraction". Probably don't need much more than an hour or so unless you're really into grandiose tombstones.
Different experience. I think this place is slightly overrated. Spent there 30 minutes and it was sufficient. Maybe if I would take a guide the rating would be higher
rest in peace!. nice relaxing stroll. surrounding area is lively with many stalls and various restaurants. lots of people around evitas tomb.. but lots other interesting things to discover
Elegantly morose. It is a beautiful place. As weird as it may be, the cemetery is beautiful and elegant. It is quite large. Some celebs such as Duarte and Perron.

Amazing.... This tour was amazing. Our guide, Albano, was very knowledgeable about the area. Born in Argentina, he spoke about the sights, and the history from the time the bus started until the end of the trip. I never got tired of listening to him. I wanted more and more of his stories! Tour ended!

The city of death people and Evita' tomb.. This is an amazing cemetery with a lot of history, beautiful architecture and a city in the city. Please put it an your must see list, you will not regret it.

Evita's Resting Place. Visiting a cemetery sounds like an unusual thing to do but it was well worth it. The cemetery itself is very big so we didn't see it all but we stayed long enough to find Eva Peron's resting place. The tombs are all above ground and are as big as houses. Some are very modern, and others are very old with broken gates and windows. There was something magical and beautiful about this cemetery that I will remember for a long time.

Beautiful but torn down and Abandoned!. Visited Evita's grave and there are no indications nor anyone to tell you where it us, you just gotta find the crowd around it. The cemetery has impressive works of art and is one of the most impressive landmarks in BsAs. Unfortunately, several graves are open, doors broken, locks too. It's such a pity to see such an amazing place completely abandoned.

Architectural Brilliance, Even in Death. What a site to see. The cemetery even has roads and avenues, this place is huge! Don't go just to see Evita's tomb and family... if you can find it. Definitely tucked away, as her tomb should be since she was so against aristocracy. However, the other tombs are marvels of architecture. If you can get around the stray cats, go on a long walk there, do some meditation, get a translator to read some of the inscriptions. You'll be so glad you did. What a beautiful place.

Very interesting cemetary. This was an amazing cemetery with a lot of history, beautiful architecture and a good trip. There are a lot of stray cats that have made this their home . Evita Peron is buried there and the museleums are very old and ornate. I must see if you are in the city.

Don't just go see Eva!. A gorgeous place to lose yourself for a couple of hours. Quickly find Eva Peron, which is quite an unassuming tomb, to pay our respects (look for the crowd) and then move on to amble amongst the amazing architecture. Bring water and layer on the sun cream as it is very out in the open with no shade. Give yourself plenty of time to enjoy it, a wonderful place.

visit in buenos aires wont be complete without this!. i walked for hours here! the mausoleums look so sophisticated with of course a touch of history! never leave without seeing EVA "evita" PERON and the entire familia duarte's tomb. by the way, the map here that says eva peron's tomb is not accurate, u have to ask the maintenance guys around if in case u get lost. i went on a tuesday, its the best time coz there are few people, u can take fotos without getting photo bombers haha. also once u get out of recoleta, a few coffee shops are there, try havana, i had a cafecito there with chocolate cookies. great day it was!

BEST CEMETERY I HAVE SEEN. This is the most artistic and beautiful cemetery I have ever seen. It is mainly designated for laying to rest high officials including presidents and other famous people of Argentina. It is comprised of many large beautiful memorials organized with walkways to allow access to each one. There are guides and maps available to help you find a particular memorial. I didn't particularly care to see anything particular. I just wanted to walk around and see what I could find while getting lost. It is a highlight to visiting Buenos Aires and I would say it is a must see because is located in a very nice neighborhood, Recoleta, where you can enjoy the best architecture found in Buenos Aires. Happy Travels!!!

It is the pantheon of Argentina. Recoleta Cemetery is architecturally very beautiful, full of sculptures in various parts of the world, full of angels guarding the eternal rest of impressive mausoleums. It is best done with a guide because it is full of tragic love stories like Eliza Brown, Rufina Cambaceres, the Felicitas Guerrero, stories of endless hatred like Tiburcia Salvador Dominguez and rail, madness as caregiver tombs and three friends. In addition there is the pantheon Argenitno presidents, founding fathers, governors, military the famous tomb of Eva Peron with its fascinating history, the Nobel Prize Federico Leloir pateon venecitas with gold. Free entrance.  Beautiful is the Church of Pilar which is next, famous cafes of the area and the craft fair in Plaza Francia.
Must see (in our opinion). You cannot visit Buenos Aires without coming to the cemetery and paying a visit to Evita's grave. Very unique and interesting place.

Morbid fun!. Visited twice. Once with a tour guide, and once on our own. Highly recommend a tour guide. We had a private one, but the cemetery offers them for a small donation. The guide helps to provide some of the history as well as the rumors and stories of some of the hundreds and hundreds of crypts within Recoleta Cemetary. Many are well maintained and cared for, many are in disrepair and downright creepy! Well worth the visit.

Recoleta Cemetery. If you are interesting in historical cemeteries, I would highly recommend the Recoleta Cemetery. It is a lovely, well tended cemetery with paved walkways that take you through and around family mausoleums of some of Buenos Aires' elite. We arrived quite late in the day, so we were not able to fit in a walking tour, but it was still very interesting to see. I heard good reviews of the walking tours.Evita is buried here in her family's grave.

Historical Cemetery. Recoleta Cemetery is the cemetery were many of the presidents and important politicians rest.There are marvelous sculptures and buildings. You can visit it on your own or you can take guided tours, where you can have these historical details are explained (for example, Facundo Quiroga, a XIXth century leader, was buried standing up) I really recommend this visit.

Don't Cry for Me Argentina. This is a very interesting cemetery to stroll around if you are on a tour of Buenos Aires. It seems one tomb is more elaborate than the next. Lots of cats are in the walkways too. You will surely see the final resting place of one of Argentina's most controversial figures, Eva Peron. This is a good way to spend a quiet afternoon in Argentina. Recommend for sure.

Something Different. in my humble view there is not too much to see in Buenos Aires. Perhaps I am blinded by all the graffiti but personally it is not one of my favourite cities. However a visit to the cemetery in Recoleta has taken me a little closer to enjoying my time here. It seems a little morbid to visit a cemetery but this one is like nothing we have at home. The area is covered with some small and some not so small mausoleums where family members can rest in peace. If you consider having your coffin starred at by thousands of tourists peaceful! It has a certain charm. There are a mixture of beautiful well maintained mausoleums and others in a state of disrepair. I found walking around both interesting and creepy! There is no entrance fee and there are free tours albeit in Spanish. It is somewhere different to visit while you are here and if you are a fan of Evita then you can visit the final resting place of Eva Peron.

More than "Just" a Cemetery..... The Recoleta Cemetery is truly something more than just a place of resting souls. The site itself lets you walk through a big part of Argentina's history; from the mausoleum of Evita to the resting places of colonial heroes like Rosas, Dorrego, Quiroga and Remedios de Escalada. The architecture and the peace are unique, specially for an area that, at the time of its construction was just next to the river. My best advise is to do one of the tours of the place or book a guide that its related with the history of the area. There are hundreds of little histories beneath the narrow passages of the most important graveyard in South America. A must, for sure...
Buenos Aires Cemetery. One of the most interesting tours you could take... please be sure to get a guide . there is so much history and interesting stories you will miss without on.

Lifestyles of the Rich and Dead!. Loads of rich and famous Argentines rest in granit or marble vaults in the cramped precincts of this cemetery. Perhaps as someone from North America the flamboyant burial styles were a bit overwhelming. Fairly modern temples are squeezed inbetween others in various state of repare or decay. We spent about a half hour here before deciding we'd seen enough.

BA history and Evita's resting place. Many travelers like cemeteries, but I don't usually visit them. Since I wanted to see Evita's resting place, we went. It's not easy to find. But we were happy we persevered. I was happy for my sons to see that she is still of interest to many all these years after her death.

A unique and fascinating site to visit – don’t miss it.. La Recoleta Cemetery, listed amongst the 10 most beautiful cemeteries of the world, is a cemetery that contains the graves of notable people, including Eva Peron and numerous Argentinian presidents. The 14 acre site contains over 4600 vaults, all above ground; 94 have been protected by the State. They are elaborate and set out in avenues with wide tree lined walkways. We were fascinated by the many elaborate mausoleums; some very well maintained, others have fallen into disrepair. Among many memorials are works by notable Argentine sculptors. I highly recommend this tour and would recommend you have a guide for part of your visit. It is easy to wile away many hours wandering around admiring the many styles of architecture – Art Deco, Gothic, Neoclassical Art Nuevo etc. etc. Absolutely fascinating.
a pearl in Buenos Aires. it is one of the most interesting sites in Buenos Airesthere are guided tours (free of charge) and i mostly suggest to take one

The dead have more place than the living!!. This is a beautiful cemetery with some outstanding buildings for the dead. However, the first though that came to my mind with the expanse of the cemetery was, while beautiful, the dead took more space than a whole lot of living can afford around the world.Must visit, especially since Evita Peron's grave is also here. Don't expect a big monument to commemorate her, however, for you will be disappointed.

The exclusive cemetery is the last stop for some of the country’s most celebrated. No one goes to Recoleta cemetery without a visit to Eva Peron's grave. Compared to Recoleta standards, it is quite nondescript. Eva Peron's body rests in the Duarte family mausoleum which can be difficult to find without either a tour guide or a hard copy map. We paid 20 pesos for a map and found the mausoleum with ease. At the time of our visit the front of the mausoleum was covered with flowers left as a mark of respect. Recoleta cemetery is an extraordinary graveyard, with over 6,400 grand mausoleums resembling Gothic chapels, Greek temples, fairytale grottoes and elegant little houses. Well worth a visit for visitors to Buenos Aires.
Evita's tomb is part of basic buenos aires tours!. The recoleta cementery is a must stop in any decent tour of buenos aires. You literally can see the history of the city.
Interesting History Inside. Very interesting, especially seeing Eva Peron's grave and the story about the young girl who was buried alive

Exceptional experience. This cemetery is a historical entity of Buenos aires. It is free and you can see the crypts and all the historical personality of Argentina including Eva Peron former military and past presidents. You can be there for hours enjoying this place

Great place to spend a couple of hours at least. The place is a compendium of anecdotes and related to the development of the city itself and the whole country as well.
We were lucky to find a very knowledgeable guide that made the visit worth and entertaining

One of a kind experience. Never once thought that I would be in awe of a cemetery but that is what Recoleta does to its visitors. Resting grounds to so many famous Argentineans including Eva Peron, Recoleta is one of the best places that Buenos Aires offers. Each mausoleum is an art work and somehow it was less haunting as I suspected in fact each grave seemed to be converted to a fine work of art and many narrating the life stories of the person resting here. While the entry is free, you might want to invest a bit on the map that can guide you through the place. Lots of cats around too.

Favorite attraction in BA. Free for admission and no tour required to enjoy. My friends and I wandered around for nearly two hours, reading the plaques and exploring the tombs. A photographer's dream spot. Lots of interesting finds in this place.

A Must See Attraction. Travelling to the other side of the planet and then visiting a cemetery doesn't sound very interesting but believe me you will want to see this amazing place. It appears egos were alive and well in the past when the Buenos Aires well-to-do citizens built their family mausoleums. They are masterpieces of design and decoration. There are plenty that have fallen into disrepair with coffins now exposed to the weather but it all adds to the atmosphere as you walk down the 'streets' and 'laneways'.

White City of Sculpture. This majestic city of tombs, mausoleums and monuments is certainly the equivalent of if not superior to Pere Lachaise in Paris or the three Saint Louis Cemeteries in New Orleans. We were on a tour, but it was very casual and we could wander some. You certainly should take the time to stroll the lovely grounds as the memorials vary tremendously in style, but they all represent cemetery art at its best. Ironically, the tomb of one of the most famous people buried here, Eva Peron, is rather modest compared to many others. Her body was in Europe for years before being returned to her family's tomb. This is a place to retreat from the busy life of the city and contemplate.
Really amazing . Although this place has thousands of reviews I just wanted to say a few words to reiterate how interesting this place is. It really is a must see if you are in the city.

A village of the dead!. Streets lined with large, ornate mausaleums all beautifully carved and decorated but housing dead people! It makes you wonder what people were hoping to achieve with these crypts. Interesting but creepy!

Amazing history. Fantastic spot to see and feel the history of BA. Come here to see gravesites of famous BA citizens and how they used to really used to take care of the wealthy when Argentina was at it's prime.
Never saw a cementary like this!. Thousands of private mausoleums. Each differently designed. Could have stayed for hours. Of course, the burial place of Evita is the biggest attraction. Amazing!

A lot of photographic opportunities. Maybe it would have helped to have a better understanding of Latin American history, and had a map of the cemetery, but just strolling the grounds and looking at the variety of architectures employed on the memorials was a fascinating way to spend a few hours. Having that map would have made it easy to find Eva Perón's resting place, although keeping an eye out for the crowds worked just as well, but that might have distracted from just wandering around and focused on the famous people rather than the interesting architecture. The light can be harsh so if photography is your thing then you might want to have a map and come back more than once so you can get the shadows to place nice.

Recoleta- a nice way to spend and hour in BA. Interesting and beautiful mausoleums. Well worth a visit and a stroll around. Will only take about an hour unless you want to see everything.Cultural difference of overground resting places is interesting to see. However I had allready been to the Cemeteria in Santiago Chile - so I got more of the culture-shock there and as it is stillan active cemetery I found it a little more interesting, however recoleta is definitely worth a visit.

Morbidly beautiful. Recoleta Cemetery is one of the most unexpectedly beautiful places in BA. The sheer size of the space, the variety of architectural styles and unique character of each mausoleum can be overwhelming. NOTE -- If you are specifically looking for Evita's resting place, make sure to pay attention to the map when entering the cemetery and reference Duarte, not Peron. There are no signs or way markers within the cemetery to help you find the spot.

Nothing special. i know is supposed to be one of place that you must visit, and taking on count that the entrance is free evidently you should take a walk in the cementery, the map is for sale it cost 20 pesos argentinos about 2 dollars, but definitely is not gonna change your world. is very quiet and some of teh crypts are very nice, maybe some people find s it creppy but is not.

Sacred at some points. A cemetery is generally not a place that tourists have on their must-visit list, (it wasn't on mine either), but I was visiting the area so I decided that I could not pass this by.I was not disappointed.I strolled through some parts of the cemetery, but the highlight was Evita's resting place. This is the area that feels the most sacred. Several people were standing in silence and simply reading all the inscriptions. It is interesting that so many years after her death people are still leaving flowers here.It is amazing how much architecture there is to admire in this cemetery. I think it is worth a visit so if you are in the area, why not pay a short visit?
Worth visiting it . Sorta strange and fantastic - a must see place. Located in a great neighborhood - I really don't know how to rate a cemetery but it's a different attraction for sure

Another visit to Recoleta Cemetery. I've visited the Recoleta Cemetery on previous trips to BA, but the group I was with this time had never been and so are tour director recommended a trip there. It was as I had remembered it and still an experience that I enjoyed. We toured most of the cemetery, but did not visit the tomb of it's most famous inhabitant, Evita Peron, as the crowds down that aisle were more than we wanted to deal with. If you're in BA and have never been here, you should visit, as it is truly unusual.

Fun to look around, but not much direction/guidance. Walked around here for ~20 min – there is plenty of incredible and varied architecture throughout to marvel at while strolling. However we had not looked at a map beforehand, so were lost as to where any of the ‘important’ sites were (e.g., Evita Peron). A good stroll, yes, but we should have done more plotting of our route in advance since directions are lacking on-site.
Interesting . . .. Elegant setting with historical importance, since 1881. Evita's final resting place is here and is easily the most visited, but I enjoyed strolling through several other areas.

A strange must-see of BA. I'm not sure how you rate a cemetery?! As somewhere a traveller needs to see in BA it's a must see so I've given it five stars/dots. The tombs are both creative and eery. The Familia Duarte tomb with Eva Peron's plaques and numerous fresh flowers is poignant. Personally I found the aristocratic one up man-ship to be grotesque but our guide explained that culturally the Argentinians have a specific relationship with their dead so I guess this should be respected. Whatever you think of it you definitely visit it.

Beautiful in a tragic sort of way; well worth visiting. I could spend hours wandering the often overgrown paths of this beautiful old place. People hand down fascinating stories about specific mausoleums and the circumstances surrounding the death of the people in them. Many of the mausoleums are over the top and meant to project the importance of the family or person buried there. Still others are in bad shape because they are not being maintained -- raising the possibility that the family line has died out leaving no descendants to care for the final resting place of the family. Many buildings look like they should be illustrations for Edgar Allen Poe stories. If you peer through the bars of some of the crumbling crypts, you can actually see coffins cracked open by time and weeds with shadowy "objects" inside surrounded by dust -- both creepy and sad. In many cases, you can see spiral stairs in the main crypt festooned with spider webs disappearing down into murky lower levels - adding to the air of morbidity and mystery. The cemetery is a definite must see - it will cause you to stop and ponder the mysteries of life and death.
Visit Evita's Crypt. Beautiful old cemetery! Nice afternoon activity! It's fascinating to see all the different crypts in the cemetery.

Very interesting place to visit.. I always have heard but it was nice to see it with my own eyes. I was very surprised with it. You can see so many coffins and knowing there is a history inside of them. I recommend it.

beautiful cemetery, full of history. the Recoleta Cemetery is gorgeous! There's so much fascinating history in here, so I would recommend taking a tour. I went with the director of my study abroad program who is a history buff, so I can't say how the tours organized by the cemetery are, but I'm pretty sure they're free so it's worth a try!Even if you don't go for the history, the architecture of the tombs is incredibly gorgeous. Warning, though, if you don't have a map (even if you do really) it's pretty easy to get lost wandering about the cemetery. It's pretty big, but you'll find your way out eventually.

Fantastic Cemetery Experience. Walked this iconic cemetery for hours. Went to Evita Peron's gravesite. Visited other older graves in the cemetery. Truly a history of the wealthy and privileged in Buenos Aires. Well worth the trip.

Most beautiful cemetery I've been to. The cemetery is beautiful, and relaxing. Nice to enjoy and walk around on a pretty day. Some free walking tours end here so its a great place to relax and sit while you rest.

A Mesmorising Cemetery!. Whether you take a guided tour, or decide to wander around the many and varied tombstones by yourselves, this cemetery has to feature on everyone's tour of Buenos Aires!Grandiose and striking, the tombstones hold so many stories of the rich and famous, including obviously Eva Peron. You are even able to see the coffins themselves in many instances. Mesmorising!

Worth taking a tour so you don't miss the many stories/history related to this cemetery. A cemetery, first built by Monks in early 18thC & still used by some rich/famous of Argentina today. After visiting a public cemetery in Santiago last week, the divide between rich & poor in this part of the world was highlighted! Glad we live in a part of the world where middle income earners still exist! The most popular site is the tomb of Eva "Evita" Perón...when there, even though we were with a guide, another tour guide with a large group told us to move on! So perhaps better to visit at 11ish as I read on Net that there are free tours on some days then. It's worth taking a tour as there are some very interesting history/stories to hear that you might miss without a tour guide. If that's not possible, good to read up a bit on Net before your visit. A mix of Architectural styles used over the years is interesting as well - Baroque, Art Deco etc. Wandering around without some background information would be a very average experience so hard to rate this one but we're glad we went!

A mini city. It is like a mini city (with dead residents however :-)). The mausoleums are just beautiful and so classy! Loved all the stone work and statues and sculptures. Talk about being buried in style. We saw the tombs of many famous people here including of course Eva Peron whose tomb was much simpler than the rest. There was a funeral of an army man when we visited so we followed the procession for a while to watch the ceremonies. There was a second funeral where everyone was dressed up in expensive suits and dresses! Ooo la la! High fashion. We peeked in many mausoleums and admired the stained glass windows and fancy altars and also saw a bony hand of a skeleton sticking out of one coffin.

Most memorable place. Recoleta Cemetery is a must see, you can not bypass it. Before we went in we were told you will see coffins laying in view and a few stray cats around, I did not know how I would feel but I was memorized I went back twice before we left to see more. The history is amazing. Most people like others said head to where Evita lies however if you turn right instead of turning towards here you will see some amazing architecture and other tombs and it is much quieter on that side of the cemetery.

A must see destination. Recoleta is a wonderful neighborhood to stay in or to visit. The highlight of the day will always be the ornate cemetery. Most tourists go to find Evita, but the other family mausoleums are much better. You can spend 30 minutes walking through on your own, or pay someone at the gate to give you a personalized tour.

Great Visit. I have been here multiple times and enjoy every visit. You can walk around this cemetery for hours. Lots of history here. Most people come to see Evita's tomb but here are many other important historical figures as well. If you want to know the history, come with a guide. If you just want to wander and see some incredible architecture and people watch, come alone. And remember it can get very busy on the weekends or days when the cruises come to port.

Most interesting. Mausoleums are both interesting and macabre, especially in a city like Buenos Aires where the rich/poor divide is so obvious. Also something that is foreign to us South Africans. Take a tour guide so that you can enjoy the stories behind much of what you see. Definitely worth a visit!

Fantastic Experience - La Recoleta Cemetery Buenos Aires. Visiting Cementerio de la Recoleta is unforgettable. The cemetery has the tombs and elaborate mausoleums of notable Argentinians including presidents, Nobel Prize winners, writers, poets, priests, military men, statesmen, Eva Perón, and a granddaughter of Napoleon. It's known as one of the world's most beautiful cemeteries and the "most relevant historical and artistic monument of Argentina".Its residents "lie in silent testimony honored by the presence of thousands of Argentine and foreign visitors who enjoy a truly magnificent human creation". The cemetery is set on 14 acres in Recoleta and cordoned off by a brick wall. The tombs in the cemetery create an eerie yet mesmerizing symmetrical pattern of crosses and angels spread out on the sky.Most people find that visiting the cemetery one time isn't enough. Having a guide walk with you to point out the details of some of the more interesting mausoleums is worthwhile. There is so much history, art, and symbolism in the cemetery it's difficult to comprehend.The tombs are close to each other and depending on the time of day and weather, getting good photos can be difficult. Some of the tombs are marble and others stone. A few stray cats live in the cemetery and are known as the cemetery “caretakers”. The groundskeepers must feed them as they are friendly and healthy.The cemetery was built around the convent gardens of the Jesuit Order of the Recoletos Monks who lived in the area in the early eighteenth century. Beautiful Iglesia de Nuestra Señora del Pilar built in 1732 is part of the grounds.Recoleta Cemetery became the first public cemetery in Buenos Aires In 1822. Governor Martin Rodríguez and government minister Bernardino Rivadavia were responsible for creating the cemetery. A French civil engineer designed the original layout and an Italian architect remodeled it in 1881.The cemetery has 4,691 vaults, all above ground. Ninety-four of the vaults are National Historical Monuments protected by the Argentine government. Entrance to the cemetery is through striking neo-classical gates with tall Doric columns.The elaborate marble mausoleums have decorative statues in a variety of architectural styles such as Art Deco, Art Nouveau, Baroque, and Neo-Gothic. Between 1880 and 1930 most materials used to build tombs were imported from Paris and Milan. The design of each mausoleum reflects the life of the family or person buried. Many are breathtakingly beautiful. The cemetery is laid out in sections like city blocks, with walkways branching into sidewalks filled with mausoleums.Among the memorials are works by Argentine sculptors like Lola Mora and Luis Perlotti. The unusual tomb of Liliana Crociati de Szaszak is of special interest. Many flock to the flower-covered tomb of Evita and the Duarte family which is beautiful but not the most impressive in the cemetery.The grounds are well maintained and most of the mausoleums are in good condition. A few of the older ones are crumbling and need repair. Sadly, a few have broken glass and litter.

Amazing cemetery!. Realy nice to walk around this cemetery and look at the the vaults of the rich and famous of BA. Our tour guide told us that you have to pay between 100K and 500K to buy a vault, as you can only buy excisting ones.The direct surroundings are nice to, especially in the weekend as there is a artisanal market just outside the cementeryAfter the walk enjoy an excellent ice cream at Persicco just down the cemetery, opposite of the café where the nazi Eichmann was identified and kidnapped.They have 4 kinds of 'dolce the leche' flavours and we tried them all!Go there, you won't be disappointed!

Architectural Cemetery. This cemetery should be seen at ground level and from above too, if you get the chance. Staying in apartments close by offered a wonderful side view. The tombs attempt to out-do each other in terms of size, type of stone, religious symbolism and in some cases look like facades of a chapel or church. The cemetery has been designated a cultural heritage of the City and it really is huge - spanning a huge chunk of space in Recoleta. It's worth spending some time here.TIP: Eva Peron's tomb is not easy to find .... there are 'map sellers' outside, but you don't need to buy this.The tomb is under: Duarte del Evita, Peron and is no. 88 on the list at C31.

A must see. Being in BA and not going there is making a mistake. It's of course mainly a tourist attraction so try to go on a weekday or early morning. It gives a good view of how things must have been back in the days.... And try to find Eva Perron! (not joking, there are no signs hehe)

Most people go there to see Evita Perron's grave. Visiting a cemetery is always a bit strange...but the set up and grounds are interesting to see. Most people want to see Evita's burial grounds. Plenty of buses bring people to this site so try to slip in between groups.

Nothing like we have seen before. As with all reviews, this is highly subjective, we have never seen a cemetery like this before. We recommend don't look at pictures before hand and just go there. Probably would have been nice to go there with a guide to know more about the people who lay there (we imagen there are quite a few famous and important people among them).

Fascinating, a mini city of mausoleums!. Recoleta Cemetery was incredibly fascinating. It's like a mini city with streets and tiny houses - except the houses are all crypts. Looking inside many of them gives you an insight into what people considered valuable, people were buried with their favourites books, bridal bouquets etc.The crypts are generally family crypts and you can see shelves of coffins.It was incredibly interesting to see!

A cemetery not to be missed. I loved the tombs here from old and new, decaying to perfectly preserved. Some are modest and others are the size of a small house! There are great examples of stained glass, iron work and stone work. It was interesting that many of the tombs have a basement to hold additional caskets. I hadn't seen that before. I was told that there are guided tours given by a local professor that are wonderful but I didn't have time to find who that was or when his tours were offered. At the entrance to the cemetery there are guided tour dates and times posted, but tours are not required.

Most beautiful cemetery I have visited. A cemetery is not always your first choice of location to visit, but the Recoleta Cemetery is stunning. Incredible architecture makes it a pleasure to walk around this cemetery.

Fun to se. Many important argentinians lie here and it is impressive to se the little town of tombs. Like many others we spent 10 mins there and took a photo of Eva Perons tomb. In the park outside the main entrance is another impressive sight: a HUGE tree with pillars to support its many heavy branches - we thought it was cool anyway..

Memento Mori?. This is a really peculiar cemetery a village with minature stone buildings (minimum plot 2m x 1 m), a graveyard for the wealthy arranged along streets and avenues. Some areas are decaying and would need restauration. The only vault that attracts crowds nowadays is the Duarte family vault where Eva Peron (another strange myth) is buried. I do not agree with BBC and CNN who called the Recolata Cemetery as one of "the best" and "most beautiful". To me a WWII war cemetery in Normandy with it's simple crosses on green grass is a better setting to humbly morn our deaths than the Recoleta Cemetery which reminds me to "a final showing off ones wealth".
Awesome!. This is such an amazing thing to see! If you're in BA, go and with a tour guide it is really worth it. Great photos. Amazing stories and craftsmanship.

Interesting and impressive. I enjoyed a lot this famous place in Buenos aires. It was very interesting, and if you want more informations about the cemetry and his history there is free tour with experienced guide! It's also a quiet place where you pass a good time!!!

Wonderful place. We visited the cemetery initially to see Eva Perons resting place but was really surprised at the grandiose of the cemetery. It's unusual but very peaceful and we managed to lose a couple of hours wandering around. It was also great to see a few cats taking lazy snoozes in the grounds!

Awesome place!. I visited this cemetery three times during my 12 visit. But was on the most peaceful places I've ever visited. Your eyes bounce from one beautiful sculpture to the next. This historical cemetery is a must see!

Unlike anything we have in CANADA!. We visited the Recoleta Cemetery on our trip to BA... We don't have anything like this in Canada and it was amazing to see how People have honoured their family members. I appreciate that the cemetery hasn't become commercialized with all the visitors that come through.

Mind Blowing. This is without a doubt Buenos Aire's finest attraction particularly when one sees it while visiting touring Recoleta. It's a great moment to Argentina's former wealth. Yes, I do remember Evita's tomb. I marveled at all the various tombs, and the sure size of them.

Amazing!. We read this is the worlds best cemetery.... And it didn't disappoint!
It is a very large place, it's really beautiful and a stunning place to walk about. The crypts are amazing to see as they are so different from a regular gave. There are many famous people here including be popular evita one.
Defiantly visit.

Truly amazing. I've heard about Recoleta Cemetery all my life, so finally being able to be there and absorb the experience was a special one for me. Many of the tombs have architecture that leaves one's mouth hanging open: other tombs have been vandalized and falling down upon themselves (as long as someone pays the taxes for the tomb, it stays--even if no one keeps it up). I wish I had had more time here; however, I did find Eva (Duarte) Peron's mausoleum, as we had a tour guide, which did help us see a variety of peoples' mausoleums.

Surprisingly enjoyable. I really didn't think I would enjoy this tour but it was very interesting. My 7 year old was fascinated by all the mausoleums and how some were in such bad shape and others were immaculate. Of course everyone was looking for Eva Perone's mausoleum. The architecture and history was beautiful. A very cultural experience.
Worth it !. Even it sounds creepy to visit a cementery, this one is really nice and peaceful to walk around and read the histories behind each tomb.

Pretty Macabre. If nothing else, it was an experience. The architecture and care given to these mausoleums is mind boggling! It was also interesting to be able to see how many of these structures have sub-floors. You can look into some that are no longer cared for - dusty coffins, torn linens: very sad. Some beautiful stained glass windows and bronzes. Interesting to see 'living roofs' de rigueur throughout the cemetery.

Worth seeing even if you are not a cemetery aficionado. I felt like I was visiting a neighborhood of ornate, wealthy apartment buildings. These tombs are elaborate and many are beautiful. We had a brief guided tour of some of the more important deceased as part of our 3-hour tour of the city. I don't think I would want to spend more than an hour here but you may feel differently. You might want to do some Internet reading about the buried and the cemetery before going to see it .

Go for the tour, then go back.. We did not visit the cemetery on our first trip to BA, thinking it was the ...shall we say ultimate...tourist trap. We did go there this trip, and it was an interesting and thought provoking experience. We went to the English tour. Very nice and competent guide. 45 minute tour. We took about thirty pics, including Eva Peron's family tomb. We learned about the total hands off policy regarding anyone's interference in the manner of perpetual care. We went back on our own, and in our wanderings, found many, many tombs which had been ignored for decades. Centuries. With families completely gone, things are left to rot. Discussion..is this disrespect for the dead, or respect for the dust to dust thing. In the end, we deleted all but two pictures and decided to let everyone rest in peace. Albeit, a messy one.

If cemeteries intrigue you ... then don't miss this one!. The Recoleta Cemetery should not be missed. The magnificent monuments and mausoleums have ornate architecture, some more than others, based on the wealth and position of the family. Of course, the famous Eva Perone, First Lady of Argentina, is laid to rest here, as well as other influential people from the past. Worth a look-see.

5 stars not enough. fascinating place to get lost in the history of Argentina. I particularly enjoyed the different architectural styles on display - different monuments styles according to date of internment - art nouveau, art deco, italinate, you name it and it'll show up at one ornate monument or more. and if you're a photography buff, hope for a cloudy day and take that extra card or roll - so much to capture!

Must Do. I didn't know much about this place beforehand so I was pleasantly surprised when I visited it. It is a cemetery that has all the movers and shakers of Argentina buried in it. Anyone who is anyone was buried here. Some of the burial units are maintained well and some obviously have no one to maintain them. It is much larger than anticipated, will take several hours to see it all. It is a good experience to visit and I would recommend it.

Extraordinary Unique and historic fitting memorial. A present surprise the Recoleta cemetery located in the Recoleta neighbourhood of Buenos Aires, Argentina is an extraordinary memorial place. I would advise if you are visiting Argentina to save a few hours to see the unique graves containing notable people, including Eva Perón, presidents of Argentina, Nobel Prize winners, the founder of the Argentine Navy and a granddaughter of Napoleon. It's an incredible place, I would say the world's most beautiful cemeteries.

Could spend the whole day here!. Visited the Recoleta Cemetery as part of a walking tour of the city - we were staying nearby so it was the final stop on our 6 hour tour. We spent around an hour wandering around the "streets" looking at some of the amazing tombs. Some HUGE amounts of money have been spent here, and the architecture is quite stunning - with each reflecting the wealth and personality of the family involved. Of course one of the big attractions is the tomb of Eva Peron, but for me this was simply a bonus - the whole cemetery is simply breathtaking.
Sounds weird but a great visit!. This is undoubtedly the most interesting cemetery I have ever seen (and one of the most famous). Unusual tombs with a variety of styles and decorations.

Incredible place. incredible memorials to the great and good of Buenos Aires, including of course Eve Peron. It really is amazing. Even if you find it a little grotesque or a little morbid, this is definitely very highly recommended. And afterwards enjoy an ice cream in the ice cream shop opposite. We loved the dulce de leche

Very nice. A great way to spend an hour or two and great photo ops. It is easy to find / get to. Didn't check out church next door. Market outside in the area just outside the cemetary was usual trinkets you would see everywhere more or less. Tango dancers outside were a treat to watch. Bring toilet paper as there is none and you have to pay for it from a guy that looks like a janitor.

Fascinating and Intriguing. This has to be the most amazing and fascinating cemetery anywhere! We walked through it for over an hour and still did not cover it all. Each grave has a fascinating story behind it and is made of materials that reflect the wealth of the family. I'm glad we had a guide who pointed out many different things which we might have otherwise missed, and told us interesting stories. A must visit site of Buenos Aires.

Beautiful place and informative guided tour. We went for one of the free tours in English at 11am on a Tuesday. The guide was very informative however it was difficult to hear at times due to the group being so large. The cemetery itself is stunning, like nothing I've seen before. It's well over the top but a must see in BA.
South America trip. Ricoletta cemetery is really one of the "must see" places in Buenos Aires even if you are only slightly interrested in history.
Has to be seen. A truly fascinating place, unlike anything I have seen anywhere else. It almost feels like its own small village, full of ornate tombs and mausoleums.
Just a cemetery. mmmmm nothing much to see, just a cemetery except there is Eva Peron's tomb.maybe it would mean alot to people who know much about the Argentinian history
Evita Peron's tombstone. A beautiful cemetery with countless interesting tombstones, including Evita Peron. Located in the Recoleta district.

Argentine history is reflected here.... Knowing that the body of Evita Peron was entombed here at Recoleta Cemetery made this a must visit, but her final resting place in her family's (Duarte's) tomb was non-descript - a simple plaque that could easily have been missed. The story of her long way back from exile to Argentina is more interesting. Grand cemetery with a vast array of impressive statues, carvings of cherubs and angels, monuments, tombstones and mausoleums that highlighted the rich and the poor; the famous and infamous and some of Argentina's notorious political figures. The largest tomb belongs to Nobel Prize winner in Chemistry - laureate Luis Federico Leloir.

Worth a visit. We were a bit skeptical when friends told us to check out the cemetery in Recoleta but it's definitely worth a wander around! Amazing history and insight into Argentinian culture. Don't forget to check out Evita's memorial

Coolest cemetery I've visited. The rich, the famous, the presidents, the military elite are entombed here. There are other above ground cemeteries in the world, but I haven't seen nor know of one that is more elaborate with such a large footprint. Of course, you should seek out the tombs of the famous like I did. For example, Eva Peron. But after doing that, feel free to wander. You can't get lost - you're inside high walls. If you feel you're lost, merely travel around the outer wall until you reach the gate.On your wanders inside, you'll see angels and cherubs, monuments and exhibitionism in stone. Well worth several hours here.

Don't cry for me Argentina!. We visited the cemetery to see Evita Peron's final resting place. What we found was an incredible display of what I would call "museum art". Rows and rows of ornate crypts. If you only want to see Evita's resting place: look for the Duarte family site.
Very interesting, . It's a beautiful collection of tombs. There's also tomb of Evita Peron. These are very beautiful and unique tombs I've ever seen. Very eyes opening.

Very interesting and surprising . I went as I was staying close by to cemetery, wasn't going to go as who wants to visit a cemetery?But was pleasantly surprised how well the cemetary was structured with the amazing tombs and history.This is no ordinary cemetery and worth a visit, many famous Argentinas people are buried their including Evita Peron.

you have seen it, check the box!. We visited this place on 10th March,2015 as part of City Tour of Buenos Aires, Having seen many cemeteries across the world, Arlington, Valley of Kings etc., yet this place is quite unique! Somewhat similar to the cemetery in Moscow. Modern and Contemporary! No splendor or great history. Perhaps, the best resting place money can buy! see this and tick your box!

An interesting group of tombs. Most tourists come to this cemetery to see the Duarte Family Mausoleum. Eva Peron was of the Duarte family but is not buried in the Mausoleum. More interesting, however are the scores of other crypts and mausoleums in the Recoleta Cemetery. It is reminiscent of Pere La Chaise Cemetery in Paris, albeit on a smaller scale.

Interesting piece of history. This is generally a must when touring Buenos Aires. It is interesting, and filled with history. Make sure you go with someone knowledgeable or have some type of guide (written, etc).
Take the tour!. Very cool place and I highly recommend the free tour. We took the English one and our guide was great. There is a pretty church next door as well that is worth visiting.
Definitely. This is an amazing place. I have never seen mausoleums laid out, almost like a city, some very grand, before. A "must see".

So moving, bring some tissues. It seemed so strange to go on a tourist outing to a cemetery. But this is a beautiful and moving place. Try to ignore the loutish tourists (it's still a cemetery people - enough with the selfies and the jokes about Lord of the Rings, have a little respect!) and enjoy this place steeped in history and full of tales of lives lived not just lives remembered. There is little to no info on display. Having a data connection will let you explore the place and its stories appropriately via your phone/ iPad. I did it this way but imagine it's a cracking place to see with a guide. If you have come to see Evita, don't be surprised that she is snuggled down a side alley. That should be a sign that you need to see more than the Duarte tomb. You won't regret it - a Buenos Aires must see

Interesting Place. Everyone comes here to see the final resting place of Eva Peron. The cemetery is huge with many many interesting tombs, all better than the basic one for Eva Peron. It is quite narrow in places and the tomb for Eva Peron can be a battle when a big tour group arrives. Take your time and the crowds do clear and you can get your photos etc.Outside there are lots of market stalls selling tourist stuff. Nothing special.

Interesting and Like No Other Cemetery. Recoleta Cemetery was not like any I had ever visited. The grounds were beautiful and well kept making for a grand entrance. The highlight was seeing Eva Peron's tomb. The mausoleums were anywhere from poorly kept to grand. In front of the cemetery is an outside artist market on Sunday.

I don't usual visit cemetaries but this one was too cool to miss!. I do not usually go to cemetaries when I visit a new city. I am much more interested in good food, wine, and museums. However, this one is just gorgeous and I couldn't pass it up. Also, I thought it was pretty cool to visit Evita's grave. I probably would have gotten more out of it if I had a guided tour, but I was still blown away while wandering around on my own.

Interesting and Historic Cemetery. We had a guide which I think is essential if you want to see the highlights of this cemetery. It is so easy to just wander here for hours. Loved seeing all the beautiful old crypts. There are so many spots to take wonderful photos. Lots of history here.

Ghoulish but beautiful. It's strange to see coffins on shelves in the mausolea and that more money seems to have been spen on the afterlife than this life but it provides a beautiful microcosm of BA architecture. Get there early to avoid the crowds around Eva Peron's tomb.

Recoleta Cemetery historic resting place of the rich, famous & powerful of Buenos Aires including Evita Peron.. Recoleta Cemetery, the historic family cemetery of the rich & famous is a must see if you want to experience the essence of Buenos Aires. We wandered in by ourselves mid-day. Stop in the entrance area where you will find a plot map with a key to important mausoleums and families including the infamous Evita Peron. If you've ever been to any of the New Orleans cemeteries, Recoleta will remind you of them except on a much grander scale. For the most part,the crypts are well cared for, except for the few that have fallen into disrepair & neglect. The wooden caskets, all sizes, are exposed and yes a bit creepy. The cemetery is very clean and there are a few resident cats that lay in the sun. We felt safe walking around, however we took heed to everyone's advice & did not wear any jewelery & I had nothing of value in my purse except a few pesos to hand out if needed.

Overwhelmingly beautiful. This cemetery was amazing. You could get lost in here for hours so get a guide. The highlight was seeing Evita Peron's grave. I think it closes at 5 PM so get there before 4:30 when they stop letting people in. Take your camera.

Interesting but a bit creepy. I found the visit to the Recoleta Cemetery interesting. It is not your typical cemetery and the crypt are big and old. Some of the crypts are breaking up and have the coffins exposed. Some of these are breaking up also which made it a creepy. There is certainly a lot of history. We didn't have a guide but in hindsight I think it would have been good to have one.

Best to see with a guide!. We were glad to have a guide take us through the cemetery as there is a lot of history to be learned at this site. One amazing fact is that you would need over a million dollars to purchase a site at this cemetery. The mausoleums are several floors below ground level and the designs are very varied and interesting. Many notable people and families are buried here including Evita Peron.

Historic family cemetery. This is a fascinating place. The cemetery is laid out like streets with cross streets. There are no yards to speak of; the mausoleums are compact. Many names go back several generations. Eva Peron is buried there in the Duarte family mausoleum. The mausoleums are tended by contractors. They are sometimes as much as 50 feet deep with remains on several floors below ground. Some caskets are visible. Many old and important families from Buenos Aires and the surrounding ranches are represented here.

A photographer's dream spot. I went to Cemetario de Recoleta twice. The first time, I think I was there for an hour and a half. The second time, 30 minutes. There were still nooks that I didn't get a chance to explore even after 2 trips. A very cool spot if you're into photography, with all of the cool statues, plaques, and crypt designs.

An unusual but essential part of any visit to BA. Clearly visiting a cemetery is an unusual thing to do, but like Highgate in London or Montauban in Cambridge MA it does not disappoint. The family mausoleums of the great and the good (and a few not so good) and architectural and cultural wonders. Evita ended up here, along with friends and foes alike.

Go for the art, drama and intrigue. I recently spent an afternoon in this interesting graveyard. The mausoleums were not only huge, unique, fanciful and ornate they held the intriguing stories of their dead. It helped that I had an excellent English speaking tour guide and he knew the people who were buried there like they were his own relatives! Examples of stories include one who most unfortunate to be buried alive and one who died in her honeymoon and whose dog also died on the same day in another location. I am sure our guide had more stories to tell but we only had a few hours. I noticed some vendors were selling some maps/guides of the cemetery at the entrance. I would buy it if I were to come on my own although I'm not sure if they sell the guide in English. Take a few hours to spend here and after learning all the stories about their dead you might just be inspired to live your own life to the fullest!

Literally a city of the dead. A cemetery generally is not high on the list of things to visit, but this one is very unique. It is nothing but countless mausoleums, side by side, of every important Argentine citizen (and their family). Both awe inspiring and somewhat creepy when you can see the coffins and then the small steps that lead underground for the rest of the family. Free to enter, and in the Recoleta district, which is a great area to be in, this shouldn't be missed.

I could have spent a full day there!. Doesn't matter what faith or belief system you hold, or if you think cemeteries are creepy, if you come to this city, it's a travesty if you don't visit this place. It's not creepy at all. The works of art are mind-blowing! We must have taken 300-400 photos, at least, in the 3 hours that we were there. We were lucky to link up with the free English speaking guide. She's there on Tuesdays at 11 am and one other time during the week, which I cannot recall.
Fascinating. An interesting place to visit. Would have gotten more out of it with a guide, but it was nice to just meander. So many different architectural styles.
Wow. I haven't seen anything quite like this. Lots of detail. Unique. Don't get lost. Felt weird taking pictures in a cemetery, but it is so unique.

Even if you aren't into cemeteries...do not miss!. I almost missed seeing this but I hope you don't! I didn't have a chance to do any research before a business trip to Buenos Aires. I'd vaguely heard about a cemetery there but it wasn't on the top of my "to see" list until I randomly ran into some folks I'd stood in line with at customs who said I HAD to go. So glad I did.It is a city of mausoleums of all different types of architecture. You can see modern and ancient ones. Some are not well kept (which makes you wonder about the story...what happened to the family and its ancestors?) and some have fresh flowers in front of them. Inside some, you only see tiny coffins. What happened to those babies? It so naturally conjures up stories and your imagination. Make it there!

Historically interesting, yet morbid. If you are going to Buenos Aires for the first time, this is a must tour. Just as if you are going to Washington DC for the first time and seeing the Smithsonian, or the Arlington Cemetery, just not as big. It pays to get a tour guide to explain all the different historical events accompanying the tombs. The crowds are usually surrounding Eva Perron's mausoleum.There is a minimal donation that is suggested at the front gates, which gets you a map. Be on the look out for the resident cats that meander through the cemetery.

Amazing...so much history...try and find Evita!. I have visited Recoleta cemetery many times and always stumble upon new and interesting plots. There are tours you can take that tell you the ins-and-outs of the cemetery, including its history and where Evita is located.Outside the cemetery is a fair that you should not miss that is there daily (but more vendors on the weekend).

Worth a visit. The cemetary is worth a visit, it is a fascinating place to see a different type of cemetary. In many of the tombs/ buildings it is possible to see the coffins in side. Sadly many are in a poor state where there is no longer any family to care for the tombs. The streets are narrow but the main avenues are wider. Eva Perons tomb is behind large closed doors there are many famous Argentinians buried here, you will recognise the names if only from the many streets named after them.It is open from 7 am to 5 pm. I went by my self and followed my guide book, there were enough people there not to make it feel eerie. It is very large so to see most of it will take about one hour.

Very Interesting Experience. whilst a slightly morbid attraction, it was fascinating to see what lavish resting places/memorials families of the deceased were prepared to pay for. Eva Peron 's body lies here also.

Beautiful and Reflective Visit. The architecture here is really unmatched and detailed. We enjoyed over an hour wandering around the mazelike corridors and getting a sense of the past history. One of the main attractions is Evita's tomb. We wished we had actually taken a tour here (available at the entry), as we think we could have gotten a lot more out of the experience.
City of the dead. An incredible place to visit - ornate mausoleums, including the mausoleum of Eva Peron (Evita). Not to be missed!! A great place to learn about the history of Buenos Aires.

A Must-Do in Buenos Aires. The tombs are architectural pieces of work - amazing. Of course, you must stop by Evita's. Tomas Hughes (Bonaventura Tours) was our individual guide and did an excellent job explaining many of the intricacies of the cemetery and was a just an outstanding guide.

An absolute MUST SEE!. My original thought was, what is so special about a cemetery? Then when you see the Recoleta Cemetery you will understand. Beautiful architecture and rows and rows of amazing statues, granite pillars. Famous deceased people in the military, past local presidents, government etc. are buried here. One of the more famous is Eva Peron. There are free guided tours through here. You can easily spend 1 1/2-2 hours here on your own. This is a definite highlight of the area.

A very interesting Tour with a great guide who had good knowledge. Our guide made this tour enjoyable for us on what was a very hot day in the sun She knew her information and delivered it well Lots of history here The tombs they have built I have seen no where else Like little houses for the dead Must do tour

more interesting than I expected. I've visited a lot of cemeteries being a somewhat serious amateur genealogist. This one is very impressive - rather than the mundane headstones of traditional cemeteries, these are all mausoleums/buildings of varying sizes and shapes. Really quite fascinating. Many historic figures are interred here so there is lots to talk about as it ties into BsAs history. Definitely worthwhile in my book.

The city of the dead. Recoleta Cemetery is where most of the wealthy people of Argentina were buried. All of the burial sites are mausoleums and many of them are quite ornate. The most famous site is the one for Eva Peron but it is listed by her maiden name Durant. The largest group of people will be in front of her grave and you will see flowers laid at the foot of her mausoleum. Some of the mausoleums are not in good shape and are crumbling. The place is quite large and crowded and are arranged like a city with narrow streets. It is actually quite charming. Eva's husband Juan is also buried in the Recoleta Cemetery but not with her. You will find that you will not be the only ones enjoying the view. The place is filled with cats who lie down on the steps of the mausoleums and bask in the sun. I've never seen any place like this cemetery. If you are interested in being buried here you are out of luck unless your family already owns property here. The placed is filled up and there is no more room to build.

A must. Even with all of expectations of this being a "must see" in Buenos Aires, it truly was. I was told that during cruise ship days, and hot days in the tourist season it can get a little packed, but visiting in late March was beautiful and peaceful. I had my 9 year old and 6 year old with me, and while there were some wide eyed questions about what we were seeing, it was beautiful, and they enjoyed it. The cafes right outside of the cemetery may seem touristy, but La Biela was a great stop for a Cafe de Leche under the trees after our hour in Recoleta.
Thanatourism at its best. Great destination for those interested in thanatourism. It mirrors the city of the living. Only for fanatics: Eva Duarte's family tomb.

A must-see. This was definitely one of the highlights of BA. It's something that you will liekly not see anywhere else. I would suggest having a tour guide to explain some of the "important" tombs to make the experience more memorable.

More than I expected but too big easy to get lost. Great architecture and an original place for cemetaries but it is not well indicated for special locations (like Evita) and if you don't know where you are going you can spend too much time going in circles

Bring the wide angle lens. This well known cemetery has many many mausoleums that are packed shoulder to shoulder and reach down onto the earth several stories. Maps can be bought for two USD in a couple of languages to provide some background and create a self guided tour. Guides can be hired to give their interpretations. All flock to Eva Peron site, but there are famous and infamous Presidents, military, rich, poor, and well known figures. The size of the place and the enormity of the structures is compelling.

Great Visit to the Cemetery. We very much enjoyed our stroll through the cemetery, looking for several of the more interesting tombs, including that of Evita. We did not retain a guide, but would have had one been seen near the entrance. (A tip based guide, Simon, had been recommended to us by folks we met on the Subte, but we did not find him until we exited the cemetery). We used our map to get through the cemetery and, other than the fact that it was bloody hot and humid during our visit, we enjoyed walking around very much. Just did our best to find the shady "routes". This is an experience not to be missed, and we would recommend looking for Simon as a guide as well. On Sundays, there is a great craft fair set up outside of the entrance.

Not like any cemetery I have every seen. Hmm. A cemetery as a top attraction? Yes. This place is fascinating to walk through. It is not your typical cemetery. It's very three dimensional, and brimming with history. Yes, Evita is there, but so are many other important figures from Argentina history. Well worth spending a morning or afternoon exploring.

Surprisingly interesting. We were "taken " here on our private Tour of BA and I must say found it surprisingly interesting , without being ghoulish It added to our knowledge of the history of some of the leading figures in Argentinian history and also of the ongoing traditions, demands and costs of using Recoleta as a Fanily burial ground - some vaults complete with their own lifts!Ricoletta is difficult to put into words, but it we feel is worth a 20 minute visit on such a City TourIt is very much part of BA and has a premium tag about it!

The best cemetery!. This is the best cemetery I have visited. Not that I make it a point of seeing cemeteries, just the above ground mausoleum types. Don't bother with a guide just wander, it helps if you "bone" up on Argentine history, presidents, artists, etc. I found some of the smaller mausoleums that were somewhat lacking in maintenance the most interesting.

Magnificent city of the dead. Our hotel overlooked this cemetery and so we were very keen to complement our birds eye view. It covers a large area and is laid out like a town - with long and wide avenues and little alleys.We just wandered around for a couple of hours - some tombs we could see from our hotel room we sought out for a ground level view. Many Argentinian notables are buried and commemorated here and several presidents.Eva Peron is buried here and we did walk over to her family mausoleum. Of more interest was the range of commerative plaques which adorned most buildings - I particularly liked the decorative ones from the 1920s and 1930s. Some of the buildings are derelict and neglected, others clearly still in use - and it can be a little easy to forget that this is a cemetery which is still being used.We really enjoyed wandering around and making discoveries - if you are so minded you can buy a map or find plenty of online resources which will help you map a tour of celebrated Argentinians and/or fantastic mausoleums.You can easily spend a couple of hours in there, very probably longer.

One of the better cemeteries. Better bone up on your Argentine presidentes.Lots of them are here.Plenty of incredible monuments to the deceased makers and shakers of Buenos Aires.Sadly, one to a young woman buried ALIVE!Oy!If you are so inclined, there are some for sale.Probably cost as much as a two bedroom in SoHo but, if you're a Russian oligarch, does it matter?

The main attraction in Buenos Aires--worth a visit!. While doing research before visiting Buenos Aires, the one attraction that kept coming up was Recoleta Cemetery. This is worth a visit, even if touring a cemetery seems odd to you. There are large mausoleums, many of famous people, such as Evita Peron. It is located in a very affluent neighborhood and as people died, they would build these very ornate mausoleums to honor their families. Over the years, each successive person who died tried to outdo the previous occupants, resulting in a small city of often beautiful mausoleums and statues. You can wander at leisure up and down the many roads and admire the stonework. The church nearby is worth popping into as well. There are not many must-sees in Buenos Aires, but this is one of them. Enjoy!

A work of art. With the sun shining along the cemetery's alleyways, this was a beautiful way to spend an afternoon in Buenos Aires. Yes, there'll be the unavoidable crowd at Eva Peron's tomb but venture away from the crowds and you'll find some stunning works of art adorning the crypts and intriguing tales in the memorial plaques.

Unique Cemetery. I'm not a fan of cemeteries but I'll make an exception for this one. Rows upon rows of brilliant architecture, families brought together when they die. It's a little spooky at first looking into the crypts seeing the coffins but after a while I just found it fascinating.Eva Perons resting place in an unremarkable family crypt, we were really pleased we made the effort to come here.
Fascinating cemetery. You can easily spend several hours walking round this cemetery. There is so much history here. There are conducted tours if you would like to join them.
Works of art. I wasn't so sure about spending time at a cemetery but very glad I did. The structures and monuments were amazing. I highly recommend this.

The Cemetery to end all Cemeteries. I live in New Orleans and thought we had the best cemeteries I had ever seen until I saw Recoleta Cemetery. It is a relatively small cemetery but endlessly fascinating. No trip to BA would be complete without a visit here. Bring your camera and explore. There is so much to see that you can't take it all in with one visit though. It is easy to find Evita's tomb as there are always people and flowers around it, but it does not compare to most of the other tombs in the cemetery.
great place to visit. amazing cemetery .... you can walk along this beautiful cementery that makes you feel in the 50's. a must

One Unique Cemetery. This is one unique cemetery. All graves are crypts of varying degrees of opulence . Theere are some that are not up kept and they can be sold to a new family if no paymens made or upkeep. Did I mention that the crypts hold many members since it goes underground do and some have upper floors. Lots of famous Argentine notables. The big attraction is the crypt of Eva Peron. Very interesting place.

Had a problem finding at first. We had a city map that needed a magnifying glass to read and consequently spent a couple of hours finding the location of the cemetery. However once you’re in the general area it’s quite easy to findAs others have said it’s quite unique in as much as you can see some of the caskets through glass underground and even above ground where the concrete has eroded and broken away through time, quite eerie A must see is Eva Peron’s final resting place in the Duarte mausoleum. On entering the main gate turn left and almost go to the perimeter, about half way down you will see the tour operators and their groups. Your there I agree with others, a must see when in Buenos Aires. We spent a couple of hours here

Absorbing experience!. I visited this place on my first trip to Buenos Aires in 2009. A fascinating place, very well laid out, beautiful structures, money no object spent on the mausoleums. Well worth a visit when you come here.

Wow... Interesting place without parallel. This cemetery is unique in the sense of the number and variety of mausoleums it has. There are beautiful structures built for the most prominent figures of the Argentinean society. The mausoleum where Evita Peron was buried was there, among many others of leaders in sports, politics, and wealthy families of Buenos Aires. It is an active cemetery that, unlike many others, becomes a touristic attraction due to its originality.

New Orleans with panache. Kinda creepy what with caskets and broken caskets right there in front of you. Had fun finding Evita's tomb. Not the most ornate but of course historical. Make sure and have your walking shoes on.

Just bonkers. Just weird what people do with the deceased. Makes you think about the time, money and time wasted on relics, remains and relations. What do you want your legacy to be, a temple to your remains or some impact on society and the common good. Fashions and beliefs change.

Definitely explore this cemetery!. We had a private guide for our tour, which made it even better. There are so many stories to be told about this place, it was great to get the inside information! Everyone flocks to Eva Peron's site, but there is so much more to see. Take your time... it's fascinating!
Amazing history. This is a must-do in BA. Fascinating architecture, tons of sculpture, marble and brick. Definitely gives you a feel of the wealthy in Recoleta.

Just fascinating. Not being a fan of cemeteries and in no hurry to visit one on a permanent basis I had some feelings of trepidation about visiting this one but I amVery pleased we did. A great insight into a cities historical past and armed with a 20 peso guide map you can go your own way or get a free guided tour, but if you choose the tour please tip generously at its conclusion. The mausoleums are incredible and whilst some are bigger than apartments I have lived in over the years some are crumbling relics of a person or persons long forgotten. I liked that aspect of it, it's a reality that there may come a time in all our pasts when we will become less than a distant memory. The place is huge too and was way beyond my expectations. A good way to spend a couple of hours immersing yourself in the cities past residents final resting place.

A must see.. So I've got a bit of inner "goth" and always enjoy cemeteries. Whether it's an old graveyard by a Norman church in Britain or a wartime cemetery somewhere, I find them peaceful places to reflect and they are inevitably full of stories and history. That said, I can honestly say I've never seen anything quite like Recoleta! It was quiet when we visited and we were with an English speaking guide (see my review for BuenosTours walking tour) so had time to learn some of the history, the fables and to see some of the more famous mausoleums. To walk among what are literally streets of mausoleums (some gorgeous, some ostentatious, all interesting) was humbling and simply awe inspiring! I also enjoyed the seemingly well cared for cats that roam about there too!
Fascinating Architecture and History. Our tour through this landmark by Betty from Say Hueque was excellent - the backstories were fascinating and the architecture was amazing.

Fascinating and well worth the time. We took a tour of Buenos Aires and stopped at the Recoleta Cemetery. It was fascinating. It is packed with so many graves and mausoleums you could hardly get around. It was like walking through a small city with streets and alley ways going every which way. The art work of sculptures and reliefs and stained glass is stunning. We found Evita's plot (Duarte family) and the burial place of several of Argentina's presidents. You should book at least an hour to get through most of this fascinating historical site.
