Mesmerizing Architecture and Statues. Worth spending time here. All the celebrities includiing presidents buried here there are lot more interesting mausoleums are there which mesmerize you. These all are beautiful tombs created by fine famous artists and are works of art in themselves. Please hire a guide here which can make huge difference.

A City within a City. We wanted to see where Eva Peron resides and in doing so wandered around the cemetery and located the history of Buenos Aires in a nutshell. Avenues upon avenues of beautiful sculpture and artistic renderings of the tombs and final resting places of the elite of Buenos Aires.

Spend an hour or two. Worth wandering around this cemetery, although Evita is buried here there are a lot more interesting Mausoleums than hers, the million pound one and the one for the daughter killed in a skiing accident, mother who died in childbirth, these all are beautiful tombs created by fine famous artists and are works of art in themselves, we had a guide which made a huge difference to our experience, while most people wandered around only looking for Evita's resting place. Tip-Take a brolly for shade as it is hot in there with not a great deal if shade especially at midday.

Hauntingly Beautiful. When I was in Havana last April, the guard at Cemetario de Colon kept telling me, "Recoleta is number one, Colon is number 2". Now I know why this cemetery is talked about the world over. The mausoleums are too numerous to see in just one visit. The stories that go with them are haunting and fascinating. It opens very early (7 am) and that is a great time to go to beat the crowds, the heat and have great light to photograph.

An interesting cemetery well worth the visit.. Recoleta Cemetery has a most interesting collection of tombs and sculpture including the tomb of the Duarte family in which Evita Peron is buried and a large tomb of a converso family which has a prominent Menora. If one has visited the Cemetery in Milan on should visit this one

Interesting and quite beautiful. I have never seen anything like this before - so elaborate, so beautiful, so peaceful. I never thought I would have such a nice time spending an afternoon in a cemetery!

Interesting and elaborate. I found the cemetery very interesting to just walk around and have a look at all of the elaborate, huge, fancy different types of graves. There were a good few people around and people on tours too. I just walked around myself as I preferred this. It's free entrance and you can stroll around or as long as you like. You would be surprised at how big the cemetery is!

Hood of the Dead. Buenos Aires is known for its barios, or neighbourhoods, and this is possibly the most unique one of them all. This neighbourhood of the dead is one of the famous cemeteries in the world and houses the tombs of some of the most famous people including Evita. Even if you are not a cemetery person, and get a very eerie feeling even when near them, this one is still worth a visit for its unique and intricate tombstones and meandering "streets".

Fascinating. This is an amazing place, located near a metro. It is very big but well laid out with some fabulous statues and memorials. They are all looked after very well. There is a map at the entrance but it is worth taking a photo of it or making notes if you want to see something in particular. The grave of the girl who was buried alive is interesting. The grave of Eva Peron is small and not easy to find but look for an aisle with lots of people in it. There are lots of cats but they are well looked after. It is free entry and there are plenty of seats around. There are people at the entrance who want to offer you private tours but if you want to go around alone you need to be firm with them.

A place to die for or at least to be seen being buried here. This place was THE place for the rich,famous and IN people to be buried. Evita is here but not her husband. His last wife didn't want him with a former wife so Evita is with her family. There are recorded cases of people of lesser means staging a relatives funeral here and then quietly moving the body to cheaper digs after everyone left.

Where the Rich are Buried. we spent an interesting hour or so, walking around this cemetery to see all the different mausoleums. Some have glass doors and the coffins are visible. Many have stairs inside leading down to the burial places below the sidewalks. It is great for photographers with the varied sculptures and interesting inscriptions. many small allies and easy to get "lost". Eva Peron's mausoleum is the most famous here and easy to miss if you don't know she is buried in her family site---maiden name - Duarte. This Mausoleum is on an extremely narrow alley/street in cemetery. It is worth a visit. Our 2nd day tour took us there also----personally once was plenty, but 2nd day gave us opportunity to focus on some of the sculptures for photographs.

Recoleta cemetery. Eva Peron 's final resting place. it is old some of the mausoleums are in a sad state and need to be repaired. It reminded me of the cemeteries in New Orleans but much grander, some of the doors are all glass but most have decorative bars over the glass and some are wood doors.I was told that some could accommodate twenty four coffins. The mausoleums have steps that go down two floors so you are not able to see the coffins only the crosses and glass vases on the altars. Very pleasant to wander around around. Not only Eva Peron's grave but a history of Argentine 's presidents and generals.There are plenty of cats that roam the area and some are friendly and some are not. I enjoyed the history and the photo ops

A 'must see' for photographers. We found the cemetery a really interesting place to visit, and a photographer's 'must see'. This is apparently one of the biggest mausoleums in the world; so instead of a cemetery as you might see in Australia, where all the burials are underground, here they are basically above ground, in buildings of various sizes, shapes and levels of sophistication. And there's amazing artwork as you wander around. Highly recommended. We visited 3 times - at different times and in varying lights.
Beautiful resting place. The mausoleums are breathtaking and full of stories and history. Our group went back a second time to soak it in more!

Interesting Day Out. Certainly one of the more interesting places that I have been in my life. I spent an enjoyable (is that the right word for a cemetery visit?) few hours wandering around the grand tombs and, of course, finding the ones of interest (Evita's being the most common one). We had an excellent tour guide - one of the many cats who live in and around the cemetery who took a shine to us and meowed us through the alleyways! So that's my tip for this place - follow one of the cats, as you never know where you might end up. There is also a really interesting museum next door and the surrounding area is very nice for a walk and an ice-cream.

Great mix of history, culture and architecture. During our stay in BA we did 2 trips to the Recoleto cemetary. The guided tour in English started at 11am and was given by a charming lady named Marta. Her 1.5 hour tour was full of interesting tidbits about the various families buried there. She's a bit soft spoken songetbup close to hear here. We also did our own little tour o the cemetary just to see the sights. The mix of statuary, architecture and mosaics was amazing. Make sure you have lots of space on your camera to capture the incredible things you'll see

Very interesting. It was very interesting to see how these people were buried in that cemetery. Some are under ground and others you can see the coffins. It was very unique and fascinating. If you are looking for Eva Perron tomb look for the Duarte location because she is buried under her birth name. It is a huge cemetery and you can walk there for hours. Look for the big map at the entrance so you can direct yourself to the right location. You can also take a tour with a tour guide, available in English.

So Much History. Even if you are not a fan of Eva Peron, a visit here is very interesting. The mausoleums reflect high society of a time long gone, and the statues and architecture whisper of wealth and hidden lives. Wander a while and take some great photos. And pay your respects to Eva - along with all the crowds.
Very cool. This was my favorite site in BA. A must see. I never expected to see such fantastic things in a cemetery. Next time I will take a tour.

Coffins in the air. Went there since my cousin is (don't know why) impressed with Eva Peron to take pictures to her tumb. I was really impressed to see that the coffins are not underground but just in the air. They just put them in the funeral house there and that's it.
Even more impressed that no bad smell was there either.

Very touristic thing. Im not really into visit cemiteries, but Recoleta Cemitery is very touristic and nice... You should go see it, but please keep all the respect. Better if you go during the week, and it is calmer and peacefull.

A who's who of departed Argentinians. This cemetery is certainly not like the majority of cemeteries in our hometown. The mausoleums and crypts are unbelievable, not only by the names on the facade, but by their construction and the details thereof. Certainly worth a visit - especially if you have any interest in Evita Peron and her resting place or the burial/cemetery protocol of famous Argentines.

Has to been seen. Poor on Life Rich in Death...it place has to been seen to be believed the most lavish cemetery I've ever seen...suggest you get a map on arrival for a few pesos it could easily get confused amongst the vast array of ornate structures

Not much interested in seeing a cemetery. I don't know about you but we weren't that interested in visiting a cemetery, whether it was because Evita Peron is buried there or not. Obviously there are some beautifully decorated sites there but this was definitely not our thing.

Eerily magical. Recoleta cemetery is an incredible place to wander around with no definite course. The most famous place is the tomb of Evita Perón, but is somewhat underwhelming compared to the numerous mausoleums of former presidents and other significant people. I reccommend the memorial mausoleum of the victims of the revolution way in the back of the cemetery. Just ask by the tomb in which Hipolito Yrigoyen is buried.

Important Cemetery. Easy to go here on your own. Lots of guides available inside the cemetery willing to give you a personal tour, any day, any time if you want one. Charge four our group was $15 and well worth it. Avoid the large tour groups. No need to jockey for position for a photo at Evita's tomb. They will be gone in a few minutes. If you have your own guide, the guide will make sure you avoid the crowds at the various sites. Go later in the afternoon after all the tour groups have left.

Interesting. Cemeteries are not only a place of a memory but often also a piece of art. If you like mysterious places, with interesting architecture and beautiful sculptures Cementario de la Recoleta is a place for you.

Fascinating. We visited with the main aim of seeing the tomb of Eva Peron; however there is so much more to see. It is fascinating to walk around what is like a village of narrow streets all lined with monuments to those who have passed on. Many of the tombs are glass fronted with the caskets visible inside. It is also a strange experience, but one you should try to take in if you visit Buenos Aires.
One of the world's most interesting cemeteries.. One can really get a feel for the history of Argentina by visiting this cemetery. There are free English tours on Tues and Thurs at 11:00 am.

The Essence Of Buenos Aires. Essence?Yes, if you take a guide and do more than run to the mauseleum of Evita Duarte Peron.Entrance is free. For a 20 peso donation, you get a map and walking path suggestions. Even better, take the guided tour in english at 11am on Tuesday and Thursdays and hear all the history of Argentina and Buenos Aires from the highly qualified guide.Finally, for 100 pesos, buy the book that summarizes the highlights of the cemetery, Buenos Aires and Argentina in general. Make this your first stop before the city tour and many things will fall into place as you get to enjoy the city.

Take a tour. This was our 2nd time visiting the cemetery; this time we were part of a group, and we had a guide. I recommend doing it with a guide if you are interested in learning about the historical figures who are here. Many great opportunities for photographs!

A must. This is much more than the resting place of Eva Peron. It feels like you are walking in a city with buildings, sculptures, statues. Even in the afterlife, people are trying to compete as to who has the tallest , biggest, most impressive memorial.

Amazing. The cemetery was already on my list, but I was still amazed. Everyone goes to see Eva Perons tomb, but it was so much more than that. The art and architecture will inspire you, but what got me was the unique and intimate look at the culture in micro. It's all there, the good and the bad in their history. Love, scandal, neglect; the tombs whisper with the voices of the past. It is definitely the type of place I'd go to every time I was there.

Well worth your time. we have visited many cemeteries around the world . Also stories to learn. The Recoleta is no different. Very well kept. Our guide had a lot of history about many of the families as well as how Eva Peron came back here. I would recommend a visit with a guide .

Great place to explore in BA. we went on a Friday morning and it was pretty quiet without many other groups. As we were going in simon, a guide from England, offered us a tour. So glad we accepted. He knew so much about the place and it would be easy to get lost. You really would miss a lot wandering on your own. It was so interesting to see the many different burial sites. Many are abandoned. You can look in quite a few and see down a couple levels. Highly recommend going and either getting the free tour or hiring a guide at the entrance.

Different ways to visit it !. This is a must-see in Buenos Aires and there are different ways to visit it : 1) On your own at your own rhythm but do not forget to get a plan at the entrance gate . You are asked to donate 15 pesos for it ! It is quite useful as it identifies the most notable personalities buried there  2) On a walking tour : there are daily guided tours (free) in English at 11.00 a.m. . they last for 2 hours . Cancelled when raining  3) As part of a bigger walking tour : we took a very good walking tour with BUE free guided tour at 15.00 hrs starting at the main gate and we spent 1 1/2 hour in the cemetery . We then proceeded to visit other parts of Recoleta for 1 hour  4) With a private guide : we met a private guide at the entrance of the cemetery who offered his services for a 2 hours tour  Whatever way you will select , it will be quite interesting ! By the way , if it starts raining , umbrellas are sold in front for 50 pesos ($4) .

Get a Guide - Great Stories Lie Beneath the Tombs. My sister and I went here with a free walking tour that meets outside the cemetery (Bue Tours, in case you're interested). The guide pointed out so many interesting features, including the tombs of Irish and other European immigrants, along with tombs with eternal leases that had been abandoned. There is also one tomb of a girl who was reportedly buried alive. There's also Evita Perón, a controversial figure in Argentine history. If it hadn't been for out guide, I would have been clueless to all of the fascinating stories that surround this place.If you are not fond of ghost stories, the cemetery is still a beautiful place to visit, especially when the sun in out. Nearly all of the tombs are works of art. Many are decorated in Neo-classical style and adorned with symbols referring to time, death and afterlife. You can also spot the occasional modernist tomb with straight lines and plain marble. The diversity is fascinating.

Historical Cemetery. We rented a condo near the Recoleta Cemetery while in B.A. thus had the opportunity to visit this beautiful Cemetery 3 times, since there is no fee for the entrance.Beware that during the day it can become very hot.You might think it bizarre to visit a cemetery while on vacation, but you should not miss this one if you are in B.A. even for a short visit.My husband who HATES cemeteries, found it most fascinating. LOL

Before you go, see where others have gone to!!!!. It's a cemetery. Grandiose tombs of famous or wealthy Argentinians. Most tourists want to see the tomb of Eva Peron Duartes -Evita. She's there with many other Duartes, 5 M down but not forgotten. A much better appreciation of her life and achievements can be seen in Palermo, close to the Botanical Gardens at the Evita Museum. Worth a visit.

Fascinating stories and history!. This is a wonderful place if you like history and hearing about people's lives. Probably not too interesting for most kids. Perhaps a little macabre, but that's easy enough to shrug off as you listen to amazing and obscure details of historical figures. Definitely worth it!

must go when in BA. Prime real estate for the dead, beautiful, creepy and amazing.
Fascinating place to see many styles and architecture.
Just Go!!!. A must see attraction! It's in the dead centre of town, so you can't miss it. If you have never been to one of these amazing monumental type cemeteries, this is the one to go to.

The definition of the word Necropolis. This is truly a city of the dead. There are no tombstones here, nor any green lawns under canopy trees. This is a warren of "streets" each lined with tightly packed mausoleums. Some are centuries old while others are ultra modern. Some are well maintained, while others are falling apart. Some are simple, some are monumental. Styles range from Spanish baroque, to Augustan Roman, to van der Rohe modernism (One is, essentially, a pile of rocks). Somewhere, deep within this maze is the mausoleum of the Duarte family, in which lies the body of Eva Perron (Evita). There are no signs to take you there, so you will need a guide, good luck, or plenty of time and perseverence. Without a doubt, this is the most amazing cemetery that I have ever encountered.

A Must see. Strange and fascinating are understatements in describing this unusual cemetery . Monuments and mausoleums compete with each other for which is the grandest, has the most elaborate sculptures, or .most valuable marble. Spiritual it is not, grandiose it certainly is. Most people go to see the tomb of Eva Peron. Of course there is no such monument. You can find her in the monument that houses her brother's family under the Name Duarte.

Best place to visit could spend ages wandering. Went with friends as part of a tour but would recommend revisiting to spend time it is truly an am amazing place . It was free to visit while we were there but they may soon be charging entry free still worth seeing no matter what

Do yourself a favour and download the App by Endless Mile. We thoroughly enjoyed our visit to the Recoleta Cemetery thanks to the guide and information from the app we downloaded by Endless Mile. It provided a great route, explained the history of the vaults and their inhabitants and gave a good background in cemetery symbolism. What could have been just another stroll and a few happy snaps ended up being a highly interesting and most memorable experience. Do yourself the favour and pay the $3 for the app!http://endlessmile.com/project/recoleta-cemetery/

Best Cemetery I have seen. No doubt one of the best cemeterys in the world, and a beautiful attraction in Buenos Aires, the detail and tombs will leave you speechless. Marvels in Architecture and design this truly is a sight everyone who comes to Buenos Aires must see.

Facinating Cemetery Tour. Very interesting tour. Reminded us of New Orleans. But much bigger, fancier. The art work and sculptures are amazing. Spend time here. We were with a tour and wished we had more time. It is very beautiful. Some of the tombs have been abandoned and they show it. Very interesting history of Buenos Aries aristocracy there. Families have the tombs for eternity until the last family member dies. Never did find out how they know who is the last one. Eva Peron is but one of the many.This should definitely be on your list of things to see in Buenos Aries

Beautiful as cemeteries go. We went on the most beautiful sunny day. As cemeteries go it is a beautiful place. If you are looking for Eva Peron's burial site look on the directory for the Duarte Family Tomb. We were wandering around and asked a worker who showed us her family tomb. Such a wonderful woman who died so young. Very special place.

Very different. We have never been to a cemetery quite like this one before and found the whole place fascinating !! We tracked down Eva peron , it really is the most amazing place, and it is free to go in and the staff are very helpful with showing us the way to Eva !!!

Must do in Buenos Aires. Apart from all the Eva Peron hype this place is a must see. There are some amazing sculptures and art within the cemetery and the whole place is atmospheric. There are lots of tourists but many just come in to see Eva Perons grave and then leave so it is easy to get away from the crowds and spend time in other parts of the cemetery.

A must see!. The cemetery is a must see in Buenos Aries. Located in the heart of Recoleta it feels like a miniature city within the city. There is no fee to get in but be warned that people will try to sell you "tours" at the entrance for a fee. Eva Peron has a very unassuming burial site here and some of the family crypts are stunning.The squeamish may not want to visit on extremely hot days as we did since the air is quite ripe.

Shocking The Hamoton's of death people. Wow never expected to see such cemetery looks like a luxury neighborhood but all death. You will find from very famous people to wealthy ones. It's a must in Buenos Aires. Try to get a guide to tell you all kinds of stories and to guide you all the way to the very important and stunning mausoleums.

Bizarre, ornate in the extreme but oddly fascinating & FREE. Given this is a cemetery were you would have expected the mood to be sombre but there is more an air of morbid fascination as its wildly flamboyant & quite photogenic more befitting your average tourist attraction, its dificult to explain on here as you have to see the place to believe what you are looking at & absorb peoples curiosity, you will see that I mean when you go, the cemetery reminded me of a similar place in New Orleans in America that was also bizarre, but this place is in first place on the od front.The Recoleta Cemetery is right in the middle of a tourist market with live street entertainers some doing there own version of the Tango with various degrees of professionalism.Considering the main attraction if you will for coming here in the first place & endeavouring to discovering Eva Peron's plaque as she was cremated is more difficult that what you may consider.When you finally do find it, it is very underwhelming & you may think, oh is that it? as we did.However the other Hugh Morse alliums many in Italian marble are worth the trip. After one hour you have done it as there is limited interest in a goulash point of view.For me its a must do.Thoughts of the day:We are all G_Ds children.The people you meet on the way up are the same people you meet on the way back down.Time is short, try not to upset anybody.

Fascinating exposure to history and artistic expression. A stark contrast of various styles and wealth reflected in the practice of honoring the dead. This offered a great meditation for considering the history and bonds of families. Very elegant, multileveled tributes were side by side with the most humble offerings.

Most impressive. Even if Eve Duarte Peron was not interred here, the cemetery is well worth a visit to view the 18th-19th century mausoleums erected by the rich and famous families. Very peaceful if you avoid the multiple coach trippers mainly in the morning when a cruise ship is in port.

A TRANQUIL OBLIGATION. You are in Buenos Aires -it is a must tick the box visit to the burial place of Eva Peron - in her Durante family crypt. Easy to find as you follow the tourist guides taking their flocks to the crypt.Street after street of the rich & famous dead of the city are contained within the cemetery with a lot of marble used in a various designs.Some families must have fallen on hard times as some crypts are falling apart.Some very good photo ops because of the layout & the light. But in comparison with the Novodevichy cemetery in Moscow -Recoleta is understated & humble. If you ever have the chance to visit Moscow ,you have to go to the Novodevichy - Ego taken to another level & all under the communist system.
Amazing place. Breathtakingly beautiful. Cannot recommend enough to visit. Plus it is free! You could easily spend a few hours just wandering around.

Eva Peron is There But the Grounds are Pretty Run Down. This place has some interest, and a lot of history. Eva Peron is there in a very understated burial site.A lot of the original families have been lost to time and there are increasingly fewer people to maintain the sites. There is too much broken glass, broken doors, cracked facades, etc.We had a private guide which increased the interest somewhat, but I had trouble getting excited about this place. In a wonderful city like Buenos Aires there are better places to spend an hour or two.If this review is helpful then please indicate so below.

Interesting cemetery in the heart of Buenos Aires. Recoleta cemetery is an older cemetery where graves are located in family crypts instead of in the ground. It is seldom used since the family must own a crypt with space within it to be buried there. Family crypts are highly decorated and the cemetery is worth a visit. Eva Perón is buried in the Duarte - her maiden name - family crypt. A more interesting story is the reason why Eva Perón is not buried with her husband, Juan Domingo Perón.

María Eva Duarte de Perón's Burial Place. We visited the cemetery as we were interested in seeing the mausoleum of Eva Peron. We did not find it on the map because her name is María Eva Duarte de Perón. So you would have to look under Duarte to find it. The tour guide stated that the door always has flowers. She died at the age of 33 weighing 85 lbs. from uterine cancer. Actually I was surprised that her crypt was not the grandest. This is definitely a most see and there is no admission fee.

Interesting and worth the effort. We walked here and enjoyed the tour. I would recommend paying for a guide to tour. What you will learn is worth the cost and for us it's a long way to go to miss learning and enjoying all you can. While there be sure to walk next door to see the church. It is also interesting and has a lot of history to see and enjoy.

Best cemetery ever!. I love visiting cemeteries when I am in a new city to get a feel for the kinds of people who lived there and the Recoleta Cemetery is fantastic. The statuary is beautiful. Families for centuries are buried here and the individual tombs are relatively large and deep. You could peer into some of the older abandoned tombs and see the urns and coffins. Some vandalism has occurred unfortunately over the years which is evident from the broken glass, open coffins and missing contents!! Yikes! Not sure what happened in those cases. In other tombs where the family lineage appears to be continuing, the tombs have been upgraded and secured and are cared for. This cemetery appears to be for the advantaged in Buenos Aires, the heads of the military, government, lawyers and heads of large organizations. I wonder where the common people have been buried??
Ok - need to read Spanish!. Almost took tour for 100 pesos...all we saw was Evita's grave which was interesting but did not know anything else

Searching for Eva. It seemed a large percentage of the visitors to the cemetery had only Eva Peron on their search list, but it was surprisingly difficult to find her vault. There is a map near the entrance that gives the impression that if you know her number it should be easy, but it is not. Draw a sketch from the map. Ask someone who seems heading back to the entrance. A lady was standing about eight feet from the vault and asked where it is.You could say it is worth the trip, but what I found most interesting was to see what terrible condition many vaults were in. It seemed they were a collection of family-owned vaults, and if the family was not taking care of it, the condition was allowed to deteriorate.You need to go; then enjoy the park and go to La Biela to eat, drink, and watch the people.
Recoleta cemetery. This was a very interesting cemetery. I would suggest going with a guide or tour though so you can learn the history of the tombs. Also go early since they close around 5 pm
a must do. A most amazing place to see, the size, concept everything about the cemetery interestinga must do in buenos aires

A must see visit!!. Visited this cemetery on three different occasions, spending several hours each time. We have never seen any cemetery like this before.The crypts / tombs were incredible. The statues,unique doors and stained glass windows, carvings, historical significance, wealthy family monuments next to 'not so famous' monuments were unique. The history behind many of the tombs and people buried within the tombs (often several stories down) was fascinating. The first time we took a tour and the next two times we just wandered on our own. This is a must see. It is not gory by any means.

Best attraction in BA; fascinating; free. We spent hours wandering the "streets" in this city of the dead. The differing architectural styles of the various mausoleums is fascinating. Most of very well kept (each family is responsible for maintaining its own) but some are nearly crumbling with collapsing roofs. You can peek inside many and see the caskets (and in one case, actual bones!) and the flowers & photos of the deceased. We did not use a guide here. There is a map & cross reference at the entrance providing information on the families - including, of course, Eva Peron.Free admission. Fairly accessible because of flat surfaces but there are a few steps up to the main entrance (do not recall if there was a ramp).

Great if you like walking around graveyards!. Fascinating place that covers over 14 acres and has nearly 4700 different memorials I believe.The place is gridded and you can just walk up and down the lanes of mausoleums some of which are very grand and obviously cost a small fortune to buy and then rent the space.Evita's last resting place is understandably popular and nice to see some flowers pushed in through the doorway.A popular tourist spot you could probably spend a couple of hours here just walking up and down and across the different lanes.Very different from your average graveyard and definitely worth a visit.

Worth a visit. Its' known as the final resting place for Eva Peron, but even without that this is worth a visit. The design and architecture of the tombs/crypts is a reflection of the culture, the times and the wealth of the families.It it well cared for, although some of the older individual tombs/crypts have deteriorate. It is well worth the guided tour to learn the history of the cemetery. Although, it is a tourist attraction because of it's structures, it is an ongoing cemetery.

Best tourist attraction in Recoleta. We wandered in here with the intent to walk around, kill some time and leave. Instead, we stayed for over an hour just wandering and looking at the plots in various states of upkeep. We decided to come back a few days later because they gave free tours in English on Tuesday and Thursdays at 11.The tour was amazing. Our guide took us all around from people that one one knows to Evita. She also gave us a really good history lesson and explained everything we need to know about the most expensive real estate in Recoleta.They give tours in multiple languages, but you'd have to find out what day on your own.

Fascinating! A City for the Dead. We toured the cemetery with a tour guide from Walks of Buenos Aires. I highly recommend a tour of this fascinating cemetery instead of just wondering on your own. Carlos gave us all the back ground information of the cemetery and many of the stories of the people and families who are buried there. We just loved the history and artistry of the cemetery and Carlos told us the story of Eva Peron. To us it was just an amazing place to visit and spend some time. Outside of the cemetery was some artists selling their goods, it was fun to walk thru the vendors. Also at the beginning of the cemetery was a couple putting on a tango show under the huge tree. We highly recommend visiting here and spending some time learning of the individuals who are buried here.

Gorgeous but pick your time of visit. I love visiting grave yards. This is considered one of the 6 great in the world so obviously I had to see it. It's important you pick your time and day of visit carefully the place gets packed out during the day so go either really early or at dusk. Don't book a group tour, I saw people on them and they looked horrid ( I do have an aversion to being shoved into a group with people I don't know. Maybe it's me) instead find a local guide to show you round. Mine was an older gentleman who was fascinating and informed. He even took me down into a family vault which as something else ( and nice and cool to boot) visit, but don't do it the touristy way

Elegant Cemetery. This cemetery is very well kept and is easy to navigate. It is similar to European crypt type cemeteries and those you see in New Orleans. It has shaded area from old growth trees that are welcome on hot days. Eve Peron's crypt is in a small alley and smaller than what I expected. The cemetery is worth a visit when visiting the Recoleta District.

Think about what you are visiting!. This was the #1 attraction for Buenos Aires, so when we were there for 4 days, of course we had to see this. As an American, it was interesting from a cultural standpoint. It also made me learn a bit about Eva Peron (the biggest attraction) and the history of Argentina. However, from a tourist attraction standpoint I found it a bit depressing. Too many mausoleums that were not maintained. Too many feral cats living off the debris. The "take-away" from this visit was that cremation is a good thing! So much for burdening generations of your family with the maintenance of one's grave. Probably worth a visit, but I would not spend a great deal of time here. The market outside the cemetary with the individual vendors was much more uplifting!

Very interesting and worth a few hours of your time. Certainly an interesting walk looking at the opulent grave sites. Not quite as artistic as Pere LaChaise cemetery In Paris but not to be missed if you are in buenos aires and have a day or 2 to wander the city.

Visiting dead people.. We visited the Eva Peron museum and decided that it would be a good idea to find her grave. By the time we got there my feet were aching and the sun was very hot. I sat down on the bench and told my brother to go and find her burial chamber and report back to me as to its whereabouts. Luckily a German couple passed and we were able to glance at their comprehensive map of the cemetery and found the location of her last resting place. The gravestones were very impressive, we should have asked for a tour but we were exhausted. I don't usually visit cemeteries on holiday, they depress the socks off me and this one did just that, I was pleased to get out amongst the living. We met some students whilst we were there and we asked them if they had found Eva's grave and they said "who is she" and I sang "Don't cry for me Argentina" They told us that they had never heard of her. I asked who was it they had come to research or find, apparently they had just gone in to wander around and enjoy the structures.

Recoleta Cemetery. This seems like a sort of odd place to visit but it can be a fascinating walk on an afternoon. The statuary and architecture on the crypts make the event more like an outdoor art display. It is a quiet place to contemplate while surrounded by thousands who have gone on beyond.

City of the Dead. Its massive, clean and packed with visitors...its well worth a visit...try and catch the free daily tour guide. The cost of being buried there is more than the cost of lkiving in an apartment !

Very unique site. I have to say, touring a cemetery was never at the top of my list, until I visited BA. The massive mausoleums are truly impressive, and the stories that go with some many of them is really fascinating. This was my favorite tourist spot in Buenos Aires.
Interesting. Interesting.....Evita's grave disappointing ....a different experience....art market near bye is good.....

Well worth visiting. As an attraction this is well worth visiting. We wandered through without any tour, but I am sure the tour would be more informative. The cemetery is set amongst parks with some nice restaurants close by. There was also two people doing the tango in the park. If you are there on a weekend there is a market with lots of stalls.A great place to spend a few hours.

Beautiful, clean and fascinating. I was very impressed with the Recoleta Cementery from the moment I saw it. I did not arrive in time for the free daily English tour but was able to join a group. Adriana is a Govt certified guide and charged 100 pesos per person. She spoke clearly and provided some great history of the Cementery. I think the tour was approx 30 minutes which was enough time to learn the basic "streets" so as not to get lost.I did see a number of organized tours groups and a few non-govt approved guides. I went on a Thursday afternoon and it wasn't very busy at all.

A strange place to walk around. For me it was difficult to understand why a cemetery would be a touristic place. Even though there are some interesting art peaces, I fail to see why the place was that famous. Maybe if I had visited with a guide, I would see it differently, knowing the history behind the tombs.

Strangely Intriguing. Read that this was a worthwhile visit and would definitely agree - may seem a little strange to see a cemetery as a tourist attraction but it is certainly that. Visited on a Sunday and chose to do our own thing rather than use a guide but there is that option. A real labyrinth but some of the crypts/tombs are simpling stunning and would really recommend it if you're in BA and want to pass the time outdoors (and who wouldn't with the weather they have!).Also, if you have the option then a Sunday visit is good as there is a large market right outside which itself is also well worth a visit!

Well worth visiting. We visited here on our own and with no tour. The cemetary is easy to get to and fascinating to spend a couple of hours to walk around. Also ensure you visit the church while there, as both are well worth taking out time to visit.

"Must See" in Buenos Aires... uniquely Argentinean.. Went here with friends in February 2015 and this was on everyone's list to visit. We wandered through the cemetery, which contains several thousand vaults where wealthy Portenos are interred. The cemetery is set up in a very organized fashion and it's easy to navigate it's "streets" to find particular folks you may want to visit. (Evita Peron? She's easy to find; just follow the crowd.)The vaults are all so interesting in their uniqueness and the variety of architecture is amazing. I found the state of disrepair of some of the vaults interesting and wonder why some of them have come to be in that condition. (Families ran out of money? No one left to maintain them?) All interesting things to ponder as you wonder through. It's a nice day trip and outside the cemetery there are some nice little vendors selling various crafts and what not. Definitely worth a visit when in the beautiful south American city.
Beautiful. A very beautiful cemetery full of history and beautiful walking paths. You can spend one or two hours there and of coarse you will see burial siteEva Peron.

Don't Miss This!. Come prepared to spend some time exploring this incredibly beautiful spot. Around each corner you will find an AHA moment. So many interesting monuments and amazing sculptures honoring the dead. Vertical tombs dedicated to the wealthiest and most famous are statements from an era gone by. Grab a guide if you wish and please be mindful of where you are in relation to the exit as it is a huge maze. Please be sure to check out the famous cats that walk amongst the dead and enjoy the beautiful views of plaza francais with a nice glass of malbec after your time there at La Biela.

smaller than I thought. Its quite small, and very crowded when a tour guide brings in a group. You can do it alone and see the Peron crypt and listen to the others tour guides.........worth seeing. good Starbucks about 1/2 block away.

Visit to Recoleta Cemetary. My wife and I visited Recoleta Cemetary in Dec. of 2014. We thoroughly enjoyed this Buenos Aires attraction. The cemetery was amazing in the fact that the very very rich families would spend millions of dollars to bury their family in these very elaborate mausoleums. The mausoleum of Eva Peron was the most popular and the most photographed. This attraction is truly amazing and should not be missed. The Recoleta area is a beautiful area in Buenos Aires.

A trip to the past. Beautiful if you like Cemeteries, very smart, plenty of famous people...It is very nice area to walk around before or after the cemetery. Recoleta parks, museo de Bellas Artes, the old little church in recoleta, etc

A bit eerie but truly worth doing. Well you really need to prepare yourself for the unworldly experience here.Lots to absorb and wonder about.Much larger and grander than any other cemetery I have seen.Can be a bit chilly if wind blowing but it adds to the experience.

Do not miss the most famous, most opulent cemetery in the world.. I have been to BA four times - I have been to this cemetery three times - it is a fascinating adventure into the posthumous excesses of Argentina's former leading citizens. This is the most densely populated portion of BA, and I say that as a serious and as an amusing statement - is a site not to miss. Breathtaking!

Will take longer than you plan. Do not go there thinking you will see it all. You really can't unless you have a great deal of time. Around every corner, and there are lots of them, is a new row to discover and study. A guide would be very helpful but if looking for an English speaking guide listen to them before committing. Some of those we overheard would be hard to understand. The "must" is of course Evita. Read about her first and it will ad more to the visit. Marvel at what has been done to honor the dead. Be amused by the sea of vendors in the park area in front.
Touristy but worth the visit. Get there early to avoid the bus tour crowds. If not possible to do so, just relax and go with the flow. No entry fee.

eva peron. The cemetery is very interesting and peaceful. Its amazing how many people visit the vault of Eva Perons family. Try and get there before the cruise ships, morning is better otherwise you will have to queue for ages.

Dreamy Cemetary to wander around. This is a interesting place to visit while in Buenos Aires. It is probably worth either getting the tour. I didn't do it, but overheard a couple of guides and there are some interesting stories about the mausoleums. There is a park next door with crafts on the weekends and holidays and green space for the kids to run around.

Phenominal. This is one one of the most amazing places I've ever visited. Beautiful, enchanting, macabre, mystical and amazing. I roamed around for 2 hours. At 9am, it started getting busy with tours, so I suggest an early arrival (they open at 7am). I'd like to return for a guided tour to learn even more. But wandering around on your own should high on the list as well.

An interesting and worthwhile 1hour stroll. This interesting cemetery, on a very grand scale, is very centrally located and an easy walk from the attractive avenues of the Recoleta district. No entrace fee, an enjoyable and peaceful place to stroll around. I believe you can get a guide but I was happy to walk around myself. I found an hour was adequate.

Not macabre at all, strangely. Our chief reason for going was that one of our party wanted to see where Eva Peron is buried - one cannot find her in the map at the entrance, unless you know that her family name was Duarte. A couple of visitors had placed flowers at her tomb - which is no more spectacular than any other in this cemetery. What is amazing is the number of statues of angels - and the fact that here the dead are given "homes" that are better than those enjoyed by many who live in Rio. I didn't find the place at all macabre, in spite of being able to see so many of the coffins through gates and windows. An interesting 30 minutes is about all one should expect.

Historical and quite beautiful. Before traveling to Argentina I knew nothing about the Recoleta cemetery. I was in Buenos Aires on business and had some free time so we walked around the city and over to the cemetery. It's quite impressive as its all mosoleums. I highly recommend it & while there...check out Evita Peron's as well.

Top attraction in Buenos Aires!. The Recoleta Cemetery is amazing. The cost is free and you can spend hours in the cemetery or I recommend about no more than 2 hours. The Family headstones are amazing and there is always a local willing to give you a tour of the cemetery for a donation. That the tour it is worth knowing what you are looking at. This is an absolutely visit when you are in BA. Do this before or after the Recoleta market on Saturday.

Equal to a 3 star michelin restaurant in cemeteries. This is one of the great cemeteries of the world. It ranks right up there with Pere Lachaise in Paris and the cemeteries in New Orleans. The architecture of the tombs is extraordinary in its complexity, diversity and beauty. If you have only one place to visit in Buenos Aires, this would be my recommendation.

A very different cemetery.. Well worth a slow stroll around the maze of mini buildings and crypts. its an eerie surreal experience that makes you realize what Buenos Aires society values. Plenty of bars and restaurants nearby to relax in afterwards.

Excellent for a sense of history and architecture. Recoleta Cemetery is a large collection of private mausoleums. Some are immaculate; others in various states of disrepair and decay. As it was explained to me, this is because the families that own them are responsible to pay for their upkeep in perpetuity - and that doesn't always happen. Sometimes, there is no family member left to pay; sometimes they can't pay; sometimes they choose not to pay. Whatever the reason, if there is no payment, there is no upkeep, and that is why some of them look as they do. Like any cemetery, just walking through reviewing the birth and death dates of those interred gives one a sense of history; unlike most cemeteries, however, the immensity of these structures gives one a sense of the architectural styles popular at the various times encompassed by the mausoleums.As others have mentioned, there are cats - lots of cats - roaming the grounds. One in particular took a liking to us. He was skin and bones and looked as if he'd been injured, and we assumed there must be quite a competition for food. But then we learned that there is a group of ladies who comes every day to the cemetery to give food and water to the cats. They encourage their presence in the cemetery to ward off rats.You could spend an hour here, or you could easily spend a day - admiring the architecture, appreciating the history, and petting the cats. If you choose to spend a longer time, there are plenty of restaurants and coffee shops within easy walking distance when you need a break. Whether you come for a short or a long visit, you should definitely come.

Beautiful place - and free. Enjoyable and moving. For Eva Perron (Evita) you will need to know her family name Duarte. There's a map on entry - ask where it is! Get there by 5:30 when entry closes. Out by 6:00. Adding photo showing location of her site

Worth a visit - really cool. It is kind of weird that a cemetery is such a big attraction, but it really cool. It is like walking around a mini-city with tons of different types of architecture. We really enjoyed the stroll through and the stories our private guide told us about many of the families.

A must on a visit to Buenos Aires. Plan on spending an hour or two in this cemetery filled with mausoleums but be sure to get a guide to get the best value of your visit. There are many important Argentinians here and wonderful works of art. be sure to visit the Duarte family mausoleum that has the remains of Eva Peron. avoid the bathrooms here as not only is there an entrance fee but they are filthy.

beautiful and peaceful. Recoleta cemetery is beautiful and peaceful. Crowds can be a problem around Eva Perons family crypt but it is so large there is plenty to see. Don't bother buying a map of the cemetery as it's great to just wander around. Some of the crypts are quite run down and others you can see deep inside to the coffins.

Well if you like cemeteries this is a big one.. Amazing difficult to find Evita's burial site here bearing in mind, most people come here dpecifically to see it. Must have been asked if we knew where it was 10 times in 25 minutes. Incredibly ornate and big buildings for dead bodies. Quite incredible how much money people spend on their graves. Cemeteries are not my thing but if you find this kind of stuff interesting then it's worth a visit. It's free as well! Cafes outside seem nice.

Curiously Captivating!. I found this place incredibly interesting. To see how such a religious country 'treat' their dead was almost comforting. The place is very busy with tourists who, quite rightly, showed a great deal of respect. This is, after all, a cemetery. There are a lot of cats in this area - mostly sleeping in the warm sun, but I suspect that they are tolerated in order to keep rats away. The tombs range from dilapidated (broken coffins make you want to look although nothing sinister is visible) to grand opulent structures. Some are built in grand fancy style and others in a more modern minimalist style. The craftsmanship is incredible. Definitely worth a visit and don't forget to check out the grave of Eva Peron.

Beautiful on a sunny afternoon. On a sunny day this is a great place to visit. The central area is full of impressive tombs with closely packed rows of lesser tombs around the edge. There is only one entrance and be prepared to walk quite a way round the edge to find it. Admission is free, but check carefully before you go in where the Eva Duarte (Evita) family tomb is as it is difficult to find. I also think it is worth googling the web about what happened to Evita's body, before it finally was laid to rest in the family tomb. The story is fantastic. Evita died from cancer in 1952 aged only 33. She received a state funeral and her embalmed body was displayed in the main trade union body building in Buenos Aires. After Juan Peron was overthrown the body disappeared for 16 years. In 1971, the military junta announced that her body had been reburied in Milan. That year she was exhumed and flown to Spain where Juan Peron maintained her corpse in his dining room. In 1973 Juan Peron returned to Argentina with his third wife, Isabel. He died in 1974 and Isabel Peron became president. She arranged for Evita's body to be returned to Argentina,, where for a short time it was displayed beside the corpse of Juan Peron before finally being buried in the Recoleta cemetery where it remains.
Interesting. A lovely walk with the dead. And interesting mix of well groomed tombs and ones that look as if highschool kids had been partying there.

Must see this unique place! . This place is fascinating! There are just so many graves to see. One regret is that we did a self-guided tour and didn't learn much about who was buried here except for eavesdropping on a few tours. Definitely do a guided tour.
.... Nice and peaceful place at the center of the Recoleta.Different kind of sn experience to go to a cemetery.The dead can't hear us.

Fabulous Fascinating City of The Dead. This nearly 200 year old cemetery in the heart of Buenos Aires is a must see. The architecture, the sense of solemn ceremony, the attention to great moments and vast accomplishment is provocative and touching. Spend time, don't rush, gaze and reflect on the ravages of time, the tenuousness of life and the fleeting sense of remembrance.

Intresting cementery. built by the monjes recoletos in 1700, has a lot of history. tombs of millonaires , traditional families built extravagant tombs, also in eva peron tomb, many other important people who built the history of Argentina. , located at the REcoleta, then after you visit the cementery have an incredible ice cream across the square Volta!! the best ice cream parlor in Buenos Aires.

So unusual- you should experience.. We didn't wait for an english tour and maybe missed out on some of the history. That being said, it was so interesting to walk around the perimeter and down many of the aisles to experience the family burial history. Very nice way to memorialize the family.

A Study in Life and Death. This is must see in BA. The cemetary is monument to life, wealth and abandonment. Tombs are beautifully built and highlight the money a family amassed. Extravagent sculptures stand next to abandoned/forgotten tombs. This is more than the final resting place of Eva Peron. Many of the founders of BA and political leaders are here. (Juan Peron is not here) Get a guide to walk you through. There's too much to see and stories of the 'residents' that you'd never get. We were happy to have the info since we never saw a map.

This alone is worth a trip to Buneos Aires. The Ricoleta Cemetary is absolutely fabolous. I strongly recomment going with a knowledgeable guide who knows all the stories (We used Buenos Aires Walking Tours, see separate review)we were really entertained with the various stories about the famous and infamous people buried here. How often can you say that you are entertained in a Cemetary? Evita's tomb is the most visited and most famous - but there are MANY others.The architecture and artwork am astonding! Very worth while.

You dont see places like this very often. Great to stroll round- strangelymacabree and very very photogenic. You can also visit Eva Perons burial tomb, but the place is much more than just that. easily spent 2 hours there.loads of eateries over the road and quick metro anywhere else in Buenos Aires.Go in the late afternoon when the sunlight gives great shades and colours.
EVA PERON. Amazing to see what families will spend on their departed loved ones. Of course we had to visit Eva Duarte's final resting place which is the local tourist attraction!

Interesting piece of history. We visited this cemetery as part of a city tour of Buenos Aires. It was very interesting to see all the different family mausoleum with Eva Duarte Peron being the most popular. The cemetery is very well cared for but you could get lost as it is huge and like a maze. FYI: if you're a woman & want to use the restroom take a tissue with you or be prepared to pay to pay for TP!

Much more than Evita's grave. We went with a guide and spent two hours in the rain because we were so interested in seeing the various styles of huge family mausoleums, as well as hearing the stories of some of the old families of Beunos Aries. Because of the rain, the cemetery was very quiet, only one other group of three. Go eat kier in the day to avoid the tour buses that stop.Eva Peron is buried here in her brother's vault. The story of what happened to her body after her death is quite lengthy. The mausoleum with the white angels near hers has quite a story with the young woman apparently buried alive. The cemetery is very old, from the 1700's, and very well maintained.Notice the numerous cats. We saw some huddling from the rain inside the grave gates. You can actually see some of the caskets in the floors if you look closely.There is a small chapel at the entrance. There are restrooms around the back. I went to use them and found two men sitting n th entrance holding toilet paper..the only tp available. Very tacky in a cemetery and also disconcerting to have a man sitting where he can watch you in the mirror. I would have preferred a py toilet to this!

More Impressive than New Orleans. This is a must see on any BA visit. The Elaborate mausoleums in a park-like setting is awe-inspiring. Although Evita Duarte's tomb generally has a crowd and it is hard to take a photo with people constantly walking in front of you, there are plenty of other spots sights to observe and there are many interesting background stories associated. We saw the cemetary once on our own then later with the free walking tour. The walking tour guide, Adam, made the second time through much more fulfilling with his knowledge of the history and intrigue associated with the people entombed there.

"Lasting Tributes". "No one ever dies unless he/she is forgotten!" We went to see Evita Peron's grave as part of our excursion but was surprised by the unique white mausoleums! It does not feel like walking in a cemetery because the statues and incriptions reflect individual tributes of who they were ! Evita's grave is in the Duarte mausoleum marked by her name and her iconic profile. Tourists congregated in front taking pictures. I took a video to show my friend I went to her idol's grave. It is a must to visit especially for those who admire her for what she had done for the Argentines.

A must see when in Buenos Aries. The village of dead has so many stories and amazing monuments. It is a must see. The cemetery was built in 1732 on 14 acres around a convent and a church, Our Lady of Pilar (Iglesia de Nuestra Señora del Pilar).
What an amazing array of statues and stone and stories
Most amazing cemetery I have ever visited.. If you wish to visit a rather different attraction, try here. This is incredible with tombs the size of small dwellings.

Opulence in death. the burial site of the elite of then.
Interesting, macabre, fun and a must see.
Download the recoleta cem app, great way to navigate through on your own in an hour.

Unique, above ground tombs. Yes, there are still a very, very few spaces available. Tombs in all different shapes and sizes. Different architectural styles. Most were in very good condition but a few were run down. It's just interesting to randomly walk thru to see them. The avenues are not really marked but other than finding Evita's tomb - basically check the general location on the map when you first come in and then closer in, look for the gathering of people in front of it - where you walk reall doesn't matter. No charge to get in.
peaceful place to visit. and get some mental rest from the busy city. so many beautiful tombs, one could certainly walk around for a whole day. bring water in hot weather!

Amazing. Until coming to Recoleta cemetary I'd never seen a cemetary like this. Some of the tombs are like little temples and come in all shapes, forms and styles, like Greek temples, colonial houses, with statues and very elaborate. It's really interesting to see. It's also nice that it's not a dark place like I know cemetaries in Europe. It's more like a stroll in a beautiful park.

Very unique. When my aunt first told me we were going to visit a cemetery, I got slightly freaked out. Little did I know that it was one of the more interesting experiences I had while travelling. Getting to the place was very convenient by bus and a short walk with clearly marked sign led us straight to the gates of the cemetery. It did not looked like a cemetery at all, but never the less, it did feel like it. It felt that I was passing through time learning about some of the lives of the people buried there. It did not felt eerie at all and it certainly made me very calm and at peace. I did not travel with a guide, but through self- exploration of the place, it was quite interesting to see a lot of the story through looking at various architectural forms and themed sculptures. The most memorable experience was when I tracked down Eva Peron's family crypt and stood in a minute of silence to honour them. I returned feeling quite inspired.
Interesting place. The family crypts are impressive and it is clear that this cemetery is for very rich dead people...It worth to take a guide in order to understand the stories behind the graves

So unusual and beautiful. I had not looked at photos before visiting and did not know what to expect, but this is as delightful as a cemetery can be! Plus the cats are the icing on the cake. The map sold at the entrance for a few dollars is helpful for locating the most noteworthy mausoleums, but it doesn't have much more information on it beyond the map. My only other advice is to time your visit, if in the summer, sometime in the morning or evening when there will be some shade. Otherwise it's very warm under the direct sun in here!

Quietly dignifed. Coming from Australia, this cemetery is like nothing we have seen before. The large family crypts come in all shapes and sizes, but they generally tower above you as you walk down the avenues between them.You can see inside many of them, with multiple caskets stacked on each other, and small tributes such as photos and flowers inside.The cemetery is in a busy tourist area, but it was still fairly quiet inside and great to roam around.

Better to visit with a guide. I did this as part of a walking tour so I think I got more out of it than just roaming on my own. When you know the stories behind the people buried there it is very interesting. The opulence and upkeep of some are a vast contrast to the unmanaged decaying ones, which in their time would have been beautiful too. A reminder of the current Argentine crisis and lack of money some familes have.

CEMETERY OLD STYLE - SOME GRAND - SOME DERELICT. This is a very old Cemetery with some magnificent Crypt's however some in poor "derelict" condition, due to age and abandonment. This is worth a visit is surrounded by high Wall Structure taking up whole block and bordering on parkland. Do not think it is a place for young children. Caskets and Coffins visible in some Crypts.

Highlight of BA. As mentioned in most BA travel guides, this is a must see. We did this with a guide however if you do this on your own - there are people giving out "free" maps at the entrance but will then ask for donations from you for some charity. Don't get suckered into doing this as we saw other tourists do so. Anyways - the cemetery itself was pretty cool to see..it's possible to do this on your own but you may want to research some information on where the highlights are and the history behind it first to get a fuller experience.
Don't cry for me Argentina. Recoleta is the hip part of BA and this eerie stop is well worth it. Most known for Evita's final resting place

Get a guide! Its huge!!. Absolutely astounding how much money people spent on these graves. Some are truly spectacular. It's a beautiful place. Visit Evita's grave site which is quite understated. We had a lovely english-speaking guide who gave us quite a bit of local history. Well-worth the visit.

Intriguing. Impressive burial site for many reasons, not the slightest being the mausoleum of Eva Peron. The individual family tombs were very interesting and the mix of new structures amidst the centuries old monuments was a great contrast. I would rate it as a definite must see on your first visit to Buenos Aires.
Enjoyed this. We took our tour group to the cemetary. It was very different than what we have at home. The mausoleums were amazing, I enjoyed seeing the Duarte Families area.

great on its own, but so much better with a guide!. I'm not normally a tour kind of girl but I definitely was grateful for doing a guided tour through the cemetery. Our fantastic guide made so many tombs, statues and stories come to life. Just a stroll through the cemetery would have been nice but no way would I have appreciated it nearly as much.

CEMETERY AS A TOURIST ATTRACTION, REALLY?. We got off the City Tour Bus when we saw some of our co-passengers getting off at this Bus Stop - the Recoleto Cemetery. The Entrance is grand, the flowers in the Garden are blooming, and the white church near by is inviting us. (See attached pictures).We, visitors had the same question - where is the tomb of Eva Peron? The Duarte Family Mausoleum looks very ordinary, but I guess the person buried in it is a SPECIAL one so visitors were flocking to her tomb. The other tombs are fancier and more beautiful, with big statutes of angels and other ornate decorations. Be sure to visit the white church located on the way to the entrance of the Cemetery. It is called, Senora del Pilar Church. Admire the Gardens and the Statute carrying the branches of the big tree near the Cemetery.

Great historical site-a must see. This is a great way to see so much of the past history of Buenos Aires. Some of the most influential members of society our laid to rest here.It was sad to see how much repair work needs to be done on so many of the staues and structures

Interesting. entry to the cemetery is free and immediately you can see & sense just how impressive the site is and how big it is. You can easily get lost so one way to avoid this is by getting a guided tour. The Eva Peron grave is popular so be patient when wanting to take pictures and keep a look out for the warning signs of stagnant water and avoid it - you don't want to get bitten by mosquitoes. Well worth a quick trip even if it's not your cup of tea.

Recoleta Cemetery. This was the last place that we visited on the day in Buenos Aires. We were so tired after walking all day, but we still want to take a look of this famous cemetery. Lots of tourists like us went there. Many splendid mausoleums and statues - worth the time to take a look. Don’t just go to see the tomb of Eva Peron (Evita).There is a map at the entance to show where the famous people buried.Happy Travelling!
A must visit. There's so much extravagance in this cemetery, it's worth visiting because there are so many beautiful and unique mausoleums.

Great place to visit when you are alive. Went to the cemetery on our own. Free to get in, and there is a free guided tour for tips only. This is my third time there and I enjoyed spending time and not feeling rushed. There are so many different crypts. Some are very old and in terrible shape. Some are enormous, probably for important people. It is fun to look inside and see how different there are. Do not miss the girl with the dog. Rubbing his nose brings good luck. Eva Peron is a must.
Bring a map. Wonderful place to explore on your own. Amazing to see the tombs of all materials and sizes! Get a map if you should visit here or hire a free tour guide at the entrance.

Visit to Evita's grave. Part of half day city tour interesting that included other landmarks in the city. Must see as part of Argentinas history. Fascinating and informative . Visit statue & cafe Evita all within 1/2 mile of cemetery.

A museum in a cemetary. This is more than a cemetary. The monuments and mausoleums were amazing. We had a private tour with Anila from designer trips. She was great showed us many of the tombs and explained many of the stories

Interested in history and architecture don't miss it. We bought the online guide for the cemetery recommended in lonely planet. We used it to guide our journey through the cemetery. The combination works as you learn about Argentinian history and the tombs - definitely better than wandering around without a guide

Where the rich go to die. Save some time when you look for Evita's grave she is buried in the Duarte family mausoleum. Or watch the tour guides and they will lead you to it. It is on a side row and is the only site with a crowd.

Weird wonderful and moving. Visiting a cemetery is not usually high on the tourists itinerary, but do not miss out on a visit to Recoleta - a weird and wonderful city of the dead close to the centre of Buenos Aires. It is impossible to describe the atmosphere produced by the gigantic family mausoleums, with a network of narrow passages connecting them all together, surrounded by walls to keep out the living. Go!

Quite eerie, to be expected.. This seems to be a popular tourist spot, oddly bizarre with tour guides, maps and buses descending on the place. Not like the cemetery in Paris. Smaller and more compact. Mausoleums show actual coffins and if you follow a tour you get some insight. Eva's grave/ mausoleum slightly disappointing, wouldn't have found it without following a tour!

A must see, An above ground city of the dead. The Recoleta Cemetery is in a neighbourhood of Buenos Airies. The graves are all above ground and you can view the different architectural styles and look into current and abandoned crypts. If you are patient and look around carefully you can find the family plot of Eva Peron but it is not clearly signposted. A must see on your visit to BA and very interesting.For a full video featuring footage of hotels, restaurants, and other tourist traps see other postings on Tripadvisor or see our trip to South America @roscoand mikey on twitteror go to youtube and search for Rosco and Mikey, go to Anamorphica Productions logo click and subscribe

Interesting but not that much. The graves are very interesting (specially Evita Peron). Stories involving this place are also nice. Visiting a cemetery for leisure purposes is somehow creepy, but this one really deserves it.

A little bit of history in a peacefully relaxing walk.. And very informative and relaxing walk to see a little bit of history. Our guide did a great job of explaining just enough to peak our interest, yet not lose use with too much boring detail. Definitely hire a guide its worth it.

Old and Impressive. The large number of famiiy resting places, the different architectural styles and abundant symbols of Freemasonry make for a most interesting visit, The only more interesting Cemetery I have seen is the one in Genoa, Italy. Very well worth a visit. Often, on weekends, there are guided tours in Spanish and in English, Inquire there . A don't miss sight in Buenos ASires

Very Historic and tells the BA story. Do not go without a guide as you will miss the significance of the area. Politicians, war heros, Evita, and others are all here with outstanding stories to be told. Magnificent tombs.
A must see. Tip: If you want to see Eva Peron's resting place, do your homework before you go. There are no signs to help you.

There's an iphone app for your phone for a tour. Very interesting stories and stroll around here. Download the iphone app for 99 cents for a tour you can read about. The cafes can be expensive with snooty waiters who don't want to acknowledge your presence, so try the ones off to the side a bit for better price and service. Alvear Hotel is also right around the corner for fancy luxury lovers and champagne drinks in a cool bar.
A must see. Evita Perron rests here and many rich people, the park open's at 7:00 am and closes at 5:00 pm go in the morning if you visit during January it gets very hot and humid in the afternoon.

Recoleta Cemetery. Bizarre as it might seem, Recoleta Cemetery seems to be the major tourist attraction of Buenos Aires. Surrounded by a high stone wall, the cemetery is jammed with various size mausolea owned by the rich and famous of Argentina and used for internments of family members. The structures vary in size and design and can be bought and sold like any other plot of real estate. The most famous "resident" is Eva Peron, so her small tomb attracts a lot of visitors that jam the small alley. The place is worth a short visit of one hour or less, unless one has a good knowledge and interest in local history and politics. It does not compare with the more interesting cemeteries in Paris, Prague or Los Angeles. Bring water, a hat and a tongue in cheek attitude.

Take your time. Buenos Aires is more than interesting. If you need a quiet time but want to have also more impressions go to this place and enjoy both - the quietness and a different world. Even if you have not so much time in Bs Aires: this is a must. There are only a few cementeries in the world with such a radiance (I read and believe).
The definite place to understand Argentina. It's much more than a exquisite cemitery, it's the huge memorial for an ancient era which still reverbarates in Argentina, in politics, society, living.

Worth doing the guided tour.... It's worth timing your visit to catch a free official tour if you can. From memory i think the English tours are 11am tues or thurs. They are free so there was heaps of people so it could be hard to hear the guide. But definitely worth it... you can ask questions and you definitely get more insight that you can get with just the map.

Lovely place to meander for an hour or two. We so enjoyed the Recoleta Cemetery, though we arrived too late in the afternoon to enjoy the official tour. Instead we wandered around, feeling as though we were entering the lives of families as observers of their choices of architecture, materials (marble, glass, stone, bronze), the size of th mausoleums and how they are maintained. I particularly enjoyed taking photos of the angels throughout the cemetery who adorn the tops of so many little family resting places...people of all religions and political persuasions (though all wealthy people) rest here in fascinating rows of history....afterwards, as it was Sunday, we enjoyed the crafts fair and music on the lawns and pathways in front of the cemetery...well worth the trip, to see Evita;'s final resting place or otherwise.

A look at how rich families honour their loved ones. I'm not Catholic, so I don't know a lot about the culture of burial, but this is the first time I've seen such elaborate tombs and mausoleums all in one place. Below ground, above ground, exposed coffins large and small. Architecture buffs will probably enjoy the designs on display. This of course is the place to see the final resting place of Evita. I didn't take a guided tour but I overheard one explaining the history surrounding her body, and I suspect a tour wil be well worth it to hear about the other famous personages buried here.
Strangeness & Beauty. You could spend a couple day looking at all the various tombs here. It is amazing the resources that some of these folks had to erect there monuments (to themselves).

A must see in Buenos Aires. A walk around this cemetery is certainly interesting. We purchased a map (15 pesos) and walked around without a guide. The mausoleums are incredible. To think that some families have spent so much on these. Some are like small chapels. It is well worth a visit. You also see Eva Perons burial site. Also visit the church next door to the cemetery.
May seem weird but worth a trip. The baroque and highly styled mausoleums of the Recoleta Cemetery are a unique window on Buenos Aires rich and famous families. Well worth the trip!

Gloriously Spooky!. Beautiful and next worldly, go to the beyond and enjoy the past glory of the respect for the past loved ones. Sad that some families don't keep up the tombs? Got to wonder what happened??? The connected church is nice go in the extra rooms for a small donation.

Just amazing. This is an incredible way to spend some time browsing through the various mausoleums and learning about some of the history. We did it with a guide the first day but went back to just meander through the aisles of history and families.

Interesting and worth visiting.. We had a couple of hours to spare during our visit to Buenos Aires so we decided to check out the Recoleta cemetery. There is no entrance fee. As we entered through the main gate, a guide approached us asking if she could take us around for a small fee and we agreed since we knew nothing about the place. For about 45 minutes she walked us around and told us fascinating stories of the different families that owned the tombs, how the plots are purchased and managed and the history of the place and how it related to Argentine culture. The memorials are dramatic and beautiful and I would definitely recommend a guide to help you get the most out of the visit.

The cemetary is an interesting profile of Buenos Aires history.. The cemetary is filled with many family memorials consisting of monuments and small chapel like mausolums. worth spending some time here to learn another view of Buenos Aires history.

Worth a stop on your BA sight-seeing itinerary!. We spent a couple of hours exploring the cemetery on our own (no guide). It was worth a visit for sure. Make a stop just inside the entrance to check the map for Eva Peron's tomb location as you will want to see that even though it is far from the most impressive. There are numerous rich and famous Argentines buried in the cemetery. Many tombs are quite elaborate. There are resident cats stretched out in the sunshine here and there, reportedly fed regularly by cat-lovers who visit daily.

Fascinating and beautiful. This was my favorite part of Buenos Aires. I was originally planning on just wandering around, but as we were standing just inside, a guide passed by and asked if we wanted to join a tour. Sure, why not. Definitely do a tour. Hearing the stories around some of the more unusual monuments was fascinating.

Eva Peron Duarte #88. Make sure you check out the cemetery map to the left as you enter the hallway connected to the cemetery. You can find Evita's site under the Duarte name. The black granite site is very simple and located down a side alley. The other grave markers in the cemetery are awesome miniature carved structures many in white marble.

Strange experience. You cannot visit BA without beeing on this strange cementary. A city of huge tombs within the city, you'll never find another place like this on earth. I strongly recommend to walk around this fascinating place with a guide cause the dead don't talk. And there is a lot to tell, believe me. Not only the relatively small grave of Evita. You'll be surprised what some guides have to tell you about the younger history of Argentina. Maybe you have to change your mind after the visit.

A Place for All to Remember. If there is one cemetery to visit as a tourist, this is the one. This is a grand visit to see how the rich and famous remembered their dearly departed. Yes Eva Peron is buried here, but there are so many more sites to see as well. A good visit to see a time gone by.

Very Interesting Tour. We visited this cemetery as a part of a city tour. It was nice to have a guide with us to identify some of the highlights of the cemetery. Quite a fascinating place, with many notable Argentine families represented. We had never seen anything like it. After the tour, it was nice to just be able to walk around and take in the splendor of the place.
