Interesting to see how some of the crypts were in pristine condition while many are no longer attended to. Fascinating place to spend some time.

fascinating way to feel the history of BA. the cemetery, which was right across from our hotel Loi Suites, is a fascinating way to learn the history of the people of BA. we didn't have any of the crowd issues other people mention. of course the star attraction is Eva Peron's resting place. don't be confused the tomb is under her family name Duarte. in any event this a must to wander on your own through the maze of intricate mausoleums.

Well Worth It. We visited on a rainy afternoon, and the weather was just right. The tombs are amazing, some movingly kept up and others left to deteriorate. One can see that the passage of time can drastically change things, and that no matter what, time does indeed march on.

Busy - top Buenos Aires attraction. This city centre cemetery is visited by hoards of tourists eager to see Evita's tomb which is sited in her fathers family tomb within the cemetery. Entry is free and Evita's tomb can easily be jfound by following the lines of tourists. The cemetery is packed with tombs lining narrow alleys. An interesting place to visit.

Go to see the whole cemetery.. I know I'm going to sound like a dunce, but I had/still have very limited knowledge of who Evita Peron is...but this cemetery is incredible! I didn't take a tour or anything, but looking around the cemetery was absolutely incredible. The mausoleums are all amazing works of art. Check it out, and see some of this incredible micro-architecture.

Not to be Missed!!!!. If you visit Buenos Aires it is important to appreciate all the sites even if it happens to be a cemetery. We visited this cemetery with our guide from BA bikes. This was a great bike tour through Palermo and Recoleta. This cemetery does not give you creepy feeling but makes you realize the aristocracy really planned well for their funeral. You are in awe looking at and reading memorials to the dead. Of course you do not go to this cemetery without paying respect to Eva Peron's burial tomb. Come and spend an hour and walk through this cemetery. Go with a guide so you don't miss out on the history.

Worth seeing if you are in the area.. Such a concentration of tombs and mausolea, many highly ornate. It gets very busy at times and on the day of our visit, the place was besieged with people from three large cruise ships that had berthed the previous night. Ended up queuing for about 20 mins to see the last resting place of Eva Peron. The cemetery opens from 8am and I think it would be good to visit early when there are fewer visitors.
Visit. Interesting place to visit, will not take all day but a must do thing in BA. Get there early and leave before the coach loads appear

Great troll back in time. This is a beautiful cemetery. It's easily walkable and you can spend several hours here if you choose. It closes early evening so make sure you don't try to stroll in too late. There are several restaurants in the area where you can dine and take a break. On the weekends there's a great market where you can stock up on local goods as souvenirs. This is a beautiful neighborhood to spend some time in. I spent more than a day here and returned a couple of times.Please note, to reach the cemetery, it is actually quite a far walk from the Subte (Pueyrredon) station. That is really the only flaw of getting to this area. So please plan on a 15 minute walk from the Subte to the cemetery.

A must-see site in BA. This is not you average cemetery. It is a city in itself with amazing monuments and small alley ways. It is a really interesting site that doesn't exist anywhere else. It is a definite stop on any trip to BA, at least to stroll around for 30 min. You can also see where Evita is buried

Interesting to see!. Even if is not a funny place it worth a visit there! Everything is different from what you know about a cemetery.All the tombs are made on different styles and they look like a piece of art.Interesting to see!

Intriguing if a bit Disconcerting, Lovely if a bit Ghoulish. This is a cemetery. It has no grass.It is basically a grid like city of structures, like small townhouses cheek by jowl, but each is a mausoleum. The amazing variety of architecture and ornamentation is the draw, as is the state of disrepair and encroaching greenery for many of them. A few notables are interred here, most notably Eva Peron.

"Storers the explorers". The architecture of the grave houses,mausoleums and monuments was wonderfull. A must is to visit the final resting place of Evita Peron.I would recommend you take a formal tour of the cemetery to appreciate this place.

Incredibly cheerful cemetary. Like the Romanian cemetery I visited just over two years before, this cemetery struck me as a rather joyful place to be laid to rest. It is obviously an expensive one too. It is a great way to spend just over an hour. To really get the most out of it, I would recommend finding a few grave houses you want to visit and finding the histories of the dead beforehand. The architecture is still wonderful to pass by and wander through. The plethora of cats was also fun!

City of the Dead. La Recoleta CemeteryDavid Goldberg 5:10 PM Keep this message at the top of your inbox To: DAVID GOLDBERGFounded in 1822, this is virtually a City of the Dead, laid out in a rectangular pattern of streets in which every structure is a mansion, a mausoleum, a palace, a lavish monument, or a florid statue. It was designed by a Frenchman, and French architects and sculptors have been responsible for its most impressive components. It is in reality an open-air museum of architecture and sculpture holding the remains of almost 5,000 persons. Real-estate here comes at a heavy price --------- currently beginning above $US 350,000. Believe it or not, these structures actually change hands. The originals were usually built to order by a single family for use in perpetuity, but future generations frequently failed to keep up with the high taxes and costs of maintenance. After a period of arrears, the "property" is re-possessed by the cemetery authorities and auctioned to new owners after the bones of the original inhabitants have been removed for disposal elsewhere. An unusual feature is that the dead are not buried below ground, but stacked within the family morgue. There is enough of interest to spend half a day here, but most visitors come to make a brief visit to the grave of Eva Peron that is, paradoxically, about the least impressive of all those in the entire cemetery. It is under her family name of Duarte, and is notable only for the fresh flowers that her admirers bring daily. You can learn a great deal about Argentine history in this place. Most of its Presidents are buried here, and I recommend in particular the graves of Nicolas Avellameda, Julio Roca, Domingo Sarmiento, Carlos Pellegrini and Bartolomo Mitre. Military men abound, and look out for the memorials to Gen. Miguel Soler, Luis Maria Campos, and the Irishman William Brown who founded the country's Navy. The Nobel Prize-winning biochemist Luis Leloir and the boxer Luis Angel Firpo are also remembered by impressive sculptures. Our tour group was fortunate to have an excellent and informative guide. You might consider hiring one if you want to get the best out of what I would describe as the most astonishingly lovely cemetery I have ever seen. I wouldn't mind being buried here myself.
Recoleta Cementery. Recoleta Cemetery is a huge complex of mausoleums. I saw Evita Peron tomb and is very humble comparing to other tombs. Never seen anything like it. Just beautiful.

MORBIDLY FASCINATING. Recoleta Cemetery is a huge complex of mausoleums with large shaded streets intersecting narrow lanes. Many famous people are buried here, including Evita Peron. The structures, mostly family crypts that hold generations of remains, vary from magnificent to neglected. It's morbidly fascinating, but more than an hour there is too long. One of the main reasons it's interesting is that it's in the center of the city, surrounded by restaurants, outdoor cafes and shops.

Very Interesting. I think most folks go looking for the gravesite of Eva Peron. While her tomb is there, it is by means the most impressive. In fact, the main reason you will even find it is because of the crowds lead there by a tour guide. Go take a stroll and see how the wealthy like to be remembered.
Must See!. This is a must see place if you plan on touring BA. The architecture is amazing and you are overwhelmed with history. Bring your camera your going to use it a lot!

Needs work. interesting place....many tombs are in various stages of needed repairs. No more English language tours, but map available for 15 pesos. Crowd in front of Evita's tomb would not move so one had to wait to take a photo. Many interesting tombs/masoleums and residential area of Recoleta is wonderful.

Piece of art. Wow! Wow! Wow! I'd heard about Recolata but didn't have very high expectations given its a cemetary. I was so wrong. From the moment I stepped inside I was in awe. I could have spent hours here just photographing. We hired a private tour guide which I highly recommend because there is so much symbolism and so many stories related to the graves and people who died. It's not freaky at all but extraordinary beautiful. If you see a kitty cat make sure to pet it and say hi. They deserve the love.

Solemn Walking Tour. The mausoleums stretch down the paths, close together, many beautiful, many different styles, many different materials and some in disrepair. Most are like small chapels. The famous (Evita, a few Generals) are buried here, but I was most overwhelmed by the testament to our desire to make a permanent presence on the earth.

Another must see if visiting BA. Considered on the the world's most beautiful cemeteries (however that is judged) it holds the remains of some of Argentina's most notable citizens including significant military figures, presidents, Eva Peron, nobel laureates and other notables. I rated it very good as opposed to excellent only because once you have seen it there is little reason to return unless you have a special connection with someone who is buried there. Other landmarks are worth visiting on every trip. You should probably bring a guide book or other documentation or have a knowledgable tour guide.

A bit weird attraction. The cemetery is a bit Paris-style (big buildings for coffins) but smaller than expected. There is only a single entrance, fortunately with no entrance fee (only plan is sold). There are lot of funeral buildings in various state, some uncared, some in well. The most visitors tend to visit the tomb of Evita Perron despite the fact there is nothing interesting with it and about it.

Beautiful in own way . The cemetery is hard to imagine from the tour books but it is really beautiful in its own way and interestingMay sure you find the famous grave sites there are quite a few besides Eva Peron.

One of the best free sights in Buenos Aires. I have seen posh graves in several places - especially France - but this one clearly tops it all. Wowsers the grave architecture business in BA must be a rather big industry. Or at least it was as I doubt that there is room for new ones to build…Really a must see on your trip to BA and it is free on top of it all. I don't think a tour is needed. Just follow one or the other to find the popular graves if you want and otherwise just have a wander...
Very cool. Neat place with lots of history...saw the Evita gravesite which was very neat. Good location, as Recoleta was very nice with lots of shops and cafe's.

Great day!. My wife and I visited the Recoleta Cemetery while visiting Buenos Aires. We visited on a Sunday afternoon. The cemetery is next to the Basilica Nuestra Señora del Pilar, and 18th century Catholic Church. In front of the cemetery and church there is a craft market every Sunday. We found the shopping cheap and entertaining with a large variety of hand crafts. Adjacent to the cemetery is an avenue of cafes with indoor and outdoor dining. The shade of the cafe portico is very inviting after a few hours shopping In the market and visiting the cemetery.There is no charge to visit the cemetery.The cemetery boasts the final resting places of several Argentine historical figures. Evita Perone is one of the most famous internationally. When you enter the cemetery there is an illustrated map that shows the locations of the departed. Evita Peron is with her family in location 88. It can difficult to locate. Once you get in the general vicinity be on the lookout for the occasional tour group, this can be helpful. Besides Evita there are several very interesting sites. Highly recommended. Foreigners should bring small denomination of US $ if possible. Bargaining with all vendors, restaurants in Buenos Aires is better done with US $. Do not exchange $ at your hotel or a bank the exchange rate is 20-30% less than if you pay in $. My one regret is that I did not bring enough $20's, $5's and $1's.

A beautiful location but not a must-see. This is a beautiful cemetery to visit if you have two hours to spare. Not something I would recommend if you have visited any of the cemeteries in New Orleans or if you are purely looking for Evita's grave.

Worth seeing.. Never thought I would give a visit to a cemetery a 5 star rating but it was pretty cool. If you have a couple of hours to kill it is definitely worth wandering around in. However, it was fun to visit but I wouldn't want to stay.Stay Golden

Worth a visiting. I recommend you make a small voluntary contribution to get the map, as without it you will struggle to find any of the significant plots (otherwise it is free to visit). Spent an interesting hour walking round and was glad to have done it.Cemetery is next to Recoletta Mall for coffee, restaurants and limited shopping.

Mausoleum Mainstreet. An amazing experience!! Who would have thought that a bunch of deceased fellow humans and the monuments that their loved ones erected to honour and remember them could leave you bereft of words to describe the sights. We were very fortunate to have as long as we wanted to wander back and forth, but stil could have spent a lot longer there than the five hours that we did. We quickly determined that clean glass on the doors and a shiny padlock indicated the active attendance of family members and descendents, webs and debris a clear sign that the family line had either ceased or fallen on harder times. A poignant reminder that after death we linger only in the memories of those that knew us or knew of our deeds and accomplishments during life. If you come to Buenos Aires you must come and visit the Recoleta.

History of Argentinian Society. A very well preserved and beautiful piece of Argentinian History. The architecture is beautiful, the cemetery is well aid out and it gives an idea of the aristocracy and important families of the past especially. I loved it. A major attraction is Evita's remains in the Duarte mausoleum.

A pleasant surprise!. We visited as part of a half-day guided tour of Buenos Aires and thought, ho-hum, another historic cemetery. We were wrong. This cemetery is incredible, each tomb is so grandiose and detailed (apparently the ego survives death in Argentina)! If you don't have a guide, there was an English ex-pat member of a foundation selling a guidebook US$10 with map at the entrance, you could read many of the stories yourself and do quite fine. Depending on how many stories you want to do/tombs you want to visit, you could spend half an hour to half a day here, easily.

Tour guide makes all the difference.. We toured the Ricoleta cemetery with a guide named Mariela Cavallo, mariela @buenosairesconcierge.com. She was amazing at giving us the history of many tombs. I can't imagine not having her as I watched others fumble with the map you can get. Mariela also gave us a private tour of BA. What a treat!

A fascinating place to visit. Extraordinarily beautiful and fascinating, this cemetery contains almost 4,700 crypts, mausoleums, and small chapels, dozens of which have already been designated as Argentinian national monuments, many of which cost a fortune to build. It is organized in streets that can be negotiated with a map, available at the entrance. A guide is helpful to understand the history and identify the location of former Presidents, politicians, scientists, athletes, and other historical figures. The Duarte family mausoleum, containing the body of Evita Peron, is perhaps the most visited spot in the cemetery. Outside, there is a lovely small church adjacent to the cemetery, and a large and delightful arts and crafts market on weekends.

Mesmerizing Tombs. This is a must see for any trip to Buenos Aires. The sheer magnitude of these monuments to death are breathtaking... Alright my language is getting a bit too big. Let me just say that walking along the small pathways between the tombs was thrilling. Each is like a mini church with some being conquered by the passing of time while others standing tall and ominous. The area around the cemetery includes a small park and an enjoyable neighborhood for walks and restaurants. I would recommend this site to any and all types of travelers.

A truely unique place.. You should not miss Recoleta Cemetry if you ever go to Buenos Aires. Some might find the place slightly bisarre as coffins are evident at some spots, but this place has also got it's own beauty. Some parts are in a perfect shape, while other parts are crumbling.

Not to be missed if you are visiting Buenos Aires. A classic Latin cemetery with family crypts. It's almost like a little village with streets and all, but there are no houses, just crypts. A guided tour is certainly in order. Evita's tomb is something of a disappointment, because it is just "average or below" in terms of size and looks. But La Recoleta is a must if you are visiting Buenos Aires, and certainly worth your time!

Don't miss the Recoleta Cemetery. I wish I'd allowed more time to visit the Recoleta cemetery. It's fascinating, beautiful, photogenic, and gives some insight into Argentina. I could easily have spent hours exploring the cemetery which was much bigger than I expected it to be, but I left it for the last day and couldn't spend more time without missing my flight.

Cool and creepy. A must see in buenos aires! Here you will find old and new mosaleums including those of former presidents, political figures, and Evita Peron. It's quite beautiful and slightly creepy to see the coffins laying in plane sight but the cemetery is very well maintained - I believe it closes at 6pm everyday.

Very interesting history. Maybe its me, but I always find a city's cemeteries interesting. If you are not comfortable around that kind of thing, this place really isn't for you,You can literally, if you wanted to, touch coffins in some of the neglected mausoleums. See it as part of the free Recoleta tour is you like, it is definitely something different. Get a program if you want to find your way around.... costs money though. DO NOT get the tour with one of the guards, they are apparently useless and charge you a fortune.

A little town of marble ...family tombs that were really interesting in a strange way.. I visited the cemetery as wanted to visit the family tomb of Eva Peron. It is strangely fascinating walking around the 'streets' between the little buildings that house past members of families. The cemetery is at stop 24 on the city bus tour. The day we visited there was a craft market outside that is worth browsing around for souvenirs and a nice restaurant where you can sit in the shade of a gum tree and enjoy a nice cold beer just 2 minutes walk from the cemetery entrance.

Absolutely faacinating. Who would have thought a cemetery was so fascinating. Firstly, you need a guide to bring the history, stories and information alive. From people tombed alive, to tombs sold and rehoused. Past presidents, rich, famous and rags to riches stories. Its like a small village and most fascinating.

Impressive cemetery but that's about it. Impressive because of its scale. You can see this within the space of an hour. It's probably not my cup of tea but many would love it and it's a must see for Buenos. It's free which is great if you're on a budget. I think it could be better if there were English translations to show you what you were looking at.

A must do in Buenos Aires. This cemetery is a must-see while in Buenos Aires. The most popular tomb to visit is Evita's, because probably to non-Argentinians, she is the most famous person buried here. Her tomb is rather unimpressive compared to the others, so don't expect too much. It's more of a "check the box" type thing to do while here, so definitely walk around and explore the other tombs, even thought you may not know any of the other people buried in the cemetery. Each tomb is different, with amazing attention to detail. Some are quite lavish (stained glass windows, altars, etc). Recoleta is the wealthy part of Buenos Aires, so it's also worth walking around the area surrounding the cemetery and seeing how the upper class lives.And yes, it's free! I guess it would be wrong to charge people to visit a cemetery..
Excellent. A beautiful place to walk around and enjoy a full day. The place is breath taking! Wonderful accommodations in the area to enjoy!!!

A must see in BA. If you love grand cemeteries like I do this is a must. There are a lot of beautiful crypts. The tomb of Evita's is a bit of a disappointment. We had a local friend to explain who the important historical tombs belonged to, so I think a tour would be a good idea. Great plave to take photos.

Art in a cemetery. Went on the free tour in English Tuesday morning 11:00am. The tour is also on Thursday morning. The guide was very knowledgeable and the tour very interesting. Many of the tombs are works of art. This Cemetery should not be missed. Very safe.

Amazing cemetery in the center of the city. There is something serene about walking through a cemetery in the middle of busy city. Every path through the cemetery is interesting and unique. Some of the statues and ornamentation is very beautiful. The Duarte family mausoleum containing Eva Peron's remains is a popular stop.

Very interesting. collection of tombstones for the rich and famous of Argentina.We took the free english tour and that was better than doing it yourself.Amazing how people regard the afterlife in a very curious way.(us included)
Visited twice. If you like cemetery's or just enjoy a closer look at history, both objectives are covered here. Take a tour for more specific information.

Great way to spend an hour or two. If you enjoy photography there are plently of great opportunities here. We didn't do a tour just strolled around for a couple of hours and enjoyed the sunny day. Nice little market to visit outside after to get some local crafts.

Beautiful and Interesting - better if you have a guide. It is like a huge town house community of individual mausoleums. Each one is different and interesting; some are huge and ornate. I had a guide (http://www.tripadvisor.com/Attraction_Review-g312741-d2694119-Reviews-Buenos_Aires_LIZ_Private_Tour_Guide-Buenos_Aires_Capital_Federal_District.html) and we spent about one hour walking through the cemetery and she highlighted a number of beautiful tombs and provided interesting stories. You can go on your own but you'll miss out on some cool stories. I could have spent a couple of hours there.

Maze of beauty and history!. When I walked through the gate I purchased a trifold for 15 pesos with information about the cemetery and a map of graves. It was nice to have a guide to lead us to the graves we wanted to see, and when our time was running short it helped us pass others. Some graves are really rundown with broken glass and plants growing inside and some are perfectly kept with shiny stone and fresh flowers. It was fun to see the juxtaposition of the graves sites and put the map down for a bit to get lost in the maze.

place to be seen. well I would say that it is a place to be seen. nice walk, surprised by the hight of the mausoleums. maybe one would think that the last place of Eva Peron is greater. well we did not regret to walk through on a very hot day. ice cream across the cemetery was great.well any ice cream in Argentina is good.

Surprisingly good. I couldn't understand why a cemetery was a 'must' in Buenos Aires but I was pleasantly surprised. I would definitely recommend it. The grave of Eva Peron, however, is a bit disappointing compared to some of the more spectacular ones.

Extraordinary place!. The Recoleta Cemetery is a very interesting mausoleum. Right in the center of the city, it is home (final resting place) to many people who contributed significantly to Argentina. Quite fascinating - it is a must see while you are in Buenos Aires. Highly recommended!

Incredibly interesting. This is surely the most interesting cemetery I have ever visited. The mausoleums have great diversity of style and materials, some kept up to very high standards and some sadly neglected, but all are charming in their own ways. Nice to see Eva Peron's tomb as well.
Worth a walk round. Hard to review a graveyard but it's an interesting diversion on a sunny day. Some historic monuments including the most visited, Eva Peron's mausoleum.

Fascinating Place. The Recoleta Cemetary is not to be missed in Buenos Aires. We walked for hours looking at the crypts, marveling at the diversity of styles, materials and condition. While seeing Eva Peron's family crypt was special, there was so much more to Recoleta. I just wish there was a place to stand above the Cemetery so that we could see it all from above.

A must see if in Buenos Aires. When our tour guide first suggested we were going to visit a cemetery I was not very impressed,not the sort of tourist attraction you expect to visit. It turned out to be a must see place. It truly is a fascinating place to visit .I think it is a good idea to have a guide who knows the way around and to be able to explain the history of the tombs. The guide we had was very good and made the visit all the more interesting with her knowledge and history of the the people who are buried there.
I never saw a cemetery like this!. Mausoleum after mausoleum. Each unique with such history. We just walked through, but a guided tour or written guide would have enriched the experience.

Unbelievable. I have never seen any cemetary like this the crypts are small elegant house. You walk rows and rows and no two are alike. Some are just beautiful, beautiful statues, stained glass, granite. Some have been vandalized with glasses broken. You can see the coffins stacked in some with linen drapes some with pictures of the deceased and even the ashes of the favorite animals. And of course Evita is buried there. They say this is the most expensive real estate in Buenos Aires. Not to be missed

Photographic Heaven. Whilst visiting a cemetery may not necessarily be everybody's cup of tea or particularly high on one's list of things to see, when exploring a new city!Recoleta Cemetery however should be!Even leaving aside that it's Eva Perron's final resting place, it's interesting to see who else has chosen this site to make their journey into the afterlife. It's also an extremely photographic site that will have most camera buffs shooting photos like there's no tomorrow.

Worth A Visit. A unique place. The above ground tombs are ornate. It is an interesting maze and a person could spend a lot of time wandering around the narrow pathways. One may even run across a few things that some may think border on the macabre, probably the result of lack of maintenance in some individual tombs.

Something different to experience. We had a guided tour of this quaint place this morning and is rather an eye opener. The mausoleums are beyond belief, something we are I use to and the expense that the families have gone to.The place is well kept and very clean, we went early to avoid the crowds which I would suggest to anyone. Evita Perons mausoleums is perfect and I believe she is buried 4metres deep under the actual walkway out side her mausoleum.Well worth a see.

A bit macabre but atypical in a good way. At first I didn't even want to visit this spot, as the Evita movie did not impress me at all, nor did the character, a melodramatic figure praised by the poor masses.Left aside that the former First Lady of Argentina is buried here, the cemetery is an interesting place, as there are plenty of tombs, meticulously carved and decorated, some of them real small works of art. It is definitely worth a visit, as it has a serene atmosphere.(interrupted by the noise made by the workers renovating some of the tombs).

Cemetery Trip. We visited the Recoleta Cemetery as part of a city tour and it was fascinating and well worth a visit. The main attraction is obviously Eva Peron's grave but the whole cemetery is fascinating. Very similar to New Orleans but far less space

Many pesos. If you travel to Argentina, then you know that the economy is not strong but this place is rocking. Located in an upscale neighborhood the cemetery is a large enclosed field that is filled with huge architecturally interesting tombs, some like houses. There are windows to peer into the past and actually see the coffins.The place is kept immaculately clean with nice benches for a picnic and lots of "kitties" for company,although they have started to neuter the residents to reduce the population.If you are a fan of Evita, her tomb is here, all black marble and lots of flowers.All in all, a worthwhile experience.Take the 62 bus- its air conditioned.

A different experience. We had a private tour of this "attraction"and felt it well worth the visit. Why people would want to build such mausoleums is strange but obviously there was competition to create the grandest and it created a street like environment. Evita Peron's was the busiest area but we arrived early morning when we had easy access.

Cry for Evita. The burial place of various people including Evita Peron, Very tidy and clean although some of the Crypts need a bit of attention, Get a map or join one of the tours you can get lost, Overall unusual expereance.

A must to see. Might sound morbid, but this is a great place to tour around and see the Cemetery. It is far from your average field of tomb stones.Full of history, and a great place for some cool pictures...
Fascinating. It is well worth the visit just to see Evita's tomb.....we had a guide with us for the tour so she was so informative and was able to guide us to relevant tombs and the history of it.

Beautiful and disgraceful. It is definitely the most impressive cemetery that I've ever seen but I was appalled by the disrespect paid to those prominent families laid to rest there. It's clearly one of Buenos Aires primiere attractions yet the place is falling apart. They don't to any upkeep or repair. You can literally look through the broken glass and see old, fallen and decaying coffins. It's a shame and sad for those who have clearly been forgotten there.

Take guided tour offered. Free tours of 90 minutes in a variety of languages BUT on different days of the week @ 11 am. Guide was very knowledgeable. Was skeptical to attend but after reading trip advisor glad we did go. Not your typical cemetery and another thing must see in BA

Yes, it's a must see, but it's worth it. If you go to New Orleans and were relatively unimpressed by their cemeteries don't let that dissuade you. This is the real deal.Yes, Eva Peron's family mausoleum is there, but walk around and take in this fascinating, odd, marvelous and certainly unique plot of land. This qualifies as a Don't Miss.

Not a fan of cemeteries. Full of famous as well as notorious names. I'm not a fan of cemeteries so maybe you should ask somebody else. But if you're looking for an example of interesting architecture in graveyards, this is the place for you.

Leave yourself plenty of time!. We could have wandered around here for hours. Absolutely stunning, and fascinating - there are so many different approaches to commemoration in here, some of which will appall you, and some of which are genuinely moving.It would be very easy to get lost here, but the map you're given is effective without being intrusive; like everyone, we used it to find Evita's tomb, then wandered happily for an hour or so until closing time. A real BA highlight - if you go in the evening, relax in the park outside afterwards, where there's a great music and folk scene. Ideal for sunset.

Surreal Recoleta Cemetery. The Recoleta Cemetery should not be missed. I wandered for a long time with my daughter, who as a student resident of Buenos Aires, had been there a few times and knew how to find Evita's maybe tomb in under thirty seconds. Evita's maybe grave is one of the least interesting crypts. The varied architecture and use of materials is amazing and the bizarre way that the buildings are all connected is something of a beautiful macabre mishmash. The plethora of cats adds a nice touch too. I loved it so much, I went back at 7:30 in the morning while running down by the park and made the mistake of running into the cemetery. It was empty and I had the whole beautiful place to myself (and maybe a few souls) until a guard saw me and yelled at me to quit running and chased me out.

A glimpse at how you want to be remembered.. You either like visiting cemeteries for their history and architecture ( and a celeb or two) or you find them creepy. I like them. Other than a modest family crypt for Evita, there wasn't a familiar name to be seen. But the fascinating combination of crumbling architecture for some and modern glass boxes ( for a very few) made it definitely worth a visit. Plus it's free! And wasn't crowded at all. Which made it eerily fun.

One of a kind place. Must see place in the city. We were with a guide who told us so much about the history of this place. There are so many interesting stories. The place is amazing. Interesting how it is so expensive to get a place here. We went over the weekend, there was music outside and some artists were selling art work. Nice part of town. Enjoy icecream on your way out from Freddys.

Cemetary and surrounding church great. To think of touring a cemetery seems morose but it was truly an enriching experience to see how people of past and present are handled at death truly beautiful structures to house the departed and the expense of the buildings is just unbelievable. The church that was next to the cemetery is a must a truly humbling experience.

Not as morbid as it sounds.. The gravestones were so elaborate and diverse - like a little mini-city. The area around the cemetery is also gorgeous. It is free to get in, but we got asked to give a donation right when we were entering. Evita's grave is not so easy to find as it is a smaller tomb in one of the alleys to the right, but look for the crowds of people. There are restaurants with nice views along the perimeter.
A must see!. Free entry. Amazing tombs, nice to stroll around in. Loads of restuarants nearby and lovely park surrounding the cemetery

Really strange experience. The tombs here are such that you could be in a small village - it's easy to imagine street names and postal codes for postmen to use. LArge and a bit eerie, depending on how spooked you get, but also interesting and thought provoking just wandering around. Yes Evita in here so many go to see her tomb, a practice I've never quite got my head around regardless of who the person is if you did not know them.
A Must Visit. An amazing place to visit. Take a guide otherwise you may miss out on a lot of the history of the interesting people who are buried there. More like a small city than a cemetery.

Very Unique Cemetery, worth the visit. This is not just any cemetery. In the US (south), we just have pretty simple cemeteries. The graves here are very ornate. Large buildings. Places for the family to come and visit and spend time. Several family members in the same place (I wonder how they do that?). I can't imagine how much it would cost to erect and maintain such a place for burial.We just walked around. We did find the grave of Evita Peron. There are many cats around the place. A tour guide would have been a nice addition. I'm sure the place has an amazing story behind some of the graves. About and hour or two should be plenty of time here. There is shopping and eateries nearby as well. Benches outside to sit on if someone in your group becomes tired, just be aware of the sprinkler heads that may pop up and give you a wet suprise.

Beautiful cemetery. This is a beautiful cemetery with elaborate tombs. There is a free English tour on Tuesdays at 11am which lasts about 1 hour. The crowd is quite large for this as the tour doesn't happen everyday but worth following along to listen to the stories of famous people buried here. Definitely a must see.

Unusual and Fascinating. Recoleta Cemetery is one of perhaps three of its type in the world. The others that come to mind are the Verrano in Rome and one in Paris. There are extravagant mausoleums adorned with fantastic sculptures and more simple ones. It is literally a city of the dead. Of course, Eva Peron is buried there and her family's mausoleum is like a shrine, adorned by messages, flowers, etc.The best way to see the cemetery is by guided tour. The Guide provides a lot of information about the history of the cemetery and the people buried there. The tour is about two hours long and well worth the time. There are memorials to historical persons, the cow (which was the original basis for Argentina's wealth), and to sad passings of dearly loved daughters. Tours are available daily. Check with the cemetery website to find what languages and times are scheduled.

Unexpectedly Interesting. I found the Recoleta Cemetery much more interesting then I expected. The variety of mausoleums (giant, tiny, old, new, expensive and delapidated) were very unique. It is worth spending 1-2 hours walking around the place. If you want more details of the history, you might like to hire a guide or buy a book but we enjoyed just exploring on our own. The kids enjoyed the statues.

Visit often. This is my favorite attraction in Buenos Aires. It is a veritable city of the dead, a city from which the dead can be evicted if they don't keep up with the rent. I recommend going at different times of day as the character of the cemetery changes depending on the light.

Unusual and interesting. Normally one doesn't put cemeteries on a "to see" list, but this one came with so many recommendations that we decided to give it a try. It's like a strange little isolated town in itself, the tombs are rather like elaborate houses, quite splendid in their own way. But the pretentiousness and the folly of it all leaves a nasty taste in one's mouth. Even in death these people had to draw attention to themselves as "important". Ultimately it can be seen as a symbol of Argentina itself - a land of appalling inequality where the rich spend money on themselves and keep the poor out of sight....

Amazing place. Not often I review a cemetery but this one is special. Some of the tombs are magnificent and very elaborate, some are in need of some tlc but there is restoration work going on. There are many famous people buried here including of course Evita Peron. Thought provoking - many of these people were obviously very wealthy but we all end up the same in the end.It's a big place and there are maps with suggested routes or free guided tours but I think it's better just to wander round for a couple of hours. We went in the morning and it wasn't crowded although there were several tour groups.

Duty! Unique!. It's a unique place to go!I think everybody should go there with the free willing tour and really understand about those strange tombs that people built to their selves !!! And after hearing the crazy story of Evita Peron, go and see her grave! It gives much more meaning if u do it that way.

Take the free tour. If possible take the free guided visit, you will hear important facts that probably you won't find if you visit by yourself.In November 2014, the schedule was:- In Spanish, from Tuesday to Friday at 9:30, 11:00 and 15:00- In English, every Tuesday and Thursday at 11:00- In Italian, every Wednesday at 11:00

Uniquely ~ A MUST !. It may seem peculiar to list a cemetery as a Must ~ but this defies every negative thought.We have gone without a 'guide' (usually a hacker in front of the cemetery), or a map, or longing to see Evita's permanent home. And we had a Fabulous time. Hardly does an hour or two suffice. Just go without any time constraints and be prepared to be astonished and amazed.There is every type of grave imiginable ; from monuments the size if a small house, to those built by narcissistic citizens, to beautifully somber and sad sites.Make sure your camera/phone is working and - hit it..You can go solo, with friends or a partner, but leave the children at home, because they are going to become bored and run riot over your experience.Hope this review encouraged some of you to view a one of a kind - destination!
Breathtaking experience. Touch of history of this beautiful country heroes. I was standing and crying in front of Evita's Peron grave - very touching place from positive side.

Simply amazing. Not that we do much cemetery cruising but this place was just so amazing. Of course the #1 attraction is Eva Peron's family Crypt, just remember the family name is Duarte when you look at the map for locations. You can spend the whole day here, so many amazing crypts and tombs. Some of the exposed coffins are a "Happy Snapper's " delight. A great reminder that when your gone, your gone!

Lovely way to spend an afternoon. Its perhaps a bit odd till you get there. But this is definitely worth seeing. Its beautiful. Ornate. A real slice of history. You could spend hours walking through here. I didn't take the tour - but I wish I had. There's so much its a tad overwhelming. The nearby park is great too. You'll enjoy your time here for sure!

Decayed Elegance. We didn't go for the famous dead folks, but just for the atmosphere. The place is gigantic, with a wide variety of mostly old but some newish tombs, some extremely ornate. When the tombs decay, they evidently just let them fall down, which is part of the charm of the place. It was hot the day we were there but there's plenty of shady (in more ways than one) avenues to shelter in. Many cats. Not for the felinophobe or the claustrophobe. Also I kept looking for folks who appeared to have been other than Christian and never found any sites that didn't have crosses or stained glass Jesuses. The Jews and Muslims must be somewhere else.

Must see "with a tour guide". We visited the Recoleta Cemetery on a nice sunny day lots of crowds. This something I wouldn't want to do without a tour guide its pointless because your hist0ry lesson will be incomplete. The facts a history behind the tombs is so much more meaningful.

Never Thought of a Cemetery As a Tourist Attraction. Highlight of Buenos Aires - just something magical about this Recoleta cemetery. It might have the nicest 'houses' in all the land! Grab a guide, take a tour, worth the trip.

Must see! Do the guided tour.... We visited the Recoleta Cemetery this morning and it was a fascinating experience. We briefly considered grabbing a map and touring on our own, but then decided to do the free* (tip at the end) guided tour, and that turned out to be a great decision!! The tour guide shares all of the interesting stories and facts, and it was much more fulfilling than roaming around on our own. This is an hour well spent in Buenos Aires!!

Amazing. This was amazing to walk around all the mausoleums. Some of which are very ornate and some are thirty feet high! I would recommend a tour guide because there is so much to see. We saw the final resting place of Eva Peron and were told many other interesting tales of the people interred there
Buy a map.. Buy a map before visit. It's only 15 pesos. Must visit to see the Architecture.Can be done in 1 hour.

a must see in buenos aires. This cemetery is extraordinary. I definitely recommend visiting this place. At the entrance you can get a map for 15 pesos, which show you the main sites. You need about an 1 or 2 to visit.

Must see. Spend two or three hours just wandering around cemetery and be sure to see Evita. My wife and I found a number of caskets of famous Argentinian people, but could not find Juan's. Later found out he is not there, but in Spain

Well Worth the Visit. This is one of the "must do" attractions in Buenos Aires, and worth a 2-3 hour visit. There is a wide variety of mausoleums and elaborate statuary. We took a guided tour (approx. 40 minutes), it is inexpensive (approx.$10 a person), and worth it as the cemetery is quite large and easy to get lost in.
Interesting in a morbid way. Definitely worth a visit. The tombs are elaborate and active, as in you'll see plenty of fresh coffins piled on top of grand ma! It is a bit morbid, but worth the visit.

Must do, but kind of weird. There's something about this place that makes it a must-do in BA, just once. It harkens (?) to a different historical time of opulence among the elite. It is like a little town in there. Of course you have to visit Evita's tomb. A tour guide we happened to listen in on said that it is usually laden with flowers but because it had been raining, there were hardly any flowers, and what was there was dead. But I think it also has a lot of interesting scultpures. My favorite was the one of the slender woman with the dog. I noticed a tour guide speaking a language I didn't understand. I made out that she told her group to rub the dog's nose for good luck, which they did, and then we had to as well.

Evita Peron is buried here, but you knew that didn't you?. Dark ominous sky contributed to creating the mood for visiting this cemetery of masoliums. Very old, right in the middle of what is now a bustling city. If you're interested in seeing where Evita ended up, stop by and pay her a visit.

Interesting. The tomb of Evita is not very exquisite or highly decorated. Lots of tour groups around her tomb. People rudely taking pictures in front of others. Some other crypts/tombs are beautiful with marble, statues,engraving etc. There is only one entrance on the east side, otherwise you have to walk around the high walls of the whole place to get to this entrance. Admission is free

Impressive and Unusual. We were told that there were 4700 mausoleums in the cemetery , and I don't doubt it. Some serious sculpture, and something that stopped me short in my tracks - a mausoleum with a working door knocker! The church next door is also impressive.
Impressive architecture for the dead. Enjoyed the rows and rows of mausoleums with historical building of all shapes and sizes. Not sure why it is so popular.
impressive. it feels a bit odd to stroll around but there are some seriously beautiful pieces of art in this cementry.

Pere lachaise take note. English language tours Tuesday and Thursday at 11 are the way to go for visitors with limited Spanish. Our guide Marta, was superb & pointed out the many, many things we would have missed on ourown

Great Cemetery. Definitely worth the visit. Old and somewhat spooky. Prime attraction is Evan Person's crypt. There are a number of other cool gravesites. I'd give it a higher rating, but it doesn't compare to Pere L'Chese in Paris.

Unique nothing more can be said !!. Yes, it's on all the tourist maps and recommendations but do not miss this going to this extraordinary sight when visiting BA.
There is nothing like it anywhere and is a wonder of grandeur and days gone by opulence!!

An interesting place to visit. We engaged a guide before we entered the cemetery and it made all the difference. Without his knowledge we would have wandered past Evita's grave and then wandered back out. Our guide was very knowledgable about the art deco style of the monuments and
the histories of some of the people buried there.

Quiet spot in busy town. Recoleta Cemetery is one of those places which one must see in Buenos Aires. The atmosphere is at times spooky, but overall the place is beautifully maintained and the graves are beautiful. You will find graves for people who have contributed to history of Argentina and Buenos Aires. Some are slightly difficult to find so try to get a map and follow the signs.There is a mall near by which has restaurants for food.

Beautiful. Yes the word beautiful must be a little odd word to be used for a cemetery but trust me when I say that there is nothing that would suit it more. The place is more than a grave yard. Here art and history rests together. Each grave is a piece of art. Lots of important persons rests here in these grounds and the recoleta itself has a lot of stories to tell. One of the tales that impressed me was regarding the grave of Eva Peron.

Don't miss this "melting pot.". I would assume that anyone reading reviews about Recoleta Cemetery already intends to visit it. Be sure that you do. It is indeed one of the most beautiful cemeteries in the world. It can be warm and the only shade provided is from the tombs themselves as there are few trees. The tombs are magnificent. Although the cemetery is the final resting place for many of Argentina's most notable citizens and a number of Presidents, we were really only familiar with Eva Peron. Mostly we were fascinated to see all of the different last names on the graves. Expecting to see mostly Spanish sounding names (I guess because they speak Spanish in Argentina?), we saw many nationalities represented there including French, Italian, Russian, German, Dutch, you name it. For the past 500 years, Argentina has received more immigrants than any country in the world except for the USA and it is quite a melting pot. Nowhere is that more evident than in this cemetery. Some examples are Luis Federico Leloir, the Nobel prize winning chemist born in France, Mariette Lydis, a painter and illustrator born in Austria, and Irish born William Brown, who founded the Argentinian navy. Even the native born Argentinians born here have a variety of ethnic names such as actor Armando Bo, medical pioneer Cosme Argerich, and Juan Lavalle, governor of Buenos Aires province. I thought this was pretty interesting.

Beautiful!! Worth visiting!. beautiful cementery, the most important in Buenos Aires City with very famous and beautiful graves to visit
Worth visiting, very interesting place!

Sad, but not how you think. The beautiful famous tombs are exactly as you would imagine them. The architecture, sculpture, art and care put into the mausoleums are incredible. But the not-so-famous tombs, many of them are in a state of disrepair. It makes me sad to think people put so much time and effort into their burial, only to have it all fall apart years later. It does remind you that nothing lasts forever.

Magnificent. Different in terms of "lacking space" this cemetery is there not just to remind you of the deceased but also of what Buenos Aires is. There is an interesting contrast between luxurious and opulent graves and mausoleum with the sort of ruined niches and exposed caskets.Nevertheless, the site is an open book on Argentinean history and worth visiting by all means.

A truly unique experience - must-see. It has been said that this is one of the most beautiful cemeteries in the world. Similar to Pere Lachaise Cemetery in Paris, or the St. Louis Cemetery 1 in New Orleans, this cemetery features above-ground tombs, and is a unique lesson in history, religion and culture of Argentina. The cemetery is laid out like a city - a true necropolis with tree-lined "boulevards", smaller "streets" and some even smaller "alleys". The tombs lined these passageways like row-houses, built one right next to the other, next to the other. In some cases, families bought large enough plots that their tombs didn't touch other tombs, and might have had a bench for the living to sit on when they come visit. The tombs were often family-based, with more than one person within. In many tombs, coffins were visible, stacked on shelves within the tomb, or you could peek at them down teeny-tiny staircases that led to space beneath the tombs. In some eras, the coffins were covered with beautiful white cloths edged in lace. Most of these cloths were fairly deteriorated and raggedy (adding to the creep-factor!)If you're unable to go on a tour (Spanish language tours daily, English language tour at 11 AM on Tuesdays), read the Wikipedia article about the cemetery before you go. Many rich-and-famous people are buried here, including a bunch of former presidents. Evita (who was born poor, but became famous) is also here.We visited the Recoleta Cemetery on Nov 1, aka Day of the Dead. It was interesting to see how many people were in the cemetery to clean the tombs inside and out. (Although it seemed like some of the cleaners were hired to do the job, not members of the family). Our kids were a little unsure about it when I first suggested that we go, but once there, and once they got over the slight sense-of-unease about visiting a cemetery, they were fascinated. They are 11 and 15. We saw lots of other teens and kids here, and all seemed to be interested.

Traditional old Argentine Cemetery. When you think of a cemetery in the states, images of smaller stones spread among acres of green lawn come to mind. But not here where land is precious, along with deceased love ones With many large mausoleums, monuments & crypts, it's almost a miniature town, as many look like little houses. Of course for those of us non-Spanish speaking visitors, the words mean or explain nothing. With all the weeds and everything run-down, one would not think this was famous. So, for most people, it might be a short visit, but everyone will expect you to visit it. No matter what your length of visit is, It's a good/free experience though. Along with the typical beggars of fake charities that your donations will help, that seem to pop-up around attractions, churches etc.

The cemetery with a charm. It was nice to see all these big tombs where family tombs held more than two coffins. The structures were interesting with the small altars, all the statues depicting the person who died. Interesting was the young girl who died of cancer. Of course the main attraction was the final resting place of Eva Peron.

Beautiful . A must see when in Buenos Aries. Can spend as little or as long as you want here. No entrance fee when I attended. Would defo recommend going in the afternoon when it's cooler and not such big crowds for Eva Peron's tomb.Such stunning tombs and also a bit eerie as you can see in some of the tombs that are run down and see the coffins.

great tour. The cemetery is huge. Take a tour -- you really need to have this visit organized for you, and the tour guides do a very good job of explaining the historical figures and the artistic significance of their mausoleums.

A must see. When we go on holiday, a cemetery is not a place we would normal go out of our way to visit. Recoleta Cemetery however is no ordinary place, it is very large and like a mini city inside a city. Its size is amazing and some of the monuments and mausoleums are both massive and very interesting. This is also the resting place of many famous Argentinians, Evita of course being one.Entry is free and and we bought a map from a seller at the gate for 15 Argentinian pesos which is less than $2 Australian and well worth the cost to help negate the many lane ways.It is a unique and peaceful experience and one we would recommend.

Amazing old place. It is great to see such a place, where the family is regiled in small close quarters once they pass. It was amazing for me to see this as an Australian as very rare at home. Some of the stone work was amazing and the place just went on and on......kind of spooky, but transfixing at the same time

Spooky. Even it is an amazing place, it is a bit awkward to see the coffins on display...kind of different. Beware of the people at the entrance trying to get money from you just for telling your way around, they start saying that they don't want money, but when they tell you where to go they ask you for a donation for a charity. The Duarte mausoleum is the most visited, I would recommend to visit Raul Alfonsin's mausoleum ( ex Argentina's prime minister). Very interesting pieces of architecture, but some of the new ones look like the front of a designer shop.

beautiful old cemetery. Recoleta is a famous cemetery for its exceptional architecture and almost luxurious resting place of some important argentines. The cemetery could be better maintained but seeing as though it is a free place to visit we cannot complain!

Evita evita. This is a fascinating place, like Pere la chaise i(sp?)Paris , the site to see evita peron's crypt. Her body/ coffin has its own unique story. It looks like it's own city from a distance. Her grave is very understated for the continued discussion of her in Argentina.

Bizzare place but really not to missed.. Most people come to see Eva Peron's crypt. Just follow the crowds. The cemetery is a tightly packed miniature city of elaborate above ground crypts. Well worth a short trip just to see. Not that far from the city in the Recolleta neighbourhood which itself is worth a visit.

I felt small and insignificant among the land of the dead. Mausoleums the size of houses. The size of them blew me off the park. We have a section of mausoleums at Rookwood cemetery in Lidcombe, Sydney. But nothing compared to this. Had a great time just walking and admiring the work put into them. Place is huge. Worth a look if you are in the area.

Beautiful and Historical Cemetery. Wow, what a place! Not only is it beautiful but is a historical place that you should not miss when you are in Buenos Aires. Many famous people including Eva Duarte Peron! I loved it so much I found myself looking for Burial Spots that have come-up for sale. I would definitely label Recoleta Cemetery a place "NOT TO MISS"!

Much hype about Evita but a cool place to visit even without Evita. We went to see Evita Peron's understated tomb. However, the cemetery was filled with amazing architecture and sculpture found on the tombs. Take 30-60 minutes to visit it. It is free and a good way to spend some time in Buenos Aires

Worthwhile if you're into cemeteries. Really top cemetery & high quality mausoleums. Eva Peron buried here in the family tomb under her family name of Duarte. Really worth looking around, very nicely kept & doubt if there would see much better.

One of the coolest cemeteries I have seen. This place is pretty cool and only a little creepy. It is a cemetery, after all, and there are a couple of stories that are the stuff of nightmares. Otherwise it is a peaceful place in the heart of a big city. Once you walk through the entryway, you are bombarded with artwork. The mausoleums are very interesting. Of course, there are some very famous people buried there, most notably several Argentinian presidents and Evita Perón. Some of the mausoleums have not been maintained for several years, adding to the creepy factor and a sense of sadness. Many cats roam around the place. Rated amongst the best cemeteries in the world, and something you should see when in Buenos Aires.

Very interesting cemetery. As cemeteries go, it is very interesting.The mausoleums are very upmarket and the names reflect the who's who of Argentina.Close to the city, you might as well check it out.

Worth doing the free guided tour. Highly recommend the excellent, free walking tour of the cemetery that takes place in English and Spanish on Tuesdays and Thursdays. The professional guide was extremely knowledgable really brought the place to life(!)The tour takes an hour and starts (promptly) at 13:00 from the main entrance. Free, although the volunteers at the gate typically try to get you to buy a map, which costs 15 pesos and the guide can accept tips.

A city within a city.. It's on everyone's list of things to do when visiting Buenos Aires. So we made the pilgrimage to the Cementerio de la Recoleta. Some of the mausoleum's are huge, some are beautiful, some are sad and delapidated. The city is now maintaining some of the graves because there are no living family members to look after them. There are free guided tours but most people prefer just to wander. It is a slice of Argentine history and it is worthwhile spending time to read some of the stories of the famous and mainly wealthy people from this era. It is so large that you can explore in peace except for the very famous grave of Evita where you can expect to wait to be alone for a minute or two.

Evita Revisited. After seeing Evita in Washington, D.C.'s Kennedy Center this weekend, I posted photos I had taken of Eva Peron's memorial in the Recoleta Cemetery when I visited in 2012. But Eva is only one of many Argentinians buried there. For example, writer Jorge Borges is buried there along with many other artists, military and political figures. Even those who are lesser known or unknown leave behind interesting stories (which we heard from a guide) and interesting monuments. The Recoleta is truly like a village with so many beautiful and different mausoleums and sculptures.

A special cemetery. There are few cemeteries in the world that I would have an interest in - it seems quite garish but you can't help looking for the famous like Evita and it is cleat that the country pays enormous respect to its people.
Impressive. Interesting to see and hear the history of the Recoleta Cementry.For detailed information, you might participate on one of the guided tours which are free.

Worth the time. Interesting glimpse of how different cultures honor their loved ones in death. This is not just a cemetery, but a cultural attraction that demonstrates how the rich and poor adorn their plots. You must check it out.
Superb. An outdoor museum that allows visitors to discover Argentine history, art and social evolution as they visit the stone and marble mausoleums. Not to be missed!

My fave. I visited here on the orders of a friend who o once lived in Argentina. Became my favorite spot in the city, and I returned again and again, at different times of day, which gave it an entirely different feeling each time. Highly recommended.

Must-see in Buenos Aires, and Free. This is just something you have to do while you're in BA for a few days. Some of the mausoleums are amazingly beautiful and have really amazing stonework and detail.Make a beeline for Evita's grave and after that, just roam around looking at the graves of some of Argentina's most famous (dead) people - including many former presidents, film stars, and the elite.The best part is that it's free, so you can stay 5 minutes or 2 hours, and there's no guilt if you get bored and leave. But it's definitely something you should see while you're in Buenos Aires in between wine, steak and tango.

Amazing cemetary. I travelled to Buenos Aires alone and I went to the cemetary three times!!! It was so amazing and different to any cemetary is australia! A fascinating experience. So much history and famous people are buried there. I would recommend it to anyone wanting to absorb history and just feel like they are in another world. The access was easy, guided tours are held, but you can happily wander around on your own. Allow a few hours if you truly enjoy getting close to this Country's past.

An Experience!. So beautiful, you could get lost in this little city of tombs. Its located in a metropolitan area with high-rise buildings in the background. The stray cats add even extra charm. You will be lucky to get close to Evita's grave though, there was a line for it. We enjoyed the little walk-around.

What a beautiful place to spend an afternoon. I just returned from a trip to Buenos Aires with friends and I'm so glad they suggested we visit La Recoleta Cemetery. I was not familiar with it and would have missed it otherwise.The place is amazing. It is a very historical cemetery that was opened in 1822. It is absolutely huge and right in the middle of the city in the Recoleta neighborhood. I love taking pictures on vacation and could have spent hours in this place. Everywhere you look there is a beautiful old cross, angel or sculpture of some type. The monuments are weathered and some have plants and grass growing out of them but this just adds to the mystique and personality of the place.The rows of plots go on and on and since the monuments are all huge and above ground they form quite a maze. You can literally almost get lost roaming around. Each structure is more impressive than the last and they are all quite unique.Of course, the most popular spot in the cemetery is the Duarte family structure which includes the final resting place of Eva Perone.The place was hauntingly beautiful and should be a must-stop when visiting Buenos Aires. Especially if you're a photography enthusiast.

THE Cemetery. Full of history and architecture. Not only Eva Perón, presidents of Argentina, Nobel Prize winners, but a granddaughter of Napoleon is buried there.http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/La_Recoleta_Cemetery
art and history. this cemetery is unique in many formsthe famous Evita rest in peace herethe amount of sculpures is amazing is a peacefull please in a beautiful neighborhood

very unique place. Very peaceful and full of history. Enjoyed the beautiful monuments with intricate art work and sculptured and unusual layout. Was nice to see Evita's burial site - but it was hard to find. One of the must see places in Buenos Aires IMHO.

Peaceful Beauty and History. You will not believe the peace, beauty, extravagance, and history of this beautiful cemetary. There are unbelieveably gorgeous masoleums lining small pathways. The statues, tombstones,and design are really breathtaking. Although I didnt know who many of the historical figures were (other than Evita), the beauty is so incredible that it is a must-see. I took many pictures but a camera or book simply cant contain the imagery.Make sure you get a map!

Unbelievable, City of the Dead!. As we entered the cemetery, we were amazed at the sight.It looked as though it were a little city. Beautiful little "houses" on avenues.We gave it the endearing term "City of the Dead". Beautiful, amazing, incredible.......the adjectives are endless. When visiting Buenos Aires, the Recoleta Cemetary simpley must be included in your sightseeing list. You will not be disappointed. We visited in may 2012, but had to select a more current date for this review. Be sure to all a few hours to fully take it all in and enjoy your time there.

Astonishing. I've been to Recoleta's Cemetery with my husband and I have to warn you: the place is beautiful. Full of statues, stone carvings and luxurious ornaments on tombstones and mausoleums. In a winter's sunny day this was a stunishing place, really rich and surprising. But with all the respect for the marvelous Evita, her tomb was never the best thing in this place. This cemetery is really impressive.

Beautiful must see in Buenos Aires. This place is amazing. If you can go on a Sunday, you can walk around this beautiful cemetery that is layed out like a small town, and you can find some unique hand made items to take home from the street fair on Sundays.. You won't be disappointed if you take the time to enjoy Recoletta Cemetery.
Great Park on Weekends. This is a wonderful place to sit and people watch, or wander through the faire on a Sunday. Lots of grass areas, many craft/food sellers, and good restaurants.
Must visit!. Recoleta Cemetery is a place where you can find people from the high society and Aristocrats.Beautiful architectural design.
amazing cemetery. la recoleta is an amazing cemetery with lots of beautiful statues right in the middle of Buenos Aires a must visit

so much legends. if you understand Spanish, look out for Eduardo Lazzari "el historiador de Buenos Aires" page on Facebook and join one of the guided visits he organize. Every Sunday at 4 PM a different moment of the history of Argentina is told there where everything ended: the cementery

Amazing architecture! Yes, in a cementery!. I love cemeteries. They tell you so much about the history of a city. Strolling through the Recoleta cemetery, you can see the hay day of Buenos Aires of the early 20th century by seeing the ornate tombstones of that era. The architecture of some of the mausoleums is so impressive. Truly a must see to experience what 20th century wealth was like.If you don´t likes cats, beware. There are a ton of them.
Spooky and artsy at once. An interesting mixture of history, art and peaceful sorroundings. Take your camera with you and roam around to make discoveries or take a guided tour.

Has to be seen to be believed. It seems a little strange to be reviewing a cemetery, but honestly, you have to see it to believe it.The main tomb people head to see it that of Eva Perone, better known to many of us from the musical as Evita.Frankly, her tomb is not the reason we went, and had it been I would have been disappointed, there are so many more tombs that are architecturally more striking.You can buy a map on the way in for next to nothing and even if you are just wondering we found this a great help. The cemetery is huge and it was nice just to know where you were sometimes.We spent a couple of hours here and morbid as it sounds I took loads of photos as turning every corner revealed another wonder.It is humbling that there are 'normal' family tombs here to and you do have to remember not to pry too much as many of the tombs are sealed only by a metal gate and you can easily see the memorials inside. Some are really only and crumbling, but this somehow added to the overall experience. Definitely worth a visit if your in Buenos Aries, no matter how sceptical you are about touring a cemetery, just do it.

Superb experience. This was my first visit to a cemetery while visiting another country and what a superb experience it was! Recoleta Cemetery should defiantly be on your list of attractions to visit while in Buenos Aires. Take an hour or so to scroll around the enormous tombs, enjoy the beautiful sculptures located throughout the cemetery and take a few photos (be creative) to capture this famous tourist sight.

Beautiful!!!. Walk around the neighborhood Recoleta with a first stop in the morning in the Recoleta Cemetery is one of my favorite things to do in Buenos Aires. Amazing monuments... an indulgence for the dead! It is a great place for pictures and a wow experience (since going to cemetery is not usually on top of the list for tourism and entertaining)... I visit it every time I go to Buenos Aires... definitely recommend.

Unusual place to visit on a holiday but it's impressive if not eerie.. It's quite unbelievable how much money must have been spent on constructing the tombs here considering how poor the country is. The cemetery is big with rows on rows of tombs.Lots of the tombs have been damaged over the years, some on purpose and items have been broken or stolen. A short walk around will be enough to see it all.The tomb of Eva Peron (Evita) is not the easiest to to find. You will need to look for the family name Duarte. There is a black lamppost with a light shining at the tomb if you get stuck. Directions: enter cemetery and it is along a row on the left hand side about two thirds of the way down. Some friends said that staff would not tell them the location. Another friend who went said that all the 'noteable' graves/tombs are located on a map.

Unique experience. Visiting a cemetery is not usually thevfirst thing one does in a new city. But the Recoleta cemetery, home to Evita's tomb and mausolea of Argentine generals and famous families is definitely a must see. We walked around these grand monuments to the dead, many of which resembled little churches with guardian angels and fanciful scupltural elements. We stayed over an hour, walking around and observing the workers who were busy polishing or repairing these edifices. Some of the buildings had evidentlt fallen on hard times, which makes one think about what it takes to maintain these family homes for life after life.

Alone time. The wonderful thing about Buenos Aires is that you need to walk - although the taxis are cheap and ubiquitous. But walking allows you to see so much more. So it is that I found myself dawdling about in Recoleta Cemetery. I am not sure whether I was simply reacting to the environment, but I did seem to, well, catch a bit of an aroma there. Again, it may have been my imagination... It is a large cemetery and one is captivated by the ornate and excessive architecture of the mausoleums. Interestingly, one leaves the cemetery without a feeling of sadness despite the obvious tragedies that are entombed there.

Wow!. When I first walked in it was a wow! I'd never been anywhere like it before!! Got accosted by a guide who, when she found out I was from the uk, decided to speak to me in a cockney accent & persuade me to buy a map for £1!! Bit of a rip-off but the cemetery itself is free & I left the map in my b&b for someone else to use. Everyone goes to see the tomb of Eva Peron (myself included) but it's definitely worth a wander about especially if you've never really been anywhere like that before!

Facinating view of rich no more. Excellent afternoon strolling the architecture of the dead, all unique and grandiose. Money was no object, only vanity. Inside the house cat followed our leftovers for blocks. Outside was fresh hippie fair with very original art worth buying.

Beautiful - great photography spot . There is so much more to this place than Evita's final resting place. Once you have been past her burial site take some time away from "usual" pathway and explore the hauntingly beautiful statues, mausoleums and graves. For people seeking great photo opportunities, there is lots to discover here and its the perfect place to take some quiet time and soak up the history.

Majestic cementery. This is an incredible Cemetery for me this is one of the best sites to see in Buenos Aires. The tombs are so beautiful and majestic.It wasn't easy to navigate but for only a few pesos you can paid to get on a tour.

No where else like it. I've been to lots of places in the world but only a few have given me a sense of awe: Venice, Alcatraz Prison, Pompeii, The Colosseum, The Karnack Temple; and now Recoleta Cemetery can be added to this list.The cemetery is, quite obviously, in the Recoletta district and my friend and I got there using the Subte and then about a 25 min walk, however there were lots of buses that go nearer to the site. We went on a Monday morning as my guide book - lonely planet - said that the English speaking tours ran that day. However, when we arrived at the cemetery the lady told us that the English speaking tours were on Tuesdays, so make sure you check this. So, we bought a map for 15 pesos and she told us where Evita's tomb was and that was that. The map gives you a suggested route and who the mausoleums belonged to, but that's about it really, no information on who that person was or any explanation about their story or indeed the architecture of the mausoleum. So I think if you can get a guide it would be well worth it.The site has 4,800 vaults and is laid out like a small village - honestly, that's what it looks like: streets upon streets of mausoleums with varying degrees of size, architecture and age. Some of the mausoleums date from 1850s and some of them are from 1980s. Some of them are small and simple vaults and some of them are so big, ornate and decorated with statues that they look more like small chapels! ...hence my sense of awe. Evita's vault is also a surprise, but I won't spoil it here.The entrance to the cemetery is free and is open from 7am to 6pm every day. Obviously, it is still a cemetery and families will still be visiting to pay their respects to their loved ones, so it goes without saying that you MUST be respectful.If you want a great view of the whole place, then head to the shopping mall at the side of the cemetery. If you go to the top floor McDonald's, they have a balcony which gives you an impressive view of the whole site.

Beautiful and fascinating. A beautiful, tranquil and fascinating place. This cemetery is one of the highlights of the six days I spent in Buenos Aires. It contains the tomb of Evita and many of the country's national heroes and gives a good idea of the city's history

Very eerie but a must!. An odd experience to say the least. Streets upon streets of what look like mini houses, many of them you can peer through the doors and see the coffins, flowers, photos of the dead. Very eerie but peaceful at the same time. I failed to find the Peron family grave and had to ask. Well worth a trip, plus it's free!

Unique Architecture and History. Visiting a cemetery doesn't sound like the most exciting time, but we loved the Recoleta Cemetery. We self guided ourselves using an app that a local historian has released and learned so much, and got some wonderful pictures. If you're tired from walking around, we recommend the La Biela cafe immediately in front of the cemetery for a coffee afterwards.

Stunning Cemetery. Open between 8am-6pm daily, Recoleta Cemetery was one of the highlights of our five days in Buenos Aires. The final resting place of some of the city's wealthiest and most influential people, is contains a fascinating assortment of crypts, many elaborately decorated. Sadly, a few are poorly maintained, leaving the fragile and cobwebbed coffins exposed. (This does, however, add to the atmosphere.) Don't miss the tomb of Eva "Evita" Peron, the beloved first lady of Argentina. Word to the wise: despite the fact that her tomb is adorned with flowers from her admirers, it can be tricky to find as evidenced by the groups of confused people searching for it throughout the cemetery. There is a map at the front entrance and you can find her burial place by counting the cemetery rows and number of tombs. Take a picture of it as a reference. Wish we'd realised that before we spent more than an hour searching for her tomb in a wild panic as closing time approached, For other tombs of interest refer to Wikipedia's entry on the site, as it contains an extensive list and photographs of the tombs. For animal lovers, the place is heavily populated by well-tended cats. Apparently there is about 80 of them. This starts to feel creepy as sunset approaches, when considering the legend that a cat leaping over a grave will create a vampire...

A Must See- Watch out for Pickpockets. This cemetery, which is full of elegant, amazing mausoleums, must be seeen. The mausoleums are very close together, so you have to look carefully to see the gorgeous detail on each one. And, with row after row of mausoleums, you could spend hours wandering through. Note the amazing work done in marble. There were many street-sellers outside, and our guide warned us to take off ALL jewelry in and around the cemetery as theft is rampant. But take 2 hours and see this amazing place.
Amazing Attraction. A must attraction to visit.You can spend many hours in cemetery looking at the various styles of burial typesThe history is amazing and so serene
