Most beautiful cemetery I've ever been to!. The graves are so beautiful but still so haunting! It's very nice to walk around inside the cemetery, read the tombstones and see all the nice things that were written about people. It's also interesting to see the old graves that haven't been kept, they're creepy though. Highly unusual and recommendable!Visited August 2013

This should be a must-see. This cemetery is beautiful. It is amazing to wonder the "streets" and marvel at the magnificent graves and tombs of Argentinas finest. I enjoyed finding Evita's grave most (because I sang in Evita) and it felt like we were connecting with the Argentinians. We visited on Monday morning and there were not many tourists, so i recommend this sort or weekday time. Definitely a must-see.

OMG--the most amazing cemetery anywhere!. Yes, so even though Eva Peron is buried here, and that is reason enough to go visit, you have never seen anything like this above ground architecturally beautiful cemetery! The streets are in a grid pattern and each structure, each mausoleum is a beauty unto itself. The architectural ornamentation, the gates, doorknobs, the positioning of all of these crypts were just breathtaking..weird to say for a cemetery, but you have to see it for yourself!

Take the free guided tour. Visited on a Friday afternoon and there were lots of people, mainly tourists taking photos, particularly at Evita's tomb. I took a free guided tour (available in Spanish: Tu-F 9:30am, 11am, 3pm; English: Tu, Th 11am; Italian: Wed 11am) which provided insights and storys about the lives of some of the prominent people buried here. A map can be purchased at the entrance for ARS 15 (USD 2). The cemetery is laid out like a city and has many small passageways which can be explored. One of the main differences between this cemetery and others in the world is that you can see the coffin of the deceased through the mausoleum door or window.

Such an amazing place of history-and beauty. The juxtaposition of the beauty of the architecture, history of those buried there and the sad reality of all those who have passed is very unique. A must see in Buenos Aires. In the old wealthy part of the city called Recoleta, it is very easy to get to. the old church and Synagogue is a must as well. Great restaurants, parks and easy walking make this a special thing to do to get a sense of the city's long and important history. Amazing group of individuals and their families.

Village of the Resting. It really is: Recoleta Cemetry is a village in itself. I could see it was extensive from the outside but as you enter streets of mausoleums open up. Just wander and sit in various places to appreciate the place. Some of the tombs are mini architectural masterpieces. A film set could not better this.

I want to be laid to rest there!. This is my third time in Argentina, and this is always my first stop! I love the fact it's in the heart of the city, and over looked by people's apartments and houses. It's so tranquil and calming, and very interesting also!

A Must Visit! Take a tour so you don't miss things. And see it from above. When we lived in Palermo in the late 90s I used to give a free, impromptu cemetery highlights tour when I happened to be here and people asked me where things were. We've been here many times. There are so many intricate and interesting mausoleums and stories of those who are buried here! People come here to see Evita's mausoleum, but honestly I don't find hers to be as special as many others. I like to just sit on the cement benches in the shaded courtyard which is straight in from the entrance at one of the 'hubs' of the hub and spoke layout. Even our 6yo enjoyed the visit... esp the cats! I wouldn't touch the cats, btw.Some tips...- I highly recommend a tour. If you just go there solely to see Evita's mausoleum then you've wasted your time, imo. - There's an English tour at 11am on Tues and Thurs that forms at the entrance -- check with your hotel to ensure that hasn't changed. - Nuestra Senor de Pilar is a catholic church offering English masses with entrance on the same side as the entrance to the cemetery. - On Saturday's there is a market in the area in front of the entrance. Really unique things on offer. We negotiated considering the blue rate when paying USD.- You can also go the Etoile Hotel 14th floor for a great view from above. We didn't this time, but we did sit in their lobby for the extreme air con! - People do blue rate money exchanges in the area surrounding the cemetery. Safer than Calle Florida, imo. It's a seriously significant savings.- There was no fee to enter. I heard that sometimes people stand outside handing out maps and make it sound like you're paying them an entrance fee.

Very Interesting. This was included in our city tour.We were here in Jan 2014.We went there early in the morning as with lots of tours arriving together it gets very busy and it is quite narrow in places.The tombs are very intersting and listening to the tour guide some of the stories of the people are sad of course but its nice to hear them .You could spend a lot of time there and if we were in BA longer i would of gone again to take more photos.The craftmanship of some of the sculptures is amazing.Evita is buried there in the family tomb which is nice to see,but it does get crowded down that avenue.A very interesting place to visit and not morbid.

Go for the crypts rather than the names. We went to the Recoleta Cemetery in December 2013. We joined the 'free' tour of the cemetery, in English, run on Thursdays at 11 am. It was a very hot day when we were there, with little shade. If you're there on a similarly hot day, take an umbrella. The cemetery was very interesting and photogenic, with some excellent sculptures and decorations on the crypts. Evita Peron's mausoleum is not the most attractive or interesting one there. The cemetery is relatively compact and you can see it in about an hour - which is roughly how long the tour took.
Fascinating. Really interesting for a wander round and set in a lovely area of BA. Evita's is also buried here but it's fascinating to see the tombs of notable portenos!

Extraordinary. This is a beautiful Cemetery, probably one of the best places to see in Buenos Aires.So much history. Each tomb is more beautiful than the next. It was a bit complicated to navigate, The entry fee was just 50 pesos.
Haunting.... I don't actually mean that in the ghostly sense but in a more profound one - a monument to those interred there as well as to the passing of time.

A Very interesting cemetery. We visited the Recoleta Cemetery in December, 2013 as part of a private tour with our friends. The cemetery was very interesting. The method of maintaining and owning a burial crypt is unusual. Of course we passed by Evita Peron's mausoleum. The cemetery is quite large but can be seen in about an hour.

beautiful. This was a very nice stroll. Dispite the crowds you had a chance to walk among a quiet and shady area. They need more places to sit and reflect. They don't need the folks trying to sell you toilet paper. It was nice to see where Evita now finally rests.

Cemetery with a difference. We stayed in Urban Suites Recoleta Hotel on 24-25 December 2013, just opposite of the Recoleta Cemetery. It was open on 25 December 2013. There were many streets and avenues within the cemetery for us to explore. Both sides were mausoleums. Most of them were magnificent and monumental. We were finding where Eva Duarte de Peron mausoleum. We met a gentleman. He came to visit his ancestors mausoleum. So he brought us to Eva Peron mausoleum. There were flowers at her door. We even bought a book 'City of Angels. The History of Recoleta Cemetery' from Omar Lopez Mato.

Interesting but not as spectacular as I expected. I love visiting cemeteries, and have been to some very old and truly awesome like the one in Milan, so maybe our expectations were a little high.This is a lovely place and it has some beautiful tombs, but you should have a guide to really appreciate it. Evita's tomb which is the main attraction is quite small and unremarkable, but it is a nice walk, it is clean and shady.

One of a Kind. There are dozens of "streets" and "avenues" in the cemetery, all lined with mausoleums on both sides. I don't know how many are in the cemetery, but it feels like thousands. You can easily walk around for an hour or two, just looking at the different sizes, styles, and ages of the monuments. Remember to look up and out every once in a while to get the feel for where the cemetery actually is - right in the middle of a busy city!

One of the most Important Attraction in Buenos Aires. It's a little odd that a cemetery is an attraction when visiting Buenos Aires, but this is a must place to visit to get the feel of what is important to the people in Buenos Aires. The place is huge and some of the grave structures are extremely elaborate.

Years of diverse and beautiful architectural styles. This was a lovely place to wonder around and relax. There were no directions, in English, that would have told you how to find Eva Peron's resting place. They did advertise a FREE tour in English, BUT when you asked about it, it wasn't free at all. We enjoyed wondering around and asked a maintenance man, who directed us to the Duarte (Peron) family grave..It is covered with flowers and easily spotted when you are in the right area. When you leave the cemetery the Recoleta area is a beautiful walk around shopping area. There is a mall and some very nice upscale shops and restaurants in the area. Lovely way to spend a few hours.

A must see in BA. It's fascinating to walk among the family vaults in the cemetery and see the variety. Old and new, perfectly maintained vs. fallen into disrepair. Also, don't miss the Evita Peron's final resting place (after they finished carting her corpse around the world: hiding in Italy and keeping it in Juan Peron's dining room in Spain).
good architectural values. Most of you, just like myself, head to this cemetery to see the one of Eva Peron. But once you take a step in, you will be astonished by the architectural values of each.

Very interesting. I have never thought I would like a cemetery so much, but this is no ordinary cemitery. It is amazing to walk around and observe the grandour of the mausoléus, it is a open museum for sure as art is concerned. I think is nice to have a guide with you to put into context the allegory that goes around, if you undertand spanish very well then the ceremitery does a guided visit for free everyday at 3pm, otherwise get your own guide and your visit will be more meaninful. The surrounding area is also very nice, you have shopping centres, bars, cafés all around it.

Peacefully Historic. Like other historic cemeteries, the air is quiet and offers a great atmosphere to reflect. It is absolutely beautiful. You can easily spend hours wandering around around the cemetery. A must in BsAs!

Truly spectacular. Absolutely worth the visit! The cemetery is free to explore & is the resting place of more than 5000 of Argentinas rich and famous family's- including the famous Evita. This Cemetry is more of an art museum than a grave yard! Make sure your camera battery is charged-there are many photos opportunities!

Hard to explain liking a cemetery. This is not to be missed. We went and visited on our own one day, bought a book on the way out. We read about the cemetery and the people in it and their stories. Then before we left BA we went back for another visit with an English speaking guide this time and actually it was good to visit again. It is kind of strange, but it truly is something to see and one of the top three in the world. Very important people to Argentina are in here.

Walking the history of Buenos Aires. Recoleta Cemetery is beautiful, historic, and interesting - and should be a "must-see" when visiting Buenos Aires. While the cemetery is known for being the final resting place of Eva Peron, it is also the final resting place for other notables - Carlos Pellegrini, Roque Saenz Pena, a professional boxer, and a Nobel Laureate, among other Presidents, Generals, diplomats, and historical figures. Prior to visiting, it might be helpful to take a look at the internet and see who is buried here - at the entrance to the cemetery, there is a map identifying where the mausoleums are located.The cemetery itself is a beautiful and eclectic conglomeration of different styles of mausoleums - some are quite traditionally religious with domes, angels, and crosses. Others are quite modern edifices of granite and glass. Regardless, it is fascinating to see them and read the plaques commemorating those buried there. The cemetery was designed by a French architect. Also interesting are the stories about some of the ghosts said to haunt the cemetery and some of the more horrific stories about how some came to be buried here.I highly recommend - it is like walking the history of Buenos Aires when you visit.
Great. If you like places like cemetary, dont forget to visiting REcoleta's one. Historic! Enjoyed a lot, even being a cemetary..lol

Incredible. The Recoleta Cemetery is one of the most incredible sights Buenos Aires has to offer. It literally takes me days to get through it all. One of my favorite things to do is to write down the names from some of the more interesting tombs and then when I get home I look them up and read their individual histories. Of particular note is the tomb of Luis Ángel Firpo. There is a statue in front of him wearing a robe and what i correctly assumed to be shoes for a boxer. His story is incredible, particularly his fight against Jack Dempsey. Anyway, I would strongly encourage you to plan on at least one full day to see all the great sites that the Recoleta Cemetery has to offer.

Dead Centre of town. Very historic cemetery, with the grave of Eva Peron being the highlight of the tour. It is rather large, on over 15 acres or 6 hectares, so if you plan on visiting the whole thing, put aside some time! We had a tour guide who was very informative and added greatly to teh whole experience, would recommend.

Very interesting place. The Recoleta Cemetery is a very interesting place where you can see a lot of art sculptures and history. And it's interesting too see how they deal with death. I think it's a very cultural program!

City of the Famous Dead. This most famous of all cemeteries in Buenos Aires has, among many other notables, the final resting place of Evita Peron. It is quite hard to locate if you just wander aimlessly, but there is a large scale map display to the left of the main entrance door and you can easily figure out how to get to her grave, or to visit that of some other notables.

Get here early. Recoleta Cemetery is a place to be enjoyed in peace. If you can, get here as early as you can. It open at 8am. At this time you will only be sharing the place with a couple of cleaners sweeping away and a number of stray cats. By 10am streams of tour groups start arriving. Everyone comes to look at Eve Peron's tomb but make sure you spend time just taking in the mini architectural masterpieces of peoples tombs. Inside these little chapel you can see dusty coffins and wilting plants in vases. It is all rather melancholy. Statues of winged angels decorate many a mausoleum. The cats wandering the grounds seem so chilled.

Graves of Argentinean history. Many tourists go to his cemetary just to see Eva Peron's grave, That's a good reason. But it's not the only one. Argenitneans and foreign tourists can see not just the history of Agentina in ther famous graves but also the cemetery of the local upper class. And, to some extent, the ememery is part of Recoleta neighbourhood, one of the tradtional and posh areas of Buenos Aires.

Absolutely stunning.. If you are visiting the Recoleta area and love history, you must stop by this cemetery. It is completely free, although there are guides for hire available. I would recommend buying a map at the entrance for 15 pesos (there is usually a guide or someone selling them), or bringing your own print out. Must see areas include the tomb of Rufina Cambaceres (a teenager who was apparently buried alive), the tomb of Liliana Crociati de Szaszak, who died on her honeymoon (topped with a statue of the woman and her favorite dog), and the tomb of Domingo Faustino Sarmiento. Eva Peron is buried there as well, but the mausoleum is fairly subdued, other than the colorful flowers decorating the area. I went here twice and felt I didn't see everything there was to see. If you enjoy beautiful sculpture in a quiet, spiritual place, go here.

Fabulous historic place. I was very surprised when I walked into the cemetery. Is like going back in time. Definitely a great place for taking photos and walk around. The Evita's vault is not that great, there are other much more complex and beautiful vaults.

different than any other cemetery. As soon as we walked in, we saw a woman selling maps to the cemetery. Glad to have bought one. this place is massive and without it, you will not be able to find all the historic people and their families buried here (including Eva Peron). If you take a guided tour, you will learn about the most iconic and important people that have influenced Argentina and its culture.

Atmospheric cemetary. The Recoleta cemetery is worth a visit, and a wander around to see how the wealthy of Argentina bury their dead. The monuments, memorials, statutes and plaques are moving, amusing and atmospheric. If you are searching for Evita, then look for her family name, Duarte, and not her married name of Peron!

Walk in, respect history. Buenos Aires is a huge city but I was told to go and see this cemetery, and I’m glad I did. Its massive so don’t expect to see it all but do walk around for an hour and take in some of the history of this fine city.

Argentina's most iconic cemetery. This is a must-see if you visit Buenos Aires. Its atmosphere is unique, and a significant part of the country's history (and its golden years) is reflected in its vaults and monuments.

Epitomizes Argentina. Use Guide. This is a breathtaking living cemetery in the middle of the city. Not only is it gorgeous, it's interesting. Old wealthy families are still being laid to rest here to this day. Like Argentina, there is great lavish beauty and heartbreaking poverty; some graves are neglected, rusting over, with trash and weeds. Others are marble masterpieces, with fresh cut flowers delivered daily.This is one site where you should VISIT WITH A TOUR, not because it's dangerous, but because it's much more interesting when you hear all the stories.

Brilliant visit - the tour is a must! . I am so thankful that we joined the tour around the cemetery, otherwise we would have been wondering aimlessly about not having any information. The guide was amazing, passionate, informative, friendly and made sure everyone's questions were answered! The tour took us to some of the integral mausoleums showing us the architectural difference from when some of the first mausoleum where built and the final ones. The guide also showed us some of the most infamous mausoleums including famous politicians, writers and Evita Peron. The history, architectural changes and political history was fascinating. Our guide also told us some really interesting tales of people that had passed and how the significance of the cemetery has changed over the years. Tours are in English on Tuesday and Thursdays at 11am and go for 1.5 hours. They are free of charge (so is entry to the cemetery) but you should leave a tip at the end! Tour is cancelled if it rains.

Interesting. Interesting checking out all the sites, seeing recognizable names etc. Pity about the trees growing out of some of the tombs but seems to be a bit of cleaning up being done. Overall can spend an hour or two just looking. The toilets could be improved a lot, not the nicest ones around.
worth a visit. I wasn't very interested at first but was presently surprised. Very beautiful tombs. It was an interesting cultural experience.

Fascinating Place. Macabre perhaps but a must. Amazing ornate crypts a short walk from the bars of La Recoleta in Buenos Aires. Not sure if it is still used as a cemetery or not but a great place to visit. Eva Peron's family crypt is there (The Duartes) and her body sits underground inside the crypt. Very elaborate crypts all around the cemetery. A bit like some of New Orleans or Paris cemeteries. Worth a visit.

So easy to be flippant, but a must-see. We visited on Sunday 9 March 2014The Recoleta Cemetery is a place that any visitor to Buenos Aires must make time to visit, If for no other reason than it is almost unique in its concept, and sheds light on Argentina’s history and the character of its people. To me, the cemetery did not have the hushed and somber tone of a place of death, or even the religious piety of a Westminster Abby where many of Britain’s famous are buried; but more of a window into Argentina’s somewhat turbulent history.I believe English language tours are to be had on certain days, but I thought that might give us information overload, so we chose to wander around on our own with a couple of mausoleums in mind that we wanted in particular to see. EVITA’s of course, everyone goes to see that one. It is the Duarte famine's tomb and it is not the grandest, but is never without fresh flowers I was told.Somewhat wilted when we were there.The one that I particularly wanted to see was that of Rufina Cambaceres, I had read her story and learned of this human tragedy. We are not people of faith, and have no expectation of an afterlife, but can certainly feel for the family of this young woman who was mistakenly buried alive. The tomb is both beautiful and poignant, and is worth the visit alone, and is recognized as a masterpiece.All the “streets” are named and you can purchase a map as you walk in the gate, but we didn’t want to spend time pouring over maps, so just wandered. It worked for us, and we found the two in particular we wanted to see.

Not overly impressed. I'll admit I'm not the religious sort so I didn't have high expectations upon arrival. If viewing crypts is your thing then this place will fascinate you endlessly with they sheer volume of crypts and architecture, some of which I'll admit are impressive but I found most to be unkept.Lots of cats wondering the grounds which I don't know is a sign of something eerie.Eva Perons family crypt is not well sign posted but does have fresh flowers like most people suggest.

Eerie and fascinating. The crypts range in conition from perfect preservation to complete disrepair and neglect. The architecture is amazing, and Eva Peron's is about the only crypt with fresh flowers. It's amazing that she is so beloved, even today.Worth a walk through-quite fascinating.

Art and memories everywhere. I was kinda reluctant about going to a cemetery for sightseeing; seemed a bit creepy. But it all went away as soon as I saw the entrance for the cemetery: it's just beautiful! Since it's always been a bit like a display of power and wealth for the rich families, the cripts are major artworks, like tiny castles with statues and iron gates. Didn't look for the famous Evita cript, though. And it is really strange to the the exposed coffins inside most crips, some broken and decayed with the years, others brand new, it sure seems almost unreal! Don't miss it. Nearby, plenty of attractions for a whole day out.

A cemetery.... That's quite a mournful attraction, but anyway... it has beautiful statues, lots of cats and a huge line to see Evita's grave. Choose a smile or a sad face when taking a picture with it.

Amazing place. I wouldn't normally decide to visit a cemetery while on my holidays but I had heard a lot about this place and from what I had seen it looked impressive. And I wasn't wrong. There are guided tours available in English as well as other languages however we set off on our own to explore. It's beautiful and each tomb is a unique piece of art. Some are really old with broken windows and you can see right in and others you can see are still in use. It's like a town just full of tombs and you can easily lose your way.It's free, and is definitely worth a visit if you are in Buenos Aires and the surrounding area is lovely to explore too.

The final resting place of Evita Perron. While cemetery's are not our normal destination this place is quite unique in the quality of the beautiful crypts that house the remains of the wealthy and famous of BA. None more famous than Evita herself. One shares a quiet moment and reflects on the woman who truly cared for her fellow Argentinians.

Incredible tombs. It seems that each tomb is more impressive than the next. Some you can even see the casket through the glass. Some of these tombs are very old and yet they had brand new locks. I don't understand why one would put a new lock on decades old tombs, and it wasn't even Evita's tomb. Just outside the cemetery is a wonderful park. I was there on a Sunday and there were lots of vendors selling trinkets. The most interesting part for me was their attitudes. They didn't seem to care if you bought anything. Every other country I've been to, they practically harass you into purchasing something.

a cemetery that is an art history open air exhibit!. This is an incredible collection of art in fact one of 3 most artistic cemeteries in the worl together with the one in Genoa and the one in Paris. There are guided tours in English on Tuesday and Italian on Wednesday at 11:00 am and in Spanish every day several times. Many publicly known figures are buried there like Evita Peron, Raul Alfonsin, héroes from Independence Wars, artists, scientists like Nobel Prize Federico Leloir, and sports celebrities. You should plan for a sunny day and 2 hours visit.

Not to be missed. While in my mind, nothing will ever match the American Cemetery in Normandy (the Punchbowl in Oahu is also very impressive), Recoleta Cemetery is by far the most unique. Located in the eponymous high-end Buenos Aires neighborhood, the avenues of impressively ornate crypts of some of Argentina's most renowned statesmen and academics is awesome. Some of the crypts are unbelievably detailed (to the point of ostentatious) and some are actually so decrepit that one could reach in and touch the caskets. You can literally spend hours just wandering around and I made two trips over four days.Yes, Eva Peron's crypt is here (and, yes, EVERYONE goes and sees it), but the random presidents, generals, Nobel prize winners and others are what makes this unforgettable.I would definitely do this with a guide rather than by yourself. We got much more out of our second visit, which was guided, than the first. A word of warning. The area in front of the cemetery is a have for hucksters, vendors, etc. Do not get scammed into buying an "unofficial" guide and watch for pickpockets. It is not "dangerous", just annoying and by no means should it prevent you from going. This is truly a Buenos Aires "can't miss".

Cemetery-best restaurants: interesting combination.... Visiting La Recoleta cemetery is a must see due its central location among parks and beautiful avenues and the pomposity of the tombs and statues. Al around La Recoleta you will be able to dine in the numerous, excellent restaurants. Guess what is their main plate? You guessed right: the famous Argentinian meat barbecued....You can not missed either one....

Weird, but true…one of the best things to see in BA. The tombs and statues are a must see in BA. Around every corner there's something fascinating. Strange to say, but my favorite thing to see in BA. In a safe, beautiful neighborhood.

Amazing. The stories of this place are both romantic and horrifying and our tour guide Vanessa made it an interesting visit.The burial place of Eva Peron is quite ordinary but the history of why is fascinating.Well worth a visit.

Nice to walk around and find Evita's grave. We had this on our list to do before coming to BA and we actually accidentally found it while we were walking around the city (before we actually planned to go) so we went in with the mission find Evita's grave. We did end up asking a few people or even following tour groups to find Evita's grave! Fun afternoon.

Amazing Stone Masonry! Must see!. It seems strange to be giving a 5 star rating to a cemetery...When we got to Buenos Aires we checked the top things to do, and this cemetery came up, although it seemed rather morbid to have a top tourist attraction the cemetery, we figured we should go.. when in Rome and all that.The city of the dead is such an accurate description, it really is like a little city all on its own.It is just jaw dropping to see the detail that goes into the statues, some of these crypts are bigger than churches I have seen.It does seem a little eerie, but is definitely a must see if you are here, plus we all know of Evita Person, so it is part of Argentinas history to see where she is laid to rest, and the story that goes with it.Take your camera, as you will want to get some pics to marvel in the Masonry.

A lesson in history. We all know the song "Don't cry for me Argentina" and most everyone has seen or heard of the movie "Evita" with Maddona. and some may even know the history of Eva Peron! When in Bueneos Aires you must never leave without witnessing this piece of history. It would be like going to Paris and not see the Effel Tower. Yes it is a cemetary and it is a grave site. (That's why I didn't rate it excellent) Something overtakes you when you stand in front of the Duarte mausoleum, it makes you more worldly and aware. It kind of overwhelms you. Eva Peron was such a hugh influence in Argentina,and to stand at her final resting place is a must! I still kick myself for not visiting Jimmy Morrison's grave in Paris.

Tombs of the rich and famous. The cemetery has 6,400 mausoleums. The mausoleums are laid out like a city. There are street names for each walkway. The most famous one is the black marble crypt of Evita Peron. We were told there are new flowers there everyday. I think you have to see this if you are in Buenos Aires. When we were there the mosquitos were terrible so be prepared.
Beautiful Historic Cemetary. It was a gorgeous old cemetary in Recoleta accurately described as the city of the dead. Eva Peron is buried in the Duarte family crypt. A must see when you are in BA.

I dont know how to explain this.... but... YOU MUST GO (if it needs to be in 3 words) whoa... I went twice in the same trip because I wanted to see it all over again, its just like stepping into another world! The tombs of the wealthy families and celebrities is just jaw dropping! the intricate designs on the outsides of the tombs and just taking a peak into some of them made me feel so eerie, i loved every second of being here... do yourself a favour and GO... if you like Romanticism and detailed statues you will love it here all the more... the little church afterwards is a nice place to visit, listening to the bells ringing sent shivers down my spine it was beautiful
You have to go, but..... Its not one of Buenos Aires best places. But if you go, and you have to go, be sure to have a Venetian or Paris coffee at cafe Branca. With warm CHOCOLATE on!

If cemeteries are your thing, this is a good one. Elaborate tombs of the wealthy and famous of Argentina. For the outsider, only a few names that you will recognize, but the marble and gilt is worth a look see.

An unusual tourist attraction. I would never had said that a stroll in a cemetery would be something that I would ever do... But would recommend this for the sense if history. We went first thing in the morning and had the place to ourselves. It was a little bit eerie walking down the boulevard of tombs that is a testament to the great and good in BA...The kids seemed to like it.... Only if they fully realised that they were really racing around in a grave yard amongst the dead!!

Interesting historical cementery to visit. It´s a must visit for people who visit Buenos Aires. very interesting as far as you can know a lot of Argentine history specially if you take a guided visit .( advisable) The best day to go is on sundays ( there are guided visits on week ends) and on week ends you can also visit the artisans market outside in the park. Visitors choose to visit Eva Peron tomb but don't limit to it as there are other important tombs and mausoleums and there are interesting stories about them ( eg Rufina Cambaceres tomb, the tomb of the just married girl who is buried with her dog, etc ) and there are also some stories about ghosts in the cementery. You can also visit Del Pilar Church that is next to the cementery and is one of the oldest in the city . The saint wooden statues were made by the indians in 1500 . Please if you go try to keep silence as far as you can also see there people visiting their families and we must respect their moments there.

I'd die to return (on a tour, of course). This resting place of the Argentine upper class allows visitors to experience first hand , the local culture since early 19th century. It provides a valid testimony of the past with a connection to the present and displays interesting moments of Argentine history through the analysis of its stone and marble mausoleums.Among those who are entombed there I would like to highlight Eva Perón Remedios de Escalada de San Martin , Juan Manuel de Rosas and more recently former President Raul Ricardo AlfonsinThe bonus fact is that the cemetery boasts its own ghost: Delfina Cambaceres whose tragic story and following legend will also contribute to visitor's delight.Do not forget to pay a visit to neighbouring Pilar Church and have a tempting treat at nearby trendy restaurants and cafes.

Dont miss it. Recoleta cemetery is a beautifull and cal place to visit, Full of history, architecture, and really nice art all around. This is a nice place to visit and really far from what a creappy cemetey used to be.

Part of Argentina's history.. It's just beautiful. Loads of history here: politicians, artists, and businessmen who made this country what it is. Don't forget to visit Eva Peron's grave, the only one that has flowers on it every day.

A piece of Argentine history. This cemetery, which is really near any if the mains accomadatikns downtown, is a piece of Argentine history, for you to enjoy and get to know. A guided tour is most advisable. Silence should be kept because it is, after all, a burial place, visited by families and friends. I would strongly recommend it. I do not know what the restroom facilities look like. It is better to avoid visiting it at noon because the sun can be bothersome, all year through, except in July-August.
Interesting place to visit. Went there with a couple of friends last year. I really liked it. It's got some interesting tombs and mausoleums, the ones in black marble really caught our attention.

Recoleta Cemetry. There is no other cemetery like Recoleta in the world. The most similar one is in Genoa, Italy.Most of Argentina`s "aristocracy" is buried here, in lavish pantheons . Evita`s tomb can be seen.

Mysterious and fascinating history of Buenos Aires in tombs. This is one of the must-sees of Buenos Aires. Recoleta Cemetery is an extraordinary place, especially for people who are not from a Catholic background. Fortunes have been spent in putting the dead to rest in mini-mansions, arranged in street-like rows. Ornate statues decorate almost every tomb, giving photographers great material for interesting pictures. The cemetery is also wonderfully peaceful, a stark change from the noise and frenetic life of this city.
Recoleta Cemetry. Interesting, slightly macabre and unusual place to spend an hour or two. Eerily like New Orleans, slightly decrepit, hauntingly beautiful , historical. Worth seeing

Impressive Cemetery. Recoleta Cemetery is quite spectacular - there is a huge array of crypts, mausoleums, and tombs of the weathy and well-known Argentine families. Many people visit the cemetery to see Eva Peron's tomb. (She is buried in her family vault so look for the Duarte name. And when you find it, you will probably see flowers there.) There are many decorative examples and the range of architecture is quite amazing. You can spend a long time here, just wandering. It's interesting to see how different families choose to remember their dearly departed loved ones. If you have limited time, you might prefer to hire a guide who can take you to key tombs. You might think that visiting a cemetery is a little macabre, but the atmosphere is actually peaceful and not sombre as you might expect.
Interesting history. We loved looking at all the family history. Would recommend a visit from all interested in local history

Spectacular necropolis of great variety. This cemetery has crypts and mausoleums of many wealthy Argentine families. Often coffins are visible through the doors; some burial places are in disrepair. Many structures are elaborate and impressive. The variety is remarkable. This place is worth a leisurely walk around to see the assortment.On the one hand, a guide is useful to assist with the history of the people buried here. Additionally, if time is limited, then the guide can direct you expeditiously to some of the more significant tombs, such as that of Eva Peron (whose body was shuttled about extensively for political reasons). On the other hand, tours limit the time available and you may feel you have missed too much. The solution would seem to be: first, a visit with a guide, and second, a return on your own to browse.It appears to be relatively safe within the cemetery in the daytime; of course, one should always be aware of people who may linger nearby. No one should leave their pocketbook or backpack open and it is best not to go alone. Don't hand your camera to any stranger to take your picture. Sensible awareness is advisable.Probably it is best to arrange a guide in advance from a reputable agency, perhaps as part of a larger tour. I would hesitate to enlist one of the touts near the entrance.

Great Cementery!. We walked through the recoleta cemetery with some friendsthat we met at our hostel and found it to be very pleasent. The highlight of the place is of course seeing eva perons tomb but there are a lot of other really beautiful examples of architecture within the cemetery

You need to see this place!. For people who appreciate the cemetery art, this is a very interesting place. It feels like you are walking inside a city and the tumble are so high and big! You must visit Eva Perón tumb (under the family name Duarte) and also Nobel Prize,Luis Federico Leloir, Chemistry, (1970). It is a very interesting tour! A must do!

Peaceful. The cemetery is a famous stop on most tourist itineraries; because we were living close by we thought of a quick self-tour, with viewing Evita's tomb as top priority. The cemetery is beautiful with quite a few tombs of porteno families, some left in disregard and some beautifully decorated. To get to Evita's tomb, either look for Duarte family on the map, or walk straight to the 1st statue, turn left and keep walking until a tomb blocks your way, walk around that tomb from the right, turn right at the next alley and walk 20 meters at which point you'll see a crowd and find the tomb.

Simply Astounding. Even if Evita wasnt buried here, it is well worth an afternoon of exploring. It is a combination of city and mausoleum, the tombs are extravagant, and you can wander around for hours observing the history of some of the most important families in Argentine history

To get the best visit... Go when raining haha. Last night we went on a free walking tour that ended at the cemetery which was closed. What our guide described, however, was enough to get us to come back today. But man was it pouring down, thundering and lightning away. Perfect ambience for visiting a cemetery I must say. It was creepy and interesting. Nothing I ever expected to do but I'm glad I did. Definitely worth a walk around!!!

Very Interesting. A very interesting tourist spot..there is probably nothing like it anywhere else in the world. It is free to enter but try and get a map of the cemetery. If you can't get a map, there is a big one on display in the foyer of the entrance. The biggest draw card is Sarah Brun's tomb.....as you enter the cemetery, it is in the direction of 10.00 o'clock.

Amazing necropolis. Seems like the politicians, military heroes, millionaires, actors and other celebrities of Buenos Aires were trying to top each other even in death. This huge cemetery contains an amazing collection of mausolea and statuary dedicated to the memory of people long gone and - one assumes - mostly forgotten, with the notable exception of Eva Peron whose corpse, after a long and undignified odyssee caused by the Argentinian military dictatorship, found its final resting place in the Duarte family mausoleum here (not without irony since her father, senor Duarte, had a separate official family and never married her mother).

wow, but got bitten. Amazing visit, so interesting - however it's now Autumn and after being in BA for three days I got hammered by Mosquitoes at the back of the cemetery. Was so bizarre but I got out of there ASAP! Also an annoying woman putting on an English accent at the entrance saying "I am from the cemetery, I am from the cemetery", trying to sell tour's or whatever, ignore her.

Lots more here then Eva Peron. We went here with a guide who talked about the history of the cemetery and some of the other famous graves, but you don't need one to wander around. There is a free guide map at the entry and people who speak English if you have a question. The cemetery is laid out like a small city with very ornate burial areas, some with very beautiful and some in disrepair. The burial sites belong to individual families not the city and when no family is left to care for the structure, they fall into disrepair. Some have been sold and new ones built (the old family has to remove the bones) It is quite interesting to walk through and see and feel the history here. Not to be missed on any visit to Buenos Aires.

Excellent piece of history. We went without a guide, and used the map in our Fodor's Travel Book. A definite must-see, but I would recommend staying close to a crowd. It can get somewhat desolate and maze-like towards the back of the cemetery and I thought for a moment it would be a good place for bad people to lurk. Not sure about the security there so maybe I'm over reacting. Plan on being amazed by the sheer size and opulence of this place. And be prepared to see real coffins, sometimes stacked 5-high in tombs! Unlike most cemeteries where the inside is pretty hidden from lookers, many of these tombs are elaborate and almost invite you to peek in. Bring your camera.

Love cemeteries. Excellent! I love cemeteries no matter how large or small. This was really the largest I have been to. Many of the musoleums are in ill repair due to the high costs and years that the families have left the area. But still a must to see!

DO NOT MISS!!!!!. This place just blew us away! If you know any history regarding Argentina, then come here and see where so many of the history makers are buried....if you can call it that! This is like a well kept, gated community for the wealthy departed! And seeing Eva Peron's final resting place is quite moving. It's great value too as it is FREE!

Very different cemetery, very cool...if cemeteries can be cool. I don't usually visit cemeteries but made an exception as I heard this one was interesting. Indeed, this was very interesting. It was like a little city for those that wanted to pay homage to themselves once they make the great leap.There wasn't anything creepy about it and it was actually pretty cool. The architecture, tomb styles and how it's settled in the city made it worth a visit.There's no cost to enter so I would make this part of your trip.

So many different genres of architecture!. It does have famous argentinian people buired in it but I enjoy all the different types and styles of architecture that are incorporatred into the tombs/mausoleums! It is a little strange looking into them and seeing caskets but is an experience you should go see if in Buenos Aires!

Cool way to see the past. Like others I had read that the cemetery was worth visiting and thought that was a little morbid. But I followed the throngs and spent about 90 minutes admiring the beautiful tombs and sculptures and stained glass windows. Would have been good to do a tour as I wondered particularly with the less maintained graves whether the family had died out or just didn't care anymore.

Hire a guide for the inside scoop. This beautiful cemetery houses María Eva Duarte de Perón (Evita) among other luminaries. Take the free walking tour or hire a guide (won't cost you much) to get the inside scoop on who's buried here. The most artful tombs have sculptures and work of famous artists - the guide will tell you their full story. You can just walk around but the history behind the place is fascinating.

Pure art. If you want to go to a museum of art , then go there. Don´´t be scare about going to a cementery, the argentinians are accustom to go there because they feel the richness of their country in their past. Is so beatiful and crowded!

Why is this # 32.. Definitely go here. Make sure to take a professional tour so that you can hear the stories and get the history of the tombs and those that are in there. The cafés across the street in Recoleta are a GREAT place to have lunch and spend some time. Do not rush. Take your time enjoy the food, surroundings and people watch.

An interesting way to pass some time. A cemetary may seem like an odd place to spend time while on vacation, but it is definately worth the trip to Recoleta.Lined with market stalls filled with tack, you enter the cemetary where you could wander for hours looking at the varied styles of architecture, wondering about the people burried inside, and getting spooked! You can take free walking tours - we just missed it as it was leaving at 13:15.We wandered for around 45 minutes, saw the Evita grave and some really beautiful sarcphagus and memorials.The park around the cemetary is also really beautiful - the largest trees you'll ever see smack dab in the heart of a large city.

Interesting, beautiful. Have been twice there in the past six years, second time was a few days ago. I found it fascinating, interesting, beatiful and really worth the effort.
Tuesday and Thursday 11AM you can join a free guiided tour in English - a nice way to explore this tomb-city.

Beautiful, peaceful ... never been anywhere quite like it. A beautiful, peaceful place full of history and many interesting stories! A hotspot for photographers and historians. Free. You can wander by yourself, but I recommend grabbing a guide to learn the behind-the-scenes stories that make this place so unique.

Don't miss this site!. Plan to spend a few hours in the area of Recoleta Cemetery. You can visit the church next door too . There is a small museum on the second and third floor of the church and the admission is just 8 pesos. From the windows on the top floor, you can have a good view of the cemetery.There are free tours of the cemetery on Tuesdays and Thursdays at 11am and it attracts big crowds. But look for the private guides which hang out in front. I met George Kleiman (architecture background) and hired him. He was excellent and our tour took about 1 1/2 hours. The $20 fee was very much worth it. He knows all the good stories!

Facinating. Its really worth a visit, especially in good weather for a walk - you can see it as quickly as 15 minutes or take hours checking our each family crypt.In a was walking round this cemetery is like going into the underworld - you can see inside the family tombs to where the coffins are stacked up...its a strange experience, at the same time the whole place is beautiful - every single tomb has been designed and is unique. If you plan on visiting Evita's final resting spot, dont expect it to stand out. Its not one of the main intersections, you will have to find our in advance, ask some people, or walk around and look for one of the ones with flowers (there were flowers when we went and I hear there are always flowers) also there will probably always be a small crowd there...

you should go here is you love Evita and Gardel. I went to this cemetery to see where the most elite people of argentina are buried. I went to see Evita Peron( the queen of the working class and Carlos Gardel the king of Tango. I most say it was very difficult to find them and more to get out. I got lost for an hour, i hope they have a better system now?. it is a very big place, a most go if you love history!!!

Great history lesson and amazing architecture experience. We really enjoyed our walk around the cemetery (approx 70 min.). Tracking the architectural transitions over the years was fascinating. We have two kids (17 &15), and they also found it very captivating.

Not to be missed. Such an interesting place to stroll through and imagine the lives and culture of people who leave behind such ornate and beautiful memorials. My favorite was the mauseloum that had a glass door so you could see the beautiful coffins of the couple buried there and the urn their dog was buried in, along with its picture.
Amazing. I wdn't normally think to visit a cemetery. Architecturally beautiful. Some big egos in there. Well worth seeing.

Creepy and Magical. If you visit BA, you must visit this Cemetery.It is like a charming horror story with many unique tombstones - some are as large as a building.It's beautiful to stroll around the monuments and absorb the silence and magic.

For Evita-adepts a must, for the rest of us a nice place to visit. It is like walking in a small village with small houses, streetlights, an occasional tree and lots of angels, cherubs, crosses and art deco details. We spend a hour or so walking around and spotting famous names.It is a big tourist attraction so come early or half an hour before closing time. Closing time was 17.30 when we got there and the gardians were very strict and refused everybody who tried to come in at 17.35. So be warned.

Awe Inspiring!. Those of us from developed western countries would be accustomed to lawn cemeteries or the more standard variety of cemetery where some ethnic sections boast large monuments dedicated to the deceased - at Recoleta every single grave is marked with either a mausoleum or massive statue. The latter are created with the most expensive of building/ sculpting materials e.g marble, travertine. The artwork on the outside of these final resting palaces is alone worth the visit. There is no entry fee but we chose to purchase a map of the site for 15 pesos - about US $1.50 to $2.00 at the time. The tombs are all numbered on the map but unfortunately you need to be quite the sleuth to find the corresponding numbers on either the avenues or the individual monuments. It was definitely a case of look for the largest crowd to locate the tomb of Eva Peron ! We had been warned about pickpockets at the site but the Saturday morning in March when we visited it was fairly quiet and easy to remain safe. Be warned - some of the tombs have glass display fronts with the coffins on clear display inside. Other very old constructions are in disrepair - we actually stumbled across a cemetery labourer who was in the process of dragging a coffin out from behind a collapsed facade ! He looked a little startled and waved us on urgently ! There are cool stone benches on which to rest and take in the atmosphere - not a morose place - more like a gallery of sorts.

Surprisingly intriguing place. The place is a collection of artful tombs and each one is better than the last. Most of the coffins around here are decorated with religious symbols and symbolic items and makes it more of an art piece than mere remains and most strikingly each had breathtaking statues over each of these graves and in case you miss the feel of being the cemetery, then there are the stray cats around here which reminds of the dangerous grounds you are in. The place boasts of a whole lot of famous personalities as it residents like evita, eva peron and likes of many such prominent argentine figures. If nothing the whole neighborhood of recoleta is beautiful and impressive

Beautiful Place..... Hard to believe it's a cemetery with the beautiful statues and vaults. Seeing where Evita was buried was interesting and walking through the cemetery was actually peaceful. A must visit while in town.

A must see. Wow, at first glance you know this is where the powerful and elite are buried, or should I say on display. The tombs are beautiful and each one a personal reflection. Obviously here to see the site of Eva Peron, however stop and take a look at most of the others. For me 30 min here was more than enough time... And there is a great coffee shop just outside approaching the mall.
A must do!. Very impressive cemetery, might be worth a guided tour. I've never seen so many monuments like little castles or homes for the dead.

Interesting. We took the free English language tour that they give only on Tuesday and Thursdays at 11am. It took about an hour. The place is a tourist attraction and you can see the cemetery on your own without the tour (they have a map in the front that lists who's buried where). We didn't want to think so we took the tour! Easy to get to on your own -- we walked from our hotel in Micro-centro (a long walk 40 minutes). There are several interesting monuments -- you learn their stories by taking the tour -- Evita's tomb is non-descript. Wear bug spray -my husband and I got bit like crazy! Also bring an umbrella or hat -- there is shade but during the tour it may be hard to find!

Wow!. Absolutely worth a visit while in Buenos Aires! Though I did my visit without a guide, I wish I had some background knowledge on some of the tombs. But it is an amazing site and you can't go without visiting this place.

Interesting and.. a bit spooky. Visiting Recoleta Cemetery – guided by the Argentina-expert Svend Aage Buus – was an interesting experience for us Danes, who are used to less impressive cemeteries. Walking around between the many magnificent sepulchral monuments organized in blocks like in the outside –living- world, we were informed of the argentine history (both the official and the ‘tabloid’ version), which put an extra dimension to the visit and made it a great experience. Spooky: During our visit we noticed a satellite dish on top of one of the about 3 meter high monuments placed in a ‘block’ consisting of only monuments!!?!. A peculiar way of servicing your departed relatives, I think.
Terrific experience. This is an absolute must do in my opinion when you are in ba. Don't cry for me Argentina is all I can say, the history is worth it in every sense of the word

Well worth a visit. This cemetery is more like a museum with the stunning architecture of the final resting place of many of the rich and famous.A lot of people may not find a cemetery very interesting but believe me if you have to finally finish in one this would be the place to die for.Well worth the time spent looking at the tombs as morbid as it may seem as some are truly exquisite.

Praise the dead!. This is a large and well-stocked cemetery with the departed housed in ornate tombs and catacombs. There are smart pathways for you to promendae your way around the cemetery, a guide book/sheet is avaialble and at the entrance there is a computer which shows you the way to hundreds of famous people interred within its walls. Seemingly every Argentina President is here, but the grave they all come to see it Evita, who gets hundreds of visiotrs a day. Once your visit is concluded there are a lot of smart restaurants just outside the entrance and the famous and rather plush "La Biela" cafe is on the corner too. If you time your visit for a Sunday, you can go to the market on the lawns outside and buy your souvenirs.

Iconic Place to Visit in Buenos Aires. So glad I took the tour to see this cemetery. The tombs were beautiful and interesting-true works of art. We were fortunate to have a wonderful guide, Ariana, who knew the history and the stories which evolved about many of the family tombs. And of course I got to see Evita's final resting place in the Duarte family tomb. Our guide was very informed about Argentinian history, and her insight made this visit very special.

interesting. I know this is a must see in Buenos Aires. The scale, sculpture and architecture are unusual. It was interesting, but not a highlight of our time in Argentina. I guess I'm just not a cemetery buff.

A MUST VISIT!. You haven't been to Buenos Aires if you don't visit the Recoleta cemetery. Yes, everyone goes to see Evita's grave but there is so much more you can truly spend the entire afternoon wandering around crypts that are larger than some NYC apts! If you can go on a Saturday when there is a craft fair outside with many artisan items for sale. A lovely place to spend the day just strolling . Maps to the cemetery cost 15 pesos and are a bit of a help but really needed if you have an iPhone.

Amazing place, well worth the visit. My husband and I took a day tour which included among many other attractions the Recoleta Cemetery with Evita's grave. I was not very excited at the idea of seeing a cemetery, but it was in fact nothing like what I expected. The Cemetery was densely packed with stunningly beautiful mausoleums and monuments. It was nothing like the cemeteries in the US. I found it a moving and fascinating experience and gave unique insights into the culture of the country.

Beautiful if a little strange. Would not have thought to come here if our guide hadn't wanted to show us Evita Peron's resting place. That was pretty amazing. But surrounded as it was by so many other mausoleums it was an exceptional experience. From the old and abandoned to the well kept and recently used sites, the quality of art and sculpture was fascinating. Well worth the trip.

The most lugubrious museum I visited!. It's a treat for the eyes talking about its arts. All the mausoleums are masterpieces, full of symbolism. On the other side, there are plenty of coffins at sight, inside the glasses (some shattered) of the tombs... They pilled up over the roads of the necropolis, giving it an macabre aspect, even claustrophobic! But is a life experience that will make you think about it for a while after you leave the gates of the cemetery.

A Must-See Site. Forget about Evita's mausoleum which is quite well hidden away (it is relatively simple and discreet compared to some of the confections you will see,) and just marvel at the great company of angels gathered above you as you wander up and down the avenues of tombs and mausoleums dodging star cats and peering through gaping doorways into crumbling coffins. This is Gothic fantasy at its best. There is an eclectic array of architectural styles and many conundrums to ponder in this relatively small cemetery size-wise, but containing many souls. Get there early if you want to avoid the trailing mobs of guide-led tourists. If you are a cemetery fan This is NOT Pierre Lachaise (Paris) or Highgate (London) or Kensal Green (London), all of which are much larger, but for sheer density of memorials it is well worth visiting.

Very cool place to visit. The cemetery had to be one of my favourite places to visit in Buenos Aires by far. The sheer size,and amount of mausoleums here was something to experience. Many of them were absolutely beautiful. Of course, you can also find Evita's grave but for me, that wasn't the highlight of this place. Be sure to take your time and explore the rows upon rows. Definitely bring a camera. It was also nice that the entry is free.

So what?. We visited the cemetery during a very hot day, which did not help. If you are used to places like Pere Lachaise in Paris or the Central Cemetery in Vienna, you are going to be highly disappointed. The cemetery is (except for a few plants and trees) made up entirely of mausoleums. One next to the other with very small alleyways between them. So unless you have a personal reason to visit, I recommend you visit the surrounding areas instead. The restaurant La Biela is well worth a visit and so is the Recoleta Design Centre. Even the HardRockCafe nearby is a better choice to spend your time.

Interesting. This necropolis is an interesting site to visit. The cemetery covers a large area in the center of Buenos Aires and is the final resting place of many Argentinian elites, most notably, Eva Peron (thank you Evita). The cemetery is composed of row upon row of elaborately constructed tombs. Even with directions, we had a little difficulty locating the tomb where Eva Peron is now interred. Look for the big crowd.

Great morning walk thru Recoleta Cemetery...... Definitely worth taking time to stroll through this amazing cemetery. The monuments are much larger than expected as seen the photo i posted of my partner, Hochi. Very odd to actually see the coffins in some of the monuments. The details are amazing. Enjoy.

Great Afternoon Activity!. One of my favorite things I did in Buenos Aires was visit the Recoleta Cemetery. It was a fantastic afternoon activity. The graves are beautiful, and the museum you can see before it is worth it. Be sure to bring your camera, you'll want to take a ton of pictures. Also, it may be worth doing a guided tour. I didn't and it was hard to find Eva's grave (except if you ask workers then they can show you).

Unique place with lots to see. This place is best visited if you have a guide that knows which tombs to visit. Sure, you can find Eva Peron's tomb if you look for the long line - but the real experience is seeing how truly large and amazing this cemetery is and learning about the many figures from Buenos Aires' history that are buried there. We had a local guide explain several important people from past presidents, unique deaths and others that are all over this cemetery. When you understand who these people are and then examine their tombs - based on the what they are made of and the types of statues and symbols that are decorated there - then you really get a better sense of the city's history. If you can't get a guide to walk you through, I'd suggest doing some research of several important tombs to check out along with the backstories of the people in them. Print it out, bring it along and then read each story as you examine the tomb. This is a truly amazing cemetery and a must see while visiting BA.

Fascinating to explore. Stay at the Lois Suites Recoletta around the corner from the cemetery.ask and pay for a room overlooking. It is mesmerizing to see from above...watch cats play at dusk. You can see the overview of the village for the dead.

A must see; but very little to see. This is the cemetery with the remains of Evita. The Durarte family tomb is only a few steps from the entrance and it took about 5 minutes to see the spot. The rest of the cemetery would be worth exploring but there are more interesting cemeteries in other countries.

Very cool place to visit. If you've got a couple hours to spare this is a great place to check out.Of course the infamous tomb of Gardel and Evita are located here, along with a bunch of cute stray cats! It was worth seeing but only once :)

One of the Best Cemeteries!. I have visited this cemetery on four different occasions, spending several hours wandering around. We purchased a book at the cemetery that provided a history of the different tombs / monuments and the people / families as well as a good detailed map. We found this very helpful. I'm not a person who likes to spend time at cemeteries but this one is different. Walk slowly down the paths, observe the architecture the statues, and the history. Gorgeous monuments are next to tombs that are aging and in disrepair but each still has great character. A good tour guide will also be very helpful the first time. There are many, many more tombs of historical people than just Evita. Bring your camera for unusual photographs. Find some of the cats that live at the cemetery. Great place! Don't rush through it!
Seriously good. I just love a good graveyard, and this is one of the best i have been to. You will need a guide to get the bets out of it. The monuments etc are outstanding.

Interesting but ... We went with a guide which is essential. I am not sure I would bother to visit without. It was quite interesting but worth no more than a quick visit - there are more living things to see in this great city without spending too much time among the dead!

A Clutural Snapshop of Argentina. A tour here gives great insight into the cultural values and importance of status to Argentinians past and present. While many rich and famous (also rich) families are entombed here,sometimes family plots are sold, in fact one is for sale now next to Evita's family plot. You do need a good guide to appreciate all of the history and nuances of the cemetery. The art work is spectacular. Sadly, acid rain pollution is having its effect on the Carerra marble statues which adorn many of the tombs. On weekends, look around for Raul by the front gate. He is very knowledgeable and will design a 2 hour tour around your interests.

La Recoleta Cemetery, Buenos Aires, Argentina. Found the Recoleta very interesting even though I only wanted to see Eva Peron's resting place.We purchased the map and itinerary from a lovely animated lady who had lots of stories to tell and her english was perfect.Actually spent 2 hours walking around looking at all the amazing sculptures. This place is like an art gallery, fascinating and such detail to the headstones.To think in the middle of a busy city there is a place like this!!!

You could spend a half day here!. There is nothing in the world like this. The private property gravesites of varied sizes and configurations have been passed down from generations for over 100 years. Some are absolute monuments, and others are in complete disrepair, depending on each family's financial ability and desire to maintain them. The only way to see it is by a private curated tour. We spent two hours here with our guide and it left me wanting more!

A Truly Weird Idea of Tourist Attraction. Personally, I do not see the mass market appeal of this "attraction" among tourists... elaborate resting spot for much of Argentina's wealthy class. Interesting enough to merit 45 minutes, but our guided tour took at least twice that... a bit too much IMHO. Do use a guide, so that you can connect names of the guests with historical events, and the added treat of gravesite architecture.

Do not miss it!. Recoleta cemetery is a place you simply cannot miss when in Buenos Aires. There is something about this place which makes you lose track of time and keeps your curiosity alive. It’s a great opportunity to make amazing photos from your trip to BsAs. The cemetery is open from 8am to 6pm every day. Your visit will probably take 2-3 hours. I suggest you come here right when it opens or a couple of hours before closing time. It can get very tiring while walking around during the hottest hours of the day as there are no shades around. Make sure you put on plenty of sunscreen and have a bottle of water with you. There are many water taps around so you can refill at any time. Also, make sure you take a good look at the map when you first get in (maybe even make a few notes before you start looking around) as this place has barely any signs.

A gorgeous way to go. This cemetery is a glamourous way to go. Magestic mausoleums, many like sumptuous phone boxes with stained glass and decorative coffins. Some are falling to bits which adds to the effect. The Duarte family plot is not the most spectacular but it is the most visited.

Most Amazing Cemetery in the World. You would have to be embarrassed to go to BA and not see this cemetery. I would challenge anyone to find a more elaborate cemetery than Recoleta with all the grand mausoleums. My only complaint is that I wish it were easier to find your way around.

Recoleta Cemetery. Buenos Aires. This well worth a visit in Buenos Aires. Free to enter and roam to your heart's contentWe had a very knowledgeable guide who told us many stories of the crypts. It contains the graves of notable people, including Eva Peron.Recommended

Unbelievable tour guide. We were very fortunate to have Pedro Werberg (Clickonenglish55@gmail.com) as our tour guide in Buenos Aires, Argentina. We had a terrific city tour...by walking, bus and cab. Pedro took us to Remolata, the palace, the cathedral, and other out of the way places. His English is impeccable. He is so knowledgeable about politics, architecture, historical events, and locales. In addition, he is very personable and friendly. Without all of his knowledge, while the Remolata would have been very interesting, but not as fascinating as an experience as we had.
Must see!. Visiting this cemetery will show you how wealthy many have been in Buenos Aires. It is almost like visiting a museum of fine sculpture! Definitely a must see!

Strange place but a must-see in BA. If you go to BA then I think you have to do this, it's really interesting and the vanity is just astonishing! Ultimately it's just (extremely) pimped-up headstones/tombs of people you don't know, but the fact that it's so different and a very unusual thing to see/visit make it a necessity in Buenos Aires. You don't need much more than an hour to see the majority/get the gist though, and it's free.

A must see. Thought it would be 'meh', but was blown away.. We took a guided tour of Buenos Aires the day after we arrived that included a stop at the Recoleta Cemetery (thanks, JourneysByKaren!).  While I enjoy cemeteries related to researching my family tree, I thought this one was going to be just another cemetery. I couldn't have been more wrong.  This cemetery is like a little city...rows and rows of mausoleums usually 20-30 feet high and made of marble or granite and fabulously adorned with sculptures and carvings and statues. Eva Peron's grave is located here. Our tour was about an hour, and I could have easily spent the entire afternoon wandering around this peaceful place and enjoying the variety of ways the people of Buenos Aires honor their dead. Recoleta Cemetery is located near a park that was lined with booths for crafts, and a huge finca tree that shades a portion of Ballantine(?) cafe on the corner. Don't forget about Freddo's for good ice cream.

Worth the visit. As you enter the cemetary, be careful of the folks looking for some kind of donation who will come up to you just before the steps. Rather wait until you are inside the entryway and give a donation to the cemetary itself, and get the official map. The mausoleums are interesting and you can see care takers still looking after them. The cemetary is also a reflection of Argentine history with people from the founding of the country to Evita Peron resting there. We came across a cat living in the cemetary that has certainly has been through the wars. It's frightening to look at, as every part of it's body has been chewed on. The locals give it food, and it seems to be living a happy retirement.

Amazing display. Well worth buying the map and giving a donation for upkeep of this historic cemetery. For non-spanish speakers the map/guide helps fill in a bit of history. A few hours at most will get you around most of the site.
Very interesting.. Amazing cemetary with some really cool and intricately designed mausoleums. Interesting architecture on a small (or sometimes large) scale.

It's good but it's a cemetery afterall. Don't get me wrong, the place is beautiful and all, architecture-wise is different but at the end of the day it's a cemetery. It's kinda strange and for me personally kind of unsettling
culture and interesting. for people who like to interesting stories, there is a place full of them. but only worth being with a guide .......................................

Worth a visit. The cemetery is lovely to wander around in the sunshine. Some of the tombs are astoundingly lavish and you can spend a good hour just soaking up your surroundings. You can also hunt for the resting places of various famous Argentinians, including of course Eva Peron, who is surprisingly difficult to find. I gave it 4 instead of 5 because I personally feel a bit uncomfortable with the idea that some people's corpses deserve such opulent surroundings. All dead bodies are equal in my opinion. But it's still worth a visit.

Unusual and interesting. We went to the Ricoleta Cemetery, burial place of Eva Peron. It is not your typical cemetery. When you enter the grounds, it looks like a small city. There are buildings everywhere, which are individually owned by the family, and are actually mausoleums. The buildings are no large enough for multiple burials on one level, so they have dug many layers down to accommodate. the remains, anywhere from 7 to 11 layers down.On the entry door posts are posted the information of each person buried there. It was interesting to walk through just to see the different designs used.It was the cemetery of the very rich in the earlier days

Strange but interesting. We had a very knowledgeable guide who told us many stories of the crypts. It contains the graves of notable people, including Eva Perón, presidents of Argentina. Most tourists who come here visit only Evita's tomb but among the many others, two are worth singling out and should not be missed. One is the tomb of the Paz family, who owned the newspaper La Prensa, as well as the palatial building on Plaza San Martín now known as the Círculo Militar.Another tomb I recommend seeing is that of Rufina Cambaceres, a young woman who was buried alive in the early 1900s. She had perhaps suffered a coma, and a few days after her interment, workers heard screams from the tomb. When it was opened, there were scratches on her face and on the coffin from her attempts to escape. Her mother then built this Art Nouveau masterpiece, which has become a symbol of the cemetery. Her coffin is a Carrara marble slab, carved with a rose on top, and it sits behind a glass wall, as if her mother wanted to make up for her mistake in burying her and ensure she could see her coffin if she were ever to come back again. The corner of the tomb is adorned by a young girl carved of marble who turns her head to those watching her; she looks as if she is about to break into tears, and her right hand is on the door of her own tomb. Many locals often place delicate sprigs of flowers into her hand.

Interesting but dreary!. We walked around the cemetery today and peeked inside the mausoleums. Pretty creepy! Some of the caskets were pretty weather beaten and most of the mausoleums had leaked. We heard from a tour guide that the families have to pay a yearly fee or sell their space. There was only one for sale though quite a few were in a state of disrepair. The only one for sale was right next to Eva Peron's . The asking price is $300,000 US dollars!

If you are into Evita this is worth the trip. I have been very interested in Evita for many years. She was actually one of the inspirations for our trip to BA. The cemetery, along with the Evita Museum was very much worth the trip. It was very interesting to stroll down the lanes. Many of the mausoleums were very ornate and interesting. Especially with the very high temperatures that day (105F 40C) we actually spent more time there than I planned. If you are there to see her mausoleum, look for “Duarte” her family name. We got a map of the Recoleta cemetery from our hotel concierge. That made it simple to find her location.

One of the best sites in BA. We went with our guide who really explained the entire cemetery. It was fascinating. I originally thought I would go and just see Evita's tomb and leave and was so glad I went with a guide as we learned so much.

Fantastic place to visit and reflect.... This is a MUST SEE in Buenos Aires. Free to enter and roam to your heart's content. Many wonderful photo opportunities. The place is full of history and interesting stories. You can visit many times and not see all of the details and interesting statues and crypts. If possible, read up on the history before you go, or buy a written guide so you can wander at leisure and know better the most important spots in the cemetery. Went with a small tour group with an english speaking guide who was knowledgeable and thorough. Went back several times to just walk around and be amazed. Stayed right across the street, so was able to do this. Very historic and beautiful location.

Beauty in Death. Its not that eerie that you run in the opposite directions after learning that this famous attraction is actually a cemetery. The place is covered with beautiful pieces of work that even the museums can’t boast. I loved how each tombs and grave had a beautiful epitaph and a supporting statue or carvings to it. The whole place is beautiful and impressive with stories and history. Guide can be a nice tag along for this place because I had a lot of fun with my guide who not only knew the tombs of important personalities that rested here but also shared some really horrific tales to our amusement. One of the tales led us running away from the cats that surrounds here. The place is a must visit and you will find a lot of popular figures resting here like Eva Peron, William Brown, Pablo Pizzurno and many of others.

Worth a Stroll. I wasn't expecting much before my visit to the cemetery. It was close to our hotel and I just wanted to go and see Evita's resting place. Once we walked through the front entrance I was surprised at how beautiful the cemetery actually was. It wasn't scary or aged, it looked like a little city with lots of sculptures and marbled mausoleums. Some of them were so intricate and detailed that it puts American architecture to shame. I was disappointed that Eva Peron's site was tucked away and much less fancy, but I guess that is what makes her so great. If you have time, definitely give the place a stroll and admire the greatness of this cemetery.

Beautiful cemetery. I stayed in a hotel across from the cemetery on a recent trip to BA. I visiting the cemetery several times during my vacation (I kept searching for Evita's tomb!). It was a lovely setting for a morning stroll with coffee. A must visit in BA.

Fascinating and not what you expect!. When I told the wife we were off to a graveyard for the afternoon she was not overcome with excitement, however on our arrival she loved the place. It is fascinating and very out of the ordinary. There is so much to see and photo opportunities are endless. Don't go too late as they kicked everyone out at 5:30pm on our visit. Great way to spend half a day and some nice little cafes opposite the entrance.

Worth a walk. Walking through the Recoleta Cemetery offers a perspective on the burial practices of prominent Argentines in the city. As a tourist, the names of families on each mausoleum mean little but the architecture of the monuments themselves is worth the visit. Also, while all the tourists are making a bee line for the Eva Peron mausoleum, I'd recommend ignoring them and wandering through the aisles of tombs to admire the design and construction of the other monuments.
