Many mausoleums are crumbling with visible caskets below the surface of the mausoleum floor and others offer some fantastic glimpses into the lives of those inside them (old photos, hand woven lace covers, stunning candelabras etc). Overall, this was a fascinating experience for us.

Evita Plus More. We had a guide as we walked through Recoleta and that undoubtedly helped enjoy its details, but my guidebook also had a two-page map with highlights so a guide is not imperative. The highlight for most folks is Eva Peron's tomb, the final resting place of the famous Evita. She's been here since 1976, having spent the prior 20 years in Italy and Spain after her embalmed body was spirited out of Argentina by the military. There are many spectacular mausoleums here (6,400+) but I was most struck by the wealthy family's tomb which had a little side plot next to the tomb for their beloved maid. It needed weeding.

Fascinating. This is a fascinating place to visit and a must-see when in Buenos Aires. Perhaps it was the sunshine but it was nothing like the morbid place that I was expecting. There is a beauty in the design and layout which is very special. It's tempting to rush through to see Evita's grave but take time to wander and enjoy the calm and serenity.

Interesting site to visit. I had my doubts at first but this is a really interesting site. The above ground mausoleums range from architecturally stunning to run down. But those that beautiful are truly that. We had a private guide who gave us a fantastic explanation of the place and pointed out some of the truly magnificent mausoleums and a history of who they were Evita has a family mausoleum here, it is worth a 2 hr visit,

Add it to the list, but not real high. . Not my cup of tea. There were plenty of beautiful mausoleums, but that's about it. Evidently the cemetery is full of highly regarded Argentinians, and I admit it is due to our ignorance, but without having an educated knowledge of the history of Argentina and it's leaders, it's just another cemetery. Perhaps a tour guide would have been useful, but I doubt we would have enjoyed it much more knowing whose graves we were viewing. The "visit" is free, but visitors do get approached by freelance tour guides asking for "donations" for a scribbled map which is not necessary. We walked through the cemetery for roughly half an hour then are lunch and had wine across the street.

Not that sure why cemeteries are so high up on the list of things to do.... It was alright. Nice monuments, some pretty good masonery, no dead bodies. Or zombies. 1-2 hours at most, then go get lunch somewhere nearby.

Amazing!. The size and elaborate designs of some of the mausoleums were quite unbelievable, as was some of the materials used such as marble. It was very well maintained which was a wonderful token of respect of those past.A 'cat lady' was also there as indeed were dozens of cats in the grounds. The kind cat patron was feeding and pampering the cats, and obliged to photos being taken.It was more than worth the requested contribution of ARS10 for the documentary booklet from the Friends of the Recoleta Cemetery. Wonderful to witness first-hand Eva Peron's and other famous Argentinian personalities' tombs.Pity that the Buenos Aires city does not provide better street signposts for getting to the renowned Cemetery even within the Recoleta area. Perhaps this was deliberate....

Definitely make this a priority!. We thought the cemetery was beautiful and very interesting. I wish I could go back and spend more time wandering through. The day we visited the cemetery (December 18 or 19, I think), the guards closed the doors at 5:30pm instead of 6pm, which was the closing time we'd read about in our guidebook and online. We arrived at 5:25pm knowing we wouldn't have much time (trying to fit too much into one day!) and were surprised to learn they were closing at 5:30 instead of 6:00. Still, they did let us in and we had probably 15 minutes to walk around. It was one of our favorite places we've visited in Argentina.
As curious as Morbid. Its nice and beautifull but a lil bit morbid to go there only to see dead people.... Still, if ur in other country, its nice to get into their culture.Worths the shot

Worth the visit, but don't have huge expectations. Worth the visit, but I'm not particularly religious so I found it a little bit morbid. However there is some great sculpture work and if you know a little about famous Argentinian people then you may appreciate it more than I did.You may get stopped at the entrance by somebody who draws you a quick map on the back of a leaflet of the most popular grave sites (e.g. Evita) then after 2 minutes of unsolicited advice he will ask you to donate some money to an orphanage. We felt a little bit uncomfortable after this because there was no way of knowing whether he was a genuine charity worker, somebody who worked at the graveyard or just a scam artist. So we gave him a bit of change and moved on it. So is there a fee for this attraction? As far as I know there shouldn't be.

Amazing!. We came here based in trip advisor reviews. Despite the incredible heat, this is a must see. The crypts and mausoleums are over the top. Row on row of incredible marble statues and structures. Admission is free and there are also free and paid guided tours but we chose to just wander ourselves. We happened upon Eva Peron's grave and I was surprised it was just in the middle of many others, not particularly lavish or opulent. Still, it was nice to take a moment to pay our respects to this famous woman. Overall, this is a must see.
worth a visit. it's a bit difficult finding the actual entrance, but it is certainly worth the trouble to see this very unique place.
What a site. Spooky, strange, beautiful are all the best ways to describe the recoleta it is a must place to visit when you are in BA
strange. it's strange to visit a cementary, but the architecture of many of the tomb's are interesting to watch, and if you like history a lot of argentine history is buried there

Eerie & Beautiful. We wandered into this unusual site without a guide or map and had fun exploring at our own pace. We asked the guard for direction to Evita’s tomb, then walked around to see other crypts and mausoleums. An eerie yet beautiful mini city for the dead and unlike anything we have ever experienced before.

The Angels of Buenos Aires. La Recoleta Cemetery stands on 14 acres in the middle of Buenos Aires. Attached to the convent and church of Our Lady of Pilar , built in 1792. It is a gorgeous and peaceful place in the midst of a loud and busy city, perfect for a lunch on a cool stone bench in the shade before a great wandering adventure. The crypts are in states of exquisite to tumbledown, although nothing is plain nor uninteresting. The carvings and memorials are magnificent, and angels abound! Argentine writer Virginia Ocampo and Eva (Evita) Peron are among the famous names to find here. A very exclusive and expensive cemetery, the crypts carry the names of the founders of Buenos Aires - the sea captains, the bankers, the generals and the builders who raised this incredible city from the earth. Some died at it's hand, others brought it glory with their might. The cemetery will add another dimension to the historical aspect of your trip to Buenos Aires, absolutely!You WILL need a map to find particular graves (you can download a pdf to your mobile device from the cemetery website, http://www.recoletacemetery.com/ ). It is a maze, and sometimes you feel as if you must leave a trail of breadcrumbs to find your way out, but it will be a fascinating journey! Spend an hour or two, spend a long afternoon.

Interesting history and beautiful setting. My husband and I walked around the cemetary early one morning while we were out and about, getting his morning coffee and then returned with our famiy on another day for the free English tour they offer once a week (I believe it was a Thursday). It's a lovely place to explore on one's own and see the different styles people used for tombs - from simple and modest to extraordinary. Entrance is free (though they are happy to recieve donations for upkeep). However, it was well worth returning for the tour in order to gain more insight into the people who are buried there and the history of the site, although - for us - it was a little long. After about an hour, we broke from the group as we had heard enough stories, and that was easy enough to do. The cemeray is in the upscale and lovely neighborhood of Ricoletta which is worth visiting in general.

The place of the desd.... The graves of the rich and famous...all for free! Set in a lovely area the graveyard is full of beautiful and very decorative crypts including the burial place for Evita. A real must for photographers and very interesting to boot.

Eva, where are you?. So use the map to find Eva Peron's tomb unless you prefer to wander around for hours. This cemetery is a must see when visiting Buenos Aires and is quite beautiful. It takes a full day to wander the entire cemetery which I recommend as there are some profoundly moving statues and memoriams. Pick a cooler day as it can get quite hot and there is not much a breeze to be had in the cemetery.Of note it is worth a visit to the attached church which from the outside appears quite humble but the inside is breathtaking.
Very Interesting. We found the cemetery to be very interesting. It's best to have a guide explain the many inhabitants especially Eva Peron. This place should not be missed.

What an incredible site to visit.. We stayed in Recoleta for 3 months, and visited the Recoleta Cemetery too many times to count. Do take a guided tour and do buy the book they sell at the entrance. After the tour or on a subsequent day, just start roaming the streets of the cemetery. It will be very helpful if you have an idea of which crypts you know you want to visit (research), then look up their location on the map inside the entrance, and always take a different street if you can. We visited at all different times of day to get different lighting for our photos. Also, do visit the church next door and pay to see their artifacts on display in the cloisters. It is really inexpensive and they have some really interesting pieces. Try and make sure that at least one of the days you visit the cemetery is a saturday or sunday so you can take advantage of the market that goes up outside the cemetery - it is well worth a visit. Don't worry about getting to the market early, as the vendors take their time setting up. You are best to go i.e. after lunch. If you want to buy artwork as gifts, or as a momento of your trip, this is a great place to do so. As well, listen for the tango playing, as sometimes local dancers will put on a beautiful show under the big rubber trees.

Takes more than one visit. We wondered through the cemetery 3 separate times. Every time we found more to photograph. We took a dozen pink roses and placed them in the hands of the various statues or the photos. Looking back on them now at what seemed like an odd idea, resulted in some of the most amazing memories. Gotta love seeing the bones falling out of the abandoned crypts!! and I cannot forget the cats of the dead. There are feral cats all over the place. This is a don't miss location.

Weird but wonderful. A must visit if you are in BA> Lovely little area and it is an amazing cemetery. You wouldn't believe the size and style of some of these mini cathedrals!! Some very modern and some ancient!! You can actually see the coffins. We went with a guide but there are guides available if you are travelling on your own. Evita buried here and that gets very busy.

One of the World's best cemeteries. An amazing cemetery, very easy to navigate. We had a very knowledgeable guide who told us many stories of the crypts and the notable people buried there among them Eva Peron.

Worth the Visit. When we arrived an English speaking guide approached us and we were pleased that we decided to employ him. He took us first into the church and and then spent an hour showing us around the cemetery, telling stories about several of the crypts and the families that own them. He was able to answer many of our questions too. The fee was unspecified so we were able to pay what we felt the information was worth. A very satisfying way to see the cemetery and a good use of an afternoon's time.
This is a must see. What an amazing cemetary. All above ground Masoleums. Eva Peron is buried here. The photo opportunities are amazing. It looks like a little city. You must visit this.

better with a guide. We had a guide which made the visit much more interesting. She told us that the tombs are expensive and that some families sell the tombs. She also told us the story of a tomb where a woman was supposedly buried alive (unintentionally) and of a young girl who disappeared in the woods (see the photo). Both of those tombs had statues.There are very old decrepit tombs and very sleek modern tombs. You can peek inside and see coffins in several of them. Of course, you can also visit Evita's tomb and there will be a line for that.I enjoyed the visit more than I expected because of the interesting stories (even if they aren't true!).

Fascinating. Worth having a guide.. The cemetery is fascinating. Evita’s resting place is the big draw but I was fascinated at the other monuments including Irishman, Admiral William Browne’s unusual memorial (coloured green). But the really intriguing facts come from hearing the guides explain about the history and practices - for instance, that the cemetery is full so some families now sell off their family mausoleum to the highest bidder. So take time and go with a guide.

Resting place of the rich and famous. Spent a couple of hours walking around, part of it guided by a local "expert"We were unsure as to whether to walk round ourselves or join a tour in the end we sort of did both.Outside we were asked by a person who does freelance tours is we wanted to be guided, after a short conversation we decided yes and were given a very informative, interesting and thorough tour of the cemetery, in excellent english by our guide. It was great value for money and I think added a lot to the experience as he knew his way around expertly and picked out highlights in terms of tombs to visit, people to focus on etc.Afterwards we stayed on and took photos at our own pace etc.It was great fun and really interesting. Hearing about the history and stories behind the tombs and just how many people are buried in some of them and the money that the crypts can change hands for was fascinating. One of the highlights in BA for us.

over the top cemetery. Beautiful crypts. A great thing to put on your to do list to see something a little different and to see how BA's rich are immortalized. Beauty can really be found even in death.
RECOLETA CEMETERY. Amazing place. Some incredible tombs and Eva Perron's can be easily seen. Well worth the time to visit.

Highlight of our holiday. It sounds kinda morbid, but I cannot recommend this place enough. It's free to enter (although a donation is 'required') and we tried to move our final days' schedule around to come here again. This place is equal parts beautiful, peaceful, moving, and captivating.

Beautiful Tombs- Free English Tours- Highly Recommend. The cemetery is really beautiful, I've never seen anything quite like it. The tombs are very ornate, lots of stained glass, cool sculptures, etc. It's massive and you could spend hours and hours in it if you chose to. There are a lot of famous tombs in there (such as Evita's), so I strongly suggest getting a guide or else you won't really know what you're looking for. Alternatively, there are free English tours (I believe Tues and Thurs at 11- but double check that) and the woman who we had was pretty good. I had a little trouble understanding her but my husband didn't. There is no fee required but you can tip her at the end.This is definitely an experience that you don't want to miss!
Easy to navigate with many lovely mausoleums. Many beautiful memories to those departed as well as Evita's resting place. Not quite the charm of Pere Lachaise, but worth the visit.
Recoleta Cemetery. Yes it is must to see this cemetery. Best early in the morning or at sunset, when there are less people but a wounderful light. It is silent and has some breathtaking views.

Don't even think about missing this!. Having lived in Buenos Aires my whole life I enjoy coming hear often. It has a magnificent architecture and many of the country's historical figures are buried here. I recommend to take the free guided tour, and then continue to explore by yourself, getting "lost" in its numerous stretch halls and discovering its secrets.

"Sculpture Garden". I took advantage of a stroll through the cemetery on a clear fall day in the early afternoon. I was with my family but I imagine it would make for a very romantic walk as well. The artistry put into building many of these grave markers is astounding and pictures simply do not do them justice. I imagine it could get hot in the summer peak season with all the stone and lack of space from tourists passing through so I recommend going at a cooler, less popular time of day when you can enjoy the quiet and serene atmosphere. I do believe the "park" beside the cemetery has concerts in the early evenings some weekends. The larger Recoleta neighborhood is also really nice to walk around and enjoy lunch and some shopping, although it can be pricey so you might want to restrict yourself to window-shopping.

History!. This cemetery visit will be part of your walk to plaza Francia. It's a beautiful cemetery. But fear not! Lot's of children, people smiling. Of course you'll miss knowing what happened to people so the best way to see it is with a tour guide. That will sure improve your visit. If you're in a rush, just don't miss Eva Peron's tomb.

Absolutely Beautiful. This may sound a little morbid, but I loved this cemetery so much that I visited it twice during my time in Buenos Aires!The weather was gorgeous both times, and the tombs were very intricate and lovely, with the more well to do having opulent tombs to show for it. Many even had gorgeous stained glass in them. It is picture perfect and definitely worth a visit. If you go on the weekends there is even a market right outside to do a little touristy shopping. Note that the cemetery closes at about 1745, not that you'd want to stay there when it gets dark, so ensure you go earlier in the day to have ample time to explore.

A 'must see' in Buenos Aires. Seems strange to be spending time on holiday trawling round a cemetery, but what a cemetery!This was a most interesting experience despite the fact that I knew very few of the 'celebrities' - for want of a better word - entombed within the mausoleums. It was just fascinating to see what importance some people attach to the housing of the departed, and the variety of mausoleums was quite amazing. Many are sadly neglected, and some are obviously well tended and no expense has been spared. Still can't help but think that the money spent on some of them could have been put to better use for the living, but that is only a personal view and I appreciate that not everyone shares it.I had intended to join the English speaking tour but I'm glad that I missed it because I didn't arrive in time. It meant that I could just wander round at my own pace and look at what I wanted to see, rather than what someone else wanted me to see. It was good to be able to take my time and look at some of the mausoleums in close detail, especially some of those which seemed neglected and out of the way. There was the inevitable crush around the Duarte mausoleum but if you were patient and picked your moment when some SE Asian teenager wasn't standing plumb in front of it, grinning like a loon and making two V signs, the your photo opportunity came around eventually. At the entrance you are assailed by someone unconnected with the cemetery plying you with a photocopied map and requesting money for, apparently, AIDS victims. It is unlikely that this is the case, but just inside the entrance is a patient official representative of the cemetery with a proper map of the site which is 10 pesos, and you are invited to make a donation to the upkeep of the cemetery. I was happy to do this as I appreciate that these places must be maintained and there is a cost involved in that. Bearing mind that this is a cemetery, it is not surprising to find out that there is nothing in the way of visitor facilities other than a tiny block of WCs hidden away around the perimeter, and these were of the type where a young child provides you with a sheet of kitchen roll (yes, I do mean kitchen roll!) in exchange for some money. There is little or no shade on the site so be sure to take plenty of water with you if you are visiting, as I was, in the main heat of the day. There is nowhere to buy drinks. A surprisingly interesting and, dare I say it, entertaining way to spend a couple of hours. Highly recommended.

Wonderful tour in English. Took the 11 am tour in English today/Thursday. Plan on that tour on Thursday or the tour on Tuesday, I think. Patrice gave a fabulous tour of a fascinating place. Do not know if we could have enjoyed it as much without the tour.

An absolute must. If you are in Buenos Aires you must see the cemetery, its filled with works of art and some windows that would take your breath away. Evita's tomb is not really something that take your breath away, but I do get that a lot of tourists go for that... Just don't stick to just looking at that one, the Cemetery is an enormous necropolis filled with amazing sculptures and tombs that are just magnificent. A real must see.

Great experience. There are free tours of the cemetery at 11 am on Tuesday and Thursday. Our guide spoke wonderful English. The cemetery is interesting, but for me the best part was hearing some of the history of Argentina, and the history of the important people who are buried there. The statuary is also magnificent. A must see! A tip to the guide is a nice gesture.

Not spooky.. =). The most interesting cemetery I've been. If I wasn't that very tired, I should have took photos of all the well-made statues in the area. I've visited on a sunny afternoon, many tourists also came. You can take your time here, there are some resting seats inside the area. Architectures in this areas are very nice.

Even if you don't know Argentine history. It's one of the nicest cemeteries try a guided tour, and if you know Spanish ask for Osvaldo at the entrance who will recite poetry at most stops of the tour he gives, truly amazing guy. He does not ask for payment but 200 pesos tip is only 20 dollars and worth the 90 minutes to 2 hours you will spend with him.

Grave visit. This was an excellent place to visit, we got a tour guide just outside for $20 and we would have missed so much, such an experience walking round the place and we visited Evita's grave, and not to be missed, near excellent places for coffee or wine.
If you are into that. I suppose it something to see. Personally not into cemeteries. But the Tombs are elaborate and above ground and you are able to see the coffins.

A very interesting site to visit - a "must see". A very impressive cemetery I have ever seen. Huge area, well organized cemetery plan (take at entrance). Monuments and mausoleums of whole families. You can look into many of them across windows, doors or openings. Must visit the Evita's, it was purposely understated to minimize the personal cult of this lady admired by so many Argentinians.

Worth it to get over to see this..... The Recoleta Cemetery is one of the most "ancient" cemeteries we have ever seen, if not THE most. This is truly a unique sight to see and experience. You are able to walk through and among the many and varied headstones and monuments which have been amazingly preserved until this day. This cemetery is close by to the shopping area of Recoleta, which is also a highlight of Buenos Aires.

Must see cemetery + Evita's final resting place.... Spent a couple hours at the cemetery, it does not disappoint. The photo ops are great, you get to see more than you expect... It goes on and on... Evita's crypt is the big tourist attraction, but many monuments are outstanding, check out Leloir! TIP: If you go into the church next door and do the inexpensive religious artifacts tour, you get a great view from atop the cemetery for overall picture of it.

Not a cemetery fan, but the Argentinian goddes had to be visited by me.... The title says it all. The Recoleta cemetery is were all the whose and whose of Argentina are buried. Objectively speaking, the cemetery is very big and impressive. It has a lot of huge tombs, where whole families are buried. When going to a cemetery you should focus on whom you want to see, so if you are interested in taking pictures with tombs of famous people, take a tour, because going by yourself, without knowing the history of the person you are looking for, is useless. I didn't take any tour.My purpose was one, and is to see Evita's grave. I followed the Lonely Planet instructions and got to the grave, and as it was said, there are many people around the grave. I took 2 pictures and started my way out.As a Jewish guy, I like to find some of the Jewish symbols, which i saw there, but didn't know whom it belonged.My mission was accomplished in 10-15 minutes (we arrived really close to the closing hours).

Odd but very good experience. Going to a Cemetery might not seem like a normal tourist activity, but in Recoleta cemetery it is totally different. This cemetery is packed with state of art tombs that are a good way to show the power of the ancient families back in the beginning of the 20th century, There are some tombs of famous argentinian people and some incredible sculptures.  This place is totally worth seeing!

Impressive and Serene. I went here with reservations as to what to expect and was pleasantly surprised. Although the tomb of Evita was not what I expected for a woman of her stature, the cemetary itself was serene and interesting. Many places were eleaborate and beautiful and amount of staff on hand to help and maintained the grounds was very attentive. It was a very nice, quiet day for me.

It doesn't have to be Halloween to enjoy Recoleta Cemetary... Even if you don't have a fascination for history as discovered in cemeteries, you can't not like this architecturally diverse, jam-packed, historical oasis in Buenos Aires. It is only open during normal daytime hours and, if you make a donation, you can buy a map that shows you not only how to navigate, so you easily find your way out, but also how to find important tombs like Eva Peron and other famous Argentinians. It's a incredible place to while away some time. Enjoy!

Rows of elegant jewelbox mausoleums in Buenos Aires. The Recoleta Cemetery is a "must see" in Buenos Aires, given its early history, elegant architecture, sculpture, and implied social commentary. We timed our visit for the English tour, and benefited from a passionate, knowledgeable guide's insights. Seeing Evita's final resting place and being captivated by the range and singularity of Recoleta's architectural styles made every glance down a lane, every new perspective on the treasures there a photographer's delight. Having accommodations near the Recoleta Cemetery made our stay even more memorable in BA.
Was TOLD this was a great tourist stop. People I was with went to this stop and said it was really interesting and worth the taxi ride down there. Lots of small shops around there too.

Where Evita sleeps. A very interesting place to visit...wonderful architecture! The statues of angels are very moving as are the many, many burial sites. The most visited site is that of Evita Peron, in the Duarte family mausoleum. She was born of the mistress of Duarte and never accepted into the family until her death. Interesting commentary on her status after her death....It is a beautiful cemetery with old trees and paved walkways with many wonderful sites. Well worth the visit.
Impressive. Loved wondering around these wonderful mausoleums. Amazing architecture(millions of dollars spent here). Was on a guided tour but could have spent another hour exploring.

Very Interesting. Went to this cemetery on a guided tour while in Argentina. It was the most amazing Cemetery I have ever seen with brilliant architecture. Our guided tour was over all too quickly and I could have spent at least another hour wandering around and exploring the mausoleums.

past lives of Beunos aires - recoleta. This is a mini city of history. Fantastic to wander through the tombs - but a tip.....google the history of the tombs and take it with you. The tours are fine, but if you really want the history and enjoy the "feel" of history, read and walk at your leisure. Great to do on a Sunday and follow up with the market in the Plaza outside

One of the 1000 must sees before you die!!. Pardon the pun as this is a cemetery, but I truly believe this cemetery should be included in the list of the 1000 must sees before you die!Not only is there no entrance fee(beware of the touts at the entrance trying to sell you pamphlets etc....really unnecessary) unless you want very detailed information), this is probably the most amazing cemetery you will ever visit anywhere in the world with scores huge mausoleums to the well healed BA families one seemingly trying to outdo the other!Of course, the highlight is Evita Perron's grave...in the family crypt name DUARTE.A DEFINITE MUST SEE IN BA!

Worth a visit. Bumped into an English fellow outside the next door beautiful Catholic Church. He offered a "free" tour of the cemetery but he took donations. My girlfriend and I weren't too keen on a guided tour but fate the church bumped into him inside the cemetery as he was taking a pair of other travellers on a tour and decided to tag along. Must say we were so glad we went on the guided tour. There is so much history with this cemetery that we would not have got by walking around ourselves. Was given so much interesting history about the different mausoleums. We gave the guide about $AUS20 each for about 1.5 hours but thought it was so worth the money. He then took us to a money changer near the Alvear Palace Hotel, not a street one, and virtually doubled our $US to peso exchange rate. Beware, outside there are scammers. They try and give you a pathetic map and ask for a donation. They pretend the money is going to AIDS research or to look for missing persons. Ignore them! A word of advice about BA public toilets. They are generally very clean but almost never, like the cemetery one, have toilet paper. Ladies, you may like to keep a small supply in your handbags.

Recoleta Cemetary. Was very interesting to walk round. A myriad of different tombs, statues and much more. Very easy to get lost and we probably looked at the same things more than once. Eva Peron's tomb is very small, an apparent deliberate act of revenge. It is not hard to find though, just look for the crowds.

Extraordinary place.. I spent over an hour experiencing this visually beautiful and stimulating location - only on the insistence of locals, who are so proud of it. From the amazing tombs of great folk, to the humble crumbling resting places of the more humble, it is a place to feel history. I loved the statue and story of the woman who died trying to rescue her dog. And of course, the obligatory visit to Eva Peron's family tomb with her ordinary memorial plate. On a lovely day, with options presented in the lovely parklands surrounding, it is a special part of visiting BA.

Full of statues. it helps to go a little about argentinian history since most famous people are buried here including Eva Peron. The mausoleums are ornate and full of statues. There are some beautiful and others neglected but even then it is a piec of history. Take a guided tour so you can enjoy it further.

Cemetery of the Nation. Recoleta’ is an up-market district of Buenos Aires, and a famous cemetery. The austere Augustinian Order of Recollects established a convent and church on the outskirts of Buenos Aires in the eighteenth century. The church is still there, and worth a visit. Less than a hundred years later, the order was disbanded in Argentina, and the vegetable garden of the convent became the first pubic cemetery, the Cementerio del Norte. The dead were not buried but held in mausoleums above ground. As yellow fever broke out in downtown Buenos Aires, culminating in the epidemic of 1871, wealthier citizens moved north to safer ground, and the status of the district rose. The cemetery was remodelled in 1880. When you catch sight of the statuary inside these gates, the effect is astonishing in its exuberance and richness.The impressive tomb of General Julio Argentino Roca stands out on its corner site. Bronze victor’s wreaths adorn the side of the structure, and the angel atop the pediment holds two more – Roca was twice President of Argentina. Known as el Zorro - the Fox – he devised and led the 1878-1879 Conquista del Desierto, which pushed back the indigenous tribes – dominated by the Mapuche people – who attacked Argentinian settlements in Patagonia, killing about 1,000, capturing 15,000 more, and pre-empting Chilean-Mapuche domination of the area. With the help of the Remington rifle, he laid claim to huge tracts of land, which were awarded to his backers. The settlement of Patagonia by Welsh immigrants dates from this time. In a section of Recoleta set aside for prominent citizens, the Panteon Ciudadanos Meritorios, there’s a charming bas-relief in marble illustrating the New Testament verse on children. Its low-key simplicity is restful to the eye.Many famous and prominent people are buried here - presidents, scientists, the wealthy - including the modest tomb of the family of Eva Peron. The (English) guide book is a worthwhile purchase. Funerary sculpture and architecture in abundance is laid out to delight the eye. The most haunting story though is associated with a memorial striking for its beauty.Rufina Cambaceres was found dead on the evening of her 19th birthday. Despite being examined by three physicians, no cause of death could be established. She was interred, but some day later cemetery attendants noticed that the coffin had been moved. When they opened it, Rufina’s face was said to be scratched and injured, presumably in an attempt to escape or at least to be heard. She had been interred alive, while suffering from catalepsy. Her family commissioned the tomb you see. There are those who say they see a young lady in white wandering near the cemetery at night. Certainly the way death is treated quite casually here – all the dead above ground, ornate coffins on display behind glass and wrought iron – lends itself to such stories. Even if the sombre reminder as you exit frames mortality firmly in a Christian context. More at theproverbial.org.

Good place to visit. The cemetery of recoleta is an amazing place to spend sometime wandering around and watching the different styles of the many tomb stands (I do not know the exact word) where families are buried, some with their pictures. Also there is the tomb of the famous Vita Beron. We took many pictures. If you go at weekends you can pass by the very nearby Plaza Francia where a fair, free shows and shops are taking place.

where to stay?. nice place in the city for the cats and the history lovers. most of the famous argentinians are here, but if you want to enjoy ? the palce it is highly recommended to do the visit with a patented guide. Not so expensive
Fascinating. Fascinating , atmospheric, haunting cemetery . Highlight to see Eva Peron's family mausoleum. Beautiful statuary . A must see.

Most unusual cemetery ever.. We got such a surprise when we went to visit this cemetery, some are like miniature churches with proper altar's, some very well kept & others falling apart.There are so many to see & you would spend a good bit of time here.Very easy to walk to from City Center through lovely area for about 2 kilometers.

Most fascinating thing we saw in B.A.. Amazing history and beautiful architecture and statues. They only downside were the bathrooms---nasty and you have to pay the attendant for toilet paper----what a horrible job to sit in a smelly nasty bathroom and sell toilet paper to people.

What a great surprise . We wet looking for Eva Peron's mausoleum and found this incredible cemetery like no other I've seen. It is an amazing collection of new an old, maintained and neglected, simple to incredibly ornate. It reflects the architecture of Buenos Aires itself. Who knew you would see all the caskets!?!? High priority to see when in BA. Free too.
Recoleta Cemetery. This cemetery is like a world of it's own. Very calming and beautiful. We didn't have enough time to spend there, but I think that 2-3 hours would be ideal.

It is not a cementery, it's a museum. Recoleta cementery is one of the most rare places I have ever visited. This is because it is suposed to be a cementery, something frightening. But it is exactly the opposite. The cementery seems more like an art gallery.Our trip was exellent. The guide has the hability of express his ideas correctly. And she also has lot of information about the cementery. Legends of spirits which came back to live in the night or curiouos storys about burials were tollen. We had time to walk all arround the cementery. One hour it's time enough. The cementery has really lots of pieces of art. The crypts, some mausoleums, or crypts are worthy of being in a museum. For example, the obelisk in Sarmiento's crypt, which resemblems his masonic. Or maybe Amiral's Guillermo Brown mausoleum, which was made from the bronze of the boat guns he commanded. Another special fact is the high number of presidents buried here and their specials crypts. Sarmiento, Alfonsin, Alver or Mitre are only ones of these ones.In my opinion it's a very special places to visit. And not only to tourist, because people who live in this city should know more about their own city. If i have the chance to go back, i will do it grateful

Requiescant in peace (T. Gorrini). The Recoleta Cemetery is a historical 'museum' in Argentina. It has great significance for its buildings, and famous people resting in peace there. The cemetery is located in Buenos Aires city, and covers a very large field.In the Cemetery you can have a guided visiting, or go on your own. There are lots of famous people and families, like Eva Duarte, Leloir family, Sarmiento, Alfonsín, for example. It's really expensive to have a crypt there.I think it's a good experience to go to the cemetery, because you learn a lot about it, but maybe people wolud be afraid of some diferent things, like old dusty thombs.I recommend going to the cemetery because it gives you general culture and you learn important things.

A interesting visit. The Recoleta Cemetery was founded in 1822 during the government of Alvear. It is located in Recoleta in the nearness of the City Centre. It is known by its great architecture, which was designed by Juan Buschiazzo. He designed the gate which has a frieze with symbols related to Christianity and death. Besides, it is also famous for the influential people in history who are buried there. Three argentinian presidents(Sarmiento, Alfonsin and Dorrego) rest in this Cemetery. Other famous people like Evita, Lola Mora, Firco (a sportsperson) and Pablo Pizzurno rest there too. There are lots of stories than you can hear from this Cemetery. Some of them are shocking and make you feel petryfied like the horryfing story about Rufina. She had catalepsia and she was burred alive. Scratches were found on the closed door in her grave because she died of sofocation. In my opinion, if you have enough time and you are interested in it, it is a nice place in which you can learn lots of stories which probably you have never heard. Why don't you try?

The cemetery that became into a museum. The fabulous and extraordinary cemetry was opened in 1822 on Recoleta, at the city of Buenos aires, and designed by the architect Juan Buschiazzo. It is popular because of the famous people that rest in peace in that place and also because of its magnificents sculptures and graves. At the entry, you can find some phrases like "Waiting for God" and "Requiescant in peace" companied by some strong symbols. One of the stories that are there, and by which i was surprised the most, was about a nineteen years old girl who suffered of epilepsy. After an attack caused by her illness, her parents thought that she was dead. Later, a cemetery guard saw the coffin moving so he ask for her family. when the young girl's mother said to open the coffin, all of them could see the top of the coffin scratched. Then they realised that she didn't died of epilepsy then she died for asphixia. Inspite there are a lot of strange and interesting stories, i wouldn't recommend the cemetry to skittish tourist to spend their time unless they be brave at the magnificent museum.

I would love to be buried there!. Recoleta's Cemetery is one of the best cemeteries in the world. It was designed by J. Buchiazzo and It's gates were opened for the first time in 1822. Since then, some of the most interesting people in Argentina's history were buried in there. In 2007, It's gate was listed as a National Historic Monument. Since it was inaugurated, it's the final destination of certainly not ordinary people. More than 4000 people were buried in there, from sportsmans, presidents, nobel prizes; up to just rich people. I totally recommend visiting this place. In there you can learn about Argentina's history and have a good walk while watching beautiful mausoleums or sculptures. I give it a 10 out of 10.

It's not common at all, but is a museum anyway.. Recoleta cementery is located in Buenos Aires, Argentina. It was innagurated in 1822 and it was firstused by the Recoletos Monks; then, it became more popular with the yellow feber. People that had died because of this ilness have been buried there. As time goes by, the cementery becames a very important, prestigious and expensive one. Only rich families could have their relatives there and they havecompeted one to other building big and expensive mausoleums to see wich family was the most important.  Because of that, nowadays the cementery is considered one of the best museums all over the world. It has ones of the best graves and obviously there are many famous people such as Sarmiento, Dorrego, William Brown and Eva Duarte Peron.As soon as you enter, you see a large number of unique and wonderful mausoleums. What is more, the cementry has manyfantastic works of art that have been made by famous artists. The place has also its own horror stories andthey are really exciting. May be before I would never thougth that a cemetery could be a tourist attraction but then I realized thatI was wrong. Moreover, I find Recoleta Cemetery more interesting as a museum than other real museums. So,I recommend it absolutely; as soon as I have the oportunity to visit it again, I will not doubt!
Well worth a visit. This Cemetary is an oasis of calm in a bustling city. Amazing sights and fantastic tombs.Afterwards get food, drinks and ice cream in the surrounding shops, bars and restaurants.

The Busy Cats of Recoleta. Legend has it that the cats in the Recoleta Cemetery play with the spirits each night to keep them within the walls of this amazing cluster of mausoleums. As the cemetery now holds nearly 5000 spirits they must be very busy each night. No wonder they were all asleep in the sun when we wandered the roads and alleyways of this city of the deceased. Our guide felt their presence may be more to do with the fact that they are fed everyday! This was one of the highlights of Buenos Aires. Set in the ritzy Recoleta area the cemetery was a mix of the weird and the wonderful. A green pole marks the final resting place of Irish born William Brown, founder of the Argentinian Navy, a huge black and white marble edifice houses the remains of Jose Paz founder of La Prensa (a BA daily newspaper) and a rather plain brownish construction houses members of the Duarte family, the most famous of which is Evita. Presidents, Nobel Prize winners, actors, writers and even a boxer are all buried in this labyrinth of marble and angels. Quiet and serene this is a must do for any visitor to Buenos Aires

Creepy, yet very beautiful. I love going to the Recoleta Cemetery (Cementerio de Recoleta), because 1). It is BEAUTFUL, 2). It is QUIET, and 3). It's a historical place in Argentina, where many known argentine people are resting in peace...It is a bit creepy to think of a cemetery as something tourists would want to visit, but it's gorgeous, the building are old and have stories to tell; it's like a city in the middle of the city of Buenos Aires. You can see all the architecture, and see the buildings (where people actually live) behind it, it is a different world, and there are lots of CATS, which are cute and friendly (however, I would not pet them, cuz I don't know where they've been). They dont charge you for the visit, but they ask you how old you are, I believe this is for security reasons, like minors shouldn't be wondering around on their own, but it's free, and it's always opened. There are some guides, but you either have to get one of your own, or pay one if you see one. If you are a tourist, which you probably are, then I would recommend getting a guide to show you around, because, like I said before, the architecture is fantastic, and there is a lot of argenitne history in that cemetery. Take lots of pictures, it's a really nice place. However, be safe.

Amazing architecture. I have never been to a cemetery like this before. The architecture on the mausoleums is absolutely amazing. I was lucky enough to find a guide hanging out in front of the cemetery. For only $25 he showed my wife and I around for 2 hours and explained any and everything there. This is a must see for any architecture buff visiting the city. It is also located in a very cool neighborhood next to lots of great shopping

Peaceful history lesson. Located in the lovely Recoleta area of Buenos Aires, this is a must stop on any tour of the city. I wouldn't normally visit a cemetary on a trip, but this is really a who's who of Argentine history. The site is incredibly well kept and free to attend. A tourist guide offers to sell printed maps of the cemetary for 10 pesos. I'd recommend it! This is a huge place.Opening hours were 10am-7pm

Strange, but hauntingly beautiful. If you are Northern European or North American, this style of cemetery will be alien to you and you will probably wonder why you would visit a cemetery as a visitor. But even if you ignore Evita's tomb (and I did) there is enough Gothic beauty to enchant you for an hour or two and if you don't feel some sadness or sympathy you are a head-hearted fool.I would class this as a "must visit" for anyone going to BA

Great tour....... We were going to wonder around aimlessly ....but ... i read other reviews on the tours and bumped in to SImon ! WHo had some excellent reviews for the tour of the cemetry.We happily enlisted his services and spent an extremely interesting morning getting the low down of the city and its history through its dead. Simon was excellent and do try and find him for your own tour - i would happily hire him for a city tour!

Most beautiful cemetery I've ever seen. For me it was incredible. Cemeteries in Belgium are quite boring. Ive never seen anything like this. All graves were like little chapels. Many famous people from BA are buried here.Sometimes it was a bit weird as well as some of the coffins were a bit exposed.Really nice atmosphere, beautiful and interesting artisan market when you come out of the cemetery.

Recoleta Cemetary. Recoleta Cemetery is a who's who in Argentine history. The Cementery includes graves of most of the influential persons of Argentina, including Generals, Presidents, famous wealthy, Eva Peron. The cemetery has massive impressive mausoleums decorated in a variety of styles. This is a definite for the visitor to B.A. Go early and allow about two-three hours. then have lunch at one of the nearby restaurants.

OMG -- Grandioso!. Who knew this cemetary would be so massive in stature. Get a guide so you can understand who's who in this cemetary. I'm so glad I found onlin FREE tours called Buena Onda. All I had to do was show up Sunday @ 3:45pm in front of Pilar Church for FREE tour of cemetary AND Recoleta. Lucky me that no one else showed up and I got a private tour for 2 hours! He spoke Spanish & English. I tipped guide, at my discretion, & went on my merry way. Was fabulous and FREE!

Fascinating. This is well worth a visit - a must I'd say. It's a cemetery with exquisite crypts which hose some of Argentina's most famous politicians, scientists, writers eye. Eva Peron is buried there. Lose yourself here for a couple of hours. On a Sunday there is a flea market outside - extensive and fun

A must see in Buenos Aires. In the middle one of one of the most beautiful barrios of Buenos Aires, la recoleta you find this beautiful cenentery. French construction, you can remember Pere Lachaise in París. Less trees but a nice place to visit and admire the great old times of this lovely city

A bit creepy; but fascinating. Wandering around graveyards is not something I would normally plan to do as part of a holiday; but this was recommended by a friend, and since it was within easy walking distance of our hotel, we thought, why not?Glad we did. It was a fascinating place, and much of the quality and intricacy of the sculpture was incredible. It was like wandering around a small ornate town, with most of the tombs the size of small houses.We saw the tomb of Evita (the Duarte family); but many of the others were much more ornate.We visited alone; but I could imagine that this would be a good place to take a guided tour, and learn a little about the families interred here.Some of the tombs had coffins visible through gates, and some of the coffins were clearly children, which was a bit creepy, and a bit sad; but nevertheless, very fascinating.

I wish I had more time to explore. The Recoleta Cemetary was an interesting site. I have not seen anything quite like this, and it was HUGE. Only regret I have is not making enough time to fully explore what Recoleta had to offer.

Palaces for the dead. This was an elaborate and immersive journey through the history of Argentina.
The cementerio recoleta is home to late elite of Buenos Aires for the last 150 years.
The elite are housed in dramatic mausoleums with memorable statues, stained glass windows, marble pillars, obelisks and several other beautiful adornments.

Fascinating place. I found my visit to the cemetery fascinating. The structures which were built to remember those who are buried there are amazing. Most people go there to find Evita's place of rest.

Fascinating place. Looking for a fun day out with the family?. Look no further than the local cemetery. What could be more fun that that?. But seriously, this place is definitely well worth the visit, although I recommend that you go with a tour guide because there are so many fascinating stories in this place which make it even more amazing that it already is.

A beautiful cemetery. This is a beautiful cemetery. The tombs are all above ground and every one is different. The sculptures are lovely and it is a nice walk. We had a tour guide with us for the day who enriched the visit with stories of the families in the cemetery. You must also visit Eva Peron's resting spot, easily found if you look for lots of flowers decorating the tomb entrance.

You can feel the souls of Evita.... This cemetery is incredible, not usually something to do when you visit a city but The Recoleta has that special feeling that maybe only Le Pere lachaise in Paris has. It is worth going there for a half hour walk, if you are there go to the old restaurant in front called La Biela, typical old Argentinean brasserie. Excellent oldish atmosphere.

Hire A Guide. This place is spectacular (more so if you come from a country that doesn't have a mausoleum). I paid 15pesos for a map but it wasn't any help at all. I wish I hired a guide because apart from Evita I don't know any of the history (there are some fascinating stories I have now read) so I highly recommend this. Take lots of photos towards the sky because there are so many beautiful angels etc on top of vaults. Few well fed cats roaming around which I also enjoyed (I read if you want to donate food at 9am and 4pm older ladies come to do this). Evitas grave was not marked at the lanes so ask people passing by. Not to be missed in BA!

Well worth a look. Great way to lose an hour wandering around the mauoleums (it's facinating). Also its free and easy to get to by bus :) Avoid the man ouside who draws you a useless map and then "asks" for a donation.....for Evita's tomb follow the tourists or ask them

Must do in Buenos Aires. A beautiful place and so interesting to walk around. Definitely bring your camera as you won't believe some of the monuments. We didn't do any research and didn't pay for the tour and wish we would have. It's interesting enough to just walk around, but I imagine hearing some of the stories would be even better.The problem is that the guides out front seem like such scam artists. They start accosting you before you even get to the entrance and are so pushy and forward, we were completely turned off. Too bad as in hindsight, I wish we had put up with one of them for the stories.

Must see!. I, ve been very impressed! That was the last stop in our trip and I've been already disappointed but then saw this! That is unbelievable! I could never imagine that cemetery can look like that! That is a city full of different marvellous houses, churches, palaces, castles but definitely not graves!!! Worth seeing! !!!

So many interesting stories, not just Evita.. As odd as I sound, I cannot reccommend this place enough, in fact I went twice! Its almost like a little town of its own and its so easy to just get lost in this beautiful place. One thing I would say though, is to research some stories first. There are some fascinating tales about a girl buried alive (Rufina Cambaceres) or the Italian Grave night worker who worked so much so he could buy his own grave then comitted suicide and the story of the young girl whos dog died at exactly the same time as her....I could go on. Despite being so beautiful, it is very touristy due to Eva Peron/Duarte´s body being buried here but dont let that put you off. This place is a photographers dream - some of the graves are works of art yet some are delapidated and unloved. We never managed to get a map but there are some near the entrance apparantly for a small donation. I suggest getting one if possible. Evita is number 88, on the left of the cemetary and is relatively low key. You will know which is hers with the mountain of flowers outside her door. Seriously, get yourself here at weekend when you can also enjoy the outdoor market in Plaza Francia, its unmissable.
Must see. A history of the country with dignitaries buried here. See Evita Peron's pantheon. Very worthwhile! Mausoleums and fascinating histories of families.
Worth a visit. Interesting place to wander about. It's like a city within a city but only the rich are buried here.
Recoleta. Throughly enjoyed walking through this cemetery. The highlight was seeing the Eva Peron site. A must see if in Buenos Aires.
Incredible. The arquitecture it's just amazing! I've never seen a cemetery like it. Great historic, political and social personalities rest here. Odd sense of reverence throughout.

Worth the time. This is a beautiful place, if you've been to the cemeteries in either New Orleans or Havana, it has a similar feel with an 'upgrade'! It feels like a mini city, with streets and houses, the statuary and workmanship are exemplary. A quiet place to wander away an afternoon.

RECOLETA CEMETARY/PERE LACHAISE (PARIS). I visited Pere Lachaise cimetary in Paris, because I have been told it was a "Must" and it was really so, but if I have to compare it with Recoleta Cimetary, find Recoleta even greater....don,t loose it !You can see even the " El Pilar Church and it´s cloister " it is in the same block than the cimetery. I recomand it very much !!!!I hope you will enjoy it, and welcome to Argentina !!!Mamines

A Great Collection of Dead People. We went to Recoleta mid morning and hired a local guide. They hang around the entrance. She was not expensive and could guide us in English, Spanish or Portugese. (Note: make the money deal up front. We did and then I knew the amount prior to touring.) She told stories about famous people that helped bring context to this city and country. Walked around about 1.5 hours. Fully enjoyable. I did see Eva Perone.

The oldest and most importante cementery in Argentina. If you want to know the customs of a people, you have to visit their cementeries. This is the oldest and more importante cementery in Argentina. The tombs and mausoleums were built by artist, and there lies the History Argentina personalities of all times.

Enchanting!. Artistic and enigmatic. Be sure you don't arrive too late, as at 17.45, they start asking people out. I will definitely come back for more. Make sure you take a guided tour or do some research beforehand so as not to miss anything!

A cemetery that is more like a park!. Right in the heart of Buenas Aires this is a site worth exploring. The setting is incredible and you can spend hours looking at monuments that are so beautiful that they are works of art. Eva Peron is buried here. Get the map when you enter. The cemetery is laid out in many paths like a village.

One of the best places to visit in Buenos Aires. Great place to visit. Be sure to spend a few hours there. We had taken a city tour that included the cemetery but only spent a short time looking at this wonderful burial place. The place covers alot of ground. I would also hire a guide to take you to the various mausolems and chapels. We especially wanted to see where Evita Peron was buried. It is difficult to find without a guide or brochure. This place is worth a visit in Buenos Aires

Not to be missed.. I live in Buenos Aires and take visitors to Cementerio de la Recoleta as a "must see" when they are here (the date I was forced to enter here is just a place holder). Technically the cemetery is a mausoleum because the bodies are interred in above ground tombs (for the most part). It is absolutely vast (14 acres), and is a rabbit warren of alleyways. The tombs range from the most amazingly ornate, decorated with elaborate stone work and statuary, to broken down wrecks that appear to have been abandoned -- last resting places of people who cover the waterfront from the rich and famous to people with no discernible pedigree. Some are very old and some are brand new. You cannot see it all in several hours or even a day. I've been many times and have never seen it all. At some point you reach tomb overload. There is a map at the entrance that indicates a number of famous people's tombs, but otherwise there is no other way to find your way around. However, there are always tour guides at the entrance touting for business (in different languages). I've never taken one of these tours, but I occasionally linger on the edges and listen in. They seem helpful and informative, especially if you are unfamilar with Argentine history, because they focus on the accomplishments of famous people. Naturally Evita's tomb is the main magnet, and even if you are on a tour you will have to wait to get up close. I'd recommend that even if you take a tour that you leave some time just to roam around afterwards on your own. I also recommend that you plan a whole morning or afternoon for your visit so that you can visit the Iglesia de Nuestra Señora del Pilar (Our Lady of Pilar church) next door. It was originally a monastery and church that was disbanded in 1732. The garden was converted to the first cemetery but the current mausoleum was laid out in 1822. If you go on the weekends there is a large flea market in a park opposite the church. All the restaurants opposite the cemetery are good, and some of them have reasonably priced lunch menus which employees outside each will hound you about. I'd take a leaflet from each and then figure out it away from the clamor to drag you in.

PROBABLY THE MOST FAMOUS CEMETERY EVER. The old Recoletos monks cemetery became gradually open to the public, and after the yellow fever of 1871 aristocrats developed the custom of building family graves here. When Argentina became one of the wealthiest countries in the world, the richness of the ruling families showed in a competence over the luxury and imagination displayed in this funerary houses. Then all architectural styles in the history of mankind were employed, from ancient Egypt to modernism. Evita Perón's body ended here (in this landmark of the class she hated) after it`s long journey. Being in Buenos Aires and not visiting this cemetery is a criminal offense!
what a wonderful cemetary. Its a BA must - full of history and the most wonderful memorials , private chapels and mazes of mausoleums . Get a professional guide . I loved this place.

Recoleta Cemetery. Recoleta is not just a cemetery but a necropolis of mausoleums of the rich and famous of Buenos Aires. It costs less to live your whole life in Buenos Aires than to be buried in R.ecoleta For more info read my blog.http://havefunflysafe.com/2013/06/22/things-i-have-learned-in-buenos-aires/

A must visit in BA. Yes it's a cemetery but it is beautiful, the sculptures, the tombs, the narrow paths weaving through the cemetery. It is sad to see the the condition of some of the tombs but this is part of life, a large part and I have never seen anything like this. Of course the main focus for most people is Eva Perons tomb which is always adorned with bouquets of flowers. For me the most interesting were the unique tombs in amongst all the others and the stories of the not so famous people. There are maps available to get to specific ones, we were on a tour so got more information too. but we also just took some time and wandered on our own finding random little lanes and enjoying the unique location. An interesting visit that I would not skip in BA but does not need a whole day or even a whole afternoon, 1-2hours max depending how much you want to see.

Unforgettable. I spent a beautiful sunny afternoon with my husband in this cemetery and will never forget it. We kept saying to each other "Come over here!" "Check this out!" "You gotta see this!" It was unlike anything I had ever seen. You will get the most out of it if you do a little homework and find one or two people buried there (like Evita) and a little about them before you go. Get a map when you enter but also just let yourself wander and get lost in the power of the place. When you leave, there are a number of great places to eat right along the cemetery to reflect and collect your thoughts.
interesting. You cant miss Cementerio de la Recoleta. Make sure you go with a guide that explains everything to you.

Cemetary worth visiting. A sort of New Orleans style collection of above ground graves. Very interesting collection of people and buildings over a long period - famous and unknown. Could use some care - list of names is only a small percentage of the people there.
Interestingplace. Worth a visit and not just to see Eva Peron's resting place, but to see the statues and art work throughout the cemetery.

Very interesting!. This was a interesting cemetery; it was a quite elaborate and peaceful city of the dead. Of course being able to spend a moment at the burial site of Eva Peron and family was memorable.

Well worth a visit. I am very fond of cemeteries and have visited several extraordinary ones around the world. Recoleta is not expansive like the huge Staglieno Cemetery in Genoa, but packs thousands of mausolea within a few acres. As you stroll along its shady avenues you will discover some astonishing examples in a wide variety of styles and often covered with delightfully over-ripe sculptural detail. Many of the family tombs are quite small with loved ones stacked up within. Evita is entombed in her family's (Duarte) mausoleum, but following some unfortunate and ghoulish incidents encased in concrete some thirty feet below grade. (Juan Peron is buried in another of the city's cemeteries.)Less melancholy is the adjacent Recoleta Church near the entrance. This 'city of the dead' is surrounded beyond its walls by a very lively assortment of restaurants and night clubs.

An interesting place to visit. The cemetary was very impressive. At times a bit eerie, a few of the doors were broken and the cats would hang out in there, which made it seem stranger. There are tour guides inside for a price and we were solicited for money outside the cemetary, with a guy who hang drew a fairly useless map on a piece of paper. I would steer clear of them. To navigate I downloaded the endless mile recoleta cemetary app, which helped us to find out way. They point out 25 tombs, which had pretty interesting stories behind them. We wandered the area ofr about two and half hours. There are lots of opportunities for great pictures so bring your camera!

Must Do in BA. It was recommended to us to visit Recoleta Cemetery when we were in BA last year. Well worth the visit to see the mausoleums and wander around the "streets". We stumbled around on our own, but take a guided tour if you are short on time. We found our way to Eva (Evita) Peron's tomb - just look for the crowds.

Back in Time. Very interesting Cemetery where you can visit the tombs of many historical and important members of the Argentine History or important families.As a sample : here was buried Eva Peron (Evita) and can visit her tomb. Entrance is Free and if you like you can pay for a guided tour.

Photographer's paradise for interesting monuments. Love the Recoleta Cemetery for photographing all the amazing monuments and structures. Contrary to other reviews, Eva Peron is not interred there, but the Duarte Crypt is located here. It can be a very dehydrating visit in warmer seasons so take water to stay comfortable!

It's a must see if you are in Buenos Aires. First of all, it is free. Many people want to visit Evita Duarte Peron's tomb. That's not the only reason to visit as there are plenty of sarcophagi and statues. The cemetery is part of Buenos Aires history. Nevertheless, if you want to find Evita's tomb, I recommend that you follow my traveling guide's directions (many people had a hard time finding it): I will quote Lonely Planet's Argentina guide (excellent aid to plan your trip, by the way! Tip: buy the book, not kindle) "Go up to the first major ‘intersection’ from the entrance, where there’s a statue. Turn left, continue until a mausoleum blocks your way, go around it to the right and turn right at the wide ‘street.’ After three blocks look to the left and you’ll likely see people at her site, along with bunches of flowers." Taken from my LP guide.

Extremely historical and interesting. I never would have thought that wandering through a cemetery would be interesting but Recoleta is no ordinary cemetery. It is not only huge but the actual tombs are artistic and spectacular! Eva Perrone is buried here along with others of importance. The tombs are like "everlasting houses", they are so beautiful, large and decorated. The church next door is also worth a look and there is a museum filled with interesting things and old religious art. The window of the museum looks out over the cemetery and gives you a great idea of just how large the area is that it encompasses. I would definitely recommend a visit...very much a part of the history of the area.

Yep.. It is a cemetery but definitely worth the visit. There are guides at the entrance that are very helpful. Take the time to visit this cemetery. I know.. it sounds rather strange but it is worth it... Evita is buried here and many other famous people from Buenos Aires. Try to pick a sunny day.
Interesting. Well worth a visit. Very interesting history. Could easily spend hours wandering around. Took a guided tour. Tipped tour guide at end.

An interesting walk !. We spent a few hours being guided around the cemetery. A little macabre but interesting. (Multi-storey burial plots.) Visited the usual tombs such as Eva Peron's. The cemetery fronts onto a square and there is a great café (Café La Biela) on the other side - "Coffee with Juan Manuel Fangio" !

The most memorable cemetery ever!. I was told to visit the famous Recoleta Cemetery and I am very glad I did! It's very clean and feels more like a park than a cemetery. The tombstones are amazing and the entire place is adorned with statues. We had a guide and she told us the stories of the tombs, which were very interesting and we saw Eva's grave as well...

fantastic architecture, and oh! the cats. The variety of architecture in mausoleum design makes Recoleta Cemetery a pleasure to explore -- gothic, celtic, art deco, and very plain designs vie for the visitor's attention, but not as aggressively as the resident cats who snake between your legs and purr as you pet them. This cemetery instilled a sense of real serenity in me.

Eerie and rather disturbing. This is like a walled city of the dead at the heart of the Recoleta district. Once inside, you forget you are in the city at all, as you wander the narrow alleys between the hundreds of enormous tombs and vaults. Once off the beaten track, you find yourself alone, with maybe a cat for company. Many ornate coffins are visible through the windows of the tombs. A few tombs are in disrepair, and we saw coffins exposed to the air, and crumbling away, high above our heads....Altogether, I found the place rather oppressive and claustrophobic...it was a relief to leave. However, the experience was memorable, and a "must do" I think.

recoleta cemetery. this cemetery is more like a small town on its own due to the neatly arranged tombs and street names. the epitaphs are very grand, some ex-argentine presidents are buried here as well.
Very cool and unusual...... This is a very unique cemetery. All above ground, with essentially mini-mausoleums containing remains. Evita Peron is intered here, and it was cool to see it.....

Remarkable Cemetery!. Recoleta Cemetery is somewhere every visitor to Buenos Aires should make time to see.It is very much like a mini city - simply remarkable and like nothing you have ever seen.For 10 pesos you can get a map of the cemetery at the entrance and this will help guide you around the cemetery.
Must see. It is like nothing I have ever seen. Make sure not to miss this when you are Buenos Aires. You can wander around for 15 minutes or stay for hours. It's really impressive.

WOW! What a place to see.. This is the most interesting cemetary you will ever see. The competition for most beautiful or unique above ground tombs is phenominal. The architecture of the tombs are incredible-amazing artisans of stone work.

Very cool. Recoleta Cemetery was like nothing we have ever seen. It was as if we were in a mini city within the city. Definitely read about it before you go though as English speaking tours are only a couple days a week and there really is not a guide to learn the history.

Can't miss. What an interesting cemetary. Loved walking around the rows and rows of elaborate mausoleums. So cool to see. You can't visit Buenos Aires without coming here. There was a cool outdoor market right outside the entrance as well. Add this to your list of things to do in B.A.

Interesting. Supposed to be 'up there' with the biggest and best cemetery's! An interesting range of 'properties'. The plot next to Eva Peron can be purchased for $75K. Situated in nice area and worth a look.
Beautiful cemetery. Highlight is the Evita tomb but many other beautiful tombs to see that are like art. Stray cats add to the character

Unique and special place. The cemetery should not be missed. There are many special areas and stories to be heard. You should plan to spend extra time here to really be able to step back and reflect on the lifes that have been memorialized here.

A must see while in B.A.. This is like no other cemetary in the world. A must see while visiting Buenos Aires. You could spend hours seeing the different tombs and never get bored. Quite fascinating, especially when you consider the money spent on the tombs and then consider the economy of the city itself.

Amazing cemetery, could spend hours walking around!. Quite unique to see this cemetery, and view the elaborate tombstones and graves! The cemetery is right in the midst of a busy shopping area, and is worth a visit!

Quirky and darkly fun. Okay, this cemetary was not what I expected - more like a miniature city than a typical final resting place. We toured it through Buenos Tours half-day tour and thought it worthwhile. There are some good stories to be heard and some beautiful sculptures and memorials to enjoy. It's fascinating how families must maintain a lease on their loved ones' plots! You can sell your plot to another family if times get hard, and they relocate the "inhabitants." Anyway, this is worth an hour of your touring time.

Worth a trip.. Huge cemetary were the wealthiest errected final shines (tumbs) for themselves as one last legacy to leave behind. It's self guided, cool, interesting, weird and a little odd all wrapped in one. I enjoyed myself and there are large museums near by.
A cemetery !!!. I was surprised that a cemetery was listed among the top attractions in BA , took a tour and it was very interesting. Eva who is still adored by many Argentinians is buried there.

Follow A Cat. Easy to get to by Taxi Tour Guides available at front entrance for reasonable price (Highly recommended) each Crypt has a story to tell the architecture and Iron work immaculate.Make sure you go to the church next door great religious gift stall in court yard selling amazing candles for a few $$
just amazing!. Being an old woman I didn´t want to go but my private tour guide convinced and I was so thankful . This is pure art

Bizarre touristic point. It is weird to think about visiting a cemetery. But, there is a lot of huge buildings around the remains of very important local citizens. Worth the visit. Evita Peron's tomb is quite disappointing.

The Cemetary. Never did I imagine myself visiting a cemetary in a foreign country, let alone Argentina. Upon arrival you are simply astonished at the amont of beaitifully crafted tombs and cathederal-esque style of so many of them. Such a beautiful and peaceful place to wander, especially on a sunny Sunday afternoon when the Argentinians are recovering from their antics over the weekend. Like nothing ive seen!

Found the whole thing macabre and boring. Aside from Eva Peron's tomb didn't have much historical or intellectual impact. Also interesting that she is buried there as this particular cemetery stands for everything she was against. Aesthetically feels way over crowded as if the rich/elite of BA are competing with one another even after death -trying to keep up with the Jones'. Recoleta itself is a beautiful area to walk and a half hour or so in the cemetery if in the area is something to consider.

Enjoyable even without a tour. We weren't going to do this, but had time left over and decided to enjoy the beautiful day outdoors. After visiting Recoleta I would say this is a site not to be missed. Whether you do your homework and/or have a guide, or choose to simply buy a map at the entrance and explore (as we did), it's a not-to-be-missed site. We found it interesting that many of the mausoleums had functioning (but locked) glass doors that revealed a casket, topped with framed photos and recently placed flowers. So, in addition to seeing incredible art adorning many of the monuments, you also get a taste of the culture's attitude toward death. Make sure you take a camera!
not at all morbid. This is a vast cemetery, where you can find Eve Peron buried. Excellent guided tours if you are interested.

Highlight of BA. This is an impressive cemetery located in the heart of the city. Was the highlight of my trip to BA which is short on attractions. Eva Peron's grave is what most people go to see but there are many ornate tombs with impressive architecture.

You must see this. Our tour guide took us to Recoleta Cemetary and it was just astounding. Yes, it might be a bit creepy to tour a cemetery but the sculpture alone makes it worth the visit. The ornate buildings are impressive and the personal touches to many of the mausoleums is really something. This is a wonderful free thing to do while in Buenos Aires.
Worth a look. It is an interesting cemetery. Very ornate. Worth a visit if you are in BA. We walked around for about half an hour and that was enough for me.

Taking cemeteries to a whole new level. This is the most incredible cemetery I have ever visited anywhere in the Christian world. The tombs are the size of small houses and the cemetery has the feel of a small city, with roads and cross roads, side streets and back streets. The great and the good of Buenos Aires are buried here from the founding fathers to Evita. It is quite something to behold; not vast but compact and with the high rise blocks of the city towering over on three sides. The park in front of the cemetery is quite beautiful too with some amazing trees, especially a huge rubber tree over 200 years old and some beautiful Araucaria. Well worth a visit to absorb a feel for the historical figures and the cultural essence of Argentina.
a must see. cemetery where Eva Peron rests , but be prepared for a queu in busy periods since this is the monument every comes for

Recoleta Cemetery. This is one place I did not want to visit, however, we went for a walk and ended up there. Simon, one of the 'free' guides out the front offered to take us for a tour. We were pleased to hear an English voice so agreed. What a pleasant surprise! He was very interesting, and was able to tell us a lot about Argentinian history based on the families there. I did find it creepy, but fascinating. It was a whole village of mausoleums, in varying states of disrepair, some simple, but most elaborate. Most of Argentina's elite seem to be represented there. i would recommend a visit, but definitely with a guide.

Lots of History. We visited as a part of our City Tour and found it very interesting. You need a guide to explain the History of the tombs. The size and number of Mausoleums was amazing. It was also something to see the tomb of Eva Peron.

Definitely worth a visit. In my opinion, this place was well worth the visit, but seriously creepy. I wasn't expecting to be able to see coffins, to see so many mausoleums in disrepair, and even feral cats (sleeping on some coffins!). Yet, it was also a really beautiful and sort of otherworldly place.

Incredible for Argentine History/Culture Buffs. If you know anything about Argentine history or culture, this is a must see. Tombs of presidents, literary greats, etc. And even if you don't know much about Argentina, the sheer size and impressiveness of the mausolea will amaze.
