The Basilica next door, Nuestra Señora del Pilar, has a charming museum of colonial artifacts and early Argentine history.

Excellent Visit - unexpected tour worth taking. Incredible history attached to most burial crypts. We were offered a cheap tour outside by "George". My wife and I hired George and we would have missed so much otherwise. He explained some of the famous/infamous families that owned the crypts and have 50, 100, 150 family members buried in their family crypt. He knows the recent sale prices USD $1 million, $2 million, and up. Some are empty as they are an investment. Well worth the visit. Again, without a knowledgeable person, we would have missed so much.
Interesting, but use a free guide. This cemetery is interesting, but there is no way you can really appreciate it without a guide. We used Buena Onda free tours and it was great.
Very Interesting. Amazing how much money and effort went into building these grand structures to house the dead. Lots of good history with great stories.

cute. We went to the cemetery on a Saturday morning. It is quite busy with tourists but free to get in. There are guides offering tours if you want one. We only had a quick wander round really. It’s very exclusive and as you can imagine the graves are huge and some quite extravagant. It’s very well kept with lovely tree lined avenues within the cemetery and is a nice place to have a walk around. It won’t take you long, depending how much you want to look at I suppose. Most of the graves have glass doors so you can actually see the coffins inside. On a Saturday there’s a cute market on the green outside the cemetery with lots of stalls selling gifts and crafts which was lovely. We had some lunch in one of the eateries opposite the cemetery which was nice but expensive as you’d expect. If you’re in the area, I would recommend a visit to the cinema to see Evita’s grave and have a look round. It’s a nice free attraction in BA and the area is worth a wander round.

Worth seeing. It was much more interesting than I thought a cemetery would be. We went first as part of a city tour, and a few days later we came back to the area to see the flea market and walked through it again. It's interesting how some are fantastically kept, and some look like they haven't been touched in many many years. Completely falling apart and the wood on the caskets falling apart. Good thing they all have to have metal liners.The stories behind them are what make it interesting, so I would recommend going on one of the tours they offer.
Must see!. This was unlike any cemetery you will see in North America, Europe, etc. It is a must see if in Buenos Aires. Bring a good camera and watch out for the cats!

no need for guide. Very unique cemetery. There are lots of tour guides outside of the entrance that make it seem like you are required to pay for a tour, but they are not neccesary. Great to walk around and see the history. If you´re really interested in knowing the details we found an iPhone App about the cemetery.

Just like any other cemetery for the riches. We went to see Evita Peron's grave. It is under Familia Duarte. In June there was no line. It was a nice grave/monument but honestly the entire cemetery is just like any other cemetery of the world for the rich and famous people. It is not a significant place for its beauty like the Merry Cemetery in Romania, or Koyasan in Japan, or the cemetery in Stockholm.

Interesting. This was maybe the best place in all of Recoleta. I was surprised at how well kept up the entire place was. Yes some of the crips are showing their age but the walkways and bathrooms were above standard. Definitely worth a look.

Interesting, in a macabre sort of way ... Getting there was an experience. Trust me, you don't want to take the subway if: a) you're in a hurry and, b) it's a hot day. We finally exited the subway only to find there are no directional signs and the street maps are not situated north to south ... they're directional based on the river (go figure). Anyway, we were meeting a guide at the cemetery so were anxious to get there. Asking directions of people on the street was useless as people either didn't speak English or were in a hurry (it was the middle of a business day) ... and our Spanish, evidently, wasn't as good as we thought. We finally arrived at the cemetery an hour late so missed our guide. After several minutes of frustration, we decided to try and decipher the cemetery ourselves. We enjoyed seeing the statuary and walking among the different crypts but probably would have gotten a lot more out of our visit with someone who could tell us about the history of the cemetery. All in all, it was actually one of the most interesting places we visited during our stay.

Interesting inside and out.. If you are in Buenos Aires this is a good place to visit, what makes it better is the location and the open market outside where you can experience the local culture (no tango dancing thou).
Fascinating. Definitely worth a visit, the Recoleta Cemetery is an amazing stroll through the history of BA. Some of the tombs are as big as our home! Incredible.

Well worth a visit, beats most of BA!. BA had left us wondering what the hype was about, mind you we have been spoilt in S America. Recoleta was one of the highlights. Fascinating just to walk and see the sights, marvel at the marble and recall the ages where only the man counted an the rest of the family was covered by y familia......
A Must!. It really is amazing. And it is huge. So many mausoleums competing to be more grand. Eva Peron's is actually relatively modest!
Not your New England cemetery. Walk into what looks like a miniature village, inhabited by cats. The history, the art of the tombs and the overall beauty is worth the visit.

Odd but interesting. It is a bit odd to visit a cemetery as a touristic attraction while locals visit their lost and loved ones there, but I would recommend to go there, not only because of Evita's tomb which is not easy to find at all, but to see all other tombs as eternal memories of special eras of the Argentine history.

Surprisingly interesting. We took a guided tour of Buenos Aires and this was the last stop on the tour, and probably the most interesting (and certainly the most unusual). Odd that a cemetery would be a major tourist attraction. But this was different from any we've seen in the States.Private, grandiose mausoleums and statues are laid out in neat rows throughout the cemetery. Yet each one is unique. A good percentage had glass windows and doors where you could see the coffins inside, and many clearly were suffering from what appeared to be years of neglect - broken windows, exposing the coffins to the elements. One wonders whether the descendants are still around to support the upkeep.Of course, everyone makes sure they stop to take pictures of Eva Peron's mausoleum, distinguished primarily by the innumerable plaques that adorn the front. We found it interesting that the mausoleum next to hers is for sale (our guide pointed out the understated way in which it is communicated as for sale).

Buy a map and lose yourself in a city of sculptures. Consult the map at the entrance, or buy one to carry for about 5 pesos. The lady who sold us the map recommended that we tour the back of the cemetery because most tourists don't go there. We only used it to orient ourselves when it was time to go and to help other tourists who asked us how to find Evita's tomb. My cousin and I didn't feel the need for a tour; we preferred to amble through the narrow alleys photographing the statues, crosses, and cats. When we finally noticed the afternoon shadows lengthening, we headed for the entrance. A guard directed us to the bathroom and also offered to take our photo. It didn't feel disrespectful to want to capture some memories of this peaceful place.
A sight not to miss. Free. We didn't realize at the entrance was a map for the cemetery to find Evita's grave. There were some very expensive looking tombs. You can buy flowers outside the cemetery.

Like being in the Louvre. I have been to Buenos Aires three times and each time I go to Recoleta to escape the fast pace of the city. I wander the narrow alleys thru the magnificent marble sculptures stopping to pere into antique crypts. The artistry of the sculpting can be compared to any of the great museums.Go early so you can get lost in the labyrinths and enjoy your walk in this little piece of heaven.
Beautiful. The most beautiful cemetery I've ever seen. Definitely worth a look. However it's odd to walk around as a tourist while people are there visiting loved ones.
Beautiful. It's a special cemetery, very beautiful and full of mystique. A bit difficult to find Eva Peron's grave, but it's there. Take your time and get a rest from the busy city.

Architectural treat. It is strange to rate a cemetery but Recoleta is very interesting both architecturally and historically. Thfere are "avenues" of monuments...all different. It is Eva Peron's final resting place but there are far more interesting monuments at Recoleta.

It's not an attraction at all!. Everything felt just awkward, it's just a normal cemetery, and it's so wierd to see people acting like paparazzi on spotting Eva Peron's funeral stone, it's just not nice at all, it shouldn't even be open to the public...If you do go there maybe it's nice to bring a flower...

English tours only on tues and thurs. I only rank it average because tours in English were only offered on tues and thurs at 11am. Therefore, we really missed out on what everyone usually raves about. Be sure to plan accordingly!

Like a city within a city!. Unique! A mini-city laid out with streets and laneways except the houses here are mausoleums! From neo-classical, to Romanesque, from Victorian era to art-deco - every style imaginable! Definitely worth a visit as it's unlikely you see anything like this elsewhere on your travels!

A little morbid but very interesting. It may seem weird to visit a cemetery on vacation but it was really interesting to see the elaborate statues and monuments that were erected to honor the dead. We did visit Evita's tomb, and it is hard to find as it is on a side "street". Recoleta Cemetery is definitely worth a trip to see though.

Very nice, but too many tourists was disrespectful.. Amazing cemetery, beautiful scenery and architecture. I felt it was a little disrespectful to come here as a tourist, especially seeing people trying to crowd around the tomb of Evita.
Most interesting. No visitor to Buenos Aires should miss seeing this area of the city with the Grave site of Eva Person.

Worth the visit. There is an English speaking tour arranged by volunteers once a week. I think it is on Thursdays at 11:00am. It is free. The entrance to the Cementery is also free. However, there are volunteers selling brochures for about AD$10. The money is used to maintain the cemetery. The tour is about an hour. The guide explains the architecture, customs and points out the resting places of some famous people, the most notable of course is that of Evita Peron. The guide gave some funny anecdotes, including how the plots are sold when the family needs to raise funds. I think the guide is very helpful in understanding the history and custom of the people. A tip to the guide is very much appreciated.If you can't join the free tour, walking around the Cementery on your own is also worth it. See how the rich are buried, with lots of marble figures imported from Europe.

The most amazing cemetery I have ever seen. We visited this cemetery on a wet day but I must say it was just as awe inspiring as ever. The Mausoleums were outstanding. The whole cemetery is set out like streets of Paris.We had a tour guide through Viator which if you can get is the best way to see this spectacular place as he provided a HUGE amount of information as to the family history & how some came to be in there. It is more expensive to be at your final resting place in Recoleta Cemetery than to be alive on the outside. I have recommended this to all my friends visiting Argentina as a must do and none have been disappointed.Great for all ages

Good photo spot. This is one of those spots that is a must see in Buenos Aires. Great for clicking photos. This is a large group of tombstones where a lot of rich and famous people in Argentina are buried. A tour guide is not necessary,unless you really want to know who is buried in which tombstone.

Just to know the place where Evita is resting.... My mother and I went for a little visit over the Cementery, being a stop in the turibus we took. It is a cementery like the ones that you might find in another old European cities, but I personally think it is worth it just to know the place were mortal rests of Evita were placed... my mother did not like cementeries, so our tour was REALLY quick... its free of charge and centrally located in the Palermo Area. Enjoy it!.

Something different, worth a stop. Oddly enough, this place is right next to the mall, a major tourist trap ha! It is a "different" stop than you would normally hear on lists of tourist spots. It is worth an hour of your time though, and it is appropriate for all types of people. I saw all types of people, including entire families and children. There was nothing "morbid" about the place. The appeal is the artistic facet of the tombs, and it is very interesting! It was worth a walk through, and you can just wander around and see what is around each corner. I took some cool pictures while walking through there. You can visit Eva Peron's tomb while in there, but really the other tombs are more impressive. Some big, some small, some ornate, some simple......worth a quick walk.
Beautiful village. Come early in the morning and enjoy the peaceful environment. Buy the book with map at the shop before you are going to walk so you can read everything about the graves.

A different world. A lovely tranquil space in the middle of a busy city. It is a fascinating insight into the culture and history of some very interesting people. A great place to simple stroll around.

Required Stop When Sightseeing in Buenos Aires. Even if you just walk through the cemetery for a few minutes, it is a required stop when sightseeing in Buenos Aires. The size and ornateness of the tombs is amazing. The only cemetery I have seen like this is Pere Lachaise in Paris. Unlike Pere Lachaise in which hundreds of well known people are buried (among them Jim Morrison), the only person I knew of who is buried here is Evita Peron. She is not buried with her husband, but is buried with her parents under her maiden name, Duarte.

not just your run of the mill cemetery, trust me. I´ve lived in Buenos Aires for almost 3 years now and can´t count on one hand how many times I´ve visited Recoleta Cemetery, it´s just that cool. It´s a maze of above ground crypts which satisfies the craving for history, architecture, sculpture and bit of macabre old Buenos Aires gossip on the side. Yes, it´s free but if you spend a few bucks to have a knowledgeable guide take you, the whole experience is magnified as you learn about who actually has enough money to rest there eternally, where the former presidents (and Evita, of course) are located, and about the rivalries between the buried that inspired some of the over-the-top crypts bigger and more elaborate than your family home. I actually work in the travel industry now at Class Adventure Travel and always include a walking tour of the cemetery alongside a city tour. It´s just taking that one additional step off the beaten trail. Extra tip – go visit on Saturdays or Sundays where the park beside it, Plaza Francia, is filled with artisan crafts and souvenirs and there are live musicians playing. With lunch, it´s a whole day outing!

Must see in BA. I'd never been to a cemetery like this one before, it was truly an amazing and moving experience. My friends and I happened to visit Eva Peron's tomb on her birthday, it was adorned with flowers and people holding a little prayer service. I'm lucky to have been there that day. It's so interesting to explore the cemetery, the tombs themselves are breathtaking, you must see this when in BA!

Flamboyant mausoleums - a must see on your tour of Buenos Aires. Armed with a map of this cemetry and knowing where to find Evita we spent about an hour wandering along the paths between these mostly enormous mausoleums. Each one of them were different and some incredibly "over the top" - others more simple and moving like the girl with her dog. Evita's resting place is quite plain compared with the others and because of this is quite hard to find. It is definitely well worth a visit and it is free.

Very interesting and free to tour. Stopped in two different times, once while on a running tour and once while shopping in the market. Very neat burial sites and such an interesting place to see in the middle of such a large city.

Incredible sculptures.. We ended up going here twice since the architecture of these tombs was worth another look. We had a guide with us who told us the story behind the tombs and some of the history of the area. Well worth the price since the stories of Evita, generals and even a young girl buried alive make the experience come alive even though the inhabitants are all dead.

Fascinating place even if you aren't an Evita fan.. The cemetery is large and contains a huge number of mausoleums laid out cheek by jowl. Evita Peron is the best known 'inhabitant' but the place provides a fascinating snapshot of Argentina's rich and powerful throughout its history. Well worth a visit.
Surprisingly Great. I thought we would just walk in and find Evita and walk out. but it's beautiful. The large tombstones are works of art. And our guide brought old Buenos Aires to life in Recoleta

If you want to visit EVITA go, but it is a little creepy.. All the tourists end up going there , mainly to have a look at the Duarte family tomb (a mini mausoleum, quite modest by the standards of its neighbours, but therein lies Evita!!!). This is why I wanted to visit but then I was ready to leave. No entrance fee but there are many people at the entrance to pay them to show you around. That is a choice. It is not easy to find your way around as it is not sign posted, it is a cemetery at the end of the day. Lots of big statues, places for the dead to rest. Nice park across the way was nice to just sit and rest .... a church next door to visit which is ok for a quick visit. Glad I went but glad to leave too.

An amazing resting place. There is no entrance fee to get in though there are volunteers that show you a map of the cemetery for a few pesos at the entrance. The cemetery is not like any other and there are only 2 others like this in the world, one in Paris and the other in Italy. Recoleta cemetery is very well laid out. There are old mausoleums and new ones. Of significance is Eva Peron’s resting place here. Some of these mausoleums are just huge to house an entire family. Others look like small chapels. The finishing on these resting places is just incredible. I would say this place is not really morbid, but peaceful. The newer resting places are made of pure marble in some cases. With others there are windows right into the mausoleum. You can actually see coffins in there!
Nice Place / Worh a visit. Very interesting and nicely maintained. Consider a guided tour and spending several hours to visit the entire place

Go for its curiosity value.. A city of tombs within the city. All the tourists end up going there , mainly to have a look at the Duarte family tomb (a mini mausoleum, quite modest by the standards of its neighbours, but therein lies Evita!!!). Have a quick wander round and then head for the lovely Pilar church next door, and a coffee in one of the cafes over the road, under the trees..

What a Cemetery!. I had never seen such a cemetery in my life. It is very luxuous and the graves are sometimes as big as houses! If you're looking for someone's tomb in particular, you'd better ask at the entrance because inside you will find no indications. There are a lot of people who can help you at the entrance, but some of them ask for money in exchange.
Huge cemetery. Good for a visit. Free of entrance (although donation was appreciated) and a lot of little castles and marble.
A little creepy and a little sad. After the first 20 crypts it got a little repetitive. It is worth seeing but don't expect to spend a long time there

Incredible art and architecture. Do you like history? Beautiful art? Amazing architecture? This is for you! It is very maze like, and easy to get turned around. If you don't have time for a long visit, I recommend getting a guide at the front.

Absolutely fascinating. The variety of architecture is incredible. We wandered around for several hours. Some areas were well cared for; others had broken glass and dust covered coffins and candelabras. Our only wish was a good self guided tour to the architectural differences in tge tombs.
Interesting cemetery in the middle of the city. It was nice for a walk. Very close to the Recoleta Mall. Never been to a cemetery with such pieces of art.

Evita tomb accessible. Cemetery had a free guide available at the gate, distributed by volunteers. The only tomb that most have heard of is Eva Peron's and it was duly visited. Surprisingly easy to find and not too many crouds.

Don't cry for me Argentina -. Some people have a great deal of money to immortalize their loved ones. This cemetery proves it. Grand statues, shrines to fallen heroes, mausoleums sadly left to decay when apparently no family or no fortune remains. This is worth a stop even in a busy day of touring .

Straight out of a horror movie. Everyone that comes here takes away something they never expected. Maybe it's a shiver down the spine, maybe thoughts about the futility of monuments, maybe disgust at the broken graves, coffins in plain sight, and rubbish thrown through broken door frames. Whatever you take away, Recoleta cemetery will stick in your mind as something very different.In all of South America, this was the only place where cats ruled. It's creepy and kooky, mysterious and spooky! And afterwards you can go to a tango show and think of Gomez and Morticia.It's free, but fork out 10 pesos for the map and check out Evita's grave. It's the one with all the flowers.

Wow a city within itself. Visiting this cemetery was like visiting a city, it's huge. It's a city within itself. I was a little disappointed with Eva Peron's mausoleum, but that's not the cemetery's fault.

BA Walking Tours. Very informative, our guide Carlos was so knowledgeable about the area we toured, which was the Recolleta area and the Cemetary. We absolutely loved this tour, it was quite a bit of walking so wear proper shoes, carry water, and dress according to weather.

Becoming run down. The history and size were interesting, but there were a number of run down mausoleums. We took a free (tip) tour with a pleasant British guy who just hung around outside the entrance.

Historical Must See Site. A burial ground featuring ostentatious tombs including the final resting place for Eva Peron, Evita, who died at age 33 from cancer. Photographers, bring zoom lens for wide-angle and telephoto needs. This is a rare be there at mid-day site so that you can minimize contrast from deep shadows on one side of an aisle and reflected stone on the other. Regarding Evita, a dinner companion regaled (or should I say impaled) us with fanciful stories of Evita's corpse: multiple burial sites in the world, copies made, extraordinary non-deterioration, and so forth. The stories must be true, for the guest had researched them on the Internet for a book.

City of the dead. We drug our feet to go here and then were so glad we did. Fascinating above ground mausoleums each built and maintained by an individual family. The are built in a variety of architectural styles.

Interesting experience. A cemetery different than others. A lot of Argentinian history, graves of famous people. Evita's grave is hard to find but tip one of the workers and they will get you there. Get ready to spend 2 hours for visiting, there's a lot.
Should see. It's interesting and free. Go early to avoid the masses, wear tennis shoes. Take bug spray. Nice places to eat outside afterwards.

The most weirdest "attraction" I have visited.. At first I really thought that visiting a cemetery as a tourist attraction was really strange after visiting this cemetery I still thought it was strange and eerie. Yes the graves were nothing I have ever seen it was almost like a museum. It is touching to see how families of those deceased look after the graves. A very strange but beautiful experience.

Not just for Evita buffs.. Apart from Evita's grave, there is much more to see her. Several mausoleums are much more ornate than Evita's with statues and columns. Line up to see hers first though as the queue builds up quickly.

Incredible slice of BA history...and a little eerie.... This is not your average cemetery. It is a snapshot of BA's history as many of their most significant citizens are interred here, including Eva Peron. The crypts are amazing in so many ways. The wealth on display here is incomprehensible with some of the crypts. Others are in total disarray as it's up to the owners families to maintain their spaces. Our guide told us that the crypts are yours forever, so if an entire family has passed, or moved elsewhere, the crypts simply decay. This is an eerie place because you can see the caskets of the inhabitants through windows, some of them broken. Not a sight you see in the states.This is definitely worth a couple of hours of your time. It's free, it's in Recoleta and it's totally unique.
Need to see it if your there. The history of Eva Peron after her passing is bizarre. Suggest a tour to get the scoop. Architecture is amazing

Very interesting cemetery. The Recoleta cemetery is in a very nice neighborhood of Buenos Aires. It is where many notable people in Argentine history are laid to rest including Eva Peron. There are a lot beautiful monuments in the cemetery. When entering you can obtain a sheet helping you find your way around. One thing I thought was of great interest is that in this cemetery most tombs have glass doors. I was surprised that by looking in the glass doors you can see the caskets inside. It seems that there are usually one of two caskets on the main level with a stairway leading below where other caskets lay on different shelves. Very interesting!! If you are in Buenos Aires I would suggest not missing the Recoleta cemetery.

Beautiful, but disappointing. If you are going there to see Evita's tomb you will be disappointed. The grave is hard to find, there are no indications and the tomb itself is definitely not impressive. However the cemetery is full of monumental tombs which will make the visit worth. There is also a lovely market in front of it and the Church close by is really beautiful.

Very interesting and worth the visit. we walked from the Marriott hotel which was a bit of a walk but safe and nice. The Cemetery is very interesting and worth seeing as a tourist. Very unique headstones and monuments. Many to see however it's like a maze so take note of your directions unless you want to wonder around to get out for some time. Be sure to see "Evita's" gravesite which is nice to say you've been there and gave respect for these graves. Nice photos to take for memories, as well. You don't need a guide so save your money and also before you enter, you will likely be approached by someone asking you for money and trying to give you a flyer but you might want to pass because they didn't seem legit to me and it was not necessary to pay. It's free to visit the cemetery so don't feel the need to pay even if they give you their speech... The vendors outside are also interesting to view their wares. Felt safe and enjoyed the walk and visit to this area as well as the shops along the way.

Went to see Evita's grave but spent more time in the Cemetary itself...... What a surprise this Cemetary was. I thought I was going to be in and out but I found myself absolutely fascinated with it. All the crypts belong families (1000+?), and it seems, in some cases, that people spent more money to be buried well than to use to live. There are crypts of naval Commanders, well-known Doctors and Professors at Medical Schools, military Personnel, philanthropists, wealthy Businessman and Politicians. The outside walls are covered with plaques, the more plaques, the more well-esteemed you were--a tangible testment to a live well-lived to be considered in the fterlife.There were even pictures of people's marriages, families, automobiles, etc. In front of one Naval Commanders site, there was a statue of him, life sized, in his uniform. The statuary alone belongs in a museum by itself. Lots of angels, crying angels, crucifixion crosses, etc. just. Warning.....most of the crypts are closed with wrought iron and locked. Some have glass protecting them. There is nothing to prevent you from seeing the coffins lining the shelves inside the crypts. If that bothers you, be aware. The Cemetary is very compact, the space between the crypts allows for about two or three people to pass. Surrounding Recoleta are to apartment buldings that look right over Recoleta. I have been all over the world and not have seen anything like this.if you are in Buenos Aires for only a day, this should be on your list.

The World's Best Cemetery!. This was my second visit to Recoleta, and my original opinion was confirmed. The most discerning, cultured people prefer to be buried here! It is comparable to Le Cimetière du Père Lachaise in Paris, but I prefer Recoleta. It's like a city of the dead...each mausoleum is a building in itself...and you can stroll down its broad avenues past architectural marvels without worry that you'll bother the "occupants".

Worth a visit.. Our stay in BA happened to be the hottest week of the year so walking around the cemetery in the sun was tough but aside from that, I enjoyed it. There are guided tours available but we just walked around on our own.

Anstonishing resting place.... This really was a wonderful surprise. There are so many different types of architecture represented. It was incredible to see how far down the crypts go. We were amazed.

Statues & Monuments. Even if you spend twenty minutes here it is enough to get a good picture of the way the dead are honoured. The map is not too helpful if you want more information than just the name or how to get there. The biggest monuments are along the back where the presidents, military men & sports stars are interned. I did hear some people speaking in english so it must be possible to have a guided tour, but I gathered that they were independent from the Cemetery, it would have been a lot more interesting. As we had a map we were asked by a lot of people for assistance to find Evita's site, which we didn't mind doing. In fact if you haven't had much luck with your spanish & have missed conversation its the place to go, as people seem glad to talk.
very different. Strange but interesting. Tomb stones like ive never seen before but also another tourist trap with "guides" at the entrance offering a hand drawn map for a donation.

Must-see: beautiful architecture in well-maintained venue. I went on a Sunday afternoon after touring the Recoleta Sunday open market. As it was off-season, there were no huge crowds; so it was very comfortable.As you enter the cemetry, there is a small desk in the lobby with a volunteer selling maps of the cemetery for 10 pesos. This small fee pays for the upkeep of the cemetery and is well worth it. There is one large map in the lobby for reference, but none in the cemetery itself. So if you are looking for Evita or the Paz Family plots, get the maps (or just follow the crowds or tour guides) to avoid walking in circles.You can easily spend 1-2 hours strolling here and taking photos of the beautiful mausoleums and crypts. It's quiet and peaceful; most tourists are still respectful that this is an active cemetery, with mourners paying their respects to the recently departed. Because the structures are so close together, there is a fair bit of shade; so it's cool and comfortable. And there are seating areas if you get tired.This is a perfect sight to visit towards the end of your stay in Buenos Aires. It'll be more meaningful when you recognize the names on the family tombs, names shared by streets and monuments throughout the city.

Cool Cemetery. The recoleta cemetery is a must visit while in buenos aires. Unique to the city with some important people buried there. The cemetery is overall well maintained with patches of unattended graves that add to the charm. The cemetery was pack full of people when we visited which took away from the charm

A historic cemetery with variably tended graves.. The Cemetery was built in 18th century when the adjacent church, Our Lady of Pilar, was established in that century. Since then it has grown to be one of the most beautiful cemeteries in the world. There are lots of graves of famous Argentinians including some presidents. Of course every one looks for the grave of Eva Peron and it is not easy to find but find one does. Many of the graves are very ornate and some are simple. The care of the graves is also mixed with some graves and structures around them in a poor state of repair. However it is a must visit if in Buenos Aires.

Fascinating.... Easy to spend hours here, we were with a guide, and learned much about this cemetary,from it's history to individual stories about some of the more famous (or not so famous) that now call this home..There are many of the mausoleums that intricately designed, with absolutely beautiful sculpture work, there are a myriad of shapes and styles, Families pay to keep the mausoleums up to date, and so there are also a large number that have been neglected, and fallen into dis-repair, grasses growing out from the top, or now exposed to the elements... and all make for fascinating photography. I'd highly recommend going with a guide here.

Very unique. Definitely it strikes you its uniqueness as you feel as if you were walking in the street of a town. If you start wondering that the "buildings" are graves you may feel a bit odd. Especially when you can see inside the buildings and see coffins. But the stroll which is hard to call "nice" due to the surroundings is in fact a pleasant walk. Obviously, yu can't spend there a lot of time, particularly because if you're not a native Argentinian, you hardly know most of the people buried there. However, if you're in Buenos Aires, I think you need to visit this place.

Don't just go there for Evita. We were amazed with the grandness of mausoleums there. People who are buried there not only rich while they were alive, but it shows even when they're dead. One thing that would have made for better experience is if we knew more of the historical figures. May be guided tour would have been better. But even without the tour, we could have spent an entire day there!

You should be dying to see it. Wow - what a place. The crypts are amazing - so ornate and over the top. I've been to Pierre La Chase in Paris which I love but this one was very different. Where PLC's attraction is mainly about who is buried there, the Recoleta Cemetary is not about who's buried there (mainly military and political figures - the only one I knew was Evita), but what they're buried in. The stray cats were a bit creepy but I suppose they serve a purpose. You really mustn't miss this one.

A photographer's dream.. Any amateur photo-nerd will love the cemetery. so much beautiful architecture. There can be crowds around Eva Peron's grave, but it's a great place walk around for a few hours on a nice day.

A nice bit of history. Although slightly morbid I enjoyed my visit to the cemetary. Very interesting to see the way different cultures feel about their dead.
Unfortunately there were some tourists who seemed to think it was more of an amusement park than a cemetery which tainted the experience but I would recommend that people spend a couple of hours exploring here.

Interesting characters buried there. Eva Peron's grave is there. It may be small compared to others in the cemetery but there is a lot of history behind it.There are a lot of mausoleums where the coffins are displayed in a window, which I have not seen any where else before.

Site of Eva Perons grave. Visited the cemetary after walking to La Recoleta to visit weekend markets and the cemetary. Helpful people to tell you how to find the grave - if travelling alone. Or offer guided tours of cemetary.

A Must Cemetery to Visit Before You Die. Went in on a Saturday when they opened and the light and shadows were perfect. A lot of history and associated wealth can be found and appreciated by touristas. Even the kitty cats were enjoying their breakfast. And it's free and and I found it quite safe. If you want to use the bathrooms, a donation is expected.A lot of craft vendors were set up around the cemetery and church next door when I exited - with some pretty good bargains to boot (bargain, don't pay asking price).
one of a kind. This is a can´t miss attraction in BA. Never seen anything else like it before. Great architecture and history.
Free tour. Free english guided tour at 11am. So come in the morning! Otherwise you'd have to comb the rows of tombs for Evita Peron's.

More beautiful than creepy.. By the end of my visit (about two hours) I felt a bit sad about reading everyone's life and how long ago that was. However I loved visiting this place. It really has to be seen, what beauty. I was intrigued that Eva perons tomb was so simple when there were some so over the top grandiose.
Unbelievable - do not miss it. This is the most amazing cemetery I have ever been to. Eva Peron is interred here along with many other dignitaries. Easily spend a few hours here.
Beautiful. This cemetary is beautiful to wander around, as the tombs and statues are simply stunning - old and new. It's quite big, and lots to see, so probably plan for 2 hours.
Great experience. Wonderful juxtaposition of architecture from many periods all gathered here for the same purpose. A peaceful place to stroll in Buenos Aires.

Very enchanting cemetery. When I told my wife I wanted to see the cemetery, she kind of looked at me as if I were crazy. Actually was a very nice place, the statuary was very impressive, and of course we got to see Evita's tomb. Highly recommended for a visit it Buenos Aires.
Fascinating. Sounds strange to love a cemetery, but this was definitely worth walking through. Magnificent and beautiful. We walked around the area after and found a street fair as well as a park.

Beautiful mausoleums and lots of history. Imagine if all the major historical figures of your country were all lying to rest in one cemetery. This is what is like to visit the Recoleta cemetery for an Argentinean. Every other mausoleum spells out famous last names - politicians, governors, presidents, military figures, artists, etc. Several Argentinean cities and street names call out as you walk by. If you're Argentinean or know Argentinean history then that is a huge allure, but also the sheer agglomeration of beatiful mausoleums is worth a visit. Outside the entrance you will be greeted by folks that will offer to guide you through the rows of tombstones, but you can also get a map from the volunteers at the gates and use that instead, for a nominal contribution.
City of mausoleums. A 'city' of some 4800 mausoleums including one containing Eva Peron. Get a map of the cemetery at the entrance.

Definitely a must to visit. I have never been to a cemetery but this is not your regular cemetery anyway. The "architecture or design" of every tomb is different and it is interesting to note the different eras of the dead here. Some families still visit the tombs and you can tell by the fresh flowers left behind or the fresh locks that have been opened on a regular basis. Of course, everyone wants to visit Evita Peron's tomb at no 88! Happy finding it :p Also loved the area around the cemetery, the nearby flea market stalls and Buenos Aires Design Centre which sold cool stuff.

What a fantastic, interesting, thoughtful place.. This is truly a "must" for B. Aires visitors not only to visit Eva Peron (whose presence today is astounding) but to see some of the unique/huge/simple tombs. From Eva go round the wall to see incredible works of art.

Interesting. Interesting to see if you've never been to a cemetary with lots of mausoleums. I've been to BA 3 times and visited the cemetery 2 times. It's interesting to see how many people leave flowers on Evita's tomb. If you go to the Recoleta market, then make a quick stop by the cemetery.
Amazing. I loved this cemetery and I don't frequent them! Well worth a wander around, I took lots of pic's and interesting if you have a tour guide to learn something more about the occupants.
Recoleta Cemetery is amazing. One of the best parts of our trip to Argentina. I have never seen a cemetery like it!! Not too touristy. You just need to see it!!!

The most interesting spot in Buenos Aires. It's like nothing I have ever seen; indescribable. A real part of the culture of Buenos Aires. Probably the most interesting thing we saw all day except for the government buildings. Don't miss it.
Self Importance. Interesting extravaganza, heck of a waste of money by families creating artificial monuments to the dead.

WOW. It is a fascinating place and shouldn't be missed. Each mausoleum was a work of art of the time. Some were touching monuments to loved one and some, no doubt, were to display the wealth and status of the family.

Recoleta: a must for all. Recoleta cemetery is a must for all visitors to Buenos Aires. Take the "free" tour, the guide of which reminds you at the one hour tour that the tour is free, but tips are welcome. It is, however, an excellent first impression of the many mausoleums, and their history, including that of Eva Perron Duarte, also known as Evita.

Walking through the cemetery!. This is an amazing experience to be able to walk through a town built for the dead. Admittedly, a rather rough way to put it but it felt like a town with all the various buildings and statuary honoring the individual families. An absolute must when visiting Buenos Aires!

Very clean. Having seen many cemeteries with mausoleums, this somewhat puts a different view on the "traditional" cemetery. First off, it is a tourist attraction and as one, I'm shocked at how clean the place was. Most cemeteries I have seen have dirt paths but this was so clean it was like a park. Do not just check out Evita's grave but the cemetery as a whole. It's like an outdoor museum.

Nice area. For some reason it is a very famous cemetery. All in it are mausoleums. Bigger, smaller, older, newer... I like cemeteries so interesting to wonder around in the sun.Of course there are some famous people buried there but other than Eva Perón, I must say I didn't know any of the others.Next to the cemetery there's a shopping center and lots of bars and restaurants and a very nice street market with all kind of items from neclaces to t-shirts or hats...

Fascinating with great variety. Despite its fairly compact settings, Recolata Cemetery offers a large variety of architecture and styles. The different tombs and mausoleums make for a fascinating stroll. We went there on two separate afternoons and still did not see everything.
Great for an hour stroll.. Be sure to take an hour or two out of your time in Buenos Aires to stroll through this impressive cemetery.
Very Educational. This is a place of respect and history! We learned alot of history here from our guide and it is amazing how they built the monuments and the stories behind some of them.

Recoleta Cemetery, Basilica del Pilar and Plaza Francia!. This is a great combo to do on a Saturday starting at around 11 am. Plaza Francia will be full with vendors of wonderful artesanal items, jewelt, art, etc. Don't miss a coffee at La Biela, right across from it, where you can have your beverage while watching some sidewalk tango being danced!
Interesting. I wanted to see where Eva Peron is buried and was able to do so. I went with a tour so didn't have to go looking. The architecture of some of the crypts is very interesting

Wow!. What a fascinating place! Never been anywhere like this. With the risk of sounding morbid, you could wander around here for hours! They offer free tours every Tuesday and Thursday in English at 11am which are worth doing. They go for about an hour.

Yes it is a tourist attraction. I wanted to visit this cemetery simply because of “Eva, Evita, Peron”. I was totally shocked, in a good way, to see what was behind the brick walls.This place has so much history. It is easy to spend hours and hours here reading the plaques and marveling at the size and construction of the mausoleums. As explained to us families maintain the individual sites so if no one is left in the family the mausoleum falls into disrepair. (See pictures) The grounds, cobblestone walkways are well maintained and there are benches spread though out the site to sit and rest for a bit before you carry on. We were disappointed that they had no brochures left the day we were there but in the end it really didn’t matter. Eva, Evita is buried with her family so you will not find her on the map when looking under the name Peron. She is buried with her family in the Durate family mausoleum. It is not what I expected to see. I thought it would be a huge site but after getting home and searching the internet I understand the history of why she is buried here. If you plan on going here make sure you give yourself time. It is easy to just walk and walk and forget about the time.
Evita's grave. Very touristy and crowded the day we were there, but worth seeing. Across from the cemetry was a impromptu tango dance under a huge old tree - much more enjoyable

Visit Evita. I have never seen a cemetery anything like Recoleta. It seems all of deceased Buenos Aires is entombed in marble mausoleums, some lovingly maintained, and others in near ruins. Don't look for the name Peron when searching for Eva, however; she is with her own people -- familia Duarte.

a must see. The cemetery is so interesting and don't miss the open-air market on the weekends in front of it. Evita's resting place was a bit understated, but there is a wonderful history lesson in so many of the crypts.

You have to go. An odd tourist attraction but worth seeing with a guide - we went on the (free) 11am English tour. The guide was very informative and gave a real sense of the history of Argentina through the lives of those who ended up here and was not pushy about her tip.You will be stopped by official looking guides at the gates who will ask for a donation to charity following a very quick introduction to the cemetery - some will offer a map. As a tourist one is never sure if these are genuine so be prepared.

Creepy at first but Fascinating. I was nervous at first thinking about walking through a Cemetery, but was blown away by the beautiful architectures and mausoleums. Its like walking through a mini city. Evitas tomb ofcourse was the main attraction but there are several otber famous people there as well. I didnt take a guide, you can walk by yourself.

Small village. This place is like a small village with streets and a wide variety of houses. The only thing is, it isn't that lively anymore! We stopped here on our way biking up to Palermo.This cemetery is beautiful with exceptional graves from a lot of famous people. Of course, don't forget to walk by Eva Peron's.We drunk a beer afterwards on one of the terraces close to the cemetery and toasted on everyone that lies there!
Hello Evita.. third time is a charm> Great place to spend the day. Definately buy the guide book. Fun to watch the living people here as well..

Best cemetery and way to learn the history of Argentina. This is not just a cemetery, but a spectacular piece of art and history. Make sure you google all the stories on the different famous people and Urban Legends and bring them with you as you walk around the 5 plus acres. They also offer free English tours on Tues and Thur at 11am. You can easily spend 5 hours in a day there. We spent a total of 11 hours there over 3 days. Must see!! Autumn and AbeAsquaredadventures.com

Recoleta Cemetary. We spent 2 hours wandering through the graves, by ourselves and enjoyed seeing all the different architecture, stained glass and statues.. We would have learned more if we'd scheduled a walking tour. Evita Peron is buried here, but under her maiden name, Duarte. Look for here name on the map at the entrance. Don't miss the church beside the cemetery also.

An unusual cemetery. Well worth a visit. Eva Peron's mausoleum is a tourist must, but the extravagant tombs covered with angels are amazing. The cemetery seems like a small town with the back of the church at one end and it is definitely worth having a guide to point out some of the more famous resting places.

A beautifully peaceful place. What a fantastic place. It is full of beauty everywhere and feels so peaceful. There is plenty to see apart from Evitas tomb. My advice would be to find an English guide who can take you to some very interesting tombs. We found a chap called Simon who was just outside. I have to say his knowledge was excellent and showed us some very interesting things. He wasn't at all pushy and really took his time showing us things. He didn't charge a certain amount for this at all. He just asked for what we thought was fair! After this we asked him for a bit of a walking tour around the area of which he was more than happy to do. Again his knowledge of the area was great. He really helped us find our way about, as this was our first day there. We gave him $25 u.s dollars he seemed very happy with this . All in all I would 100% recommend the cemetery wether you have a guide or not. Allow a couple of hours there and take a camera as people back home simply won't believe it....especially as you can still see all the coffins. Also see Simon if you need to know any thing he was great......

Worth a look. The chief attraction is Eva Peron's tomb, which is surprisingly modest and tucked away in a side alley. It's a popular attraction and often crowded with sightseers, while other areas are relatively quiet. People still leave flowers at her tomb. You can take a free tour of the cemetary, but a donation is encouraged.It's worth having a look at some of the extravagant resting places of Argentina's rich and fampus, but quite ironic that Evita is buried there among the people who hated her while she lived. It's home to many of the country's leaders and luminaries. Some of the tombs and crypts are staggering in theirextravagance and opulence, highlighting the gap between rich and poor here.Outside, there is often an interesting artesan's market and several cafes and bars, as well as pleasant parkland.
Not just for Evita. This is a mini city of the dead. The mausoleums are as elaborate as town houses. You can view the coffins through class. A guided tour or read up ahead recommended.

Interesting. This was the second time I visited a cemetery while on vacation. It can be an interesting but different experience. You spend a little time just walking through or hours looking at each tombstone, many of which are pieces of art themselves. I could imagine if you were interested in world history and prominent historical figures you might enjoy this visit. You can pay a small fee when you enter for a small map that outlines where everyone is entombed, or there is a big map you can review just beyond the entrance.
Fascinating Place. this place is definitely worth a visit. It was really interesting. We didn't take an organised tour, just wandered around at our leisure.
Great visit. Fascinating to go round this cemetery and see the mausoleum of Eva Peron. I went with a tour guide who gave me lots of fascinating and interesting facts

Unbelievable. Unbelievable cemetery, simply amazing, we wish we had of had time to go back as was very interesting. Recommend a guide as you will miss the finer points, architectural highlights and the history such as Eva Peron is buried here, also a guide will help you to not get lost as it covers SIX CITY BLOCKS!

Definately worth seeing if in BA. I wandered around the cemetery for quite a period of time admiring the "over the top" crypts. Laughing every now and then at those that contained fake turf that looked like putt putt golf greens.There was opportunity for hiring a guide which I opted out of. I probably would of learnt interesting facts but just looking was enough for me. It's pretty easy to find Eva perons as its covered with the most flowers.

Resting Place of Eva Peron. This is an interesting way to spend an hour or so made famous as it is the last resting place of Eva Peron. There are some interesting architectural graves here and some good photo opportunities. The grave next to Eva Perons is for sale if anyone is interested?!

Worth Seeing. In you are in Buenos Aires, this is something you should see. Very old, very interesting. Evita Peron is buried here. Only bad thing was a man who would hardly let us go in until we gave him money for researching AIDS. A con, but what could we do? Admission is freel
City of Death. Cemetery was more fascinating than expected. We hired a guide just inside and for a reasonable fee, she told us facts and history about the site.
not just another cemetery. the tour guide told the story of the famous people buried there..Eva Peron etc..very enjoyable tour.
cemetery. Very interesting especially the history of Eva Peron's death and how she ultimately was buried in this cemetery
Beautiful. Worth seeing, not your typical cemetery. Recoleta is filled with beauty and very serene. The nearby church is also worth a visit,

Like nothing I've ever seen!. You will never see another cemetry as grand and beautiful as this. A lot of people go there to see the tomb of Eva Peron, but there are other more impressive tombs to see.You should pop into the church next door, and on weekends there's an extensive artisan market on the sloping plaza next to the cemetry.

Not to be missed!. We went here as part of a private tour....we were staying at the Hotel Etoile so it was a short walk for us. Our guide pointed out the highlights of some of the more spectaclar tombs. If you don't like seeing the actual casket containing the body, then don't go. Otherwise open up your mind and "EMBRACE THE DIFFERENCES"! To avoid lineups to see Eva Peron's tomb, go very early or very late.

Worth visiting. There is a lot of argentinian history there. This is one of the prime attractions in Buenos Aires and really worth visiting, but to really enjoy and learn about who is there you have to get a good guide.

Interesting mausoleums to be found. I liked the variety and quantity of mausoeums to be viewed throughout the cemetery. Had no idea who any of the people were, but that is our fault, not the fault of the cemetery. Never took the time to find a brochure or information. One could spend hours wandering around viewing the intricacies of the cemetery.

This is a must-see if you like visiting cemeteries!. We visited Recoleta Cemetery as part of a tour from Princess Cruise Line. Recoleta Cemetery is a virtual city of 6,400 mausoleums arranged in narrow rows resembeling small streets. The First Lady of Argentina, Eva Peron, was buried here in a black marble crypt after her death in 1952. Her body once disappeared for 16 years, and she is now buried under several feet of concrete to prevent a repeat disappearance. We wish we had more time to explore this gorgeous cemetery. Each monument/mausoleum is more gorgeous than the one next to it. So much beauty! It is now the most beautiful cemetery we have ever visited. If we ever get to Buenos Aires again, we will definitely pay another visit to Recoleta Cemetery.

Unexpectedly great experience. I went to the cemetery expecting the same old same old but boy was I wrong! This is a virtual metropolitan community of beautiful tombs nestled one beside the other, organized in streets and avenues. It has the who's who of Argentinean history. Even if one is unfamiliar with the various personages it is well worth a visit just to see the fantastic archecture and marble statuary. The famous tomb of Eva Peron is interesting, but not the highlight (which was another surprise).The entry is free and a map is available for a nominal fee (10 pesos). A free tour, in English is available on Tuesdays and Thursdays.
A must see. The magnitude, history of the cemetary is a must see. The ornateness, architecture and detail is beautiful.

If you like visiting cemeteries, then you'll love this one.. I'm not one of those people that like visiting cemeteries, actually. But this one is so interesting, so full of history, and a bit macabre too, that I found myself wandering around here for a couple of hours. First of all, some of these mausoleums are as big as a studio apartment in San Francisco! And you can see a lot of these coffins too. A bit ghoulish, but it makes the whole visit fun.

Must-See Site in Buenos Aires. This might sound odd, but this cemetery is so cool. There are some wonderful structures and statues. It's like a small city of wildly unique mausoleums - including, of course, Evita Peron's final resting place.

unique in the world. This was a very unique experience. I´ve never seen anything quite like the cemetery! I highly recommend you visit it even though it is quite touristy. Avoid the restaurants right around it though!
Great History lesson. If you get a good guide, you will learn all about Argentinian history. Ask for Patricia adn ask lots of questions! She was very informative and gave a great tour!

A city within a city, but this is with the dead!. It is sort of weird to be walking down what feels almost like narrow streets with mausoleums closely packed together and in varying stages of decay, all for the wealthy to have built these places for the dead of their family. Upon closer inspection some interesting things to notice and with a bit of hunting you find Eva Peron in the Duarte family mausoleum.
Unique Above-Ground Cemetery. Tombs of the rich and famous, including Eva Peron, are prominent in this beautiful setting. Certainly one of the prime attractions in Buenos Aires.

Surprisingly fascinating. This is defiantly a sight worth visiting. I have never seen anything like this, each grave is a full size building of a monument making this a small city of beautiful (graves) monuments. In march, very few tourist and the entrance is free. A must see in BA.
Cool and peaceful place to rest.... An interesting way to learn the history of Argentina. Peaceful and quiet with good restaurants nearby.

Simply astonishing. We were fortunate to have a private guide to show us around this amazing place. Every square inch is packed with monuments to the dead, some of them even minature churches. The architectural variety is incredible as is the amount of money that must have been spent by the living to commemorate the dead. Marble, bronze and stained glass abound and bears testimony to the city's wealthy past. This was the most overwhelming experience of our Buenos Aires tour and is a fascinating must see.

hidden gems with a guide. I toured this with a guide selected by Country Walkers and it was much more educational and organized than simply wandering the grounds. There is so much more than meets the eye in this cemetery. A must see if you have such an interest.

Interesting in a cultural sense, reminiscent of new orleans cemeteries. Interesting in a cultural sense, reminiscent of new orleans cemeteries but with the twist of multilevel underground crypts. The architecture and history is amazing. If you come by yourselves, pay a guide for their tour it is MUCH more in depth than walking the rows yourself. If you are too frugal to hire a guide, just wait and pony into a bus tour.

Interesting City of the Dead. Recoleta Cemetery is not only a big cemetary. With its many mausoleums it gives the impression to the visitor of being in a large city - with only dead inhabitants. You can take a tour through the history of Buenos Aires and Argentina just by walking around.And of course, do not miss the grave of Evita. But remeber, she is not burried under the name "Perón", but under her birth name "Duarte".

Absolutely fascinating. It was a surprize discovering how large this mini-city is with "streets" of masoleums, and the variety of each masoleum's architecture. There is much more to see besides the Eva Peron memorial at the Duarte family site. The cemetery is a multi-century necropolis reflecting the people who made much of Argentina's history and their wealth or military/political status. The cemetery is "sold out" and if a family no longer pays the annual fee for its site, the coffins are moved to other burial locations and their Recoleta plot is re-sold.
An overrated cemetery. A very famous lady is there; but this in itself does not warrant a visit; unless you are a dedicated peronista

One of the best sites to see in this city. We had never heard of this special place before but it is a not to be missed. It does seem strange that this would be the best site we saw in the city, but it was by far the best. We read so many interesting family histories and the presentations were just amazing, from elaborate architecture to museum quality sculptures. What is also interesting is that there are many crypts that had family members spanning hundreds of years and many caskets in multilevel spaces. Yes, we did find Eva Peron's grave and while it had great historic significance, it was by far not the most elaborate. Worth a few hours' stroll.

Not just about Evita!. On a hill in the exclusive neighbourhood of Recoleta this cemetery chronicles the tastes of Argentina's elite. Each mausoleum presents a glimpse into the past and to make the visit without the free tour that is offered is a less rich experience by far.

Amazing Cemetery. I visited the cemetery the third time in buenos aires- still an amazing experience.Without paying an entrance fee, this cemetery gives you an extraordinary insight of how different cemeteries can be - as in argentina regular ground graves are not regular and are granted for a period of 5 years...The almost palace-alike graves range from extremely old to very new. Cats strolling around give the cemetery a very special atmosphere.Tipp: dont go there when its darker or very clouded/rainy... as you will for sure get lost, it might get scary ;-)
very big. The cemetery has some graves that are true works of art. It is very great, and I particularly found it a bit tiring.

Impressive. For BA this is quite a significant experience. No danger going here and giving it a look. The cemetary is crowded with graves and some of them look scary with their broken front plates. Free of charge!

Not for the squemish. I've been visiting graveyard art all over the world for the last 40 years so was looking forward to this cemetary which even the Lonely Planet rated as the best attraction in the city. I actually overheard a guide describing it as in the top three cemetaries in the world. Sorry have to disagree. Yes its fascinating but the the main cemetaries in Sao Paulo and in Krakow have the lead in interesting sculpture. The monuments here are more conservative although some are very grand. What did astound me, and I'd like to warn squemish travellors about, was the fact that the most recent coffins are in full view in most of the tombs. Some in broken tombs are suspended in mid air exposed for all to see. In 40 years of viewing tombs I have seen coffins down in vaults and sometimes accidentally exposed when graves are broken but this was the first time I've seen them so publicly on view. It made the hordes of visitors seem a little insensitve and (including myself) a bit voyeuristic. Evita's tomb is modest and probably not worth viewing if you're into good art in cemetaries but the fact she got into this hallowed ground despite the upper class objections makes it ironic that she has becone the main attraction. I believe the city are repairing the tombs so hopefully you won't have to view the open air nature of some of the tombs for too long.When you come out of the cemetary turn left and within 100 metres you'll come to a left turn onto a lovely terrace with some upmarket shops and restaurants looking down over the park - Hard Rock cafe at the very end. If you turn right and walk to the end of the cemetary wall you come to another big shopping mall which has some nice views over the cemetary from the upper floors.

Eva perons family tomb. The cemetery itself is very interesting and you could look around all day looking at the different styles of architecture, but also very sad. To see the family tomb you may have to queue up as it is very popular. You also need a map of the cemetery in order to find it, these are available free of charge from people giving them away as you enter the cemetery, or you can pay for a guide, again there are lots as you enter the cemetery.

My favorite place. For years, I had wanted to visit this cemetery to see how it compared with Montparnasse in Paris. Although it is smaller, there are many cats here and they give my photos an extra benefit. The cemetery opens at 7:00 in the morning and it is more like a park than a place of sorrow.

Worth a visit. Interesting way to spend a few hours. See how the rich spend the afterlife as the rents are phenominal and non payment results in eviction. Most visitors are only there for one reason - to see the last resting place of Eva Peron - but there are some exceptional sculptures/crypts within the rest of the cemetary and its a very peaceful way to spend an hour or two away from the hustle/bustle outside. Need to time visit to avoid major tours/cruise boat outings as the main attraction is down a very narrow alleyway and queues can be very long to take a quick look/photo. Probably best either early morning or later in afternoon. Bit of a hike from the nearest metro station so maybe worth getting a cab.

Interesting. This place is very interesting - for about 30 minutes. It is really not very relevant unless you know something about the people who are buried there and are conversant with Argentine history. The tombs are, however, works of art. One does get a bit over-saturated with tombs after a while.
Best free tourist Attraction in BA. This was by far our favourite free attraction on the city! So neat to see how they bury the dead in BA...and also to see famous crypts like that of Evita.

Evita :). I went to the cemetery to visit the grave of Evita. This day was her birthday and had many flowers and people. There's a map at the entrance of the cemetery. It is not very easy to find the right tomb.

fun to visit. The cemetary is very clean and not as old as the famous cemetary in Paris. The kids still had fun walking around and taking pictures of the different tombs and statues. We couldn't find any maps though. There are also English and Spanish tour-guides.
Outstanding!!. Aside from Eva Peron's tomb, the entire cemetery is impressive, monuments and statues incredible. It's free to enter, so worth the time, wow!
Pretty Cool Place. A little creepy to think this is a cemetary, but nevertheless its worth the trip. You could possibly spend the day in this place so much too see as far as the architecture etc.
Evita Peron is buried here!. Nice cemetary to visit, make sure you check out Eva Peron's grave. A bit tough to navigate through, but just look for the crowds and there you will be!

Worth a Trip. The cemetery is incredible. We spent about an hour there and saw about half the cemetery. The only disappointment is the poor condition of many tombs. The rich and famous monuments are in good condition, but the others are falling apart.

Definitely worth a stop. I didn't know too much about the cemetery before our visit, so I was expecting an overdrawn touristy affair with a bunch of people huddling around Evita's grave. It IS touristy, but the cemetery is so big and grand that you can get completely lost in it. It's filled crypts recent and old, dating back to the early 1800s that are simply magnificent. Eva Peron's crypt took a little bit to find and was actually far less impressive than some of the ornate building size crypts from other families. I do wish we had made time for a tour or hired some one to show us around as there isn't much in English and I'm sure we missed out on some great history. Beware the guy at the entrance who gives you directions to and then asks for money. It's free to enter and definitely worth an hour of your time.

A must visit location in Buenos Aires - odd but true. This is a little weird. Trying to review a cemetery as a tourist attraction. But its True! This is one of the few cemeteries in the world that should be on a someones bucket list. Its a not to be missed attraction and not just for the fact that Eva Peron is there. While it would be tempting to just wander on your own, I would actually recommend you get a guide to walk with you and point out the history, the stories, and fine points of these grave sites. If not that at least buy the guide book they sell. Its very safe place and very fascinating. Plan on at least an hour - maybe more if you're into the architecture. JUST GO.
Must see. Great, full of history but it must be done with a guide. Very interesting. We spent over an hour and didn't see it all, just the highlites and a bit more.
Maxinefrombrisbane. It was amazing to see all the huge family mausoleums. The attraction is to see the burial place of Eva Peron.

One of the top 5 things to see in Buenos Aires. If your visiting Buenos Aires you have to check this cemetery out, if nothing else you can say you saw where Eva Peron is buried. This place is fascinating, unique, macabre, quite interesting and worth seeing. You can look inside some of these crypts and see coffins of all sizes. We had our own personnel tour guide that brought us here which was really great because she told us the history behind many of these crypts. She also told us that the owners of this crypts have to pay annual property tax, interesting. I thought I saw cemetery tour guides at the entrance that could be hired for a walking tour, definitely the way to go otherwise you miss a lot if you do it by yourself.

Historical mausolems. If you like antique and historical sites, this is a great place to visit. There are mausoleums dated back to the 1860's! Incredible to view but can be a little creepy :) I didn't feel comfortable walking around areas where there weren't any other people.

GREAT. I faced death every step of the way, a cemetery like no other. Amazing what people will do to remember the dead. Worth the visit and perhaps a MUST stop for everyone. Plan for an hr walking the different sites.

A must see.. The graveyard is packed with opulent tombs. This is death at no expense spared. I know quite a lot of people will say "Why did they give their money to the poor and needy rather than tombs". I cruised South America and the Falkland Islands and this was one of the highlights.

an absolute must. Quirky architecture squashed together but 5 metre crypts underneath - famous people such as Peron are buried here but the fun is the over-the-top sentimentality behind the facades. Look out for the guy cleaning the monuments with a feather duster!
Cats. I loved the cats who lived here the best. The cemetary itself is very interesting, monuments like small buildings. It reminded me of a miniature Rome.

Unique for us. Walking thru Recoleta Cemetery was an eye opening experience. Seeing the wealth spread over the area in contrast to the poverty in other places in this wonderful city was a deep contrast. Of course we stopped to see the main attraction, Evita's apparent final resting place. Impressive!

Beautiful architecture like you've never seen before. It was strange to think of a Cemetary as a must see site but this was such a beautiful place with a lot of history. You could spend an hour or more there wandering around the maze of mausoleums and afterwards, get a coffee at one of the many great Cafes in Recoleta. I suggest you go on a Sat or Sun bc you can do the market at Plaza Francia on the same day.

Be a part of history. If you know anything about Eve Peron, the different stages of her life, and her concern for the poor people of Argentina, then it's a must visit to the Recoleta Cemetery and her grave located among the masoleums of this beautiful and well maintained cemetery. You will find her grave with the Duarte family, in a narrow passage from the main walkway. For those who have never visited a cemetery of this sort, it is well worth the hour or so to see how this country, and its wealthier people, have cared for its dead.
Interesting. Very interesting and worth the visit. Many powerful Argentine families lay in rest here and of course, Eva Peron. Really no need to buy a map, just follow the crowd.

An extraordinary place. A must do! Use the map near the entrance to find Evita's resting place (in her family's mausoleum) but don't bother to try to find her husband - apparently he wasn't posh enough for this cemetary.

Very interesting history and architecture. A cemetery with history, architecture and well maintained.
Enjoyed walking around the grounds, beautiful trees, flowers etc. Seems to always be a busy place.

Eva Peron Tribute (Evita). It was good to see where Eva Peron was laid to rest in her families black marble crypt. It has a rose on it each day.Do not expect something fantastic however it is in fact quite simple as the government of the day did not want her to become a saint. Many visitors are there each day and it does move you to think she is actually there

Cemetery. Interesting grave sites of families. An elite cemetery, only more wealthy permitted to be buried. When yellow fever hit, no one dying of yellow fever would be permitted burial. Went especially to see Evita Peron's grave. Dismayed with person insisting you give money for the upkeep of the cemetery to enter.
facinating place!. I never miss a visit here every time I come to Buenos Aires. It is so interesting to see how the rich and famous are buried and the tombstones are incredible! One not to miss!!
Arrive Early. Rise early and go in right when they open; you'll have the place all to yourself for a while. Beautiful cemetery with many photo ops.

very impressive. For visitors from Northern Europe or the Unites States this kind of cemetery is an outstanding experience. The mausoleums and sculptures are fascinating. It is easy to spend hours looking at the different buildings and family tombs. Unfortunately the atmosphere is not very peaceful due to loads of tourists which mainly come to see the grave of Evita Perron.
city of the dead. More interesting than I thought it would be. The grave of Eva Peron (buried with the Duarte family) is obviously a much venerated shrine to some Argentinoss!

You can't afford to die here. it's a neat little monument to vanity and when extra-rich people run out of spare parts, they continue to linger encased in funerary boxes used in the display and containment of otherwise dead people, and no one will ever take their spot. Good thing Recoleta cemetery does not charge at the door, but you are invited to pay professional tour guides to impart some nationalistic history fiction on locals and tourists alike, the fat undertaker's cats don't seem to lose their feces over the crap they tell you at Evita's hole in the ground.... enjoy life while it's spring time!

Don't Miss this Beautiful and Fascinating Site!. This Cemetary is certainly One of the Most Beautiful in the World. It is filled with Beautiful Masoleums decorated in Fine Marbles, Granite, and Statuary. Allow Enough Time (1 Hour?). A Guide or Good Guidebook is Needed to Bring the Stories to Life.
Amazing Place. The architecture and the "buildings" are amazing. Very helpful staff and easy to get around - once you find the side of the site where the entrance is!

A cemetery like no other. You can not visit Buenos Aires and miss the Recoleta Cemetery. It's most famous resident is of course Evita, but the monuments the rich and powerful of Argentina built to house their remains is one work of art after another. Each mausoleum has its own rich history. Many have their own caretaker and you can see them emerge from underground, which adds to the atmosphere. Many are no longer cared for and you can see open coffins and cobwebs taking over what once was an obviously powerful person. A very intriguing 2 hours and then neighborhood surrounded the cemetery is also not to be missed.
Mildly interesting unless you are really into cemetaries. There was a nice man out front taking donations for an AIDS charity, allegedly. Not sure he was with the cemetary.

The garden of the dead. This cemetery is filled with mausoleums from the last century, decorated with angels, memorial plaques, and, sometimes flowers. Some are new and shiny, with lovely poetry, others are old and crumbly. All honor the dead, some contain many generations, and some are for sale. Perhaps more easily done on a self-guided tour. Although our guide was very informative, the sun was hot and the historical significance wasn't hidden. And, yes, Evita's tomb is there as well.

Worth an hour or two...... This is certainly different and perhaps gives an insight into the outlook of the populace of the city, past and present. Apart from being the last resting places of the great and good,(e.g. Eva Peron), and the not so good... Beware of the helpful guy at the gates offering free advice and a hand drawn map who then tries to sting you for a donation.
Monuments to Argentina - distant and recent past. Beautiful tombs and history. Go with a Porteno who will highlight their favorites - or hire a guide to get below the surface.
Nice for a stop. Of course the Peron-grave is the must-see. The rest of the cemetery is also well worth seeing. Nice for a stop visiting Recoleta.

Quite interesting and worth spending some time here. Yes, Eva Peron is resting here. But,go here and take some time wandering many of the pathways. Reflect on the people who built these vaults. You can see into many of them. Look at the interesting and varied architecture of the crypts. Fascinating place. Don't rush through it. A guide may be nice, but not really needed to get a lot out this place. You can buy a map in your language from a volunteer as you enter for $2 US.Kids will get bored fast.

Interesting. This cemetery was fascinating and free. It is worthwhile not going there with a tour as you can spend ages walking around. Seeing the coffins close up at first was strange but then you forget what they are and enjoy the architecture.
Cemetry worth a visit. You have never seen a cemetry like this. Definitely worth a vist, to inspect the elaborate monuments. Rows and rows of vaults and family crypts.

A Must in BA. This is an amazing place and so much history is held within the confines of the cemetery. Get a private guide (find on internet) as it is more personable. We did a walking tour of Recoleta district which included the cemetery.
