Nice cementary where famous personalities are buried. At the entrance some people collect money for poor people but I think it is a fraud. Avoid paying them. They are very pushy!

Incredible. This place is unlike anything i've ever seen before. The place is huge with row after row of huge tombs that are decorated with beautiful sculptures. As you wonder around you are amazed by it's scale but also a little creeped out by the fact that this is a cemetery.A must see when you are in BA. A quick tip, it's free to enter so just walk past any scammer at the door. Also don't bother with a guide just follow other people that have paid for a guide and listen in.

Amazing and overwhelming. We'd been told that our hotel overlooked the cemetery so I pictured an area filled with headstones. How wrong could I have been! This cemetery is like nothing I'd ever seen. We had a guide to take us round which was great as he was able to explain everything and show us the highlights (see Jonathan Evans tours). You see the mausoleum of Evita but to be honest there are more interesting ones. There are a lot of coffins on display though and after a while you kinda wanna get outta there.

City of Angels. For Real.. La Recoleta is where people with money took it with them when they died. The elaborate mausoleums, erected one right after another for acres and acres, is almost beyond belief. Our tour guide said she once got lost and they almost closed the gates with her inside. That I believe.This is where the famous Evita finally came to rest, with the Duarte family. There's a lot of fascinating background on her journey after dying in 1952. She was buried, dug up, sent to Spain, lost, hidden and finally sent back to spend eternity in peace and quiet. Not in the mausoleum, however; under the sidewalk, encased in concrete. She was a hard one to keep down!You could easily spend a day here, if you're the quiet type. The landscaping is beautiful and the statuary is magnificent. It's an oasis in a bustling Buenos Aires.

More marble than you can poke a stick at!!. An amazing sight. The cemetery felt like a sort of city as we walked down the "streets" between the huge graves and monuments. Eva Peron's burial site is "modest" compared to many of those surrounding it.

A real surprise. We were disappointed that nothing was happening over Christmas in BA but wondered over to the cemetery. Really interesting, even though we didnt understand a lot of the spanish but we had never seen anything like it. They say its more expensive to be dead in this cemetery than live in BA and you can see why. Oh and visiting Evita is a must, you will know the grave by all the other tourists standing around it.

Different cemetary. Many people visit to see the grave of Eva Duarte Peron (Evita). Gets crowded. Many of the mausoleums are in disrepair because the families can't afford upkeep-- makes it interesting because you can look in thru broken doors to see down in.

Wow.... I found it amazing the different ways that families choose to memorialize the family heritage. We could have walked through the cemetery for hours but our tour only allowed an hour. I would recommend to anyone if you have never seen a memorial of this size.

The necropolis. Of course everyone goes to see the tomb of Eva Duarte Peron. Great if you are in to cemeteries, I am not. The story of how her body was treated after she died is appalling. Glad she ended up with her family in the end.

In BA this is a must see. Over the top, filled with mausoleums, crosses, Christ on the cross, statues, etc etc - it's like no other cemetary I know. A must see while in BA. And of course you must visit Eva Peron's mausoleum, if only for history's sake. A photographer's paradise - but first LOOK and then take a picture if it strikes you as interesting.

Must see in Buenos Aires. This cemetery was really amazing to see. So much history and great architecture; never saw anything quite like this. One tour guide told us that a small masoluem could hold as many as 100 caskets since many of them had 4+ levels underground and that there were approximately 6 million people buried there. Sadly there was a funeral happening while we were touring the cemetery. Many of the crowds you will find around Eva Peron's gravesite however there were many that were much more ornate in detail and architecture. It is not large in size, but depending on your interests, you could really spend a good amount of time there.
Beautiful tombs.. Great architecture on the tombs. Very interesting to visit. One of a kind cemetery. Evita's grave is here so make sure to look for her tomb.

A must see. A visit to a cemetery may sound strange to some, but there is so much to see here. Yes, Evita is buried here, but so much history of Argentina is at this cemetery that a visit to BA would be incomplete without a stop here. The cemetery is free, but for a small fee a friendly English speaking docent will provide a map that is all that needed to tour the cemetery.
Great Cemetery. Much like the above ground cemeteries in New Orleans. Eva Perone's tomb is under her maiden name, Duarte.
Must see in Recoleta. This Largest necropolis is a place to visit in recoleta. There is plenty of places to visit around as well. Visit during day time, since it closes at 5:30PM

Incredible place. Across the street from our hotel I have never seen anything like it the closest would be the cemetery in New Orleans. The place is enormous you can purchase a map for $10Pesos half of which is given to charity. It is open from 7am to 7pm with free guided tours in different languages English on Tuesdays and Saturdays. Highlight is the resting place of Eva Peron.
Well worth a visit. It's huge and,like the rest of Buenos Aries, shows a past and fading splendour. The Evita site is surprisingly modest
Not to be missed.. Free. Fascinating. No need for a guide. The residents may be long dead, but this place makes B. A. history come alive.

Increidble--Make sure to have time and a camera!. No traveler should leave BA without seeing this cemetery. It's nothing you could imagine, and they are not kidding when they say you could spend several hours walking through here. It's truly massive with the thousands of beautiful tombs of the once rich and famous. Make sure to have your camera, and some water--because you will be here for awhile!

Interesting. The primary reason most people travel to the cemetary is to see Eva Peron's tomb. There are, however, other interesting noteable tombs to observe. The architecture over the years has changed and the older tombs are interesting

A cemetery that's filled with history. I went to look for Evita, as thousands do each year. I found her and her family's resting place and also discovered so much more! Narrow paths throughout this cemetery take you past so many crypts and burial vaults, dating back over several centuries. Engage a guide who specialize in this cemetery if you want to make the most from your time here, and learn about Argentina's history. Make sure you have a hat and wear sunscreen because there are very few shady areas within the cemetery. A bottle of water is also a good idea, but not as important as a hat.

Astounding - the world's finest cemetery?. Full of beautiful sculptures and proud tributes to the famous and privileged - this is a truly remarkable place. Recoleta is not only a collective monument to the dead, but also a statement of national pride. To my knowledge there is nothing else quite like it elsewhere.

I never thought I'd say a cemetary was beautiful. This is a great FREE thing to do in Buenos Aires. The mausoleums were breathtaking. Carve out 30 minutes to take a stroll back in time. Something you've never seen before!

Unexpectedly interesting, a definite must-see in BA. I'm from England. A cemetery is a rather low-key place, containing row upon row of headstones, perhaps 3-4 feet in height. Not so in Recoleta. The cemetery is a sprawling mini-city containing street upon street of elaborate mausoleums of myriad architectural styles, some kept immaculately, others derelict. It sounds ghoulish, but it's a great place to wander around.Oh and the embalmed body of Eva Peron is entombed here.
Interesting. Apart from its most celebrated resident - Eva, this cemetery is most interesting with elaborate or sometimes mausoleums. It is central and well worth visiting.
Evas burial place. We visited to see the Duarte family vault but the vastness of the cemetry and the grandness of some of the vaults was amazing. Every visitor to B A should visit it.

Interesting. One of the main reasons you are recommended here is that Eva Peron is buried here, but the real interest is in the lovely mausoleums in the cemetery. It's truly a city of the dead, particularly the rich dead.

A Surprise Attraction. Liked the Guides explanation that Eva Perron is burried here, however with a previously lower class class upbringing, and havinf fought for the common people it would not have been her choice as this site is reserved for high society, wealthy people and recognized political figures. Her crypt, like all the other above groud crypts , surrounded by attractive gardens, were quite interesting to see. Disliked that some cemetary sections seemd to be closed off for no apparent reason; a minor nuisance.

For English speakers, the tours at 11 am on Tuesday and Thursday are well worth it.. I think most non-Argentians have a more difficult time appreciating the Recoleta Cemetery without a more thorough presentation of the history and current thoughts presented through a tour or private reading. I admit my suggestion would be to enhance the tours with audioheadsets which would allow everyone on the tour to hear (and prevent idiots from asking too many dumb questions) as I think most tourists would be more than willing to pay a small fee for a tour. Be prepared for a line as you try to see Evita's tomb, as every tour group tries to cram into this narrow passageway. Later in the day can be a bit less crowded. You can print off a map free off the internet if you don't want to pay the 10 pesos (2 USD).

Great experience. It was interesting to read about the wealthy historic figures to Buenos Aires history that buried there. The architecture styles of the tombs range from neo classic to art deco and the some of the sculptures have declared national historic monuments.

In the shadows of angels. When in Buenos Aires, hang out with the dead! Truly. I have been in old cemeteries before, but this sculpture garden of mausoleums in the middle of this huge modern city, is a delightful stroll with a bit of ghostly grisliness to spice it up. With such famous "inhabitants" as Eva Peron, whose simple tomb denies her audacious life, the cemetery at Recoleta has row after row of tiny houses with ornately carved doorways, many of which also have amazing statuary. Most of this housing is well kept up, someone in the family is still alive to sweep & dust, wash the windows, care for the statues. Others are falling apart, with broken windows, the glass of which still litters the floor within. Some of the walkways are crowded with visitors but many are as silent, well, as the tomb & there are trees & benches to contemplate the overwhelming array of sacred imagery. Most have a rather Catholic connotation but many are more political or having to do with work or play rather than religion. All in all, definitely worth a visit, especially since it's free to the public though it closes at sundown & is locked up tight to prevent the vandalism that has so obviously, & sadly, caused some of the apparent damage.

Very Unique Place. This is definitely not your average cemetery. There are just rows and rows of mausoleums and tombs. It is amazing. After awhile, I admit I got bored, but it is worth a visit. To get a better view of the place, go to the church next door and do the cloisters tour. It is only about AR$10 pesos. From their window on the top it looks down on to the cemetery. Nice view.
probably have to go see Evita. nicer than that fancy cemetery in Parisyou can see the whole thing in under an hoursome of the crypts are in state of disrepair, some are very nice

A must-do if you love art, architecture and history!. If you really want to do get the most from your visit here, use the free maps, a guidebook or have a tour guide. Seeing the magnificent structures and knowing the story of the many notables resting here makes this a must-do if you visit this city.
Best part of the city tour, different than others. This was one of the stops on a half day city tour. I don't visit cemeterys very often, however this was worth the stop.
Something very different. This place is a show of for Buenos Aires rich people,but you have to to understand and it is worthwhile to visit and of course take photographs

Unique take on death. The mausolea are impressive and crammed in at this must-see cemetery. There are maps available but we tagged along behind a guided tour which soon went to the Eva Peron vault, and otherwise just wandered around enjoying the statuary and architecture. What amazing hubris these people had to commemorate themselves in such an extravagant way.

A MUST SEE. The Recoletta Cemetery is steeped in history. English tours are offered but just to walk around and look at the beautiful grave sites is worth the visit. Great photo opps. There are free maps giving directions and highlighting the important people buried there including Evita.

A must...the most beautiful cemetary.. You must bring your camera...a real visual treat. So many beautiful statues adorn the various family mausoleums. A lovely place to spend a few hours on a quiet Sunday. If you are loking for Eva Peron...she is buried in her family mausoleum...look for Familia Duarte. You can spot it by the flowers...it is one of the only ones that have fresh flowers no matter what day you visit. Also go to the Basilica and Arts Center next door.

What an Amazing Cemetry. In early January 2013 my friend and I, while visitng Buenos Aries visited Recoleta Cemetery. This was an amazing visit. So, historical. We spend over an hour there and it was well worth the visit. The staff that were on duty at the gate to cemetery were most helpful and the lady was able to speak Excellent English and as I was from Ireland she told to go and visit the tomb of Fr. Fahy from Ireland. Her information was Excellent.

Grand and Solemn Visit. I'm not one for mausoleums and cemeteries when sightseeing but the Cementerio de la Recoleta is unlike anything I've ever seen. It is magnificent, imposing and jaw-dropping, all at the same time. Many visitors go to the cemetery, not because they know someone buried there, but to gawk at the grand statues and tombs. We spent an hour just wandering around the labyrinth of tombs, reading the names for famous people buried in the cemetery and googling them on our mobile phone to read more about them.Of course, no visit to the cemetery is complete without dropping by Eva Peron's grave. Head to the directory by the main entrance to locate her grave. She is listed under 'Duarte'.

evita peron. evitas remains are in this cemetery which is worth a visit just to see the many mausolems. the only problem if you want to visit evitas resting place is it is a bit hard to find. apart from the main directory at the entrance there are no other signs directing one in the right direction. if you happen to be there on a busy day its easier to find just follow the people carrying flowers.any other day carefully look at the main diectory and locat it then count the streets and blocks just as though it was a city.

A very interesting place to visit. Lots of Argentinian history here located right in the middle of the Recoleta neighborhood. If you want to make the most of your visit be sure to look for and get one of the guides who station themselves right at the entrance to the cemetery. We used Simon, an Englishman now living in Buenos Aires,who gave us a detailed and interesting tour. We highly recommend him. Note that the guides don't charge you a fee, you just tip them what you think is appropriate.
The best cemetery. This is an amazing cemetery. It is a place not to miss. A must visit. My hubby and I had an personal guided tour then come back in the afternoon taking more time to take it all in.

What a beatiful place to walk. Beautiful Cemetary, and the monuments are stunning. You can walk around for hours and not see everything. Eva Peron's headstone is very small and almost hidden but you will be able to find it, just follow the people.
People are dying to get here!. I never knew that being dead would create such a sensation! It was interesting to see how Portenos respect their dearly departed,

Probably on the B.A. "Must Do" List. Best thing to do is to take up an offer for a half hour tour by one of the guides at the entrance. The stories are entertaining and you will save a lot of time trying to hunt for mausoleums on your own. The most visited mausoleum is that of Eva Peron, who is buried within or underneath the Duarte family crypt. The various mausoleums are a sight by themselves, some quite ornate and others rather plain. There is no entrance fee. Cabs are plentiful. And there are cemetery cats that roam amongst the crypts. Our guide, a fellow named Simon, explained how the crypts needed to be vented to avoid the smell of decay, and that many of the crypts had several meters of underground lairs.Afterward, walk down the main avenues of Ricoleta before grabbing a cab. Also, there is an adjacent church which is also worth a brief look.
A real gem. A very solemn place to walk around on a warm day. Free entry, there's no need to buy a map or have a guided tour, just stroll round in your own time in respectful silence.Really charming.

Fascinating Cemetary. A tour of Buenos Aires is not complete without walking through the Recoleta Cemetery. This is where Evita is buried and the crypts are one of a kind. Hard to describe the structures that are built over the crypts,

Edward Everett would be pleased.... Everett was an advocate of cemeteries where living people could share and enjoy the space with those who have passed, like Mt Auburn Cemetery in Boston and Pere Lachaise in Paris. Everett gave the main oration at the dedication of Gettysburg where President Lincoln gave his Gettysburg address. Recoleta is a perfect example, and all ages and kinds of people move in and out of it with comfort and it is quite peaceful. It is also beautifully maintained. It would be difficult not to be moved, walking through such an historic and peaceful place.

amazing and scary. if you are not afraid to see some old ruined crypts, broken coffins with some ..remains.. go ahead.also you can find some nice statues and if you take guided tour you can catch interesting story.free entrance.i would suggest to find some iinformation and cementry map in the internet and take with you, so it will be interesting to walk around. also you can buy this from the lady inside, up to you

An ancient site. Well worth the visit which was included as an overall tour of Buenos Aires. There are so many different and varying mausoleums within the cemetry and the histories that go with it makes it very interesting!

One of my favorite sites in Buenos Aires!. This place is both beautiful and a little creepy. So many gorgeous packed in mausoleums in a variety of styles. Evita's was actually a bit of a let down, it seemed pretty modest compared to the many other showy memorials all around. Oh and who doesn't love a cementery with its own cats?

Both amazing and sad. Visited here as a group during a day off from business. I had no previous information about this cemetery. I was blown away by how ornate and how many were within the cemetery. It is worth a stop (free) if you are in the area. There are people at the entrance looking for donations for kids with aids or something but I'm not too sure if they are legit. The sad part for me was the state of some of the sites. It was clear there was no long term funding to take care if a window breaks or part of the site startes to crumble. It would be worth charging a few bucks just to keep up the sites that are in need of repair.

The Recoleta Cemetary. A must see in Buenos Airies and not just for Eva Peron's burial place, which is simply part of the Duerte Family Mausoleum, but is always crowded with visitors. However, to simply walk through the place is fabulous and there are some stunning mausoleums in the cemetary. We were there when the market was on outside the cemetary and were able to buy some jewelry while there. The cafes adjacent are great places to people watch.

Beautiful cemetery.. Was very busy when we went and we had to que to see Evita Perons grave, it was really small and not as grandiose as some of the others. But worth it to go look. Around the cemetary there are markets and some good restaurants.

Curious, interesting resting place to visit. This cemetery is the final resting place of Eva Paron, as well as many other important figures of wealth and political influence in early Argentinian history. The many winding rows of mausoleums are as fascinating as they are macabre. Look hard for the few Freemasonry symbols that can be seen on several facades.

Should not miss it. Amazing place - free to visit. You need to get a map so that you can see all important sights. Not sure if you need a guide. We did it without, 1.5 hour is enough to see all the highlights

A mix of New Orleans and Paris. True of a few things in this town, but especially true of Recoleta Cemetery. I went on a BA walking tour, so it was extra special to hear the stories and intrigue. Well told, and a very cool place to visit.

An amazing place to spend an afternoon. La Recoleta Cemetery – located in the La Recoleta neighborhood of Buenos Aires is 14 acres and contains 4691 vaults, all above ground, of which 94 have been declared National Historical Monuments by the government. Evita is buried here among others. Easy to spend hours walking through history, reading the tomb signs and talking about life and death. May sound strange but it is a highlight in BA!!!

Interesting. As part of our city tour we spent some time at the Recoleta Cemetery. As others have said, it is certainly not what one would expect in a cementary. The cemetary is a maze of mausoleums, from the rather plain to the elaborate. They are organized into "streets" and "alleys" giving the cemetary a "City" appearance/feeling. While the main attraction is the grave of Evita (Durante) Peron, many of the mausoleums have interesting stories behind them. Our particular guide, Alex, was very well versed in the stories of a number of the sites, and kept up a running commentary as we made our way through the various streets and passage ways. Without knowing the stories the mausoleums arelittle more than interesting pieces of architecture. However, hearing about the families, and/or the people buried there made the visit all the more interesting and in an odd way personal. If you do not go on a city tour, or you want to go a second time, there are always a number of guides at the entrance. It is well worth the money to hire one to shepherd you around this thought-provoking site.

like nothing i've ever seen before. the architecture of the mausoleums is so cool. looks like a mix of lots of different types and styles. it's kind of hard to find evita's tomb unless you're with a tour group, or just follow a tour group until you see a mass of people waiting in line down a narrow corridor of the cemetery. it's not that impressive, sorry to say, but the rest of the place certainly makes up for that.

Atmospheric...must see...and free. This is an amazing place and really must be visited if in Buenos Aires. Everyone goes to Evita's family (Duarte) tomb - look at the clear & simple map near the entrance first. This is a mini-city of mausoleums, churches, tombs...very atmospheric, especially if visited in the evening.PS - Apologies if my review of Recoleta (the area) reads the same as this one - I thought I was reviewing the cemetery (doh)!

Atmospheric must see...and free. Amazing place to walk around - a real little city of the dead with not just tombs but churches and mausoleums. It pays to look at the map near the entrance, then you can go straight to Evita's family (Duarte) tomb and after that just stroll around.

Go with a Guide. overwhelming to see the many many mausaleums. Everyone simply goes to see Eva Peron's buriel spot but if you go with a knowledgeable guide you will learn about other very famous people buried there as well as how they shaped the city and country.

a dying art. No one gets burried this way nowadays,but yet this cemetary is still active today. The statues and buildings of the graves are really unbelievable.It is very interresting to walk through the graves and see what people were ready to invest to commemorate the dead.

Have to see it!. I never had been to a cemetery before, this one was my first. Everything is beautiful, you get touched by the amazing mausoleums. We went there to see Evita's grave and it was emotional to be there, to see argentinian's devotion to it. As the guide said, there is always flowers there. If you go to Buenos Aires, you should try to go there.
Go!. Visit the cemetery at least once, if not twice. If you hire a guide or bring a detailed guidebook with you, it will be even more worth it. Allow plenty of time for a visit.

Looking backwards and ahead. Recoleta Cemetery is a vast place with graves, masoleums that are arranged in "streets", each one longer, bigger than the next. One has to wonder where future burials will occur as this cemetery is very full.Said hello to Evita, again, and moved on."

Well worth a visit. Not just for visiting the Eva Peron tomb but also just wandering round the place. Not necessarily somewhere you would think of spending a few hours (in a cemetery!!!) but actually completely fascinating, like a little mini city! You can easily get lost in there so take a compass to get your bearings!

Amazing Place to Visit. I thought we'd just spend a little time there but ended up staying for a couple of hours. So many wonderful mausoleums to see and explore. It's magical and of course Eva Peron is buried there.

Worth a trip..... Beautiful, haunting and well kept in the middle of Ricoleta. A lot like a smaller Pere Lachaise in Paris, the cemetery is right by Our Lady of Pilar church and an area with a weekend artisan market.

Creepy...! ;). Beautiful and creepy at the same time, saw many coffins, old ones, new ones...all shapes and sizes. Eva Peron´s grave is fairly new...but we saw awkward and enormous picture perfect ones also...

Very interesting. We stayed in a hotel close by to the cemetery and visited it more than once. The entrance is free and there are many guides at the gate offering their services, plus a tour of the cemetery is included in many of the city tours.It’s fascinating to walk through this city of elaborate 'houses'. Some of the buildings are new and shiny, other are decrepit and very interesting. You can see coffins and staircases leading deep down into the earth. It’s a restful place especially when it’s not full (once we went late in the afternoon). It was easy to find Eva Peron’s grave as most people make a beeline for it. On Sundays there is a large market in the park in front of the cemetery, and directly opposite the main gate (across the park) are restaurants and tango dancing. Near to the entrance is the Recoleta mall (which is air-conditioned but rather boring) with some fast food shops and expensive clothes shops. If you are in Buenos Aires I would recommend you spend a few hours walking through here.
Beautiful Statuary. The Recoleta Cemetery is a big draw for most BA tourist. This is the resting place of Evita. That said, the cemetery is beautiful and the statuary is amazing.

Amazing detail, tomb after tomb. We went late in the day, right before close as we heard bus loads of people came earlier in the day. Reloceta cemetery of Buenos Aires was a quiet escape for us given the emptiness in late afternoon, the most movement we saw was from the cats lounging around the various tombs. Lots of walking back and forth and plenty to see including Eva Peron's tomb so wear good walking shoes!

Eva Peron is buried here, but she is not alone!. This is not the only cemetery that we have visited as a tourist attraction, but it is certainly one of the most interesting. The fact that most graves are buildings of a similar height makes it feel as though you are walking through streets of houses of the dead, but there are so many interesting facts and features. it is very important that you have a guide otherwise you will miss so much. You can't miss Evita's grave - just follow the crowds. A reflection of the history of Argentina, through the lives and deaths of the more wealthy citizens - where are the poor buried? Generations of the same family are interred in family plots/buildings, and the is a waiting list to take over plots where the family line dies out, which doesn't happen often.The properties overlooking the cemetery are more expensive than those looking the other way, because their view will never be impaired by tall buildings!

A fascinating place. I never thought that a cemetery could be so fascinating, but this one truly is, it is like walking through a small town without street names! A must, of course, is Eva Peron's tomb. You can see coffins placed one on top the other, separated by linen cloths, there are photos and flowers, some coffins are in pristine condition, some of falling apart. It is all steeped in history and well worth a visit.Plenty of facilities nearby.

Great Crypts.. This is a great cemetery that is not depressing in the least, rather, it has a carnival atmosphere about it on aSunday afternoon. The cemetery was once established for the local catholic priests to be interred at, but later became THE Place to be buried if you were a BsAs important family, war general, or generally important person. The crypt architecture has to be seen to be believed and is definitely worthwhile. There are clean toilets just inside the enterence, either side. There is an excellent marke place outside the gate where an enjoyable time can be had. There are Tango Demonstrations on the far side of the park as you go towards town which were very good.

Evita's buried here, but there's so much more to see. The big draw is Evita Peron's (Duarte - sp?) burial vault, but there is so much more to see here. Some of the vaults are simply grand, some are abandoned, but the architecture and the history makes for a nice several hour walk/visit.I can't remember its name, but there is an absolutely fabulous outdoor cafe near the large spreading limbs of a giant tree just off the cemetery. Be sure to stop there and have a beer and/or lunch.

Amazing diversity. The cemetery is open to the public, and there are tours, but we chose to just wander around. Everyone wants to see the Evita mausoleum, but that not even one of the impressive ones. Walk around, look at all the angels topping the different buildings, and be amazed by the intricate detailing on them.

Interesting time for wandering around something you wouldn't think was so interesting.. Cool place to just wander around and check out all the tombs and family plots. All very interesting to check out, from delux to run down, but all worthy of time spent.
Dead centre.. A fascinating piece of history viewed during a city coach tour. Of course we saw Eva's repository. Could have done with more time.

Definately a must. We loved the cemetery. Does not compare to the cemeteries of Paris but has a lovely intimacy about it and is absolutely pristine and beautiful. PLUS you have to see Evita's spot. We went on a rainy day which was perfect....Argentine's don't go out in the rain so we had the place to ourselves!

Strange and fascinating. Visiting cemeteries is not something we tend to do in our holidays to large cities like BA but this is an exception we were pleased to have made.Recommend you take a guide to explain the history and locate the highlights as its a bit of a jumble and you could take hours to locate some of the better known mausoleums like Eva Peron.We hired a guide at the entrance and it cost us around usd50 for our group of 4 and it turned out to be great value for the hour and a half we had available
Must see in BA. One of the places in Buenos Aires where you have to go. It's cementary, but you feel there like in open-air museum.
strangely wonderful. Quite amazing! Rows & rows of mausoleums from simple to extravegant. Lots of stories. Remember Evita's tomb is under her family name not Peron.

Mausoleum Heaven. Not one to make it a habit of visiting a cemetery, this is one plot that is unlike any other. Absent of any graves, every inch of space is taken up by large, ornate mausoleum. Down one alley is the place where Evita Peron is buried. Visiting this place is a must see, and the price of "free" makes it even the more worthwhile.
Fascinating and historical. This is a place to go back to often to learn the stories about the people memorialized in this incredible cemetery.
Top BA Attraction. Yes, this is the #1 attraction in Buenos Aires for good reason. It really is a "Must See". Many mausoleums would cost more than the typical 4 bedroom house. Free Admission.
The resting place of Elvita. Her black family tomb may have a line-up to walk by and take a picture. The other tombs in the area may be more dramatic.

Marvelous. Row upon row of mausoleums. Burial places of famous historical persons, politicians, generals and famous people. The one taking most attention is the Evita Peron's resting place. Rather modest in comparison with some of the other mausoleums. Interesting.

Visit the grave of Evita Peron.. Well preserved monumental cementary, comparable to Père Lachaisse in Paris or the Monumental Cementary in Milano. You have to visit the grave of Evita Peron, but make sure you first consult the map at the entrance. And have a walk around to see the other monumental graves.

Eerie insights into another culture. We lucked out - our guide's family owns a crypt in Recoleta Cemetery, so we got a very detailed explanation, at her actual crypt, of how burial rites and ceremonies are conducted, along with an understanding of the physical layout of the mausoleums, both above and below-ground. We learned that her mother receives phone calls nearly every week from families that want to "rent" their crypt, just for one day, to hold a funeral service there, before interring their deceased loved one at a less-fashionable cemetery elsewhere! Even in death, class and status matter!With this background information, seeing the many hundreds of family crypts, in all states of repair and disrepair, some humble, others grandiose, and the messages they convey to visitors, gave us much to reflect upon.

MUST SEE. So much history here - and not just Eva Peron's family tomb (Duarte). Although Eva's burial place is the main reason to visit, you can easily get lost in the grand tombs that overtake this cemetary. From gothic to modern - this is definitely a must see in Buenos Aires.
An absolute must when in BA!. Stunningly gorgeous cemetery of Eva Peron's final resting place ---along with many other notables Argentines.

A true gem. The pathways are clean, the stray cats, friendly, the mausoleums grand and impressive. Evita's tomb always has a crowd but there are so many other beautiful tombs just go around the corner and wait. Many good restaurants nearby including a great pizza place near the mall.

Amazing. Recoleta cemetery is like a miniature city of mausoleum homes of the dead that you can leisurely roam through for hours if you care to. It almost feels like you're peeking in someone's living room window when you take a step up the little porches and peer in the beveled glass doors secured with ornate iron gates. You'll see shelves lined with family photographs, intricately carved coffins, some covered with fine lacy linens, kneeling stools, crucifixes and potted plants. Some are regularly maintained and others have fallen into such disrepair you can almost see the bones through the coffin's cracks. The statues throughout the cemetery will leave you in awe. I've lived in BA for a couple years and return to Recoleta cemetery often. If you're visiting BA, don't miss it!

Great to see tourists. Love to crowded by tourist? Well this is probably one of the best places to visit.A major tourist spot and one of the few I liked. It was nice to see the old stone work and the talent went into making such designs. The draw back is the amount of crowds of tourists. If planning on coming here, make sure it is early in the morning before the crowds come, so that you can enjoy the gorgeous burial sites.
Never seen anything like it. Well worth a visit. I takes one hour of your time in BA and it is truly something else. A cemetary different from all others. And free!

Beautiful. I know it's a cemetary. But it is truely and very beautiful cemetary,. People come here just to pay there respects to Evita but the crypts here are so impressive and beautiful that the cemetary is an attraction. Worth a visit and spend an hour or 2 walking aound and seeing the different monuments.

Amazing!. You have to visit the cemetary even if it's just for a quick walk around. I've never seen such an amazing cemetary. I know that sounds odd but it's really worth checking out and can be done farily quick if that's what you want or take an hour or 2 to wonder around. Don't miss it.
intersting place to visit. take your time ..dont rush though the place and have time to look at the details of the graves which are emblemed with different styles .
Fascinating. With or without a guide, the cemetery is an interesting visit. There are lots of stories about the occupants.

More than just Evita Peron. Loads of interesting mausoleums and crypts to see along with Evita's. Friends of the cemeterty sell maps (bewore of one of the lovely but very very chatty ladies their) which are worth it to save time.

Drop Dead Gorgeous. I've been to Père Lachaise in Paris but I thought this was better. More compact, neater and mausoleums are much better maintained. Besides being an insight into the BA view of death & celebration of the life. It is really a tour of some of the most fabulous architecture and sculptures by European masters in the finest Carrara marble. We paid a registered English speaking private guide around 50 pesos per head from memory. Without question it was worth it. He could tell you so much about the person or families and their place in the hstory of BA or Arg, It was the passion that he had for the cemetery and the history that maps and the internet cannot give you. Who knew there was such a rich Irish history in BA?Time to kill in BA? Put this on the "must see" list.

Weird place. It is very weird to go to a cemetery, but it is awesome to see all different headstones. The most important families use to build very ostentatious and beutiful headstones. A lot of important Argentine politicians are buried there. And the most famous Evita Peron!

never ceases to amaze. no visit to BA is complete without a return to this amazing city of the dead. You can spend hours wandering, wondering, speculating about the people who "live" here. And of course, you must admire the felines who hang out among the tombstones and mausoleums. I never get tired of it...do it with a guide, or on your own...but you have to go!

Amazing City of the Dead. A map of the site would have been helpful but none were available. After all those years hosting dinner parties in Paris, it's nice to see that Evita's corpse has a nice final resting place. The architecture of the death is some of the most diverse, inventive, and somewhat perverse, found anywhere.

Peaceful Haven. We have never considered walking through a cemetery before but in this city this is must do.This place is so full of history, it does help if you can get a local guide to really appreciate the stories behind some of the gothic headstones and vaults. I was worried that it would be a sacrilege to view this location as a tourist destination. However if you treat the site with dignity and respect the locals appreciate you being there.

Best cemetery i've ever visited...but i wouldn't want to stay there :-). Even though the day was hot and airless, this museum/cemetery must be on everyone's to do list when in Bs.As. We showed up for a very informative 1.5 hr free English tour on Thursday at 11 am. Quite a few characters are buried there, and it's interesting to hear how Portenos with means bury their loved ones...
A must see.. Planning to be cremated myself but if burial is your thing then you must spend an hour in Recoleta. The history, the architecture, the people. A must visit in BA.

Fascinating. I could have spent an entire day walking around this place. It is a wonderful monument to the people and history of the city. It is worth getting some kind of guide as you learn wonderful things about the people buried here and there are some incredible stories. It is also great just to spend time wondering around on your own. There are beautiful statues and frescos - wonderful architecture and ruins. It was also interesting to see the burial spot of Evita - to find it look under her family's name Duarte not Peron.

Bring your camera. This unique cemetery is amazing. We did not bother with a tour guide - you can read up on the cemetery's occupants on the Internet. It is just very interesting to wander around and then you will probably accidentally find Eva Peron's mausoleum because there will be a crowd in front of it. We went on a week day which is probably less crowded than on weekends. Best of all, it is free.

Awesome! You will be amazed!. We first thought it was weird but we were passing by anyways so we stopped by. You will never see anything like this! Coffins are in mini buildings and everything is super elaborate. It's like a fancy park for the rich who have passed away! We loved seeing it! It was definitely something different and unique to buenos aires!

Unique and Surprisingly Interesting!. Even if you hate cemeteries, the Recoleta Cemetery is a must see! Very Unique...This cemetery is built like a subdivision for the dead! Hundreds and Hundreds of Mausoleums made of various architectural styles, sizes, and materials. We found it interesting just walking around and admiring the monuments.

Fascinating insight into Argentine culture. Recoleta Cemetary is worth visiting for its aesthetics (nicely maintained grounds), its novelty (few cities that I'm aware of have such elaborate crypts and are as heavily visited), and the insights into how Argentines view family and death.
Interesting for a short while. A little different from standard city tourist sites, unless you frequent New Orleans. The secret to finding Eva Peron is to know that her maiden name was Duarte.

Nice monument. Although I am usually not keen on visiting cemeteries, the Recoleta cemetery was very different of traditional cemeteries . It has a lot of grandiose tums belonging to large Argentinian families that have impacted the Argentinian history

loved it!. you got time on your hand in BA, than go to the cementery, try to book a tour - a map can do as well, but one needs guidance... it is so impressive to stroll through the pathways lined by huge mausoleums with famous citizens of BA, not so famous, families and so on .... getting lost to read the names and to study the buildings, watching the straying cats, it will take at least 1-2 hours to go through.short cut to the grave of Evita is marked at the entrance-map.

Hauntingly beautiful. Extremely impressive cemetery for Argentine luminaries. Plenty of tourists as it's free and definitely somewhat creepy when you look down the mausoleum stairs and wonder what lurks beneath. Conveniently placed to a large shopping centre and also some restaurants right outside for a decent lunch (we had Cantina Italiana and it was good!).

Beautiful and haunting. I never thought I'd say this about a cemetery, but I love this place! It's unlike any cemetery I've been to. Normally, I find them sad, dreary, lonely places. But this one is truly beautiful. Each crypt has its own design, varying from sleek and modern to ornate and gothic, with many beautiful sculptures and statues throughout. You see a huge range of maintenance and upkeep (you can tell some are meticulously cleaned and maintained while others probably haven't been touched in decades), which actually makes the place even more interesting to look at. Beautiful place to be buried, and an intriguing place to spend an hour or two wandering around.
Recoleta Cemetary. Interesting collection of eclectic mausoleums and graves. A great place to spend time just wandering around and taking pictures in the middle of Buenos Aires.

Pay homage to Evita. The cemetery itself is worth a visit with streets lined with the mausoleums of Argentinian worthies. The main attraction of course is that of Eva Peron. Look for the Duarte crypt that houses Evita. It is the only one dripping with floral tributes.

Historic, nostalgic, evocative. Everything is overdone in Argentina -- the size of the steaks, the size of the country, the number of psychiatrists per inhabitant. Recoleta Cemetery is no exception to this. Perhaps only the Père Lachaise cemetery in Paris can match Recoleta Cemetery's ornate profusion of mausoleums, some of which are miniature mansions complete with chandeliers and stained glass windows. Walking along the paths between the tombs one can make out Argentina's rich immigrant history, with Italian, German, Croatian, Polish and of course Spanish names on the gravestones. There is even a little section of English graves. Of course, everyone will need to visit Eva Duarte's (Evita's) family crypt, but the cemetery would be well worth a visit even if she were buried elsewhere. Perhaps it's a pun to say that the Recoleta Cemetery is "in the dead center of town" but in this case it's certainly true. Don't miss it if you are in Buenos Aires.
Really interesting. This cemetery, for the rich and famous, is certainly not creepy.It is architecturally beautiful and looks like a small enclosed city.I would def recommend a visit.
Very impressive. But Evitas tomb is possibly the least impressive.This cemetary is clealry forthe wealthy and really impressive

Free, "must see". This is probably on everyone's list. Probably the most iconic place to visit in Buenos Aires. We stopped by and walked around for a while. It was crazy to see so many mausoleums, one right after another. It was particularly interesting to see how many of the tombs were well taken care of, but others seem to have been forgotten over the years. Liked that it was free.

Worth a visit. This was like no other cemetery that I had ever visited. You will eventually find Eva Peron's family vault. But it is a process. The day we visited it was hot, and hard to find shade. So be prepared to spend at least 30 minutes or more exploring. And bring water.

Totally different experience!. This cemetary is totally different from any other graveyards I've seen anywhere else in the world! Loads and loads of "mausoleums" right next to eachother, some very old and decayed, covered in spider-web (yes, it actually looks like Halloween-decorations...) , others newer and extravagant. A very odd experience to a northern European...
Evita, RIP. Cemetery where Evita Peron's body was buried. Pretty simple, but with high historical value. Located in a square with other attractions

Very unique experience. Really, really enjoyed this place. It was unlike anything I've ever visited before. Some of the tombs are built with the same care and design as you might find in much larger religious structures. It wasn't at all creepy as some of my traveling companions were initially concerned about!

Cemetery for the aristrocrats of Buenos Aires. This is where Eva Peron aka Evita was finally buried , 20 years after her death. Her body was moved from place to place, even to Milan, Italy for some years

A hauntingly beautiful piece of history. Definitely visit the cemetary, and if possible hire a reasonable guide outside. Our guide made the visit very special by telling us fascinating stories about some of the families, and pointing out special features(cut out doors where you could view amazing stained glass) that we noticed regular visitors did not see. I's better to go when it is a bit cooler, not the midday heat. There are some fabulous photo opportunities!
Epic show of wealth in death. Amazing architecture and the resting place of many of Argentina's finest including Eva Peron. Free guides will show you around although we didn't have time.
This is a must see. Beautiful & unique.. The tomb of Eva Peron is nestled b/n other ones. Best way to find it is to find the lines of people lined up to take photo in front of it.

A beautiful and insightful piece of BsAs history. One visit was not enough to the Recoleta Cemetary. Most of my pictures of my month-long stay in BsAs consist of my one visit to the cemetary. The artwork is incredible as well as the stories behind many of the family mausoleums.I think it might be worthwhile to hire a guide or make friends with someone who can tell you a little about the background of a few of the family mausoleums. A friend went with me whom had visited often and was able to enlighten me as to the early deaths of a few of the people whom had monuments built in their honor. (Thank you Ismaela!)The surrounding area is very charming and there are many parilla restaurants to accommodate all budget sizes. I am not a big beef eater, but in Argentina I loved their beef. I could not get enough of it. There are some attractions close-by (an overly large tree and market, I believe) that make the trip a must-see on a short itinerary visit.

a quiet oasis in a busy city. Beautiful funeral monuments designed by the best architects and sculptors of the early 20th century.Better to visit early in the morning or late afternoon to avoid groups.
A lot of important dead people. Amassing works of masonry.To be buried here one could say that living was ok but dying is expensive.

Definitely a don't-miss if you have the time. Eva Peron's tomb is here, and is overwhelmed by the tombs of other prominent Argentinians who have engraved themselves in monuments so ornate that they could be a separate sculpture museum. It's worth 30 - 60 minutes to wander through-- probably not the half day recommended by some guidebooks since most of us are unacquainted with the deceased.

Get a guide. Never thought I'd got 'sightseeing' in a cemetary, but then this is no ordinary cemetary. Mind boggling was the architecture and lavish displays of both wealth and love for the dead. Wished we had of waited and spent the small amount of $$ getting a guide to get more out of the experience. Still enjoyed it nonetheless and managed to find Eva's family vault by following the noisy throng of tour groups.

Better than I thought. I enjoyed this place more than I thought I would. Peaceful place to walk around and soak up a bit of history. It is conveniently located near the weekend street fair and some nice cafes, and so makes for a good outing overall.
A fascinating place to wander around.. I wish we had more time here, but it's worth a visit just to see Eva Peron's grave. We had just enough time to view old and modern sites.

Don't skip the cemetary!. Wow - what a surprise to walk through the white gates to a village full of tombs. The tombs are built with incredible details (and wealth). We went the first time to see Evita's tomb and went back the second time at the end of our City tour, where we heard some of the stories. Definitely worth visiting!

Unique walking experience. A lot of Westerners will find this an extraordinary place to visit. We had a perfect day to look through the place and find the Eva Peron site which wasn't all that easy due to lack of signs or helpful staff; worth the effort to get there.

Evita of course. Wandering the cemetery was quite interesting and enjoyable. We took a lot of pictures. It can get quite hot so try and go early and take some water. The artists feria in front was interesting too.

Where Eve Peron is buried. but there is so much more to this place than the little plaque showing where Eve Peron is buried. The whole place is amazing with monuments to the areas most influential and wealthy citizens.

Worth a visit. We did not happen upon the right time for one of the free tours, but they are fairly frequent.When we walked there, we did not know where entrance located. So walked pretty much around the block and a shopping center on a hot day. Yikes! They do not have signs to indicate, it is on the side that has cobblestone walks and driveways, I think it's streets Ortiz or Junin on the map.

Worthwhile, but definitely find a good guide or a good map of this Cemetery!. One does not expect to enjoy a trip to the cemetery but who can go to Buenos Aires without visiting Recoleta Cemetery! One plus is we had a guide who knew where "the bodies" were buried and gave us countless stories about who was buried where and the circumstances behind their deaths. Finding out there were as much as two stories beneath the above ground crypts amazed us as much as what was found in some of them. Although parts of the cemetery were in disrepair and some of the crypts as well, that, too, is part of the story. You have to be very rich to be interred in Recoleta and your descendents must be rich as well and interested enough to pay for the upkeep of your crypt OR. ....We wandered with our guide and then by ourselves and could have spent hours here but it was a hot day and we wore out too quickly. One suggestion might be t have an overall map of the Cemetery with some of the names of the more prominent (or interesting) crypts listed on it. We did not expect Eva Peron Duarte's crypt to be anything special, but the flowers adorning it and the notes tucked into the front of it truly impressed us. Eva certainly left her mark on Argentina and the world?
Beautiful. We went when it was close to sunset, and everything was beautiful. Take and evening off to spend atleast a couple of hours here.

Worth visiting, but do a little research beforehand. We enjoyed our visit to Recoleta Cemetery -- it is a very interesting piece of Argentina history, and very different from most other cemetaries you will ever visit. However, for people with limited knowledge of Buenos Aires or Argentina history, there is so many more stories here than just Eva Peron's burial site (which is pretty much where all visitors are headed once inside). We were fortunate enough to have a private guide with us who led us to some of the other, less known sites, but with very colorful and interesting stories. Was a great way to make the most of this very unique site. Just wandering in without having at least a little more historical context will result in just a very average experience versus something quite unique. This is a definite "must visit"...
Amazing. Amazing - beautiful architecture on a grand scale. Eva Peron's is certainly not one of the most impressive but that was no suprise.

Famous. I am not much for visiting cemeteries but this one is a land mark. It has statues of which you cannot imagine. Some mausoleums even have elevators, I was told by the tour guide! I guess you cannot go to Buenos Aires without visiting this one! At least that is what they say!
Interesting Historical Site. Unique cemetery with many historical Argentine figures buried here. Many ornate mausoleums with beautiful architecture. Many nearby cafe's for relaxing on a warm day.

Not just for Evita.... The cemetery is probably the most amazing place for outlandish architecture in the world. It is a definite must see. While Evita's grave site is not the most over the top, it is definitely worth a visit as is the rest of the cemetery. A trip to Buenos Aires would not be complete without stopping here!
Beautiful. Wandering through the cemetery is an excellent way to pass an afternoon - beautiful, haunting and historic.

Fab, must visit. This cemetery is everything one of our trip coordinators said it would be - a must visit place in BA. Its style contrasts with cemeteries in other locations, very grand. Of course everyone visits Eva's grave, however there is a lot in this place and encourage to walk around to see the rest. Unfortunately, english tours are tues and thursdays, so we were not able to take advantage of a tour, but worth planning around if you can do that

Definitely worth a visit. I didn't know much about the Cemetery beforehand and I was skeptical of how interesting any cemetery could really be but this one was pretty incredible. They really take their burial houses seriously and you will know I mean if you visit! Also, it wasn't too crowded and you can decide for yourself how much time you want to spend there wandering around.

Bit of a maze but really interesting.. I wandered here on foot on my own and like most people headed for the Duarte family crypt. It was really difficult to find but I'm glad I persevered. I found some of the other family monuments really interesting but would probably have enjoyed a guided tour more.

surreal and stunning. I didn't expect to be so enthralled by the Recoleta Cemetery. In fact, my husband and I explored it twice on the same day. Although most of the names on the mausoleums were unfamiliar to us (except for that of Evita!), the statues and diversity of architectural styles were fascinating in themselves. If you walk through the outer areas of the cemetery, you are likely to have the place to yourself, and you feel as though you are wandering through a city frozen in time. The guided tour in English, which we did not take but kept running into, sounded very thorough and interesting. If you are a photographer, this place provides an endless source of subjects - from monumental sculpture to decorative iron gratings. Go early in the morning (the cemetery opens at 7:30 am) or later in the afternoon so the sun isn't directly in your eyes when you try to take pictures. In any case, be sure to wear sunscreen and bring a hat. It can be very hot and bright when you get away from the central avenue with its beautiful trees.

Worth a look. If someone told me to "Take a stroll through the cemetery" whilst I was on holiday, I'd think they were insane but here I am suggesting that other tourists do just this. The cemetery is actually very beautiful and you could easily spend an hour strolling through the avenues of the 'city of the dead' marvelling at the final resting place of the extremely rich (and sometimes famous) people of BA.
Charming. This is a must see in Buenas Aires! Small and manageable. While the drawing card is Eva Perons Gravesite.. The whole cematary is full of architectural gems.

Tributes to past glory. This is one of the great cemeteries of the world, and a snapshot of Argentine's history. There are former Presidents, huge monuments to military leaders (reflecting Argentina's former idolization of their military), Evita Peron's grave (with plastic flowers) and an interesting display of how quickly the Italian immigrants gained positions of power and wealth. A good idea is to first go to Distral Libros near the entrance to the cemetery, order a coffee in their beautiful chandelier laden coffee shop and buy the book "City of Angels" which gives you the history of some of the more magnificent monuments. Then walk the cemetery, book in hand, to fully enjoy the experience.

Weird city feel. The cemetary lived up to the hype. It is beautifully maintained. The streets are paved and there are no weeds. It is possible to look into some of the tombs and see many coffins stacked on shelves. However, it is a happy and peaceful place and some of the tombs are works of art. As everyone does, we visited Eva Peron's tombs which has ornate doors which people had poked flowers into.Well worth a visit.
Something different!. Nothing like that in other cities, a must go to visit. Some graves buildings really are grand. I thought Evita's grave rather simple if compared with others.
Four Tourists. Visit a cemetrey is not something enjoyable for everybody, however Recoleta is a famous cemetery. The architecture is interesting and there is Evita´s place.

I am not one to wonder around with the dead.... But it is truly a beautiful cemetery.Evita is in one of the cripts, which I did not find.All the people at the front of the gate pronouncing to be guides are just trying to dig deep deep into your pockets. A good tour guide book and one hour will more than let you find what you are looking for...The ice cream parlour across the street is amazing and cheap.

Interesting place!. A cemetery, not the first option of what I want to see but hey it's actually quite interesting! I didn't other with a guide and researched it beforehand and found it rather good! Yep, this is where evita is buried but it has a lot more to offer besides that! Some of the sculpting is amazing and very vast!Open crypts with coffins on show was a bit odd mind haha!

Monument to Porteno egos.. This cemetery is like an ego trip for rich Porteno dignitaries. They have built miniature monuments to praise and show off the glory of their families and themselves in the after life. There is nothing humble about this place. It is interesting though to see who the movers and shakers of the day were and what there taste in architecture looked like.
Look at the past. Who can not visit this extraordinary cemetery with the grave of Eva Peron. Also the unbelievable grave stones certainly made me think again about personel vanity

The Most Beautiful Cemetary!. We enjoyed the broadway play Evita and the history Eva Peron and wanted to see her grave, we spent some time seeing other graves as well, very moving.A must see if you are in Buenos Aires!
A must see. This is the place Evita is buried, a vast collection of graves from people of every religion can be found here. Its free to get in, and you can take many hours to explore.
Fascinating. Very interesting don't just go to see Eva Perons grave. The different styles and sizes of the graces are facinating.

Argentina history at its finest. Besides the obvious visit to Evita Peron's grave, there is a host of other notable historical personalities buried there. Take a tour. Don't forget to visit the church there.
Wow! never thought a cemetery could be so interesting!. A must see - spend an hour or more walking and wondering about the families buried here... Quite a popular site with tourists.

More than Eva Peron. Whilst everyone heads to Evitas mausoleum there are many ex presidents and important figures within the cemetery gates. However a map of the important 'residents' would be of great use as it is a sprawling area and easy to get lost in.

Interesting Homes for the (Rich) Dead. Everyone seeks out Evita's site but there's plenty more to see here. The mausoleums are quite elaborate and an interesting place to walk. Watch out for hustling tour guides and be cautious if you are alone.

This place is a must see. A great experience for all ages - so much impression and history - definitely worth a visit. Evita Perons place was difficult to find but ask one of the friendly gardeners and they will direct you.
Fascinating. If you've never been to a Latin American cemetery before, this is a great place to wander about and marvel at the strangeness of it all.

Interesting, but get a guide for sure!. A very interesting place. It is fairly big, lots to see, but the best is if you get a guide to explain some of the major burial sites, and the history of the city and the people who are resting here. Many of the mausoleums have fallen into disrepair, but there is a story behind that reason too. Evitas tomb is here, the only one with permanent flowers, but again if you don;t have a tour book, or a guide, you might look for it for a long time, as it is very small and inconspicuous.

Take the tour. You will get so much more out of a guided tour. Anyone can find Evita's resting place but there is so much more history when you get the tour! Also, consider going to Chacarita Cemetery. I contains remains of many important people, including Juan Peron and the famous tango singer, Carlos Gardell (forgive me if I did not spell his name correctly. His statue is above his tomb and we saw locals putting a lit cigarette in the statues' hand. Apparently it was his trademark. The family mausoleums are magnificent. I discovered during my visit that my friend is also interred in Chacarita in the Vault of Gaselu. Why this place is a secret among tourists is a mystery as I found it far more interesting that Recoleta alone.

Fantastic!. Incredible mausoleums, like a miniature city with amazingly ornate and varied architecture and sculpture. I'm sure there's lots of history as well be we didn't have a guide or guidebook so we didn't get a lot of that. Well worth a visit!

One of the world's most amazing and beautiful cemeteries. This cemetery lived up to its "star billing" - as I'd been hearing raves about it over the years. It's much more compact than Pere Lachaise in Paris, so can be visited more quickly. The mausoleums of Buenos Aires' rich + famous are a riot of architectural styles, from Greek temples, to gothic to art nouveau. Eva Peron's is just one of many, tho the most visited.
Evita Peron. This is a very different type of cemetary. All masoleums. As expected the one for Evita is not much too look at. Stroll around and see some of the other famous ones.

A "must see". A city within a city. Nothing like this anywhere in the world. Do not miss it. Just be prepared to walk...and walk...and walk. We went on a very hot day and were worn out by the time we finished.

Linger in the nooks. This is such a great cemetery with an incredible story. Other than the obvious draw of Evita, there are lots of interesting anecdotes about different mausoleums. And there's such variety; some are in disrepair, some well maintained, some modern, some classic. It's a great place to stumble around at your own pace and, once you're done exploring on your own, get a guide to educate you on the finer details. Worth it. Lots of kitties around, too, which is fun.

Lots of history!. We lucked out and were able to get a free English speaking tour. The guide gave great information about the special people in the cemetery, including Eva Peron. The mausoleums were interesting. A must for tourists.

Don't miss it!. I didn't think a trip to visit a cemetery would be on the list of what I wanted to do in Buenos Aires, but our tour guide said we were going, so we went. What an interesting place! Pictures don't do this place justice, it has the feel of a miniature city, the mausoleums are like little houses on narrow streets. The differences between each mausoleum is interesting and the history is great. Our guide was helpful as she was able to point out some details that I'm sure we would have missed on our own.

incredible experience and big impact. We were surprised that a visit to the cemetery could be so.. cultural and interesting... so many well know names and such pieces of art... it is a walk in the past, and due respect to great people.. we surely RECOMMEND to visit it even if you stay only 1 day in Buenos aires.

Worth walking around!. This was an interesting spot in Recoleta. I would recommend going with a tour guide as I felt that we missed some cool things to see as we didn' know exactly what was important and what was not.

A Grand Monument to Argentine Greats!. If you're an Eva Duarte de Peron fan, this has to be on your "must see" list! You can actually visit the Duarte Family mausoleum hidden among the incredible variety of tombs in this walled city of the dead. While it may be a little difficult to track down amongst all the other incredible displays, just look for the crowds lining up to take photos in front of this national heroine's final resting place.However, be sure to leave time to wander around. There are some amazing works of art to be found here. Some of the tombs are really incredible and tell amazing stories. You'll find generals and presidents and doctors and mothers and daughters and sons along with some amazing trees!

Interesting. Very interesting cemetery. Not just because important people are buried there, but also for the amount of beautiful sculptures in the graves. Avoid going there between 11 and 15 in the summer.

Don't just go to Eva's grave!. We like visiting cemeteries and find them very interesting, and this really is one of the most beautiful we've been to. But, Eva Peron's grave is one of the most unimpressive, so get away from the crowds and you'll find some amazing tombs in the nooks and crannies of the cemetery.
Not your average cemetery!. Definitely worth a look. And it's free! Row after row of extravagant mausoleums. You've probably never see such a gathering of rich, dead people. Plus a few scrawny cats.
A bit of Confussion. Best to go on Weekend when all the stalls are opened outside selling everything possible. Evits's cript can be a zoo on weekends

Must See; Even If Only for 15 Minutes.... I've written over 130 reviews and believe in the power of feedback and take it seriously. I hope you find my review helpful.Even if you only spend 15 minutes here, you have to see it. Words, even pictures are hard to describe. It's like a city of miniture churches. Much bigger than a shed or a 1-car garage. This city of the dead with their opulent graves is over-the-top. It's like rich people that still wanted to show their wealth after they die. We spent 90 minutes there and I could have left after 15 minutes. Okay...lots of history...but once you see a few hundred of these live and in person, you get it. Obviously, the biggest attraction is Eva's tomb. There is a story at every corner and you could spend months there, I'm sure. See it, feel it, and move on.

Walking tour of Recoleta. Our guide met us at our condo and we taxied to the middle part of Recoleta. Had lovely weather for the 3 hr tour and ended at the cemetery. Jessica told us a lot of history and storys about the families in the tombs.

Need to go on a guided tour here. The cemetery was worth the trip, but most of the figures are from Argentinian history, so have limited appeal if, like me, you know very little about the history! Guided tours in English are offered, so I would go on one of those, to get the most out of it. Very atmospheric place, even in bright sunshine.

yes, you must see this cemetery. It was our first day, torrential rain, exhausted from flying all night, and still we had to walk around this extraordinary place. My husband said, Not a cemetery, a Necropolis. I say it's a sculpture garden spanning nearly 200 years of mausoleum styles. Breathtaking and unique.

Very unusual cemetery. Each family has it's own crypt, with a mausoleum. Many had stained glass windows and items such as photos and candlesticks, some had fresh flowers. Very sumptuous coffins could sometimes be seen at ground-floor level, and a peek of the narrow stairs going down to the crypt. A huge variety of architecture, and some beautiful bronze plaques commemorating the various family members. Sadly some buildings have fallen into disrepair as the family has died out or moved away. Some very plump cats around!
Alot of history crammed into one place. When you realize how many famous people are here, from all different aspects of Argentina's history, it's really interesting....a bit overwhelming though.

Beautiful cemetery. A very charming cemetery in the heart of Recoleta. A lot of story being told here. Beautiful monuments of some of Argentinas leaders and most important people during the time. Dont miss it.
kind of fun. got to visit eva, which was great. lots of little bitty catholic cathedrals, which is kind of weird. sort of a mini BA in terms of architecture and general falling apartness.

An unusually interesting attraction. I'm not one to seek out cemeteries on holiday, however this one is fascinating. The mausoleums are huge like mini churches one after the other. They are all in different condition, some pristine and some rusty and falling apart. You can actually peer into many and some are totally sealed.You must see the one for Eva Perron, easily found, just follow the crowd or ask one of the keepers. An oddly fascinating place.

Don't miss this place.. You cant be in BA without visiting Recolata, and any visit in Recolata must include the interesting and unique cemetery. Very nice mausoleums, decorated nicely and interesting colourfull stories.

Must See Cemetery. I never thought I'd be recommending a cemetery as a must see site--but really, you must see it. It's likely unlike anything you've seen before. It's more a small city for the dead with roadways lined with small buildings. The architecture is at times beautiful, aesthetic, morbid and sometimes crumbling and neglected. Stray cats wandering amongst the memorials just add to the atmosphere. It's more unique than morbid. Worth a pit stop en route.

Learn about Argentina's history. Good to go with a guide because they are able to tell you the history behind the tombs. It's huge. The tombs are so big it looks like a city from above. Worthwhile to see - very different from North America. We did it as part of a day tour of Buenos Aires.
Awesome Cemetary. The most incredible cemetary I have ever seen! Masoleums with the finest of sculptures. And od course you must visit the crypt where Evita lays in rest.
good to go with a guide. We booked a private guide and the first part of our tour was a visit to the cemetery. It wasn't what I was expecting but all the more enjoyable for that. recommend

Can feel the history. Everyone flocks to the tomb of Eva Peron but there are many other famous historical figures. The tombs vary but are quite elaborate. The only downside is that the "maps" to locate specific tombs are vague and not entirely accurate

Very interesting. Very interesting and definitely worth a visit but obviously quite dark. I also managed to lose my way a bit and wandering around the crypts not seeing anyone was a bit worrying for a while!

Feels weird to 'rate' a cemetery ... but this one deserves 5 stars!. We visited the Recoleta Cemetery as part of our day long tour of Buenos Aires ... it should not be missed as it is filled with so much history and beautiful architecture devoted to family mausoleums and other monuments. We were lucky to have our very own tour guide who showed the best way through the crowds (and were there crowds!) .. The draw here is the final resting place of Evita Peron ... but don't look for a Peron tomb, as she is buried in her family mousoleum .. Duarte. It is told that her family did not want her buried in the Peron tomb as she might be stolen ... so when she died, she was returned to her first family. We were told her tomb is the only one in the entire cemetery that has constant fresh flowers. There really is a pilgrimage to her tomb ... as she is still revered by many, many in this country. It is truly a beautiful cemetery ... interesting side note: lots of resident cats and as we were coming in, I noticed one woman leaving a bag of dry cat food with one of the attendants ... so they are well taken care of, too. Don't go to Buenos Aires without a visit to this beautiful special place. I would go again and spend hours. And take some cat food for the kitties!

Wow!. This place is full of history and the mausoleums are unlike anything I have ever seen before. It was absolutely incredible to see the artistic beauty of each one and to gaze at them and try to appreciate the enormous wealth that each family must have had to construct one!

Amazing architecture and sculpture right in the heart of Buenos Aires.. I have been to the world famous cemeteries in New Orleans and I can tell you that the Cemetery at Recolete is much better. We took a tour as part of a all day city tour and unfortunately it was cut short due to the rain on this day. If you like architecture, sculpture or history I suggest you take a guided tour here because the stories are amazing.

A beautiful place full of history. We were greeted by a multilingual guide at the gate who was most helpful. The cemetery is filled with history and beautiful artwork. If you visit during the summer, or in the heat of the day, bring water and perhaps a hat or umbrella. This isn't much shade.

Very Interesting. There is lots to see here including Evita's grave. Pick up a tour guide out front and enjoy! We liked the tour guide but we didn't like being hit up for a donation to a different cause just to enter.

Social History Melodrama. This is a neo-gothic experience with plenty of quirks and historic images, but only related to the upper class of Argentinian history. The worship of the dead is taken to the same extreme as the Montjuc Cemetery in Barcelona. I really appreciated Eva Peron's family tomb, the Duartes. It is modest compared to the fascist monsters that abound here, and is the only one adorned with flowers. The others are mostly in decay.
Huge art example. A must do, partly for the tomb of Evita, partly just to stroll around different art periods and styles.
Must Tour. It is absolutely huge. Filled with mausoleums. Suggest a guided tour as our guide made the tour very worthwhile far beyond just visiting the Tomb of Eva Peron.

Interesting!. Eva Peron's mausoleum is not the only reason to vist this cemetery. Very interesting mausoleums are everywhere for you to discovery. Well worth a visit. Also, next to the cemetery is a great market on the weekends.
Interesting. we went on a rainy, cloudy, gray day. perfect. it was almost empty because of the lousy weather but it added to its charm. evita peron and others are there.

Artistic and Inspiring. I went to Recoleta for the day, we went from Retiro Station as we were staying with a friend and walked to the Recoleta. The Cemetary had beautiful dramatic white painted stone walls as you walked in the floor tiles were beautiful and had some amazing patterns. If you are interested in History and art this place you will love. I am from Australia and the cemetaries here are not very interesting, Recoleta was the first cemetary I have been too which was beautiful and historical. You will notice that a lot of the persons who are buried there are from other countries than Argentina, I was surprised to see Egyptian styled morgues and greek morgues with the traditional greek letters around them. The only thing that annoyed me was that majority of the statues and angels were weeping over the place of buriel.But I am not going to discount that!It was also fascinating to see stray cats walking around the cemetary and most of them lying inside or around the morgues.A must see :)
EVA PERON. Worth a visit. Didn't like people trying to sell you maps to find the grave. Just follow the a groups of tourists and you'll be sure to find it.
Fascinating. I was a little reluctant to spent time in a cemetery; however, I was pleasantly surprised. This place is truly amazing and worth a trip to see it when in Buenos Aries.
