Interesting, but not Pere Lachaise. Unfairly I guess I was expecting a very large tree lined beautiful cemetery when I went to Recoleta. Architecturally it's interesting and historically it's certainly fascinating, but it's not a pretty place that you want to hang out like Pere Lachaise.
Good but Over-rated. Go in the morning to avoid the crowds. It's a peaceful island among all the buzz. A bit quaint, though I think over-rated.
Must-see in Buenos Aires. Very cool cementary in the Recoleta barrio. Extremely big and has tons of interesting graves, including that of Eva Perón. Go with a guide to hear lots of cool stories.

Out of ordinary promenade... worth a look. All welthy argentinian families from XIX and early XX centuries have their graves and Pantheons in here. You will see a good sample of mortuary sculptures and some creepy tombs and gravestones.

recoleta. A must see in Buenos Aires. It would be hard to find Evita's crypt if you did not go with a guide, but i was part of a free walking tour that my hostel organized. If anything, just try to tag along to a tour group... hehehe. They have a great handcrafts market on Saturday. So if you are there on Saturday I would recommend it! I picked up great jewelry made from authentic metals (bronze, copper, silver) for a great price.
Weird. You can actually see the coffins. Its really awkward and uncomfortable. There are a lot of nice sculptures in other - nicer- places in BsAs.

A must stop. The cemetery is well maintained and an interesting walk. Every street has notable people buried there. While most come to pay homage to Eva Peron, we were here on a rainy day. We basically had the cemetery to ourselves and were able to get up close and personal with Evita.... Even did our own rendition of "Don't cry for me, Argentina"!

Beautiful. It's a beautiful place and not creepy whatsoever. In fact I found it quite peaceful strolling around (as long as you avoid big tour groups). Lots of interesting sculptures to look at. Definitely worth a visit.

Buried in style. I'm normally not one to trek to cemeteries but this one is not to be missed. Clearly Eva Peron's mausoleum is the draw but there are other notables here as well. Great photo opportunities down every avenue, and some of the crypts are more well maintained than others, we weren't there when there was a tour but you can do it on your own,
Highlight. Great free tour in English. Check the schedule and do not miss. I've visited cemeteries all over the world. This is as cool as any.

Very cool. Evita's tomb was a bit disappointing compared to the rest but the cemetery overall was very cool. Reminded me of Paris. We were there on a beautiful sunny day and spent over an hour just wandering about.

Take the tour PLEASE. The Recoleta Cemetery gives all tourists a FREE tour in English and other languages. I took the English tour on Tuesday at 11:00am. I believe that this English tour is free on Tues and Thurs at 11:00am BUT pls check with them. The tour was so wonderful because, they direct you to the specially interesting cemetery plots and give good stories of the reason the architecture is a certain way or the grandeur of a plot. If you wander by yourself, you are guaranteed to get lost. There at least three Presidents buried there and the guide gives you a decent explanation of their time as President and what they contributed to the nation. Of course, everyone wants to visit the tomb of Evita Peron. It is a simple memorial but everyone wants to take a photo there. The tour lasts for over an hour and it is perfect time to break for lunch following this tour and the many places nearby. Please try the Melanesa dish in Buenos Aires - a good specialty.

Falling into Disrepair. I was here 12 years ago. Many of the tombs are falling into disrepair, likely because of the economy and cost to maintain them. The main one of interest is still the one of the DUARTE FAMILY, which houses the remains of EVA PERON ( EVITA -"Don't Cry for Me Argentina" Andrew Lloyd Webber Musical fame)and tour groups crowd this area in a never ending parade. On Saturday there is a Flea Market next to the Cemetery.

Interesting History. Fascinating piece of history and a must stop in BA. In retrospect wish we hired a guide to take us through the cemetary. When we left we realized there were guides to hire...don't know the cost but would have made it more valuable. Guide or no guide a must do in BA

Particular cemetary. Most famous and rich people were buried there during 19 th century, it will give you an idea of rich people in B A at that time. Very little about spirit in the funeral writings, just what they were : owner of this, President of that and so on. Very few words like love, beloved, regrets ... Some nice sculptures.SPEND AN HOUR NO MORE, SEE Eva Peron tomb on the tomb list you will find it no 88 under DUARTE her name, her tomb a bit difficult to find , go first to see it, and you will see the others tombs while looking for Eva' tomb

Prime real estate for the dead....strangely beautiful. Great place for photography, especially black and white ones. But seeing throngs of tourists in a burial place just didnt seem right.... Somewhat voyeuristic. I went out of curiosity and for what its worth, thought it was strangely beautiful. Evita Peron, if you're interested, is in the Duarte Familia tomb located to the left of the cemetary upon entry. Far less spectacular than many other tombs there, I personally think that it is more appropriate- these places of rest are afterall for the dead! Not to judge, but the expense of building and maintaining these tombs may be better spent on the many beggars stationed outside the grounds. I'd recommend only a short visit, if at all. There are enough other things going on around the area to make the trip there worth your while - the flea market (weekends only), church, Design Buenos Aires, Hard Rock Cafe, museums, shops, etc.
Wow. Interesting or what?. Blown away by the size of this. Extremely interesting too. You need to buy a map from a guide outside for 20 pesos if you want o head straight to Evita vault.

A must see when in BA. If you need a break from the intensity of Buenos Aires, step into the Recoleta cemetery and wander around the collection of who's who in Argentine social structure. Though it is a bit hard to find, don't miss the surprisingly small and modest mausoleum of Evita.

History Lovers. If you love history and genealogy, you would love this place. The guide was very informative and with a fantastic sense of humor. the Mausoleums were impressive. They even have the Eva Peron family mausoleum. It is free of cost. Great place to visit.
Interesting sights. Fun to see, but not more than 30 or 45 minutes worth really. Evita is the only person I knew there, but the ornate monuments were fun to see.
Hours of enjoyment. I know it sounds weird but fun in a graveyard? Get the map from the volunteer at the gate for 10 pesos.

We did not think we would enjoy this - wrong!. Spent a few days in BA, one with a guide, German Landau, who took us to the cemetery. We were not looking forward to it, but it was close to our hotel so we went. This is an amazing place, and having a guide who knew so much more about who was buried here and all the stories just made it so much better. We would recommend this even if you think you won't like it, but if you can get a guide who knows all the little stories it will be very memorable. The true story of the picture of the young girl standing outside of her tomb is especially poignant and very sad, Also, look at the orb on Evita's tomb, this was for real and not visible when taking the pic.

Sunday afternoon ...... Very Different. Grab a Cab - 30 Peso's gets you there and its free in, dont worry about a big organized trip, and you'll find Evita's grave no bother, just follow the crowds. Its a strange place, but worth seeing and strolling thorugh for a few hours - and the strange thing is the family have to pay rent on the tombs, stop paying the rent and the body gets booted out - welcome to BA

What hasn't already been said and written about Recoleta Cemetery?. This is probably the one thing in Buenos Aires that you must do, if you do nothing else. Plan to spend some time here; it's worth several hours. Wander into the chapel next to the cemetery, too. If you're lucky, like we were, you might get to watch or participate in a mass, complete with singing, guitar-playing school girls from the nearby Catholic school. Breathtaking.

possible to spend half a day here. Besides, of course, Evita's tomb, the stories of the families buried there are captivating. It was part of a tour for us, but years earlier we wandered around clueless, found E's tomb and left none the wiser. Strongly recommend either homework with a good guidebook or a hotel recommended guide.

Incredible tombs but not our thing. No one can argue that the amount of money invested in the monuments is incredible and some of the architecture is amazing, but strolling through a cemetery looking at coffins and monuments of people you don't know wasn't very interesting to us.

Fascinating visit . Not even the subway strike could stop us visiting Evita's last resting place.The cemetery is in need of some restoration, but we could see that they are collecting donations to put this into action. Perhaps a small entrance fee would help them do the same thing, especially as millions of people must visit here. Walking round the family tombs of so many famous and important Argentinians, really makes me want to look into Argentinian history more. All in all, a very interesting visit.
A must see. Be sure to find the spot for Eva Peron- but it's not easy. Plan on spending about 2 hours here. Be sure to check out all of the interesting architecture.
Historic Cemetery in heart of Recoleta District. Not something I would normally recommend, but if you have ever been to New Orleans then you'll understand. Just visit you'll be amazed.

Best cemetery I've been to!. Our first day in Buenos Aires was cold and rainy so we thought it would be good to go to the Cemeterio. The dark weather added a eery vibe to our trip which was kinda cool.My wife and I wandered around the alleys and little paths of the Cemeterio amazed at the grandiosity of the tombs. We got lost trying to find Evita's grave but that was half the fun as each turn offered something different. The bad weather turned a lot of people away so we pretty much had the place to ourselves. Some people we met later on did a free English language tour and said it added extra context to the visit so perhaps that sounded worthwhile. A great place to kill at least a few hours in BA!

All this to see Evita's tomb. I was disappointed by all the hype around this cemetery. While it is a beautiful place due to all the architecture and the different types of crypts, unless you know something of the families, it is just looking at crypts (if I am using the correct term). Evita's tomb was somewhat disappointing after all the hype about this woman in the city. To top it off there was at our group standing directly in front of it with the man speaking in Spanish and going on for far too long to allow other tourists to see. There's is only about the width of 10 feet between opposing crypts. It was clostraphobic and I got out of there as soon as possible. I had more fun looking at all the vendors and artisans that setup outside the cemetery.

No Ordinary Cemetery. Me and my friends came here and we didn't really know what to expect, and we were also a little hungover so we weren't necessarily going to be easily impressed. Yet this cemetery and its grand scale and beautiful designs were just amazing. We had an amazing time, and also had fun walking through the place.For younger adults and teens its not typically something you would think of visiting, but it is definately worth it. It is also so culturally different and interesting from anything in Australia (well Melbourne anyway!)

The rich and famous. An amazing bit of realestate for the wealthy and famous of BA. Although Eva Peron, probably recognized by the world as Argentina's most notable citizen is buried in a very simple, humble plot.

A City Within A City. Never thought visiting a cemetary could be so interesting. Each plot is a monument and condo. Truly set up like streets and buildings. Take a tour to learn about the history of individuals and BsAs. We visited on a day without a free tour in English. Rather than return another day, we "hired" an excellent guide named Patricia and got a private tour. She is officially a volunteer, but makes a living off your tips. Well worth it, and don't forget to tip generously. Reach her at info@cotytours.com.ar.

Bueno Recoleta. Way more that Eva Peron's tomb... just photographing the 'doors' of the mausoleums was worth the trip.... What a special collage. A bit 'creepy' for the kids.. (what cemetery is not creepy for the kids)... Way cool for all the adults...

I find this place both fascinating and peaceful. This is really worth a visit. Today was the third time I have been there - but the first time I went on a guided tour. I highly recommend that. It was free, in English, and I learned a great deal from it. For instance, I did not know that the tombs were purchased for eternity, and that generations of people are buried within. A "medium sized" crypt can hold up to 18 coffins, and when they get full - the choices for the family are either to seal them forever - or - more commonly, they take the oldest caskets/remains, cremate them, put them in small urns/boxes in the vault to make room for the newly dead. If you look inside those with windows you can see the caskets stacked on shelves - and small boxes that contain cremains, or small caskets of children. Also interesting is that they are often two below ground crypts, the first at 15 meters deep and the second at 5 meters. You can see the steps inside of the tombs that lead down to them. They fill up the bottom one first, then move to the next level, and some tombs also have above ground shelves where you can see additional caskets stacked. The tour guide said that some are pretty tough to get caskets down into - they use a series of ropes and pulleys to lower them (upright) down into the lower crypts. Families hold the key to the tomb, and come and visit inside. They can walk down the steps to the lower crypts to place flowers or memorials. Claustrophobia city down there - I bet.It is sad to see that some have fallen into disrepair, but the guide said that sometimes families die out, and there is no one to pay for the upkeep. While there we saw keepers inside of tombs, dusting, polishing, painting, plastering the tombs that have paying families. In the case of the falling apart tombs - because they are private property, the government cannot take them over. There is no rule that allows the government to do that in BA. The only thing they will do is put up scaffolding or caution tape to keep people away from falling tombs. Interestingly, families who are still around but don't care about the upkeep or who have lost their genealogy are missing out on a gold mine. According to the guide, if the tomb "account" is in arrears, a family member who can claim lineage can pay up the account, clear out the caskets (cremate them), then sell the crypt to someone else for a fortune. "New" families come in and rebuild the crypts. Argentinians should tap into Ancestry.com! Maybe your great-great-great-great-great grandparents are there, holding on to your inheritance!Anyway, a good, safe walk that is very interesting. Take a tour, learn about the place and the history, then hit one of the cafes nearby afterward to rest your feet and have a coffee or cold drink. This is not to be missed - and really it is NOT morbid, it is a fascinating history lesson.

One of a kind. I have never seen a cemetery quite as intricate. It was fascinating walking around. Definitely recommend a tour though, we skipped it but I heard a guide and found out relative's of Che are located there as well.

Great architecture. From romanesque to art nouveau, these tombs are well worth a visit...truly a Necropolis, a city of the dead and not at all macabre. Evita's tomb is surprisingly modest although her family was very wealthy. Get the guide and enjoy! Especially early in the morning. It opens at 7:00 am!!

Interesting cemetery where Evita was buried. The cemetery itself is interesting with lots of very large tombs. But the main reason everyone goes is to see Evita's tomb. An interesting visit in the lovely neighbourhood of Recoleta which is worth visiting even if you don't like cemeteries.
Gorgeous!. This was a beautiful cemetery, the statues and mausoleums were breathtaking. Worth a couple hrs of your time - don't miss it!
A must see. A very eclectic cemetary with of course, Eva Peron's grave. Others were interesting and the sculptures invited lots of photos.
Love this place. So cool. Could spend hours here. Architecture from so many different eras. Super over the top and awesomely creepy. Like the upstairs of the Paris Catacombes.
Worth a Visit. IT is worth a visit just for the amazing bronze work and architecture on the tombs.......i find the area very touristy

Great for a walk back in history. Good for a morning walk around. Near a nice park and good food. When I was here there were little handy craft markets in the park area, not sure if they are there all te time or if they were here because Argentina had a public holiday.

A must-see place if you're visiting Buenos Aires. The tomb of Eva Peron = Evita, in the Duarte family tomb is a must-see attraction in BA. The cemetery is also highly atmospheric and a fantastic insight into the great and the good of Old Buenos Aires. Try to come early to avoid the crowds - the alleys through the cemetery get very busy as everyone does come here. Check out the instructions to find Eva's tomb online - its not tht straightforward to find her - unless you come during a busy time, in which case jut follow the crowds.
Outdoor museum!. It's "Must visit" place because it's like a outdoor museum - history of Buenos-Aires, traditions - very interesting! Entrance was free.

Its more than Evita. Our perception before visiting the cemetery was that Evita's tomb was the main attraction.However, there are many other tombs with historical background that should be seen. One could use a map and try to locate them, but the best way is to use a guide, not only to locate the tombs but to learn about the fascinating background of many of the people. We used Buenos Tours and the cemetery tour was part of the half day Recoleta Tour.There are many stories and much history in this place which should be part of any Buenos Aires visit.

Historical Visit. Very interestng how they remember their deceased, from the past. Yes mainly the prominent citizens of importance, but what a maze of tombstones and marble burial places, like houses.A bit scary but an insightful visit.
Worth half an hour. Over the top Latino tombs and the grave of Evita make this worth the stop. Great sculptures as well.
Been there done that. "Had" to go for the tourist thing. After walking around for a couple of minutes and looking at evitas grave there is nothing else to do.Been there done that
Interesting. You can learn some history there. A lot of important people in the Argentina history were burried there, such as Evita Peron. Its huge, buts not necessary to walk it entirely. Very good.

Don't miss this. I thought it odd that a cemetery is such a big attraction but if you like history, architecture, or hobnobbing with the elite (er, sort of) this is a must-see. This is where the Argentinian elite are put to rest and I think the mantra of the place is "go big or go home." We walked around without a tour, as we were more interested in the architecture and experience. But there are tour guides available and it might be worth it as so many of the elite are buried here. I suspect their resumes alone would give you a rich history for the last 250 years. Definitely worth the trip

Must-do in BA. Excellent historical site - such variety of mausoleums - quite the experience. There was a bit of a crowd around Evita's tomb, so I skipped that part, but there was plenty to see. If you go down the little side alleys you can even escape the crowds...
A different tour. We were lucky to follow a special guide , who deeply knew the history of the characters buried there. Architecture and history in an unusual place.

Grand ornate tombstones. Great to have visited the large ornate tombstones of many famous people. Buy a guide leaflet only if you are really interested to have a keepsake, otherwise you can just walk around at your leisure and see for yourself.
Photographers Dream. If you like to take photos the cemetery presents many opportunities for drama and beauty. The older sites along the edges are filled with cobwebs and coffins. Watch for ghosts!
A must see while in BA.. Beautiful, peaceful, interesting and unlike any other cemetry I have visited. A true 'must see' for all visitors to the city.

English tour. English tour is on Tuesday and Thursday at 11 am
It is free, but please tip your guide.
The tour is about one hour and a half
and should be included in your schedule
while in Buenos Aires

Total Must-See!!!. Words cannot describe the Recoleta Cemetery. It is an absolute must see if you are visiting Buenos Aires. We we captivated by the amazing architecture and could not believe how much time we spent in awe of the grave sites. Please visit this place if you have time and have never been.
Atmospheric. Enjoyed walking round the cemetary although did not expect it to be so small in comparison to Pere Lachaise in Paris.
cemetary. A must see architectual wonder. very interesting. use Check-out Buenos Aries.com for a guided tour ! Have your picture taken at Evitsa's grave

A must. The elegance!~well designed, clean and amazing to see how much effort we place sometimes on the memories of the dead!~a good idea!~to go on a Sunday morning and after it go to the market, just outside!~a great day and lunch at Ricoleta Restaurant!~

A Gated Community for Dead People. We aren't Ann Rice fans but we do enjoy a good cemetery here and there. This cemetery is filled with very elaborate mausoleums and tombs living people would love to live in, let alone the wealthy, deceased families of Buenos Aries. Truly, this makes for an interesting insight into Argentina's history and culture. Its easy to find Evita....just follow the crowds.

Would make my list of 5 things to do. You haven't seen anything like this! Minature city displaying the wealth of the past and present. Impressive modern and ancient crypts with amazing stories behind many of them. Went twice, took husband back and he was SO glad he visited. Impressive and easy to wonder through. Allow at least 45 minutes. See Eva Peron's tomb amongst many others.

A step back in time. What a beautiful cemetery. I would definitely recommend a visit. You won't see many cemetery's like this anymore.It was interesting to read the inscriptions on the edifices.The cemetery told a story of a time and place that is long ago.

Very interesting from a historical and architectural standpoint.. I'm not much for history, but just walking through this cemetery is a visual treat, and interesting time, no matter what depth of interest you have. Worth a stop.

Interesting. Not the normal place to spend an afternoon, but very different , interesting to see how different cultures bury their dead. Finding where Evita was laid to rest was a bit of an adventure, very low key compared with others old and new.

Interesting. Just the thought of visiitng a cementery may give you the creeps, but La Recoleta is more like a museum. It was well worth going there. You think you can only see there the Evita tomb, but there is alot more.DO GO with tour guide, he will explain you all about it and he will share some of the legends too. Very funny guy.

Best Homage to the Dead You'll Ever See. Let's be honest: strolling through a neighborhood of countless homes housing dead bodies may not be everyone's idea of a good time, but the Cemetery is more than that: it's a massive collection of aged sculptures and buildings unlike any other. Sure, you're meant to be sad and perhaps experience a bit of fear about your own mortality, but these wealthy departed spent a great deal of money to show you how fantastic they were and you could at least entertain their vanity. Do it for them!Seriously, though, it's beautiful. I could spend hours in here looking at all the statues and the buildings and you should, too. Keep a lookout for the cats that live there - they're quite the characters.

Impressive Designs and Different. Having been to above ground cemetaries in Lousiana, Recoleta is very different. It is somewhat of a competition as to the designs. Families go all out and the structures are big enough with a basement to include all generations of family. A visit here should not be missed. Be sure to see Evita, but ensure you get a guide who can take you to some of hte most interesting monuments in the cemetary and provide you the background stories. It would not have been the same without the help of our guide.

Eva Peron Mausoleum. Fascinating place, so many mausoleum. A bit like a maze! Eva Peron's one is worth seeing although very crowded in. There were others that were much more ornate. You could look through the doors into little shrines and often see the caskets. I've never seen anything like it anywhere else.
Most unusuall cemetry I ever seen. Very unusuall place. Better take a guided tour because a lot of the history around this place so the story about it is very interesting.

WOW!. What an incredible experience! The cemetery was breathtaking and seeing the old structures was really neat! At first it was a bit eerie for me, but then I really enjoyed seeing all the mausoleums.

Better than Pere La Chaise. A must see in B.A. Streets of mausoleums that look like townhouses, wonderful art & ornament, marble & wood. It is a history of Buenos Aires, via the famous families. Evita is there as well.

History & Diversity in one!. The scale, size, history and diversity of the monuments make this an interesting excursion. Entrance is free. Skip the people outside the gates trying to get money, they aren't legitimate. Inside there are people selling maps, I found the map worth the money. The cemetery is quite large with many "streets" and would be easy to get lost or miss out on the "famous" burial sites.

Beautiful Mausoleums, interesting viewing. We spent about 2 hours visiting the cemetery, beautiful mausoleums, saw Evita Perron's final resting place (Duarte) , some mausoleums are incredibly opulent, some of the old ones are in a poor but incredibly fascinating.
Resting place of Evita. Her tomb is dwarfed by mausoleums of such size, grandeur and, in places, vulgarity. A stroll in this wired and wonderful place is a must for all visitors to Buenos Aires!
not what was expected. Everyone talks about Evita's grave...It wasnt that serious at all. Nothing about it stood out. It appeared to be a regular grave. We could not even found it

How can a cemetery be so interesting?. I was actually surprised that this was one of the sites I preferred in Buenes Aires. It feels like a city within a city and is very touching in its tribute to people who made this city.

Un Jardin de las Piedras. One of the great Stone Gardens of the world, this city cemetery is now nearing its 200th year and houses the notables of Argentine society, one of whom - Eva Peron - garners most of the present day tourist attention. Take a guided tour offered by a local: these are Portenos looking to augment income and - in my experience - give more in the way of information than they are "typically" recompensed by their tourist clientele. The layout of the cemetery is like to a village, the side streets offering just enough clearence for foot trafic alone, wherein each of the masoleums is a small or larger dwelling housing its inhabitants mortal remains. My favorite casita is that of Lois Angel Fripo, the heavyweight known as El Toro Salvaje de las Pampas ( The Wild bull of the Pampas ) who in 1923 - though knocked to the canvas seven times in the first round - recovered to knock Jack Dempsey from the ring before secumbing to "The Manassa Mauler" in a 2nd round knockout. Take that Eva! Have your picture taken in muscular pose with his imposing stone figure. And once you've taken in Recoleta Cemetery, I highly recommend a trip To La Chacarita Cemetery in Bario Chacarita. Here is a magnificent city of stone with broad avenues and also the resting place of one of the truly great luminaries of Argentine society: Carlos Gardel! Have your picture taken in a Tango pose in front of his statue, and, if so inclined as many Argentines, place a cigarette between his fingers.

It's beautiful, however nothing special. Ok, has the Evita's place and the architecture its amazing, but just this. Do not expend more than one hour in this visitation. But is typical and you can get good pictures. Be careful with floor, veto accidentally in some parts. Recommended it!
Second time and still amazing. Just love to see. Saw some I missed my last trip, there is so much to see. May take years to see all. A must see

Wow, this is some final resting place!. I was absolutely blown away by this place, and went back twice. I took so many photos I felt like a ghoul, but the tombstones were unbelievable. Apparently you can buy a plot, recycle one that no longer has any relatives to visit, for a mere $US 500,000! Stunningly beautiful crypts! I would definitely recommend visiting here.
wish we'd had more time. A giant maze of stained glass, statues and mausoleum. Everyone rushed to Evita's but there is so much more to see - like a giant history lesson. Not to be missed
Take your camera. This cemetery is photographer heaven. From the beautiful statues to the mangy cats, I snapped more than I have for years.

If you like cemeteries.... Buenos Aires doesn't have many cultural centers or attractions so if you are looking for something to do, the cematary is worth a visit. It is in a nice location and is well kept. As far as cemeteries go, this was one of the nicest that I have visited.
Fascinating area. Free tours (work for tips) is a wonderful, informative way to see the Cemetery and the Recoleta area

Cemetery.... I think it is overrated as a tourist attraction ... some as a cemetery is beautiful, but it is a cemetery. That is very much worth having a ride in the market that's in front all weekend!

A unique experience. Of course everyone visits the cemetery to view Evita's tomb, if you can find it. A guide showed us the tomb during our last visit, this time we attempted to find it on our own. We were not successful. We however we enjoyed wondering along the labyrinth of elaborate tombs lining the narrow passage ways within the cemetery more than seeing Evita's tomb.

Unique. It is beyond my powers to discribe, you have to see this facinating and huge collection of hundreds of small buildings for the diseased remains of the old controlling families of Argentina. Down rows without identification you willingly get lost in this maise - another world, another era of their history.
This is worth seeing. At first I thought, 'How Bizarre' but it turned out to be fascinating. We spent hours there. Well worth the visit.

What a surprise!. Well it is the first time that we visit a cemetery and it was worth it. You could spend an afternoon there just looking around. It was interesting to see Eva Peron's resting place. Recoleta is a very nice walking area of Buenos Aires. Nice park La Plaza Francia and lots of very nice cafés like La Biela next to the park.

amazing. This is like nothing you have ever seen. It's a labryinth ofmausoleums in a huge variety of styles. Art deco, art nouveau, modernist, it's a crazy patchwork that during the day is intriguing to see. Would be scared to death wondering around in the dark though...

Beautiful! Odd considering it's a cemetery. Great place to take pictures and explore! Very interesting cemetery - It's like a little city. I would recommend reading about it or taking a tour. Make sure to Eva Peron's resting place.

A Must see. The thought of a cementary creeps me out, but this is a must see. This is not your traditional cementary in the states. Even if you spend 10 minutes, it is worth it. We spent about 3 hours walking around looking at the different statues, which some looking like mini houses and churches.

A quiet place in the middle of a big dity. An amazingly beautifull place top go and take a break fro mthe hsutle and buzzle of the city. Visit E Perons grave and pay respect to one of the most important person in the history of Argentina.

Tour a cemetery? Definitely YES!. Generally, cemeteries are not a tourist outing. La Recoleta Cemetery is different, though.A cemetery of the rich classes (in Spanish known as Familias Patricias), with a European feel, very different from all cemeteries. Impressive. Some tombs look like palaces, temples or mansions. Entry is free. You can either buy a map with the cemetery’s history and the description of selected grave sites to help support the restoration society to preserve this historical treasure or take a guided tour.It may sound weird to say that one enjoys a cemetery, but La Recoleta is not only a graveyard. It is much more than that: it is an open door museum, a History lesson, an Art lesson, a Cemetery-Museum, where you will feel no creepiness. Quite on the contrary, you can get a perspective of time and experience a living piece of history.The scale and grandeur of the mausoleums and tombs vary. The cemetery is a showcase of architectural styles. You can take a peek through the windows or doors of some mausoleums. If you dare do so, the reward will be beautiful stained glass windows, among other surprises (Rosas’ coffin wrapped in an Argentinian Flag, for example!). The alleys between the graves are like a labyrinth so you can easily get lost. However, the place is always full of people so you can get help if needed.The main attraction and the big draw is the last resting place of Evita Peron. There are many other more interesting tombs, though. Take a look at some of the Argentinian Presidents’ tombs (Marcelo T. de Alvear, Illia, Roca, Alfonsín, Mitre, Sarmiento, Yrigoyen), San Martin’s parents and wife are also buried there (San Martin is our National Hero). Many famous writers are buried here too: José Hernández (famous by his book Martín Fierro), Paul Groussac, Adolfo Bioy Casares, among many others. Alberdi (the writer of our Constitution), and many, many other renown personalities. Even the most amateur of photographers will be delighted by the cemetery’s unique & gorgeous architecture. Still in use today, it will sure be an open mouth experience. Although it is not a lighthearted adventure you will simply get a feeling of opulence of the upper class in Bs. As. Take time to look up, down, and from different angles to really enjoy the beauty and majesty of the place. Take one thing for sure: you could visit La Recoleta Cemetery many times and always see something you didn't see before. Even if cemeteries don’t ring a bell on you or you are not into cemeteries, don’t miss it. It will be time spent worthwhile.

A Must See in BA. This sounds like an odd sight to see, however definately do not pass this up! This is a beautiful cemetary with many ornate gravestones, including Evita's. Excellent photo opportunities and the entire experience is free!

Feeling of a Bygone Era. This cemetery has a very European feel. Try to go in fine weather to linger and fully appreciate the ambience of an extraordinary resting place in the heart of Recoleta. Don't miss the Eva Peron mausoleum.
impressive. Impressive and creepy at the same time. Architecturally, it was very interesting. Not much else to say.
As described earlier. Entry is free. Buy a map with its history and the the description of selected grave sites in support of the restoration society to preserve this historical treasure.

Amazing, different - must see. it is definitely worth spending an hour at this place. very different from all cemeteries I have seen. Both impressive and freaky! Amazing buildings, some looking like little palaces or temples, others are very old and half broken, which gives you perspective of time. There are cats walking around and living there - adds a bit of a mystery to the place!

A most while in Buenos Aires. A cemetery is one of those places that does not ring a bell on me, but this is different.Its amazing all the mausoleums, monuments and money spent on the last place of rest of those beloved.You will not feel any creepiness.

An interesting and some what creepy wander around. The entrance is free and you can roam around as you please. We had a good time just wandering around looking at the amazing sculptures and trying to find the oldest tombs. Some date back to the 1700s. It's a sometimes spooky but beautiful experience. Don't miss it if you're in BA.
Evita's Tomb. The cemetary is an architectural mishmash of tombs and mausoleums. It is worth the visit to see where Evita was buried

Most creepy place in BA. Being Swedish and not used to cemeteries like this one, it was an experience like no other! It was both interesting and extremely bizarre seing the big monuments of the dead, often with the coffins visible. Evita Peron's grave was ofcourse the most visited, although it was not that much to see in comparison with some of the other graves.

Yet another city of Angels. The place is worth visit from many perspectives: historical, architectural, general curiosity, taking step back in to the past... There are many ways to explore: have stamina take a 3 h history tour, or photo tour, or just use a map provided and jump from one celebrity resting place to another, or take a sit at one of the stone benches scattered around and think about ....Tips:get another view at the Cemetery from the 3rd and 4th floor of the mall located next to the Cemetery. Use entrance at the corner Of Vincente Lopez and Uriburu.
Really interesting. A must visit. Not really morbid,,,it is a cemetery. But I would recommend. Some nice cafe's across from main gate.

Fascinating walk and experience. Definitely a great stop on your BA itinerary to experience history and grab some great photos. The Eva Duarte Peron (Duarte Family) tomb is a humbling experience once you locate it

Loved it!. I love statuary and this place is full of beautiful ones. I feel like you could visit many times and always see something you didn't see before. I wished we could have gone back another day when the light was right so we could have gotten better photos. I found an angel monument that is a replica of a statue that I bought a framed, hand-colored photo of at an arts fair here in Columbus. The original statue is in a cemetery in France, so I understand, and the statue there has glass eyes, which makes you feel like it's actually watching you. Creepy, but in a good way. The cemetery has a colony of cats living in it- we were lucky enough to see several of them- one jumping from top to top of a couple of the monuments! We took some cat food to donate to the woman who feeds the cats, which we were told she has been doing for many years. You can tour the grounds for free or hire a guide at the entrance for a small fee if you want more details or to perhaps help you find Eva Peron's burial site. A hauntingly beautiful place.

pure relaxation. It is the most beautiful cemetery I have ever seen, and I know it sounds weird when one enjoys a cemetery :). It is so much more than that - it is a history lesson, an art lesson, and a peaceful place to stroll and enjoy even few hours just relaxing.

It is quite amazing. You walk through the gates into the cemetary and get this sense of a village in a strange kind of way. It is amazing to absorb first off and then becomes fascinating as you go through. A range of notable people and families resting here. It is well worth the visit.

Wild!!!. Off the charts, open mouth experience cemetery in the heart of Recoleta. All of the rich and famous and military war heroes and former Presidents are buried in Mansion style crypts. Eva Peron is here too. Amazing place to tour.
Fascinating and historical. Still in use today, always good to experience a living piece of history. Spectacular sculptures, clear maps and very helpful guide who spoke extremely good English.

Slightly Sinister. Strolling among the marble mausoleums of Argentina's rich and famous is a great way to spend an afternoon. Or an entire day if you are truly morbid.And if you want to know where Evita is planted -- deep under concrete and steel to prevent her body from disappearing yet again -- look for the biggest crowd.Some people say the tour in English and/or Spanish is worthwhile. I had more fun doing it on my own.

Very unique. While it sounds odd to tour a cemetery, this place is more like an outdoor museum. The above ground graves are artistically done and unique. I went with a tour guide which is what i recommend because there are many stories about the various people and families here that I wouldn't have known. If you go on a saturday there is an outdoor arts and crafts market out side of here that is very cool.
What a cool place . This cemetery is definitely worth the visit. It's very beautiful. They do free tours in English and Spanish. I forget the times however.

Fascinating Place to Visit. Well worth wandering round for a few hours - no need for an official tour - just buy a map ( good souvenir ) as you enter showing the location of the various graves . Eerie but very interesting .

Beautiful architecture & tranquil environment. My husband and I wandered around for a few hours one afternoon. The tombs really tell their own stories. We didn't take a guided tour because we just enjoyed the feel of the place. We stopped by briefly on a Saturday, and I will tell you during the week is much more serene. Some of the most amazing pictures I took in Buenos Aires were taken at the cemetery. You simply get a feeling of the magnitude of history in this place. While it isn't a lighthearted adventure, it is stunning.
hey! dont even think about missing this one!. I just loved it!Went by myself, no tour. Got the map and started my journey...Beautiful! Great experience!

Best graveyard I've ever been too!. The scale and grandeur of many of the mausoleums and tombs was amazing. Evitas resting place was very unassuming and tricky to find so keep your eyes open for the one with lots of flowers and a larger crowd standing around. Was eerie but fascinating to visit!

Great place to visit. We have been to the cemetery on many occations, well worth the Visit. We enjoy visiting with the cats that live there and looking at the Graves. On weekends there is a giant crafts market next to the cemetery which is a must see.

Loved wandering around. This is definitely not to be missed. We went twice, once alone to wander and once for the tour in English on Tuesday at 11 (it is on Thursday too). The tour was less than expected. It was large, the guide difficult to understand and soft spoken which with the size of the group made it very hard to hear and since she spoke with such a thick accent I was already straining for comprehension. Regardless, I would recommend the tour as it filled in some of the story that goes with the visuals of the cemetery. I would recommend also just wandering and going for a bit on your own away from a large group so that you can really experience it and notice the small details of the crypts that are easily missed in a larger tour.

Amazing Place to Wander & Marvel. We went to see this famous place and to locate the grave of Evita. The entire cemetery is full of lovely statues, small lane ways and beautiful architecture. It is the most amazing cemetery we have visited and it is quite intriguing to walk around and go back in time, as you view the various monuments to those who lived in the past. A somber yet incredible place to visit!

Just follow the crowd to Evita's mausoleum. The cemetery is a showcase of architectural styles. But the main event is the Duarte Family mausoleum where Evita is buried. Just follow the crowd - go to the left as you enter the cemetery.

One of the few things you MUST do in BA. Everyone says that the Cementerio de la Recoleta is a must-see when in Buenos Aires...and I agree with them. We visited on a chilly but sunny afternoon. Several school groups and tourists wandered the paths. Otherwise, only two security guards at the gate, a few maintenance workers and a bunch of lounging cats shared the cemetery with us. The tombs are truly works of art and come in many different shapes, sizes and styles. Some of them are quite grand, others are smaller and quite a few need serious maintenance. The cemetery itself is beautiful with a few tree lined paths that soften all of the marble, stone and concrete tombs. Surprisingly, many of the tombs showoff the caskets holding the dead. Many have glass doors giving you full access to see what is inside. The larger tombs have what could be considered a place of worship at or above ground level with stairs leading to a basement full of caskets. In some cases the glass has broken and dust, dirt, plants and trash sit with the bodies. It is sad to think that some families spent so much to build these monuments only to have them disintegrate due to lack of care.

Beautiful and worth a walk through. I wouldn't (and didn't) pay for a tour, I simply bought a map and found my way to Evita. There was a brochure that gave a lot of information that I am sure was the same as the guided tours. The Cemetary itself is definitely worth a visit. The architecture is like miniature examples of the local buildings.
A must if you visit Buenos Aires. This is an amazing cemetery quite unlike anything we have seen before. It has to be seen to be appreciated and visiting Eva Peron's grave was very poignant.

you can't visit BA without coming here. We loved the cemetery and recoleta in general. The cemetery itself has lots of cool tombs and statues. Not much else to say. It's also in a very nice area with lots of surrounding parks and cafes/restaurants.
A BUE must-see!. This is better than the cemetery in Athens. So many great, small architectural wonders crammed together. This historical site is required for any visitor to Buenos Aires.
Nice architecture. Its a historical cemetery and in my opinion it worths visiting it. Its not a typical cemetery, but a very large one and with different buildings.

A must really..... The name Eva Perron is synonymous with Argentina. There are some exceptionally ornate and grand crypts of the well to do surrounded now by apartments, a mall and a park !A Freddo outlet across the road providing sustenance for the next site !

historical cemetery. This is not the typical cemetery, believe me, it s worth taking the tour, walking around to find EVITA 's tomb and other national heroes. it s unique place at the heart of the city, inside the most expensive neighbourhood.

Not the normal kind of cemetery. Normally one would not consider a visit to a cemetery as a tourist outing, but I was amazed to see so many visitors. The attraction of course is the last resting place of Evita Peron. After I’ve read a lot about the life of this well-known woman, I was curious to see this cemetery. The mausoleums are impressive, often opulent and a strange sight to those not used to this burial method. Beautiful statues and inscriptions often allow some insight to the impact important individuals had on the shaping of the country. Some mausoleums allow a peek through windows or doors and the reward can be a beautiful stained glass window to photograph against the outside light. The alleys between the graves are like a labyrinth and one can easily get lost especially if you are looking for a specific family site. At the entrance of the graveyard there is a guide map to all the residents. Although an eery place to visit, it was time spent worthwhile. As always, keep some change ready to use the well-maintained public toilets or face a grumpy stare!

Interesting, a bit spooky though. The recoleta cementery is one of a kind. It is like going through history by visiting crypts. Unless you are into that kind of stuff, I wouldn´t spend the couple of hours needed to go through it, instead I would walk around the area, visit the Iglesia del Pilar (which is the cementery church) and the cloisters where the monks used to live many years ago.If you do find this kind of thing interesting, you will be thrilled.

Unique Cemetery to visit. Located in Heart of Recoleta Neighbourhood, it's definetely a must to see place. You can get a free tour inside, visiting famous, aristocratich people graves from argentinian history.

Always my first stop. It seems odd to say that one's first stop as a tourist in their favorite city is to a cemetery, but you haven't visited Recoleta's historic gem. On my 7th visit to the city, this is the one place I always go for peacefulness and beauty, all for free. Each time, I wander in a new direction, and get a new perspective on the past and present, and take in beautiful sculptures. In the U.S., where I'm from, we visit cemeteries when the bad news strikes, then, perhaps, on Christmas or a birthday. Recoleta marks time gone by and a great respect for those past by inviting visitors to visit Evita's final resting place and getting to know some of Argentina's lesser known families. It's a picture taker's dream, and the wild cats that guard the place aren't as intimidating as they sound- often doing the familiar belly rolls for tourists (as they are fed daily by doting "cat ladies"- there isn't a skinny one in the lot) to get a scratch on the tummy.Place your skepticism aside and visit; it's a place of beauty.

Must see !. This place is a must see - we were so glad we got to see it. Its a grand mausoleum, little rooms/ mausoleum for each dead person or bigger ones for families. Never saw something like this before. Eva Peron is number 88, the map at the entrance is helpful. But like someone else said - her tomb is just like the others. You really have to look. Also peak in the windows and you will see interesting, different settings inside the mausoleums.

Resting in Style. This is very strange to see but a must see.It is amazing how each family try to out do each other by creating these. Family resting places,it is also sad because some of them are not being maintain so you can see the remains. If you like bones this is the place to visit.A must see for me was eva peron final resting place,not as impressive as some of them but a lot of history behind same,flowers being place by some locals daily.Don't let darkness catch you in there it gets very creepy. If you like reading tomb stones this is the place. There is a beautiful one of a young girl and her dog,sorry can't recall the lane she was on or her name .The craft work on some of them is amazing.So if you like old buildings there is something for you also. You can walk on your own or with a guide you pay for.

A Little Creepy. It is a nice cemetery with interesting architecture and cute cats, but I thought that there was a lack of information about the people buried there. I feel that would be a nice touch that could let people learn something about the people. I still think it was a good experience, but it wouldn't hurt to put more details into the plaques, instead of two-three sentences they could have several paragraphs.

Impressive its the word. At first I didnt expect much from the cemetery, I mean, its a cemetery, what can make it different than the others right? Well, I was IMPRESSED by the mausoleums, the crypts and the statues in this place, they are HUGE and some of them are even 3 stories tall... its a great spot to visit, its takes you 20 minutes to go all over it, so plan it along with a city tour.
surreal cemeter. This beautiful cemetery has a amazing funereal adornments. They do have tours in english and spanish.

Take the tour!. There are free tour guides to the cemetery, they are worth waiting for! They tell you a lot of Argentinean history so you can understand the cemetery, the tours are available in many languages.

Quirky must-see for photographers. Its unique architecture and layout will thrill even the most amateur of photographers. While Evita seems to be the big draw, there are plenty of other more interesting and photogenic aspects to Recoleta. Try to get there early to avoid big crowds. And as always, take time to look up, down, and from different angles to really enjoy the beauty.

Beat the crowds - go early in the morning.. This cemetery is definitely worth a visit. You could spend 30 minutes or hours here depending on your interest but do put it on your 'must do' list.When we were there in January the weather was very hot and the bus loads of tourists filled the place all day from about 9 or 9.30 in the morning. We arrived at the Cemetery at 7.30am and had a good couple of hours to really enjoy the experience before the crowds took over and the temperature soared.

Good to See.... Lovely cemetery in the center of Buenos Aires with some nicely designed tombs.
Some of them are really have interesting architecture.
It is quite a touristic place and generally busy however still need to see.
Need respect and better to investigate quietly and calmly.
Queque for Evita's grave.. Nice cemetery for walk but queque at Evita's grave made it very touristy. Still worth a go and nice to stroll through the markets afterwards and grab some lunch.
Life and Death. For a cemetery where you mourn the dead, the architecture of the different sites as well as the flowers and love felt, it was as if the place was alive.

Nothing else quite like it. It's fascinating for the sheer oddness of it all. Narrow stone paths with one masoleum immediately next to the other leaving no breathing room - literally. The architecture is a hodge-podge of every type imaginable and in various states of decay. My favorite was an Egyptian-looking one right by the entrance. I think the designer was inspired by the silent movies of D.W. Griffith. Some of the tombs are as creepy as you'd ever want to see. One had a glass door so you could look inside to a mess of cobwebs with moldy, crumbly stone stairs going down to an underground sarcophagus. This cemetery is well worth the trip. You should also see the small church ajacent.For those with mobility challenges -- get the attention of one of the people at the entrance and they will lead you to a door near the steps and you can get it without going up several steps and then back down again to get into the cemetery. There are no handrails on the steps. The guards were very glad to help us out. It's flat inside the cemetary.

Bizzare but interesting. beautiful green area. The graves represent art pieces of various types and styles: photo walls, marble profiles... some very fancy. Evita and general san martin tombs are there, with frequent visitors. Taking pictures there was awkward, no smiles at all. Once there, no more comebacks. NOT a romantic places (as some people suggested).

What a way to go!!. I love cemeteries. They're quiet, they're well kept and they're great places to reflect.Recoleta cemetery is all that, but if anything I walked away feeling I had visited a grand museum of and for the dead. The "Louvre" of cemeteries if you will. The people did not just want to be buried. They wanted to be buried in grand style and they wanted everyone to know it!The sculptures, the statues, the friezes and most of all, above everything for me, the stained glass inside the crypts are too amazing for words. This is a life's history done in marble with wonderful artistic flair. Not all crypts are over the top and quite a number are in a very bad state of disrepair, but even with that being said they do have a tragic elegance to them.The overall feel of reflection and quietness still surrounds you while you take in these works of art. I only wish I had more time to spend there. I could have easily spent two days there easy. Will definitely go back for a visit, unfortunately not to be buried :-)

It may seem creepy but you must go!. When I was first researching things to do in Buenos Aires, Recoleta Cemetary kept coming up and I was slighted weirded out because it was a cemetary, but let me tell you, IT WAS A HIGHLIGHT of our trip! Even my skeptical boyfriend really enjoyed it! It's not a typical cemetary at all, it's more like a small city! If you want a tour in English go on Tuesdays and Thursdays. I believe tour times are at 11am and 1pm, but I could be wrong. Otherwise, it is still free to enter! Spent three weeks in Buenos Aires and this would be in my top 5 for sure!

Worth a brief visit. Although some mausoleums are really impressive, specially the ones from wealthy family. I went there to see the one where Evita Peron is buried. My recommendation: go for a quick visit and do not have high expectations on Evita's mausoleum, it was one of the simplest. No entrance fee but if you need a map, you can get one for $4. Definitely wear sunblock and bring water, you can easily get lost here and end up walking in order to find a certain tomb.Grab a Choripan outside in the park :)

interesting cemetery. The most interesting part of our visit was seeing the tomb of Eva Peron and the other incredible family vaults all arranged almost like a little town all on its own. The sculptures are incredible and each family crypt seems to tell its own story.

You can't beat FREE. Wife and I spent a few hours here on a Monday afternoon in BA. You can walk at your own pace through the cemetery. This can be very nice after you visit La Boca (with all the noise and touristy things). The cemetery shows how the wealthy are buried in BA. It's also close to a mall and restaurants/bars if someone in your party does not want to pay their respects to Evita.

Good example of the classicism that exists in BA.. I can't say that I've ever enjoyed a cemetary so much. Even with all the tourists, it is so easy to get away from the crowds and explores these ridiculous examples of wealth. It is shocking to see how extravagantly the corpses here are housed while the poor go roofless outside. Just watch out for the cleaners - there are some with a sense of humour who don't mind giving you a little scare!

The only Cemetery worth visiting. I know this will sound weird to many of you but i highly suggest that you should go to this Cemetery to chillax. There is a very romantic feel about the tombs on display, and it will even make you think about your tomb preparations, people at the Recoleta Cemetery really left with a bang.You will also find a lot of feral cats hanging around might be a good idea to take a picture with them as some are quite pretty.I don't know if it's open at night, may not be worth going. Check with the locals.
Stones of interest. Wonderful place to spend the afternoon, even if it might seem creepy.

Evita. We stumbled by accident near the Recoleta Cemetary and when I realized that that is where Maria Eva Duarte a.k.a. Evita Peron was buried it became a must see. She is in a simple family crypt which surprised me somewhat given the fact the she was adored by the poor and was actually embalmed... The rest of the cemetary is a must to see, many of the Argentinian greats are buried here.

Amazing history and artistry. Stunning! You could spend hours wandering the cemetery admiring the workmanship and taking photos of the beautiful monuments. Well worth the visit. Be sure not to pay any "volunteers" outside of the cemetery.
Unusual Cemetery. It is well worth a visit. The tombs are beautiful and unusual.

favorite of BA. It sounds creepy but this place was filled with gorgeous cementary plots, with stained glass, wrought iron, very ornamental. Many famous folks buried here and for a small tip/fee someone will give you a brief tour.

Very atmospheric. A nice place to wander and get lost in. This certainly isnt your average cemetary. I would recommend getting a guide from the front enterance to give you a bit of background. Then wander and lose yourself for hours!

Everyone's after Evita. Once the tour crwods disappear then you can enjoy Recoleta, it is small but has fabulous tombs, sculptures and gardens.Everyone goes for Evita's tomb, but hang back and you'll have it all to yourself.

The city that is a cemetery. Amazing to see in person. You can tell the wealthy of B.A. took great pride in having a stately monument. I have photos that one would think is a city street shot becasue of all the marble facades, landscaping, and pristine walkways,
Eva Peron plus. Wow! this is a city unto itself with historic and stunning resting places. It is well worth a visit.
A visual masterpiece. The cemetary is not only beautiful, it is filled with history. From the girl that died twice to Evita Peron, you can easily spend a couple of hours taking it all in.

Join a Tour group. This is a must from BA vivitors. The place is a mirror of the last 10 years pf the country, but you'll want to have a native guide show you around to really understand what is there.
Lots of other interesting collections in the Church as well as the Artists' displays in the adjacent park

Definitely worth a trip especially if you have a guide. This is a beautiful cemetery. The visit was especially enjoyable as my guide Mariela (Buenos Aires Concierge) was able to guide me and provide the "back story" to many of the monuments. The church next door is beautiful too.

Pretty, interesting & great with a guide. We had a guide who told us the history of the different mausoleums that made the whole trip interesting. Otherwise just walking among anonymous tombs would be boring.

Weird and Wonderful city for the dead.... this is really a special visit....a little bit weird maybe, to take our two children on a walk among the tombs of the well heeled and famous Argentinians...but it really is a walk down history lane, and it is really worth while doing a bit of research of who is who before visiting. My husband was born in Bs.As and this was his first visit to the cemetery, but he really enjoyed it as much as the children did, we were all amazed by the carved statues and wonderful decorations all over. dont miss it!

Guided tour might be best. It was certainly quite a sight, crypts to the left and to the right. I think a guide would help here, to bring some context. There is a map at the entrance with key graves marked. It isn't like pere lachaise in the sense of being a 'normal' graveyard- its more of a high rise equivalent. If you have a bent for history feel free to go - its free after all, but it isn't the unmissable feature some reviewers suggest.

A Cemetery full of history. This emblematic cemetery, in the heart of Recoleta quarter, is full of history. There are very important personalities of the Argentine history, including among others, presidents (Sarmiento, Mitre, Avellaneda, Roca, etc), members of the army (Dorrego, Lavalle, Admiral Guillermo Brown, etc), people of the historic Buenos Aires society, the wife of General San Martin, and the wife of President Peron, Evita.There are some impresive mausoleums, do not miss them.There are guided tours available.

Go if you have time. It shows how tradional families with more money than sense buried their dead in valuts made of marble, bronze and whateve material conveyed the impression that you were seriously wealthy. Join a tour to learn who was who, Evita and her husband are buried there as are many other argentine heros both military and civilian.
A must see. Certainly one of the most interesting and artistic cemetories I have ever visited rivaling that of Paris

Worth a visit. This must be one of the most poshest cemetriesin the world.The resting place of Eva (Evita ) Peron is here.It is ironic that the dead a better housed than some of the living in this city.
Much better than expected. highlight of our trip--well worth seeing. just to warn there are people collecting for charity outside who are very aggressive

Incredible Cemetery. This is by far the most beautiful cemetery that I have ever visited. We stopped here on a guided tour and we learned many stories about the Presidents and Generals and many other very influencial figures who are interred here. It is free to visit.

Used to be.. The place is interesting architecturally. Full of "important" stiffs. But maintaining the mausoleums is so expensive that families have decided to abandon them. You will find open doors, view broken coffins, trash and filth gathering in and out of the buildings. A few hundred cats roam the premises like ghosts (wonder about reencarnation). If you decide to go, do look up, quite a few of the mourning figures are interesting to look at, and symbols of death, eternity, wisdom, pain, and rebirth are all over the place.

This is to be visited while doing Recoleta. You will make better use of your time if you organize your visit so you can do Recoleta Cemetery and then spend some timein the area around it, where you will find a good number of restaurants and cafes where to sit and watch the locals.(See Recoleta review)The Cemetery is indeed worth a visit as it is the final resting place of the rich and famous. Evita Peron is buried there as wellas a large number of prominent - and wealthy - argentinians.Some mausoleums are so opulent that they resemble little villasor part of one, in many instances the altars therein coveredwith lacework done by the ladies of the family. If you are not familiar with Catholic cemeteries, do not miss this one.
A must see. Beautiful place and don't just focus on the famous grave of Evita Peron. The graves in the back of the cementry is the most beautifuls

Recoleta. This is an absolute must see in BA. I wondered around this HUGE cemetery, browsing and sight-seeing all of the beautiful and interesting mausoleums. After wondering around for about an hour, I decided to go see the most famous resident here, Eva Peron. Everyone wants to know where she is, and if you follow the masses of people, you will find her. Her site is very modest compared to some of the fancy and HUGE plots, but it is also very impressive.Overall this is a nice place to wonder for hours and take in the peaceful and historic site in beautiful Recoleta.

Gotta See!. Definitely a "must see" when visiting BA. We hired a guide at the door for a modest fee (the cemetery is free) but found having an expert guide was informative and probably saved time. We got to ask a lot of questions and see it on our timetable. The statues are amazing!
Very Cool. We spent hours walking through this cemetary. We saw the famous museleums...they were truly spectacular. My fiance is facsinated with graveyards...
Can't Miss. Has to be the thing to see. Just crazy place to see. You can't miss it.

not only evita. i am not the kind of person that likes Cemeteries this one is a must if you have time see apart from evita also all the wonderfull statues that the cemetary is full and enjoy the garden outside with huge trees and very nice restaurents

Eva. Every one wants to see her resting place. You can feel the love
if you are fortunate to be there when Argentines come by.
Unique. This cementery has a unique designer, it´s reminds me living a hundreds years ago. When you walk around you can feel a bit scared most if it´s cloudy. You can´t loose it.
A nice excursion for a sunny afternoon.. Nice to see but after twenty eye-opening musoleums, enough. Then walk over to row of outside restaurants, cafes for late lunch!

A very impressive cemetery. Visiting a cemetery is not normally a holiday activity... nevertheless a visit to la Recoleta is worthwhile to see such an impressive collection of crypts (some are huge) and gravestones in one place. A mix of traditional and some more contemporary architecture.It's free to enter, we spent about 45 minutes as we did not find it necessary to walk around the entire cemetery, but many do to locate all the famous folk in their final resting place.On leaving the cemetery you can relax in the park under the shade of the huge trees, there is also a selection restaurants next to the park.

Must see while in Buenos Ares. Truly unique visit where the luminaries of Buenos Aires have been immortalized with great statuary and fanfare. Interesting to see how the family crypts are laid out and how some of the contemporary crypts sit amongs the traditional ones.

A good budget day activity. Buenos Aires is expensive but this place is cheap, it is free!! My advice though is to buy the 10 ARS map that will guide you around all the most interesting of gravestones.Be warned some of the tombs are not in great condition and you can see directly into where the coffins are resting.

Interesting. A very unique cemetery, though I have never visited a cemetery on vacation before. Interesting to learn the history of the cemetery but it was a bit creepy to see all the tombs, especially since some of them have broken glass and you can see right into the coffins. There were stray cats all over the place which made it even creepier. But now I can say I have been to Evita's final resting place.

Excellent tour. There are two English speaking tours per week, I think on a tuesday and friday, but not 100% sure. I would recommend the tour as there is much more to the cemetery than just Eva Peron's crypt. The guide(Patricia) gave us a fascinating insight into the history of the cemetery and the stories behind several of the characters buried there.

Wow! This is a must experience!. It looked like a small city. Tiny houses - but not for the living! At least not for the "living people". LOTS of resident cats roaming the "streets" of the cemetery. This is a must see just because you are in Buenos Aires.
Intriguing. Go by the Evita tomb quickly as there is always a crowd and the rest of the cemetery is much more beautiful, and quieter!

Fascinating. Incredible site to visit with seriously ancient mauseleums and history of families ... it has to add to nostalgic for any spanish decendants visiting the cemetery... its well worth spending a couple of hours peeping into doors that are welcoming the idea and seeing all the old coffins etc.. some are highly neglected and there are hints of breakins etc. even saw some exposed human bones in the seriously old sites where doors have collapsed and coffins have disintegrated. The La Biela cafe across the way .. has loads of history too however its a complete rip off... soooo very expensive its not worth it!!!

Don't Cry for me Argentina. You can't leave Buenos Aires without visiting the famous Recoleta Cemetery, which is also located in a very cool area of the city. It is the place where the infamous Evita is buried. Though depending with who you speak with in Argentina, even today, she either is held in high regard or disdain.
The city of the dead. unusual monumental cemetery a must see, beautifully done homage to the passed
Kind of boring. Not very exciting. Could be interesting if you take the time to read all the signs, or maybe if you had a tour to show you the most interesting ones (no tours on Mondays).

Amazing Cemetery. I really am not a person that likes to visit cemeteries, but this one is a must see. As a North American, used to seeing tombstones, this cemetery amazed me. It's like visiting a small city, with above ground tombs decorated to the nines. There are statues and stories not to be missed, and of course the tomb of Evita, which by US standards is extravagant, but by Argentina's standards many told me is a shame that it's not extravagant enough. Well worth the trip.

A must-see. What an impressive sight. The cemetery is small and packed with such magnificent memorials. Take a tour to get the most out of the experience. You will walk out amazed by this beautiful spot.

A "must see".. Evita buried here. Kind of hard to find her (look for the Duarte crypt). The cemetery is reminiscent of the New Orleans cemeteries. Some of the crypts are falling apart and others are well-kept. They are above ground, many with small staircases inside. Beautiful grill work on the doors.

Incredible cemetery. A mini city of the dead within Bs As. A surprising variety of architecture, a bemused cat population and a somewhat ghoulish display of coffins in some buildings. People obviously shelled out big bucks to be buried in this monumental cemetery.

Very beautiful and full of history. Very beautiful cemetery, and full of history. I would try to do a guided tour (which I couldn't), as it probably makes the visit much more interesting (tours in English happen only twice a week).
Ghoulish, but gotta go. You end up spending hours strolling through this national icon.

Beautiful architecture. If you appreciate places with great architecture and valuable history, This cementery is for you. It's full of impressive mausoleums with beautiful desings. Statues are also amazing, most of them are angels. You walk through narrow alleys that can be kind of creepy, but it's still awesome!It would be better if you like cats, because there are lots of fat cats that.live in the cementery. In addition, it is important to bear in mind that it closes at 5:00 pm

It is what it says it is. It´s a cool sensation entering this city of the dead after the noise of the living city. Go in with an idea of what and who you want to see, though, look them up in the board at the entrance, and then try to maximise the effect by splitting from any groups and seeing the monuments on your own.

Beautiful cemetery. Some of the tombs are amazing and well kept while some others are in disrepair. A lot of people flock to Eva Peron's tomb and it is worth seeing, but do wander around to look at others too.

A tourist must....... This may sound a little macabre but this was one of the tourist attractions that I was most looking forward to visiting whilst in Bueones Aires. Being a fan of the hit musical Evita and knowing the history of this amazing argentinian figure Eva Peron, the first lady of Argentina, I could not wait to visit her resting place. We undertook a 3 hour bicycle tour in Buenos Aires, riding through the city, it was an amazing way to see the city. La Recolletta Cemetery was the last stop on our tour. We found this to be an amazing tourist attraction. Having seen nothing like this in my life, I was totally in awe of the amazing architecture and the grandness of this cemetery and enjoyed wondering through it. As much as I enjoyed this, it did make my stomach a little churned at the end, just visually being able to see the coffins stacked on top of one another and then seeing mother and baby coffins., reality shock!! Eva's family crypt was hard to get a photo as it was so crowded but it is very plain, at her request, she didn't want anything fancy, according to our guide. This is really amazing, I recommend that everyone in this beautiful city visits this attraction.

History, Beauty and Death. This is one of the best attractions of all of Buenos Aires. A must-see. It doesn't matter if it's sunny or not, but do download the app on iTunes. Robert Wright wrote it. Walking around with a great map and the stories behind who's buried where makes the experience that much better. Though I have spent days there with just a camera and myself. Splendid!

Weird...but interesting. Going to a cemetery isn't really a normal honeymoon activity...but everyone including the people working at our hotel told us we had to visit it. We took a free tour and learned a lot about the history of the cemetery along with the history of some of Argentina's most famous people (who all just happen to be buried here).We had a great time.
Stroll for hours.... This is a great place to just get lost in time. Amazing monuments that seem to defy time. Some at least. Others in a sad stage of decay.

Cemetery Architecture. Some lovely cement sculptures here.. a few better in Bronze ( don't forget to swipe the dog's nose for luck ). Evita's Mausoleum is Plebean, as was her family ( Duarte ), this is not to say it is not nice, not suitable, perhaps for a First Lady. As a cemetery Buff, above ground burials ( i.e. Mausoleums ) are not unusual. New Orleans has some, Charleston SC, etc. Savannah GA ( St. Boneventure is far more impressive, Spanish Moss, and some wonderful lyrics on benches, etc.). I would recommend, however, a visit to the adjoining Monastery where one might get a lovely view of Recoleta from 2 stories up and chance to see Alabaster Window panes ( this Tourist had not seen them before ) and a few other interesting wall decorations.While in the area, you may try to find some Empenadas ( flaky crust, sorta like a Pierogie, with cheese, beef, or chicken inside ). Unfortunately, the best place I can recommend is next to a Leather Store 3 blocks away... Lunch with Beer for 3, under $30. US.
Free English speaking tour. Took the free english speaking guided tour of the cemetery. The guide was very informative and excellent.

Must see for Architecture Buffs. Come on, if you are in BA, this is at the top of your list. The visual impact of this historically significant cemetery is unbelievable. The final resting spot of Eva Peron is poignant and moving.

Only in BA does a person maintain status in death!. You must see it to believe it and don't forget to bring your camera! If you can't find Evita Peron's tomb, ask a guard or touristo with a map. Makes for a fun hour or two of strolling. If you can't get to Mercado San Telmo on Sunday for gift shopping, Feria Artesanal, right outside the cementerio gates is fabulous. We picked up jewelry and leather goods for the kids at home and things for ourselves as well at great prices. The atmosphere is festive with music and buskers too.

Great place. Walk among the living dead, visiting Recoleta is something you won't regret. The place around the cemetery (the recoleta area) is really nice, especially on Sundays when everyone heads our for a picnic or just hanging around.
Must See. Being from the US, I have never really seen anything like this. It seemed weird to be amazed walking among the dead, but the tombs were incredible. See Evita's, but see more too.

Eva Perón, Raúl Alfonsín, and several presidents of Argentina. The monks of the Order of the Recoletos arrived in this area, then the outskirts of Buenos Aires, in the early eighteenth century. The cemetery is built around their convent and a church, Our Lady of Pilar

THE VILLAGE OF TOMBS. Recoleta is truly unique--well, almost so as there are a few other similar collections of mausoleums and tombs scattered around the world. The sheer size of the cemetery, embedded in the middle of B.A. as it is, is impressive and Recoleta has a decided creep factor for those (my wife) uncomfortable with such ostentatious displays of the honored dead. Evita's resting place is far from the most expensive or impressive, but somehow this adds to its mystique. This is a great place to take a leisurely stroll down "avenues" and alleyways and to consider, as we often do in graveyards, what misadventures and scandals may have brought some of Recoleta's 'residents' here.
Surreal!. just so surreal ! A brilliant hour wandering around (easy to get lost)
