History. Amazing to see this in middle of city.Evita's grave a bit hard to find as she is actualy buried under her maiden name Eva Maria Duarte ,but there is always someone you can ask that will give direction

Wild. Nothing like it.. It is like a stunning city of the dead for rich Latin American Catholics. It almost defies description. Be sure to make a pilgrimage to the tomb of Evita. And here is a tip. There is a thriving market for souvenir goods outside of the cemetery. And the farther you get from the main entrance, the more bargains you will find.

Well Worth Visiting. I spent a very enjoyable time wandering around this cemetery looking at the various tombs. One of the key attractions is Eva Peron's family tomb but many of the other ones are very ornate and interesting. Some are better kept up than others; one of the favorite photos I took were of caskets peaking through the crumbling ruins of one tomb. Also fun were all of the stray cats wandering about.

eerie beauty. stopped in several times when walking past.
it is impossible to take a bad photo here, no matter what time of day or weather conditions.
Must Visit Site. Any visit to BA must include a stop by the Recoletta Cemetery. Combine it with a walk through the adjacent Sunday market.
Well worth the visit. Must see Eva Peron vault but very crowded there. Tour guide made the visit more interesting with stories about the history of some of the families having vaults there.
Evita. It's fascinating to wander around and explore this extensive mini-city of statues, detailed marble facades. Just follow the crowd and you will see Evita's grave

Fascinating and worth a visit. The stark clean entrance of Recoleta Cemetery does well to hide the contrast of numerous impressive monuments dedicated to some of Argentina’s most notable pioneers. It is clear that the Argentine people are passionate about their history and the people that shaped it. Maps can be purchased for 10 pesos at the entrance and the suggested route can take 1 to 2 hours dependent upon how curious you are about the inhabitants. Guides are present and are free but gratefully accept tips at the end of the tour. Whether you walk it yourself or take a tour it is worth a visit and one of the “must see” items in Buenos Aires.

Calm afternoon in a cemetary.. Families battle it out to provide the best resting place for their loved ones. Beautiful crypts. Very interesting to wander around. Eva Perons tomb is very understated compared to many of the others. Delightful outdoor cafes opposite to while-away time after a few hours traipsing.

WOW! What a place!. All of the guidebooks make a big deal about visiting the cemetery and now I see why. It is absolutely amazing. In some ways it reminds me of the cemeteries in New Orleans, but this is a more grand scale. It is free to go it, but they also offer a map guide for 10 pesos. If you don't have a guide, it is a good thing to purchase as it helps to point out where significant figures are buried. If you do not know much about Argentine or Buenos Aires history, most of the names will not mean a thing, but it does not matter. If you know a little Spanish, you can sometimes figure out why someone was important. The tombs are amazing architectural wonders in many cases and run the gamut from marble masoleums to more contempory structures built in the 1970s. The reason that most people come to visit is to see the grave of Eva Peron which is just tucked away in the middle of one of the rows with no extraordinary fanfare. You can generally find it by looking for a line of people or a ton of flowers tucked into the door. But you should take the time and walk up and down the rows. You will be astounded. The statuary is better than you will find in some museums. As one other reveiwer said some of the crypts are in horrible shape. It is sad that for whatever reason the families of thise people have forgotten them. It reminded us of a phrase that we use at Lent in our Episcopal Church: "Remember that you are dust, and to dust you shall return."
Loved this!. This place is so peaceful and beautiful! Wandered for hours to see all the monuments.

Incredible. On my first trip to Buenos Aires two decades ago, the cemetery was the most memorable sight I had seen there. Upon my return to BA I re-visited it with my friend, who was also charmed, and we returned the next day and picked up a local English speaking volunteer guide to learn more about the families who are buried here, and how the mausoleums are constructed. Besides being very beautiful and admiring the varied architecture, this is a calming place filled with history and personal stories which are very interesting. This is a totally unique place.

Interesting place; worth the visit. I really enjoyed my visit to the Recoleta Cemetery. I often visit sites such as this as well as lesser known burial grounds because the differences in custom are very interesting. I wish there had been more information provided about who was buried at the cemetery. If you are interested in that kind of background to what you are seeing check out a tour or do some research ahead of time because you won't find it at the site. It was still really fascinating to see the sculptures and the tombs and the way it was all put together in the midst of the city.

Ancient mausoleums, some in bad repair. As you stroll up and down row upon row of concrete and glass mausoleums, you can feel the wealth and power of many of the individuals and families entombed here over the past 150 years or so. Large statues, memorial plaques, and stained glass adorn these architecturally-designed resting places for generals, presidents, and the business class. But mixed in with the extravagant and gaudy tombs are many dilapidated and vandalized tombs with broken windows and missing doors. Some have become garbage bins, and through one open door we could see bones poking through a wood crate. the grounds are well kept, but surely someone could go through the forgotten tombs and clean them up and put things back into place.

This is where Evita is buried. Really cool area.. Check out the cemetery here - it's FREE to enter. There is a cute fair just outside with lots of vendors you can buy local stuff from the artists there. Then you might be able to catch an outdoor tango show if you're there in the late afternoon to evening.

Surreal. No one could have prepared me for this, we spent almost an entire day in Recoleta Cemetry and we could not stop taking photos, so make sure you have a full roll of film or an empty sg card and a fully charged battery when you go. We actually ended up visiting the cemetery twice while in Buenos Aires, because we had never seen anything like it, perhaps they are common in certain parts of the world but definitely not where we are from. You will see miniature versions of the Sagrada Familia, Mayan Temples, Art Nouveau carvings etc. If you are a cat lover, take a bag of cat food with you, because there are cats artistically draped in various places that are relatively well looked after because they keep rats our of the crypts. Truly a fascinating place.

A must place to see if you are in Buenos Aires.. This is very unique and a must see when visiting Buenos Aires. The ornate architecture of the above ground crypts is like walking through history. Make sure to visit the crypt of Eva Peron!

Give it a try!. I am not too crazy about cementeries, but this one was really a good stop for us. There are many beautiful tombs. I think what impressed me the most was the peaceful feeling you get while you walk the grounds. It's very well maintained. It's free so all you have to lose is your time, but I don't think you will feel it was a waste. Evita's grave is not well marked so we had to ask a couple of times to find it. It's not an impressive one, there were some other ones that I liked best.

tour the cemetery? Really?. The crowds gather to see where Evita Peron is lying - I hope they don't miss the amazing ornate sculptures that mark graves of the wealthy class that rest here. Wondrous works of art, equal to any gallery exhibits

Unique Cemetery. This is a unique attraction in Buenos Aires and worth a stroll to see the above ground crypts - they are quite impressive and some are quite ornate. See if you can find the crypt for Eva Peron ( Evita!). There is a nice park nearby and if you are there on a weekend there is usually a craft fair that you can enjoy and outdoor cafes across the way for a leisurely break.

Worth it just to see the grave of Eva Peron, and the family of Che Guevera.. I loved this tour. I was skeptical at first , becuase let's face it...it's s cemetary. However I was lucky enough to be approoached by an English speaking tour guide who did an awesome job of explaining the significance of many of the people in the graveyard. We spent almost 2 hours there, and were not bored at all. The tour guide didn't even ask for a tip or anything, we were just inclined to give him one because he was so good. He really loved his country and was well versed in the history of the cemetary and country. Buenos Aires is a great city...and cheap if you have dollars ..and if you have Euros your a KING!!!!!!

Beautiful, unusual experience. Entire city block of above ground crypts, most from years ago. It's beautiful and serene and gorgeous. The church next door is beautiful as well. You absolutely have to visit Recoleta Cemetery when you are in BA.

One of the best cemeteries to see in the world.. This is a fabulous, but small cemetery in the beautiful area of Recoleta. It is easy to walk and the monuments are outstanding. The ADACRE offers a brochure for $10 pesos, about 2 plus U.S. dollars when you enter the cemetery. It is worth the purchase price and proceeds go to restoration. You can see where the money has been spend and improvements continue to go on. You can also find the famous Eva Peron, Familia Duarte, crypt and many other famous families' resting places. All the caskets are kept above ground and each family has its own monument. Quite outstanding.

impressive cemetary. Very nicely kept cemetary grounds and many impressive graves / monuments in the cemetary. English tours available on Tuesday and Thursday mornings. Much larger than I thought and almost impossible to see every single one of them (nor was it necessary). Located in a nice area with a shopping mall and some restaurants nearby. Also some hotels nearby.

Recoleta Cemetery. Although I had been to Buenos Aires before, this is the first time I had the time to visit the Recoleta Cemetery which is very interesting from the architectural point of view. This is a monumental cemetery, like the Staglieno Cemetery in Genova and it is certainly worthwhile a visit

Beautiful cemetary worth a visit when you're in B.A.. I highly recommend the free tour. We took the 11am tour on Thurs with Marta. She was extremely knowledgeable about the cemetery. The tour took about 1 1/2 . I learned a lot about burial customs, methods and highlights of some interesting graves. There are some really ornate and massive memorials mixed in right next to ones that were abandoned and decrepit as well as modern marbled ones.By the way, be careful with your belongings while strolling around. While I was photographing the very busy Evita tomb I was warned by other tourists who noticed a shady character standing behind me trying to get into my purse. There were security guards also walking around which makes me think this destination is often a target for pickpocketers.
The Village of the Dead. Well worth an afternoon stroll round , amazingly large area of graves, tombs, and splendid memorials to predominantly the rich and famous, including Eva Peron.

A different place. Have visited cemeteries before and can say that this one is unique. You can see the different architeture as you have a peaceful walk among the graves. It is one of the main attractions in Recoleta.
Wierd to visit a cemetery. It seems odd to say you visited a cemetery, however its really not to be missed. The monuments are family for the most part, very old and all very different

Hostorical site... almost couldn't find Evita's grave. better than the Cemetery is the whole neighborhood. Though I'd say the place is worth visiting and a great oportunity to understand the culture a bit better. I've always beleived graveyards are a good place to see the cultural aspects hidden behind the cities.

Resting place for Buenos Aires aristocracy. For people interested in Argentine history, but not everyone's choice in my opinion. This small cemetery with its elaborate tombs is the resting place for many of the better known families in Buenos Aires including many of its past Presidents, but it is a cemetery, and rather crammed and gloomy. The Recoleta district surrounding the cemetery is in the wealthier part of the city containing many places of sightseeing interest.

Beautiful Stroll. Visiting the Recoleta Cemetery is like being in a mini city. We enjoyed a beautiful, sunny day just strolling casually down the 'streets' snapping photos of beautiful stonework and really amazing bronze work. You could spend a day at the cemetery or just 20 minutes and since it's free, what difference does it make. For me an added bonus were the cats that appear to live in the cemetery. I was really missing my kitty back home so some kitty loving from the cemetery cats made my day. Entry is free but we chose to buy a map to help us find our way around and understand who the important people were. A lovely day and the cemetery is right next to the Recoleta Street Fair.

The best in Buenos Aires. This cemetery is a must. You may be wondering why would you visit a cemetery on your holidays, well because it is unique and special. It is a necropolis full of architectural art. A visit to the city wouldn't be complete without this. The elite of the city is buried here including Evita Duarte de Peron.

Interesting site to include when in BA,and cat lovers bring a ox of dry food. We enjoyed our visit very much,however if you are a cat lover it is ok to bring in some dry food to feed the poor cats who live there.Some volunteers feed but funds can be low at times.So enjoy your visit and bring some Friskies!

Strangely interesting.. While I do not usually go to cemeteries I made an exception based on our guides recommendation. It is very historical and interesting to see how old some of the tombs are and how they are decorated. Of course Evita Peron is buried there so that is almost a must see from a Argentine perspective.

A museum on a cementery.... This cememtery has a lot of history....it was and still is a very important place for certain society groups in Buenos Aires. The main attraction is that it looks like a small city...and the mausolea are amaizing...big and extravagant. It is recommended to go on saturday and after the cementery visit Plaza francia, where a handycraft fair takes place just near the cementery

Worth a quick peek. This will only take you half an hour to go through, but it is interesting. Be aware that it is FREE to get into the cemetery, but many people will try and force you to pay for a map or donate to some fund.

A must see in BA. You won't find anything like this anywhere else in the world. A city of the dead (and wealthy), who went in style. The architecture inside the cemetary, really gives the rest of Recoleta a run for it's money.
very impressive. really enjoyed visiting the cemetery ...some of the monuments were really beautiful
Another New Orleans!. Very interesting and worth the stroll. Remember Evita is in the family tomb Duarte

The famous cemetery where Evita Peron rests. This amazing cemetario is in the park. Eva Duarte is the name on the tomb which you will need directions to find as it is tucked away in a small corridor. There usually a crowd gathered there and fresh flowers on the tomb. The rich and famous are buried here
Very atmospheric!. It's great to wander around among the tombs - see Evita's tomb but don't go only for that.

Creepy but awesome. The idea of visit a cementery can be not nice to everybody. But this place is unique. First cause here you are gonna see the last home of many important figures of the history of Argentina, like Evita Perón, President Sarmiento, Hipolito Yrigoyen, Bartolome Mitre... But you will also see how rich use to be this city, how important some families are, and will have the possibility to see some amazing sculptures, pieces that could be in museums, all them together in one place. The tour can be a kind of creepy, but i don't think there is another place with so many history and art in the surroundings.

A Fitting Resting Place For the Dead. Recoleta Cemetery contains huge structures where the dead have plenty of space to roam around (if they could). The magnificence of some of the mausoleums is truly breathtaking (pun intended). You have to be someone of significance to get in, but once in, unless you are Evita Peron, you're in to stay. Evita lies there, finally, with many plaques proclaiming her greatness. It is amazing that a woman who lived to the ripe old age of 33 has had and continues to have such a profound effect upon a whole nation. Walk up and down the aisles. Each structure is unique and memorable.

Must see when visiting the city. Interesting few hours walking around the grave sites, particularly the ones off the main 'streets'. Great photo opportunities and some fascinating inscriptions. Note, visiting the cemetery is free; the aggressive individuals claiming to be 'official' with the fake ID and demanding a contribution to some charity are just scammers. Push past and ignore them, they will not bother you once inside.
not your average. This cemetery is an interesting experience not to be missed

Wonderful!. I could’ve wandered around the Recoleta Cemetery for hours! We were there on a Thursday, and the free English tour started promptly at 11am. Lots of interesting and beautiful memorials. Some of the sentiments on the mausoleums are just so touching, you feel the loss of the bereaved. My favorite statue was the one of Valeria and her dog. It’s in bronze, unlike most of the statues that were marble. And it had a Tim Burton-esque feel to her mausoleum, so it’s quite unique within the cemetery. So, if you do visit the Recoleta Cemetery, go ahead and take a gander at Evita’s tomb. But make time to wander around and look at the others, or you’ll be missing out.

Like a Mini Buenos Aires. This fantastic necropolis in the heart of the ritzy Recoleta neighborhood is worhty of a long visit, and not just to see Eva Peron's final resting place (a surprisingly nondescript mausoleum). Wandering around the 13-acre cemetery is like walking around a miniature city, with a grid pattern of streets, a small central garden-like section, and impressive architecture on the final resting spots of some of the city's wealthiest and most famous residents. From pyramids to chandeliers, from stained glass to domes, I found that these monuments -- some in disrepair, some well maintained -- are all alluring, and provide for some creative photography.

a city in itself. when walking through it's a city of death....literally. large apt like monuments/mausoleum surround each other similar to a condo. famous is the eva perron one. although not as glamorous as the others, it's a strong part of their history

So NOT spooky!. It´s amazing to roam around the cemetery finding all the historic Argentinian last names. During the weekends there are guided tours (around $20 - 5 USD) focusing on different topics (historic families, masoneries and so on)
Historic and interesting place. You can see here Evita tomb and other important people in the history of Argentina.

a nice cemetery of u like that kind of thing. im not a goth but it was a fine cemeteryt top see all the great dictators and questionably wealthy dead people, a modern day valley of the kings of Buenos Aires. nezst to a nice park and a wealthy part of Buenos Aires recoleta, the whole area is lovely

A special cemetery -- if you like cemeteries. It is an interesting cemetery with a lot of Argentine history, but of course you need to know that history in some detail. Some interesting sculpture. The highlight being Eva Peron's burial site. The large nearby street market -- Sundays and holidays (and maybe Sat. also) was more interesting to my companion. The nearly Recoleta neighborhood is also interesting.

Monumental memorial place. Access to the cemetery by public transport is easy, if only you know how to use map of the city transportation system, or you know the city. Unfortunately, there is no nearby subway station, so you have use bus or walk 1-2 kilometers. More expensive option is to take a taxi. Cemetery makes a great impression, despite the small area. The tombs are competing with each other in size and richness of form. Certainly worth seeing the tomb of Evita Peron, for which the majority of visitors arrive here. It is worth to look into the less frequented alleys to get to know a bit of the history of this beautiful city.

As a visitor, you do need to go here.. I am a minor cemetery junky. Find you can learn a lot about people from their cemeteries. This is certainly true of Recoleta Cemetery. It is all crypts – and each one may cost more than our house! Just amazing the detail and structure of each. We did not take a tour, but I learned more from others that did. I wish we had. The construction of each – that you can not see from outside the crypt is amazing. Of course, most people come to see Eva Peron’s. But walk around – it is worth it.
Amazing city within a city.... Do not miss visiting. It was a truly unique experience.

Not what you expect when you thibk cemetery. A definate must see while in BA. Very interesting cemetery with some great architecture. Free entry and free guided tours on certain days. The market outside is good too
Argentina Feb 2012. Visited as part of a morning run (so no crowds at all). Had been before but forgot how to find Eva Peron's (Evita) grave and no help on the board at the entrance.
Different. Worth the visit something totally different, Remember if you go to the public toilets here you have to pay 2 Peso, and the lady will hand you 2 pieces of toilet paper.
Must see! Fascinating!. English tours Monday and Thursday at 11am. Tour was great. Morbid, but so much to photograph! Unbelievable architecture. Much more than where Eva Peron lays.

Take the English tour and hear some great stories!. This cemetary is full of beautiful mausoleums that have been well maintained for the most part. There are great stories inside the walls of Recoleta, including those regarding the mystery of Eva Peron, known as Evita to her countrymen. Take the English tour (only offered on Tuesdays) or hire a guide. There is nothing inside the gates to tell the tales.

Look beyond Evita's tomb. Most tourists who come here visit only Evita's tomb, but among the many others, two are worth singling out and should not be missed. One is the tomb of the Paz family, who owned the newspaper La Prensa, as well as the palatial building on Plaza San Martín now known as the Círculo Militar. It is an enormous black stone structure covered with white marble angels in turn-of-the-20th-century dress. The angels seem to soar to the heavens, lifting the spirit of those inside with their massive wings. The sculptures were all made in Paris and shipped here. Masonic symbols such as anchors and pyramid-like shapes adorn this as well as many other Recoleta tombs.Another tomb I recommend seeing is that of Rufina Cambaceres, a young woman who was buried alive in the early 1900s. She had perhaps suffered a coma, and a few days after her interment, workers heard screams from the tomb. When it was opened, there were scratches on her face and on the coffin from her attempts to escape. Her mother then built this Art Nouveau masterpiece, which has become a symbol of the cemetery. Her coffin is a Carrara marble slab, carved with a rose on top, and it sits behind a glass wall, as if her mother wanted to make up for her mistake in burying her and ensure she could see her coffin if she were ever to come back again. The corner of the tomb is adorned by a young girl carved of marble who turns her head to those watching her; she looks as if she is about to break into tears, and her right hand is on the door of her own tomb. Many locals often place delicate sprigs of flowers into her hand.

Beyond belief .... It is like 'sampler' room for elegant office buildings. Miniature edifices at a human scale. The crypts are lavishly finished with marble and stone both inside and out. Sculptures usually found only in palazzos and European squares are all around. Little windows let you see into the tiny parlours, some with fireplaces.At times it is difficult to remember that one is in a cemetery. Look for the cats ... they are said to be the ghosts of the residents.

Evita Peron's tomb...and a whole city of the dead. Always wanted to go see this famous cemetery and it did not disappoint. The mausoleums are incredible to see. Most go to see Evita's tomb but there is so much more. We covered the area in about an hour and had coffee at one of the many outdoor cafes that are near the entrance. The Recoleta Park is adjacent as well as handicraft vendors...some worth looking at...no one bothers you to buy or look...

Interesting but overated. Not a bad place to spend an hour or so, the mausoleums are interesting, although some found the experience a little creepy. Worth visiting if you are in the area, but a little over-rated. If you like cemeteries, the central cemetery in Sucre, Bolivia is much better.

Amazingly beautiful!. The Recoleta Cemetary is a must see when visiting Buenos Aires. Words cannot describe how beautiful the sculptures are, you have too see it in person to understand. One of my favorite places.
Interesting and worth visiting. Aside from this cemetery being famous for the burial of Eva Peron it is worth seeing.

Interesting Bit of Argentinian History. Huge, ornate tombs of every family (seemingly) who had a role in the history of Argentina! Guided tours are given in various languages. The cemetery is more like a museum than any cemetery I had previously visited. I was dubious about going (who really wants to see a typical cemetery?) but it was close to my hotel, so I went. I was pleasantly surprised. It's definitely worth the trip. Also, don't miss the church next to the cemetery. For 5 pesos, there is an area where you can view art and archives maintained by the church.

Most Amazing Cemetery Ever. Why come to Buenos Aires to visit a cemetery? Well, if you only want to visit one IN THE WORLD, visit this one. The tombs and mausoleums here are amazing, many the size of normal houses. Ornate, somewhat gaudy occasionally, they are all worth wandering by. Interestingly, Eva Peron's tomb is not the most ornate or elaborate, or even in a central location. Perhaps this shows she really wasn't one of the highest rung of Argentine society. Definitely walk through here. It's unlike any other cemetery you'll ever see.

Morbidly fascinating. I took a slef tour of the cemetary. The mausoleums are ornate and beautiful. Creepy due to the exposed caskets you see in most of the vaults. A true representation that distinguishes the "haves" and the " have nots" sad but true.

Astounding Sculptures. At the entry door I was hit up by a "fund raiser" man. He had some kind of a "charity". As I was leaving he was getting into a very nice car. I am not sure of that particular activity right at the gate of this wonderful attraction. Anyhow, the cemetery is huge. You need to purchase the map. Don't wander around. You'll miss too much.The map is well worth the money. A camera is a must. The tombs I appreciated most: Doctor Toribio Ayerza, number 16 on the map. The mother with the two children nearly brought tears, it is that touching. The soldier in the arms of a woman, number 112, Juan Lartigau, is poignant, also. Luis Angel Firpo, the champion Argentine boxer's mausoleum inspired me to read his life history. What heart! Admission if free if you can get past the man asking for donations. The hours of operation are 7 AM to 6 PM, every day. I visited in the afternoon and wished I had given myself more time. It's a feast for the eyes and for the heart.

Recoleta Cemetery. ...it's quite unique and grand, and most of the fathers of the land rest there. Unfortunately many of the monuments and crypts are in bad shape and that diminishes the overall look of the place.

a beautiful memory. We enjoyed walking around and seeing the vaults of notable people and sharing in the history of those long gone. We loved seeing the Evita family(Duarat) vault and also how those in the Argentina memorialize their loved ones.

This is like walking through a Buenos Aires time capsule. It's about so much more than just Evita's grave!. See photos and a description of my walk through the cemetery at: http://antonio1028.wordpress.com/2009/12/13/links-to-the-past/
Well worth a visit, but take a local guide. Absolutely fascinating place, steeped in history and politics.
3 hours tour, during daylight, take your camera!. Great place to take good pictures if you are practicing photography. Perspective, close ups, light and darkness, etc.

Never thought I'd like being in a cemetery. Wooooooowwwwwww. I think that's the best word to describe it all. It just reminds me to old hystorical places I've seen in France. Beautiful art, it's so strange saying that..
interesting. If you are into visiting cementaries definitelly a place to not miss when in Buenos

Beautiful Sculptures. Recoleta Cemetery is like a city. The sculptures are BEAUTIFUL, and rival anything I've seen in Rome or Paris. It is also the resting place of major heros (mostly military) of Argentina. It is also a great place to take a book and just sit and read.

Unique concentration of family vaults. You will discover the history of Buenos Aires there. The rich side of it at least.Doctors, Génerals, Lawyers, Ministers and so on from the 18th to recent days have chosen to mark their presence on earth with a final touch that will be reminded for ever. Chosen ? Yes probably because the vault must cost a fortune to buy and to built (and to maintain).Some of them are subtled, most of them are pretentious and arrogant but the place is fantastic because of its unique density. You feel like you are visiting a city, where each small house shelter a family over centuries.Entrance is free. Take an umbrella with you in summer. It can be very sunny even though you can manage to find some shadow everywhere and then.
Not your average cemetery. I didn't see the point in visiting a cemetery- but this one is must see!! Absolutely incredible!
Never seen anything like it.. Definitely a must if you go to BA! Not so easy to find Eva Peron but searching was fun. You will always remember this place.

Interesting place. OK to visit for an hour or so, and it's free! Although Eva Peron's tomb is here in Recoleta, the Eva Peron Museum in Palermo is perhaps a more interesting place to spend some time in a nicer neighbourhood.

The best cemetery I have seen. It's amazing to see how gorgeous the tombs are. Just a walk around the cemetery will make you realize the amount of love (and money) people have showered on their dead-loved-ones. If you want to see Eva Peron's tomb, go all the way to the left (from the entrance) and take a right in the last big lane. Follow the hoards of tourists going there.

Beautiful. It may seem strange that a tour of the cemetery was a must, but honestly the free tour at 11 was a great experience. Out knowledgeable guide not only showed us the sites of famous historical figures like EvaPeeon, but provided a great review of Argentine history. You will be astonished at the elaborate architecture and statues. A cultural experience in a very unusual setting
Surreal. Fascinating. Totally over the top for the deceased!

Once in a lifetime. There are too many beautiful moments to experience in this lovely cemetery. We went very early on a sunny day and had the place to ourselves for the first couple hours. I never took so many pics of beautiful crypts, walkways and famous gravesides of the founding families, artists, politicians etc. Try to see it all, not just the Duarte family (Evita) crypt.
Spectacular Cemetery well worth a visit. Fantastic mausoleums with wealthy families trying to out-do each other. And the feral cats that are cared for and live there are great!
Truly a different experience. It is a cemetery but never depressing. A combination of family pride and plain showing off.

Peaceful, tranquil, but most taken by the felines and Canine. Like most tourists, we went to pay our respects to Evita, but that was the least memorable part of our walk around the cemetery. The cemetery is host to over 80 cats who have made a home there and we watches them almost guard over certain tombs. The Canine is named Sabu, and the statue of him with his master, tomb of Liliana Crociati de Szaszak, was a beautiful reminder of our connection to animals even after death.
Nice walk. Nice walk to view the cemetary. It was a hot day so bring water. Gets crowded with tour groups so plan accordingly.
INTERESTING. Very interesting and unique. The cats here need vet attention.
Definitely something to see. It is place worth taking a couple of hours to go see!!!

Good Architecture. We did not stay here long since we wanted to the cemetery, since it is a very famous one. When we entered we were surprised to see such big contructions. Each of the big construction is dedicated to several members of a single family. So if you look closely you will find stairs leading down. All of the architectural work done on the cemetery is worth visiting. The place is very well maintained.

Highly recommended and a tour guide is a must!. My wife and I went to see Recoleta Cemetery which is definitely a must if you are in Beunos Aires.We were very lucky as we came across a great tour guide at the entrance called Raul. We had a very long tour with Raul who gave us an extensive and very interesting overview of Argentina history and the various (and most impressive) monuments. I would urge you to take a tour guide as most of the people who visit the site only look for Evita Peron’s monument which is not that impressive in comparison to the entire site. Raul was able to take us to the right places and add the commentary and draw our intention to the details which are unique for each of the monuments.In a nutshell, highly recommended and a tour guide is a must! We personally highly recommend Raul who was very knowledgeable, personable and fun:Raúl Rivas Telch [--]

Very interesting. Loved spending time here wandering through and looking at all the different architectures and the entire look of the structures. Was a definite highlight of our time here and would recommend allowing at least an hour or so to see it.

Worth visiting. Free to visit, i would recommend visiting here. The main attraction is the tomb of Eva Peron but there are many other impressive tombs to see. Recommend getting a map to find the tomb easier!

Lots of hype to see Evita Perons tomb. Thankfully it's free to walk in La Recoleta cemetary to see Eva Peron's tomb. She is buried in the Duarte family tomb with engraved panels around the tomb with her picture. The cemetary is interesting to walk around. It reminds me of the cemetary in New Orleans.
Extraordinary city of the dead. Well worth seeing - it's not just Eva Peron's last resting place.More herehttp://alisonontheroad.blogspot.com/2012_01_01_archive.html
Interesting walk. Definitely worth checking out! Just be mindful of the closing times to avoid disappointment, it is not open all day long!
A must. This is a place not to miss. Get the guide book or take an organised tour with a guide, then wander round on your own and admire the statues and mausoleums of the rich and famous.

Argentine glamour. It sounds weird to find pleasure from walking around a cemetery but the heavy art déco style of the mausoleums and the fact that there lie the founders of the city make it a great place to get a feel of Buenos Aires.

Truly bizarre. Get anybody to describe a cemetary to you, and they will not come up with the Recoleta Cemetary in a thousand years. it's like a city dedicated to the dead; a luxurious city, too. Absolutely incredible, and a definite must-visit when you're in Buenos Aires.

Could easily spend hours here.. Admittance to the Recoleta Cemetery is free; although the maps which are sold for 8 pesos (less than $2) are a good idea if planning to spend any amount of time there. As well,free guided hour long tours (in English, Spanish) are offered during the week for those who only want to hit the highlights of the Cemetery. Come prepared for lots of walking - and during the summer - for very hot temperature without much shade, water, a hat and sunblock are needed.

MUST SEE. I was blown over by the absolutely grand buildings that housed the family coffins. Sounds weird to want to visit this first, but these were built to be admired. The grand doors, stained glass, monuments, marble, granite, sandstone, sculpture, gold leaf etc...mini grand mansions. The stories that go with are fascinating, ironically Evita is located in a non descript family crypt

Ok, but purely for tourists.. This is a beautiful scenic place, steeped in Argentine history. However, the graves that are most popular are almost impossible to get near, let alone get a good photo of. Tour guides are necessary if you dont know much about Argentina but be careful who you choose because some of them speak very little quality english. Arrive earlyish and see if you can see the end of a tour and be selective, the good ones always have a crowd the bad ones just stand around a bit sorry looking. And there are rabid cats around every turn, which are a bit off putting. And dont bother with the graves of Evita et al, but a good tour guide will tell the fascinating stories of the likes of Rufina Gambaceres. Much more interesting!!

This is a strange place, but..... ...no trip to Buenos Aires would be complete without it. Go with a guide, go early in the day to beat the crowds, and the visit becomes a lesson in the culture and history of BA. Any good hotel will arrange a guide for you, and it is well worth the investment for an overview of the entire city. You can then spend the next few days revisiting the spots that looked good to you. A great trip!
Unusual mausoleum. Gigantic mausoleums abound in many styles. Impressive although some are run down. Row after row of monuments to the dead. Makes you think about being remembered.

Interesting cemetery.. This is different to the usual cemetery, no graves in the ground, only ornate vaults, tightly packed into a small area. Contains the remains of important people, most notably Eva Peron. A significant part of BA, so it should not be missed.
Strangely Appealing. If you have never visited one like it (e.g., Lachaise Cemetery in Paris), this is a "must see." It might make you more appreciative of life and ideas of how to live it!
Not much, I'd say; frankly: oversold!. I am not a fan ... oversold: they say you ought to go and see it ... I'd say: a better use of your time is the adjacent historic church.

A very spectacular cemetary. A wonderfully atmospheric and very moving place to visit , particularly on a blisteringly hot day. The architectural styles of the vaults are amazing, from the gothic to a modern one that looks rather like a ATM machine! There were a couple of sites for sale when we were there, It was tempting! It would be a lovely place to end your days. Look out for the feral cats. They've usually found the shadiest places. The church nearby is lovely too.
I never thought a cemetery could be that interesting. This palce can show you how rich Argentinians were a generation ago.

Get the tour to make this meaninful. This is an amazing trove of history, intrigue and Argentinian culture, but you should get a guided tour. It comes alive. We had Pablo Guzman of Cultura Cercana tell us the stories behind the crypts and it was fantastic!

Not to be missed when visiting Bs As. If you enjoy getting a feel for local history and whose who by checking out tomb stones, then the cemetery will occupy an entire day for you. Right in the center of the city, incredible masoleums. On Sundays there is a major flee market just adjacent and the Buenos Aires Design Center is right here as well. A real city hot spot.
Amazing Gravesites. An drawing art class could be held in Recoleta Cemetery. So many interesting mausoleum structures.
Very ornate. Even if you're just there to seek out Eva Peron's grave, the other crypts are so detailed and decorative, it's hard not to poke around. It's worth a detour.

Nice area of Buenos Aires and glad we wandered round the cemetery. It was quite funny as we felt most were like us and seeking the famous grave of Eva Peron but too embaressed to ask, may be worth taking a guide as quite rightly there are no signs.

That was different. I could not understand why a cemetery was such a tourist attraction. It was not until after going there - a stop on our tour with our guide - that I appreciated it. It was very unique and filled with history and culture. It's worth the visit.

We would never thing we get exited about cementary. It's like a small city, but instead of houses it's all thombs. Some quiet big. The iron work and stone work is amazing. This is where the prominent Argrntinians rest. Including Eva Peron. Don't miss.

Amazing graveyard architecture. Another must-see place in Buenos Aires. The grave stones in the Recoleta Cemetery are just so unique and the stories behind them are fascinating. I highly recommend a visit to this place with an informed guide. Here are my photos from the visit to the Recoleta Cemetery: https://www.facebook.com/media/set/?set=a.10150374715791091.348013.300778126090&type=3
A must see for the historic value.. Mausoleums are crowded together, but famous and infamous people are buried here.
Evita's tomb is here. It's an architecture fortress. See the many tombs for the old argentinian families and of course, Evita's. It's a must see.

Do not limit your visit to one tomb!. This cemetery is definitely very interesting, but I would suggest to plan your visit carefully: it can be very crowded! From our hotel, just in front of it, we could see on a tuesday morning dozens of buses loaded with tourists. They were driven like sheep to Eva Peron's tomb as if this was the only place worth a visit there. This is crazy. The cemetery contains dozens of beautiful family tombs and monuments, worth an hour's walk through the narrow alleys. Poke your nose through the glass doors of the chapels (many of which are by now totally abandoned) and look at the coffins exposed in plain view, not buried in vaults. Most of the visitors do not even realise this. When you leave the cemetery, or before visiting it, do not miss the splendid annexed church of Nuestra Señora del Pilar (completed in 1732 by the Franciscan "Recoletos" friars), one of the most historical and elegant churches in town, and its fine museum.

hightlight of argentina. Wow for my 1st time I surely enjoyed this cementery. Its not what I expected...I thought it was going to be old/ugly but omg what a suprise I got. Such beautiful scultpures and seeing where evita is buried was worth the trip. Weird to say but its a nice way to spend a hr or 2 strolling and looking who else is buried there. Def a must do!!!! The cementary is easily accessible by local bus/train....bring an appetite there's tons of places to eat in this ritzy town. No cost to enter but ofcourse donations are always welcomed. Also there's random cats walking around which I luv.
Wow. If you have been to Pere La Chaise in Paris and you think why see this, don't miss it. With it's daunting tombs and alley after alley of monuments it's really incredible,

Interesting and very impressive.... I have visited a lot of churches and cemetaries during my trips - but this is one of the most impressive ever. The monuments are more or less all in marmol and the great skills of the artists who did the work is easy to tell. There are a lot to see and experience, but most of all the tomb of "Evita" - Eva Peron.Before visiting the cemetery I recommend:Read the story of Eva Peron on the internet - very impressive and absolutely making the visit better.When you enter the cemetery, on your left, all the cemetery is shown on a board. Don't look for Eva Peron - as you will never find ! She is listed under her maiden name, which is Duarte. Then it's only af 5 min. walk from the entrence to the place. If you want the story of the area and Eva, then you can join a guide who shows you around giving you a lot of information.It is, to me, a must go - to see the final resting place for "Evita", and you easily spend more than an hour walking through the area.

Beautiful Architecture in a Peaceful Setting. People go here because Evita is buried here. However, visiting it is a study in architecture and sculpture and people's lives. I especially enjoyed photographing the many angels. Each grave site is an architectural work of art. It is kept up very well. Well worth the visit. I wish there was a booklet on the cemetery.
Fun to explore. Amazing effort has been placed into countless tombs in Recoleta Cemetery.
Take a step into history and spirituality. Well worth your time! beautiful and very different from what you would expect of a cemetery.

Interesting couple of hours. Recoleta Cemetery is a interesting place to spend a couple of hours wandering through Argentine's history pages.Grab a map from the "tour guide" just inside the entrance for a guide to whose who and where they lay inside. Lots of stray cats who I believe are fed quite well.However unless you are well briefed on Argentinian whose who then the cemetery is not as interesting for the general tourist as it would be for those more keen on this type of "city highlight".There are some nice cafes across the park from the cemetery where you can enjoy some people watching. Make sure you check out the enormous tree on the edge of the cafe strip - its literally the biggest tree that I have ever seen! Watch out for bag snatchers - we were warned by a friendly local lady to not hang our bags over the back of the chairs - obviously a silly thing but sometimes you just forget to be careful!

Fascinating. It is true that it costs more to die Buenos Aires then to live. This is the most spectacular cemitary I have ever seen. We frequently visit at least one cemitary everywhere we go because they are peaceful and interesting. You can see who the promenant families were.
Must do. If you come to Buenos Aires you must do the free trip to the cemetary. Evita lies there but it is the fantastic array of mausoleums that attracts.
Historical place. Interesting and historical place. You could even find Evita´s grave, just remember that her last name was Duarte (not Peron)

A day between life and death. I liked very much.: the statues are great and the cemetery is very clean. One thing: Evita Peron corp is not in the grave, anymore, but were translated to another cemetery.
It not disturb your sleep. I filled like walking in a city. It´s different from brazilian cemeteries.

A must see. If you are going to Buenos Aires, you must visit the cemetery. I recommend going on a Saturday because there is a very nice art and craft market right outside the entrance to the cemetery. We happened to find an English speaking touguide, that gave the 2 of us a private tour for only 90 pesos. I recommend a guide. The cemetary is a maze and can be overwhelming. The guide filled us in on all the wonderful back stories. Plus the guide knew exactly where to go, so in about an hour we saw all the key things in the cemetery.

One of the world's most amazing cemeteries. The big draw is Evita Peron's grave site -- her is beautiful, but understated compared to many of the sites here. That said, this entire cemetery is a work of art. There are dozens of huge, staggeringly beautiful mausoleums, and you could spend hours wandering through the rows of gravesites. The cemetery is free, but there are "volunteers" outside who will draw you a map and talk to you for a few minutes, then ask for a donation to a local charity. We got caught by one of these volunteers, who have name tags and look official, and we were guilted into donating. You can walk right by them if you want, because the cemetery is free. You can also purchase a map of the cemetery for 8 pesos, but it is not really necessary. The main sites are easy to find, there is a large map just inside the main gate, and you can find Evita easily by following the crowds.

An interesting place to explore. Recoleta Cemetery was an interesting place to explore. I advise purchasing the map, that was offered to us as we entered, 8peso. It highlights the graves of note and was useful when we wanted to navigate our way back to the entrance. But don't just wander to points of interest, and from one famous crypt to another. Spend some time, look up - there are some impressive statuary on top of some of the crypts, look in - there are some beautiful shrines and stained glass windows within some, and look down as in some of the crypts you can see into the basements containing ornate and fabric draped coffins. Its an amazing place, this city for the dead.

Definitely worth a visit. Spend an hour wandering around this amazing cemetery. Play homage to Eva Peron's grave if you like, but there are much more interesting graves to see, along with lots of cats!
You must visit. No visit to Buenos Aires would ever be complete without a visit to Recoleta Cemetary. You must visit the Duarte's family crypt that house Eva Peron.

Home of Evita. The cemetery is good and impressive but everybody visiting there just only for Evita. Othervise who likes to visit the cemetery in a touristic trip? But.... Evita's small.. room was impressive. You will feel like touching her...

Recoleta cemetery - peaceful location. Really enjoyed the visit to Recoleta cemetery where Eva Peron's tomb is located. Very impressive tombs if you like that sort of thing and nice and peaceful away from the crowds of BA
Huge place, small Eva Peron shrine. The cemetery is full of the tombs of the rich and not so rich of BA but the place all people go to is the final resting place of Eva Peron and then they're off.

let your self go. Just relax and wander around. If it rains, even better (of course have an umbrella with you) for the mood of the pictures. Argentinians say: you can be as rich and powerful as you like, but if don't get buried in La Recoleta, you didn't make it.
Eva Peron's burial site.. Amazing experience--above ground family memorial buildings with every form of sculpture and style in evidence.

It's a must see.. No visit to Buenos Aires would be complete without a trip to the world famous Recoleta Cementary. Our guide took us to the very pretty church first, and then we took a visit where we learned of the past wealth, the choices of crypts and why..these monuments are incredible works of art and architecture. Suprisingly there was a funeral the day we were there. The guide said that was most unusual to see, as it would be a very rich family indeed who could afford to keep up the maintenance on a particular family crypt. Of course we went to Eva Peron's family "Duarte" crypt. It's a fascinating history. We're glad we had a guide to discuss this interesting aspect of Argentine culture.
Wonderful!. Beautiful, historic cemetery, in stylish Recoleta! Although Evita's tomb is not spectacular, it is surrounded by "little streets", full of amazing, major BA family crypts to see.

Weird...but interesting!. On my last sunday in BA I hiked over to Plaza Francia to check out the flea market and the cemetary. Touring a cemetary sounds a little strange, but this is where all of the famous Argentinian generals & politicians are buried. The place is humongous and is unlike any other cemetary I have ever been in (keep in mind I have limited experience, luckily!) Be sure to check out Evita's grave, even though it is quite inconspicuous.

Eva Evita Peron. You have most likely not seen anything like this ever. Very impressive. It is a cemetary, so show respect for mourning locals, and in return get a chance to 'just be' for 1 hour in the middle of Buenos Aires.
Disappointment. Not as interesting as advertised. All marble dark monumemts similar to each other.
Don't miss this place. It is unique.. Each crypt is different. It's a remarkable place Having a good local guide who can explain things was a big help.

above ground? interesting artistic burial sites. well worth a visit, regardless where and how many other interesting cementries u may have seen already between Vienna - Austria, Pula - Croatia, havana - Cuba, etc. ......

just a cemetery. I really don't get this one. Recoleta is one of the most beautiful neighbourhoods in Buenos Aires and you should definetly take the time to go there... but the cemetery, well it is just a cemetery. You can enter and see Evita's grave, maybe take a picture and that's it.

NICE DAY TRIP. Wonderful day trip - but be ready to get lost in a maze of tombstones.
Be sure to stop by the butterfly garden next door.

Lots of photo opportunities. Grand cemitery that reflects the past wealth of Argentina. Lots of beautiful sculptures and even if some of the graves/monuments are not in a good state of repair many are and all look wonderful in their own way.
A few stray cats add on to the experience!
well worth a visit.

Not worth it. Just went to see Evita tomb really. Wasn´t worth it apart from good steak sandwich outside the gates.
Full of graves for overly rich show offs.
Art. Visiting a cemetery gives us some idea of how its people live and die. Some good funerary art, an exotic cemetery, not to miss, though I expected a bit more

Not Your Average Cemetery. Hard to believe a cemetery would be at the top of the "must see" list, but this one is very unique with elaborate monuments, and of course the "Familia Duarte" with Evita Peron. It's big and very confusing if you don't have a guide, so don't try to figure it out on your own. Can see the highlights in an hour, and then explore the rest of Recoleta.

A nice place to see Eva Peron's grave...and that's about it. What can you say, it's a cemetery. Kind of interesting architecture but not much else going on. You could skip it and still feel like you weren't missing much.

Sweaty but worth it!. On Tuesdays and Thursdays there are free tours in English at 11 a.m. The tour was very thorough and included a lot of historical facts and stories of the dead. While it was 100 F we still were able to find some shade while listening but I recommend bringing a bottle of water. You can also get some great shots if you go upstairs (5 pesos) in the church next store.
The best cemetery. It's supposed to be better that "Le Père Lachaise" in Paris. It's lovely. It's very big and very clean.It's beautiful!

Cry for me, Argentina!. Again, there is significant historical perspective to be gained by visiting the various areas of the Recoleta Cemetary and learning who is venerated (or not) and why. Of course, the most popular location in the cemetery is the tomb of the Duarte family (Evita Peron). Kind of underwhelming when you get there, given the crowds searching for the tomb in the cemetery. However, the stories of the "body snatching" and body swaps to get the remains of Evita back was worth the trip.
Very interesting. I've never seen anything like this. Grand burial site. You can see Evita's tomb. It's very interesting if you've never been to anything similar.

A must see while in Buenos Aires. I took a tour of the cemetery with a tour company and really enjoyed the history of the president's, Evita and other key figures that shaped Argentina. It rained the day we went, so we got a little wet but still fun
Stunning and Spooky. Well worth a walk around. Fascinating insight into Argentine society. Well kept and interesting. Take advantage of the guides.. they are helpful.

excellent. This place is amazing! It's definitely a must see in Buenos Aires. I have never seen people be so elaborate with their head stones. Some of these are almost as big as some smaller churches - you really have to see it to believe it!

A must see if you are in Buenos Aires. It may seem a bit macabre to some but visiting this cemetery is very normal. Walking between the mausoleums and seeing all the beautiful art is quite an experience. Of course, you must see the mausoleum of Eva Duarte (better known to us as Evita)

Fantastic cemetery. Truly a great place to visit. quiet, peaceful and amazing. I never thought i'd be so curious to see what's around the corner at a cemetery, but this cemetery did this to me. I liked exploring the site and discovering fantastic family plots. Strangely enough is the site of Evita Perron difficult to find and even more difficult to have for yourself ;-)
Like no other you have EVER seen. But then, who goes to a cemetery when on vacation.This place is over the top! 2700 vaults - every one is different and each is a family tradition.

City of the Dead. A must see. This city of the dead is amazing. The crypts are in varying states from very well kept to decaying. It gives a different insight to the culture. The famed Eva Peron has found her resting place here. Go first thing in the morning before the tours start arriving and you will have the place to yourself!
Evita's tomb. Every body wants to see only the Evita's tomb, but a guided visit will surprise you.
Worth a visit. Go first thing in the morning for no lines to see the historical cemetery of the rich and famous including Eva Peron.
Impressive. It is really impressive to see the cemetery, however, there are more cementeries like Recoleta in Buenos Aires. So the main attraction is the grave of Evita Perron.

Cemetary Tour. I went to the cemetary as part of an excursion with my Spanish school, Ìbero Spanish, and we had a guided tour of the whole place. It is so much better doing it with a guide, who can explain the stories behind many of the graves. There are a lot of photo opportunities too. The star attraction is, of course, the grave of Eva Peron, and is definately worth a visit!

Morbidly Fascinating. This cemetery is especially interesting to non-Catholics. A must-see if you have a couple of hours spare. All the better if you can commandeer a tour guide to take you to the most important mausoleums, because there are many fascinating stories to be told. There are even toilets for the public!

Simply unbelievable. My family loved visiting this cemetery!! Sounds strange, but we were simply bowled over by the sheer size of these family crypts and the display of wealth. Unbelievable is the only way I can desribe it. Magnificent statues and marble carvings ect.

No place like it in the world! fantastic to see in Buenos Aires!. Loved going to the Recoleta Cemetery! We have been here a couple of times and there is always a different aspect to look at- it is such a large cemetery right in the middle of the city. It is best on a Saturday or Sunday because the markets are happening outside in the plaza (park)- I LOVE the Recoleta markets!You can get guides Spanish or English speaking which is inexpensive and will give you a good insight- these can be group or private guides. But I found it best just walking around myself and peaking in to the catacombs- you see the coffins so up close! spooky and cool!

Cool to See Graves?. The best part about visiting the cemetary, is the stories behind the families who have lived and are buried there.If you don't speak Spanish, be sure to get a guide or join one of the large tours. Its worth the small price. And the whole point is so that you find out the local perspective and the history behind the cemetary.Its interesting to see the various monuments, "Evita's" included, but after an hour it loses its lustre.The cemetary is a must see if touring the city, especially if staying in the Recoleta area; but it was definately not the highlight of my week stay in Buenos Aires. My wife and I have never said "Remember the Cemetary?"
Overrated. I'm not a fan of cementaries. This one is set in a beautiful part of Buenos Aires. You can go in, walk a bit and go out!
For those who like .... It is a traditional visit when in BA, for those who like to go to cemeteries. The tour lasts about 2 hours and you can visit the grave of Evita, Carlos Gardel and others.

Interesting but do a tour!. I went with friends and we aimlessly wandered through the cemetery. While this was interesting enough, we overheard several tour groups while we were walking and wished we had done the tour! The guides have many stories about the families and people buried in the cemetery and I think it would be worth the extra cost to learn and really understand the history of the place than just walking around alone.

The most magnificent man made place I've ever been. The most magnificent man made place I've ever been. I say this on multiple levels. The craftsmanship, the devotion of the families, the historical aspects. There is no charge to enter.If you go to BA do NOT miss out on this!

Not To Be Missed.. This nearly six hectare cemetery is the resting place of national heroes (e.g. Eva Peron), presidents, politicians, military persons, scientists, artists and celebrities. Located in the bustling Recoleta neighborhood, the lovely cemetery offers a calm and peaceful respite. At the gate, free tours are offered in various languages. I would recommend a tour as there are many, many interesting stories.

step back in time. like many famous cemeteries, walking among mausoleums, pretending to be in the 1900 its a good experience. the guided tour is really worth it as they tell stories of the ones buried there famous and not so famous.
closed. really? come on, stretch your hours... and all the other stuff in the reoleta area was craaaap...

A sumptuous cemetery that will leave you in aw. More than a cemetery, this place resemble an open air museum with tombs like little buildings and beautiful statues disseminated along the grid system paths.
Like the majority of the visitors, I was attracted there by Evita's tomb, finding out that it is only a disappointment, compared to many others beautiful ones.

Historic cemetery in the middle of the city. The Recoleta Cemetery is located in heart of the Recoleta section of Buenos Aires. There are 3200 mausoleums on 14 acres. It is incredible. And of course this is where Eva "Evita Peron is entombed.

Recoleta Cemetery Well Worh a Visit. I liked everything about the cemetery. The whole place is full of large family burial tombs, all elaborate. Of course I made a pilgrimage to the Duarte family tomb, where Santa Evita is buried, apparently about five feet down so as to prevent anyone from seeing the preserved body under glass. Blame it on the Generals, so one of the guides announced. They were afraid of cult worship. Sixty years after her death, Evita has outlasted the Generals. She presides, literally and figuratively, over the beautiful city of Buenos Aires.

An interesting experince.. Plan on spending asbout 45 minutes or so. It[s right outside the main shopping district so plan onwalking to the cemetary at the same time. Quite interesting to Eva Peron's mausoleum.

Absolutely great historical place - a must see. A must see .First of all; bring a camera or you'll regret it. This place is amazing.. Buy a little map at the entrance, it's handy. The cemetery is huge, and there are so many beautiful sculptures and architecture, you can wander around for several hours. If in doubt where to find Evita's grave, look for a queue of tourists: there it is!One of the sculptures that were really moving, is that of a pretty girl and her dog.According to the story, she was missing. Her family, friends and the police looked for her, and in the search, her dog disappeared as well. So they made this wonderful piece of art in honor of their friendship. On Sundays there's a artisanal market on the plaza nearby, good for souvenirs.We enjoyed some nice free concerts there on weekends, surrounded by locals, just hanging out in the park, enjoying the sunshine, music and good company.

Aged opulent cemetery - surrounded by the city. I enjoyed wandering the aisles of the cemetery. Locating Evita's grave. The crumbling old mausoleums -showed the old grandeur of Buenos Aires. Mahogany caskets could be seen through chinks in the wall and hundreds of cats wandered about. A fascinating and beautiful place
Where people die to go. Interesting to see centuries old monuments and shrines, family traditions for loved ones. Everything has to end no matter what.

Unique. Fascinating. Calming.. I lived around the corner from the Recoleta Cemetery for 3 months. Yes it's touristy, but you can always find a row of mausoleums that's void of people. In a city where it seems like everyone is constantly rushing around--where are they all going???--the cemetery is a welcome respite -- quiet and peaceful. The endless tombs are always interesting to look at and photograph. You can give a donation to the people at the entrance but you don't have to.

historically insteresting. I grew up in Argentina, and I therefore find Recoleta fascinating because you basically "meet" all the heroes of Argentinean history, it's like a history lesson in school! Not sure how interesting this might be for tourists that are not that familar with the country's history.... Most people go to see Evita's grave, which is kind of hard to find actually. But take your time and stroll around and ge ta feeling for this place. Still, as said, I believe the more familiar you are with the country's history the more you will enjoy it, as you'll recognize so many names!
Interesting. Good place to visit, easy to spot Eva Peron's resting place by the huge crowds..

A place with lots of art!. We visited the cemetery, and we must say it is one of the most beautiful after that of Paris, the statues are beautiful, the art that is seen is very artistic and care Argentines have with this place is awesome. All tourists must visit.
Intesting. Very interesting. Visited the tomb of Eva Peron. Must take water if visiting during summer.
Wow. Seeing this place is a must for a visit to BA. The size of some of the graves is impressive and the sheer size of the cemetary is amazing.

Very Interesting, Hire a guide to help navigate. We visited with a guide, which made it much more manageable to see the cemetery. Very interesting and some beautiful crypts. I would definitely visit the cemetery and use a guide.
Must See!. This is a classic attraction in Buenos Aires. Go on a Sunday so you can buy gifts for your friends and family at the nearby flea market in Plaza Francia.

Just like Cimitero Monumentale in Milan. Most people come for Evita Duarte-Peron. Try to learn and distinguish between the myth that has been created in the US and Argentina and reality. Besides, or despite (depending on your historical knowledge and opinion), Evita – this is very interesting place and is of great historical value. It is a look inside Buenos Aires society, its origins and beliefs. It is almost Milan’s Cimitero Monumentale recreated. This in itself tells a lot of who matters in this city.

A fascinating glimpse into Argentinian history. A fascinating glimpse into Argentina's history! See the graves of famous personalities like Eva Peron and previous presidents as well as those of families wealthy enough to afford large, impressive tombs elaborately decorated. Spend a couple of hours wandering around the walkways examining the variety of tombs.

A Must See. A great place to wander about and find such interesting tombs and treasures. Just outside the walls is a fabulous flea market, tango dancers and it is surrounded by great places for coffee and snacks as you watch the world go by.
Evita's Final Resting Place. This is a very interesting thing to do in BA. See Evita's mausoleum along with other interesting gravesites.
city of the dead. A fascinating look into the lives of Buenos Aires' privileged class. We particularly liked the tomb of a famous boxer.
fun. it's free and you can wander - but probably best to go with a guide. you could get lost, but you also wouldn't get all the stories.

Unique experience. The compact size and central location make it very easy to take in this cemetery. Many mausoleums and crypts have artistic or historic value, but some are in disrepair. Go early, because they close at 5:30 or so. A half hour gives you a good impression, but you can easily spend two hours or more, especially if you want to take pictures.
Must See....... We went to a few cemeteries throughout Argentina...and this was the most striking. Not as colorful as some in the Salta region..but the opulence and experience here is second to none.

A maze of impressive mausoleums!. There is indeed so much more than Evita Perón stone. Most of the mausoleums are quite impressive. I suggest you ask right from the start where she is so you won't be finding all the cemetery around for her. Nothing indicates where she is, apart from at the entrance. I recommend this walk in early afternoon, with a walk to Palermo for an afternoon snack, or even supper.
Cemetery where Evita Peron is buried. I'm a sucker for cemeteries, and this one has all the fancy tombs and crypts one could wish for, plus is the mecca for people who are Evita sightseeing.

Interesting Place on a Nice Day. It is like visiting a small town where everybody is dead. The mausoleums range from the magnificent to the slightly bizarre. Of course, like everybody, you have to pay a stop at the Duarte family mausoleum to see the final resting spot of Evita Peron.
a great walk through time. a wonderful way to spend an afternoon! After lunch a stroll through time in this beautiful relic.
interesting place to visit. what an interesting place to visit, different than what you would expect, reminded me of being in rome and pompeii
The land of the dead!. This was definitely worth seeing- although a little morbid, it was quite a grand place to visit, especially when comparing with your standard cemetry!

Definitely worth seeing. I'm normally not into visiting cemeteries even the famous ones like in Paris but this is worth the visit. Take the free guided tour if you can. It's very informative and less hectic than figuring things out on your own.
weird but a must see.... it was weird walking around and taking pics of the cemetery but quite memorable...

So cool, and there is SO much more than Evita here. Would highly recommend splurging for a private tour guide to learn all there is to the amazing cemetery. Very unique place, learned a lot about BA history and culture visiting here.

The Cemetary. This was a spectacular unusual look at the histories of some of the families of Buenos Aires. We did visit Eva Peron's tomb although we were fortunately told she was buried under her family name, not Peron
Not much to see. Doable attraction because it is free and near center with cafes& museums nearby. Lot of mauseloums, few trees, not much to see
wonderful experience. It was peaceful and the architecture was fascinating. It was very enjoyable.
Eva Duarte. exciting to see the tomb where Eva Peron's body-supposedly-is.
Atmospheric. Interesting to wander around following the map otherwise you could get lost or go round in circles .Fresh flowers are put every day at the Masoleum of Eva Peron.

Must see. A real jewel.. I wasn't expecting this at all. Rows and rows of graves/mausoleums documenting the history of Argentina. While some might just go to see the resting place of Eva Peron, you would do well to linger longer and absorb this jewel.
Obligatory stop on even a short visit to Buenos Aires. Evita and much more to see here. You will need a guide or a good guide book to make the most of it.
Quirky and worth a visit. Unusual cemetery - worth a visit to search for Eva Peron's tomb.

Creepy and cool. I've never seen a cemetery like this in the middle of one of the fanciest neighborhoods in the city and surrounded by restaurants and a craft faire. Definitely come on a weekend when you can browse the faire, wander through the opulence of these homages to Argentinian greats, and then get some touristy, but good food. Munich is one of the nearby restaurants and was highly recommended.

Interesting place if you like cemeteries. This is a good hour stroll. Some people might not like the idea of walking round a graveyard, but if you are interested in history and monumental architecture it is worth a visit.

Must see. This is a must see. The architecture is amazing and you can spend a short time here or all day. There was a girl selling a map and information booklet for 8 pesos at the front-which we bought and carried with us. The big draw is Eva Peron's tomb-but there are many that are more interesting than hers. Take the time to do a little research on the internet prior to visiting and then spend some time walking around. One thing is there is someone charging to use the restroom-unsure if they were legit or just camped out there asking for money.We also toured the church that is attached. It was very interesting.

A "must see" attraction in BA - which will give you a sense for the history of this great city. This is a must-see for any tourist or business traveller to Buenos Aires, even if you only have 30 minutes to spare.It is free to enter.The cemetry will give you a sense for the class, style and grandeur of this city (not only from its former heydays, but also in its future potential given the current boom in agricultural/mineral exports). Many of the tombs and edifices of what are essentially the aristocracy and leaders of Argentina/BA are truly magnificent (Eva Peron’s included).The Recoleta cemtery certainly ranks up there with eg the American war cemetery in Normandy in terms of “impressiveness” of cemeteries. It is also located within the posh district of Recoleta – which reminds me of the Upper East side of Manhattan – so you might also enjoy the adjoining park and then strolling along Avenues Alvear and Posadas.

Beautiful and not morbid. Went there on a sunny tuesday afternoon and it was as crowded as Jardin Japonés, a good park not far from there.It is a very organized cemetery, for the rich and powerful in Argentina, with dozens of president's burial grounds. Nonetheless, a first lady rests in the most important tomb: Eva Perón. The most loved first lady in Argentina's history remains are in a quite humble place, when compared to the other ones, her father's family (Duarte) mausoleum.In a sunny day, it's so enlightened and, fresh from the trees in the main street, that you almost forget it is a cemetery. Not the most important attraction in Buenos Aires, but surely worth a visit. Entrance is free and you pay eight pesos (less than two dollars) for the cemetery map, and its profit is used to preserve the place.
Absolutely gorgeous!. This place is unlike any cemetery in Canada or the States! Fabulous free attraction with such beautiful statues & structures!

Evita?. The cementery is big and finding her grave can be difficoult. There is an oversight just inside the gate to your left but jo have to know what her familiy name is. Evita was married Perone but was born Duarte. So if you want to visit her grave look for det name Duarte Family.

An architectural delight. This is a MUST SEE stop on your visit to Buenos Aires. Yes, Eva Peron is entombed here but Recoleta is so much more. Filled with rows and rows of stunningly deisgns mausoleums, you will be awed by the craftsmanship of the works of art in this cemetary. A defiinite stop for art and architecture lovers. There will be young men outside the entrance trying to give you a map for a "donation" to some seemingly worthwhile cause - but use your own judgement. You don't need a map to appreciate the beauty here and just follow the crowds to Evita's mausoleum (one of the least imposing on the site).
Recoleta Cemetary. A surprisingly beautiful haven in the heart of Recoleta where you can view the elegant tombs of the rich and famous, including Evita.

Definitely a Must see when you are in Buenos Aires. It's located in Recoleta. Only a few minutes walk from Recoleta Mall. The cemetery has an interesting and amazing feel. When we walked in, there was a lady who showed us the map and asked us to buy a brochure for 8 pesos. I think that was fine as the money will support the cemetery itself and she was very nice.

Interesting, but overly touristy!. Everyone should probably visit the Recoleta Cemetery, but it is has become so touristy and commercial. I recommend the Chacarita Cemetery over this one. It is equally as impressive and a more unique experience.

A cemetery...without rest. The only place we got hassled at all, in BA, was in the vicinity of this tourist (trap) attraction... nothing malicious, but people asking for donations, and staff outside eatery's stepping up with "special vouchers" trying to steer the tourist $ into their establishment... The cemetery itself, is just that. And Evita's tomb marked by a plaque with her name. I am more interested in life in BA now.

Amazing sculptures. The really nice thing about Recoletta cemetary is that it is the sort of attraction that could take up a whole afternoon, or even just 20 minutes. The majority of tourist snap pictures of the larger tombs and then get lost looking for Evita´s (can be tricky as there are no signs pointing towards its direction), but you can really explore the whole grounds and find many small inscriptions or ancient poems dedicated to the dead. I also recommend visiting on a saturday or sunday so you will have the opportunity to check out the market in recolleta (feria) that is the largest and most diverse in Buenos Aires.
Nostalgic. Eclectic and needs more maintainance. Location in downtown denotes its importance to the 'platino' community.
Awesome. In the "Plaza Francia," the Recoleta cemetary is truly amazing. It is like a city. They also do a free tour which was quite good as well. Definitely hit this up!

The most pleasant place to stroll in BsAs.. Despite being a cemetery, there is a very pleasant and nice atmosphere at this historical place, where some of the most prominent argentines are resting "in peace". Beautiful esculptures and free entrance as well. Certainly a must.

Most interesting place I've been in a long time.. This is a must see in Buenos Aries ... We ended up going to see it 2 days in a row...I love taking photographs and really enjoyed the beauty of the architecture of this place. So much history and beauty in one place. It is very special and worth seeing.

So interesting !. I like cemetereries anyway, but this one was fascinating. I was fortunate to be able to participate in the free English language tour, which, if I remember correctly, is Tues and Thurs at 11:00.
Interesting place to wander. Not typically a fan of cemetaries - I did found this very interesting and enjoyable.
Interesting Place. Must see in BA. Even more interesting than other above-ground cemeteries because of the diverse and elegant architecture of the tombs.

Must see!. The cemetery has a lot of history and the stories about the dead are quite fascinating. There are over 6,500 graves and you could spend an entire day looking at each one. We stayed about an hour and it was enough time.
