Beautiful. Was nice, really pretty. Looks like the Père-Lachaise cemetary in Paris, only I feel like it's bigger and better!

Worth a visit. Really interesting place to spend an hour or so. It really shows the history with some interesting memorials to major political and other events.Eva Peron's tomb is nothing special, but the locals love having their photo taken there. There are far more interesting and amazing tombs to look at.Entry is cheap, but definitely take the bug spray with you. One of the lovely parks inside the cemetary was a haven for mosquitoes.

Great on weekends. The cemetery is free so it's great to just go for a walk and see all the mausoleums. On weekends, there's a great fair to just browse through. It has local artisan crafts and jewelry.

Must see Cemetery. This was my second time in BA and my hotel was only 5 blocks from this historic cemetery. The cemetery is so large that I felt I didn't get to see enough the first visit two years before so back in I went. First off, a great value as it is free entry. There was a lady selling cemetery maps at the entrance. At first I declined but then I found out it was for the cemetery restoration and only $2. Can't beat that and want to give a little back to the places I visit. A great place to wander alone in and out of the different alleyways. First time I visited Eva Peron gravesite but not this time, too many people and there are many other graves to see and take time with. Really a must see and give yourself a lot of time (2-4 hours) if you are a photographer as a I am.
History lesson. Amazing history Have to visit the church so amazing and the overwhelming sense of peace

A must see in Buenos Aires. Very interesting place to checkout. It's like it's own little city! Very old, but well kept up, some of the tombs are big enough to be houses. You can see coffins exposed in some tombs, of eire but cool. Home to the resting place of Evita.Definitely worth checking out.
Must See!!!!. The Recoleta Cemetery blew me away! This is not to be missed!

Death can be Luxurious. Best statute garden in the world. Do not miss the English tours at 11am (check for day). Worth a couple of visits at different times of day for the varied lighting for photos. The Recoleta crafts market next door is on Saturdays.

Evita's Gravesite, a must see. Intriguing cemetery, reminiscent of Pere Lechase or New Orleans. Above ground sarcophagi abound; that there are still fresh flowers being put on the Duarte (Eva Peron's family name) grave site amazes me. Very interesting place.

A maze of crypts. The Recolleta cemetary is in the borough of the same name in central Buenos Aires. Most of the more important personages in Argentine history are interred here and you can wander through the lanes ways and see some of the most impressive statuary of any grave yard. All tourists to B.A. come here to see the crypt of Eve Peron, who still holds a soft spot in the average Argentine's heart. Aside from the rumors, she did have a good effect on society, all in favor of the working classes. If you come here, bear in mind that she is actually buried in the family crypt, Not the Peron crypt ... her family name is Duarte, so look for that name on the doorway. There will be map sellers at the entrance (free entry ... but beggars will ask for money) but don't buy one. Just follow the tourist groups and they will lead you directly to where you want to go to see the Duarte crypt. As for the rest ... just wander about and see what's there. Very interesting.

Beautiful. Absolutely beautiful.. Definitely a place one should visit in Buenos Aires -- best to go on a weekend when there are ferias around Recoleta -- artisenal booths selling a range of things, fresh smoothies and juices, home-made alfajors and other desserts. Often live music.The cemetery has some of the most incredible gravestones one could imagine. Sometimes it isn't even the most famous or influential people who have the most elaborate and incredible headstones. Some of the old-money families in Buenos Aires had incredible funds and their resting places explain the meaning of the old European phrase "As rich as an Argentine"

Don't Cry for me, Argentina.. Of course you are going there to see where Evita is buried. But read (if you paid attention to your college Spanish 101) the bronze plaque on the mausuleum. What does it say? "No me llores, Argentina." Now go back to your Spanish book and translate that phrase....Gracias, clase. (Sincerely, your college Spanish instructor).

Impressive!. The whole area of Recoleta is very charming, and a walk through the cemetery is obliged. It's impressive to see all the crypts from noble families, some of which are done in a beautiful art nouveau style.

One of the 2 best above ground cemeteries in BA. If you have never been to an above ground cemetery than this is the one to visit. Evita and many other famous Argentinians literally remain here and the atmosphere is quite surreal so it is worth the visit. Plus, it is one of the few areas in BA that is relatively trash and dog poo free so you can walk about without worry about what you may step into.

Fascinating history.... Interesting cemetery that's worth a visit. Most all of the Argentine founders and other war heroes are interred at Recoleta. Admission is free but a donation is accepted. Tons of feral cats running around the cemetery.

Extravagant but interesting. This contains the most elaborate mausoleums of some notable people that you are likely to see anywhere. Of course the Eva Peron grave is the main drwa and its hard to get past the crowds
Unique cemetery. Easy to get lost in this maze of tombs some of which are almost like small houses!

I just don't understand why this is so popular. Just like any cemetery in any big city, except it seems to have been the reserve of the rich, famous and military.
Visited on a Saturday, and I preferred the market just outside the cemetery walls, I would have been more disappointed if I had to pay to get in, thankfully it's free.

A MUST SEE if visiting Buenos Aires!. Taking photos on a sunny day in a Cemetery sounded a little strange to me. But, after being told we should visit this place countless times by locals and friends alike we decided to give in and check it out. We are so glad we did.  If your visiting Buenos Aires you must spend an hour or two at the Cemetery. Its worth it. Not only is it FREE (always a bonus) but it is also in a nice neighborhood to shop and dine after you explore.They highly recommend online that you get a guide but you do not need one at all. Its a nice sized cemetery but in no way will you get lost. I should restate that; your going to get lost and its kind of the appeal. But its pretty easy to find your way out. They have free maps at the entrance that mark the more significant people who reside there but not even that is needed. Its hard to describe other than its a beautiful, victorian cemetery for the wealthy and powerful. You can easily enjoy it in the span of an hour to two hours.
You definitely have to see Evita's tomb. The cementery is definitely a must see in Buenos Aires.. You definitely have to see Evita's tomb. The cementery is definitely a must see in Buenos Aires.

City of the Ostentatious Dead. Go to see Eva Peron's final resting and find the quintessential Argentine one-upmanship continues to beyond the grave, as a who-was-who of early Argentine society compete to build the most ostentatious memorial to have one last preen before their adoring public.

Good tour. The Recoleta Cemetery was an interesting place and on our tour we learned a lot about the history of Argentina as well as various important political and other famous people who are interred there. Our tour guide was excellent and the tour was free as we took the Spanish tour. (donations are accepted).

Like a city!. Visiting a cemetary as a tourist attraction is a bit weird, but this was in all the guidebooks so we had to go of course (at least to see Evita's tomb). The statues (graves) were magnificient, the place was huge, and the free tour was awesome. If you're expecting Evita's grave to be the most beautiful tombstone ever, you'll be sorely mistaken!

Forget Evita - explore a little.. What an amazing place, to see the detail and expense that has clearly gone in to these lasting tributes to family and friends is amazing. Free entry is great, but I bought a map from a very well spoken Argentine lady who had the most amazing English accent, apparently the money helps keep the place.I must say I expected more from Evitas plot, although it was mobbed pretty much all the time.
Beautiful. A place like no other. Beautiful architecture, a tranquil setting, and a unique experience.
Worth a visit. It is amazing just to walk around the rows and rows of these elaborate tombs, some even with stained glass windows.

Amazing!. I never thought in my life that I would see something quite this outstanding. If you are visiting BA and dont visit this cemetary then you are missing out. Full stop. Culturally different and incredible is about all i can say.

A little weird. Amazing to see the shrines that various people have built for their families but couldn't help but feel a little uncomfortable walking around here effectively looking at people's coffins! Part of every city tour so you probably won't have an option and you won't see anything like this in many places so worth seeing for that but just seemed strange seeing people taking pictures of people's graves.
Recoleta. Guide was marvellous in explaining the gravestones

One of the greatest cemetery in the Worl. The Recoleta cemetery was inaugurated on Nov 17,1822 becoming the first public cemetery in the city of Buenos Aires,and the most relevant historical monument of the country.The site of 54,843 sqm has 4,800 vaults.
Not easy to find Eva Peron's mausoleum. Relatively easy to find the cemetery, not well signposted to Eva Peron's mausoleum inside.

Evita Mausoleum. I have visited this place now on four occasions. The last time, i had plenty of time before I had to catch a plane so i was able to wander round many of the "streets" within the Cemetery. Most people will say that the Familia Duarte mausoleum is quite modest, but one time I was there, the birth of Evita was being celebrated and the wreaths were something to behold.To someone who is not used to it and where cremation and maybe a plaque is the order of the day, the amount of money lavished on the dead is staggering. It is also interesting to see the variety of tombs and the varying state of repair - from polished coffins and fresh flowers to broken dusty vaults with a few bones sticking out. There is also a bargain basement on the principle of a warehouse shelf with the several boxes built in. Some of the vaults are stunning and the Cemetery is testimony to the importance of family life in Argentina. Certainly a place not to be missed
Spooky but worth a visit. Free to enter and worth a slow walk around. Not the happiest of places.
Very interesting and free. Evita's tomb is located here, but also many other intricate and spacious mausoleums.
Most incredible cemetary ....... This cemetary was indeed a must see. It is virtually a museum of fine sculptures and artwork. Amazing and definitely a " to do " while in Buenos Aires.
Unusual. May seem odd looking around tombs when on holiday but it was quite fascinating and we found Eva Peron's tomb

Death and the City. This scenic cemetery is one more aspect of cultural Buenos Aires. It might seem odd to different cultures this fixation with death, but in reality is nothing more than social status positioning. How so? In a rich city, the place for eternal rest of a clan or family can also be seen as a sign of status. So tombs here are extremely valuable as real estate, but they are extremely artistry as well and worth a visit. If you don't like to be reminded of death, don't visit otherwise a couple of hours in Recoleta are a must see to understand a significant part of what is to be a citizen of Buenos Aires.

Very interesting, for a cemetery. Definitely worth a visit to see a unique "city of the dead." Not your typical cemetery, as it is arranged more like a city with "streets" and incredible architecture of the tombs. You can get a quick lesson in Argentine history in politics, especially if you speak/read Spanish.

Interesting..... It is a typical French cemetery, it reminded me of Pere Lachaise and the Montmartre cemeteries in Paris. You see the resting place of the Peron family which of course includes the body of Evita Peron Duarte. They have free tours in English and Spanish and talk about other famous Argentinians who are buried there. I would skip this visit if you have limited time in B.A.
Nice visit. Monumental cemetery, worth a quick visit, includes Evita's family pantheon .

If not for Eva. The cemetery visit is only for Evita (Eva Peron) .At the entrance is a large Map and signage for the various mausoleums.You can guess which has the most finger prints .The site its self is interesting as we know some of the history of the occupants but while there were plenty of crowds around Evas resting place the rest of the cemetery is of little interest topeople with no Spanish history knowledge .It is the resting place of business people ,generals and politicians .the highlight for us was the markets were in full swing and we spent a couple of hours (and some pesos )invetigating some really good local handmade items

make sure you have your camera battery charged. having spent a reasonable amount of time in Europe I find it difficult to get excited about yet another cemetary...... however this cemetary is worth a visit. Get a map at the entrance and get lost for hours.
interesting. it was weird that you could actually see the caskets in a lot of the mausoleums ..
An artistic Cementery. It was so wierd but amazing!! Evita´s tomb!The toms are a bit creappy because you can see yo the inside, but as arquitectonic place it´s just wow!!
Who'd ever think a cemetery could be so interesting. Do not miss this whatever you do. It is worth the trip just to see the artwork let alone the tombs and so much more.
Interesting. Very Interesting, I have never seen anything like it. Eve Peron is restign there.

landmark recoletta. A main attraction when in Argentina , here is where the famous leader Evita peron is buried, many tours given at no cost around cementary and at recoletta while their one must go to the church and shop along recoletta from the arts and craft market along the area. there is also an indoor mall at the end of this wonderful stretch. Many restaurant and hotels in the recoletta area.
Nice walk. Recoleta is a charming neighborhood. Cemetery is a must-see, but is not that amazing place. Nice restaurants nearby.

Should be listed as one of the world's man-made wonders!. It's truly hard to take in these incredible mauseleums...to think that these magnificent structures are the equivalent of one family tomb and yet many of them are mini-churches...architecture varied and amazing. This in my opinion is the most important sight in BA and cannot be missed. The fact that Evita Peron's tomb is here is a bonus to the history of the cemetry and adds to the intrigue and fascination of the entire place... A MUST VISIT!
A must in Bs. As.. Very old and well designed grave stones and constructions in a central and very fashinable district. A part of Argentine history that you should not miss.

The Dead Centre. After more than two hours and about forty photographs, I realised that I was spending an unhealthy amount of time in a cemetery! However, it is one of the most famous in the world, and to see the amounts of money that wealthy Argentinians bestowed upon their tombs is quite a privilege. Don't visit Buenos Aires without visiting Recoleta Cemetery. I had truly perfect weather, a clear blue sky, ideal for photographs.
nice to see. amazing how many graveswe were there on a half cloudy day and that is okeimpresive

Ok, if you liek cemeteries but did not like the sales of a map.... A gal hit us up just upon entering to purchase a map and we were only poping in to take a quick look since we were in the area. After we got by her there was a big permanent map right at the entrance so its not needed to buy a map. Most tourists come to see Eva Perons grave.

Not to be missed !. I think Buenos Aires is one of the few cities which a cemetery is a top tourist attraction. This cemetery is more like a museum. All the important characters of Argentinian History lay there. There is plenty of art in the mausoleums and please don't just go to Evita's tomb and then leave. The opulence of the cemetery art is breathtaking.

If you enjoyed Evita.. This is the place where Eva peron is buried alongside many other rich and famous Argentinians. I enjoyed the musicaland wanted to see the Evita's tomb. On exploring the graveyard it is easy to walk past the tomb as it is nothing spectacular compared to some of the tombs. in fact it is quite hard to locate without some guidance. We were given a number to find her grave but that didn't help as we could not work out any order in the way the tombs were laid out. In the end we found it by looking where the crowds were going!

Worth a look. A very unique cemetry, it has to be seen to be believed. Visit Eva Peron's resting place. Wander around on your own, you can also puchase a map. You don't need much time to visit this attraction but it's worth seeing.
Eeerie place, but a must. 6500 tombs in one place. Enormous amount of feral cats, some needing urgent attentionThe cemetery is not for lingering

A maze of little streets and mausoleums. Before you go in make sure you know your way around (either by getting a little map with the names of those who have a mausoleum there or paying for a guide). I think I would have got more from my visit if I knew what I was looking at (past presidents of the country, writers,..). Even Eva Peron (Duarte) was hard to find. Worth seeing -no entry fees- but after a while it gets a bit overwhelming. Nice views from the food court of the Recoleta shopping centre just accross the road.
Great tours. Worth going on the English speaking tours on Tuesday or Thursdays at 11.00. Fascinating

Must see. Wonderful to see the crypts and the sculptures around them. Everyone should go to Recoleta...pass by Evita's grave too, a little hard to find...ask crowds..just say "Evita", they will point if they don't speak English. I use to hate all the feral cats, but didn't see so many this time?

Unique and worth the time. While most visitors seemed to be there to see the tomb of Evita it is far more interesting. The Recoleta is the spot to see unique grave architecture and history. In about one hour you can see enough to understand Recoleto. Take the guided tour to get some interesting history.

A must!. it is very interesting. The entrance is free and the surroundings are pretty. Twice a week they have free tours but you can get a guide in any language. It is incredibly historical! Check the huge tree in the park besides the cemetery.
A real destination!. Great architecture and history. Get a map or hire a local guide to get the most out of the experience.
Perre Lachais, in Recoleta. Nothing to envy to the parisian cementery, this one in recoleta has the most famous and wealthy guys buried there, some are really great sculptures. Don't miss Evita!

Kill two birds with one stone - visit on a weekend!. Visit a cemetery during a vacation??? This is one of the world's most impressive and will give you a sense of the opulence and power of some of Buenos Aires' wealthiest families. (We were told these cemetery plots are more expensive than adjacent apartments!) After 30 minutes here you'll get the picture and can opt for a lovely outdoor lunch (what a view!) at one of the nearby restaurants. Best bet - the Recoleta Feria (weekend outdoor market) is large and has quality goods. Make an afternoon of it and do all three.Recoleta is an important barrio in Buenos Aires and a lovely area to visit. It is more upscale than some and should be comfortable for everyone.

Street Crime. The cemetery is one of the best in the world for monuments. It is unique in design and interesting. However, the surrounding street scene can be dangerous. My partner was a victim of a vicious strong armed robbery in broad daylight on a busy street. The english speaking police officer stated that during tourist season, there are 6 to 20 incidents. A man will come up behind the victim and steal a watch, purse, ring and then a speeding motorcycle comes and picks him up. My partner was badly injured while being thrown to the ground. Buenos Aires is becoming dangerous.

Weird but cool. Pretty weird to go to a cemetary while studying abroad...but everyone said you had to do it. The place was like a city, with these crazy huge monuments. Evita's grave was surprisingly conspicuous. Be sure to take a lot of pictures!

Interesting for Americans, maybe.. Let me explain my title. I never really wanted to go there in the first place but my partner wanted to so I had to give in. As I expected it is a cemetery just like other cemeteries found here in Brazil. Kind of small with very opulent tombs (amazing how far we go in our vain attempt not to be forgotten...) Anyway, I left to stroll around in the park nearby while my partner spent some more time trying to find Evita's tomb. He found it rather disappointing, btw.
Fascinating Glimpse into History. Take the guided tour of the cemetery. Remarkable story of Evita's body snatching (literally) and much more interesting information.

If you have a cemetery thing. This place is on the list of tourists spots as it reflects the old Argentina and the final resting place for Eva Peron,Interesting crypts and history,walking distance to the Hard Rock afterwards along with much of the tourist shopping in the area. Pay attention to your belongings at all times in this area.Not dangerous but be aware
So grand. This is definitively a place to visit on a stay in BA. The cemetery was beautiful. It was neat to see the Evita's resenting place as well.
Fascinating. Reminiscent of New Orleans' famous cemetery, this one is chock full of ornate mausoleums. Great for photography.
Interesting.. The neiborhood is beautiful. You don't need to enter in the cemetery, if you prefer.

lovely place. the cemetery is situated in a lovely part of b a and is a great place to wander around, particularly if you like cemeteries - which i do! there are informative maps for sale for 8 pesos and the volunteer who sells them will point you in the direction of any tombs/monuments which may be of interest to you, including evita. the tombs are spectacular and are kept in great condition and when you're finished there are some lovely cafes just across the green at the front of the cemetery!

Very impressive. Amazingly unique site to visit in Buenos Aires and recommend visiting on a sunny day and spending time here beyond just Eva Peron's site. Here's a hint, there's a board inside that lists all the sites and Evita is listed under Familia Duarte not Peron. Also, there is one Jewish mausoleum that belongs to La Familia Benjamin Breitman that now lies empty which is located right near Domingo Sarmiento. The Star of David (Magen David) has since been removed or fallen off and appears to be lying in the mausoleum itself. Interesting to see nonetheless.

The dead centre of Buenos Aires. Love it or loathe it, you can't help but be impressed by this necropolis. I'd never seen one quite like it, and am fairly sure that I don't want to again, but I'm glad I went.
Who would miss this one?. The most unusual cemetary I've ever seen. The grave sites are all enormous. Well-worth the visit.
Very unique and beautiful. Great with a guide so you can learn the ghost stories and history. Finding Eva Peron's gravesite is challenging unless you have a map or a guide. Architecture amazing!
VERY INTERESTING AND ENLIGHTENING. The difference between Recoleta and our local cemetaries. The eye opening mausoleums and the shock at the simplicity of Evita Perons final resting place.
Worth a visit. A sense of history - and an area of calm in the big city. Look for the Duarte family tomb for Evita.
beautiful. a place to relax in busy Buenos Aires. A must see and a nice connect between Palermo and Downtown
Awesome place to see.. A must when you are in BA and a very interesting walk from av de mayo. The church is amazing too. Very beautiful ans serene.

Not so beautifull.... It is not that great as the magazines tell us. Evita Peron's mausoleum is not even beatifull.
You won't loose to much if you don't there.
At least, it's free...
Very interesting....peaceful place. On a beautiful day, it is the perfect place to walk, to reflect and appreciate life.

Do Not MIss This!. We saw this on a tour that we booked and it was so wonderful! I defintely recommend seeing this with a guide if you like history. The cemetary is a sight to see in and of itself. However, aside form Evita, I did not know anyone else who was buried there. Most of the presidents, and well known general are there. Not to mention some "interesting" stories that accompany some of the tombs. If you are in Buenos Aires, please make sure to stop here and try to get as much information as possible beforehand or from a guide to add to the experience.
interesting. interesting to see how huge tombs there are. from the cemetery you can take a nice walk through one posh neighborhood Recoleta

A great place to walk. This was the top spot recommended to me before my trip and it didn't disappoint. Aside from Evita's tomb, there are some very pretty sculptures, stained glass, and architecture. A little creepy, but very interesting.

The elaborate mausaleums including Eva Peron's make this an easy and quick trip. Easy to access and you can see it at your pace. It is near other attractions, so combine a trip with them and at many lunch nearby restaurants.
More architecture than cemetery. Worth going to see the amazing sculptures and art nouveau designs.
Must See. Take a tour. They are free (tips hoped for) on Tuesday and Thursday at 11. There is a lot more here than Evita.
Worth a visit. What is there to say about a cemetery - it was worth the long walk we made there and had a lovely lunch afterwards in a restaurant across the road.
One of The most Beautiful in The World. It is a great experience, full of History and legends stories. You need a good guide to visit it.

A nice thing to do. If you're walking in that part of town it's worth a quick visit. Might as well go see Eva Peron's burial site. Watch out for a guy on the door posing as some charity dude. He first draws a map of where you'll find Eva Peron's spot and then turns the piece of paper around to show it's some leaflet about AIDS in Africa or some nonsense. Then of course he wants some cash. Annoying but he did draw us a useful map!

A MUST!. A must do in BA. Lots of history, its a cemetery but you can consider it a museum. There are a couple of free tours a day, tour guide is very knowledgeable, although they are conducted in Spanish. Please take advantage of this. It will take about an hour. Plus I recommend to go back and wonder a little more on your one. We had lunch in one of the restaurants across the plaza and had a 3 course meal special for a very reasonable price.

Compelling viewing. Almost a city in its own right.. Fascinating looking round this cemetery which surely is grander than any other in the world. The tombs are amazing, created on the back of the wealth in BA at the turn of the century. Full of amazing architecture and beautifully crafted statues. There is a free English tour (small tips expected at the end) at 11am on Tuesdays and Thursdays for about 40 minutes which tells the stories behind a few of the key tombs, but lots to look at regardless. Closes at about 6pm when we went (October). Free to visit.

Hauntingly Beautiful. If there is one place to see when visiting Buenos Aires it is the Recoleta Cemetary. The brick paths are like streets with crypts on either side. They are elaborate with glass doors where you can actually look into the crypt & see the coffins. It is a very quiet place even though it is in the middle of the city. Be sure to grab a map on your way in as this is the only way to find the tomb of Evita. There are guided tours but I preferred to wander on my own.
Amazing cemetary. No words to describe this place. Crypts that are works of art. Like a museum of architecture and culture, not creepy at all.

Interesting. If you're ever in Buenos Aires, this is one place you will want to visit. This also goes to those interested in history. This cemetery contains the tombs of some very important people in Argentina's history. This also includes the Duarte family (Evita) as well as other political figures
Tourist Attraction.. What a cemetery. Privately run with some works of art as mausoleums.
interesting, but kinda creepy. You can actually see the coffins through the windows of the mausoleums (some of the windows are broken). Worth a trip - shouldn't take more than 1 hour.
Look around the cemetery. The plaza in front of the cemetery is very nice. There is also the cafés around. The cafés in the Design Mall have also an interesting view.
Very special. Don't miss the opportunity of visiting this very special cemetery where Evita's grave exist.
Amazing. this is nothing like i expected! i definite site to see
Interesting but it is not a must.. The only reason to visit this place is because Evita is buried there as some historical figures in Argentina. I do not see anything else attractive.

Freaky cats and creepy mausoleums with pretty greenery.. I thought it macabe for a cemetery to be an "attraction" but it really is interesting. The first thing that greeted me as we turned right towards the Panteon was a cat coming at me from high atop a mausoleum. I didn't know about the cats there so it scared me and I screamed and scared it away. The cat was soo fluffy and had an enormous head. Then we started seeing more and more cats and they all looked a little weird. I haven't heard anyone mention this but my friend and I were a little freaked out by them.There were some beautiful tombs and some really decrepit ones. I was a little weirded out with being able to see through some of the glass entries and seeing the coffins inside. Also, there was this one decaying marble mausoleum with one of the doors completely gone and an exposed coffin at eye-level.

We cried for Evita. It was well worth an hour to walk around and see Argentine history in their cemetery. Lots of Presidents, Generals and Admirals buried there. You'll actually SEE their fancy caskets as that's how they do it there...
Must see!. wow, what a surprise this was. it is just as much an Art Museum, as a cemetery. Get a tourguide for this! A good one will tell you lots of great history behind the scenes.
Meh, it's not Arlington National Cemetery or anything. It's small and cramped and it's all walled off anyway. We just walked around it.

Very interesting, not so morbid as it sounds. Worth an hour or so to stroll around and then pop out to a street cafe nearby for some great Recoleta people watching. It was amazing to see the variety of architecture and tombs at the cemetary, as well as to observe the various states of care and disrepair.

Worth the visit. We were approached by a guide outside and were so thankful that we took up his services because we would have missed so much. The wealth and extent that some family’s went to for the dead was amazing. There were tombs for Doctors, writers and Army heros. One tomb copied the Notre Dame Cathedral. There was a sad story of a family who had a daughter who seemed to have died suddenly aged 19 years. The mother noticed the coffin had moved. It took 3 days to get permission to get the coffin opened. They found the girls face scratched. This was first known case of someone being put in a coffin alive.
take a map. unless you like walking around lost in a cementary, ask where the evita peron is or take a tour guide...

Strange and overrated. It is a strange place, enormous mausoleums crowded into streets like a weirdly overbuilt city. But, architecturally is is far less interesting than the City itself.Buenos Aires is a city of magnificent buildings, for anyone who enjoys historicist architecture, it's more fun to walk around the streets and see the splendor of the city's golden age classical, baroque, art nouveau and art deco palaces and palatial commercial and residential towers.

Wow, freaky place to visit! Cool "architecture". I know this is a cemetary so it seems kind of macabre to be "rating" it! But it is considered an attraction in Buenos Aires, and if you are in Recoleta, it is worth a visit! Its like going into a little city of beautiful tiny townhouses! Some of the "tombs" really are like tiny townhouses. Its quite freaky to be walking around and gazing into some of the mausoleums.There are some interesting people buried here, including the famous Eva Peron. A cool piece of history.

Best cemetary we've ever been to. The guides book says this place is a must to see in BA, mainly because it is the resting place of Eva Peron, but it is so much more. It has rows of ornately carved tombs - many with the coffins in full view, but it is not a sad or macabre place. The tombs of BA's wealthy families are arranged in neat rows. A lot of money has been spent on these family tombs - some are spectacular. We were not expecting the place to be so wonderful. An absolute gem of a site. Entrance is free, but you are asked for a small donation and you get a map of the site.

definitely a "to-do". When it comes to tourist site seeing in BA, la Recoleta is a must. Its location is easy to get to, inexpensive, and definitely one of the neatest cemeteries I have seen. On my visit we went in the late afternoon before close while the sun was beginning to set, providing wonderful light for a ton photography opportunities and very minimal crowds.

Time out .... On a sunny day Recoleta Cemetery is a place you can sit and contemplate, it is not at all grim. Purchase a map for a tiny fee inside the entrance if you are interested in which tombs belong to historical figures; the map has a route to follow which can be confusing to some so allow time to explore ... and take the time to visit the mausoleums around the edges. This cemetery is like a mini city, narrow streets draw you in to see who resides there. Guards are present in the cemetery and whether that was due to the 2 funerals in the afternoon I'm not sure but they will only approach those not showing proper respect or allowing privacy to grieving families.

Better than Arlington!. For all you Americans (and world-travelers) who have been to Arlington National Cemetery near DC, the Recoleta Cemetery beats that any day of the week! The intricacy in the graves is astounding, and aimlessly wandering through the narrow alleyways was truly a pleasure. We didn't even need a map to find Evita... Just go where the people are going! It was also fun to just "stumble upon" some of Argentina's most prominent figures' graves. Awesome place to go, and afterwards, if you're hungry from all the wandering, La Baita is a great cafe just across the park! Definitely recommend this as a must-see in BA!

Another definite for your visit to Buenos Aires. Probably not too much more I can add, which hasn't been already said. However, this certainly is a must see whilst In Bs As. The architecture and sculpturing is truly awesome and the whole place is beguiling. It's strange in the scorching sun, as it creates an atmosphere you may associate with darkness.Go and see the tomb of Eva Peron, but this is in no way the grandest. Marvel at some of the stones and try to imagine the wealth of the families who could afford them.

Don't miss visiting the Recolata Cemetary. The Recolata Cemetary was one of the most interesting parts of our recent visit to Buenos Aires. Be sure to take the guided tour...do your research ahead-of-time so you can be sure to get a tour in the language you speak. You may be asking, "What is so interesting about visiting a cemetary?" This cemetary is full of the most architecturally beautiful mausoleums you have ever seen. Many of them are pieces of art, worthy of being in any museum. As we learned on our tour, well-to-do Buenos Aires residents at the turn-of-the-last-century would build a beautiful home to live in first and a beautiful mausoleum "for their eternal life" second. You really do have to see it to believe it. If you visit on a Saturday or Sunday, one of the city's best arts/crafts fair is set up in the huge park in front of the cemetary. Entrance is free, which is amazing, considering the historical and artistic significance of the site.

A Unique, Interesting, Historical Site. The Recoleta Cemetery was one of the first places I visited when I arrived in Buenos Aires. It seemed interesting and unique as far as cemeteries go, but I had no Argentina knowledge or context to help me appreciate the spectacle. I was enjoying the architecture of the graves and the layout of the plaza, but I wasn’t really reading in depth some of the stones, nor walking into the “pasillos” which stem off from the main walkways. A few months later I went back to the site after having heard about it from various other people, and having learned about some of the people buried there (Eva Peron, for instance) and their significance. I enjoyed my second trip much more. Pay Attention to the Details!! The graves are spectacular and their layout is also impeccable. Make sure you go in between the graves when you can there is interesting history and sculptures in every nook and cranny. People are ACTUALLY buried there and some of them are people who have profoundly shaped Argentine history, politics, and culture. It is an amazing and recommended site.

Pay attention to details, and admire the beauty of this place!. The cemetery is, for lack of a better word, "halloweeny". Tombs are one next to each other, forming alleys. You can see coffins and relics through some doors, and there were some cats around. Once I passed this feeling, however, I realized the cemetery says more about life. It tells of about the families that lived during that golden Argentinian era. Some mausoleums were impressive! Pay attention to details. You can tell there was a lot of work and effort put towards the final product. Besides, you can also visit Evita's last resting place. Do not miss it if you are visiting Buenos Aires!Note: We did not take a tour, but I know there were some available.

Tuesdays and Thursdays 11h00 free English tour. You can give a donation to friends of the Cemetery. The English speaking Guide we had told lovely and sad stories about some of the gaves. Anybody can buy a grave there... at a price!

Not really impressed with it, but good if you are looking to kill an hour or so. I ended up being stuck in Buenos Aires for an extra day because the ferries to Uruguay were all full, so I decided to wander around and walk the city. I decided to check out the cemetery because of Eva Peron's grave. After wandering around the place for about 30 minutes without a map, I found her grave. There are some impressive tombs, but many of them show neglect and unfortunately, vandalism and disregard for those buried there. I took some pictures, found many of the infamous Recoleta cats, then left. It is okay to visit and kill an hour or so (admission is free), but otherwise not really much to see.

Sounds strange but do it!. It sounds strange to visit a cemetery while in vacation, but this one is excellent! It really gives insight into the culture of Buenos Aires and the history of those who founded the city. What´s more, the architecture, etc. is impressive!
Quite a place. What a place to visit?! Really was quite an experience and I would recommend it to anyone in the city for a few days.Be sure to search for Eva Peron's grave in the Duarte family tomb

A Time to Reflect. As I wandered around this graveyard with its elaborate tombs of people who were once VIPs but are now mostly all but forgotten---with 2 or 3 exceptions for now, it makes one think. Unfortunately, when I think about these things, I rarely come up with actual answers, so it can be a bit depressing. Many of the tombs are beautiful, but rather than coming away with an idea to emulate them, I concluded that it was all fairly useless, and that I might as well leave my assets when I die to my kids, than blow them on a monument. (If my kids had any inkling that this was my conclusion, they'd pack me off weekly to other cemetaries, so don't tell them!) I suppose there are a couple other reactions you might have. Some will blow through, just check out Evita's tomb and move on. Cool enough if it fits. Others will look at the beauty of the tombs, take 2 or 3 hours, and think of legacy, essentially those with much more faith than me. If it helps you connect with god, I'm envious, as it only helped me connect with dust-to-dust. I thought this was worth doing, but I wouldn't want to do it too often.

Macabre. I wasn't expecting open tombs with clear views of dusty coffins and other relics, it was a bit spooky since I am used to the grassy gravestones kind of cemetery. Unless you have an extensive interest in the graves of famous Argentinians or grave art you probably just want to have a quick look around and see the grave of Evita Peron, which is marked on the map at the entrance so don't bother buying a map from the vendors outside. Half an hour is definitely enough to wander a few of the paths to see the variety of mausoleums of varying opulence.
take the guide. Interesting but defenitely a guide is needed otherwise you'll just see some nice old tombs, also lovely cats :)

Fascinating and Insightful. The Cemetario is a fabulous experience for anybody who loves to wonder "why". It's full of mysteries and is a wild departure from the orderly and simple cemeteries of the USA. Great for history buffs, anthropology dorks, photographers or anyone with a penchant for the spooky. Not for anyone who is allergic to cats, as there is a massive population of very friendly resident cats in the cemetery. If you're the sort who likes to sight-see from a motor-coach, skip this one. But if you like to let your imagination run wild with the mysteries of people who came before you, Recoleta is a magical place.

very interesting and beautiful. You can spend a ton or very little time in the cemetary. There is a lot to see and wandering around was fun. The archetecture is so interesting. Of course, pay homage to Eva Peron.

Half an hour is sufficient to explore.... you can probably edge near an english-speaking tour group, Day of visit also enjoyed the cultural center nearby, my one church peek and the arts and crafts fair with some rather good musicians playing at various spots. I was told the Design museum nearby has a great lunch, but, I had other plans.

good to visit but more people than tombs. A very interesting way to spend an hour walking amongst the tombs and family burial sights. Like an open air museum / gallery. However I visited in the middle of the day and there were lots of other tourists wandering around which spoilt the ambiance a little. I would recommend to visit earlier in the day before the tour buses arrive.

A Must See!!. If you go to Buenos Aires, you MUST go visit the Recoleta Cemetery!!!!!! This is an AMAZING place and it will blow your mind. Keep in mind that English speaking tours are on Tuesday and Thursdays at 11am or you can find an English speaking tour given by someone else and follow closely behind the rest of the tour. Afterwards, take time to wonder around Recoleta if you are not staying in this area.

Can I be buried here?!. The tombs in this beautiful and tranquil city of the dead are fascinating, as are the inscriptions detailing the lives of the residents buried there. Evita's tomb is interesting, but I found others even more intriguiging. It would be easy to spend hours here exploring, for the architecture of the tombs is gorgeous and varied; each tomb is personal and unique, and the local cats welcoming. My favorite thing was peering inside tombs with glassed doors in search of hidden treasures not readily visible, such as luminous stained glass pictures, or marble statues of the dead in repose. One, a mother holding a small child, was haunting. Some of the interiors had stairwells curving into the earth below. Steps to eternity.

Most grandious cemetery & favorite thing in buenos aires. This is a free, for all ages place to go. I could have spent the day there literally. It was beautiful!! There are hundreds of mausoleums. There is nothing like it in the world that I have seen! Beautiful sculptures and old old mausoleums with ornate styles and just truly a sight. Photographers dream come true! It's hard to even call it a "cemetery" as it is so different than anything I have ever seen with a cemetery.

Worth while on your to do list.. Very interesting site. Highly recommend! It's quite intruiging. Great for photographers. Beautiful structures and lots of sculptures. Should be on your to do list when in BA!

Unmissable. One of the unmissable visit in Bs As is the Cementerio de la Recoleta . This place where rests a large part of Argentine history, you can enjoy luxurious mausoleums in various architectural styles - it is considered a National Historic Landmark.Since there isn't a subway station nearby, the options to get there are a taxi or walking.When you arrive the area, do not go straight to the Cemetery, stop for a 'expreso' at La Biela (at this café notable) and, also, visit the church - Iglesia Nuestra Señora del Pilar. The Cemetery of Recoleta was opened in 1822 and houses the most important protagonists of Argentine history - presidents, politicians, soldiers, statesmen, writers, poets, there are 4,800 tombs distributed in a area of 54 000 m².But undoubtedly the most famous tomb is of Eva Peron. Evita, who died in 1952 and had her body stolen and hidden in a graveyard in Milan in 1971. It had her body moved to Spain and only in 1974, it was brought back to Argentina.But do not forget to visit the Familia Paz mausoleum - the founder of the newspaper La Prensa. It is a black granite mausoleum with white marble sculptures of angels, Those sculptures were made in Paris. It also has many symbols of Freemasonry - is considered by many the most beautiful.And for those who like urban legends, an account that young Rufina Cambaceres was buried after a supposed sudden death. It is said that after a few days after her death, the employee who took care of the mausoleum of Cambaceres noticed that the lid of the tomb Rufina was broken and the coffin was moved, when he opened it he found her all scratched in an attempt to escape. In fact, she had suffered an attack of catalepsy, and therefore having died asphyxiated. Her mother built a mausoleum in Art Nouveau, with a tomb of Carrara marble, it has a rose engraved and sits behind a glass wall - as if her mother wanted to see her if she would return again. Other residents are also found in this cemetery. About 84 cats live there and are maintained by a group of volunteers women .The entrance to the cemetery is free. It is open every day from 7 am to 18 pm. A kiosk at the entrance you can buy a map for 8 pesos, but it isn't worth buying as the most famous tombs are easy to find - and it is more interesting to walk aimlessly through them.Amen!

Not sure what we expected.... Cemeterio Recoleta was definitely a must see for us, principally because Evita is entombed there. We were shocked at the condition of many of the tombs- broken doors, coffins exposed to the elements and generally dilapidated conditions.We were surprised to learn that many vacant tombs were of families who had removed their loved ones remains after Eva Peron was placed there.It is an interesting place and you can learn a lot about the history of Buenos Aires there. Never seen so many cats in one place before...

Pretty interesting way to spend an hour. Free entrance but people collecting money for charities at the door. The main entrance looked like it was undergoing a refurbishment so entered via a small doorway. You should walk to the main entrance once inside to see the map of where the 'important' people are buried, such as Evita. Definitely worth a look but wouldn't plan on spending all day there.

This place defies words. I was speechless after visiting this place and still can't words to describe it. The only thing to do is go visit it and see for yourself. Eva Peron's grave is quite modest compared to some!

Recoleta Cemetery: A True Art Gallery. A visit you cannot miss during your stay in Buenos Aires is Recoleta Cemetery, which is both an outstanding cemetery and a highly valuable architectonic piece located at Recoleta, Buenos Aires.Recoleta Cemetery was born together with the Our Lady of Pilar Church, whose history is also linked to the Recoletos Franciscan OrderAfter being the first public cemetery in Buenos Aires, during Torcuato de Alvear administration, the cemetery was remodeled and the current entrance gate was built.Recoleta Cemetery is a true outdoors art gallery, a unique exhibition of different architectonic styles and sculptures. Along the tour around Recoleta Cemetery, you will find the graves of several national heroes, Argentine presidents, renowned artists, great scientists and brave soldiers, such as Eva Perón, Adolfo Bioy Casares, Facundo Quiroga, Domingo F. Sarmiento, Juan M. de Rosas, Remedios Escalada de San Martín, Mariquita Sánchez de Thompson, among others.

Totally Unique Experience - Fascinating. I didn't really have any expectations in coming to the Recoleta Cemetery, but it was absolutely one of the most interesting places I have been. It's free, so that is great. But the sheer expansiveness of the place is impressive. I intended on spending 15, maybe 30 minutes walking through the cemetery. But after winding through alley after alley of elegant tombs, I left the cemetery. 2 hours later. There are very modern tombs, but there are increidibly old and beautiful tombs as well. The juxtoposition of the two makes for a great experience. It's a little off-putting to consider that you are photographing tombs and meandering through the final resting place of BA's elite. But once you acknowledge that, and move on, it's a cool experience. The main attraction is Eva Peron's tomb (Familia Duarte). You won't miss it, just follow the droves of people and stop when you get to the tomb with constantly fresh flowers.In summary, this is a beautiful cemetery and is worth 15 minutes or 2 hours of your time. Either way, you should take some time to wander around.

This was one of the most beautiful cemeteries I've seen.. This was one of the most beautiful cemeteries I've seen around the world. There were different designs of marble or stone mausoleums and tombs. The spaces, doors, and coffins were designed beautifully. A lot of the designs were so elaborate, it was lovely to take my time looking at the architecture. I hired a guide as I wanted the more in-depth explanations behind the tombs, it wasn't overly expensive and was worth it to hear the stories!

Go on a beautiful day and take a good camera!. This is a "must do" when visiting BA. If you have the flexibility, wait for a beautiful day and go either early or late in the day when the sun is low and casts beautiful shadows. The maze of tombs and statues, in all different styles of architecture, is truly a photographers dream. This is not to be missed. (But, walk past the "unofficial" tour guides at the entrance and take your own tour---you'll thank me as it is wonderful to simply wander.)

Bizarre, macabre, curious... PRICELESS.. This place is hard to describe or believe. I visited on a Saturday two days before the anniversary of Evita's death. I would highly suggest either a private guide (like Buenos Aires Historico) or one of the public tours (Tues. or Thurs. at 11AM) as there are so many layers to this "attraction" that are impossible to appreciate as a solo-traveler.Recoleta Cemetery, as many who are reading this are aware, is the final resting place of many of Argentina's most famous citizens including the Paz family, President Alfonsin, and of course Eva Peron. It is also a showcase for what is best described as a mild case of cultural necrophilia (according to my guide). Many who come just see Evita's tomb, walk around for a few minutes, and leave. This is a shame as there are stories behind almost every tomb or gravesite that have to be heard to be believed. There are also a group of indigenous cats who are constantly slinking around, giving the place an even more eerie atmosphere.Absolutely essential and a must visit for anyone visiting the city.

Unlike anything I've ever seen before. This is hard to explain until you see it. It is a city of shrines for the departed. The tomb of Evita and other notable Argentines is definitely a must on a trip to BA

Very cool... add it to your list.... There is no entry fee -- definitely worth a visit. Most folks will flock to Eva Peron's resting place, but do visit other areas within the cemetery, as they are equally as intriguing. I lost count of how many mausoleums there are, but probably well over a couple hundred. The cemetery is located in the northern heart of Recoleta, an upscale neighborhood in Buenos Aires.

When in BA, please do NOT skip this. What a magnificent site. We wanted to go there a second time but didn't have the time anymore. The place is in the center of the city so it can easily be accessed by public transportation or by walking. It's located near a park and several avenues with amazing cafes and restaurants. The cementary just demonstrates the luxury & grandeur of the citizens of Buenos Aires. What a fantastic site to an unbeliavably vibrant city! Don't miss Evita's tomb :)

Free guided tours in English. Recoleta Cemetery is well worth a visit. However to get the best out of it, I recommend one of the free guided tours in English that take place at 11am from the main entrance on Tuesday's and Thursdays. You get to hear about the history of the cemetery and stories about some of its incumbents. The tour lasts just short of 2 hours.

AMAZING -- do not miss this if you're in Buenos Aires.. Sure, I'd read about the Recoleta Cemetery before my trip to Buenos Aires ... but nothing prepared me for the enormity and intricacy of this historic place. While it was sort of interesting seeing the tomb of Eva Peron (the biggest "draw" there), the real fun came from wandering the "streets" and admiring the architecture and artwork of the thousands of tombs. This place is a photographer's dream.
Beautiful -- must see.. Walk around for an hour, then have lunch at Locos por Futbol across the street -- good lunch, cute patio, futbol on TV and a view of the cemetary.

an excellent place to spend an afternoon. We spent a few hours here. We bought a map and of course went to see Evita's mausoleum, but we did not know many of the other Argentinean poets/politicians/etc. buried here so we just wandered around, taking pictures of interesting monuments/mausoleums, and playing with several of the cats that live here. If you are a cat lover, like I am, this is a must stop for you. The cats are being cared for by an old lady that lives nearby and her staff (she's now too old to do the rounds herself). I petted several of them. Some are cautious, while others are super friendly. Definitely visit and give them some love.There is no entry fee. Bathrooms are very basic.

Visit as part of a walking tour. The Recoleta Cemetery is an amazing place but to really get the most out of it I would strongly recomend doing it as part of a walking tour. We were staying near there and so wandered in on our first evening. It is amazing but with little information on site and the maps really only say who's buried where, it left us a bit cold. We went back on the afternoon walking tour run by BA Walking Tours (www.ba-walking-tours.com) and it was a completely different experience. We were told the sad, gruesome and occasionally funny stories behind the graves. Our guide was fantastic as was the rest of the afternoon tour which runs for a bit over two hours, of which the first hour is in the Cemetery. Our guide gave us a great insights into Argentina, that we'd really not understood till that point in time. We did this on our last afternoon and if we'd been staying longer we would definitely have done their morning walking tour as well.

A Highlight. A great sight, interesting to wonder and wander ....Across the street is a fine cafe under the shade of a 200 yr old tree (Bielo) or go across the street to Aromas and get the same view without the atmosphere and prices... Don't miss the Buenos Aires Design Center next to the cemetary -- great shopping especially for household design items -- cafe has free Tango on Wednesdays.

Wander the cemetery, then visit a great cafe. We started our 4-day visit in B.A. with an orientation bus tour around the city. It was Saturday morning, and very hot, and when we got to the cemetery, we could see it was very crowded (people who went in said it was so jammed it was hard to walk down many of the "streets.") So we stayed at the bus. (Weekends, we were told, tend to be extremely crowded, especially in the summer.) We took a taxi back to the cemetery on Monday morning. It was delightful to walk through (no crowds at all) and to sit on a bench and observe the visitors. When we left, we went straight out across the little plaza in front, and to the cafe - La Biela - that is under the huge gum tree - for a shaded, excellent lunch. The inside dining room is fine too, but if it's good weather, having breakfast, coffee, or lunch on the outdoor terrace is a treat.

Beautiful cemetery!. Recoleta is obviously one of the "tourist attractions" in Buenos Aires, but for good reason - the tombs there are absolutely amazing! Some date back hundreds of years and they are beautiful and extremely ornate - there's one we saw with a mosaic inside the dome; many have stained-glass windows; and they can be as much as 40 or so feet tall! Each tomb is different and you could easily spend all day wandering around here admiring the details and art, because they really are works of art. Admission to the cemetery is free, and there will be people selling maps outside the entrance for around 6 Argentine pesos. With that, it is easy to find the tomb of Eva Peron, who is the cemetery's most famous resident. There are also many Argentine leaders in the cemetery, and the map includes several tombs that might be of interest to individuals with more than a cursory knowledge of Argentina's history. And the cemetery was large enough that it didn't seem crowded when we were there (except for around Eva's grave), even though there were a decent number of people there. Definitely go to Cementerio de la Recoleta when in Buenos Aires!

Amazing cemetery. You cannot bypass Recoleta Cemetery in BA. It is located in the Recoleta district, which is a hill.It is the most fascinating place to spend time in this city. All the tombs are pieces of art.The sculptures on the crypts are so beautiful that you wish to be buried right then and there. There are tombs for very famous Argentinians, like Duarte family-Eva Peron, etc. You have to be really wealthy to afford such a grave. Please don't skip any of them, take your time to see the personal belongings, pictures inside the crypts.You may find most of them have open doors.it is for the family members to come in and pray. Some of them are really dilapidated, which means there are no family members left to take care of them and some of them are in immaculate condition as if the deceased was placed there yesterday. You can check the board at the entrance to find English speaking tours. The best bet is to sign on with the free walking tours of Buenos Aires and visit the entire area with a guide.
How can you not give this 5 stars?. I love getting lost in the rows upon rows of ornate tombs and gravestones.

Creepy. Fascinating but very creepy. So I gave it "above average" just for how interesting of a tourist spot this is. I give it a "terrible" however for the spirits-floating-around-you factor. Both my wife and I were freaked out by this place. At first we were all interested in the different crypts but as we got deeper in among them we were freaked out. You can look in them and see coffins. Many of the crypts were in poor repair. We got out of there after only about an hour. I wouldn't bring kids in here or come here for more than a pass through. EEEK!

MUST SEE while in BA. My husband and I liked BA and found it to be a very livable city that feels more European than Latin American. There was a lot about the sightseeing that reminded us of places we'd been in Europe. One absolutely distinctive thing, though was Recoleta. It feels a bit weird to be recommending a cemetery as a must-see, but after wandering the countless alleys - we left saying this was undoubtedly a unique view into the history of BA. As you wonder at the grandioseness of most and the simplicity of some, the meticulous upkeep we saw next to the sheer decay of others, poets next to politicians next to business people. It's a historical mélange that plays itself out very well for a half-day visit. Grab some empanadas and tamales afterwards at El Sanjuanino on Calle Posados

Cat Tombkeepers. Well worth the visit - the recoleta area is also good to tour around in. - Don't just visit the Eva Peron gravesite, as the rest of the cemetery is as interesting in its different periods, as it is for its different state of repair for certain graves, and cat tombkeepers.

Loved my visit to the cemetery. While I typically wouldnt visit a cemetery as a tourist, I am fascinated by this one. It is much like a little city and the architecture is unique for each tomb. It is truly a place to go when in BA because of its rich history and interesting design. Our group (9 people) all were happy to have gone and seen this place. I didnt feel creeped out or wierd about being there. Just respectful of those buried and interested in the history. Having a tour guide helped.

creepy and fasinating at the same time!. There were no free maps going but some lady was selling maps of the cemetery for 4 pesos. I just followed the crowd to Evita's grave which was straight into the middle of the place then turn left about 3/4 into the cemetery. It is in the family name of Duarte and can survive a nuclear bomb with trap doors so no one can steal her body (again). The whole place is all crypts and no headstones, so it very different than what you are used to seeing in America. You can peep in the crypts and actually see caskets, which freaked me out a bit. It is a great place to wander around and take pictures. The place is open 10am- 5:50pm. Don't miss it when you are in Buenos Aires.

Great Tour. The entrance and tours of the Cementerio de la Recoleta are free, and they are very informative and interesting. The site is beautiful (as odd as that may sound), and it is full of history...The tour guides are very knowlegeable and willing to answer questions...Eva Peron's body is here, although totally hidden...There are other beautiful monumets to see as well...Very nice...

Recoleta and Recoleta Cemetery Tours. I have been in Buenos Aires for over a month now. I am here writing a book and am doing research about the Cemetery in Recoleta. In order to help me find out as much information, I have taken 6 different tours of the Cemetery. Each one has offered me a new piece of information. There are so many interesting stories in the cemetery. The woman that was buried alive is the crowd pleaser. And all the political legends and finsters buried side by side. There is no cemetery like in the world. On my first visit, I was simply amazed at the architecture and visual treat that it was and had a hard time remembering the stories behind the tombs. There are free tours of the cemetery offered twice a week. I took both of them, each from a different tour guide. The first one was very entertining however I almost felt embarassed for the young women who clearly has a future in drama. The second one was very dead pan (no pun intended) but some good info. I hired a private tour guide for 25$USD, and found that tour to be overpriced but still, I learned about about the architecture of the cemetery. One of the last tours I took was for 30 pesos (10USD). It included both Recoleta and the Cemetery. I really learned the most here and was able to ask questions and explore and enjoy myself. It was a private tour. Just me and the guide. Very fun and entertinaing and great ideas for my book. The cats of the cemetery included. Found it here - Tango-History-ToursThere are many good tours of the Cemetery. If you search around a little you can find a real bargin. But no matter what you do, you should take a tour. Because there is simply so many treasures buried there, that you will never discover unless you spend days and days of researching.

I would recommend you take a tour of the Cemetery!. I was in Buenos Aires for a week around a month ago during my travels around South America. One day I decided to go and check out the Recoleta Cemetery to see what all the fuss was about.It was beautiful certainly, but I was a little bored because I had no idea who any of the people were with their names on the tombs, apart from Evita, but then I didn´t really know much about her apart from the fact that Madonna played her in a movie. So I got a little bored very quickly, and after a while started to walk out. On the way out I noticed a board saying there were free cemetery tours, and luckily one of them was due to start in half an hour. I waited around, and some other tourists gathered, but half an hour after the tour was due to start, still no sign of a tour guide. We were all a little annoyed at that point, so asked around to see if anyone knew what had happened, but no one knew anything. So I left the cemetery at that.HOWEVER, that night I got talking to a guy in the Kilkenny pub who happened to be a tour guide for an English Walking Tours company. I didn't know this at first, and started to tell him about my cemetery experience and how I thought it was a little boring. He told me about his job and persuaded me to come on the tour the next day, claiming he would bring the cemetery to life with interesting stories of the famous people buried there, plus also the tour would include a section on the rest of Recoleta, the most stylish area of Buenos Aires apparently.So I took his tour the next day at 11am, and it was fantastic. Just 20 pesos, he even turned up on time where he was supposed to unlike the free tour theday before! They were daily scheduled tours so there were 4 other people on it, but that was fine as they all seemed nice and the tour guide, Thom, made sure we all felt included. He showed us some great places to shop, eat and go out at night in Recoleta along the way to the cemetery, which although I couldn´t afford, all looked very nice, and I will definitely return one day when I am rich and famous!The famous people in the cemetery had some really interesting stories about them too, and the tour guide really did bring them to life with some funny jokes too. So I recommend that to get the most out of Recoleta and the Cemetery that you take an organised walking tour from that company, whose web address is Buenostours.That way, I hope you enjoy the cemetery and recoleta as much as I did, eventually!

We Took a Self-Guided Tour of the Cemetery. My husband and I went to the Cementerio de la Recoleta last month. We decided to go to Recoleta on our own and stroll around the cemetery. Outside the front entrance a young woman handed us a very nice and free map of the cemetery. A young man who was with her handed us a tract about Aids and explained that he has Aids and would we like to donate to help Aids patients. My husband handed him a few pesos. We then proceeded to use the map to navigate our way around to some of the main mausoleums. Once we entered the cemetery there were several people who offered to be guides but we turned them down. They were not pushy at all.We enjoyed wandering around the tombs. It was interesting to see how people had competed to see who could have the most impressive memorial. It was also surprising to see that others are neglected and even have trash thrown in them. The photos I am posting with this review are located in the center of the spoke where number 44 is. It is a shady spot where we were able to rest for a few minutes on a bench.I would recommend going to the cemetery. It is possible to go for a casual tour such as we did or get a more in depth tour once you get there. These options are available for those who want to be flexible in their plans.

Take the tour - then see it from on high. I just took a tour of the cemetary the other day, with a guide from Cemetary. (The prior day a city tour had walked us to Evita´s grave.) The cemetary is a very beatiful collection of monuments, statutes and history. I highly recommend that folks who want to see and hear a little more than Evita´s burial try to get the english tour. I think they only give it one or two days a week, presently one of those days is Thursday at 11 (or 11:30). Your hotel can call to confirm. The volunteer guide (Florence) had was very enthusiastic and entertaining.2nd tip that may appear elsewhere - across from Cemetary, along the sidewalk cafes, there is Etoile Hotel. They have a little bar with sun terrace on 14th floor, and you can ride up and get a drink and look out over an amazing view. I also highly recommend that.

A little overrated - what is there to do in a cemetary?!. I went to the cemetary in Recoleta - though looking back on it - I don't know why. Dead people have never been an interest of mine. It is absolutely massive, and the tombs are very ornate but thats as far as it goes. Everyone heads to Evita's tomb (which is nothing to write home about), then just wander round aimlessly. I mean really, unless you're Argentinian, and you know who some of the residents are, what can these tombs mean to you?! Luckily though, its free. No harm done.

Beautiful Recoleta. In photographs, the cemetery looks like a small city. In reality, it is a city of the dead. Each tomb is different from the next. My first visit was on a sunny day (shortly after Christmas 2005) and many tourists were walking around looking for Evita's tomb. Evita's family tomb is beautiful but not outstanding or memorable. I visited again a couple days later by myself on a rainy day. It was quiet and almost ghostly. No other tourists were around. Many tombs have glass doors so you can see inside. The coffins are on shelves and sometimes decorated with religious items. Some tombs have stained glass, many had elaborate and amazing statues. In one area I saw a lot of stray cats sitting in the doorways to avoid the rain. I have to admit that I creeped myself out when walking in narrow paths with tombs surrounding me. It really was an incredible experience.   My mother and I stayed at the Alvear Palace a few blocks from the cemetery. Alvear is the most elegant and sophisticated hotel I have ever stayed in. It is quite expensive, but I recommend it to anyone who wants to vacation in luxury. Although I was in Buenos Aires for almost a week, I felt like I didn't see anything because the city is so impressive. I highly recommend staying in the Recoleta neighborhood.
